HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Hall for Midsize Exhibits Is Planned for Pier 94

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
A new exhibition hall called the Unconvention Center, one mile north of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and about one-third its size, is being planned for Pier 94 by the Giuliani administration and private developers.
At a cost of $50 million, the 750-foot-long pier shed would be renovated and the one-story head house, which runs from 52nd Street to 54th Street, would be replaced by a structure of two or three stories. Once laden with Cunard Line cargo, Pier 94 was more recently used as a parking garage. 
 The Unconvention Center would be T-shaped, its long stem over the Hudson River, with three exhibition areas on the main floor for midsize trade shows, which typically draw 5,000 to 10,000 visitors. In the head house, at the top of the T, would be a ballroom and meeting rooms for corporate events, as well as a cafe.
"These trade shows are a big job generator," said Michael G. Carey, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, which is negotiating the deal with the development team, Unconvention Center Inc., headed by Elyse N. Kroll, a trade show producer.
Mr. Carey said the Unconvention Center and the Javits Center would be "complementary, because they go to different constituents."
Gerald T. McQueen, the president and chief executive of the Javits Center, said, "New York needs all the trade show space it can find, so we are not opposed to efforts to increase exhibit area.
"The Javits Center's success is a prime example of the tremendous need for its own expansion," Mr. McQueen said. "Currently we are turning away almost as much business as we're able to accommodate."
Neighbors have some concerns, said John Doswell, co-chairman of the waterfront committee of Community Board 4 in Clinton. They will be looking closely at how much of Pier 94 would be open to the public, how the center would relate to the future Clinton Cove Park nearby and how traffic generated by trade shows -- trucks, vans, taxis, limousines, buses -- would affect the overall Hudson River Park.
Issues of traffic and park design will be resolved in the course of hearings and review leading to a vote in the City Council, said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission and a board member of the Hudson River Park Trust.
"One of the goals of the park is to bring people to the waterfront, to make the Hudson River an integral part of the life of the city," Mr. Rose said. "This project will do that in a felicitous way."
The development group at Pier 94 is led by Ms. Kroll, president of both the Unconvention Center Inc. and of E.N.K. International, a producer of trade shows for the fashion industry.
As business travel and tourism increased in recent years, Ms. Kroll said, hotels were less eager to set aside entire floors for exhibitors. "There was no place to grow," she said. "That's why we needed to create new space."
Her search took her to Pier 94, which New York City opened in 1964 as a freight terminal for Cunard.
Inside is an astonishing and almost column-free expanse of 175,000 square feet -- four whole acres.
Ms. Kroll can still recall her reaction when she was shown the space two years ago by Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine: "Oh, my God."
E.N.K. has leased Pier 94 from the city since summer 1998, using it for its own shows or subleasing it. More than 15 exhibitions have been held there, including the New York International Gift Fair.
As a tenant, Ms. Kroll said, E.N.K. has spent more than $3 million to comply with building codes and improve aesthetics. It insulated the pier shed by covering the roll-down gates that line both sides, installed duct work for air conditioning and heating, built bathrooms and waterproofed the roof.
"They have had a good run on Pier 94 on an interim basis," Mr. Carey said, "and we have every confidence that they'll have great success on a more permanent basis."
Unconvention Center Inc. would lease Pier 94 for 49 years. The city expects to receive rent, to share in the revenue and to receive money from the developers toward the long-term maintenance of the pier. The exact terms are still being negotiated, both sides said.
Construction is to begin early in 2001 and take about a year, said Paul Travis, a managing partner in Washington Square Partners, the real estate advisers to the Unconvention Center. He said the project would be financed by $40 million in borrowing and $10 million in equity.
Construction would add about 100,000 square feet of floor space to the pier, bringing it to 270,000 square feet, but that is still well below the maximum allowed by zoning rules, Mr. Travis said.
The center is being designed by the Atlanta firm Thompson, Ventulett, Stainback & Associates, whose other projects have included the Pennsylvania Convention Center in Philadelphia, incorporating the historic Reading Terminal train shed.
A preliminary sketch shows a bowed roof on the new head house, an esplanade, arched fanlight windows and twin towers at the end of the pier. "The intent is to animate the building in a way that's more festive and inviting," said H. Preston Crum, a senior principal in the architectural firm.

HEADLINE: Clinton Aides Push Budget to Congress

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
Clinton administration officials fanned out across Capitol Hill today to sell the merits of the president's budget plan, but found no takers among the Republican majority in Congress.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers told the Senate Finance Committee that President Clinton's plan to eliminate the part of the national debt held by the public would be like a tax cut for most people because it would push interest rates lower. 
 Jack Lew, the director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, said Congress should adopt a restrained estimate of future budget surpluses, as Mr. Clinton has. To construct a surplus estimate just to allow for the bigger tax cut that Republicans want, he told the House Budget Committee, would risk a return to deficits and imperil efforts to assure Social Security's solvency.
Other administration officials, including Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, also appeared before Congressional committees.
But Republicans said Mr. Clinton's budget called for too much spending and too little in tax cuts and missed an opportunity to use the surplus to overhaul Social Security.
And they said they planned to press ahead with a tax and spending plan of their own, starting with a vote in the House on Thursday on a tax cut for married couples.

HEADLINE: Aetna Reports 20% Increase in Income

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Aetna Inc., the nation's biggest health insurer, said yesterday that its operating income rose 20 percent in the fourth quarter. But Wall Street analysts said the underlying numbers were disappointing, reflecting deterioration in Aetna's core health business and losses overseas.
The Cigna Corporation, the No. 3 managed health care insurer, said operating income rose 31 percent to $296 million, or $1.66 a share, in the quarter, far exceeding the $1.38 expected by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. 
 On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Aetna shares plummeted $9.75, or 17 percent, to $46. Most managed care stocks also dropped. Cigna shares declined $1.50, to $74.75.
Richard L. Huber, chairman and chief executive of Aetna, stressed the positive: a greater-than-anticipated 3.1 percent increase, to 15.9 million members, of the Aetna U.S. Healthcare health maintenance organizations, not counting 5.1 million customers of the recently acquired Prudential Healthcare unit.
He said the Prudential unit "met our expectations." Projected annual losses at Prudential declined $50 million in the quarter, to $150 million, the company said. Aetna said the Prudential loss would fall $100 million further late this year and disappear in early 2001.
But most analysts were concerned about medical costs, led by prescription drugs and hospital stays, which appeared to be overrunning rate increases. They saw the cost increases as a warning of continuing uncertainty about Aetna's ability to turn Prudential around. Losses at Prudential have been softened by fees and other payments to Aetna that end Jan. 1, 2001.
"The fear on Wall Street is that Prudential will hurt them in 10 months" when those payments end, said Todd Richter, a health care analyst at Banc of America Securities.
Aetna said rising medical costs absorbed 83.1 percent of revenue at the Aetna U.S. Healthcare H.M.O.'s in the quarter, up from 82.6 percent in the period a year earlier. When Prudential H.M.O.'s were added, the combined cost ratio rose to 84.8 percent.
Costs at Medicare H.M.O.'s rose even faster, to 95.3 percent compared with 92.6 in the 1998 quarter.
The increases included "higher-than-anticipated medical costs" in the preceding quarter, which emerged in the final quarter, Aetna said.
Lori M. Price, an analyst at CIBC World Markets, said Aetna had been "underestimating its medical costs for the past few quarters." She added, "Part of what we're seeing is a catch-up from past underestimates."
Robert Hoehn, an analyst at ING Barings, said that raised an issue that had plagued a number of health insurance mergers: "the degree of integration of information systems" of the merging companies and "the ability to process medical claims."
Roberta Goodman, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, added that the "most important increase was in hospital costs," especially for Medicare patients.
Joyce Oberdorf, a spokeswoman for Aetna, said premiums were raised 10 percent in January, a month when most big employers renew contracts. But analysts said the increase was only 6 percent or 7 percent after employers trimmed their coverage to hold down their own costs. The underlying costs of medical care, meanwhile, are also rising by 6 percent to 7 percent, said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein.
Aetna said profits from operations were $173 million, or $1.18 a share, in the fourth quarter, compared with $144.4 million, or 91 cents a share. Earnings included $33 million from the sale of securities owned by a Brazilian affiliate.
Earnings in Brazil were weak, Mr. Huber acknowledged, reflecting a recession there and price controls, which Aetna said were temporary.
The Aetna U.S. Healthcare operating earnings, before Year 2000 costs, were $127.1 million, up from $112.9 million in the 1998 quarter. Earnings from overseas units that sell health and life insurance and other products were $52.7 million, including the $33 million one-time gain in Brazil.
Cigna said its H.M.O. earnings rose 31 percent to $118 million in the quarter. Non-H.M.O. health insurance gained 10 percent to $113 million. "It was clearly an excellent quarter," said Mr. Abramowitz at Bernstein. Wendell Potter, a spokesman for Cigna, noted that share repurchases had added to the $1.66 earnings a share.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Markets Stage Broad Rally On Strength of Labor Data

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices staged a broad advance yesterday after a government report indicated the economy could continue to expand without an appreciable increase in inflation.
Technology stocks were particularly strong, and the Nasdaq composite index rose to its third consecutive record. But the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which so far this year have been struggling, registered solid gains. And the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks rose to a record. 
 The gains came on heavy volume.
A billion shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange. At 1.94 billion shares, the Nasdaq stock market had its second-busiest day ever.
All of these gains were set in motion by the Labor Department, which early yesterday issued a report showing that worker productivity rose faster than expected in the fourth quarter while labor costs fell for a second quarter.
"The calculus is pretty straightforward," said Jeffrey Applegate, chief investment strategist at Lehman Brothers. "As productivity accelerates, the need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates becomes less and less."
Led by stocks like Microsoft, Immunex and Qualcomm, the Nasdaq composite index jumped 105.73, a gain of 2.5 percent, to 4,427.50. It was the seventh consecutive gain for the index, and the first time it has closed above 4,400.
The Dow gained 51.81, an increase of 0.5 percent, to 10,957.60. Interest-rate sensitive financial stocks like J. P. Morgan and retailers like Wal-Mart Stores helped to pull the Dow higher.
Big gains in technology names like Yahoo and EMC pushed the S.& P. 500 up 17.51, or 1.2 percent, to 1,441.75. And the Russell 2000, which like the Nasdaq is moving on strength in technology and biotechnology stocks, closed at 537.49, a gain of 5.10, or 1 percent.
"There are lots of people who are seeing technology as the instrument for growth," said Steve Witt, a managing director at Firsthand Funds in San Jose, Calif., a mutual fund that invests exclusively in technology issues. "As long as technology is perceived that way, I don't think this is going to stop. The majority of these companies have reported phenomenal earnings numbers."
Cisco Systems became the latest technology company to issue a strong earnings report.
After the close, the company, the biggest maker of Internet equipment, reported earnings that were better than consensus estimates. It also announced a 2-for-1 stock split.
Cisco, which has risen sharply in the last week, fell 3/8, to 12413/16 during regular trading. But the stock jumped after the announcement, and traded as high as 131 5/8 in after-hours trading.
Microsoft, another technology bellwether, had a good day. The stock gained 35/16 , to 10915/16 . And I.B.M., another Dow component, climbed 4 5/8, to 118 5/8.
Among retailing stocks, Wal-Mart rose 2 5/8, to 59 1/4, after an analyst at Lehman Brothers raised his price target on the shares to 100.
With the exception of some big insurance companies, financial service stocks did well.
J. P. Morgan gained 5/8, to 119 1/2. American Express was up 9/16 , to 163. Citigroup rose 1 5/8, to 55 3/4. And Merrill Lynch closed at 971/16 , up 5 1/2.
But it was a bad day for the beleaguered tobacco companies.
Allegations in a lawsuit that the companies conspired to fix cigarette prices sent the stocks lower.
Philip Morris fell 11/16 , to 19 1/2, a record low. R. J. Reynolds Tobacco declined 3/8, to 18 1/4. And British American Tobacco, a holding company for Brown & Williamson, fell 3/4, to 8 1/2.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasuries Rise Sharply
 (By Bloomberg News) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday as a government report suggested productivity gains and falling labor costs are helping hold back inflation, even with unemployment at a three-decade low.
Bonds extended gains after a Treasury note auction met with slack demand, prompting some investors to sell shorter-maturity government debt and pile into the better-performing bond, as they have been doing since late January, traders said.
The productivity and wage reports "are really good numbers for the bond market," said Patrick Kennedy, who helps manage at Pitcairn Trust Company in Jenkintown, Pa.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 113/32 , to 9819/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.23 percent from 6.34 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Productivity Soared 5% in Second Half of 1999
The efficiency of American workers surged in the last six months of 1999, the Labor Department reported. With these final numbers, the 1990's entered the books as the decade that produced the greatest improvement in productivity since the golden 1990's.
Analysts said the report showed that the economy would keep growing strongly with low inflation, perhaps convincing the Federal Reserve to moderate future interest rate increases. Page A1. 

Aetna Profit Grows but Shares Fall
Aetna said its operating income rose 20 percent in the fourth quarter. But Wall Street analysts said the underlying numbers were disappointing, reflecting deterioration in Aetna's core health business and losses overseas. Shares of Aetna fell $9.75, or 17 percent, to $46. Most managed care stocks also dropped. C6.
 
Nasdaq Index Sets Another Record
Stock prices staged a broad advance after a government report indicated the economy could continue to expand without an appreciable increase in inflation. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 105.73 points, or 2.5 percent, to a new high of 4,427.50. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 51.81 points, to 10,957.60, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 17.51 points, or 1.23 percent, to 1,441.75. C14.
 
Coke Seeks Settlement in Bias Suit
Coca-Cola, in an effort to put one of its largest image problems to rest, has begun settlement talks with lawyers representing eight current and former black employees who filed a racial discrimination lawsuit against the company nine months ago. C6.
 
Hackers Hit More Web Sites
Hackers mounted what appeared to be a coordinated seige on the world's largest e-commerce sites, including Amazon.com, CNN.com, Buy.com and eBay.com. A1.
 
Tobacco Wholesalers Sue Makers
United States cigarette wholesalers filed a lawsuit against the five leading tobacco companies, accusing them of illegally fixing prices. Stocks of the tobacco companies, which denied the allegation, tumbled on the news. C8.
 
New Message for Corporate Success
The business theorist who coined the phrase "core competencies" has a new message for corporate America: The key to success lies in the untapped power of your customers to exploit the Internet. Fred Andrews: Ideas Into Action. C10.
 
Tokyo's Governor Plans Bank Tax
Shares of Japan's major banks fell after the Tokyo metropolitan government announced a startling plan to impose a temporary tax on their operating profits. The plan, by Shintaro Ishihara, Tokyo's governor, aims to raise 110 billion yen, or roughly $1 billion, from 30 Tokyo-based banking institutions by taxing their profits before taxes and extraordinary gains and losses. C4.
 
Reuters to Shift Focus to Internet
Reuters said it planned to reposition itself as an Internet concern, sending shares of the company up 23 percent. The news organization plans to invest $802 million over the next four years to shift its content delivery to the Internet, including the creation of a Web portal that will compete with the same Web sites that license content from the company. C4.
 
Bond Trader Files Suit Over Firing
A former bond trader for Goldman Sachs Group contends in a lawsuit that the investment bank fired him last year because he was having an extramarital affair with a co-worker and his boss had religious objections to the relationship. C14.
 
Sales Triple for Online Bookseller
Barnesandnoble.com said its sales in the fourth quarter more than tripled from a year earlier, but its losses widened. C8.
 
The toymaker Hasbro said fourth-quarter profit fell 56 percent, to $57.7 million, but its sales were up 22 percent. C8.

HEADLINE: New Chinese Guided-Missile Ship Heightens Tension

BYLINE: By CRAIG S. SMITH 

 BODY:
China's first Russian-built guided-missile destroyer is expected to arrive in the East China Sea as early as this week, enhancing Beijing's ability to threaten American aircraft carriers in any future encounters over Taiwan.
Within weeks of the Sovremenny-class destroyer's arrival, Russia is expected to deliver the ship's most formidable weapon, Sunburn antiship missiles specifically designed to penetrate American carrier battle group defenses. The Russian version of the sea-skimming supersonic missile can carry nuclear or conventional warheads. 
 Conventions to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons, as well as Russia's own strategic interests, make it unlikely that the missiles will be delivered with nuclear warheads. But Russia could provide, or China could develop, technology that would enable the missiles to deliver a Chinese nuclear warhead.
The ship, expected to join China's East Sea Fleet based in Ningbo, will arrive at a time of heightened tension in the narrow strait separating the mainland from Taiwan, which Beijing has long considered a breakaway province. Taiwan holds presidential elections next month and during the last elections, in 1996, Beijing fired missiles into the sea near the island. The United States responded by sending two aircraft carrier groups to the area, infuriating Beijing and embarrassing its military leaders.
Even with conventional warheads, China's new missile-armed destroyer, together with four recently purchased Kilo-class submarines from Russia, will raise the threshold for any future American intervention in the region, military analysts say.
"These two systems, in particular, are ones that give us pause and make us realize that we are in fact going in harm's way," said Eric McVadon, a retired rear admiral who was a defense and naval attache in Beijing and is now a consultant on East Asian security affairs. "That's something the Chinese didn't possess before."
China has built its own guided-missile destroyers, but they are considered less threatening than the Sunburn-equipped destroyers from Russia. China purchased two of the Russian ships last year -- the second is expected later this year -- and is believed to be negotiating the purchase of at least two more.
"This is a generational leap for China into a much more advanced type of surface weaponry," said James Lilley, a former American ambassador to China and now a fellow at the conservative American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research in Washington.
Official American reaction to the ship's arrival has been muted.
"The U.S. military is adequately prepared" to deal with any threat posed by the destroyers, a Pentagon spokesman, Lt. Cdr. Terry Southerland, said this week. He said there has been no decision on Taiwan's request to buy American Aegis destroyers to counter the Chinese purchases. Military analysts say it could take China years of training before its navy can handle such a sophisticated ship in an actual conflict.
China "is trying to make us sweat," one analyst said, "but one ship does not a Navy make."
Congress is considering expanded military ties with Taiwan. Last week the House passed the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, which would increase coordination between United States and Taiwan forces and provide more American training of Taiwan's military officers. The Senate has yet to vote on the bill, which the Clinton Administration has threatened to veto if it does pass.
American military technology could find and sink the new Chinese destroyers in a matter of hours of any conflict. But the presence of the ships and their missiles in the Taiwan Theater complicates the calculus of cross-straits relations, the most volatile flashpoint in East Asia.
Ever since the Chinese Nationalist Army retreated to Taiwan in 1949, Beijing has threatened to occupy the island by force if its government declares independence from the mainland. Tensions increased last summer after Taiwan's president, Lee Teng-hui, declared that talks between his government and the mainland government should be on a "state-to-state basis," affording Taipei diplomatic parity with Beijing.
So far China has lacked the ability to carry out its threat of invasion -- dubbed by skeptics "the million-man swim" -- largely because of Taiwan's superior air force and the backing of the United States Seventh Fleet. Instead, Beijing has elected to threaten and intimidate Taipei with a formidable and steadily increasing arsenal of short-range ballistic missiles such as those used in 1996.
Under the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, the United States is obligated to help Taiwan defend itself from a mainland attack -- although in a 1982 joint communique with Beijing, Washington pledged not to increase the quantity or quality of arms sold to Taiwan.
The commitment to Taiwan's defense was reinforced last year when a senior State Department official told a group of Chinese businessmen that a mainland attack on Taiwan would be "disastrous for U.S.-China relations, and could, no doubt, pit us in an actual war." Those comments were intended as a warning to Beijing, American officials say.
But China's new destroyers and their Sunburn missiles, with a range of up to 65 miles, will alter the equation. The United States Navy currently has limited defense against the missile, which Russia designed in the 1980's to sink Arleigh Burke-class Aegis destroyers guarding American carrier groups or to hit the carriers themselves. The radar-guided missiles can deliver a 200-kiloton nuclear warhead to a target beyond the horizon in about two minutes. Even one of its conventional warheads could sink a cruiser or disable a carrier, depending on where it hits, military analysts say.
China's purchase of the destroyer and its missiles is part of an emerging pattern of procurement in the wake of warming relations with Russia. With the United States and much of Europe refusing to supply China with advanced weapons, Russia and Israel have been the country's primary options. Israel has helped China with the avionics for a fighter aircraft it is developing. But Russia, with a sophisticated arsenal and weakened economy, has been a more willing supplier.
Russia has sold China four quiet Kilo-class submarines, which carry "wake-homing" torpedoes designed to detonate beneath a ship's keel. The torpedoes are difficult to detect because they approach the ship from the rear where their sound is masked by the noise of the ship's propellers. And Russia is helping China assemble Russian Sukhoi Su-27 fighters.
Many American politicians, military officials and analysts deride these purchases, saying China is assembling a "junkyard army," cobbled piecemeal from outdated, castoff weaponry that poses little threat to the United States or its allies. Many of the weapons systems China has purchased require extensive training and sophisticated electronics and software to be used effectively. The People's Liberation Army has not demonstrated prowess in mastering such technology.
But other American analysts see a sinister logic to the procurement program, suggesting that the weapons purchases meet specific tactical needs within broader strategic goals -- the ability to challenge American dominance in the Taiwan Strait, for example, or to protect its claims in the resource-rich South China Sea. Some warn further that the incremental arms buildup represents the early stages of a broader armament intended to prepare China for potential conflict with the United States or to allow the country to eventually supplant the United States as the leading military power in the Asia-Pacific region.
China says it has no interest in projecting military force beyond its borders, arguing that it wants to maintain regional stability and focus on its own economic development. It could take decades to develop the integrated armed forces necessary to challenge American dominance in the region.
But Beijing considers Taiwan a domestic, not regional, issue.
"The trick," said Mr. McVadon, the former military attache, "is to find a way to preserve U.S. interests in Asia and yet accommodate China as an emerging military and economic power in the region and the world."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: U.S. PRODUCTIVITY ROSE AT 5% RATE IN 2ND HALF OF '99

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The efficiency of American workers surged in the last six months of 1999, the Labor Department reported yesterday. With these final numbers, the 1990's entered the books as the decade that produced the greatest improvement in productivity since the golden 1960's.
Productivity, an arcane statistic, nevertheless explains -- more than any other single statistic -- how the economy can grow as strongly as it has the last four years without generating more inflation. Workers, in effect, are producing much more without having to be paid more, and that takes pressure off corporate America to raise prices. 
 "This kind of data keeps alive the expectation that the economy will keep growing strongly with low inflation and that means the Federal Reserve will not have to end the expansion," said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, chief economist at the Salomon Smith Barney unit of Citigroup.
Almost all of the improvement came in the last four years, when computers became much faster and the Internet expanded rapidly, suggesting to some economists that the new technologies played a significant role in lifting labor productivity. Others insist that technology has made only a small contribution.
Investors in stocks, perhaps reassured that the expansion has more running room, pushed up share prices after the Labor Department announced that productivity rose at an annual rate of 5 percent in both the third and fourth quarters. The Nasdaq market, where most of the Internet companies are listed, jumped 105.73 points, to 4,427.50, another record, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 51.81, to 10,957.60.
Interest rates also eased off in bond market trading, one interpretation being that the Federal Reserve -- while still committed to one or two more small rate increases similar to the quarter-point increase last week -- will not raise interest rates enough to so discourage spending that the expansion is brought to an end. At nearly nine years, it is the longest in the nation's history.
Productivity rises when a worker produces more goods or services in an hour on the job than he did in the prior year. A phone operator who handled 100 toll calls in 1998, for example, handled 103 in 1999. This extra revenue can be used to raise profits or the wages paid to the operator, or both profits and wages. In any case, customer tolls do not have to rise to cover the extra outlay.
Starting in the early 1970's, the productivity growth rate fell sharply, averaging no more than 1.5 percent a year until 1995, a sea change from the 1960's when the average was a spectacular 2.9 percent a year. Productivity no longer made possible the improvement in wages, and living standards, that had benefited so many Americans in the 1960's. And to compensate, millions of people worked longer hours or at more than one job to keep from falling behind.
But starting in late 1995, productivity surged. The growth rate jumped to 2.6 percent annually, on average, pulling up the performance for the entire decade to 2 percent a year.
The latest numbers reinforced this improvement. Productivity in the fourth quarter rose at an unusually strong annual rate of 5 percent, the Labor Department said. An earlier third-quarter estimate was revised to 5 percent from 4.9 percent, and thanks to the last six months, the growth rate for all four quarters of the last year of the century averaged 2.9 percent, the highest for any year in the 1990's expect 1992, when there was a momentary jump.
Does that mean that the productivity drought that has afflicted the United States since the early 1970's is now over? Has a New Economy arisen, one in which faster computers, the Internet and the new high-speed communications networks have resulted in sustained improvement in labor productivity?
Some economists argue that this is the case. But others note that the rise in productivity coincided with a jump in economic growth as a run-of-the-mill economic expansion suddenly turned into a boom in late 1995. While technology plays a role, they say, the booming economy is the main cause of the rising productivity growth rate, which will taper off once the economy inevitably slows or falls into recession.
"We are not going to know how much is due to strong economic growth and how much to the new technologies until the current business cycle runs its full length," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, who gives most of the credit to technology. "We are seeing things in this cycle that are unprecedented. Productivity is accelerating late in the expansion, when it should be easing off. That is because of the new technologies."
Others argue that productivity surges when economic growth surges, whether that strong growth comes early or late in an expansion. During the 1980's, for example, the strongest growth came early in the expansion, the usual pattern, and the productivity growth rate, in response, rose at an annual rate of 2.7 percent from 1982 through 1986 -- virtually the same performance as the late 1990's -- only to taper off as the economy grew more slowly in the last years of the 1980's expansion.
"Productivity is very sensitive to growth," said Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist. "When the economy is growing above normal, the output of a worker also jumps. That is because companies, faced with a growing demand for their products and services, find ways to squeeze more output from their employees. And when the economy slows, the same workers find themselves producing less."
Manufacturing has been an enormous factor in the latest surge in productivity, rising at an annual rate of 10.7 percent in the fourth quarter, and 6.4 percent for all of 1999, the best performance since 1971. Nearly half the latest improvement came in the manufacture of computers and other electronic gear. Citing this bias, Mr. Gordon argues that productivity in manufacturing is narrowly focused, while Mr. Steinberg sees in the same data a much broader improvement. That is a result of new technology, he said, and of the strong rise in capital investment.
Whatever the final outcome of this debate, the productivity report yesterday had buried in it more evidence that labor costs are rising rather mildly, even if the productivity growth rate might justify bigger raises. Unit labor costs in the fourth quarter fell 1 percent, which means that the cost of producing a particular piece of merchandise fell.
That is a result of two factors. The total output of goods and services rose faster than the total hours needed to produce them, the Labor Department said, and compensation costs -- wages, bonuses, benefits and stock options -- rose at an annual rate of 4 percent, down from 4.7 percent in the third quarter and 4.8 percent in the second quarter.

HEADLINE: At Least One Yankee Team Gets Its Wish

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration is nearing completion of a deal to construct what would be the country's most expensive minor league baseball stadium, a $71 million complex near the Staten Island ferry terminal that would be built entirely with taxpayer money.
Under the terms of the 20-year agreement, the Staten Island Yankees, which play at the lowest level of the legendary Yankees farm system, would pay a modest rent and control the stadium year-round. The team, which plays 38 home games a year, would not have to pay any money for construction and would reap half of any advertising revenue and 70 percent of the revenues from any events booked into the stadium during the 327 days annually that the Yankees did not play there. 
 The stadium would be the first new professional ballpark in the city since Shea Stadium opened in 1964.
The Giuliani administration and the Staten Island borough president, Guy V. Molinari, hailed the project as a boon to the neglected area surrounding St. George Station, where the ballpark would be built along Richmond Terrace at Wall Street on a gravel and mud parking lot northwest of the Staten Island ferry terminal. The city would have the right to use the stadium for about 30 public events.
"We see it as the key component in the revitalization of the St. George neighborhood," Michael G. Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, said yesterday. "These things are very popular, affordable family entertainment."
Mr. Carey said the negotiations with the Staten Island Yankees should be completed by Friday. The 6,500-seat stadium, which has already been approved by the City Council, would include 21 luxury boxes, a restaurant, a clubhouse, an arcade and a novelty store.
Many cities have proved willing to provide enormous subsidies to lure professional teams, but the cost of the project for a team in the Class A New York-Penn League is extraordinary, said Robert Baade, an expert in the economics of professional sports. The estimated price tag is well above that for the $34 million minor league stadium that opened last year in Newark, and the $18 million stadium in Fishkill, N.Y., that is home to the Yankees' Penn League rival, the Hudson Valley Renegades. Leases for those stadiums have revenue-sharing similar to what is planned for Staten Island.
Since major league clubs cut their financing for farm clubs in the early 1990's, minor league teams have increasingly moved to those cities willing to build new ballparks. At the same time, minor league baseball has drawn new fans, because of relatively low ticket prices, intimate settings and the chance to talk to the players from the stands.
Some local officials and analysts say the project represents another gift from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to a borough that provided the margin of victory in his 1993 race against David N. Dinkins.
"Just because baseball is played on a diamond it doesn't mean you have to build a jewel box," said John Sabini, a councilman from Queens. "A lot of people stand to benefit from this and all of them are close to the mayor. One gets the feeling that this is part of a larger deal with the Steinbrenner family."
In separate projects for the borough, the city is also rebuilding the decrepit Staten Island ferry terminal, whose cost has swelled to more than $80 million from $20 million. It is also subsidizing construction of the nearby National Lighthouse Museum and a new home for the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences. Mr. Giuliani has also promised to close the Fresh Kills landfill by 2002, a pledge that helped secure the loyalty of Staten island voters.
Mr. Molinari said, "I don't see this as reparations for the landfill so much as the city of New York getting something wonderful." .
But economists questioned whether there would be any economic benefit from a minor league team that plays only 38 home games a year. They said the deal could set a pattern for large public subsidies at a time when the Giuliani administration is pressing to build a $30 million minor league stadium for the Mets in Brooklyn, as well as major league stadiums for both the Yankees and Mets, and possibly the New York Jets. The total cost to taxpayers could exceed $2 billion if all the plans come to fruition. But the stadiums, critics argue, provide mostly seasonal jobs and redistribute money spent on entertainment, rather than generate additional spending.
"It's all about serving the interests of the private sector through public subsidies," said Mr. Baade, a professor of economics at Lake Forest College. "We're not talking about an industry that's large enough to have an impact on an economy as large and diverse as New York's."
The project has wide political support on Staten Island, although some residents are concerned about potential traffic tie-ups when commuters pour off the ferry and head for their cars at the same time baseball fans are trying to get into the parking lots.
During the City Council hearing last December, Jerome X. O'Donovan, a local councilman who favored an alternative location on Staten Island, pushed for more community-based events at the stadium and additional parking, while complaining about how the project's cost had soared well beyond Mayor Giuliani's original $20 million estimate. Such cost overruns have often afflicted stadium projects.
The Giuliani administration and Mr. Molinari prefer to put the stadium cost at $29.5 million, not $71 million. "The other costs are not the true costs of constructing the stadium," Mr. Molinari said, "but infrastructure improvements that must be made whether or not there's a stadium."
But the city's figure does not include the $12.75 million cost of buying the land on which the stadium would be built. Nor does it include what developers call the soft costs of construction: architectural, engineering and construction management fees totaling $10.95 million. Mr. Carey said some of the architectural costs are attributable to other aspects of the project, like shoring up the bulkhead for the esplanade to the stadium.
In any event, the costs total $71 million when the environmental cleanup, landscaping, parking lot construction and a $6.75 million esplanade are added into the budget. The money would come from taxes raised during the course of the project.
The city has already spent $5 million to build a temporary ball field for the team at the College of Staten Island. The team, which moved to Staten Island last year from Watertown, N.Y., drew a sellout crowd of 4,500 to the season opener in June and an average of 3,183 fans a game, mostly from Staten Island, over the season. The team is owned by the Getzler family and members of the Steinbrenner family, who also have a stake in the major league team.
Josh Getzler, the club's chief operating officer, disputed criticism that the Yankees were getting a sweetheart lease: "The reality of the situation is that it's probably the most substantial lease of any minor league affiliate in terms of the amount of money going back to government."
If all goes well, Mr. Getzler said, the city could get as much as $1 million a year in rent and fees. City officials estimated the stadium would generate $175 million in economic activity in the life of the lease.
The team would have the option of walking away from the lease if it failed to make a profit for three consecutive years.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE ISSUES;
McCain, Sure on Military Issues, Is Less Certain on Domestic Ones

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8

 BODY:
It was telling to hear John McCain proclaim his impatience with President Clinton's last State of the Union address.
"A two-hour marathon," Mr. McCain said dismissively, promising reporters that should he be elected president he would keep the ritual address to Congress to a crisp 15 minutes. 
 "I think what you should do is give a vision for America," he said, "not give a laundry list that looks like a Chinese menu with one from column A and one from column B."
"I know he likes that," he said of the president, "because he's a policy wonk." Mr. McCain by contrast is not a policy wonk, at least when it comes to domestic issues.
While the Arizona senator can speak in great detail about unneeded weapons systems or his theories of containing rogue state dictators, he seems less fluent on the issues that were not his Senate specialties -- like health care or the environment or education.
Just a few months ago, Mr. McCain sometimes used the words Medicare and Medicaid interchangeably, mixing up the federal health insurance programs for the elderly and for the poor. He has since stopped.
And it is instructive that his pledge to audiences that he would never be guided by opinion polls but would always act "on principle" applies only to national security matters. On domestic affairs, Mr. McCain says it would be helpful to use polls to find out what Americans want.
In fact, despite Mr. McCain's reliably conservative voting record in his 17 years in Congress and his image as a reformer, his ideas on domestic matters sometimes seem far from fixed or fully developed. Although he has declared war on pork barrel spending and continues to call for an overhaul of the system of unlimited donations to political parties, he has yet to explain fully how his vision of conservative reform would translate into a comprehensive domestic agenda.
In some ways, Mr. McCain seems caught between his desire to help people solve big problems and his natural instinct as a conservative Republican to find small-government solutions. Occasionally when voters ask him about difficult social problems, he pledges to gather "the best minds in America" to work toward answers. And while Mr. McCain calls himself a "proud conservative," he sometimes agrees with questioners that various federal programs need more money.
At other moments, Mr. McCain almost plays down the importance of domestic matters when he says he is "fully prepared to lead" because of his experience in the military and his expertise in national security affairs.
The difference in Mr. McCain's command of foreign policy and domestic policy shows on his free-wheeling campaign bus, where reporters can question him all day long. He assesses world leaders and European defense capabilities with gusto. But he was far less animated last month when reporters pressed him at great length on whether he would stick to his vow against Internet taxation if recession ever loomed or if so much commerce moved to the Internet that states started seeing a decline in sales tax revenue.
"It will be a permanent ban on Internet taxation," Mr. McCain finally said, when questions continued even after he said that Internet commerce was expanding the economy, not cutting into other sales. "I cannot elaborate," he said several times in order to cut off the conversation.
On another day he became impatient when quizzed closely over when he views an issue as a state matter and when he sees it as a federal concern. "We're getting into the rarified atmosphere here of the academic Talmudian aspects of the role of the federal government," he said as reporters pressed him on federalism. "I like to deal on the level of the problems today."
And while he considers the lack of universal health care coverage a pressing social problem, he shies away from a big government solution, instead proposing tax-free savings accounts to help some people buy insurance and expansion of a current program to insure children. He also says general tax cuts would help people buy insurance.
"I think every American should have access to health insurance," he says. "I can't force every American to take it."
So far, this has mattered little in an insurgent campaign run on a blend of character, biography and reform. "What's driven the McCain candidacy thus far is his story, his personality, not his issue positions," said Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster unaffiliated with any presidential campaign.
In fact, voters virtually never point to any specific issue when asked why they like him. Katie Koenen, 18, who waited until 3 a.m. for Mr. McCain to arrive for a rally in South Carolina after winning the New Hampshire primary proclaimed him "more upfront" than Gov. George W. Bush.
Margaret Avery, a retired bookkeeper who went to one of Mr. McCain's New Hampshire town hall meetings, said simply, "I think he's truthful."
Audiences even seem appreciative when Mr. McCain admits he has some learning to do. "I don't claim to you to be an expert on this issue," he told a group of young people demanding a solution to global warming at one of his town hall meetings. He promised he would gather experts to study the problem.
Whether this will all catch up to him is an open question. Mr. Bush is beginning to point to his record as a governor to draw distinctions with Mr. McCain.
"I stand before you as a governor who led my state to managed-care reform," Mr. Bush said today in Delaware. "Some people in Washington say we can't get anything done because of all the lobbyists and special interests," he said, in a reference to Mr. McCain. "That's somebody who doesn't understand how to lead."
Supporters of the governor like Ralph Reed also note that Mr. McCain has never unveiled a comprehensive education plan the way Mr. Bush has. Mr. McCain had an education speech scheduled before the New Hampshire primary but canceled it rather than shift the focus in New Hampshire away from the tax cutting and Social Security debate.
He advocates a test of school vouchers paid for by closing corporate subsidies. And he speaks generally of giving merit pay to teachers based on student performance. Mr. McCain has put forward plans for Social Security, tax cuts, health care and the environment but even as he has done so, he has been hazy on the fine points of his own proposals.
Should Mr. McCain become the Republican nominee, he will face Democrats who are already researching his voting record in order to paint him as a Gingrich-style Republican out of step with mainstream values.
He embraced the Contract With America and voted with his party on the budget and tax cut proposals of 1995 that would have made $270 billion in savings in Medicare while granting $245 billion in tax cuts. Democrats are also poised to run against his anti-abortion votes and his votes against gun control.
Yet for now Mr. McCain has managed to transcend ideology and appeal to voters across a broad spectrum in part because his battle against special interests does not fall neatly along the right-left divide. Conservatives and liberals alike can warm to his promises to take government "out of the hands of the special interests and the big money and give it back to you."
Even on the polarizing social issue of abortion, Mr. McCain constantly points to his anti-abortion votes in Congress. Yet at the same time, his comments suggesting that he would let his daughter decide whether to have an abortion have created the impression among people on both sides of the question that he is not committed to the cause. He later said that he had misspoken.
He tells audiences, "Everyone -- pro-life or pro-choice -- has the same goal, which is to eliminate abortion." He also says that he would not use abortion as a litmus test in picking Supreme Court nominees, but would look instead for judges who are strict interpreters of the Constitution.
He told reporters last month, "I don't think that anybody in my personal opinion, who can say they adhere to the Constitution would have rendered the Roe v. Wade decision." But he also said he would consider judges as nominees not on one decision but on their "overall philosophy." He noted for example that he continued to admire Antonin Scalia even though he had dissented from a recent decision upholding limits on campaign contributions.
What adds to the enigma of Mr. McCain is that he sometimes seems to be embarking on a new intellectual journey along the campaign trail.
After years of voting for Republican tax cuts, Mr. McCain broke with his party's supply-siders in this campaign and advocated that the federal surplus be used for modest tax cuts and for shoring up Social Security. He likes to point out that virtually no one at his town hall meetings asks for a tax cut. And in New Hampshire at least, the primary results suggest he had a better grasp of public sentiment than Mr. Bush.
When voters in New Hampshire spoke of elderly relatives who could not afford prescription drugs, he came up with a federal-state block grant program to help the older people pay for drugs.
Mr. McCain likes to say that his many town hall meetings and inquisitive audiences have helped him. "I am a better candidate," he said one night, summing up his 114 town hall meetings in New Hampshire.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS with Joe Brescia and Corey Kilgannon 

 BODY:

Can He Carry Vote As Well as a Tune?
VICE PRESIDENT AL GORE was saying, "The occasion is piled high with difficulty," adding, "We must rise with the occasion." Another campaign speech? No, those were the words of Abraham Lincoln, and Mr. Gore was the celebrity narrator on the podium Monday night for Aaron Copland's "Lincoln Portrait," in Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center. Cued by LEON BOTSTEIN, conductor of the American Symphony Orchestra, Mr. Gore was the draw at a fund-raising event for charities including the Harlem School of the Arts, Bard College and the New York Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra. After three standing ovations, the audience joined the vice president in a revival-meeting rendition of "The Battle Hymn of the Republic." 
 "I made sure my microphone wasn't on" during the singing, the vice president said in a private moment of candor at the post-performance reception. "I'm not a bad singer, but I'm not ready for Lincoln Center!"
 
A Veteran's Strut
At OZWALD BOATENG'S men's fashion show at the Metropolitan Pavilion the other night, after a parade of suits and shirts in iridescent blues, purples and oranges passed along the catwalk, the last model in the spotlight, wearing a comparatively staid, black suit, received the loudest ovation. Maybe it was the exaggerated walk, part Mick Jagger, part Naomi Campbell. But more likely, it was the fashion crowd, which included the actress ANGIE HARMON, acknowledging LAURENCE FISHBURNE'S first strut down a runway.
"I used my veteran walk," Mr. Fishburne said after the show, where the actors BILLY ZANE and STEPHEN BALDWIN also modeled Mr. Boateng's suits.
"Veteran walk of which war?" someone asked.
"Veteran of my craft, of the stage," Mr. Fishburne said with a laugh. "To me, this is another stage to perform on."
But he's not just a suit-and-tie guy. "I've always loved the rags that Stevie wore," said Mr. Fishburne, referring to Stevie Van Zandt, Bruce Springsteen's guitarist, and his custom-made bandannas. "So I had someone make up a bunch for me."
 
But Is It a Crime Or a Misdemeanor?
WOODY ALLEN'S on-screen personas include hypochondriac, sports reporter and human chameleon, but the filmmaker turned up at City Hall yesterday afternoon playing a neighborhood advocate.
At a hearing held by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, Mr. Allen stepped up to a lectern to testify against a developer's plans to put up a 17-story apartment building on the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and 91st Street, a block away from the building Mr. Allen recently moved into.
In the self-deprecating style shared by many of his film characters, Mr. Allen noted that he had a losing record when battling on behalf of the community, and joked that local property values had declined since he moved to Carnegie Hill last year. The area, which stretches from 86th to 96th Streets between Fifth and Lexington Avenues, is often depicted in his films, including the one he distributed yesterday to the commission's members: a three-minute video he made.
Since much of the area is designated a historic district, plans for new buildings must be approved by the landmarks commission.
Approving the 17-story building, said Mr. Allen, would be "an egregious mistake" because it is too tall for the neighborhood.
"It's the wrong building for that site," he said. "This is a beautiful, beautiful, small, human-scale neighborhood, and to suddenly come into it and throw up a 17-story building seems, you know, like an obvious, obvious, awful thing to do."
Earlier in the hearing, architects for the project contended that the plans had already been revised to incorporate the neighborhood's style.
But Mr. Allen recalled "an old joke" about a man drowning a hundred feet from shore who is thrown a 50-foot rope by people claiming that they are "meeting him halfway." GLENN COLLINS with Joe Brescia and Corey Kilgannon

HEADLINE: Fashionably Early: New York Starts Buzzing Before Dusk

BYLINE: By RICK MARIN 

 BODY:
THE early-bird special. Is there a more mocked and maligned dining ritual? Who eats before 8 o'clock? It's so Boca Raton, so AARP, so tacky as to be ripe for reinvention as New York's next big dining trend -- as long as everyone agrees to call it something else.
Pretheater, prix fixe and "sunset menu" are the preferred euphemisms for cut-rate dinner specials between 5 and 7 p.m. The concept has trickled up from the all-you-can-eat buffets that service Florida's gerontocracy to Manhattan's whitest tablecloths. 
 Restaurants that once might have shunned such vulgarity now have early-bird specials. Three courses for $46 at La Caravelle. Half-price sushi at March. Pretheater prix fixes extend well beyond the theater district, from Avenue uptown at 85th Street down to Phebe's, on the Bowery, and sunset menus are promised in establishments where sun seldom shines (like the subterranean Vice Versa in Midtown).
Even buzzing places of the moment seem eager to make arriving early seem less unfashionable.
Metrazur, in Grand Central Terminal, throws in a free miniature "suitcase" with its pretheater meal, filled with cookies to munch on during intermission and a $3 MetroCard for the commute to Broadway. Pastis does its desperate would-be patrons the favor of accepting reservations at 6 o'clock. Windows on the World's Greatest Bar on Earth even has a romantic 5:30 seating for Valentine's Day. Kudos to the smooth operator who can sell his date on that timing.
To see how New York's chronic late birds were reacting to these efforts to get them to migrate to the early hours, I tried a week's worth of pre-emptive dining, from 3:30 -- yes, 3:30 -- to 7, but only at places offering the equivalent of early-bird bargains. A few times, I was even able to persuade people to go with me.
I like to think I was early on the early-bird trend. I was trained that you ate 6:30, and in the company of Walter Cronkite. In adulthood, I was ridiculed for espousing the upsides of early dining. Faster service. They're never out of the special entree. Finish at 8 and the whole evening stretches before you: see a movie, read a book, shop. Burn calories!
After years of abuse, vindication was mine one evening last summer on Long Island. Four of us went to the Palm in East Hampton at 5 o'clock -- the only time we could get a reservation. We got there in broad daylight, and as we were walking in, who was walking out? Ron Silver! He must have gotten there at 4. I vowed to go on an early dining crusade.
The first night out on my early-bird experiment, I needed somewhere I could do dinner and make a 6 p.m. movie at the Sony Lincoln Square. Conveniently situated, for my purposes, on the corner of Columbus Avenue and 85th Street, Avenue offers a $20 pretheater prix fixe from 5 to 6:30, with a decent selection of appetizers, entrees and desserts (coffee included). I roped in a colleague, who seemed excited by the novelty of the early dinner experience, and the promise of making the movie afterward. Arriving just before 5, we were the first people there. And for the next hour, we were the only people there. The woman nibbling alone at a table by the bar turned out to be a waitress.
One advantage of the 5 or 6 p.m. dinner preached to me by a couple of restaurateurs is better service. The waiters are fresh, not yet beaten down by demanding patrons. Our waiter at Avenue was, for the most part, attentive, though not all that attentive considering he had no other customers. I had to wave him down at least once and remind him we had a movie to catch. Getting out in time meant either coffee or dessert, but not both. We passed on the banana gateau and, just as we were leaving, another couple arrived.
"Welcome to my dining room," the woman bellowed to no one in particular. Then, still standing, her coat still on: "How are the veal chops? Tender?"
Now, we were getting some of that wacky early-bird ambience! Just as we made it out the door at 5:50. Enough time to make the movie, walk out after 20 minutes, go to Cafe Luxembourg for a drink, then Coco Opera for another drink. Then go home and read.
How often can you cram that much action into one evening?
Like Avenue, Vice Versa also offers a pretheater prix fixe. Which makes sense because there are actually Broadway theaters in its immediate vicinity. It's a 5 to 7 p.m. deal. Two of us showed up just past 6 on a Thursday night, with a third on the way. For $29.50, the choices are two appetizers, two mains, two desserts, and tea or coffee. A la carte, a $40 meal. One of the owners, Daniele Kucera, told me, when I called him a few days earlier, that about half of the 60 customers he serves in those two hours go for the prix fixe.
"It's mostly an older crowd," he said. I wondered if the older diners would be satisfied with the binary choices on the menu.
"They are picky," Mr. Kucera said. "They can be asking for this and that. I'm trying to be flexible, but you can't put the homemade pasta on there because it's a lot of work."
While we were there, it was a demographic cross section. A middle-aged couple. A young woman waiting for her date, who then showed up. In a corner booth, a grande dame, who never took off her fur hat, sat with a gentleman of similar vintage. No children, though.
Like almost every other place I checked out, Vice Versa was stroller-free. The only stroller I saw was at Artie's, the big new delicatessen on Broadway at 82nd Street, where I ate my 3:30 dinner two tables away from a new mother and her well-behaved baby daughter. The mother was enough of a regular to know about Artie's early-bird special -- free soup and rugelach for the price of an entree. (Not listed on the menu; it's a word-of-mouth thing.)
At Vice Versa, the middle-age couple, Sal and Janet Mannuccia, from Wilton, Conn., said they usually ate at 8 o'clock at home, but got here at 5:30 because they had theater tickets.
"That leaves plenty of time for dinner," Mr. Mannuccia, a high-school physics teacher, said. As a regular eating time, though, he said, 5:30 is "just too early." They ordered a la carte.
As a test, I asked if I could have the lemon mousse instead of the chocolate one on the prix fixe menu.
"You can do that," the waiter said. "No problem."
Being demanding is a key part of the early-bird ethic. Accept no soup that is not filled to the brim! I resolved to be more demanding on my solo excursion to Acacia, the brasserie that opened last May a block from Bloomingdale's.
Three different salads were on the two-course, $15.50 "sunset menu," but not the one I wanted: baby frisee aux lardons with a poached egg on top. The menu said "No substitutions" -- unless the diner was willing to pay any difference. I asked if I could make one, without paying extra.
"Non," the waiter said.
I agreed to pay. Sitting in the amber glow of the ostrich-egg light fixtures, how could I not ask for the specialite de la maison? Could I substitute the 10-ounce hanger steak, listed with a $5 surcharge, for the $12.50 ostrich burger?
"Non."
I felt like Steve Martin in "L.A. Story," when Patrick Stewart, playing a French-accented maitre d'hotel, tells him, "You cannot have zee duck!"
I looked the waiter in the eye: "I'm not really having the sunset menu, am I?"
"Non," he said again. "You are not having it at all."
Why do I get the feeling that waiters don't love the early-birders? Maybe because, as Gabriel Aiello, a co-owner of Gabriel's, told me, they are by definition not big spenders. That's why he doesn't solicit their business. "They're kicking the tires," Mr. Aiello said. "They're ordering water."
But the food at Acacia was delicious, and I got through two newspapers. A little lonely when I got there, it was about a third full by 7. The real action was at the bar. Overheard early-bird dialogue isn't the bad Noel Coward knock-off stuff you hear later on. At Artie's Delicatessen, for instance, I heard, from a woman to her dining companion, "You wanna take that home?" At the otherwise understated Acacia, it was "Another tequila shot!"
Philippe Feret, the chef and owner of Acacia and of Brasserie Julien, farther uptown, said his sunset menus attracts mostly regulars, a lot of them on their way to one of the three movie theaters around the corner. "More than ever, people are looking for special deals," he said.
All the new money around is starting to act like old money: cheap.
After dinner, inspired by all the money I had saved, I walked through the Bloomingdale's shirt department, trying to spend it.
The economics of the early-bird offering, for a higher-end place, are hard to work out. The kitchen is up and running, the waiters standing around rehearsing their lines. As David Cunningham, the chef at the Lenox Room, said of his Monday-to-Saturday, 5:30 to 6:30, $25 menu: "We're open. We have the staff there and we have the food there." Jimmy Bradley, the chef and a co-owner of Red Cat, in Chelsea, said "There's no way to make money off it." His $20 prix fixe, Monday to Friday from 5:30 to 6:30, has drawn in "dribs and drabs," he said, adding, "Some people are like, 'Wow, that's a crazy value' or 'Wow, that's really cheap!' "
For Mr. Feret, who also does a two-course $9.95 lunch, it's a loss leader. "We really just want to be known," he said.
Hotels led the way in what is referred to in the trade as "downtime food service," said Michael Batterberry, the co-author with his wife, Ariane, of "On the Town in New York" (Routledge, 1999).
"People consider it their birthright to eat what they want when they want," he said. "And there has been a continuing erosion of former meal hours."
Upscale steakhouses contributed to the erosion over the last decade, he said, feeding hungry bond traders their protein slabs in time for the 8:02 Metro-North to Greenwich. Last month, to accommodate customer demand, Oceana moved the start time of its $65 prix fixe on Saturdays to 5, from 5:30.
"The early bird suggests people who might not make it to nightfall," Mr. Batterberry said. "It has the aura of the excessively elderly." But hip foreign foods like tapas and sushi can get people used to dining after work without feeling like grandparents.
It is not, apparently, the key to longevity. Sadly, the idea that eating early is also a dietary boon is merely a pleasant theory. While there have been no studies on the early bird per se, in the October 1998 issue of the University of California's Berkeley Wellness Letter, a reader asked if eating late was more likely to cause weight gain.
The answer: "Over the years many experiments have shown that the time of day you eat has no connection with weight gain."
It's a good thing, because the only problem with early-bird dining is, like your grandparents used to say about Chinese food, three hours later, you're hungry again.

HEADLINE: Disguising the Sting of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
JEFFREY NEWHOUSE, a tax lawyer with a lot of Wall Street clients, is basking in the New Mexico sun, dreaming of the Colonial-style four-bedroom house that, even in the snow, is rising on four and a half acres of woods in Killingworth, Conn.
And he is pleased -- some might even say smug -- about the deal he made through a broker for his mortgage with the Bank of America. 
 In one of the many arrangements being offered by lenders now, Mr. Newhouse, 44, got what he considers the best of both worlds of mortgage financing: he got to lock in the rate before it went even higher, and in the unlikely case the rates go down, he got the option to reduce the rate when he actually closes on the house.
As the Federal Reserve keeps raising the rates -- last week's quarter percent was the fourth such rise since June -- banks across the country are coming up with gimmicks to disguise the higher rates; in this case, taking the borrower's mind off how much the rates have gone up in the last year, while making clients feel lucky that they aren't even higher (a neat trick). The practice offers peace of mind in a volatile market.
Besides loans like the one Mr. Newhouse is taking out, called a "lock in, float down" loan, banks are also luring less affluent, first-time buyers, with 40-year mortgages instead of the more conventional 30-year mortgages. Monthly payments will be slightly lower, but the buyer will pay tens of thousands of dollars more over the course of the loan, mortgage brokers say.
"Everyone's selling the same lousy rates, so every bank is offering some 'product enhancements,' " said Melissa Cohn, the president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company, one of New York City's biggest residential mortgage brokers. "That won't make the rates any lower, but it can make the payments lower."
No matter how many bonuses and incentives they advertise, banks are offering rates that are a lot higher than they were a year ago. Last February, a conventional 30-year-fixed mortgage could be snagged for 6.78 percent. This week, the average rate is 8.25 percent. On a $200,000 mortgage, that means $201 a month more to pay.
"Taken together with the rising cost of houses, that really blows the payments out of the water," said Martin Sasbon, a group vice president at the EAB Mortgage Company, a division of the bank.
But interestingly enough, the payments for a 40-year loan aren't that much lower, and the total amount one ends up paying is higher.
For a $200,000 loan, the borrower would end up paying back $540,720 with a 30-year loan, versus $685,440 with a 40-year loan.
And the difference in monthly payments? With the 30-year loan, they are $1,502 a month, and with the 40-year loan, they are only . . . $1,428 a month!
So who takes the 40-year loans?
"People at the two extremes: the first-time home buyers who want a little more purchasing power and, at the upper end, the big players with jumbo mortgages who are just looking for increased cash flow," Mr. Sasbon said.
Anyone getting a mortgage these days might be concerned about rates heading upward. It takes a minimum of about two months to buy a co-op or condominium, assuming the most straightforward transaction, from signing to closing; almost all mortgage institutions offer the borrower the option of choosing the rate either on signing or at closing time.
Now, many banks will commit to a current interest rate for up to a year. Mortgage brokers say that most of the borrowers who take advantage of these really long lock-in times are waiting for their new condominium to be built on Third Avenue or for their new mini-palazzo to be built in the suburbs.
Rajat Gupta, a finance manager with a Westchester chemical company, thinks the mortgage that he and his wife, Vanita, a financial analyst, got for their new $425,000 house in White Plains is terrific. Mr. Gupta said he first scanned the Internet for the lowest mortgage rates before he went to a mortgage broker.
Then he accepted a deal that protects him from the stormy rate seas until his family's four-bedroom Georgian-style house is finished, which it won't be until next November. He locked in a 7.87 percent rate.
But he had to pay $600 to the bank for the privilege.
He says he could make back that $600 in two months, if the rates go up one percentage point. "It's a great deal," he said.
And there are more deals being offered by lenders. Negative-amortization loans are back, after a few blissful years of not seeing ads for artificially low rates like "3 1/2 percent for the first 60 days!" For some borrowers, such a deal "takes the sting out" of the first few months of payments, Ms. Cohn, the mortgage broker, said. But the sting returns: buyers usually end up paying more over the course of these loans.
While many lenders promote the new products as an opportunity for borrowers, Ms. Cohn, who negotiates them every day, remains dubious, especially about the benefits for newcomers to the housing market.
"It's a lose-lose situation for the buyer in the long run," she said.
 
What Not to Do
LIKE so much in life, a lot of the mortgage deals these days could be defined as "Pay now, or pay more later." So check the fine print.
With the so-called negative-amortization mortgage, which offers an introductory rate lower than the average, the borrower actually winds up paying more.
"In the long term, you're actually accruing that difference," said Melissa Cohn, the president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company. "You're paying the interest on the unpaid interest."
The same principle applies to the lower payments for 40-year mortgages: you will pay a lot more, a lot longer, for monthly payments that are only slightly lower.
To Ms. Cohn, which loan you pick depends on your goal. "If you have a cash-flow problem," she said, "you'll be forced to pick the lower rate." That way, you will get the lowest possible monthly payment, but you will have to pay it for a decade longer. (You might also choose one of those options if you are going to keep the apartment or house for only a year or two.)
Another tip: Look for mortgage deals without prepayment penalties. If you find a lower rate later, you want to be sure you can get out of your existing mortgage without a fee. If you are buying a condominium and want to refinance your mortgage, you might have to pay the mortgage recording tax twice, which would add one and three-quarter points to the deal.
"That could certainly wipe out your reason for refinancing," Ms. Cohn said. TRACIE ROZHON
