HEADLINE: For Sale: Everything but the Props

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9

 BODY:
There are times confronting a sherbet-green entryway in a house for sale or a globe light fixture from the "Brady Bunch" era -- when Ken Fulk thinks of himself as a pair of glasses, correcting people's vision.
"You don't want to walk into a house and say, 'Oh my God, the carpet,' " said Mr. Fulk, 34, one of a growing band of decorators specializing in the fine art of "staging" or "propping" houses for sale, a phenomenon that has reached epic proportions. "My job is to help create a frenzy." 
 Here in the nation's most expensive real estate market, where it is not uncommon to have 15 buyers in a bidding war, staging -- also called house-dressing or "fluffing" -- is rapidly becoming the norm. Eager to get top dollar, homeowners are paying $2,000 to $10,000 to have humdrum rooms transformed into scrumptious interiors. To professional stagers like Mr. Fulk, who has a retinue of haulers, painters, floor and tile refinishers and carpet layers at the ready, falls the task of eliminating the orange shag, smoked mirrors, 1960's bathroom tile and dead plants (dead is a major turnoff) that can stall a sale.
Like human eyeliner, stagers are brought in, usually at the urging of a real estate agent, to "bring out the good features of a home," particularly in aging homes, in the words of Marlene Wharmby, an Oakland stager, who propped nearly 200 houses last year and whose signature is the telltale Tiffany box she leaves on the night stand. (Arthur McLaughlin, a San Francisco stager, leaves chocolate kisses.)
"We live in a house one way, we sell it another," said Malin Giddings, a broker at TRI/Coldwell Banker, who often summons Mr. McLaughlin to stage million-dollar listings with props plucked from an inventory of some 20,000 items: linens, towels, plates, wingback chairs and lampshades. (Mr. McLaughlin buys 350 lampshades at a time.) "He does in four days what a housewife does in nine months," Ms. Giddings said. "I mean, it's a miracle."
Objects that do not fit in are out. Mr. McLaughlin once asked a client with an original Georgia O'Keeffe to put it under the bed. "It didn't fit in with the overall decor," he explained. (He prefers to have his own artist, Janet Bogardus, copy any painting, Monet to O'Keeffe, and alter it to his own specifications -- it might need a smidgen more peach, say.)
Such staging tricks can also warm up a newly minted house, said B. J. Droubi, a San Francisco real estate agent, who estimates that staging adds $30,000 to $60,000, often more, to the final price of a home.
With a profusion of I.P.O.-flush clients, the Bay Area has become the epicenter of staging, home to some 70 professionals with names like Stage Hands, Center Stage, Stage Right and House-Dressing. Then there is Stage Interiors, a 10,000-square-foot warehouse filled with rental furniture and accessories. In this town, it sometimes seems that all the world's a stager.
"Staging was supposed to be about creating a facade," said D. J. Grubb Jr., president of the Grubb Company, an Oakland real estate agency, who dates the craze to the period just after 1991, when developers were trying to lure buyers to houses they had built to replace thousands destroyed by wildfire in the Oakland and Berkeley Hills. Now, Mr. Grubb said, "it has become an icon, the branding of a house."
Although still largely a West Coast phenomenon -- the 1920's hacienda outside Los Angeles owned by William Boyd, a k a Hopalong Cassidy, was staged recently -- the trend has caught on in cities like Minneapolis, as a strong economy and expectations among time-pinched buyers seeking perfection grow, said Martha Webb, an author of "Dress Your House for Success: Five Fast, Easy Steps to Selling Your House, Apartment or Condo for the Highest Possible Price" (Three Rivers Press, 1997). "It's harder to look at a house that's well staged," she said, "because you lose your heart."
Ms. Droubi tries to steer buyers to houses that aren't staged, so they won't get into bidding wars on overpriced properties. "A staged house evokes an emotional response -- people will pay whatever it takes to get it," she said. "I tell them to try to see past the dirty orange shag carpeting."
Her sellers, however, are another story. "We tell them to paint the living room pale yellow," she said. "All of a sudden, it's a darling little house."
Mr. Fulk has a personality as buoyant as the sofa pillows he keeps, along with several hundred antiques, in his barn in Napa. "I see so many houses filled with bad carpets and wrong decisions," he said.
One afternoon recently he paid a visit to Charlotte Albright, 42, a confectioner who is selling the three-bedroom Victorian house she shares with her schnauzer, Rocket. "Pretty . . . I would lose it," he said of the yolk-colored sponge paint in the living room. "Let's minimize the track lights to focus on the beautiful woodwork." He then turned to the delicate matter of scent. "Anything that evokes Rocket we need to eliminate," he said sweetly but sternly.
Staging takes diplomacy. "You really have to be polite," Mr. McLaughlin said. "People's sofas are very emotional to them."
Stagers "depersonalize" a space, removing family photographs and other cherished possessions. "You don't want buyers thinking about who lives there," Mr. Fulk said. "You want them to think about themselves living there."
It's not uncommon for a houseful of lovingly accumulated objects to be banished to a garage or basement, which is what happened recently to Antoinette Broussard, an interior designer and writer in San Francisco. She is staying at her mother-in-law's house while Mr. Fulk stages her house of 22 years. "It's difficult," she said, her voice tinged with sadness. "But if you want to get the best price, you have to take your ego out of it, put your personal feelings aside."
Ms. Albright will spend $20,000 on staging. "It is a little invasive," she said, noting that she was feeling "a little protective" of the smashed-Fiestaware tiles around the fireplace, which Mr. Fulk deemed "too kooky."
Staging requires a different knack from regular decorating. Gray, for instance, is not a good resale color, "because it doesn't make a space look happy," Mr. McLaughlin said. Turquoise is a turnoff, reminding people of "the 'Miami Vice' era." Mr. McLaughlin, who has been staging for 18 years, possibly a national record, recalled a client in the Pacific Heights neighborhood with baby-blue halls and stair runners. "Baby blue is not a resale color, especially in a multimillion-dollar mansion," he said.
Maximum wattage is another staging must. "You want dramatic shadows," he said, "as opposed to dark, depressing shadows." Among the telltale signs of staging are unopened bottles of olive oil on the kitchen counters, a dining room table set for dinner (minus the silverware, an antitheft touch) and cozy-looking double duvets and mattresses piled a la "Princess and the Pea." Television sets -- "too harsh a reality," in the words of Ms. Wharmby, the Oakland stager -- are usually absent.
Staging is a little bit like romance, Mr. McLaughlin said: "You never get a second chance. First impressions -- that's it!"
For buyers, staging can present pitfalls, causing them to swoon over day lilies artfully placed in a kitchen corner where the refrigerator should be. "If at first glance a place looks like a perfect person lives there, then like nobody lives there, it's probably been staged," said Bob Powers, founder of Stage Hands.
Ralph Holman, a lawyer for the National Association of Realtors in Chicago, said sellers must disclose "material defects in a property of which they are aware," like a crack in a foundation. But strategically placing a Venetian glass vase at a window to block an unappealing view or making a bedroom look bigger by installing a narrow antique bed are not against the law. "Most buyers are unaware of staging," Ms. Droubi said. "But there's a fine line. You don't want people to feel manipulated."
Peter Sargent, a science professor at the University of California at San Francisco, recently bought an 1883 house in the Noe Valley area that had been staged by Mr. Fulk. A pewter tray on the coffee table had green apples lined up in a grid, three on a side. "You look at it and say: 'What is this? Pottery Barn?' " he said.
But what appealed to Professor Sargent was not the things that had been staged. It was the old stove and the view of a steeple between poplar trees. Staging, he said, "reveals the pathology of the real estate industry and how calculated it has become."
On a recent rainy Sunday afternoon, it was difficult not to be smitten by a humble three-bedroom bungalow on the market for $519,000 in Piedmont, an affluent community adjoining Oakland. No detail had been left unstaged. Lamps glowed invitingly in the front window, and an antique cookbook lay evocatively on the breakfast table. The house's defects -- tiny, undistinguished rooms -- seemed like assets, the narrow antique beds and floral comforters evoking a thatched-roof bed and breakfast in Dorset.
Striving to instill as many feelings of home as possible, Ms. Wharmby placed a bottle of Champagne with four antique glasses on the dining room table. She even brought a touch of class to the "Motel 6 bathroom," as she called it, taking attention away from dated, beat-up decor with cut-glass bottles of designer perfume.
"If you have drugstore perfume," she explained, summing up the stager's art, "it's never going to have the impact of a few bottles of Chanel No. 5."

HEADLINE: Long-Term Care Crisis

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Feb. 4 editorial "The Shortage of Health Aides" calls attention to a looming crisis that will take an enormous emotional and financial toll on millions of Americans. As the baby boomers age, studies show that nearly half of them will need some sort of long-term care. 
 A majority of them mistakenly believe that Medicare will pay for their care. It does not. At a current average national cost of $51,000 per year, long-term care has the potential to destroy most families' economic security, forcing them to rely on Medicaid, the federal and state program that helps pay for health care for the poor.
We believe that the president and presidential candidates must begin a national dialogue on long-term care financing reform so that we can help maintain economic and retirement security for our nation's elderly, chronically ill and disabled.
 
PATRICK BRADY
Executive Director
Citizens for Long-Term Care
Washington, Feb. 7, 2000

HEADLINE: Vienna's Woe Is Heartening Isolationists Among Swiss

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Resentment against what is viewed as European Union meddling in Austrian affairs has given isolationist groups in Switzerland an unexpected lift. After months of trying, opponents have quickly gathered enough signatures to try to derail long-planned Swiss ties to the European Union.
A petition for a referendum with 70,000 signatures was delivered last week to the governing council in the capital, Bern, accompanied by a donkey draped with the European Union flag. 
 A coalition of 11 groups, including two right-wing parties, said they had gathered the bulk of the signatures last week.
"We have never had a dictator and we don't need to have one now from Brussels," said Flavio Maspoli, an official in a right-wing party.
The drive for a referendum has been led by Rudolf Keller, a former member of Parliament who, at the height of the controversy over Holocaust victims' money in Swiss banks, called for a boycott of American and Jewish companies. (He later backed down from the statement.)
As recently as early last month, Mr. Keller and his supporters had attracted only half the number of signatures needed to force a referendum -- 50,000. And it looked as if the effort had failed.
But a surge in signers from the eastern part of Switzerland, closest to Austria and considered the most conservative region, has forced the government to set the voting date for May 21.
Contention over neutral Switzerland's links with neighbors has been simmering for a decade. In 1992, the country voted against joining an economic grouping tied to the 15-member European Union.
Recently, views appeared to have shifted in favor of closer ties, in the face of prodding from the central government and changing economic realities. Polls now show that two-thirds of Swiss support closer relations with surrounding countries. But the referendum will be the first time that sentiment is measured at the ballot box.
In the fall, the center-left government was threatened by a better-than-expected showing by the country's most nationalist party, the People's Party, led by Christoph Blocher, in elections held after unflattering disclosures about Switzerland's actions in World War II.
Swiss are quick to say that Mr. Blocher's brand of nationalism is less strident than that of Jorg Haider, who has taken his far-right-wing Freedom Party into the government in Austria. But the Austrian situation has drawn adamant commentary here that the European Union is interfering.
"To sanction a country solely because of the political composition of its executive is a serious and unacceptable precedent," Eric Hoesli, editor of a daily in Geneva, Le Temps, wrote in a front-page editorial last Friday.
Opponents of the European Union here say by spurning Austria the organization has shown that it is not democratic enough and is too big and bureaucratic.
One organizer of the petition drive, Bernhard Hess, said that realization caused voters to sign for a referendum that would decide by a simple majority whether Switzerland should adhere to bilateral accords with the European Union. The Parliament has already approved the accords, which are to take effect next year.
Negotiated over four years, they are seen as a steppingstone to eventual membership. The agreements would ease tough border controls and immigration rules and eliminate trade barriers. In an unusual alliance with the conservative groups, Swiss environmentalists oppose the accords, in part because they would allow 40-ton trucks on trans-Alpine routes.
Supporters of the accords, which include many businesses, banks and unions, see them as crucial for Switzerland to gain access to the vast European Union market.
Economics Minister Pascal Couchepin pledged to lead the fight to win approval of the accords, which he maintains would allow Switzerland to be treated as an equal but would not require the country to be involved with decisions from Brussels.
Taking note of the donkey that delivered the signatures in Bern, Mr. Couchepin said, "It's necessary to know whether the donkey represents those seeking the referendum or those fighting it."

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 3; Foreign Desk

HEADLINE: Fight Over a Chinese Prisoner Goes Public

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Frustrated after six months of fruitless inquiries to Chinese officials, American legislators are mounting a public campaign on behalf of a prominent Muslim businesswoman from China's Far West who was jailed on vague charges of revealing state intelligence to foreigners.
The woman, Rebiya Kadeer, 53, was detained Aug. 11 in Urumqi, the capital of Xinjiang province, where she owned a department store and a trading company. She was picked up just before she was to meet visiting Congressional staff members, who had invited her to a private dinner. Later, two of her sons and her secretary were detained as well. 
 One son was released after three days. The other, accused of supporting subversive activities, was sent without trial to a labor camp for two years. The secretary was sentenced to three years in a labor camp.
Ms. Kadeer's trial was delayed and may take place in the next few weeks, her family has been told.
For years, Ms. Kadeer had been officially touted as a rags-to-riches inspiration for her fellow members of the Uighur ethnic group. Now, her arrest has highlighted China's troubled relations with the Uighur Muslims, who are a dwindling majority in the province as ethnic Chinese move in, and have been struggling to assert their national identity.
Ms. Kadeer's arrest has been condemned by international legal monitors, including Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International, because the case appears to be flimsy and the real target appears to be her husband, Sidik Rouzi. He is an Uighur nationalist who fled to the United States in 1996 and made radio broadcasts critical of Beijing.
The son who was detained and released in August, Alim Abdiryim, asserted in an interview from Urumqi last week that his mother and his imprisoned brother, Ablikim Abdiryim, 26, had done nothing more than send published local newspaper articles about Uighur affairs to their father.
"She was arrested because she was one of the most patriotic members of our Uighur nationality and one of the people most willing to help the poor," said Mr. Abdiryim, who is 24. "The other reason was because of my father, who they said was engaged in counterrevolutionary activities in the United States."
Because Ms. Kadeer had been about to meet with the Congressional staff members, who were on an official tour, when she was arrested, several American senators and representatives have followed the case closely.
But letters and meetings with Chinese officials have yielded no explanations. So Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican, plans to seek wide support this week for a Congressional resolution calling on the Chinese to release Ms. Kadeer, her son and secretary, and calling for a United Nations human rights investigation.
Senator Roth, as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, will manage the key trade legislation seeking permanent normal trade status for China in connection with China's entry into the World Trade Organization. He has strongly supported China's entry into the trade body, but said he had been frustrated by Chinese stonewalling on the Kadeer case.
"Six months of quiet diplomacy has achieved nothing," Senator Roth said in an interview on Sunday, adding that he was worried by indications that Ms. Kadeer would soon be put on trial. A guilty verdict in Chinese security trials is virtually preordained. Depending on how the court defines her transgression, Ms. Kadeer could receive anywhere from a short sentence to more than 10 years in prison.
A separate resolution calling for the release of Ms. Kadeer, her son and secretary was introduced last week by Senator Paul Wellstone, a Democrat from Minnesota and a frequent critic of China's human rights policies.
Splintered and lacking an internationally recognized leader like the Tibetans' Dalai Lama, Uighur nationalists have received relatively little international attention.
Xinjiang security forces have periodically battled members of a small, armed separatist movement that seeks an independent East Turkestan, and scores of Uighur militants have been executed in recent years.
But the Chinese are also struggling to contain a much broader effort by Uighurs to strengthen their sense of identity and their economic status in the face of domination by ethnic Chinese and the Communist Party. Outspoken intellectuals like Mr. Rouzi have been jailed or have gone into exile, and publications about Uighur history and conditions are tightly controlled.
In the mid-1990's, Ms. Kadeer was praised as a bootstrap millionaire. Born in poverty, married at 15, she amassed a trading fortune even as she raised 10 children.
The Communist Party held her up as a product of its enlightened ethnic policies. She was appointed to the Chinese People's Political Consultative Congress, a prestigious national advisory body, and a was delegate to the United Nations conference on women, held in Beijing in 1995.
Her star apparently began to fall after her husband left for political asylum in the United States in 1996. Mr. Rouzi had been imprisoned in the late 1960's for his role in an anti-Chinese demonstration, he said in an interview last week from Oklahoma, where he now lives. Then in the mid-1990's he published two articles in Urumqi newspapers criticizing Chinese treatment of Uighurs.
Fearing arrest, in 1996 he moved to the United States. He angered authorities further by broadcasting nationalistic messages on Uighur-language programs of the Voice of America and Radio Free Asia, United States-sponsored networks beaming into China.
In 1997, Ms. Kadeer's passport was revoked and the authorities froze the funds of an organization she had started to aid Muslim businesswomen. In 1998, she was removed from the national consultative conference and publicly castigated for failing to condemn her husband's broadcasts.
"She was never involved in politics," Mr. Rouzi said of his wife in an interview last week. "But she loves the Uighur people."
Mr. Rouzi said he had stopped his radio broadcasts. Five of their children live in the United States, while the other five remain in China.
Mr. Rouzi said the family had been told that Ms. Kadeer's case would be brought to trial soon after the Chinese New Year holiday.
The freed son, Alim Abdiryim, said relatives had been allowed to visit their mother only once since her arrest, on Jan. 5. "She was in poor spirits and said, 'I'm innocent, get me out of here,' " he said.
Soon after her arrest, he said, the authorities said she had been charged with providing foreign organizations with state secrets and intelligence.
"My mother is simply a businesswoman," Mr. Abdiryim said. "She doesn't know anything about state secrets or intelligence."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Modern French Aristocrat in Trade's Fractious Arena

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Pascal Lamy is known as "the Exocet" for a personality as direct and aggressive as the missile built in his French homeland. But now that he is Europe's top trade official, Mr. Lamy's subtle diplomacy may be a more useful weapon.
The 52-year-old career civil servant, appointed as the European Union's trade commissioner last fall, has found himself at the center of some of the world's most contentious trade disputes. French farmers want him to preserve the subsidies that keep their prices artificially high but are regarded as obstacles to free trade. European consumers want him to keep genetically modified food from abroad off store shelves. Then there are the seemingly never-ending fights between the European Union and the United States over bananas, steel, aircraft noise and hormone-treated beef. 
 There had been some surprise at Mr. Lamy's appointment, partly because of a widespread impression that he was simply too blunt and might alienate Europe's trading partners with his no-nonsense approach. But Mr. Lamy has shown himself to be adept at compromise.
He took the initiative to help restart the World Trade Organization talks that collapsed in Seattle two months ago, becoming the first top-level trade official publicly to propose a plan to break the impasse. This week, the Geneva-based trade forum announced that it would reconvene the talks, although with a narrower agenda than Mr. Lamy had wanted. "We have to repair and reignite the process," he said in an interview a few days earlier in his office in Brussels, headquarters of the European Commission, the European Union's administrative arm.
Mr. Lamy was named to the trade post after top officials of the previous European Commission had been dismissed last year over accusations of mismanagement and cronyism. His selection was a surprise partly because he had a not-altogether-flattering record in Brussels.
He served for nine years as assistant to the former European Commission president, Jacques Delors. It was in that post, where he handled top-level meetings of the Group of Seven industrial nations, that he acquired the sobriquet as a Delors hatchet man or, alternately, the Delors Exocet.
In 1994, Mr. Lamy left Brussels and returned to Paris to help in trying to salvage Credit Lyonnais, a troubled big bank that had accumulated enormous debts and required repeated taxpayer bailouts.
A graduate of an exclusive French management school, Mr. Lamy is identified with the country's political elite, a circle he mixes in easily as a member of a well-to-do Normandy family. Skeptics have wondered how a man ensconced in the French establishment would deal with the European practice -- espoused most forcefully by France -- of subsidies for farmers.
"Agriculture is a tricky one for him," said Paul Brenton of the Center for European Policy Studies. "He may want to move ahead, but he will face the strength of the agricultural lobby and ministries in Europe. He can only move ahead carefully and subtly in this atmosphere."
Mr. Lamy, trim from his passion for marathon running, maintained that he can make progress on agriculture. "I have room for maneuver," he said in the interview. "We believe agriculture has environmental, social, local and landscape impact, which deserve the taxpayer paying for this."
Deep-seated differences between Europe and the United States over the American view -- one backed by other exporting countries, that farm goods should be treated like any other item of trade -- contributed to the failure in Seattle. European and Japanese representatives strongly argue that farmers must be protected in order to preserve rural life.
"He has been less French than expected in agriculture," said Nicholas Clegg, a British member of the European Parliament, who was dubious about Mr. Lamy's selection. "He has said the future of agriculture reform is not taboo. This has been a highly pleasant surprise."
Mr. Lamy departs from some European colleagues on the even more fractious topic of genetically modified food. He thinks such disputes should be decided at the World Trade Organization. "The W.T.O. will have to articulate the rules about this," Mr. Lamy said, acknowledging that his view is unpopular in Europe.
He strongly defended the trade organization, which a broad range of critics have called a secretive group that has little public accountability. The W.T.O. "has been painted as the black box where multinationals do their dirty tricks in getting rid of barriers that protect nice people," Mr. Lamy said. To counter that, "my prescription is going out loudly on the idea that we need more trade liberalization with rules that benefit everybody."
He has proposed that the trade forum release more internal documents, sponsor a yearly public debate and open its deliberations to nongovernmental organizations. "This is all part of the democratic scene-setting at the international level," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Shocking Old Brands Back to Life

BYLINE: By PATRICIA WINTERS LAURO 

 BODY:
F. Scott Fitzgerald said "there are no second acts in American lives." But he never heard of the new Volkswagen Beetle or the Apple iMac -- to say nothing of the comebacks of entertainers like Cher and Tony Bennett.
Today, second acts are as popular in the world of consumer marketing as they are in the entertainment business. Just in the last year or so, Maxwell House coffee, American Greetings cards, Volvo cars, the New York Stock Exchange and even the United States Navy have produced new advertising that tries to recast their brand names as hip and contemporary. 
 Whether it is by creating a new image, a new package, a new product benefit -- or a mix of all of the above -- long-established brand names are finding it necessary to update their acts in a bid to keep up with the rapid changes in American society and the economy.
"Every single brand, especially classic brands like Chevrolet and John Deere that are always given credit for trust and high quality, are fighting to become more contemporary and energetic," said David A. Aaker, vice chairman of Prophet Brand Strategy, a San Francisco-based consulting firm. "I'd say 70 percent of brands want to be perceived as younger than they are now perceived."
The buzzword in marketing is relevance. Brands have to be on top of the trends, or face the specter of declining sales. And the trends are changing at Internet speed. Brands now compete in a revved-up global market and face product trends that come from around the world. The competition is even fiercer at the supermarket, where instant sales information dictates how much shelf space brands get. Multiculturalism and changes in family life have also contributed to the need for change.
In such a market, a youthful image is more important than ever.
Take the New York Stock Exchange, the market leader whose previous advertising promoted its strength, stability and venerability. These are all great product attributes, but could be viewed as a tad stuffy. Besides, the Big Board wanted to show its current success in important global industries -- a message that was being overshadowed by rising competition from the National Association of Securities Dealers, the parent of the Nasdaq market, which has become synonymous with cool technology and Internet stocks.
"The reality is more technology companies are here than there, and that's lost on people," said Robert Zito, senior vice president of communications of the N.Y.S.E.
Last year the Big Board brought in Omnicom Group's BBDO New York, which introduced an untraditional television campaign, modeled on consumer product marketing and using sports celebrities, but aimed at corporate decision makers and other opinion leaders, Mr. Zito said.
In one spot, a little boy is propelled into a fast-paced almost breathless journey after he asks his computer, "Where is the center of the tech world?" He ultimately lands on the floor of the exchange where, a voice-over explains, the "most highly successful technology companies" are listed, like America Online and Gateway.
The other commercial features Terry Bradshaw, the former quarterback turned broadcaster, on an engaging quest for the center of the sports world as he interrupts, among others, Mia Hamm on the soccer field and Sammy Sosa at bat. The point? Big-name sports-related companies like Reebok International and Nike are traded on the Big Board.
Jack Trout, a marketing consultant whose book due next month, "Differentiate or Die" (John Wylie & Sons), notes the vast proliferation of product choices. In the 1970's there were 17 over-the-counter pain relievers; today the total has soared to more than 140, he says. Five hosiery brands existed then; today consumers can pick from 90. If you wanted contact lenses then, Bausch & Lomb was your only choice; 36 contact lens companies now vie for your eyes, offering everything from tinted lenses to disposables, he said.
"I think part of it is the global economy, brands are coming from everywhere and the international guys are getting a lot better at it," Mr. Trout said in an interview. "It's an explosion of choice."
It has also become more expensive and difficult to create and market new brands, explained Carol Davies, managing partner of Kane, Bortree & Associates, a New York marketing firm. That encourages companies to reposition existing brands rather than take the extra risk and cost of developing a new one. With scanners and other research, supermarkets are very sophisticated about what sells and are reluctant to give shelf space to new brand names without sales histories.
"The trade has become much more sophisticated," Ms. Davies said. Supermarkets are saying, "We can't afford to carry all your brands," and they have forced companies to reassess, she added.
At the same time, the emerging generation of consumers is much more comfortable with diversity than its parents are. "It's fusion -- what kids are doing with music, with food, with words," said Cathy Clift, a senior vice president at McCann-Erickson, West, a unit of the Interpublic Group. "We are looking at a cross-culturalism, and many more ethnic influences today."
Indeed, the Navy discovered that it had to reposition itself for a new generation after its 1998 recruitment efforts fell short. Research showed the Navy that young people aged 17 to 24 reject glossy messages with paid actors and instead want information and an honest approach, said Steve Lowry, public affairs spokesman for the Navy Recruiting Command. "They can spot a phony a mile away, and that will turn them off faster than anything," Mr. Lowry said.
Plus, the commercial has to move.
The Navy switched its campaign from a high-toned, earnest approach set to classical music. The new commercials, created by BBDO New York, have a documentary style and use real sailors who talk about the service. One spot shows young recruits on a ship alternating between work and jamming in their own hip-hop band. Another shows a young newscaster who landed her job after a Navy stint. In 1999, the Navy did meet its recruitment goal, but factors including changes in eligibility and better pay and pensions also played a role in the gain.
Brands are fighting to be forever young, not just for image sake, but to replenish sales. Kraft Foods' Maxwell House has lots of consumers, but its marketers want to attract younger consumers, aged 25 to 35, to keep the brand thriving in the future.
Faced with Starbucks, Maxwell House has been fighting back for several years by introducing high-end varieties and running new and different advertising. Still, its research showed that despite an enviable status as an American icon, it needed to "prove to younger consumers that Maxwell House is not only timeless, it's timely," said Rick Roth, worldwide client service director for Maxwell House's agency, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, New York, a unit of WPP Group.
As a result, last year the company replaced a line of ads that relied mostly on nostalgia with new advertising set to original music and showing people of all ages getting the most out of ordinary moments. The tagline reflects the theme: "Make every day good to the last drop." Ogilvy also reworked the media schedule, dropping out of daytime television and running more ads during prime time, as well as focusing on youth-oriented magazines. Ogilvy even covered city buses and subways with striking images.
The advertising, said Ann Fudge, executive vice president of Kraft Foods, a unit of Philip Morris Companies, and president of Maxwell House and the Post divisions, is aimed at making Maxwell House more relevant to young consumers by identifying with their state of mind.
"Our research showed while young people remembered us, they had not fully connected with us in a stronger way," Ms. Fudge said. "We need to be really plugged into what's going on and what's important to them."
Like Maxwell House, Volvo, the Swedish carmaker now owned by Ford Motor -- which long produced dependable and safe cars -- is trying to reinvent itself. But while it wants to attract younger buyers, it also realized that it had to change its overall image to appeal to a broader audience, younger and older. With all cars now safer than before, safety alone is no longer an exclusive selling point for Volvo, said Bob Austin, Volvo Cars of North America's director of marketing communications. Other features like style and comfort were necessary to broaden the market.
One commercial for its lower-priced model aimed at young people is a comical spot showing a couple dropping off a 2-year-old after a horrendous baby-sitting experience.
"We're trying to reach that prefamily group to get them in the Volvo family," Mr. Austin said.
American Greetings is also reaching out to younger people, even though most greeting cards are bought by women over 35. The idea is not just to appear youthful, but to introduce consumers to the card line before they reach peak buying years, explained David DeMuth, general manager of the Cleveland office of Doner, the advertising agency that created the irreverent print advertising to reinvent the brand. One image: a biker type in a tutu.
Of course, recasting a long-established brand is not easy. One risk is losing the core customer. Moreover, perceptions are difficult to change. Mr. Trout, the marketing consultant, said that Timex tried to go more upscale a few years ago, but had more success returning to its traditional position as a reliable, relatively low-cost, watchmaker. The General Motors Cadillac division, which is promoting sporty vehicles, has to fight its image as a maker of big, roomy cars, he noted.
"It's extremely difficult to reposition an established brand," Mr. Trout said. "You can try to change things, but sometimes your old identity just haunts you."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
From Nemesis To Ally On Schools

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
AN unexpected voice of support from, of all people, Ramon C. Cortines for, of all people, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his call for mayoral control of the New York City school system.
"Give it to him," said Mr. Cortines, now interim head of the school system here. 
 This from the man Mr. Giuliani all but hounded out of office as schools chancellor in 1995, after two years on the job?
Well, yes. Sitting in his sunny (of course) office one afternoon this week, the 67-year-old educator poked holes in the current structure of the New York school system, from the perspective of someone who should definitely know better than most how things can go wrong when everyone is in charge, and therefore no one: six politicians (the mayor and five borough presidents) select the seven-member Board of Education, which picks the chancellor. And school funds flow through the city budget.
Small wonder that New York's school system is in perpetual tumult, with finger-pointing raised to a high art and chancellors coming and going with revolving door frequency. The setup so dilutes leadership of the schools, Mr. Cortines argued, that responsibility is fragmented and the mayor is forced to horse trade to try to get what he wants from the board, with mixed results.
"If the mayor were responsible, he wouldn't be as critical of the schools," Mr. Cortines said. "He would begin to understand some of the problems, the complexities of how kids learn. If he is accountable, if it is his board, his teachers, his contract, his parents, the education of children doesn't become the political football of a community."
To those who say that a mayor would turn the city school system into a fief and the chancellor into a puppet, Mr. Cortines says no way: "Mayors will find out that they cannot dictate policy from City Hall. You can have Jesus Christ as mayor and he could not run the school system. You have to have teachers, parents, administrators. Any mayor will learn that."
Given his unpleasant history with Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Cortines's support for mayoral control is not only surprising, but also gives those who want to revamp the system a persuasive ally. Mr. Cortines said that the schools should be no different from other city agencies, whose success or failure affect the mayor's reputation. Now politicians in New York and elsewhere, he said, can duck responsibility for education. "Give the mayor direct control and there won't be those sound bites," said the former chancellor. "The mayor can't say, 'If only I had control.' "
MR. CORTINES, who expects to work as interim schools superintendent here through the spring, did not address the situation in Los Angeles, where mayors are weaker and have even less say over education than in New York.
He did say that sound bite-itis infects the larger debate about education throughout the country, as elected officials grab for easy answers. Schools failing? Go for vouchers. Students failing? Raise standards and end social promotion. Teachers mediocre? Give merit pay.
It is not that he automatically opposes any of those approaches, he said, just that he would welcome a little more understanding of their complexities. For instance, merit pay -- another Giuliani idea -- is fine in concept, Mr. Cortines allowed, but who sets what criteria? Ending social promotion is a laudable goal, too, in his judgment, but unless schools set up strong tutoring programs and summer sessions to help students catch up -- as officials recently failed to here, he has complained -- proclaiming an end to social promotion will end up a mere publicity stunt.
The issue of vouchers is even more complex, said Mr. Cortines, who suggested that his successor, Rudy Crew, overreacted when Mr. Giuliani embraced the idea of a voucher experiment. Vouchers can be just another tool if educators insist that a certain percentage of them be set aside for economically disadvantaged students.
But with vouchers, as with school governance, the main problem is the same, suggested Mr. Cortines: politics. "The politicians don't get it. They're always looking for a quick fix. For most of them, vouchers is a quick fix. It isn't. It isn't the end-all. But instead of really trying to help education, the politicians give us sound bites.
"A sound bite does not fix anything."
Even his old nemesis at City Hall would figure that out, Mr. Cortines predicted, if he got what he says he wants -- direct control of the largest school system in the country.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1643 words

HEADLINE: Issue of Elderly Housing Separates Suburban Generations

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y, Feb. 9

 BODY:
In a span of 35 years, Ruth Dewey has led the Girl Scouts here and presided over both the Board of Education and the Friends of the Library. Now, at 77, she looks forward to living out her final years here and believes she has the perfect place to do it: a proposed continuing-care retirement community, the sort of place that lets you decline gently into old age with a range of supports.
But there's a snag. A group of residents is trying to stop the project and its six new buildings. They warn about dangerous zoning precedents and increased traffic and argue that the project's scale is too big for this tiny riverfront village. 
 "You feel you've put in your two cents of work for the community," Mrs. Dewey said. "There's an assumption that the elderly are somehow different from the community, that we're not part of it. But I'm not somebody whose interests should now be ignored."
The skirmish here is part of a broader battle unfolding in suburban communities, particularly in Westchester County, where the 65-and-over population is expected to grow by 26 percent in the next 20 years. Those projections, coupled with the county's affluence and a recent loosening of state regulations, have put Westchester on the radar screen of developers eager to build the type of upscale housing that lends older people a hand with daily activities.
And so the county's older residents find themselves asking neighbors and elected officials to make room for them at a time when many feel that congestion and development have reached a critical mass. The resulting clash is providing a revealing glimpse of generational and real estate politics in the New York suburbs, often playing out as a conflict between the housing values of young professionals and the housing needs of their parents' generation.
Developers and advocates for the elderly say the kind of supportive housing designed to keep the elderly out of nursing homes has swept the South and West with little opposition. The New York region has posed a tougher challenge, and Westchester County has perhaps put up the most formidable resistance of all. In the last five years, dozens of projects representing about 7,600 units of housing for the elderly have been proposed. Many have been approved and are being built. But many others have become ensnared in high-powered local resistance -- opposition Web sites are whipped up and lawyers retained before a formal application can be presented to a planning board.
"We're heavily into New Jersey and Massachusetts and Connecticut, and New York is our only big void," said Michael J. Giacopelli Jr., senior vice president of development for Marriott Senior Living Services in Bethesda, Md.
The company, with 143 housing developments for the elderly in 29 states, has had five separate proposals for elderly housing fail in Westchester and Long Island over the last two years. "There are a lot of barriers to entry," he said. "Zoning codes don't even recognize the use in many cases."
Private groups and public agencies working with the elderly find the issue a source of rising frustration. "What communities are saying is that when you become too frail to live independently, there's no place for you," said Mae Carpenter, director of the Westchester County Office for the Aging.
But in many ways, the vehemence of the opposition has to do with the special nature of the housing. Developers, whether for-profit companies or nonprofit organizations, want to put the housing for the elderly in or near residential neighborhoods so that occupants feel part of a community.
The projects, however, are not purely residential, and that is the problem. Like hotels, they rise higher than two stories and have dining rooms, laundry facilities and 24-hour staffing.
Opponents are quick to point out that they are not "anti-senior." Indeed, some of the most active foes of such proposals, like 72-year-old Malvin Gersfeld of Ardsley, in Westchester, are themselves retired and have the time to digest environmental impact statements the size of phone books.
"The idea of senior housing is great for those who can afford it," Mr. Gersfeld said. "But we don't want it because it will destroy what little green space we have left."
Mr. Gersfeld is leading the opposition to a proposed senior housing complex on 12 acres in Ardsley. The developer, Hassett Belfer Senior Housing of Great Neck, on Long Island, needs a zoning change for the project, which would offer three levels of care and charge a monthly rent. But the community's protests, plus a preliminary thumbs-down from the planning board, have sent the company back to the drafting table.
"We met with a lot of opposition, and we are resubmitting a new plan with fewer units and addressing the concerns," said Andrew B. Belfer, a partner in the development company.
Supporters of the plan outnumber opponents, Mayor Sam Abate of Ardsley said, but he fears they are growing anxious. "When I campaigned around the community, one of the comments I got from seniors was, 'Will it be built before I die?' " he said.
There are two main kinds of elderly projects under discussion in the county. Continuing-care retirement communities, which allow residents to progress, if necessary, from fully independent living to 24-hour skilled nursing care, were not allowed in the state until 1989. State officials had been concerned that elderly residents would be vulnerable to losing their life savings if developments failed.
The projects require a large initial fee of $200,000 to $600,000, depending on the size of the apartment, in addition to a hefty monthly rent. Typically, 90 percent of the entrance fee is returned to the estate when a resident dies.
Assisted-living developments, on the other hand, charge a large monthly rent with no down payment. The drawback is their lack of 24-hour medical care, and some residents eventually need to move to a nursing home.
In addition to concerns about the effect on neighborhoods, some opponents worry about repercussions for school districts, because elderly voters are commonly assumed to oppose school budgets. Another fear is whether the current rash of proposals could saturate the market for housing for the elderly.
"What are they going to put in there when they can't fill it?" asked Mr. Gersfeld, the Ardsley opponent. "Will it go to the state, which could use it to house people? And will the residents spending $3,000 to $4,000 a month stay there? I don't think so."
Developers counter that in Westchester, there is pent-up demand for the housing. "There's a huge supply of senior citizens in the county, and a lot of them happen to be affluent," said Michael D. Daly, president of Forest City Daly Housing in Manhattan.
Mr. Daly has discovered firsthand what an unwilling suitor Westchester can be. His company recently failed to get the town of Eastchester to rezone to allow a 125-unit project. He is now presenting his wares to Pelham, a village in southeastern Westchester. But resistance to his plan for a mix of what are known as independent and assisted apartments has grown so fierce that opponents controlled the nominating process at the Jan. 31 Democratic caucus, forcing the selection of a slate of Republicans to run under the Democratic banner in the village's March election.
Here in Hastings-on-Hudson, where there is a proposal to create a continuing-care retirement community called Andrus on Hudson on the grounds of an existing retirement home, the zoning implications of the plan have taken a complicated turn.
To avoid being accused of seeking a preferential zoning change specifically for its property, Beth Abraham Health Services, a nonprofit health-care network in the Bronx and a sponsor of the project, has asked the village to create a "floating zone" for senior housing that could, in theory, apply to three other parcels in the village.
That tactic has created a small furor, as village residents envision a glut of complexes. "People think we don't want any senior housing, and that is absolutely not the case," said Leslie Chervokas, 41, a chairwoman of the Hastings Community Coalition, an opposition group. "What we don't want are four of these very large facilities, because the residential character of the community can't sustain them."
Like other senior housing plans, Andrus on Hudson is geared toward elderly residents with deep pockets. The entrance fees would run from $209,000 to $665,000; monthly rents are expected to range from $1,995 to $4,550.
Those projects are affordable only to elderly people with household incomes of at least $50,000 a year. That includes fewer than 25 percent of the county's residents 65 and older.
But soaring real estate prices have allowed many older residents who never considered themselves wealthy to sell their homes at prices that make even projects like Andrus on Hudson affordable.
Ruth and Donald Dewey paid $30,000 for a house in 1965 that they recently sold for $400,000. "When we came here we never thought we could afford something like this," Mrs. Dewey said, referring to Andrus on Hudson, where she and her husband have already secured a future home with a $1,000 deposit.
She and her husband, a retired Columbia University economics professor, are excited about plans for an outdoor pool surrounded by gardens and the smart apartments with magnificent river views. But the main reason they want to live in a place like Andrus on Hudson, they say, is to avoid feeling like a nuisance.
"I cared for my mother and my mother-in-law, and I thought how nice it would be to decline without all these crises, without having to involve one's own children in crises," Mrs. Dewey said. "If I fall and break my hip, my daughter doesn't have to come from California and say, 'What on earth am I going to do with my mother?' "

HEADLINE: U.S. Supports Tightening Of Sanctions on Belgrade

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
In an effort to tighten pressure on the Yugoslav leader, Slobodan Milosevic, the Clinton administration said today that it supported a plan to expand some sanctions against Belgrade while allowing some commercial airline flights to resume.
The most effective sanction so far, according to many officials, has been the little-publicized tool of refusing travel visas to Mr. Milosevic's political and financial supporters. 
 Under the plan of tougher sanctions announced by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the number of associates of Mr. Milosevic officially barred from traveling to the United States and the nations of the European Union would be increased from the current 600, perhaps as much as 25 percent.
The administration also backed a plan, to be presented to the European Union's general affairs council in Brussels on Monday, to strengthen enforcement of a ban on banking transfers from Yugoslavia to European capitals, Dr. Albright said.
The secretary of state made the announcement at a joint appearance here with the British foreign secretary, Robin Cook.
In response to requests from the struggling opposition parties in Serbia, the ban on flights by airlines of European Union countries would be suspended for six months. If free and fair elections were not held in Yugoslavia within six months from the lifting of the ban, the concession on the airline flights would be "automatically" withdrawn, State Department officials said.
How to undermine Mr. Milosevic, who has been indicted by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague, while unifying the the squabbling factions of the opposition, has been a subject of considerable debate within the State Department.
Dr. Albright has let it be known in recent weeks that one of her most fervent hopes for the remainder of her term is to see the end of Mr. Milosevic's power.
A recent round of political killings in Belgrade has encouraged some administration officials to speculate that Mr. Milosevic's regime may implode. The Yugoslav defense minister, Pavle Bulatovic, was shot and killed on Monday as he was eating dinner in a Belgrade soccer club. Last month, the Serbian paramilitary leader and close associate of Mr. Milosevic, Zeljko Raznatovic, was shot dead eating dinner at the Intercontinental Hotel in Belgrade.
The cause of these killings and whether they were masterminded by Mr. Milosevic is still unclear. But what does seem clear is that the dominant black-market economy in Serbia and fights over who controls it are resulting in the increased tensions within ruling circles.
In that respect, officials said, the visa ban on close associates of Mr. Milosevic -- many of them accustomed to high living in European capitals and on checking up on their foreign investments -- has been most effective. Some of these associates appear to be complaining that Mr. Milosevic's rule is hurting rather than benefiting them.
By tightening the screws with the tougher travel ban, the administration hopes that further cracks will emerge in the Belgrade government.
For several months, the administration had rejected proposals by European countries to lift the ban on civilian airline flights to Belgrade. Such an easing would open the door to lifting other sanctions, administration officials argued.
But Dr. Albright said today that the airline flights would be permitted because they had been requested by the opposition parties. The secretary has met twice in recent months with leaders of the Serbian opposition, and her aides are in daily contact with them.
"Today we are making very clear that the sanctions are going to be targeted, expanded and tightened against those from the regime that are not allowing the people of Serbia to express their will," Dr. Albright said.
The European Union and the United States have comparable regulations banning bank transfers from Belgrade, but enforcement has been lax in Europe, the State Department said. The European Union had pledged to increase its staffing to monitor and stop such transactions, officials said.
But how effective these banking sanctions would be remained an open question. "It's like squeezing Jello," one official said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: EDUCATION;
Bradley Urges $80 Billion Plan to Improve Quality of Schools

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: UNIVERSITY CITY, Mo., Feb. 9

 BODY:
Declaring that the quality of education in America unfairly depended on the wealth of the district, former Senator Bill Bradley today unveiled an $80 billion education proposal that he said would improve the quality of teachers, hold schools accountable for student performance and give parents the safety valve of taking their children out of inferior public schools for better ones.
"I'm here today to say that we have separate and unequal when it comes to the quality of education in America," Mr. Bradley said at a school just 35 miles from where he grew up and attended public schools. "Education may be the great equalizer, but when schools are unequal -- when poor children get an inferior education to wealthy children, when minorities get a worse education than nonminorities -- we are often preparing them for a life of failure." 
 The former senator from New Jersey also criticized his opponent for the Democratic presidential nomination, Vice President Al Gore, for being part of an administration that Mr. Bradley said had increased the number of teachers without insuring that they were highly qualified.
Speaking before about 1,000 people at the University City High School gymnasium in this St. Louis suburb, Mr. Bradley proposed doubling the financing to $16 billion a year for Title I, the federal aid program for schools in poor communities. He said he would require teachers to pass a test in the subjects they teach or to have majored in that area. And he said he would triple federal money for charter schools, to $500 million.
Mr. Bradley has not focused on education with the fervor he has lavished on issues like health care, gun control and race relations.
Mr. Gore, speaking today at an early childhood center in Southfield, Mich., talked about his education proposals and faulted Mr. Bradley for not speaking out sooner about education. "There are sharp differences between his approach to education and mine," said Mr. Gore, who has outlined plans for universal pre-care, testing teachers, providing grants to train teachers and improving failing schools.
"Fourteen months have passed in this presidential campaign and three states have had elections," the vice president said, "and only today has Senator Bradley made his first speech" about education.
Mr. Bradley struck back at Mr. Gore in a news conference after his speech today.
"Once again, he's saying something that is not true," Mr. Bradley said. "It's defying reality to say that I haven't talked about education."
Instead, Mr. Bradley said, he had waited until now, as a crucial series of primaries on March 7 and 14 approaches, to tie elements of his education proposals together into one big package so that his ideas would be fresh on voters' minds.
"This is when the country is actually paying attention to what someone who's running for president would do," he said. "And I think it is an important part of reaching out to Democratic constituents and America to defining what this candidacy all about."
Indeed, Mr. Bradley promised that he would probably present more policy proposals about major issues of concern to Democratic voters.
He emphasized the need to improve race relations in speeches at a black church in Queens on Sunday, a town hall meeting in Tampa, Fla., on Monday and a predominantly black college in Columbia, S.C., on Tuesday. Along the way he criticized Mr. Gore; Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, a Republican, and the two leading Republican presidential candidates, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Senator John McCain of Arizona.
On Thursday, Mr. Bradley plans to talk to Los Angeles voters about gun violence. And on Friday, he will talk in Seattle about women's issues.
Today, as the backdrop for his speech on education, Mr. Bradley chose a racially and economically diverse school district that counts Tennessee Williams as its most famous son. The student body, however, is more than 80 percent black.
Mr. Bradley said the keystone to education was the quality of the nation's teachers, not class size or per-pupil spending, offering a different emphasis from that of the Clinton-Gore administration.
By requiring teachers to pass state-administered tests or to major in the subjects they teach, Mr. Bradley said, he would complement an earlier plan that would add 600,000 teachers over the next decade and offer to forgive student loans for college graduates who teach.
"Yes, I'll give schools that money, but I'll tell you, there are strings attached," he said. "I will hold those schools that receive federal money accountable for their results. And I expect them to show results."
 
In His Own Words
 
BILL BRADLEY
 
Remarks yesterday in a speech on education that he delivered in University City, Mo.:
 
"Fifty years, the Supreme Court ruled that separate but equal was unconstitutional when it came to race and education in America. I'm here today to say that we have separate and unequal when it comes to the quality of education in America.
 
A good education in America today is an American birthright. While millions of children are getting such an education, there are far too many children who are trapped in failing schools. Education may be the great equalizer, but when schools are unequal -- when poor children get an inferior education to wealthy children, when minorities get a worse education than nonminorities -- we are often preparing them for a life of failure. To me, that is unacceptable.
 
I believe there is nothing more important to education than a qualified teacher. Research shows that one of the strongest predictors of how students perform on national tests is not class size or per pupil spending, but the presence of a qualified teacher, a teacher who is fully certified and majored in the subject he or she taught. That is why I will require that schools that receive federal money will have to ensure that their teachers are fully qualified. 'Warm bodies' are just not good enough for our children, millions of who sit down every day in classrooms before teachers who do not meet the minimum requirements for teaching in a public school."

HEADLINE: Sid Abel, 81, a Hockey Star On a Famed Red Wings Line

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Sid Abel, the Hockey Hall of Famer who starred with the Detroit Red Wings and was later a coach, general manager and broadcaster in the National Hockey League, died Tuesday at a hospital in Farmington Hills, Mich. He was 81.
Abel won the Hart Trophy as the league's most valuable player in 1949 and for several seasons he centered Detroit's Production Line, with Gordie Howe on right wing and Ted Lindsay on left wing. 
 Inducted as a player into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1969, Abel knew the hockey business from many perspectives. As a player, he married the secretary to the Red Wings' general manager and later he was considered a "players' coach" who was sensitive to their moods and needs.
Although Abel's career lasted long into the modern era of expansion, his roots were in the old six-team league, when players traveled by train, salaries were low and grudges were well nursed.
"We played hockey for money, but we would play the Toronto Maple Leafs for nothing," he once said.
The Red Wings won the Stanley Cup three times when Abel played for them, with their most memorable championship coming in 1950, when they beat the Rangers.
In the first series of the two-round tournament, Detroit lost Howe when a collision with a Toronto player left him in the hospital with a life-threatening brain injury. In the final game of the finals, Abel, the captain, scored a goal in a game at Olympia Stadium that went into overtime tied at 3-3. The Red Wings won on a goal by Pete Babando.
Many hockey books include pictures of a weary, sweat-soaked Abel kissing the silver trophy that night.
Abel's Production Line got its name because it produced goals and because his team played in the Motor City, where the economy was based on cars produced on assembly lines.
Howe was known as Mr. Hockey, Lindsay was Terrible Ted and Abel was called Boot Nose because of an altercation with Montreal's Maurice (the Rocket) Richard. After Howe flattened Richard in a fight, Abel skated by and asked him, "How do you like that?" and added a reference to Richard's French-Canadian ethnicity. Richard responded by re-arranging Abel's nose with a punch.
Howe, reflecting on the fight, said: "Today, if you called someone what Sid called Rocket, you'd get called up before a judge."
"There was never any question about his leadership," Howe said. "Sid was very much respected."
In a playing career that spanned 12 seasons with the Red Wings and 2 with the Blackhawks, Abel scored 189 goals and had 283 assists during the regular season.
Sidney Gerald Abel was born on Feb. 22, 1918, in Melville, Saskatchewan, played as a junior for the Saskatoon Wesleys and the Flin Flon Bombers before turning professional with Detroit in the 1938-39 season. His career was interrupted for almost three seasons during World War II, when he served in the Royal Canadian Air Force.
He left Detroit in 1952 to play and coach for the Chicago Blackhawks. He returned to the Red Wings in 1957 as a coach, and added general manager's duties in 1962, but left the organization in 1971 and worked with teams in St. Louis and Kansas City.
Abel returned to Detroit as a broadcaster in 1976 and became popular for his insights and speech patterns. Speaking in a Western Canadian accent and verb forms, Abel would tell his Motor City listeners "Montreal are a skating club" or "Detroit are pressing on the power play."
Abel was blunt on the air and sometimes angered management with his tart observations. But fans admired his honesty even while mimicking his voice. For several seasons, when the Red Wings struggled in the early 1980's, Abel the broadcaster was more popular than any player.
His No. 12 was retired in 1995, hung between Howe's 9 and Lindsay's 7.
Before Tuesday night's Red Wings game at Joe Louis Arena, hours after his death, the fans stood for a moment of silence in memory of Abel, and the banner that bears his number was briefly lowered.
Abel is survived by his wife, Gloria; a son, Gerald; a daughter, Linda Johnson; a brother, Don; five grandchildren; and five great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Rowland Offers Tax Cuts and Tighter Investment Rules

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 9

 BODY:
Gov. John G. Rowland laid out a proposed $12.27 billion budget today for 2001 that includes substantial tax cuts and credits for Connecticut consumers, families and corporations, and fundamental changes to the state treasurer's office and county sheriffs' systems.
In his annual speech to the General Assembly, Mr. Rowland, a Republican, repeatedly praised Connecticut's continuing prosperity, saying, "it is hard to remember a more prosperous moment in the history of this state." But his budget message was founded on the expectation of a cooling state economy and projected declines in sales and income tax revenue in the next fiscal year. 
 So while Mr. Rowland's new budget proposal is 4.3 percent larger than last year's adopted budget and includes $237 million in tax cuts for education, gasoline and business, it is also $84 million below the state's constitutionally mandated limit on year-to-year spending increases.
"With Connecticut's growing economy, with the state budget producing another surplus for the sixth year in a row, it would be all too easy to go on a spending spree," Governor Rowland said in his 36-minute speech this afternoon. "Connecticut has pledged never to let that happen again," he added, referring to the law capping how much state budgets can increase year to year. "It falls on us to keep that promise."
Among the most debated tax cuts the governor proposed today was a 7-cent reduction, beginning April 1, in the state's 32-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax, the nation's highest. The governor said the reduction, to 25 cents, would save drivers $99 million a year. But state Democrats, who control both houses of the legislature, questioned whether such a move would end up helping gasoline wholesalers without reducing pump prices.
Other tax reductions Mr. Rowland proposed include the elimination of Connecticut's 4.5 percent gross receipts tax on hospitals, totaling $75 million annually, and a four-year phase-out of the state's inheritance tax, valued at $52 million.
Mr. Rowland also proposed eliminating the state's county-based sheriff's system, which has come under great criticism in recent years as a corrupt patronage mill. In its place, the governor would have corrections and court officers perform most of the duties deputy sheriffs have now, like serving legal papers and transporting prisoners.
And, like his Republican colleagues in the legislature, the governor called for the creation of a board of advisers to supervise how the state treasurer, currently a Democrat, invests the state's $21 billion pension fund.
That move is just one more indication that Mr. Rowland, for now, has successfully navigated his way through a corruption scandal that threatened his administration last year.
Last September, Paul J. Silvester, whom Mr. Rowland appointed treasurer in July 1997, pleaded guilty to money laundering and racketeering charges stemming from financial schemes he ran from his office. The scandal touched the governor, who has since called Mr. Silvester's appointment the worst mistake of his six-year term. Mr. Silvester is expected to be sentenced in March, and the investigation into his conduct continues.
"I think we've seen that in a positive economy, no scandal stays in the public mind very long," said David B. Pudlin, a Democrat and the majority leader of the state House of Representatives. In fact, Mr. Pudlin, who will offer a detailed bill next week to limit campaign spending and help finance campaigns with public money, said he was encouraged by Mr. Rowland's professed flexibility to consider "everything" to do with campaign finance reform this year.
Over all, Mr. Rowland's budget provides what was expected from a Republican governor of a prosperous state. It focused not on ambitious new spending proposals but instead on tax cuts and credits, including a plan to finance private school tuition with $17 million in tax credits.
After the address, Republicans and business leaders offered praise, particularly for the governor's plan to use much of this year's estimated $241 million surplus to pay down the state's $11.8 billion outstanding debt.
Kenneth Decko, the president of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said he was particularly pleased with proposed corporate-tax reductions totaling $21 million that would help Connecticut companies that sell their products outside the state. "We need to do this to keep our businesses healthy," Mr. Decko said.
Democratic legislators, conversely, signaled that they considered this budget proposal, while perhaps more detailed than they had expected, to be only the opening salvo in the legislature's 12-week session this year.
"A number of things that were proposed are really going to have to be changed if they're going to be passed," Mr. Pudlin said.
Mr. Sullivan criticized Mr. Rowland's vow, made during his speech, to spend the surplus, cut taxes and still stay under the spending cap next year.
"Our first look at it suggests you just can't move those kinds of numbers around and stay under the cap," Mr. Sullivan said after the governor's speech. Of Mr. Rowland's pledge to sign no budget over the cap, Mr. Sullivan added, "He's already signed two that bust the cap and he's proposed another that busts the cap."
The budget proposed today, while it offered relatively smaller increases in welfare-to-work programs to aid the poor, left some groups feeling excluded.
Daria M. Plummer, the president of the Connecticut Education Association, which represents 33,000 public-school teachers around the state, said she was dismayed at a private-school tax incentive that she called tantamount to a voucher system. "The children in the least wealthy homes don't even have a shot to earn these tax credits," she said.

HEADLINE: The High Price of Oil

 BODY:
Home heating prices in the Northeast, the region that relies primarily on oil to heat homes, have doubled over the past year. Indeed the residents of the Northeast have suffered a double blow. First OPEC, the consortium of oil-exporting countries, conspired last spring to cut production by millions of barrels a day. As a result, crude oil prices nearly tripled by December and gasoline prices rose by over 30 percent during the past year. Then a cold wave struck last month, drawing down inventories of home heating oil and sending its price soaring. Residents are demanding relief from Congress, but it is already too late to push down heating bills before spring.
Last September Senator Charles Schumer of New York, anticipating the impact of the OPEC cutbacks, called on the administration to release oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, almost 600 million barrels of oil stored in salt domes in Texas and Louisiana. The administration has balked at using the reserve because it is designed to soften the blow of another oil embargo or similar energy crisis, not to control market prices. Using it to offset temporary price increases can discourage conservation and run down reserves that will be needed in any future crisis. Legislation sponsored by Mr. Schumer to tap the reserve has gone nowhere. 
 In any case, the reserve cannot provide immediate relief because it takes at least several weeks to get oil out of the salt domes and into people's homes. If the reserve were tapped starting now, the oil would not arrive in the Northeast until the crocuses start to bloom, heating needs fall and home heating prices drop on their own.
Yet there is still good reason to open up the reserve today, though not in the way Mr. Schumer originally proposed. OPEC cutbacks have driven worldwide inventories down to dangerously low levels. That could send gasoline prices rising this summer. Worse, by next winter a combination of low inventories and cold weather could send crude oil prices to $40 a barrel, about twice the normal price of crude over the past several years.
The way to handle this problem is to open the reserve for "swaps" rather than sales for cash. The administration is reviewing the idea and is expected to make a decision soon. Under a system of swaps, a company would take oil out of the reserve and sell it at current prices. The extra oil on the market would help drive prices down. Later the company would return a somewhat larger amount of oil to the reserve. The incentive for the companies is that they would earn a profit from selling the reserve oil at today's high prices and replacing it later with cheaper oil bought when prices almost certainly will have fallen. Swaps could not only knock the edge off oil prices but, unlike outright sales, fill the reserve above its current level. Philip Verleger, an energy economist, estimates that swaps could reduce crude oil prices by $3 or $4 a barrel, a fall of more than 10 percent.
A virtue of swaps is that they could be made a permanent feature of the reserve. The administration would let companies withdraw oil at any time as long as they return it and additional oil at a predetermined date in the future. That would eliminate the need for jockeying that comes every time politicians are asked to open up the reserve for this or that episode of high oil prices. Had swaps been permanently in place when Mr. Schumer, who supports their use, first called on the administration to act, Northeastern homeowners would already be reaping the benefit. If a system of swaps is put in place today, they will be there in time for this summer's possible run on gasoline stocks or a run on heating oil over the winter.
Oil has already entered campaign debates. Bill Bradley has embraced the idea of swaps, and George W. Bush has called for the administration to pressure Saudi Arabia to ramp up OPEC production levels. Both ideas make sense. Pressuring Saudi Arabia is a way to get OPEC's production rates higher. Though the tactic has often failed in the past, the Saudis may be more receptive this time. By driving oil inventories to near zero, Saudi Arabia has inadvertently put Iraq, which could produce much more oil than it now does, into a powerful position. Next winter Iraq could well demand that the United Nations lift sanctions on its oil exports in return for added production. The Saudis might want to reconsider decisions they have made that have put their archenemy in control.
