HEADLINE: In Welfare-to-Work Dispute, Giuliani Seeks to Limit Hevesi's Power

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Escalating the feud over $500 million in welfare-to-work contracts, the Giuliani administration is pushing to severely restrict the city comptroller's power to review and approve municipal contracts, which now total $7 billion a year.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has asked his three appointees to the city's five-member contract policy board to rescind city policies that require Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi to be given detailed documents and enough time to determine if bidders have been treated equitably. Mr. Hevesi appoints the two other board members. 
 Mr. Giuliani's maneuver occurred after the comptroller rejected three contracts that the city had awarded to organizations hired to help people on welfare find work. Mr. Hevesi found that the mayor improperly applied a provision that allows an administration to limit competition on certain contracts.
The mayor said yesterday that his effort to change the policies was unrelated to the welfare dispute and that he was merely reasserting his long-held belief that Mr. Hevesi routinely oversteps his authority. Mr. Hevesi and City Council leaders vowed to block the mayor's initiative, which they said threatened to disrupt the delicate balance of power in New York City government.
"Last week I said even the mayor is not above the law," Mr. Hevesi said. "Now the mayor has attempted to change the law and destroy this checks-and-balances system. And that is wrong, and we are going to fight him on it."
The Giuliani administration's proposal was scheduled to be voted on by the contract policy board this morning, but the mayor announced yesterday afternoon that it had been taken off the agenda. The mayor, however, said he would continue to push the matter.
The jockeying came as new questions were being raised about one of the Giuliani administration's recently awarded contracts. The City Department of Employment has hired a job-training company run by two former executives of Blake Business School, a trade school in the city that closed in 1997 after investigators determined it had misled students and defrauded the state.
New York Works Training Center, the company run by the former Blake executives, started training unemployed city residents last July, even though the state five months earlier denied New York Works' application for a private school license, citing misleading statements in its application forms and improper business practices at the 1-year-old company. The company, on West 29th Street, maintains that it has obtained the proper state license for training security guards.
City Council members and Mr. Hevesi, whose office still has not approved the $174,000 New York Works contract, said the episode illustrated the need for a thorough and independent review of city contracts.
Late yesterday, Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota said the city could not dispute the questions raised about New York Works.
In the last six years, Mr. Hevesi noted, he has objected on grounds ranging from fraud to tax delinquency to 347 contracts worth a total of $1 billion submitted by the mayor. In $220 million worth of those deals, the contracts were never submitted again, Mr. Hevesi said.
"If you have complete control over who gets contracts," said Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, chairwoman of the Council's Contracts Committee, "you can use that to prop up your own office, meaning everything from kickbacks to campaign contributions to getting your unemployed brother-in-law a job. I am not saying this mayor is doing that. But that is why you have these checks."
Currently, the 30-day period required by the City Charter for the comptroller's review begins only after the contract and the documentation justifying its award have been submitted. Under the new policy, the clock would start as soon as the contract is submitted, meaning that the city could withhold details explaining why one bidder was picked over another until the end of the 30-day period, Mr. Hevesi said.
Another policy change would remove a requirement that city agencies respond quickly to the comptroller's questions. Two other revisions would eliminate a requirement for a written recommendation that would explain to the comptroller why a city agency selected a particular bidder for a new contract or a contract renewal.
On Feb. 3, the day after Mr. Hevesi rejected the three welfare-to-work contracts on the ground that they were not properly bid, the Giuliani administration proposed that the five-member Procurement Policy Board begin the process of making these revisions.
"The mayor is furthering the welfare-to-work scandal rather than taking steps to stop it," said Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, who has been highly critical of the contracts. "To change these rules is outrageous. This is not a dictatorship. It is a democracy."
The Giuliani administration officials emphasized yesterday that it had previously proposed scaling back the comptroller's contract review, which they said at times unnecessarily delayed mayoral initiatives.
The proposed changes had been on the Procurement Policy Board's agenda for today. But after Mr. Hevesi held a news conference denouncing the changes, Mr. Giuliani announced yesterday afternoon that although he was still advocating the revisions, they would not be considered by the board today. Instead, the Procurement Policy Board today will address the welfare contract dispute, he said. "If the welfare contracts are approved, we still are going to press forward with a redefinition of the power of the mayor and the comptroller," Mr. Giuliani said. "If the welfare contracts somehow don't go through, we still are going to press forward."
While Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Giuliani disagreed yesterday over when and why the mayor had decided to temporarily put off his push for the contract review policy changes, aides for the two agreed that something appeared awry with the job-training bid submitted by New York Works Training Center.
The company, which listed Carlos Alvarado as its executive director and owner in its application to the city, offered to train adults 55 years old and older on how to become security guards and other types of safety officers, at a cost of up to $2,200 for each person trained and placed in a job. But the documentation submitted by New York Works cited as a reference a security company that the New York Department of State said it had no licensing records for. And the contract application did not disclose the link between New York Works and Blake Business School.
Herbert Marion, who is listed in state documents as the former owner and administrator of Blake Business School, acknowledged yesterday in an interview that he financed the start-up of New York Works and worked at Blake. He said, however, that he owned neither Blake nor New York Works. Mr. Alvarado also did not disclose in city documents that he is a former director of admissions at Blake Business School.
The school, which had branches at Union Square and Cooper Square, closed after state investigators concluded it had inappropriately received more than $1.5 million in tuition assistance and had used "false, misleading, deceptive and fraudulent bait-and-switch advertising as a means to procure, solicit and enroll students," according to a 1996 New York State Education Department complaint.
More recently, the state rejected a request by Mr. Alvarado and Mr. Marion for a private school license for New York Works, on the ground that the company had tried to hide Mr. Marion's connection with it, according to state documents. New York Works was selected as one of the winning bidders by the city for the job training contract last year, and Mr. Marion said yesterday that it had provided training to about 55 city-referred clients. But given that the contract has not yet been approved by the comptroller's office, the company has not been paid.
Mr. Alvarado and Mr. Marion yesterday rejected any suggestion of wrongdoing, saying only that they were legitimately operating a security guard training company. But Mr. Lhota, the deputy mayor, said that if the comptroller's findings regarding New York Works are accurate, the company will never be paid.
"I concur," Mr. Lhota said yesterday of the comptroller's findings, which came after a detailed review of the city's selection of the winning job-training contractors. "As far as I am concerned, we have no contract with New York Works and we will never do business with them."

HEADLINE: The Strength of theInternet Proves to Be Its Weakness

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The Internet's greatest strength has proved to be its most disturbing weakness.
As attackers let loose a barrage of data that overwhelmed some major commercial Internet sites for a third day, the global network's administrators scrambled today to find a way to protect it and trace the culprits. 
 But the network's designers acknowledged that the attacks exploited the same attributes of the Internet that have made it one of the world's most effective engines for commercial and technical innovation over the last five years.
"This is a fundamental consequence of an open system," said Lawrence Lessig, a Harvard law professor who has written on the Internet's social and legal aspects.
Unlike recent episodes in which Web sites were defaced or credit card records were taken from an online music retailer, this week's attacks have not involved stolen or altered data. But in a world of growing dependence on the Internet, even being denied access to an Internet web site like E*Trade can have an economic impact.
Indeed, longtime Internet executives muse about potential technical disasters in an increasingly interconnected world. What has been seen so far is not the Net's Armageddon, they say, but only an alert.
"There are nightmare scenarios that are real, but that's not where we are," said David Clark, an M.I.T. professor who was one of the Internet's original designers.
Even so, finding ways to contain anti-social acts in such a system -- one that by its very design permits anonymous behavior -- without compromising its openness is proving increasingly thorny for network designers, law enforcement officials and civil libertarians.
"We have run into a situation where the attackers are coordinated and organized but the people who have to respond -- both companies, Internet service providers, and most particularly law enforcement agencies -- are fragmented," said Mark Rasch, a former federal prosecutor who is now a vice president at Global Integrity, a computer security consulting firm based in Reston, Va.
This week's attacks have exploited a set of software programs developed over the last year, computer security experts said today. Known variously as Tribe Flood Network, Trin00 and Stacheldraht (German for "barbed wire"), the programs first identify individual computers on the Internet with specific security flaws, then use those computers as launching pads for an orchestrated attack.
Like the sorcerer's apprentice, the programs let a small group or even an individual pour buckets of data at one or many targets, inundating a Web site's computers with data.
Moreover, it is not easy to identify the person carrying the bucket. In some cases, the malicious programs systematically falsify the network addresses from which the data is sent.
But while the consequences of these programs are harmful, it is just this kind of novel intervention that the Internet was designed to make possible.
In the early 1980's, Mr. Clark and two other M.I.T. computer network researchers, Jerry Salzer and David P. Reed, first described one of the Internet's most powerful aspects: it was a simple network -- or even a "stupid" one, as it was later described by David Isenberg, then an A.T.& T. Bell Labs researcher -- in contrast to the more centralized, or "intelligent," and tightly controlled telephone network.
The very simplicity of the Internet, they wrote, made it a platform for innovation in ways that a more centralized and tightly controlled network could never become.
In the last decade the Internet has served as a virtual petri dish for new ideas -- from low-cost communications systems that have redefined telephone, radio and television, to business methods that have remade industries like stock trading, auctions and bookselling.
But that same power for innovation can be redirected upon the data network in a way that makes it remarkably resilient but extremely vulnerable.
"If an owner of a specific network wants to add some kind of cool feature it doesn't matter in an internetworked world," said Mr. Isenberg. Because there is no central point of control, as on other networks, "you have the control way out on the edges, and anyone can do anything," he added.
Other Internet pioneers are concerned that incidents like this week's attacks may lead to increasing calls for government and law enforcement intervention into the structure of the Internet.
Last July, for example, the Clinton administration began circulating a plan for an extensive software system monitoring government computers, and possibly those of private industry, to protect data networks from intruders.
The network, known as the Federal Intrusion Detection Network, or Fidnet, alarmed civil libertarians who said it could be used to curtail privacy in the Internet age.
"The real danger of any terrorism is not so much in the act itself as the overreaction," said Robert Frankston, a computer researcher who is the co-inventor of the spreadsheet. "The Internet has enabled rapid economic growth because it has made it difficult to prevent disruptive innovation."
And he suggested that the Internet becomes more secure as it experiences attacks and its administrators reconfigure it to repel invaders -- "just as our immune system is strengthened by exposure to disease."
In any case, some longtime law enforcement officials said that there was no simple centralized solution to these kinds of attack.
"The problem is that if you're smart about this there is no trail for law enforcement to follow," said Scott Charney, who until recently was the Justice Department's top computer crime official and who is now a partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers. "There are obvious privacy implications. The real question is how strong a response do you want."
The best response, several computer security experts said, would be to strengthen the security of individual computers on the Internet. That would make it more difficult for the automated programs that now take over many systems to find systems to exploit.

Chart: "How the Sites Were Besieged"
The attacks that overwhelmed several big Internet sites in the last few days used a method called distributed denial of service.
 
THE ATTACKER
The attacker uses a computer to find other computers on the Internet that are not protected from attack.
 
THE NETWORK
The attacker gets access to those computers. They in turn are used to carry out the attack or to control a second group of computers that attack.
 
THE ASSAULT
A Web site can be brought to a standstill in two ways. The attacker may send data to the site and ask for confirmation. Because the attacker is using many computers, the requests can overload the system. Or, data may be sent that the site's computers cannot understand, causing them to crash. (Source: Computer Emergency Response Team)(pg. C6)

HEADLINE: In Britain's Health Service, Sick Itself, Cancer Care Is Dismal

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL 

DATELINE: MIDDLESBOROUGH, England

 BODY:
Jackie O'Donnell's oncologist couldn't have been more clear about her prospects.
Suffering from advanced ovarian cancer, with five inoperable tumors after surgery, Mrs. O'Donnell urgently needed aggressive chemotherapy. But, the doctor explained, her local health authority would not pay for the treatment he was recommending, a drug that can prolong life for a year or more and is routinely used in the United States, Europe and some parts of Britain. If Mrs. O'Donnell wanted it, it would not be free, as most treatments are in the government-financed National Health Service, but would cost her $16,000. 
 "I just didn't believe it, because in this country we were brought up to believe that we would get the best treatment available," said Mrs. O'Donnell, now 55. She chose her life over her budget, put the bills in a drawer when she could not pay them, and has been in remission since last spring. "It's hard, when it stares you in the face that what you thought was really all nonsense."
In a country where cancer care horror stories are as common as the winter flu, Mrs. O'Donnell's is striking only because it is so familiar. Doctors, health-care advocates and even the government say that Britain's record on cancer, the country's second biggest killer after cardiovascular disease, is nothing short of disgraceful, a stark example of the limitations of Britain's fraying system of socialized medicine.
Problems in the health service, advocates and doctors say, are so pervasive that literally billions of dollars directed specifically at cancer are needed. But cancer is not the only disease making demands on a system struggling to cope with rising patient expectations and increasingly stretched resources.
Health care has already become one of the major political headaches confronting Prime Minister Tony Blair, who is debating whether to increase the government's health spending and, if so, by how much.
In cancer, the problems include a chronic lack of money, specialists and cancer treatment centers; a lack of national standards that means that treatment is available in some parts of the country but not others; and a tendency at times to postpone aggressive treatment until it becomes too late.
Cancer programs are so underfinanced and chaotically managed, the World Health Organization says, that 25,000 people die unnecessarily of cancer in Britain each year -- people who would most likely have survived if they lived in countries with better standards of treatment, like France, Germany or the United States.
"The phrase 'third world cancer care' has hung heavy over the National Health Service for years," Gordon McVie, director general of the Cancer Research Campaign, one of Britain's largest cancer charities, wrote recently in The Daily Mail. "Today it is no longer a sound bite; it describes a reality."
The problems in the overstretched National Health Service are not limited to cancer. It is hard to pick up a newspaper these days without seeing signs of a system in trouble. A critically ill patient is shunted from place to place in a desperate 100-mile search for an intensive-care bed, and finally dies in the ambulance. A new study shows that 500 patients die a year while on the national waiting list for heart operations.
In a particularly grim instance, a 73-year-old woman with advanced esophageal cancer has the misfortune of being scheduled for surgery in mid-December, when operations are routinely canceled to make way for emergency patients suffering from pneumonia and the like.
The operation on the woman, Mavis Skeet, was scheduled, and canceled, four times over the next five weeks: first because the anesthesiologist had the flu, and the next three times because no intensive care beds were available. After the fourth cancellation, an ultrasound scan showed that the tumor had spread and was now inoperable.
Mrs. Skeet is now in a hospital, being fed through a stomach tube and receiving chemotherapy, waiting for the inevitable, her daughter, Jane, said in an interview. "They haven't given us a timetable, but it's spread so quickly in five weeks that anybody can work it out," she said.
Experts say that in a system with some successes -- the infant mortality rates in Britain are lower than those in the United States, for instance -- there are few areas where the situation is so demonstrably bad as it is in cancer. "The health service has been chronically underfunded in the last 10 or 15 years and is desperately short of money, and I'm not aware of where things are any worse than in cancer," said Dr. Tim Maughan, a clinical oncologist specializing in gastrointestinal cancer and lymphoma at Velindre Hospital in Cardiff, Wales.
According to the most recent studies, a British man with lung cancer has a 6 percent chance of surviving for five years after treatment, compared with a 12 percent chance in France and a 13 percent chance in the United States. For colon cancer in men, the five-year survival rates are 41 percent in Britain, 59 percent in the Netherlands, and 64 percent in the United States.
And for breast cancer in women, the figures are 67 percent in Britain, 72 percent in Germany, and 84 percent in the United States.
Even the relentlessly optimistic government of Mr. Blair has begun, however reluctantly, to acknowledge that its cancer care is, in fact, bad. Last summer, Mr. Blair pledged to try to reduce the death rate from cancer for people under 75 by 20 percent in the next 10 years, saving 100,000 lives.
It is unclear exactly how he plans to do this, short of injecting billions more dollars into the system or changing the way it is financed. Britain currently spends 55.7 billion -- about $89 billion -- a year on health care, or 6.8 percent of its gross domestic product -- nearly all of it public money. There is little political will in Britain to move to a more cash-rich European or American-based model. Germany spends about 10.7 percent of its gross domestic product on health care, and the United States, about 14 percent.
In a recent television interview, Mr. Blair appeared to promise that Britain would bring its health spending up the European levels by 2006, but when Treasury officials calculated that that would cost perhaps an extra 12 billion a year, money that would have to come out of roads and schools, the promise was hastily downgraded to an "aspiration." Mr. Blair has already made an extra 21 billion available to the health service over three years, but much of that is being taken up by steep salary increases for workers.
The problems in cancer care start at diagnosis. The National Health Service is set up so that no patient can see a specialist without first visiting his local general practitioner. But many Britons never visit their doctor until their symptoms become alarming, by which time their cancer might be advanced. And they are culturally inclined not to demand things that Americans take for granted, like regular physicals.
The next problems are an aging network of radiotherapy and other equipment, which health-care advocates say would cost hundreds of millions of pounds to replace, and a severe shortage of cancer centers and doctors. With about 600 cancer specialists serving a population of 59 million, the average British cancer consultant sees 550 patients a year -- and in some cases sees as many as 1,000 -- compared with 250 in France or Germany.
"Britain has about half the number of cancer specialists it needs," said Karol Sikora, the vice president in clinical research for oncology at Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. and the former chief of the World Health Organization's cancer program. To reach European levels, he said, Britain would have to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to hire, train and support new cancer doctors.
Once cancer is diagnosed, care can vary significantly. The health service is divided into about 115 local health authorities, each of which receives a fixed sum from the central government and decides independently how to spend it. That is why some authorities will pay for drugs that others won't.
"You end up with a situation where if you live on one side of the street, you may be eligible for expensive anticancer treatment, and if you live on the other side, you aren't," said Dr. David Secher, director of drug development for the Cancer Research Campaign.
Specialists say that the worst aspect of their job is having to tell patients that the system will not pay for the drugs they need -- drugs that, in some cases, have been developed in British laboratories.
In Birmingham, Prof. David J. Kerr, a specialist in colorectal cancer at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital, spends much of his time begging various health authorities to let him administer the cancer drug Camptosar, or irinotecan, which costs less than $10,000 for a course of treatment and can prolong life by three or more months. The drug is available in some parts of England, but not necessarily where his patients live.
"For these patients, sometimes the drug increases their life expectancy by 100 percent," he said. "That might be an anniversary reached, or a first child born."
Before Christmas, Professor Kerr said, he asked the health authority to provide irinotecan, or Camptosar, to a 39-year-old woman with three small children who has advanced colorectal cancer and a life expectancy of six months. The authority balked. "The patient asked me, 'Aren't my life and children worth a few thousand pounds?' " he said.
Last year, the government created a group charged with recommending whether cancer drugs like Taxol and Camptosar, and those that treat illnesses other than cancer, should be used nationwide. But the panel has not yet issued recommendations on any cancer drugs. And when it does -- it is expected to recommend Taxol, for instance -- this will be good news for some cancer sufferers, but bad news for other patients.
"Every time there is the prospect of a new and effective drug that's going to help people suffering from cancer," said Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the N.H.S. Confederation, an advocacy group for health authorities and hospitals, "my colleagues running health authorities are going to have to think, 'What are we going to stop doing in order to pay for that drug?' "
What is to be done? Many health-care experts argue that if the government is not willing to raise taxes, then it should allow more private money into the system, perhaps introducing nominal charges for visits to the doctor, for instance. Under one scenario, Britain would move closer to an American-style model, where richer people would buy insurance and poorer people would have their bills paid for by the government.
But Britain is wedded to a National Health Service financed by taxation, and any tampering with it would touch off a heavy political fight.
And few British experts are persuaded that the United States is anything to emulate when it comes to health care. "America doesn't deliver much bang to the buck," said Dr. Anna Donald, a clinical lecturer in health policy at University College, London. "There are definite problems in the U.K. but over all the health system works reasonably well on a shoestring."
Mr. Thornton, who heads the advocacy group, is not so sure.
"If we are to attempt to meet the demands and the expectations that people seem to have at the moment of a publicly funded health care system, then we need a substantial increase in money," he said. "Some would say it is one of the cheapest services that provides the best value for money. But that's debatable. It may be that we're just providing cheapness."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE END;
Forbes Spent Millions, but for Little Gain

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Steve Forbes's withdrawal from the presidential race -- after having spent $69 million of his own money on two runs for the White House -- was heartbreakingly clear in a photo on his campaign Web site yesterday.
With snowflakes falling and his aides at his sides, Mr. Forbes is shown gamely walking through the cold. The caption says that Mr. Forbes "has canceled all of his previously scheduled" events for the day. 
 So ends one of the most expensive personal odysseys for the presidency. Mr. Forbes spent around $32 million of his own money in this campaign -- on top of $37.4 million he spent on his failed 1996 effort. His current spending, along with some $5 million he received in donations in this campaign, gained him 2 to 19 Republican delegates and no primary victories.
Mr. Forbes's spending puts him almost on a par with Ross Perot, the Texas businessman who spent almost $71 million on his 1992 and 1996 Reform Party bids. And, on a per delegate basis, it brings him into competition with John C. Connally, the former governor of Texaswho raised $13.7 million in 1980 on his failed Republican effort and won only a single convention delegate.
As Mr. Forbes returned to his New Jersey home yesterday, his aides were scrambling to cancel the 14 live radio appearances and the three television interviews his campaign had set up for the day. After midnight yesterday, just after he came in third in Tuesday's Delaware primary, Mr. Forbes had met with his closest campaign adviser, William Dal Col, and the two decided to end Mr. Forbes's second presidential bid.
"It was very straightforward," Mr. Dal Col said in an interview yesterday. "We realized it was time to go. We talked last night and we basically discussed how to get from here to there. And the answer was that there wasn't really an opportunity in light of Delaware. It was hard to see how we could put it together to get the nomination and, if not, it was time to leave the race.
"So we did," said Mr. Dal Col.
With that, Mr. Forbes halted a quest for the presidency that began in 1996, when he first challenged Bob Dole for the nomination, and ended in Delaware, where Mr. Forbes's 20 percent showing in a state primary he had won in 1996 gained him no delegates to the Republican convention and illustrated how his campaign had begun to falter. His last days in Delaware were spent on a four-day bus tour talking to high school students, too young to vote, and holding events like an impromptu visit to a bakery where fewer than two dozen people greeted him.
Mr. Forbes's campaign began to unravel after having scored a strong showing in January in the Iowa caucuses, where he came in second to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. But Senator John McCain of Arizona was not running in Iowa, making that an easy race. In the tougher New Hampshire primary, Mr. Forbes was unable to capitalize on that success and he took only 13 percent of the vote, just a single point above his 1996 showing there and far behind Mr. McCain, who won the race, or Mr. Bush, who came in second.
And polls were already beginning to show that Mr. Forbes was still stuck in the single digit range in important coming primary states like Michigan and South Carolina.
In the analysis of why Mr. Forbes's effort failed, both those inside the Forbes campaign and Republican observers say Mr. Forbes's anti-tax, anti-abortion message may have been too abstract and too issue-oriented at a time when polls say that voters are looking more at a candidate's personal character than his exact message. In response to the Clinton White House scandals, polls show that voters are interested in tales of character-building and the perception that their candidate could beat the Democratic nominee.
Moreover, in a robust economy, voters are less interested in issues of drastic changes in the tax code than in the character of the next person in the White House. Even Mr. Forbes, in an interview yesterday with NBC News, his only one of the day, acknowledged as much: "While I did have a strong message, I did not want to have the fate of the messenger get in the way of the message."
The Forbes campaign agreed. "While a lot of people may have liked our message, it didn't translate into votes," Mr. Dal Col said. "You have a healthy economy and not the anger you had in 1992 and 1996. With the Clinton White House, issues of morality and character were important. This became a race more about biography and character, and Steve's strength is as an issue candidate. Voters were not looking at Steve as the type of person they wanted as president at this time."
Mr. Dal Col said it was hard for Mr. Forbes, the son of a millionaire publisher, to compete with the war record of Mr. McCain and the legacy of the Bush family. "If it was a biography fight," Mr. Dal Col said, "we couldn't win."
Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist and Washington lobbyist, said: "Fairly or unfairly, Steve does not come across as presidential. It's hard for the public to envision him in the Oval Office. He's smart and has lots of ideas, but doesn't fit the role."
For starters, Mr. Forbes has never held office. In his career he has had only one boss, his late father Malcolm, from whom he inherited a publishing empire that forms the basis of his $440 million net worth. Also his conservative message evolved very little, while his rivals adopted many of Mr. Forbes's anti-tax themes, drawing votes away.
Rich Galen, a Republican strategist, said that Mr. Forbes's anti-tax message was "so old it was growing whiskers." Many of the conservative voters that Mr. Forbes had targeted, Mr. Galen said, felt Mr. Bush reflected their views and had a better chance of winning the White House.
It appeared that Mr. Forbes had ruled out running for the United States Senate in New Jersey. "He flat out has no interest in the Senate whatsoever," Mr. Dal Col said.

HEADLINE: White House Raises Expected Cost of Medicare Drug Plan

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9

 BODY:
The White House now says President Clinton's proposal to provide Medicare coverage of prescription drugs will cost 35 percent more than it estimated just seven months ago.
In late June, when Mr. Clinton unveiled his plan to offer drug coverage to all Medicare beneficiaries, he said it would cost $118 billion over 10 years. In his new budget request to Congress this week, he put the cost at $160 billion. 
 While Mr. Clinton's basic proposal has not changed, the White House estimate of its cost has shot up. White House officials said today that they had revised their estimate to reflect several factors, including a realization that the use of prescription drugs by the elderly and the prices of new drugs were rising faster than they first assumed.
The rapid increases in drug spending help explain why millions of elderly Americans want government help with the costs and why some members of Congress are apprehensive about establishing new drug benefits. Critics of the Clinton proposal said that the first White House numbers were too low and that the revisions showed that the government must move carefully in designing Medicare drug benefits.
Asked why the cost estimates had increased, Chris Jennings, the health policy coordinator at the White House, said today: "We've had another year of experience, during which drug utilization and costs have increased. We included that experience in our new projections."
In addition, Mr. Jennings said, the administration's earlier estimates did not adequately account for the cost of providing drug benefits to Medicare patients in nursing homes.
After Mr. Clinton offered his proposal last summer, the Congressional Budget Office said he had grossly underestimated the costs. At a Senate hearing in July, Dan L. Crippen, director of the budget office, testified that Mr. Clinton's plan would cost $168 billion over 10 years.
Beyond the basic Medicare drug benefit that Mr. Clinton proposed last year, he is now asking Congress to set aside $35 billion to help protect Medicare beneficiaries with extremely high drug costs in the years 2006 to 2010. Mr. Clinton did not say exactly who would be eligible.
The change in the White House cost estimates underlines the difficulty of predicting the course of drug spending at a time when scientists are continually developing new drugs to prevent and treat disease and improve the quality of life. Economists have developed rules of thumb to predict how small changes in variables like economic growth and unemployment will affect federal spending and revenue. But they say they have no reliable models to predict drug spending.
Two members of the Senate Budget Committee -- Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, and Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon -- said today that they would seek money for Medicare drug benefits as part of the budget blueprint for the coming year.
Their approach is different from Mr. Clinton's: it would offer consumers a wide range of private insurance policies to cover drug costs. The government would offer to pay at least 25 percent of the premiums for insurance covering the drug costs of any Medicare beneficiary, with larger subsidies for lower-income people.
Ms. Snowe and Mr. Wyden said they had been working closely with the White House and Senate Republican leaders. They described their proposal as a middle ground between the Clinton plan and more conservative schemes.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, the ranking Democrat on the Finance Committee, which has authority over Medicare, has endorsed the approach proposed by Ms. Snowe and Mr. Wyden.
Senators Snowe and Wyden said Congress should authorize Medicare drug benefits this year, even if lawmakers could not agree on a comprehensive overhaul of the entire Medicare program. In addition, they said, senators generally agree that the federal government -- specifically, the Health Care Financing Administration -- should have little or no direct role in operation of the drug insurance program.
Charles N. Kahn III, president of the Health Insurance Association of America, said few insurance companies would want to offer free-standing policies to cover drug costs.
"It would be like providing insurance for haircuts," because so many elderly people need prescription drugs, Mr. Kahn said.
But Senator Snowe said she believed that some insurers would offer drug coverage to Medicare beneficiaries with the federal subsidies envisioned in her bill.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
A Sidewalk Soapbox Assails Braves' Rocker

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Commissioner Bud Selig, who suspended John Rocker for all of spring training and the first four weeks of the season, was the first and chief witness at the hearing on the pitcher's appeal of the suspension yesterday, but what went on outside the hearing room said at least as much about the controversy Rocker has stirred as the testimony inside.
Rocker's presence at the commissioner's office on Park Avenue in New York prompted curious and critical onlookers and a series of signs protesting Rocker's remarks that denigrated foreigners, gays and some minorities. That the Atlanta Braves closer was back in the city where his problems began last fall during the Braves' games with the Mets only added to the unusual atmosphere surrounding the day's events. 
 "Go back to Atlanta, you rat," one sign read.
Said another: "New York immigrants against Rocker."
Selig, who testified for nearly six hours on the first day of the grievance hearing before the arbitrator, Shyam Das, disclosed afterward that he had met privately with Rocker yesterday. He declined, however, to discuss their conversation.
"Anything that was said will remain private," said Selig, who headed back to Milwaukee immediately after completing his testimony.
Following Selig on the witness stand yesterday were Derrick Boazman, an Atlanta city councilman, and Stan Kasten, the Braves' president. The hearing is expected to be completed today. Kevin Hallinan, baseball's chief security executive, will be Major League Baseball's final witness. When the players association presents its case, Rocker will be one of the witnesses.
Although the union appealed the suspension, management presented its case first because, under the collective bargaining agreement, the burden of proof falls on the person imposing disciplinary action.
Selig issued his penalty, which also included a $20,000 fine, on Jan. 31, after hearing the outcry over Rocker's remarks in a magazine article in December. The players association appealed the suspension on Rocker's behalf the next day, contending that the suspension was excessive.
"They do have the right to appeal," Selig said after his testimony, speaking with reporters outside the building that houses the baseball offices. "That's his right under our process. He has strong feelings on the matter and so do I. Other commissioners have had to go through this process. I did what I thought I had to do. I'm very comfortable with what I did. The matter is now in the hands of the arbitrator."
Rocker said little. "Just be patient," he told reporters. "You'll find out later."
When he arrived for the hearing, Rocker was greeted by a round of boos from a group of Bear Stearns employees who were outside taking a mid-morning smoking break.
A group of Bear Stearns mail-room workers appeared with hastily made signs on brown packing paper that read, "Go back home, Rocker."
"John Rocker is a rat; this symbolizes Rocker," said Matt Reischl, a labor organizer from Local 78, which represents asbestos, lead and hazardous waste laborers. He was manning a 12-foot tall inflated rat he had set up along the sidewalk in front of the building. "We don't appreciate the statements he made about immigrants. Our union consists mostly of immigrants."
Reischl, 24, of Salzburg, Austria, said the local membership was primarily divided between Spanish-speaking and Polish immigrants.
Workers from nearby buildings ignored the cold weather to linger outside 245 Park Avenue in anticipation of getting a glimpse of Rocker, who took an instant dislike to Mets fans when the Braves played at Shea Stadium. His comments and feelings about the fans fueled his larger verbal attack that he extended to many other segments of society in an interview in Sports Illustrated.
In suspending Rocker, Selig said, "Mr. Rocker should understand that his remarks offended practically every element of society and brought dishonor to himself, the Braves and Major League Baseball."
A 25-year-old Georgian, Rocker returned to New York yesterday for the first time since the Braves played the Yankees in the World Series last October. His return prompted the assignment of more than a dozen uniformed and plainclothes police officers from the Manhattan North precinct. The officers said they were concerned with keeping the sidewalk clear for pedestrian traffic.
One curious sidewalk observer was Tom Halligan, 39, a client manager, who works on the 27th floor of a building across Park Avenue. "I've been looking out the window every 15 minutes to see if he was coming out," Halligan said. "I understand what all the commotion is about, but I believe in freedom of speech. He should have kept his feelings to himself, though."
Also on hand was a delegation of community leaders and clergymen from Atlanta.
"The mere fact that this hearing is being held shows that Rocker is in a total state of denial; he doesn't get the message," said Michael Langford, a member of the Atlanta coalition.
In the hearing room, Selig testified about why he felt disciplinary action was necessary. Gene Orza, the union's associate general counsel, questioned him about precedent in his cross-examination.
 Boazman, the city councilman, followed Selig to the stand and told about community reaction in Atlanta. He testified, he said after, "to convey the message we were disappointed in the appeal and that these comments were very serious, bigoted, homophobic, racist." He said Rocker deserved the suspension and added that the Braves should release him. Kasten, the final witness of the eight-hour session, testified about the impact of Rocker's remarks on the Braves, particularly what he said was the economic impact.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Spread of Attacks on Web Sites Is Slowing Traffic on the Internet

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL with JOEL BRINKLEY 

 BODY:
As anonymous assaults on major Web sites continued yesterday, computer vandals crippled a large online brokerage operation and a media site. The Justice Department pledged to find those responsible, but computer experts questioned whether any defenses could easily be deployed against the attacks.
On the third day of what increasingly appeared to be a well-planned and tightly coordinated siege by a single individual or group, the impact of the attacks deepened. In addition to damaging commerce at the sites that have become targets, the attacks slowed traffic in some portions of the Internet. 
 In Washington, Attorney General Janet Reno, while pledging a vigorous pursuit of those responsible, also acknowledged that the attackers had covered their electronic tracks well and remained unknown to authorities.
Concerned e-commerce companies across the Net, many of whose publicly traded shares dropped in value yesterday as investors tried to understand the implications, began taking measures to protect their Web sites from becoming targets.
Even so, computer security experts said the complex, anonymous nature of the attacks made them difficult to trace or stop.
Indeed, security experts said that the attacks appear to have been weeks or months in the planning, since they required clandestinely loading software onto dozens, if not hundreds, of computers around the Internet.
When those programs were activated this week, the host computers were transformed into platforms for starting the attacks. In almost all cases, experts said, the owners of the computers never knew -- and still may not know -- that their machines had become cogs in the attack machinery.
"We tend to believe there are thousands of these tools out there waiting for the launch button to be pushed," said David M. Remnitz, chief executive of IFsec L.L.C., a information security company in New York. Suggesting that the attackers already had the infrastructure in place for the attacks to continue indefinitely, he added, "I don't see any reason why they would stop."
Ms. Reno said that the F.B.I. had opened a criminal investigation, but she and bureau officials acknowledged that they had no strong leads and had heard no credible claims of responsibility.
"At this time, we are not aware of the motives behind these attacks," the attorney general said, "but they appear to be intended to interfere with and to disrupt legitimate electronic commerce."
Keynote Systems, a company that measures the reliability and performance of Web sites, reported yesterday that during the attacks, it took eight seconds to call up a typical Web site's home page, nearly twice the time required the last two weeks.
Government and computer industry officials also continued to acknowledge yesterday that they could not be certain that the same group or individual was behind all the attacks, but they said the nature of the assaults seemed too similar to be coincidental.
What began with an attack on the popular Yahoo portal site on Monday spread yesterday to Zdnet.com, a media site, and E*Trade, one of the largest online brokerage houses.
And at least one other major site appears to have been a target. Although CNet, the Internet media company, declined to comment yesterday, its network service provider reported detecting an attack on the company's sites Tuesday afternoon but said it had managed to prevent any crippling effect on users.
Patrick DiChiro, a spokesman for E*Trade in Menlo Park, Calif., said that the company planned to deal "one on one" with customers who contend that they had lost money by not being able to gain access to the site to place trades.
Mr. DiChiro said that after the assaults Monday on Yahoo and Tuesday on Buy.com, a retail site, and eBay.com, an auction site, E*Trade began discussing what steps it might take to defend its site against a similar attack. Though he said unnamed measures were taken, the company was unable to prevent the attack, which hit at 5 a.m. Pacific Standard Time and slowed access to the site for about three hours, according to Keynote Systems.
The company did have several contingency plans in place, including directing customers who called E*Trade to an alternate Web site.
One reason it is difficult to defend against such an attack is that finding and cutting off the responsible parties requires a cooperative, concerted effort between the affected Web site and its network service provider -- the company that connects the site's own computers to the Internet.
Paul Vixie, senior vice president of Internet services for AboveNet, a network service provider whose clients include eBay and CNet, said the attackers appeared to have installed widely available software that, when secretly planted on other people's computers, flood a target site with instructions to perform meaningless tasks.
Mr. Vixie said that AboveNet was hit with as much as 800 megabits of "spurious traffic" a second, a level that could cost $400,000 a month to transport if it continued.
"It would cost us $400,000 a month just because some teenager with a $300 Linux box doesn't like one of our customers," Mr. Vixie said. "It makes us a little testy."
An earlier incarnation of this type of attack emerged two years ago, but new illicit software has circulated that makes such an attack easier to start and more difficult to defend against. The attacks themselves have intensified in the last nine months, striking not just the well-publicized major sites, but also smaller sites.
CERT, a federally financed computer security organization based at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, along with private computer security companies have released numerous warnings in recent months describing the attacks and suggesting ways to combat them.
Ron Dick, chief of the F.B.I.'s computer investigations and operations section, acknowledged that tools for this type of attack, known as a distributed denial of service attack, are so readily available on the Web that "a 15-year-old could use them to launch these attacks."
"It doesn't take a great deal of sophistication," Mr. Dick said. "In a relatively short period of time an unsophisticated intruder or unsophisticated computer user can take advantage of not only the U.S. government, but also e-commerce."
Under Federal law, purposely disrupting computer networks is a felony punishable for first-time offenders with a term of as much as five years in prison and a $250,000 fine, plus assessment of damages.
But Mr. Dick repeatedly said the F.B.I. had no hope of solving the crime without "help from the entire community" -- primarily meaning the various Internet service providers, or I.S.P.'s, whose servers were used to pass the data from the attacker to the victims.
"We are working with the F.B.I. to track the source of the attacks," Mr. Vixie said, echoing similar statements from officials at Yahoo and eBay.
Mr. Vixie said there were several steps sites could take to protect themselves. Those include increasing their capacity to handle traffic; using operating systems that can sift out malicious traffic; and installing new security patches that prevent sites from being commandeered to begin attacks.
But he added: "This level of alertness is not sustainable. We are hoping that there will be a technological or legal solution so we can go back to building our network rather than defending against attacks."
For their part, AboveNet and other Internet service providers have begun filtering out suspicious traffic. But that approach, they said, must be continuously adjusted as attackers change their means of assault.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 26, 2000, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Feb. 10 with an article about attacks against several Web sites referred imprecisely to the durations of the interruptions. Keynote Systems, a company that measures Internet performance, supplied data ranging from the point of less than 5 percent availability to the point of at least 80 percent availability. The sites were not necessarily blocked altogether during the periods shown, and some say their disruptions were shorter than indicated. The sites and the times they observed were Amazon, 1 hour 7 minutes; Buy.com, 3 hours 10 minutes; E*Trade, 1 hour; Yahoo, 3 hours 10 minutes; ZDNet, 2 hours 32 minutes.
The chart also misstated the day of the attack against Buy.com. It was Feb. 8, not Feb. 7.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 2716 words

HEADLINE: WEEKEND EXCURSION;
For Relaxing, Luxury Helps

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va.

 BODY:
"So do I need to curtsy when I go in?" Gabriela wanted to know.
Gabriela, my daughter, is a month shy of 10 and has been to places like Versailles and Blois. So her awed reaction surprised me. I had just shown her the brochures for the Greenbrier, the grand old 6,500-acre resort with the world-class golf courses 2,000 feet up in the mountains of West Virginia. 
 One color photo showed a tuxedo-clad waiter serving two women in black evening dresses and two men in dark suits and ties dining in a high-ceilinged, mirrored room under a five-tier crystal-and-gold chandelier. The main dining room is so formal that it has a dress code for dinner: suits and ties or black tie for men, dresses or evening suits for women. Gabriela figured she'd fit in fine with her new black velvet dress with the leopard print bolero jacket bought for $9.95 from the sale rack at Limited Too.
I am in the final stretch of writing a book, the stretch where day after day you work 18 hours to make deadlines that defy logic in the computer age. My husband was heading to California for a bar mitzvah of the son of one of his childhood friends and taking along our elder daughter, Alessandra. How delightful it would be to spend a quiet weekend at home together, I told Gabriela. How dreadful, she replied.
Gabriela was determined to top her sister. She wanted nothing less than Disney World; I wanted a spa. So we came up with a Disney World of sorts: a step back in time known as the Greenbrier.
Indeed, the Greenbrier is a magical kingdom for mothers and daughters, particularly if they're prepared to drop a lot of money. The resort boasts 637 guest rooms, including 46 suites and 71 guest and estate houses, 10 lobbies and 30 meeting rooms. The 1,600 employees serve a maximum of 1,200 guests. There are three 18-hole golf courses, a golf academy, 20 indoor and outdoor tennis courts, indoor and outdoor swimming, croquet, mountain biking, trap and skeet shooting, whitewater rafting, horseback riding, carriage rides, fishing in a trout-stocked creek, wild game hunts, ice skating, exercise rooms, personal training, a medical diagnostic clinic and a 25,000-square-foot spa.
There is simply too much to do in one weekend, even in winter.
In the 19th century, the plantation owners of the South -- men sporting top hats and walking sticks, women in sweeping skirts and parasols -- gathered on the Greenbrier's lush, manicured lawns to sip a Champagne-watermelon juice cocktail. President John Tyler spent his honeymoon here in 1844. (So did Joseph and Rose Kennedy and Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher.) The spa's famous heated sulfur water, from natural springs smelling like rotten eggs, gained an international reputation for curing rheumatism and arthritis. "A European cure without going to Europe," one of its early 20th-century brochures boasted.
During the Civil War, both the Union and the Confederacy alternately occupied the Greenbrier. During World War II, the State Department housed several hundred German and Japanese diplomats here for several months until they could return home. The hotel was also used as a hospital for 20,000 wounded American soldiers. An ultra-secret bomb shelter to house all of Congress in the event of an enemy attack on Washington was built in a separate wing in the 1950's. More than two dozen presidents have visited the resort.
 
A Contrast in Colors
By car, the Greenbrier is four and a half hours from Washington, eight and a half hours from New York. Since our time was short, Gabriela and I flew in on a 19-seat US Airways Express propeller plane. We were the only passengers on board the one-hour flight that Friday morning.
Gabriela was entranced by the decor. We live in a house that has white walls, hardwood floors, Middle Eastern carpets and art bought mostly at flea markets around the world. There are no draperies, no floral print upholstery, no boiserie. The decor at the Greenbrier, by contrast, is Martha Stewart on an acid trip. The resort is particularly proud of its decorating style, originated in the late 1940's by Dorothy Draper, the New York interior designer who used bold colors (mixing pinks and greens with red was her favorite) and made flower-patterned chintzes an American design statement.
Our room was a vast expanse, with so much space between the king-size bed and the television set that we could scarcely see the screen. Like the rest of the hotel, nothing in the room seemed to match. The striped pink-and-pale-green-flowered wallpaper did not match the kelly green carpet or the red comforter with the forest green trim or the pink-and-white checked upholstered armchairs or the cranberry-and-white print tablecloth and dust ruffle. It wasn't supposed to, we were told. This was all part of the Draper plan.
Gabriela was fascinated by the wallpapered walk-in closet, the cupboard that pulled down to reveal two ironing boards -- a large one for shirts and a small one for shirt sleeves -- and the well-stocked mini-bar, which she photographed from several angles.
The Greenbrier has remained faithful to Draper's fastidious attention to detail. The fluffy bathrobes in our walk-in closet and the towels in our bathroom were monogrammed with elaborate G's. The end sheet of the toilet paper roll in our bathroom did not hang; it was folded into a V and secured with a gold sticker engraved with the same G. The G was stamped into the sand in the urns used to snuff out cigarettes at the entrances to elevators and restaurants. Pots of perfectly trimmed fresh flowers graced every public room.
 
Aiming to Please
The Greenbrier may not be for everybody. For urban Northerners like us, it was a dramatic leap backward. During our three-day visit, neither Gabriela nor I saw one nonwhite face among the guests. "The History of the Greenbrier," a 222-page hard-cover book, includes only a few nonwhite faces, including a member of a United States pro golf team, Japanese diplomats interned during World War II and the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Colin L. Powell. But where else can you find a mosaic-tiled pool? O.K., so it's not Piazza Armerina, the 1,800-year-old Sicilian villa where the pool's colored mosaics depict frolicking women in bathing suits. But the Greenbrier pool is big -- Olympic-size -- and lined with tall white columns, with hundreds of yards of fabric draped from the ceiling.
The Greenbrier also believes in service, real service, the kind in which the staff really seems to care that you're perpetually comfortable, fed and entertained. On the weekend of our visit, there were only about 400 guests, including a veterinary convention, which meant we got appointments whenever we wanted and instant pampering.
 
Bowling and Tennis
Even in the dead of winter, the Greenbrier isn't cheap. But the beauty of traveling here as a single parent is that the child stays free. It cost $220 a night for the two of us, including breakfast and dinner. (That doesn't include taxes or an automatic service charge.) The price also includes free access to the game room, the swimming pools and an outdoor ice rink, afternoon tea and a movie every evening. And Gabriela got to choose her meals from the adult menu. A couple would pay almost twice as much.
Other activities come with price tags: bowling ($8, including shoe rental), horseback riding ($42 an hour), indoor tennis ($37 an hour for singles), a 30-minute carriage or sleigh ride ($26), a falcon and hawk demonstration at the Falconry Academy ($65 for adults and $40 for children). The shops sell gift items geared to indulgent grandparents. Gabriela spotted a small metal horse as a gift for her baby sitter. The only problem was that it cost $495. Porcelain-shard boxes that can be found in Beijing's overpriced state-run stores for less than $2 started at $15. We didn't do much shopping.
But we did do a lot of eating. We arrived and headed straight to lunch in Draper's Cafe. Gabriela was wide-eyed. "It's just like the ice cream parlor in 'Annie,' " she said of the pink-and-white striped entrance and the wicker chairs with cushions covered in plasticized cabbage-rose chintz. It was an odd menu, a combination of regional American and ethnic. (The soup and sandwich of the day on Friday was New England clam chowder and lox, lettuce and tomato on a bagel.)
Nothing on either the children's or the adults' menu appealed to Gabriela, and she wondered out loud if scrambled eggs and bacon were an option. When the waiter smiled and said sweetly, "No problem, Gabriela," she gave the cafe five stars.
Breakfasts were perfection. The miniature muffins were homemade; the juice was fresh-squeezed; the mixed berries were fresh, sweet and piled high in big bowls. This is farm country, and the eggs tasted like eggs, the bacon like bacon. Second helpings were allowed.
Dinners were almost as good, and we ate our way through multicourse meals of respectable American-Continental cuisine, to the music of a violinist and a pianist who welcomed our requests. Gabriela goes to a progressive school in Washington with no dress code, so she embraced the Greenbrier's formality and even learned how to use which utensil when. Much to her chagrin, a woman was admitted to the dining room wearing what looked like a coral sweat suit.
 
Sulfur and Scotch Spray
During our stay, I made two appointments for myself: one at the spa, the other at the beauty salon. At the spa I opted for the $93 "Greenbrier."
For 15 minutes I was soaked in a deep, bubbly hot bath of sulfur water and salt. A steam bath or sauna followed, then a "Swiss shower" of water from 16 shower heads and something called a "Scotch spray," when the spa therapist turned a high-pressure hose on me. The finale is a 15-minute Swedish massage, not nearly enough to iron out all the kinks, she informed me. It was in the spa that I noticed the pink rhododendron, West Virginia's state flower, on the tiled walls. Of course! Romance and rhododendrons had been Draper's motto. (Throughout the weekend Gabriela and I found rhododendrons in all sorts of places: on the menus, on the china, on the napkins, on the minibar price list.)
Gabriela, meanwhile, spent an hour bowling in the Greenbrier's eight-lane bowling alley with the other children registered in the "Brier Patch" program. For $40, a child can spend the day. A team of baby sitters feed and entertain the children, in winter with bowling, swimming, ice skating and arts and crafts.
Afterward, Gabriela reminded me that this was our weekend together. So when I went for a facial ($130) at the beauty salon the next day, I took her along.
Reluctantly, I signed off on a mini-manicure for her (I've had only one manicure in my life) and a trimming of her bangs. (How much could a bangs-trim cost?) When I saw her again, her hands had been paraffined, her nails multicolored and topped with sparkles. Her bangs were indeed shorter, and her hair was swept up in a French braid. The tab: $80.
 
Tea and Napoleons
Along the way during our weekend, we also watched a PG-13 movie, "The Bachelor," in real leather seats in the Greenbrier's movie theater, which is larger than many commercial ones. (The nearby powder room displayed dozens of black-and-white glamour portraits of movie stars from the 1940's and 50's, from Clark Gable to Jane Russell, the latter in a bubble bath.) We took tennis lessons together from a good-natured and very patient high school chemistry teacher named Bill, who doubles as the tennis pro. We sipped tea and ate tiny napoleons at the 4:15 afternoon tea in the main lobby with a live violin and piano concert. We walked to the outdoor Springhouse, where we held our noses as we sampled the sulfur water in plastic cups with the signature rhododendron on them.
But Gabriela discovered pool at the Greenbrier, and what she really wanted to do was to spend as much time as she could at one of the two pool tables in the dimly lighted game room.
I hadn't played pool since I was about 13, and the deep-green-and-black plaid wall-to-wall carpeting and reproduction fowl prints at the Greenbrier bore little resemblance to the neighborhood pool hall at the foot of Porter Avenue on the west side of Buffalo.
 
The Bomb Shelter
The high point of the trip was our tour of the cold war-era bomb shelter, built 720 feet into a hillside below a wing of the hotel during the Eisenhower administration; the president frequently visited the resort. Code-named Project Greek Island, the shelter was kept secret -- and active -- until The Washington Post revealed its existence in 1992.
The bomb shelter is closed for renovation now; we were able to finagle a private tour. There are 12-foot-wide, 25-ton concrete-and-steel "blast doors" to shield inhabitants from a nuclear explosion as close as 25 miles away; a decontamination room; chambers for the House and the Senate; a kitchen and a cafeteria; a power plant; a medical unit (complete with an operating room and 12-bed hospital); a communications room; and dormitories for the lawmakers. (All this was very exclusive: the families would not have been allowed in, although they might have booked space in the resort proper.)
To help fill up the resort during the slow winter months, the Greenbrier wants to convert part of the bomb shelter into a casino with mostly card games, we were told. The museum, it seems, is simply not enough of a moneymaker. The fusty old image would be shed. Eisenhower would be replaced by Kennedy. Cold war seriousness would be out, Rat Pack glamour in.
Last year the West Virginia State Legislature passed a bill allowing the county commission to put the casino question to a referendum by the people of Greenbrier County. But the county is a conservative place, and the project faces stiff opposition. Even many on the resort staff, some of them third- and even fourth-generation Greenbrier employees, have expressed concern to management that a casino could bring in hard-drinking riff-raff. Still, management has a golden argument: this is an economically depressed area whose main source of income is the Greenbrier.
Gabriela decided she liked the bomb shelter just the way it was. In fact, there was nothing about the Greenbrier she would change. On Sunday, after the East Coast was hit with more than a foot of snow, Gabriela and I opted out of flying and took a six-hour train ride home on Amtrak's Chicago-Washington line instead. We asked Draper's Cafe to pack box lunches.
As we chugged along the back yard of rural Allegheny Mountain country, eating B.L.T.'s and sipping chocolate milk, I realized just how well the weekend had gone when Gabriela asked, "Mom, does it cost a lot to have a wedding there?"
 
Retreat, at a Price
 
The Greenbrier is at 300 West Main Street, White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., about 475 miles from New York City. The largest nearby town is Lewisburg, about 10 miles away. In the late fall and winter, daily room rates are $196 to $222, based on double occupancy and including breakfast and dinner; children under 18 stay free in the same room. From April through October, daily rates range from $266 to $328. Holiday packages are available. Information: (800) 624-6070.
 
Getting There
 
BY CAR: From New York, take Interstate 95 south, past Baltimore, to Interstate 495 West. Continue on 495 to Virginia to Interstate 66 West. Continue on 66 West to Interstate 81 South. Take 81 South to Interstate 64 West. Continue on 64 West to West Virginia, and pick up Route 60 West to White Sulphur Springs.
 
BY PLANE: US Airways offers flights from La Guardia Airport to Greenbrier Airport in Lewisburg, with a plane change at Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington; there are nonstop flights during the peak season. A shuttle bus to the Greenbrier is available for $15 a person each way. A round-trip ticket, bought 21 days in advance, is $425; with no advance purchase, $763. Information: US Airways, (800) 428-4322.
 
BY TRAIN: Amtrak offers service to White Sulphur Springs from Penn Station in Manhattan on Sundays, Wednesdays and Fridays. The trip lasts about 10 hours, including a change of trains in Washington. Round-trip fare, $140; $70 for children under 16. Information: (800) 872-7245.

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 29; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 743 words

HEADLINE: NEW VIDEO RELEASES

 BODY:

The Muse
Suddenly booted off the studio lot, the screenwriter Steven Phillips (Albert Brooks, left) finds himself with no livelihood and an expensive wife, Laura (Andie MacDowell), and photogenic Hollywood abode to maintain. Short on ideas and convinced that his best years are behind him, Phillips is advised to get help from Sarah (Sharon Stone), who is billed as a muse of the original ancient Greek variety. But while Sarah comes up with a workable project, she is expensive and seems more interested in teaching Laura the right way to shop. Stirring his own ingredients, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, Mr. Brooks concocts a "mordantly hilarious cri de coeur about contemporary life." 

1999. USA. $108.01; DVD, $24.95. 97 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Feb. 15.
 
The Story of Us
In a middle-aged marriage running on empty, a surburban dad named Ben (Bruce Willis) and his beleaguered spouse, Katie (Michelle Pfeiffer), keep up appearances for the children's sake. While Rob Reiner's film means to depict the workaday realities, its elbow-in-the-ribs humor doesn't work, nor does "trumpeting its insights at high volume, relying on heavy shtick and turning its characters into clowns" (Maslin).

1999. Universal. $107.37; DVD, $24.98. 90 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Feb. 15.
 
Brokedown Palace
Defiantly proud of her own deceitfulness, Alice (Claire Danes) persuades Darlene (Kate Beckinsale) to lie to her family and say they are visiting Hawaii on their high school graduation trip. Actually, the girls are headed for Bangkok, where things turn nasty when they are gulled by a charming Australian (Daniel LaPaine) and arrested at the airport with six kilos of heroin planted on them. Thrown in prison, Alice really has a chance to show how clever she is. With a pungent sense of cultural dislocation and Ms. Danes riding a strong emotional current, Jonathan Kaplan's film is "good enough that you wish it were better" (Maslin).
 
1999. Fox. $107.37; DVD, $34.98. 100 minutes. PG-13. Closed captioned. Release date: Feb. 15.
 
In Too Deep
For this film's purposes, God is the name of a blustery Cincinnati drug lord (L. L. Cool J) and J. Reid is the alias of the agent (Omar Epps) charged with infiltrating God's operation. Not the most original situation perhaps, but within the framework there are some interesting subtleties, provided in the main by Ellery Ryan's cinematography.
And "to its credit, the film treats its characters seriously and doesn't resort to the obvious very often" (Maslin).

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk
