HEADLINE: The Calculus Of Voter Support;
For Some, Politics of Senate Race Come Second to Personal Concerns

SERIES: UNDECIDED/First Impressions

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS 

 BODY:
A lot rests on just a few.
Of the nearly 11 million registered voters in New York State, 3 to 11 percent of them tell pollsters that they have not yet made up their minds about the race for United States Senate. The figure is surprisingly small this early in an election campaign, perhaps because the two candidates, Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton, are celebrities. 
 The undecided voters are registered in both major parties, or no party, or they cannot remember which party. Some yearn for a third choice, a candidate on a white horse. Some have single-minded concerns like the upstate economy or campaign finance reform. One voter, perhaps exaggerating, says he simply wants to hear a candidate say the word "lymphoma."
Understanding the thinking of these voters, and winning them over, will be crucial to both campaigns, but no easy task. The calculus behind a decision to support a candidate can have as much to do with personal circumstances and gut feelings as with political philosophy and ideology.
Some of these undecided voters, culled from respondents to recent New York Times/CBS News polls, have agreed to discuss their decision-making as the campaign unfolds. Their willingness to do so suggests they are not typical, if there is such a thing, and their participation could alter their thinking about the campaign. But, with those caveats, they will offer a window in the coming months into the minds of the handful of voters who could decide this race.
Well-Informed, And Cynical
Tom and Barbara Smith of Saugerties speak the familiar, even fashionable, language of voter cynicism. But for them, skepticism is no pose. Their lives are so hard, their status so lowly, that they do not expect much from politicians.
"At our end of the food chain, nothing they say or do matters," said Mr. Smith, 41, a customer service manager at Wal-Mart and the embodiment of the working poor.
The Smiths scrape by, barely. His current job, at $18,000 a year, is a step up from his last, at a convenience store, because he now has health insurance and the opportunity for advancement.
But repairs are out of the question at the house they rent on an unpaved street in a rundown part of town known as "the Gut." And the Smiths do without a car. Their old one died, and their "new" '88 Ford Tempo needs $600 in repairs, which the Smiths do not have.
They are well-informed voters, he a registered Democrat and she a Republican. But they are not party loyalists: Mr. Smith twice voted for Ross Perot, not in protest but because he believed the blunt industrialist had something to offer people like him. And Mrs. Smith, who works part time stuffing advertising inserts into the local newspaper, chose Charles E. Schumer in the last Senate race because he seemed to have a good heart.
In this race, for the seat being vacated by the retirement of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, they see little but negative qualities in either candidate and wish for a surprise third option.
Mayor Giuliani is "too mean, too harsh," said Mrs. Smith, 53, who is stooped by osteoporosis. "It's the old U.S. attorney coming out in him," her husband agreed. "He doesn't know when to back off or give in."
As for the first lady, both say she has much to overcome. "There's Whitewater, Travelgate, her husband, the fact that she's imported, so to speak," said Mr. Smith, who moves stiffly on a lame leg, the result of a childhood injury.
"The way he runs New York and the way she just decides to come here and set up residence, I get the feeling we're dealing with superior beings, and you can put that in quotes," he said. "People like us, trying to make ends meet, that's who they should answer to. But I don't get the impression they care."
When Illness Is the Only Issue
Karl Schwartz has only one thing on his mind.
His wife, Joanne, has non-Hodgkins lymphoma, and Mr. Schwartz, a self-employed computer consultant, has spent the last five years learning everything he can about her disease, its treatments and its causes.
Ms. Schwartz, 47, has never voted. She dislikes them all, she explained. But her husband goes to the polls each Election Day, usually voting Democratic. He made an exception, and does not regret it, in choosing Mr. Giuliani over Mr. Dinkins. "I respect the idea of enforcing little rules," Mr. Schwartz said of the mayor's campaigns against urban nuisances. "That's a good sane position to take."
But these days he cares little about the quality of life in New York City. Or about crime rates or race relations. Even the havoc in the New York City school system, where he once taught, is a minor ripple next to his wife's illness. And Mr. Giuliani has never spoken a word about cancer research or qualifications for drug trials, at least not in Mr. Schwartz's hearing or in any of the publications, mainstream and otherwise, that he reads on the Internet.
Mr. Schwartz gives a slight edge to Mrs. Clinton. Despite the failure of her plan for universal medical coverage, Mr. Schwartz has no doubt that the first lady knows all about the ins and outs of health insurance.
But he has gone way beyond that into the minutiae of his wife's disease, and he wants a candidate who cares about the details as much as he does. He said he would gallop to the nearest polling place on Staten Island, where he lives and works in a tidy cottage near Raritan Bay, if one or the other would say the word "lymphoma." Or talk about the Food and Drug Administration, the agency that sets criteria for drug trials, for which his wife has been ruled ineligible. Or issue a position paper on the environmental causes of cancer or the safety of foods.
"These are issues for a senator," Mr. Schwartz said. "But you're considered on the fringe if you're concerned about these things."
'Isn't There Anybody Else?'
Thomas Beck, a guidance coordinator at a special education school on Long Island, is also hoping that "somebody will ride in on a white horse" and offer an alternative. "Isn't there anybody else out there?" he asked.
Mr. Beck says he is not particularly interested in ideology or party affiliation and makes his political choices in a personal way. He is at least as interested in a candidate's qualities as in policy positions.
In the 1992 presidential election, he voted for Bill Clinton, because "he made sense" and "looked like a grass-roots politician" -- without George Bush's "patrician" airs. In 1996, he chose Bob Dole because of President Clinton's personal indiscretions. "He's a lounge lizard type of guy," Mr. Beck said. "Can't you just see him in a Holiday Inn dancing to 'Feelings'?"
Mr. Beck, 47 and divorced, sees good in both candidates. "If you could take Hillary and Rudy and combine their best attributes, you'd have a great senator," he said.
But each, in his mind, also has huge deficiencies.
The mayor is "well-organized, has an excellent political mind and a great staff," Mr. Beck said. 'But his management style is 'My way or the highway.'
"He gets things done, no doubt about it. But he gets it done by not caring who he steps on. He's very callous in the way he treats people. You can get rid of the squeegee guys in a more humanistic way."
Mrs. Clinton is "clearly in the forefront," he says, on issues close to Mr. Beck's heart, like education and mental health. But he doubts that a stranger to New York can "know the problems and the pluses" of the state. He cites, as an example, the challenge of keeping the Long Island economy booming should the current bubble of prosperity burst.
"I do, to an extent, think about the carpetbagger thing," said Mr. Beck, who lives in his childhood home in Bethpage and continues to frequent sporting events there, sometimes as a coach or referee. "If the Democratic Party had a viable candidate who was charismatic and could raise money, I doubt she would even get the nomination."
 
Upstate, Tired Of Being Ignored
Upstate, in the land of abandoned carpet mills and toy factories, politics matters. The old industrial cities are hurting, untouched by the prosperity in the metropolitan region. And voters, of all political stripes, are looking for government to pay attention, relieve their pain.
In Amsterdam, Bob and Cathy Harrison are insulated from economic distress because of their professions -- he is a high school history teacher and she is a nurse. But they were born and raised in these parts, are committed to the well-being of their community and sick of being ignored by downstate politicians.
The Harrisons, both in their late 40's, with two teenagers, usually vote Republican. But they took a liking to the first lady during her summer visits upstate and think her connections in the nation's capital could help them.
"Who's going to find incentives to get industry back?" Mr. Harrison asked. "We need help from Washington."
The Harrisons recall with excitement Mrs. Clinton's appearance at a Labor Day parade in Albany, where their daughter played the flute in a high school band. The first lady was accompanied by the Harrisons' neighbor, their state assemblyman. He whispered something in her ear and she flashed a thumbs up at 14-year-old Kristin Harrison.
"That's the ultimate baby-kissing, I know," Mr. Harrison said, as if ashamed that he enjoyed it. "But she's showing some interest."
Mr. Harrison said he was automatically suspicious of someone like Mayor Giuliani, who made his mark south of New York's Mason-Dixon line. He mentioned a family trip to Disney World, where fellow tourists identified New Yorkers by how pushy they were. "We always say we're from upstate New York," Mr. Harrison said.
But Mrs. Harrison, citing the turnaround in New York City during the mayor's tenure, was more forgiving. After all, she felt perfectly safe in Manhattan last spring during her daughter's class trip to see "Les Miserables" on Broadway.
And then there was New Year's Eve in Times Square, which she saw on television. "It was a pressure situation and Giuliani came through," she said. "With him being -- what's the word? -- pig-headed, wouldn't he fight for us if he knew what we needed?"
Taking Offense At Corruption
Doug Taggart, a 41-year-old vice president at Standard & Poor's, says he is offended by the corruption of the American political system. The candidate who interests him most this political season is Senator John McCain, the Republican insurgent who has built his candidacy for president around the issue of campaign finance reform.
Restricting campaign contributions, in what is expected to be the most expensive Senate race in history, is what Mr. Taggart cares about. And he doubts that either Mayor Giuliani or Mrs. Clinton, vying for a seat in what he calls the "special interest branch of government," will make campaign finance reform a Holy Grail.
Mr. Taggart, a father of two from Cortlandt Manor in northern Westchester County, sees little to like in either Senate candidate. "I wouldn't want to say they are monstrous," he said. "But they are both very unlikable people."
He appreciates Mayor Giuliani's accomplishments in making New York City a more orderly place and commends him as a "take-charge person" compared with his predecessor, David N. Dinkins, "who was laid back to the point of doing nothing."
But the mayor chooses the wrong battles, Mr. Taggart said: rousting the homeless from the sidewalks, ticketing jaywalkers, prohibiting protests on the steps of City Hall. Referring to Mr. Giuliani's "relationship management skills," Mr. Taggart wonders "how somebody who is such a bully will adapt to a consensus-building environment" -- the Senate -- "where he doesn't always have the right of way."
But the first lady is just as easy to scorn, he said -- for small matters like whether she roots for the Yankees or the Cubs, medium-size matters like whether she lives on Old House Lane or on Pennsylvania Avenue and large matters like whether she made money in questionable stock deals. Lumping Mrs. Clinton with her husband, Mr. Taggart calls them "the couple that never learns their lessons," continuing to "live in a totally unconscious way" despite a succession of scandals.
Referring to both Senate candidates, he asked: "Why reward that type of person? I almost don't want to vote."
 
Day-to-Day Life Before Politics
For some people, politics doesn't matter much. Their lives are good, their problems few and personal, and their days stretched full with new careers, new babies, new houses.
This is how it is for Brad Easterbrook and Kim Shaunesey, both 33 and parents of an infant daughter. Ask this couple what they need and they will tell you: a shorter commute; lower property taxes; weekends together; more sleep. These are not issues that United States senators can do much about.
Mr. Easterbrook is the pro for tennis and other court sports at the Short Hills Club in New Jersey. Ms. Shaunesey is clinical coordinator for disturbed children at a hospital in Connecticut.
To accommodate these far-flung careers, they chose to live in between, in Rye Brook in Westchester County. Now Mr. Easterbrook commutes 90 minutes each way and his wife 45 minutes. He works every day except Monday, until 8 at night. She works four days, including Monday. This saves money on child care, but the savings is more than eaten up by their property taxes -- $12,000 a year for a routine three-bedroom raised ranch on a quarter acre. It also means that they rarely see each other awake.
So commonplace concerns trump politics. "We're too involved in our own lives," said Mr. Easterbrook, a registered Republican.
Their thoughts on the campaign come haltingly. Mr. Easterbrook is a fan of the mayor because "the city is definitely a better place to be." He has heard that crime reductions might have been a result of heavy-handed tactics, but he dismisses that as media exaggeration. Plus, Mrs. Clinton's strong suits are "touchy feely things" that don't interest him. He sees the mayor as a politician with a clear agenda. "Guys with simpler approaches tend to make things happen better than guys who think too much," he said. But he's not sure Mr. Giuliani's style would work in the Senate, and "that's where my undecidedness lies."
Ms. Shaunesey knows she is registered but isn't sure of her party affiliation. "Probably Republican," she said, with the distracted air of a sleep-deprived mother.
The mayor, she said, is "a hothead," who "overreacts and makes things a huge deal." She notes that "at least Hillary treats everyone nicely." But, Ms. Shaunesey said, the first lady "is so far removed from what my life is, I don't see how she can represent me. Do you think Hillary washes her own floor?"
 
Poverty May Be More Pressing
Politics can also take a back seat to poverty.
Charlene Clinton, a 44-year-old Buffalo Democrat, barely noticed that the first lady was in town twice in recent weeks. Struggling to make ends meet as she eases her way off welfare, Ms. Clinton -- no relation to the president -- has more pressing matters on her mind.
For her, the political visits came on days like any other: waiting in a drift of dirty snow for the bus that would take her to her job as a school monitor; wheezing with asthma and listening to her 13-year-old daughter do the same; worrying about her grown son, a high school dropout, and his girlfriend, pregnant with their second child, with four others under the age of 5 scattered in foster care; trying to find a ride to her weekly Bible study class.
Ms. Clinton does not whine about her lot and, in fact, says she has much to be thankful for. She owns her two-story house on Buffalo's east side, where her parents raised one son and eight daughters. Her late father, a janitor at the post office for 30 years, "made excellent money," Ms. Clinton said. She hopes to do the same and praises the decision to phase out welfare.
At her current job she nets $488 a month, compared with $230 from Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Briefly, as a secretary for a state drug program that lost its funding, she brought home $940 a month. She attends a training center where she is polishing her computer skills, hoping for another office job. She continues to get food stamps and Medicaid.
Ms. Clinton said that to choose a candidate this early in the campaign would be "taking wild guesses." She simply doesn't know enough. "I have to hear these people speak on different subjects," she said. She has every intention of voting, having missed only one election that she can recall, the last presidential contest, when she was recovering from a heart attack.
The issue she cares about most is how to move people from welfare to work. Will they get help finding a better job? How long will they remain eligible for food stamps? Will there be affordable health care when they no longer qualify for Medicaid?
Ms. Clinton said she would shape her views from television and "word of mouth," especially discussions with her elderly next-door neighbor, whom she generally escorts to the polls, for safety in a rough neighborhood.
"She reads the paper faithfully," Ms. Clinton said of her neighbor, "and is always telling me something about something."

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1052 words

HEADLINE: Winnipeg Journal;
Old Traditions on New Network: Igloos and Seals

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: WINNIPEG, Manitoba

 BODY:
Like most children growing up across North America in the 1960's, Jim Compton took cultural cues from the family television set.
"I had six-shooters and a cowboy outfit," Mr. Compton, a member of the Saulteaux tribe in Saskatchewan, said. "I identified more with John Wayne, not with the Indian that got shot down." 
 Now, after a 20-year career in television, Mr. Compton has his hands on a tool that he hopes will improve the television images that will wash over the next generation of Canada's indigenous peoples.
In December, from newly completed studios in this city on the central plains, broadcasting started for the Aboriginal People's Television Network, APTN. Mr. Compton is program director for what he bills as "the world's first national aboriginal television network."
As the cultural collision between Indian America and European America grinds into its sixth century, the aboriginal network seeks to create an electronic home and meeting place for Canada's million Indians, Eskimos and Metis, or people of mixed race. Aborigines constitute the fastest-growing segment of the population. But native communities are often the most troubled, with high rates of suicide, unemployment, incarceration and alcoholism.
Many Indians say the intrusion of European-dominated programming into native houses contributed to cultural dislocation and loss of pride. In the 1970's, a group of Eskimo elders in the eastern Arctic called television "an atomic bomb that leaves buildings intact, but destroys the lives and souls of the people."
"All of a sudden, they were getting images that did not reflect their cultures," Mr. Compton said of television's demoralizing effects. "All of a sudden, native people had to try to be like Barbie and Ken."
In contrast, an Indian-centered view of the world is the fare on APTN, which is now included by law in the basic cable package received by all Canadian subscribers, nearly eight million households.
Reaching into the far corners of Canada, the network started broadcasting in September from studios in Yellowknife, where it supplanted a decade-old network that served only Inuit communities in the Arctic.
"Inuaraq teaches his son how to survive using the old ways: driving dogs, building igloos, catching seals in open water and running down caribou to feed the family," says the network program guide about "Dog Team," an Inuit, or Eskimo, show broadcast in English, the lingua franca of the large majority of Canada's indigenous peoples. About one-fourth of the programming is in one of about 18 aboriginal languages.
For young people, there is also "Spirit Bay," a half-hour drama told through the eyes of children who live in a village in the northern wilderness. The program guide summarizes, "Lives of trapping cabins and fishing boats, freezing winter storms and quiet summer afternoons."
For aboriginal peoples steeped in oral history traditions, there is "Storytime," English-language segments filmed at the Yukon International Storytelling Festival. For Inuit speakers of Inuktitut, there is "Kippinguijautit," described on the network Web site, www.aptn.ca, as "funny and interesting stories of traditional and contemporary Inuit ways of life."
Touching on political issues, the network has shown "Hunters and Bombers," a documentary on the fight by Labrador natives against low-level military flights over their homeland, and "Unfinished Business," about having the government live up to land treaties.
For perspective, the network has shown films on tribes in Brazil, Papua New-Guinea and the Philippines.
To ensure a high percentage of Canadian content, the broadcasting authority limits "foreign" shows on all stations. APTN is allowed 12 hours considered foreign out of the weekly broadcast of 120. But in the Indian world view, Mr. Compton said, the rule reinforces the artificial European division of North America, where Blackfoot, Dine, Mohawk, Ojibway and other tribes straddle the United States-Canada border. Speaking in a province with a sizable Ojibway population, Mr. Compton predicted that regulators would rule that a six-part series on the Ojibway of Minnesota was "foreign."
The network hopes to generate advertising revenue by telecasting programs intended to draw large white crossover audiences. This year, a weekly "blockbuster" film program will begin, with Gary Farmer, a Cayuga from Ontario who acted in the movie "Smoke Signals," as host. Popular programs shown include a music special by Buffy Ste. Marie, a Cree from Saskatchewan, and "Cooking With the Wolfman."
"I have had 14,000 hits on my Web site, a lot of queries about recipes," said the host, David Wolfman, a member of the Lillooet tribe of British Columbia. "People are liking the caribou and venison recipes. But we also have done vegetarian recipes."
In March, the network plans to start a regular native-affairs news program.
Mr. Compton, who worked for nine years here as a reporter for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, the government-controlled network, added, "Our people do not trust the mainstream media to be forthcoming on these issues."
The national press has largely given a sympathetic welcome to the network, which under the terms of its approval by the federal licensing authority draws most of its $10 million annual budget from mandatory cable fees, $1.25 a year for each subscribing household. Although an Angus Reid poll in 1998 indicated that two-thirds of Canadians supported the concept of a national aboriginal network, some caustic press reviews reflect a deep racial and cultural divide among some Canadians.
"Only white liberals will watch the Aboriginal Peoples Television Network," headlined a column by Kevin Michael Grace in The Western Report, a conservative newsweekly.
Making cable customers support the network perpetuates "the stereotypes of Indians as people who must be given a handout to succeed," said The National Post, which is edited in Toronto and sells nationwide. "It also sends the message that a politically favored ethnic group can force its way into our living rooms and wallets."
Such comments fall flat in the APTN newsroom here. "Don't judge us with racist attitudes," said Mr. Compton, whose goal is rub out the old stereotypes of Indians as sidekicks or savages.

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 801 words

HEADLINE: Socialist Is Charting Middle Way For Chile

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 9

 BODY:
With a month to go before he becomes the first Socialist to lead Chile since Salvador Allende, President-elect Ricardo Lagos is showing a strong streak of independence from his party leadership and has appointed a relatively conservative, American-educated economic team that promises to keep down budget deficits and inflation.
Aware that his stature was diminished by a campaign that often lacked direction and by the narrowness of his victory last month, Mr. Lagos has worked hard to project a take-charge image. He has quickly appointed his cabinet and announced the broad outlines of an ambitious agenda that will focus on crime, housing and education. 
 He has broken new ground by appointing four women -- more than ever before -- to the cabinet, obliging senior aides to disclose their personal holdings as an anticorruption measure and promising to introduce a law that would limit campaign contributions and spending.
His governing style concentrates decision-making within a small circle of aides known more for their technical abilities than ideology. And he has shown that he will carefully balance the often contradictory demands of his varied constituencies, ranging from leftist Socialist Party stalwarts to the conservative business community.
Rising prices for copper -- Chile's primary export -- and a pick up of economic growth after a yearlong recession have come at just the right moment for Mr. Lagos. After he is inaugurated on March 11, he should be able to increase social spending without producing inflationary budget deficits or major new taxes.
In an article in the Santiago daily El Mercurio, a political writer, Blanca Arthur, said that Mr. Lagos, a 61-year-old lawyer and economist, "has shown that he is secure and confident in himself." She added, "He has shown the disposition to conduct presidential authority without submitting himself to party pressure."
In the days after his election, Mr. Lagos consulted with the leaders of the Christian Democratic and Socialist parties that constitute his governing coalition, but he ignored their preferences. His cabinet is heavily weighted with technocrats who are young and not closely tied to any party. In a clear act of revenge, he ignored the conservative wing of the Christian Democratic Party in his appointments after its leaders essentially sat out the campaign.
Before Mr. Lagos took off this week for a vacation at his country house outside Santiago, he announced almost a barrage of policy plans.
He said he would personally lead a stepped-up anticrime program that would coordinate the activities of the police with community groups and focus more attention on drug addiction. He pledged to set in motion a vast public housing program that would build one million units in 10 years to house every shantytown resident around the country. His appointed education minister, Mariana Aylwin, announced that the new government would make a major effort to reallocate resources to public schools serving rural and impoverished communities.
But just as Mr. Lagos distanced himself during the campaign from Dr. Allende, who was overthrown in a United States-backed military coup led by Gen. Augusto Pinochet in 1973, he has shown himself to be a moderate as president-elect.
Mr. Lagos has appointed two orthodox economists as his economy and finance ministers, mindful that business leaders and foreign investors would be watching. Jose de Gregorio, a conservative economist educated at M.I.T., will oversee energy, mining and fishing as economy minister. And Nicolas Eyzaguirre, a Harvard-trained economist, will step down as an executive director of the International Monetary Fund to take over the finance ministry.
In an interview with El Mercurio this week, Mr. Eyzaguirre said that after creating jobs, the major economic goal of the new government would be to create a budget surplus quickly. "This is fundamental to reaffirm the credibility Chile has in international markets," he said.
Mr. Lagos's most important cabinet appointment was of Jose Miguel Insulza, currently the chief of staff of President Eduardo Frei, as interior minister, a position that combines law enforcement and vice presidential duties. Mr. Insulza is a Socialist Party member, but his long defense of the government's attempts to block General Pinochet's extradition from Britain to Spain to stand trial on human rights charges has made him anathema to the party's leaders.
Still, the official who will most likely receive the most attention is Soledad Alvear, a former justice minister, who will be Mr. Lagos's foreign minister. A Christian Democrat, Ms. Alvear will fill the most senior political position of any woman in Chilean history, and she is already being talked about as a presidential contender in 2005.

HEADLINE: Administration Takes a Bow In Final Economic Report

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
With a technological revolution, low inflation and global integration in full swing, the current United States economic expansion, already the longest in American history, shows few signs of old age, President Clinton said in his administration's last annual survey of the economy.
In a 500-page report released today that mixed politics with an analysis of the country's record-breaking prosperity, the president's top economic advisers said a combination of deft fiscal management and a surge of entrepreneurial activity had made the current economic expansion not only the longest in history, but also by many measures the most unusual. 
 By the late stages of previous economic booms, in the 1960's and 1980's, inflation had surged, productivity had ebbed and income inequality had risen, the report said. But this expansion, which began in March 1991, has defied gravity, with inflation tame, productivity rising and the income gap narrowing after nearly a decade of growth.
"I don't know how long it can last, but the economic fundamentals look very good," said Martin N. Baily, chairman of Mr. Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers. "As long as we stick to the fiscal policy we have there is no reason this shouldn't continue indefinitely."
The report updates projections on how fast the economy will grow this year and next. It predicts the economy will expand at a slightly slower rate of 2.9 percent this year, down from 4.2 percent in 1999, with growth of 2.6 percent in 2001, and no recession in sight.
The administration also adjusted its estimate of the rise in productivity, a measure of worker efficiency and a crucial determinant of the longevity of an expansion. The more each worker can produce in the same number of hours, the more the economy can expand without straining resources and igniting inflation, the thinking goes.
The report predicts that productivity growth will average 2.1 percent a year for each of the next four years, far higher than the 1.4 percent average for the period between 1973 and 1995, but slower than the average gains over the last couple of years.
Indeed, that estimate could be conservative, Mr. Baily said. Productivity actually grew at a 5 percent rate in the final half of last year. If that were to keep up, then the overall economy could probably grow much faster -- perhaps at almost 4 percent a year -- without serious risk of inflation, he said.
Economists are sharply divided on whether Mr. Clinton, or any president, for that matter, does much to influence the overall direction of the economy. To the extent that the widespread use of computers, the growth of the Internet and the stock market surge have powered the economy, for example, the administration's fingerprints are barely visible.
But the report contends that Mr. Clinton deserves credit for what it calls two of the most important ingredients of today's strong economy: a sharp improvement in the financial condition of the federal government and the sizable increase in the role of trade.
"The expansion has been the result of a complementary set of developments in policy and in the private sector," the report said. "Rapid technological change has occurred in an economy that is more globalized than ever."
When Mr. Clinton took office, the federal government was deeply in debt and adding to the red ink in huge annual chunks. Today, the government is running a hefty surplus and paying down the national debt for the first time in decades. That reversal has freed hundreds of billions of dollars for investment in more productive sectors, the report says.
The sound economy and the resulting rise in tax revenues have a good deal to do with that, of course. But some economists outside of government agree that Mr. Clinton deserves a tip of the hat.
"Government spending declined as a share of the economy during his term," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch. "There was a surge in tax revenue, it's true. But in another era, it could have been frittered away."
Another engine of the economy has been globalization. Trade -- the sum of exports and imports -- accounts for a greater share of economic activity today than at any time since the turn of the last century, the report says. Moreover, the flow of capital among nations has exploded in the 1990's.
Credit Mr. Clinton's push for market-opening initiatives around the world, the White House argued. Mr. Clinton persuaded Congress to ratify free trade agreements with Mexico and Canada and helped usher in the creation of the World Trade Organization during his tenure. The seeds for both those achievements were laid in the Reagan and Bush administrations, the report acknowledges, but final credit for making them a reality goes to Mr. Clinton, it says.
The report notes two less rosy indicators, either of which could eventually contribute to the next recession. Private households are spending lots of money now based on expectations of future earnings and a continuing run-up in stock prices, the report says. That could foreshadow a sharp reduction in consumption if the stock market slumps.
The United States is also running a record trade deficit with the rest of the world. Long term, the deficit threatens the strength of the dollar and the reliance on cheap imports and capital from abroad to help fuel the domestic economy.

HEADLINE: Jamaican Fishermen's Tainted Boom: Rising Trade in Cocaine

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: YALLAHS, Jamaica, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Gordon, a villager whose family has been fishing the waters off Jamaica's southeastern coast for generations, needed a little extra cash. So one day last year, another fisherman introduced him to a local cocaine smuggler.
Gordon became a bit player in a growth industry. In his 18-foot boat, he makes regular pickups at prearranged spots a few miles offshore. Occasionally he is called at the last minute to pluck floating packets from the sea when they are jettisoned by traffickers spotted by American and Jamaican coast guard patrols. 
 It is dangerous work -- but very tempting in a land where times are hard and hopes are scant.
"Fishing can't send my kids to school. Fishing can't buy a new motor for my boat," said Gordon, who spoke openly about his activities but refused to give his full name for fear of being arrested.
Smuggling cocaine has more than doubled his income, Gordon said, sipping rum at a seaside bar and talking about the $15,000, 45-horsepower Yamaha engine that now graces his boat. While local residents refused to discuss Gordon specifically, they confirmed that cocaine-smuggling by fishermen is widespread.
"I hear it happens all up and down the coast," said Reddy Gilson, 32. "This kind of thing is hard to keep secret. One man shows up with money, new shoes, new clothes, more money than he had before, and everyone knows where he got it from."
Jean-Luc Lemahieu, manager of the Barbados-based United Nations program to fight drugs in the Caribbean, said the phenomenon is rather new in Jamaica. "Up to two or three years ago, the impression was that Jamaica's major problem was marijuana," he said.
Colombian traffickers began routing more shipments through Jamaica -- as well as Haiti -- as American authorities clamped down on smuggling through Puerto Rico and as enforcement improved in the Dominican Republic, Mr. Lemahieu said.
Jamaica, about halfway between Colombia and Florida and offering a well-established network of gangs as allies, is an attractive alternate transit point.
"Where we used to see maybe one boatload of cocaine a week, we're now seeing three to four boatloads of cocaine, each weighing" 800 to 1,800 pounds, said Beres Spence, head of Jamaica's police narcotics division. "Traffickers can access every inch of our shoreline, but it would be impossible for us to cover every inch."
Mr. Spence and foreign analysts estimate that at most a fifth of the cocaine passing through Jamaica is intercepted. A record 5,500 pounds was seized last year, more than double the amount of the year before. .
Only a small amount of the cocaine is consumed by the local market, where a kilogram, 2.2 pounds, fetches $6,000. Most is smuggled to the United States, where the same amount sells for $20,000.
With unemployment running officially at 15 percent -- in reality much higher -- finding "mules" to carry the drugs is easy. More than a thousand Jamaicans -- out of a population of 2.6 million -- were arrested for possession of cocaine in the past two years, and most were also charged with trying to export the drug, the police say.
The extent of Jamaica's role is summed up by one statistic: according to the United States Customs Service, 64 percent of those arrested for cocaine smuggling at American airports between October 1998 and September 1999 were coming from Jamaica, though not all were Jamaican.

HEADLINE: Online Fingerpointing Finds Suspects Everywhere

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Lacking information about who has been attacking some of the biggest sites on the Internet, cyberkibitzers have been busy nominating suspects in chat rooms, electronic bulletin boards and mass e-mailings.
Teenage hackers, the government, foreign terrorists and the owners of the Web sites themselves are mentioned repeatedly as having ideological or economic motives for overwhelming various sites with traffic, thus denying service to millions trying to use them. And while hackers were the main suspects in most published reports, it was the federal government that raised eyebrows in the chat rooms. 
 "Maybe it will turn out to be a couple of 12-year-olds in a basement somewhere and maybe it won't," said Michael Sims, one of many at www.slashdot.org suggesting that the media investigate possible government involvement. "The national security apparatus of the United States has the means, motive, and opportunity to have done this."
That motive, several said, would be to bolster the Clinton administration's request for more money to counter illegal Internet activity.
But some fancied that powerful private-sector forces might also be at work. Wall Street analysts, always ready to see everything through the lens of trading, passed around rumors that those jamming the sites had shorted the stock of the companies first. Short-sellers borrow and sell stock when they anticipate bad news, expecting to buy the shares back after prices decline.
And, of course, some posters could not resist anonymously blaming William H. Gates, the man whose power and wealth as chairman of Microsoft inspires as much envy as admiration.
"Maybe little Billy Gates has a NEW product under wraps that will protect all those poor e-businesses," said one such submission to the Time Bomb 2000 discussion group on Lusenet at www.greenspun.com.
A posting signed Mad Monk offered a rebuttal that was not exactly a defense: "I doubt that Microsoft has sufficiently good security products to halt the denial of service."
Mad Monk continued, "My personal suspicions are foreign nationals, possibly with some covert foreign government support," only to be rebuked by "kritter," who said, "Just don't forget, there really ARE roving bands of idiot kids who live to do stuff just like this." Kritter's conclusion: "This is the work of bored teenagers, moronic Hacks, plain and simple."
Postings that dismissed the likelihood of hackers said the interference did not actually require serious enough hacking skills to make it attractive to those who break into computer systems for thrills. "Hackers to Blame? Doubtful" read the headline on an editorial at www.2600.com, the site for a company that publishes a magazine for hackers.
The editorial speculates that the attack could have come from "someone who lost their life savings to electronic commerce," communists, and the government. Then there is "corporate America itself", the editorial says. "After all, who would be better served by a further denigration of the hacker image with more restrictions on individual liberties?"
Amid the cynicism, one optimist in an America Online discussion suggested that if the reports that hackers were at work turned out to be true, "Those who 'control' the Internet" could, among other things, "set up a series of Web sites specifically for the hackers, with challenging twists, turns, keys, and codes, well fortified and harmless, for their enjoyment and as a kind of contest between them."
Such sites, the posting suggested, could be monitored and used to "recruit the most talented hackers and mainstream them into the system with lucrative rewards and great jobs."

HEADLINE: Fake Auto Inspection Stickers Lead to Arrest of 2 Merchants

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 10

 BODY:
All the problems with New Jersey's new motor vehicle inspection system have suited Rafael Ottenwalder and Jesus Valle just fine, the police say.
Mr. Ottenwalder, 44, owns a bodega here, and Mr. Valle, 57, operates a tire shop. And at each place, detectives said today, the two men operated a black market in fake or stolen automobile inspection stickers and counterfeit auto insurance identification cards. Business has been brisk in the weeks since December, when the new, more stringent inspection system went into service, contributing to long waits for drivers and sometimes damaging cars, the detectives said. 
 "There seems to have been a drastic increase in the sticker sales since the new system started," said Sgt. Walter G. Kierce, commander of the Jersey City Police Department special investigations unit. "Some people have been waiting on inspection lines four, five and six hours, and if you have to take a day off from work to do that, some probably figure it's cheaper to buy illegal stickers.
Police Chief William Thynne said the street value of fraudulent stickers has tripled since the new inspection system started faltering. In some cases, Chief Thynne said, they are selling for $200 on the street here.
Detectives in Sergeant Kierce's unit raided the bodega and the tire shop and arrested both men on Wednesday on charges of forgery and possession of stolen or fictitious documents. Detectives learned about the suspected black markets while investigating a stolen-car ring, Chief Thynne said. Just before the raids, undercover officers bought an inspection sticker at Mr. Valle's tire shop for $45 and a counterfeit insurance card for $40, Sergeant Kierce said. At Mr. Ottenwalder's bodega, an undercover purchase involved 10 stickers for $100, he said.
During the raids, Chief Thynne said, detectives confiscated 249 fraudulent stickers and 108 counterfeit insurance cards at Mr. Ottenwalder's and 25 fake stickers and 113 counterfeit insurance cards at Mr. Valle's.
Detectives displayed the confiscated stickers and insurance cards at a news conference today. To the untrained eye, most of the inspection stickers appear identical to legitimate stickers.
Sergeant Kierce said state police detectives would be called in to examine them. "Possibly, some are stolen and some are counterfeit," he said. "If they are phonies, they are very, very good copies."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Falls 55.53 Points, But Nasdaq Keeps Soaring

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Nasdaq composite index soared to a record yesterday while blue-chip stocks once again lagged, pulled down by persistent worries that their earnings were not growing fast enough to offset rising interest rates.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 122.39 points, to 4,485.63. It was the fourth closing high in five sessions for the index, topping Tuesday's record of 4,427.50. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 55.53 points, to 10,643.63, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 5.13 points, to 1,416.83.
The technology shares that dominate the Nasdaq rose as investors determined that their powerful earnings growth puts them in the best position to thrive even if interest rates move higher later this year.
"Investors are seeking out the biggest earnings gains," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company in New York. "The companies in the Nasdaq are probably going to grow their earnings 30 percent this year, while the companies in the S.& P. 500 will probably see 13.5 percent growth."
Investors are scrambling toward the fastest-growing companies on concerns that the Federal Reserve will continue raising interest rates in its effort to cool the economy enough to ward off inflation. Four modest increases since June have done little to slow economic growth.
Higher rates can cut into corporate profits. In recent sessions, investors have punished old-line industrial stocks much more than high-technology shares, wagering that their slower growth rates will be especially endangered by rising rates. Yesterday, Merck, down 2 3/8, to 69, and Minnesota Mining, down 1 5/8, to 86, led the Dow lower.
Also, DuPont fell 2 5/8, to 54 1/16, and Procter & Gamble fell 2 59/16, to 91 7/16.
On the Nasdaq, earnings were a catalyst for buying. MCI WorldCom rose 1 11/16, to 49 13/16, after reporting that fourth-quarter profits nearly tripled from the final quarter of 1998 because of strong growth in its Internet and data services businesses.
Also, Dell Computer rose 3 15/64, to 38 51/64. The company, considered a bellwether for the technology industry, released its latest earnings report after the regular close of trading, beating Wall Street expectations by a penny a share. In after-hours trading, shares of Dell traded as low as 37 3/4. The stock has lost about a quarter of its value this year.
Internet stocks were mostly lower a day after hackers disrupted several popular Web sites. Amazon.com fell 4 1/16, to 76 3/16, and the online auctioneer eBay fell 1 5/8, to 162 3/8.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: EDUCATION PLAN;
McCain Attacks Unions And Vows Better Schools

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: SPARTANBURG, S.C., Feb. 10

 BODY:
Repeatedly attacking teachers unions and "self-serving union bosses," Senator John McCain called today for an experimental program of school vouchers, for merit pay for teachers and for judges who would allow voluntary prayer and the posting of the Ten Commandments in schools.
Mr. McCain's proposals were set out in an education speech in which he said the nation must "insist on high academic standards" but left it up to the states to devise them. 
 "Some believe that educational standards should be established by the federal government," Mr. McCain said. "I do not. Education must remain under the control of state and local authority that is closer and more responsive to the needs of parents and students. States are better able to develop appropriate standards than a one size fits all."
Though he has been a maverick on issues like campaign finance or tax-cutting, Mr. McCain stood squarely with the Republican Party on education, calling for a sharp reduction in federal regulations, no federal standards and for an experimental program of school vouchers. While he spoke of local accountability, he gave no indication of how he would measure or enforce it.
Gov. George W. Bush, Mr. McCain's chief rival for the Republican presidential nomination, has proposed a loosening of federal education regulations, but he would require in return that states conduct annual testing of elementary and middle school students. He would use a system of incentives and punishment for lack of performance.
Mr. McCain's education speech had once been scheduled to be delivered before the New Hampshire primary and was then postponed. Mr. Bush's supporters had pointed to Mr. McCain's failure to give a full-scale education address as a sign that he was not serious about a domestic issue at the top of voters' concerns.
And today the Bush camp called Mr. McCain's proposals insufficient to turn around poor student performance. The plan, said Scott McClellan, a Bush spokesman, "has no accountability and continues to allow federal dollars to follow failure."
"Governor Bush," Mr. McClellan said, "has shown in Texas that real education reform must include real accountability."
Little in Mr. McCain's speech today was new, and few details were provided. Mr. McCain had already called for a three-year, $5.5 billion test of school vouchers for one million students and for some kind of merit pay for teachers. For the first time time, he said he would create a $500 million annual federal block grant program for teacher testing and merit pay, leaving it to states to decide how to use the money.
Mr. McCain used his school voucher proposal to try to center himself between Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore.
"Governor Bush and I have a serious difference of opinion on school choice," Mr. McCain said, saying his voucher program would not use already existing public school money but money obtained by closing corporate tax loopholes that help the sugar, oil and gas and ethanol industries.
Mr. Bush has proposed that economically disadvantaged students who are supposed to be helped under the federal Title 1 program be given a voucher option to switch schools if schools have failing programs that they cannot reverse in three years.
Mr. McCain noted that Mr. Gore opposed vouchers, asserting that "he defends the status quo and reaps the money, the organization and the votes of entrenched interests."
There was no mistaking whom Mr. McCain was calling an entrenched interest. Time and again he attacked teachers unions.
"At the beginning of this new century," he said, "it's time to break the grip of the education monopoly that serves the union bosses at the expense of our children."
Mr. McCain also set himself apart from both Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore because he would wrap most federal education money into a block grant to the states, whereas, he said, "they would continue to use federal funds to require local communities to meet federally approved standards and they would continue to allow bureaucrats to determine how federal funds should be spent."
Mr. McCain said he would "insist that this money makes it to the classroom and is not diverted to bureaucrats -- and that accountability is measured not in federal paperwork, but by improved performance."
When Mr. McCain was asked at a news conference afterward about what guarantees there would be of performance, Lisa Graham Keegan, Arizona's superintendent of public instruction, who was accompanying him, tried to jump in to answer the question for him. But Mr. McCain said, "If the student performance goes down, all those people will be thrown out of office by their voters." He was apparently referring to state officials and school boards.
He also pledged to nominate judges "who don't divine from our Constitution nonexistent prohibitions on basic rights" including posting the Ten Commandments and reciting the Pledge of Allegiance.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Investors ShunAuction of U.S. Bonds, Causing Yields to Jump

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
For several weeks, the Treasury bond market has been whipsawed by uncertainty associated with the government's plan to buy back some publicly held long-term debt with the budget surplus. There have been sharp daily moves, then reversals a day later. And traders say that they have often been on the wrong side of the action, causing painful losses for some.
Yesterday, Wall Street dealers and traders indicated that they had had enough. They shunned the Treasury's auction of $10 billion in new 30-year bonds, leaving the government with the least demand ever at such a sale. "People didn't want the risk of participating because they didn't know where it would come out," said Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson Associates. 
 Those results, and growing frustration over the signals from the Treasury -- even though some have been misinterpreted -- sent Treasury prices tumbling while yields, which move in the opposite direction, shot higher.
In recent weeks, the yield on the 30-year bond, which is usually higher than that on short-term securities to entice investors, has fallen below that of the two-year note. Then yesterday the spread between the yield on the two-year note and the 30-year bond narrowed sharply, giving the bond market another sudden jolt.
The yield on the new 30-year bond, which was auctioned at 6.34 percent, finished at 6.32 percent, well up from the 6.17 percent Wednesday in the so-called when-issued market. The yield on the old 30-year bond jumped to 6.43 percent from 6.31 percent, while the price fell 1 12/32, to 96 1/32.
The yield on the two-year note rose to 6.65 percent from 6.63 percent Wednesday. On Tuesday, the yield on the two-year note was 6.67 percent, while the yield on the new 30-year bond was 6.10 percent, a spread of just over half a percentage point. That spread has now narrowed to a third of a percentage point.
These swift and costly swings are a result of the distortions that have occurred in the market since the Treasury confirmed on Jan. 13 that it would be buying back longer-term debt. The yield on the 10-year note has also been distorted as investment firms indicated that Wall Street would replace the 30-year bond as the market benchmark.
The distortions intensified last Wednesday, when a few more details about the buybacks were announced along with the news that the amount of the new 30-year bond offering, being sold yesterday and in May, would be much smaller than expected. The prospect of limited supply led to panic buying last Thursday. As the price rose, the yield on the 30-year bond fell to 6.13 percent, from 6.28 percent Wednesday and then jumped back up to 6.26 percent on Friday.
Dealers say these swings produced big losses, but no one is owning up to them so far.
Before a Treasury auction, dealers on Wall Street usually go short the issue to be sold -- that is, in this case, they sell 30-year bonds they own to make room for the ones they expect to buy when they bid in the auction. This assures that they do not wind up with more than they want.
But because so many dealers wanted nothing to to with the new 30-year bond, they did not go short ahead of the auction, traders said. They then made very weak bids in the auction, leaving the bonds to insurance companies and pension funds that need them for investing and money management purposes.
This meant that the new bond's yield soared. Just before the bidding closed, the yield in the when-issued market was 6.24 percent and the yield at the auction was 6.34 percent.
"People didn't feel confident going short," said Charles Parkhurst, managing director for government bond trading at Salomon Smith Barney, explaining that dealers just did not want to risk being short 30-year bonds if the price suddenly took off again and they did not want the new bond either.
N. Graham Allen, managing director for global fixed income at Wells Capital Management in Los Angeles, said he was not interested in the new 30-year bond because the trading distortions had sent the yield down too low and "we couldn't see what was going to maintain that."
Adding to the confusion yesterday were comments made on Wednesday by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers. Many investors took his remarks as a signal that the Treasury would also buy back shorter-term securities, leaving many investors to conclude that the 30-year bond was not so special after all. Although the Treasury indicated this interpretation was wrong and that the buybacks would be of long-term securities, investors sold the 30-year bond Wednesday, pushing the yield up.
But the flight from the 30-year bond may not be so bad. Mr. Crandall said the two-day sell-off was unwinding some of the distortions that had racked the bond market.

HEADLINE: Dell Computer Posts Profit That Meets Lower Forecast

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Feb. 10

 BODY:
The Dell Computer Corporation reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income yesterday that matched the sharply lowered expectations of investors.
The personal computer manufacturer, based in Round Rock, Tex., said net income in the period, which ended Jan. 28, rose to $436 million, or 16 cents a diluted share, from $425 million, or 15 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
 The numbers, which included a special gain of one cent a share, matched Wall Street's recently revised consensus estimates.
But the results were far short of the 21 cents per share that Wall Street had been anticipating before the company said on Jan. 26 that earnings would be hurt by a component shortage and by what the company called the failure of corporate customers to step up purchases after worries about the Year 2000 computer problem had subsided.
Dell said revenue for the quarter was $6.8 billion, a 31 percent increase from $5.17 billion a year earlier and slightly higher than what Dell officials had forecast last month. However, it, too, was far lower than what Wall Street had expected before the company's warning.
Dell, which pioneered direct selling of personal computers, said sales through its Web site approached half of revenue, and, by the end of the quarter, were averaging $40 million a day, up from $14 million a year ago.
In regular Nasdaq trading yesterday, Dell shares rose $3.23, to $38.80, but they slipped back to $37.88 in after-hours trading. Dell announced its earnings after the 4 p.m. close of regular trading.
Despite the stock's 9.1 percent gain yesterday on another record-setting day for the Nasdaq, Dell shares have fallen 4.8 percent in the last three months, compared with a gain of 51.2 percent for the Nasdaq index. Some analysts say investors are beginning to recognize that Dell's days of 50-percent-or-better growth are gone for good.
Dell executives have said they expect revenue to grow in the low-30-percent range this fiscal year -- a huge number, for sure, that would give Dell annual sales of more than $33 billion. But that follows 38 percent year-over-year growth for the just-completed fiscal year, and growth of 50 percent, or more, in the prior years.
Charles Wolf, an analyst at Warburg Dillon Read who lowered his rating on Dell from buy to hold earlier this week, said he was concerned that Dell had reached the point that it may be impossible for it to ever enjoy the sort of growth it had in the past.
"The kind of levitating growth rates we've seen in the past just aren't possible any more," Mr. Wolf said, in part because the company has grown so large. But he also said Dell's rivals were becoming more competitive on direct sales. For example, the Compaq Computer Corporation, the big Houston PC maker that stumbled badly last year and lost its lead in domestic sales to Dell, announced plans last month to increase its direct sales.
In an interview, Michael S. Dell, the company's founder and chief executive, said it was not feasible to believe the company could consistently post the sort of growth of past years, now that it has annual revenue of more than $25 billion. "Let's say $25 billion grows 40 percent a year. After 5 to 10 years, it has become bigger than the whole economy," Mr. Dell said. "Certainly as we approach a higher share of the market, our growth rate will look more and more like the market's growth rate."
But he added, "We're still growing at two to three times the market's growth rate, and there are new markets for us to expand into."
He also said that results for the first fiscal quarter this year would not be much better than what the company released yesterday. "We don't expect that the first-quarter bottom line will be considerably different than the fourth quarter," he said.

HEADLINE: New Airline To Emphasize More Flights For Upstate

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
The nation's newest discount airline, JetBlue Airlines, is to begin operations today out of its new home base at Kennedy International Airport with flights that, among other things, seek to ease air travel to an underserved upstate New York market.
With its first flight taking off from Buffalo and flying to Kennedy and then on to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., JetBlue is to inaugurate a service that its president, David Barger, said would eventually send 100 flights a day to more than 30 cities in the eastern two-thirds of the country. 
 In its first month of service, the startup airline will charge $25 one way between Buffalo and Kennedy, and thereafter as little as $98 round trip depending on travel time. Other scheduled airlines charge as much as $600 for a round-trip ticket between Buffalo and New York.
Mr. Barger said the airline hoped that travelers would be lured by a number of features not normally associated with the cattle-car image of discount flying.
The airline is emphasizing the greater leg room on its 162-passenger Airbus A-320 planes, which include all-leather seats and television monitors at each seat back with 24 channels to choose from, as well as the less-crowded traffic at J.F.K. compared with Newark and La Guardia Airports.
"It may take longer to get down the Van Wyck Expressway to get to us," Mr. Barger said, "but once you get here you are not going to be No. 18 in line on the tarmac to take off."
The start-up of the airline, which with $130 million is said by analysts to be among the best capitalized new airline ventures since the 1950's, comes as the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, proposed a $650 million plan to improve airports around the state to increase air service to Buffalo, Rochester, Syracuse and other upstate cities.
Mr. Bruno and others have long criticized the high fares and lack of service to upstate cities, calling them factors in the region's stunted economy.
JetBlue expects to be serving Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse within 18 months, Mr. Barger said. Its entry into that market was made possible by a waiver that federal transportation officials granted to Kennedy late last year, lifting restrictions on the number of takeoffs from 3 p.m. to 8 p.m.
Kennedy, along with La Guardia, O'Hare in Chicago and Ronald Reagan National Airport in Washington, are the only airports in the country where the Federal Aviation Administration restricts the number of flights to limit congestion in the airways.
William R. DeCota, director of aviation for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates Kennedy and La Guardia, said that the waivers were granted after pressure from Senator Charles E. Schumer, Gov. George E. Pataki and members of New York's Congressional delegation.
Mr. DeCota noted that Kennedy had plenty of underutilized capacity in the morning hours since most of its international flights arrived and departed in the afternoon and evening. JetBlue, he said, wanted to run domestic flights during those peak hours when the F.A.A. limited traffic so that it could get the maximum use and efficiency out of its fleet of new Airbuses.
Flying those new planes up to 12 hours a day is one of the factors that Mr. Barger said would allow the airline to offer the lower prices. Another factor, he said, was the Kennedy location, which put the airline close to a potential market of air travelers that had four million more people than were close by La Guardia and Newark.
Mr. Schumer and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani are to be among the airline's first passengers out of Buffalo today and are to participate in an inaugural ceremony at Kennedy.
Adam Whiteman, a senior vice president of Moody's Investors Service, said that while airline start-ups are risky ventures, JetBlue seemed better capitalized than others and, unlike other discount carriers, was starting off with new planes rather than older, used planes, which require more maintenance. Among the backers of the airline, which was founded by David Neeleman, are the financier George Soros's Quantum Fund, Weston Presidio Capital and Chase Capital.
"All of this makes them a little different than other start-up, discount carriers," Mr. Whiteman said. "It will be interesting to see if they can expand the market for air travel to their destinations."

HEADLINE: A Toast to Larry Summers, Bond Salesmanof the Year

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
LARRY SUMMERS is taking heat for the way he has handled the bond market. I say it's a bum rap. He just saved the taxpayers a billion dollars while leaving Wall Street baffled. He is the salesman of the year.
Consider the situation the Treasury secretary found himself in three weeks ago. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds had climbed to 6.75 percent, and the market value of such bonds was down 9 percent in just two months. Sentiment indicators showed that investors disliked bonds more than at any time since 1987. 
 It was the Treasury's job to sell bonds into that market. With sentiment like that, Mr. Summers faced a daunting task. It's not easy to sell something that the buyers have come to hate.
So what did Mr. Summers do? He put on a dazzling display of fakes and feints that would have made Michael Jordan proud. Suddenly, Wall Street seers who hated bonds came to love them, and there was talk about a shortage of bonds. Then Mr. Summers seemed to switch gears this week and hint that maybe the government wouldn't be buying back as many long Treasuries as he had indicated.
He left Wall Street traders stumbling and gasping for air. Some of them are mad. A few weeks ago, they were happily selling bonds short -- only to get ambushed by Mr. Summers. So yesterday they bought bonds in advance of the 30-year auction, secure in the knowledge that demand would be huge and prices would rise after the auction. They lost money again, and they blamed Mr. Summers.
The reality here is that the supply of Treasury bonds is not a very important issue for the long term. Anyone who fears that there won't be enough bonds to go around hasn't paid much attention to corporate America, which has been eagerly issuing bonds. But Mr. Summers managed to get a much better rate for the Treasury. It paid 6.34 percent at yesterday's auction, down from the recent market rate of 6.75 percent. Taxpayers will save $1.4 billion in interest payments over the life of the bonds.
The real issue on interest rates remains the same as it was before Mr. Summers faked out Wall Street. As Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, noted, Alan Greenspan has made it clear that short-term rates "are going to go up until the economy slows down."
Two questions remain: How long will it take for that medicine to have the intended effect? Will the slowdown turn into a recession? If a recession were coming, you would expect long-term interest rates to fall even as short-term ones were rising, which is just what has happened.
Of course, you'd also expect the stock market to fall if a recession was likely, and the Nasdaq composite hits new highs almost every day. But the strength of the technology stocks that dominate major indexes has obscured general weakness. The Morgan Stanley index of cyclical stocks -- companies that generally prosper in a booming economy and suffer in a weak one -- is down 17 percent in three weeks. Most bank stocks are lower than they were during the 1998 scare over Asian and Russian collapses. The Dow has fallen 9 percent in four weeks.
That kind of stock market action is not what you would expect if the economy is destined to stay as healthy as almost everyone thinks it is. Perhaps the stock market will soon reverse, and the longest period of economic growth in American history will continue. If not, it may turn out that long-term interest rates were going to fall soon even without the help of Mr. Summers's brilliant salesmanship.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Mr. Bush's Homework

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
The Times Op-Ed page sponsored a forum yesterday for people to give advice to George W. Bush on how to reinvigorate his campaign. I'm a day late, but here's my entry:
The first thing Governor Bush needs to grasp is the context of his campaign. He should consider just a few facts: 
 1. When Bill Clinton was elected president seven years ago there were 50 pages on the World Wide Web. Today there are over 50 million.
2. In 1992 no one had heard of e-commerce. This year retail e-commerce alone in the U.S. will hit $50 billion -- all of it untaxed, which is starting to drive mayors and governors crazy, because they're losing their tax base. The original Boston Tea Party was colonists throwing tea into the harbor under the motto "No taxation without representation." The new Boston e-party will be mayors and governors throwing Internet servers into the harbor under the motto "No representation without taxation."
3. The three biggest foreign relationships the U.S. has today -- with Japan, Russia and China -- have all been turned upside down, as all three countries go through the painful adjustment to globalization. While U.S. foreign policy in the cold war was about how to manage the military strength of Russia and China and the economic strength of Japan, today U.S. foreign policy is about how to manage the weakness of Russia, China and Japan. The old security agenda has been inverted, and with cyber-vandals disrupting Yahoo, eBay, E-Trade and Amazon.com, who knows what new threats are emerging?
In other words, the whole context for this campaign is that we are now in a period of radical change, possibly more sweeping and complex than in any period since 1776-1789. While the candidates are not talking about it, many voters feel it. And this leads to Governor Bush's biggest problem -- that many wonder whether he is up to managing this complexity.
You remember that silly picture of Michael Dukakis riding in a tank, with an ill-fitting helmet on his head, in the 1988 campaign? That picture helped to destroy Mr. Dukakis's chances because, at the height of the cold war with Russia, who could vote for someone who looked so dopey in military headgear? Well, the dunce cap is to this presidential campaign what that Army helmet was to the 1988 campaign. Any candidate who looks too comfortable in a dunce cap has a real problem today.
George W. is not a dunce, but he has not exactly demonstrated that he is a master of complexity, and that is a particular liability in this campaign. Voters look for one of two things in a candidate: convictions or capabilities. Ronald Reagan was not the smartest president, but he conveyed strong convictions about the biggest issue of his day -- how to confront the Soviet Union -- and people connected with that on a gut level. So much so that they gave Mr. Reagan the freedom to pursue a nuanced, far-reaching arms control policy toward Moscow. President Bush was not ideologically consistent, but his curiosity and instincts made him extraordinarily capable at managing the complexities of ending the cold war.
What hampers George W. Bush today is a gnawing sense that he has neither the convictions nor curiosities to cope with this new world. (But beware John McCain: he may have too much conviction about the cold-war foreign policy, and be too quick to invade in all the wrong places.) George W. doesn't convey any sense that he understands the period of radical change we are entering, or has any big ideas -- other than a big tax cut -- for how to deal with it.
He also has another problem: We all know him, or at least we think we do, because we all went to high school with him. We all had a kid in our high school class -- the charming, pampered goof-off, the one you let peek at your homework -- whom you loved for fraternity president, but not student council president.
A president doesn't need to be a genius to be successful, if he has strong convictions relevant to his times. A president doesn't need to have strong convictions to be successful, if he has capabilities relevant to his times. But in a period of radical change, a president must have one or the other. If George W. is to survive, he must prove that he indeed has one or the other, that we really don't know him, and that he really isn't just copying his advisers' homework. 
http://www.nytimes.com
