SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1780 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Yankee in Europe's Court?

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Airbus aircraft are strange birds.
Their wings are made in Britain, their bodies in Germany and parts of their tail assemblies in Spain. They are put together at a factory in southern France. Yet this cosmopolitan creature has become a symbol of the challenge facing Boeing, Airbus's lone remaining rival. 
 In recent years, Airbus has clawed its way to roughly half the world market for commercial jetliners, often evoking a mixture of aggression and disdain from Boeing.
Yet to orchestrate this remarkable feat, Airbus has relied largely on a cheery 49-year-old native of Rockville Centre, N.Y.
Of course, that man, John J. Leahy, senior vice president for sales at Airbus Industrie, does not see it as a one-man show. He stresses the size of his sales team, the 500 people stretching from brochure designers to finance experts, and the company's seven sales regions, including North America, Europe, China and the old Soviet Union.
In recent years, as America pioneered deregulation, European airlines have often turned to American executives to transplant a rough-and-tumble spirit to Europe. Jeffrey G. Katz, a former American Airlines executive, is chief executive of Swissair. Frederick W. Reid, another American Air veteran, was president of Lufthansa before leaving last year to become chief of marketing at Delta. Three years ago, when British Airways started a no-frills carrier, Go Fly Ltd., it hired an American, Barbara Cassani, to run it.
In part, Mr. Leahy has benefited from an industry consolidation. With Boeing's 1997 acquisition of its rival McDonnell Douglas, the field has essentially been reduced to two, Boeing and Airbus.
Yet Mr. Leahy's remarkable rise is also a result of deregulation. As head of the Airbus division in North America in the 1980's, when deregulation unleashed competition and forced airlines to examine their cash flows, Mr. Leahy convinced many airlines that buying an Airbus was more economical over the long haul than buying a Boeing. In the 1990's, as deregulation lapped across the Atlantic, he brought that pitch to Europe, where Airbus was already strong.
His scorecard is impressive. In 1995, his first full year as global head of sales, Airbus booked 106 orders, against 468 for Boeing. Last year, though Boeing continued to turn out roughly twice as many planes, Airbus had signed orders for 476 planes, against 391 for Boeing. By now, the companies' order backlogs are roughly equal -- about 1,500 each.
And as the European partners that control Airbus seek to transform it into an independent company and start its biggest project ever, a 550-seat superjumbo jet, Airbus's thirst for private capital is growing sharply. Increasingly, Mr. Leahy has assumed the role of Airbus ambassador, intensifying a practice he began not long after moving to Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, in the south of France, of explaining the company's strategy to international investors and analysts.
Thanks to his success, few airlines remain all-Boeing. One is the Israeli airline, El Al, and Mr. Leahy's efforts to change that illustrate the challenges he and Airbus often face.
After Mr. Leahy and his team briefed El Al pilots and executives and flew an A330 to Israel for a demonstration, the board of El Al, which wanted to expand its long-range fleet, voted in October to purchase new Boeing 777's and Airbus A330's.
The sales effort was out of all proportion to the size of the deal, which was worth about $400 million, an amount Airbus often books in a single month. Yet the victory had symbolic importance. Israeli economic dependence on the United States had made El Al reluctant to buy planes anywhere but in America. If El Al bought Airbus, the reasoning went, it would have to be because Airbus was better.
In December, however, after extensive lobbying by American officials, including Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Israel froze the decision pending a review by the government, which controls El Al.
Mr. Leahy "staked a lot of his reputation on convincing El Al to buy Airbus," said Jim Frank, the Boeing sales representative responsible for trying to secure the deal. "I'm glad to say he didn't win it."
Mr. Frank has never met Mr. Leahy, but "based on hearsay," he said in an interview, Mr. Leahy is "a real charmer, a smooth talker." El Al executives, Mr. Frank said, told him "they had never met a better marketer and salesman."
Nachman Kleiman, the El Al spokesman, who saw Mr. Leahy in action, described him as "very personable," and added: "I would buy a used car from the man. You have a sense of trust. And cars don't cost over $100 million." The Airbus deal, he said, was suspended until the Israeli government decided whether "El Al can buy and pay for the planes."
Mr. Leahy said he remained confident that El Al would stick to the deal and chided the State Department for its interference, accusing American officials of "forgetting all their lectures on free trade."
Boeing's ultimate weapon, of course, would be to hire Mr. Leahy away. Yet Mr. Frank said he was not aware Boeing had ever sought to do so. In the early 1990's, McDonnell Douglas tried, asking through a headhunter whether Mr. Leahy would become senior vice president for marketing at its Douglas aircraft division. Mr. Leahy declined.
Mr. Leahy's mix of entrepreneurial flair and a passion for flight became evident early on, when he earned his pilot's and flight instructor's licenses after graduating from Fordham University. While working toward an M.B.A. at Syracuse University, Mr. Leahy flew cargo planes four nights a week from Syracuse to Chicago to help pay tuition. (He stopped flying seven years ago, when he was unable to fly the 50 to 100 hours a year he feels are necessary to fly safely.) After getting his degree, he joined Piper Aircraft in Pennsylvania. In 1985, at age 34, he was hired by Airbus of North America.
By the mid-1980's, efforts by Airbus to crack the North American market had stalled, with few orders after a big sale to Eastern Airlines, now defunct, in the late 1970's.
To this day, executives involved in hiring Mr. Leahy marvel at his doggedness. "He would not take no for an answer," said Alan S. Boyd, a former Amtrak president who was then chairman of Airbus North America. Mr. Leahy, he added, possessed "bulldog tenacity."
Yet the key to Mr. Leahy's success, he said, lay in the growing influence of financiers in America's newly deregulated airline industry. "There were no more people in silk scarves and leather helmets," Mr. Boyd said, in an industry that "was being taken over by money men." Airbus's idea, he said, was "to put M.B.A.'s out on the road, who could talk their language; John knew that language."
In 1986, Mr. Leahy hauled in his first big catch when Northwest Airlines agreed to buy Airbus planes.
Daniel Solon, managing director of Avmark International, an airline consultancy in London, agreed that deregulation was crucial: "At the time, Northwest was in play, and the industry was taken over by financial players. They were potentially receptive, and you could induce them to buy other than Boeing."
Yet Mr. Leahy's early years were not all smooth. At times, the other side of his charm appeared to be aggression. Noel Forgeard, the Airbus chief executive and Mr. Leahy's No. 1 fan, described him as "the best marketing person I know." He added: "He's always angry. He cannot relax. He's always in movement."
Mr. Boyd, former chairman of Airbus North America, said Mr. Leahy sometimes treated employees harshly if they did not perform, and cut them off from communication. "I talked to him about that several times," he said. "But he considered me an old fogey."
Other executives defend him, however, arguing that what might appear as aggression is his relentless drive. "People notice that he's extremely focused on the matter of the day," said Nick Tomassetti, president of Airbus North America. "And guess what? They're right." Yet, he said, Mr. Leahy "means no disrespect in an angry way."
In 1990, when Mr. Tomassetti worked for International Aero Engines, a consortium of engine makers that included Pratt & Whitney and Kawasaki of Japan, Mr. Leahy cobbled together an innovative package of low-interest loans from aircraft-leasing companies and engine suppliers that enabled America West Airlines to acquire the Pan Am shuttle in exchange for America West's agreement to buy or lease more than 100 Airbus aircraft. Such loans have since become familiar features of aircraft purchases.
In 1994, when Mr. Leahy moved with his wife and three children to France, one immediate goal was to crack British Airways, a stubbornly all-Boeing carrier. Four years later, British Airways purchased its first Airbuses, the single-aisled, short-haul A319, after Mr. Leahy put the 319 side by side with a Boeing 737-700 on the tarmac and invited British executives to compare them. The Airbus offer, said Robert J. Ayling, chief executive of British Airways, "was a better value than the competitive offer."
But can Mr. Leahy keep up against the giant of the industry, Boeing?
To do so, Airbus is now busily transforming itself from a loose consortium into a unified company. The agreement last year to merge three of its partners -- Aerospatiale Matra of France, DaimlerChrysler Aerospace of Germany, and Construcciones Aeronauticas of Spain -- to form the European Aeronautic, Defense and Space Company, or EADS, leaves Airbus in effect with two shareholders: EADS, with 80 percent, and BAE Systems, as British Aerospace is now known, with 20 percent.
Moreover, Airbus plans the 550-seat jumbo, the A3XX, to compete with the Boeing 747 on the high end. If Airbus decides later this year to build the A3XX, Mr. Solon of Avmark said, it may be the first aircraft started not by a single big airline order but by the alliances of airlines that increasingly dominate intercontinental travel. Indeed, KLM and Alitalia, the core players in an alliance that also includes Northwest, have already decided to merge their fleet planning and purchasing activities.
Given the size and cost of the A3XX, Mr. Solon said, alliances will have to ask, "Can we make sense of this?"
Mr. Leahy disagrees. The A3XX, he said, with an estimated list price of up to $220 million, will be costlier than Boeing's biggest plane, the 747-400, which costs up to $180 million, "but we are not talking double the price."
Yet he does not underestimate the scale of the challenge. "Life isn't fair," he likes to tell his team. "If all things are equal, they're buying Boeing." He added, "We have to show them it's not equal, that we've got a better mousetrap."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Rocker States His Case at Appeal of Suspension

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
John Rocker's words earning him a 73-day suspension appeared in a national magazine for all to read. His words concerning his remarks and his subsequent suspension were recited in private, aimed only at the arbitrator who will decide Rocker's immediate future.
Rocker, the Atlanta Braves' closer, testified yesterday at the hearing that resulted from the players association's challenge of the suspension that Commissioner Bud Selig levied against Rocker on Jan. 31 -- all of spring training, which for pitchers lasts 45 days, and the first 28 days of the season. 
 Shyam Das, the arbitrator, will decide if Selig's disciplinary action was appropriate or if it should be overturned or lightened. His ruling is expected to come near the end of the month.
Rocker, who in his comments published in Sports Illustrated in December denigrated foreigners and many other segments of society, was one of three witnesses on the second and last day of the hearing at the Major League Baseball offices on Park Avenue in New York. Kevin Hallinan, baseball's chief security executive, was management's final witness, testifying about the increased burden Rocker's presence would present for the Braves if his suspension were reduced.
Rocker was the union's first witness, and Scott Sanderson, a former major league pitcher, was the union's only other witness. Sanderson testified about the ill effects an abbreviated spring training can have on a pitcher.
Under the suspension, Rocker, a 25-year-old left-hander, can begin working out in the Braves' extended spring training on April 3, the day the major league season begins, and then work with their minor league teams and join the Braves on May 1.
The arbitration panel consists of three members, but Das will decide the appeal because he is the only impartial member. The other two members are Donald Fehr, head of the players association, and Robert Manfred, the owners' chief labor executive.
Fehr declined to comment on the proceedings. "We're in the middle of an arbitration," he said. Asked about the feelings of the others present at the hearing, he said: "I wouldn't comment on what anyone else felt or thought. I can only tell you that the case has been submitted. There has to be the process by which a decision is reached."
Manfred, when asked, declined to discuss Rocker's testimony.
"I think the entire grievance process has been handled in the way that you'd hope that the grievance process would be handled," he said. "We had a disagreement; it's been handled in a businesslike way."
On the first day of the hearing, Stan Kasten, the Braves' president, testified about the negative impact the club says Rocker's remarks have had and will have on the Braves' economics. Asked yesterday about those problems, real or anticipated, Kasten declined to talk about them.
"I have no intention of discussing it at all," he said by telephone, meaning any aspect of the case.
The atmosphere surrounding the second day of the hearing was less circuslike than that of the first day. Fewer police officers were on hand outside 245 Park Avenue, and fewer office workers and passers-by lingered on the sidewalk protesting Rocker's presence or waiting for something to happen or for someone to emerge from the building.
Rocker, in fact, entered the building almost unnoticed, going through a construction area entrance. About an hour earlier, he arrived at the players association offices on East 49th Street. Before entering that building, he put his arm around a stunned news photographer.
"How you doing, buddy?" he said. "Want me to do anything for you?"
The photographer was Robert Mecea, who came to this country from Romania. "I didn't tell him I'm an immigrant," Mecea said.

LENGTH: 937 words

HEADLINE: Web Attacks Have Government Revisiting Laws and Security

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10

 BODY:
Expressing concern about the economic damage, including sell-offs in the stock market, caused by the attacks on leading Web sites this week, the Justice Department said today that tougher criminal penalties might be necessary to prevent malicious disruption of Internet commerce.
"We don't consider this a prank," Deputy Attorney General Eric Holder said today at a news conference. "These are very serious matters." 
 The Pentagon announced today that as part of the investigation, it had begun a check on some 7,600 military computer systems to determine whether any had been used as relay points by the Internet attackers.
At the Federal Bureau of Investigation, a spokesman said that four field offices had opened formal investigations: San Francisco, Los Angeles, Atlanta and Seattle.
"This is not cyberterrorism; this is cybercriminality," said an administration official, speaking on the condition of anonymity. And it has frightening implications, he said. If eBay and Yahoo can be shut down, the next target may very well be the National Security Agency or satellites, he suggested.
Since Monday, attacks have blocked access to several major Internet sites, sometimes for several hours. They have included Yahoo; Buy.com, a retail site whose stock began trading this week; E*Trade, one of the largest online brokerage firms; and eBay.com, the online auction site.
As the attacks appeared to taper off, law enforcement agencies and computer security experts said evidence suggested that the three days of digital assaults had been the work of more than one person or group. They said many Web sites remained vulnerable because of inadequate security precautions.
The White House has been holding meetings for the last two years with leaders in the computer industry to discuss security, and another meeting is set for next week, David Leavy, a White House spokesman, said today. He said the focus would be on the need for the government and private industry to cooperate in enhancing computer security.
Though the government recognizes an obligation to prosecute criminal activity on the Internet, there are knottier questions about the obligation to protect private Internet companies from vandalism and about just how much protection is possible.
Investigators are moving into relatively new ground: no crime scene, no rubble to comb through, no DNA. At the same time, experts say, some of the traditional police techniques, from developing informants to picking up tips on the street, may eventually crack the case.
The administration has been expanding its computer crime-fighting capabilities in recent years, establishing computer crime squads in F.B.I. offices around the country and training prosecutors in United States attorneys' offices. At the F.B.I., a National Infrastructure Protection Center was established to help coordinate such investigations, and Mr. Holder said the president was seeking an additional $37 million next year to expand these efforts.
He said the extra money would help set up regional computer forensic labs that would respond more quickly to problems. "Time is important in these matters," Mr. Holder said.
Under Federal law, purposely disrupting computer networks is a felony punishable on the first offense by up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Asked if that would be adequate in this case, Mr. Holder said: "We will obviously have to determine what the magnitude of the loss actually is. But it seems to me that you could end up with a situation where we might want to consider raising the penalties."
The fall in stock prices on Wednesday, attributable at least in part "to what we saw happening in these attacks," he said, "points out a reason why these things have to be taken extremely seriously."
Although the government has an obligation to prosecute the perpetrators of such crimes, experts say, companies have the primary obligation to protect themselves.
"The company has to hire their own guards," said William Arkin, an expert on the national security dimensions of the Internet. He used the analogy of a house burglary: law enforcement agencies have an obligation to search for the criminals, and to prosecute them. But the government does not have an obligation to install an alarm system in any home.
The police do, of course, have patrols that are intended to provide protection in neighborhoods. "There are no patrol cars on the Internet," Mr. Arkin noted.
Whatever resources the government puts into its efforts, it will be impossible to protect against all invasions, said John Thomas, commander of the Pentagon's Global Operations Security Center for four years until his retirement last summer. He is now with AverStar, an information technology company.
Given that there is no absolute defense against computer crime, a company, like the government, has to ask what information must be protected and how much it is willing to pay, Mr. Thomas said.
Mr. Thomas said it was possible to become alarmist about the risks from computer crime. But, he added, it is not possible to know who the attackers are, and who might be behind them. "Who is to say it is not being mentored by organized crime, corporate espionage, foreign governments, or terrorists," he said.
In the end, this case will be solved, if it is, "in physical space, not cyberspace," Mr. Thomas said.
Investigators will have to go onto the streets, as they do routinely, looking for informants or someone the hackers bragged to. "Hackers will do a lot to cover their tracks in cyberspace," he said. "Where they're vulnerable is physical space."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 573 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

House Passes Bill to Cut Taxes for Married Couples
The House passed a Republican-sponsored bill that would cut taxes for married couples by $182 billion over the next decade, brushing aside the Clinton administration's position that any such tax cut should be far smaller and be enacted only after more pressing issues are resolved.
While they stopped just short of an outright veto threat, administration officials made clear that Mr. Clinton would not sign a bill like the one passed by the House. Page A1. 

Dell Meets Revised Profit Estimates
Dell Computer reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income that matched the lowered expectations of investors. Shares of Dell had increased in regular trading by $3.23, to $38.80, in anticipation of the numbers, but fell in after-hours trading to $37.88. The results were far short of what Wall Street had been anticipating before the company disclosed on Jan. 26 that earnings would be hurt by a component shortage and by what the company said was the failure of corporate customers to increase purchases after worries about the Year 2000 rollover had subsided. C2.
 
Nasdaq Surges; Blue Chips Wallow
The Nasdaq composite index soared to a record while blue-chip stocks lagged again, pulled down by worries that their earnings are not growing fast enough to offset rising interest rates. The Nasdaq composite index rose 122.39 points, to 4,485.63. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 55.53 points, to 10,643.63, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 5.13 points, to 1,416.83. C8.
 
Shares of Ben & Jerry's Increase
Shares of Ben & Jerry's Homemade rose $2.875, to $28.375, after it was reported that the ice cream company had received a buyout offer for $268 million from Meadowbrook Lane Capital in a bid including the venture capital firm Chartwell Investments. C2.
 
Greenspan Urges Derivative Growth
The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, urged Congress to encourage the growth of complex financial contracts known as derivatives before the United States share of that market and associated benefits are lost to other countries. C19.
 
E-Commerce and Valentine's Day
Scores of e-commerce entrepreneurs are making Valentine's Day the next battleground, defying predictions of a big post-Christmas shakeout among Internet start-up companies that had been expected to substantially lower demand for commercial time and ad space after the fourth quarter. A number of online retailers are running special Valentine's Day ads, including Flooz.com, an online gift store that is featuring Whoopi Goldberg. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C2.
 
Brazilian Rival Confronts Coke
The merger partners in what would be Latin America's leading beverage company accused Coca-Cola of trying to derail their deal so as to suppress a new competitive threat in one of Coke's most important overseas markets. The accusation, made by Companhia de Bebidas das Americas, known as Ambev, was called groundless by Coke. C4.
 
Profit Triples at MCI Worldcom
MCI Worldcom said fourth-quarter profit nearly tripled, surpassing Wall Street expectations, with growth in its data, Internet and international operations. C5.
 
Clinton Submits Survey on Economy
The current economic expansion, already the longest in American history, shows few signs of old age, President Clinton said in his last annual survey of the economy. C8.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
East Side Tower Extends Luxury Rentals North

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Continuing a northward pattern of luxury apartment construction in Manhattan, a development group later this month will open Century Tower, a 128-unit apartment building at the southeast corner of First Avenue and 90th Street.
The building has studio to three-bedroom units of 440 to 1,450 square feet. Half of the apartments have one bedroom to appeal to young professionals and couples, but the units may also be combined to accommodate families. Monthly rents range from $2,000 to $7,000, and since leasing began in December, contracts have been signed on 24 units, according to Wolf Management and Leasing of Manhattan, the project's leasing agent. 
 The $50 million project is being developed by RFR/Davis, a partnership of Trevor Davis, Aby Rosen and Michael Fuchs that has been building mostly luxury rentals on the Upper East Side for the last five years. Century Tower is one of five such projects, totaling 746 apartments, that the group has built or is building in the neighborhood.
It is also the farthest north in the area that the partners have developed a building, reflecting the northward migration of new construction, many residential brokers said.
"We have never been market makers," Mr. Davis said. "Rather, we follow the market, and the market is moving north."
Indeed, north of the 23-story Century Tower is the Chesapeake, a recently completed 205-unit mixed-income rental building at 345 East 94th Street at First Avenue, developed by Sidney Fetner Associates of Manhattan. Leasing began in August and all but 17 apartments have been rented in the building, according to the Feathered Nest, its leasing agent.
Mr. Davis said that he and his partners "remain focused on the Upper East Side" and that the Chesapeake had reinforced "our decision to build Century Tower."
Nancy Packes, president of the Feathered Nest, said the lack of available building sites on the Upper East Side was pushing development northward and in turn "redefining by expansion the neighborhood's borders." Construction in Harlem "is also a positive," she said.
Another factor stoking the expansion, said Marilyn H. Kaye, president of Prudential MLB Kaye International Realty in Manhattan, is that the demand for apartments continues to outstrip the supply and may grow as some would-be buyers turn to rentals because of the recent rise in mortgage rates.
"The 90's are no longer pioneer country," Ms. Kaye added. "The real frontier now is around 110th Street."
Rents on the Upper East Side, as in the rest of the market, continue to rise. According to the Feathered Nest's year-end 1999 report, average rents rose in the neighborhood by 11.2 percent for all size apartments in the second half of last year. Ms. Packes said that increase put the average rent at $4,125 a month for a typical 1,000-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side.
The monthly rent for a similar size unit in a building on the fringe of the neighborhood, above 86th Street, generally is lower, she said, noting that a 1,191-square-foot, two-bedroom apartment on the 10th floor of the Chesapeake leased for $3,500.
The rents at Century Tower appealed to Robert J. Schneider, who has signed a contract to lease an 870-square-foot, one-bedroom apartment on the fifth floor of the building. Mr. Schneider, who is 35 and vice president of sales for his family's custom bookbinding business in Farmingdale, on Long Island, is moving back to Manhattan, and the Upper East Side, after living in Newport Beach, Calif., for two years. His company has a factory in Santa Anna, Calif.
Mr. Schneider said that compared with rents at other buildings, the $2,800 a month he will be paying at Century Tower "is reasonable and I feel I am getting more bang for my buck."
As for the building's location, Mr. Schneider said: "The 90's is actually more quiet and has more of a neighborhood feel. Being so high up also gives me easier access to the Triborough Bridge and to my business on Long Island."
Felicia Harrison, director of marketing and leasing at Wolf Management, said the building's 90th Street address had not proved to be an issue with prospective tenants. "The good thing," she said, "is that they already know they want to live in the neighborhood."
Century Tower replaces a Mobil gas station that stood on the site, which RFR/Davis bought 18 months ago because of its corner location. The site, Mr. Davis said, "lends itself to more creative layouts and multiple exposures" for the apartments.
The building was designed by H. Thomas O'Hara of Manhattan with a traditional masonry facade colored in multiple shades of red. Michael Graves & Associates of Princeton, N.J., is the architect for the building's interior public spaces, including its elliptical-shaped lobby, with an ocher and gray stone floor laid out in a checkered pattern.
"We wanted to take a classical-based design and adapt it to a modern high rise to provide something familiar, yet with a twist," said Thomas P. Rowe, a principal at the Graves firm in charge of the project. This is the first such project in Manhattan for the firm, which is also designing the common spaces for another RFR/Davis project: a three-building, 216-unit rental complex, called the Impala, nearing completion on First Avenue between 75th and 76th Streets.
Amenities at Century Tower include a screening room that is available for rent, a business center and a health club with a children's play area. There is also garage parking for 60 cars and 8,000 square feet of ground-floor retail space. Tenants will begin moving into the building in two weeks.

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about a new residential building at 90th Street and First Avenue misstated the period covered by a report on rents by the Feathered Nest brokerage firm. The report found that average rents on the Upper East Side increased by 11.2 percent in all of 1999, not in the second half.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Nights Turn Brighter

BYLINE: By ANN POWERS 

 BODY:
GO out in Brooklyn? On the weekend? For groovy New Yorkers, that was once an unbearably tepid proposition. Russian immigrants may drink vodka in Brighton Beach leisure palaces, and Trinidadians let loose to soca near Nostrand Avenue. But the students, artists and hipsters seeking the cultural edge started their evenings on the subway to the Village and beyond.
Now the Brooklyn-Manhattan power balance is changing. Exiled trendsetters eventually found themselves loving their neighborhoods and dressed them up with shops, restaurants and bars. Younger residents tried spots that no one else had yet declared chic. Hot spots multiplied, some as buzz-filled as Manhattan, others retaining an air of simplicity, messiness, home. 
 As a Brooklyn dweller, I knew Smith Street in Boerum Hill, where the bistros have sprung up as suddenly as Brooklyn's famous ailanthus trees. I had hung out at that strip's wonderful cafe, Halcyon. But I'm always working at night, when others are relaxing. To find Brooklyn's best hangouts, I needed expert assistance.
I enticed some Brooklyn savants into showing me their favorite pleasure dens. As we made our way, we discussed how the influence of time and money have affected Brooklyn's rim by day as surely as it has made things more fun after dark.
 
THE RISING CAFE.
Toshi Reagon sat at the bar of the Rising Cafe in Park Slope, smoking a cigar. "I picked up the habit on tour," she said. "I don't do it often. But this is our night out."
That's Ms. Reagon -- always one to make a simple meeting a party. The singer and songwriter knows the importance of cultivating merriment. She had obviously made an impression at the Rising. A co-owner, Christine Marinoni, greeted her with a big hug and joined us as we corralled a table.
"I should play here sometime!" said Ms. Reagon. The Rising, which caters to a mostly young, mostly gay crowd, has many events, including readings, political meetings and music about once a week.
"But my band wouldn't fit," she added, gesturing to the tiny stage.
"Toshi, I'd build the stage out the door if you'd play!" Ms. Marinoni said with a laugh.
As she turned to help a customer, Carl Hancock Rux and Chrystalin Wright entered. Ms. Reagon had enlisted these two old friends to take us farther than her favorite watering hole. Mr. Rux, a writer and musician who is one of Fort Greene's brightest talents, and Ms. Wright, a dancer and choreographer who was once a leader of the troupe Urban Bush Women, are self-described night crawlers, full of stories about their adventures in the borough's seedier spots.
This night, however, they had planned a more fabulous route along De Kalb Avenue, the center of Fort Greene's latest revival. As on Smith Street, restaurants and bars are rapidly multiplying here. Chez Oskar, the Buttercup, Sol and Lucien Blue around the corner have made this the place to be seen among the multiethnic elite.
Our first stop was a South African restaurant Mr. Rux had mentioned, where the congenial waitress mixed up a fresh batch of the ginger beer he loves. It was delicious, sharp and cool. Our hostess overheard Ms. Wright mention a recent trip to Johannesburg, and soon they were caught up in lively conversation. Brooklyn night crawlers love this friendliness.
 
A Pan-Latin Stop
Yet bigger and changing crowds are making such connections harder. When we entered Sol, a Pan-Latin restaurant that features live music in its long front bar, Mr. Rux declared it his hangout. But over crab cakes and chicken wings, he shared his mixed feelings about Fort Greene's recent transformation.
"This used to be the Claremont Lounge, one of the oldest bars in the neighborhood," Mr. Rux said. "It was very ghetto. You'd see people coming in with their yellow suits and ties, and the women would have their long nails. It was great! I went there because I'm always out in my neighborhood.
"Then Sol opened about a year ago, and I remember sitting here being very mad because there was a middle-class white couple -- the kind of people who've bought property but you didn't see out at night. And the woman said: 'This is great. Finally somewhere to eat in the neighborhood.'
"I said to her: 'Wow. You couldn't find anywhere to eat? Because there are places all up and down here.' There was a little Dominican chicken and rice joint then, where Madiba is now. And I got my dinners there for $3, and I was really happy."
Ms. Reagon added, "These neighborhoods have gone round and round." She noted that Fort Greene had endured another arc of popularity and decline in the late 1980's. "It's almost like nobody really owns anything; it's just the cycle. But it was really strange. One day there was an article in the paper that said Fort Greene's kind of cool. And then the next week, it seemed, there was this whole level of people coming in."
There is what Mr. Rux calls "a new socio-cultural-racial reality" in Fort Greene. Yet my three companions know that they, too, are part of the change. Artists make the first inroads. Night life, as Mr. Rux put it, anticipates changes in day life.
At Alibi, where we headed for a nightcap, the artists were in full force. The crowd at this classic bohemian dive, with its tin ceilings and graffiti-covered back walls, was almost all white. But these were students at Pratt Institute, the Clinton Hill art college, not stockbrokers. One man in a cowboy hat greeted Mr. Rux, and they settled into a corner for a conversation.
"I'm a bar guy," Mr. Rux said. "I love the community." He finds that fellowship among the painters at Alibi as well as the hip-hop poets at Sol or Lucien Blue. He knows it's fragile but he's glad it's blossoming.
 
Along Fifth Avenue
I was hoping for a straight-ahead pub crawl from one end of Fifth Avenue in Park Slope to the other with Greg Zinman, who plays guitar in the band Sea Ray. He brought along his friend Robert Galligan of the newly defunct group Sunday Puncher; both have lived and imbibed in Brooklyn since their Yale days half a decade ago. When we ventured into the subzero weather, however, we quickly amended our plans to include only four spots on this growing watering-hole row.
We started at O'Connor's because it was closest. Another "old man's bar" like the Alibi, O'Connor's was the first this neighborhood's hipsters commandeered. Other classic rooms, like Montero's on Atlantic Avenue and the Brooklyn Inn at Bergen and Bond, have their loyalists. But O'Connor's was the one for the youth in the Slope.
"O'Connor's wasn't a scene when we first came here," Mr. Galligan said. "The jukebox was just a boombox. There were more neighborhood people. The gentrifiers didn't outnumber them."
Mr. Zinman said: "Here's the hypocritical thing. We don't like it as much because more people like us come in."
These two friends are quite aware of their place in their neighborhood's transformation. They are renters, and as musicians with day jobs they don't enhance its economic profile. But they explore the bars and drag other friends to the ones they like. In Brooklyn, they could pioneer a scene already set in stone in Manhattan.
After leaving O'Connor's, we ventured across Flatbush Avenue to Freddy's. With decaying fixtures, a friendly barkeep, good beer on tap and a generous back room with a pool table, it's an exceedingly comfortable joint. My guides immediately ran into friends, including Kid Millions of the band Oneida, who shared the exciting news of good reviews in the British press.
Some of Freddy's clientele publish a literary 'zine, Lurch, out of the bar, and it decorates the walls along with the notices of open-mike nights and a weekly screenwriters' workshop. The posted information is haphazard; the staff likes to keep things low-key and local. Freddy's is a little bit blessed, a place on the verge. In a few months, I thought, it will be different.
It will be more like the Gate, probably, where a quick car service ride took us next. "This place is what it wants to be," Mr. Galligan said. Every bench in the rectangular room was taken; the barkeep skillfully kept up with orders from the lengthy beer list.
"It's got a publike atmosphere," Mr. Galligan said. "The decor is homey; there are dogs in here. People just start talking to each other."
Indeed, a host of apparent strangers were chatting at the bar. One couple danced to Sinatra on the sound system. Mr. Galligan called his roommate and musical partner, Howe Lin, who soon joined us. We had to pull ourselves away from our snug spot to keep the crawl going.
 
No Longer Jostle Free
We dashed into Loki, a new place with Victorian-style couches in the rear, but that sweet rear room was inadequately heated, and we headed down the block to Great Lakes, a bar with a Midwestern theme that archly plays on Brooklyn's unpretentiousness. Mr. Galligan spent a long stretch at the jukebox, selecting underground hits by Bailter Space and Nick Drake.
"When you go out in Manhattan, it's eyeing people and vibing -- looking and being seen," Mr. Lin said when I asked him about the lure of Brooklyn night life. "Here you can have a conversation because you're not distracted."
Mr. Zinman said: "As more time goes by, all I care about is being with my friends. I already have a girlfriend. I just want to be able to catch up at the end of the week and see how my friends are doing, and if I can't do that because I'm standing up, jostling with people, looking at people, it's just not worth it."
Brooklyn is no longer jostle-free, though. The bars on Fifth Avenue can be uncomfortable, especially on the weekends.
"We want to go someplace new, that has something to inspire us, to make us talk to each other in different ways," said Mr. Galligan, back from the jukebox. "It's this weird mix of hometown hanging out and new experiences. But where are the old dudes with their dogs and their dreams of writing the great American novel?"
Mr. Lin concluded: "It can be kind of constructed, this sense of community. A lot of Manhattan refugees are trying to find it here. Sometimes it doesn't ring true."
 
Williamsburg
 
If anywhere in Brooklyn houses a constructed community, it is Williamsburg. People jokingly call Williamsburg's main strip, Bedford Avenue, Avenue E because so many bohemians have fled the East Village to live there. With spacious converted factories attracting visual artists and no brownstones for Wall Street types, Williamsburg has made it to a solid and prosperous phase of gentrification.
Nicholas Hill has lived here since 1987. The multitalented music entrepreneur once ran one of Williamsburg's many speak-easies, Quiet Life, in a funeral parlor. I paired him as a guide with Judy McGuire, a writer who moved to Williamsburg in 1995, because they were players in a classic Brooklyn story -- a real estate story. A while back, sorely needing a new place for his growing family to live, Mr. Hill found a deal at the final hour through a friend of a friend. That contact, whom he had never met before our night out, was Ms. McGuire.
That's Williamsburg: an elaborate web of people and establishments. Many here have been pioneering for years. Trust overshadows the inevitable worry that change brings.
We started at the charmingly garish Greenpoint Tavern, then quickly hit the Charleston, where a fledgling band was churning out painfully earnest Celtic rock. We walked through the glamorous and huge new restaurant Planet Thailand just to see the boat hanging from the ceiling. But we lingered at Sweetwater, a punk bar where, Ms. McGuire said, mohawks often bump in the back room.
"I come here on Sundays to play pool," she said. "It's emptier. The bartender, George, shows movies on the television. He's getting his master's in poetry."
In Williamsburg the nightmare of being squished by scene-makers comes true. Sweetwater was so packed that I couldn't hold my beer straight. Galapagos, closer to the river, teemed with beautiful people. It is a visual artists' showcase with a reflecting pool in the foyer and vast walls that act as a gallery. We wove through the scattered crowd to the back room, Ocularis, where art films are shown and performances held.
"The way Galapagos established itself, its owners lived in the neighborhood," Mr. Hill said. "And they sought out a place that wasn't a problem for people living nearby. They opened slowly, over two years. They just got their hard liquor license last month."
Not all Williamsburg establishments have made such peaceful transitions. Residents are protesting the opening of the new Brooklyn branch of the defunct St. Marks Place club Sine. The room could be New York's hottest showcase, Mr. Hill said, but may never serve its rightful purpose as a nightclub. Mr. Hill understands the residents' concerns about crowds and noise because he also lives close by.
We wandered toward the Stinger, a three-week-old bar that opened with a bang. Inside a band called Tinker had the crowd in a frenzy of punk-style Irish clogging. We lucked into seats at the bar and were immersed in a musicians' confab. The bassist Tony Maimone joined Ms. McGuire, while Mr. Hill bent the ear of the guitarist Phillip Marshall of Teenage Mustache. Soon, Joe McGinty, the maestro of the Loser's Lounge at the Fez in the East Village, ambled up.
What made the Stinger so successful, I wondered? "It's owned by Cathrine Westergaard, who was a bartender at the Abbey," Mr. Hill said. Williamsburgers are loyal to their drink-pourers. Perhaps the club's location off the beaten Bedford Avenue path added to the attraction for this obviously local crowd.
 
A Peek at Greenpoint
The wrong kind of invasion can rankle. Leaving the Stinger with Mr. McGinty and Mr. Marshall in tow, we headed to Enid's in adjacent Greenpoint. The big tin-ceilinged room was lovely, and everyone says the crowd is local, but my guides were put off by the young people draped over the thrift store furniture. We headed to Pete's Candy Store.
Several musicians from the Stinger had stumbled over to tiny Pete's Candy Store. Again, family loyalty seemed to draw them; this bar is co-owned by Juliana Nash, the former singer of Talking to Animals. Plus there's the future promised by the bar's back room.
Simon Peach, a bartender there since Pete's Candy Store opened, ushered us into an unfinished space shaped like a train car. The dainty room will be a live music venue, a real neighborhood space where artists can try out their new material before friends.
The Candy Store's miniaturist aesthetic suits a neighborhood where the locals keep looking for new hideouts. Yet Mr. Hill said they ultimately tolerate newcomers, glad for the amenities they bring.
"Frankly, most of us are happy that there's a health food store and a yoga place," Mr. Hill added.
And what do the curious find when they take the L train to Williamsburg on a weekend? Something we all want, Mr. Marshall said.
"Have you ever been on vacation somewhere, and you know you're not part of it but you think, 'I could live here?' " he said. "That's what most people feel about Williamsburg."
 
Around the Academy
For my last night's frolic, I turned to a professional. Limor Tomer has worked at the Brooklyn Academy of Music for seven years. She now books the music at BAM Cafe, and has established it as an adventurous and congenial spot in its first year. "When we opened we wanted to make this a showcase for Brooklyn musicians," said Ms. Tomer, who also books acts from all over the world. "It wasn't hard. Ninety percent of the phone numbers on my list are in the 718 area code."
Ms. Tomer herself currently has a good rental situation in 212. But she gets her inspiration from Brooklyn.
"I see the Upper West Side as my little home in lower Westchester," she said. "But where I go out, where my friends live is Brooklyn."
She certainly showed the command of the local as she steered us toward Frank's, a vintage blues bar adorned with balloons, Christmas lights and red plastic tablecloths, a few blocks from BAM Cafe. She greeted the owner as a favorite uncle and exchanged pleasantries with the regulars at the bar.
"I need to have good relationships with the locals," she explained. BAM's foray into night life might have been perceived as a conquest, but Ms. Tomer's good will and other proprietors' desire to expand their own possibilities through collaboration have helped keep the peace.
She insisted that we stop by the Brooklyn Moon Cafe, two blocks from Frank's, because, she said, "it's totally essential to the story." It was one of the first spots to open in this latest night life wave. The owner was locking his gate as we walked up, so Ms. Tomer gave him a kiss and speeded us toward her next connection.
The Up Over sits above the Wing Wagon restaurant at Seventh Avenue and Flatbush, just across from the busy D train stop where hundreds of Slope dwellers pass every day. But how many know about this pristine room where classic jazz is played four nights a week? This small treasure represents the subtle side of Brooklyn night life -- not imported trends, but individual dreams played out close to the homes where they were devised.
Another kind of dreaming was happening at our next stop. The Atlantic Night Cafe is a place few hipsters may penetrate; the Middle Eastern men smoking hookahs at sidewalk tables intimidate the average Brooklyn lager-seeker. Ms. Tomer, of course, had crossed the threshold long ago. Entering the room, which resembles a deliriously decorated wedding reception hall, she greeted the staff and ordered a hookah for us.
"It's just tobacco, sweetened with apple," said Ms. Tomer, who is Israeli-born, with a laugh. "In Jordan the men are puffing on hashish!"
We watched as men and a few women slowly freed themselves from the jovial groups seated at long tables to dance solo, swaying their hips and brandishing beads or sticks, in the center of the room. Ms. Tomer's attention was on the duo playing music.
"I should get that oud player into BAM Cafe," she said. "I would hook him up with a real band. Lose the synth."
In this setting, though, the synthesizer sounded great, and it was hard to abandon the tasty smoke and the serenely festive mood. We wanted to hit Dumbo, the newest point on the Brooklyn night life map.
"The bars there aren't having any music tonight, but let's check it out anyway," Ms. Tomer said. A few minutes later we were in Between the Bridges, where three female chefs operate the tiny bistro Superfine and sometimes have "fire shows and cabarets."
It was nearly 2 a.m., and Between the Bridges had reverted to its natural state as a great dive with a fine jukebox. Led Zeppelin blasted through the speakers, and tattooed night owls occupied the tables. A few trucker types hugged the bar. We took a rear table and talked about all we had seen.
Ms. Tomer sees the expansion as overwhelmingly positive and is convinced that even if it increases tenfold, Brooklyn will still remain Brooklyn, day and night.
"It's freer; it's more real; it's more mixed," she concluded, echoing all the guides I had enlisted. "It's everything we moved to New York for that doesn't exist in Manhattan anymore because Manhattan has become a playground for the rich. All the creativity and the energy that we came here for is living and breathing here."

PUB-DATE: February 11, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 16; Column 5; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2220 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:
Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
*"ANY GIVEN SUNDAY," starring Al Pacino, Cameron Diaz, Dennis Quaid, James Woods and Jamie Foxx. Directed by Oliver Stone (R, 160 minutes). Mr. Stone's brawling, hyper-macho professional football film has enough in-the-thick-of-it playing-field action to satisfy the fantasies of most armchair players. In the style of Mr. Stone's "Wall Street," the movie is also a crude morality play that pits the old ways against the new, with the veteran coach Tony D'Amato (Mr. Pacino) embodying tradition and a young hotshot quarterback, Willie Beamen (Mr. Foxx), the new. Although the acting is uneven (Ms. Diaz is disappointing as a tough team owner), and the final scenes are shamelessly "Rocky" -ish, the movie delivers a credible, action-charged vision of the frenzied world of professional sports as a metaphor for the volatility of American culture (Stepehn Holden). 

"EYE OF THE BEHOLDER," starring Ewan McGregor and Ashley Judd. Directed by Stephan Elliott (R, 105 minutes). Mr. McGregor is a British surveillance expert and Ms. Judd the serial-killing femme fatale he falls in love with (while observing her kill a boyfriend) in this ludicrous psycho-thriller. As Mr McGregor's character, known only as the Eye, follows the object of his obsession from city to city, the movie tries futilely to capture some of the mystique of "Vertigo." But the film, by the director best known for "The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert,"is so garish, disjointed and incoherent that it feels like an extended music video posing as a movie (Holden).
 
"FANTASIA/2000," with James Levine and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra and introductions by Steve Martin, Bette Midler, Mr. Levine, Itzhak Perlman, James Earl Jones, Angela Lansbury, Quincy Jones and Penn and Teller. Various directors (G, 75 minutes). The millennial version of Disney's 1940 ground-breaking fusion of animation and classical music includes seven new segments and keeps one from the original film (the wonderful "Sorcerer's Apprentice," starring Mickey Mouse). Despite the science fiction title and the Imax-size screen on which it is shown, "Fantasia/2000" is more backward-looking than futuristic. The two best segments are "Rhapsody in Blue," a witty Manhattan-in-the-Jazz-Age homage to the caricaturist Al Hirschfeld set to the music of Gershwin, and the finale (set to Stravinsky's "Firebird" Suite), in which a cometlike sprite whooshes around the globe explosively creating, destroying and renewing the planet's life forms. Celebrity introductions lend the film the feel of a deluxe corporate promotion. At the Sony Imax Theater, Broadway at 68th Street (Holden).
 
"GIRL, INTERRUPTED," starring Winona Ryder and Angelina Jolie. Directed by james Mangold (R, 120 minutes). Except for being several years too old for the role, Winona Ryder, an actress who oozes high-strung intelligence, is ideally cast as Susanna Kaysen, a college-age girl who lands in a Massachusetts mental institution in 1967 after a halfhearted suicide attempt. (The movie is based on Ms. Kaysen's memoir). The period details are perfect, and Ms. Ryder has the courage to make her character a pain in the neck. But the small, introspective movie is nearly stolen by Ms Jolie as a charismatic, brutally truth-telling sociopath who becomes Susanna's best friend (Holden).
 
"THE GREEN MILE," starring Tom Hanks, Michael Clarke Duncan, David Morse, Doug Hutchison, Sam Rockwell and Bonnie Hunt. Written and directed by Frank Darabont (R, 180 minutes). In adapting the death row drama that Stephen King wrote in multiple installments, the director of "The Shawshank Redemption" could have managed more economy and fewer talky bits of business around the cellblock. Still, this lengthy film is vivid and well played. Smooth ensemble acting builds up to the discovery that a gigantic condemned man (Mr. Duncan) is a prisoner with very special abilities, which gives the film its mixture of religious overtones and mild horror. Mr. Hanks, as a wry Southern prison guard, is so unaffectionately good that it's redundant to say so (Janet Maslin).
 
* "GUN SHY," starring Liam Neeson, Oliver Platt, Jose Zuniga and Sandra Bullock. Written and directed by Eric Blakeney (R, 102 minutes). Last spring saw both a film comedy ("Analyze This") and a cable series ("The Sopranos") about gangsters forcing themselves to unload to a shrink. This year, in "Gun Sky," we get a shaken undercover Fed, Charlie Mayo (Mr. Neeson), seeing a psychiatrist on the down-low. Charlie, a wreck who has lost his nerve after he was exposed during an undercover operation, is assigned to a job that involves his acting as an organized-crime envoy. He moves between the preening Fidel (Mr. Zuniga), a yuppie Colombian thug, and Fulvio (Mr. Platt), whose vulgar pride in his violent streak is perverse. Mr. Blakeney has come up with one of the most subtle and inspired comedies you'll see this year in his feature-film writing and directing debut (Elvis Mitchell).
 
"HOLY SMOKE," starring Kate Winslet and Harvey Keitel. directed by jane Campion (R, 95 minutes). Having roamed so gorgeously through North Africa as a young hippie mother in "Hideous Kinky," Ms. Winslet this time appears in India as Ruth barron, a head-strong young Australian seeking enlightenment. Eventually Ruth's mother coaxes her home, where a "cult exiter" named P.J. (Mr. Keitel) is waiting to wean Ruth away from her Indian guru. But as the film moves from its early mix of rapture and humor into this more serious, confrontational stage, it runs into trouble. It doesn't help that Ms. Winslet's obvious strength and beauty leave Mr. Keitel's P.J. looking overmatched (Maslin).
 
*"THE HURRICANE," starring Denzel Washington. Directed by Norman Jewison (R, 120 minutes). The life story of Hurricane Carter, a middleweight contender who spent nearly 20 years in prison for a triple murder he didn't commit, is a big, schmaltzy ballad of a movie redeemed by Mr. Washington's moving, bone-deep protrayal of the boxer from Paterson, N.J. But the movie plays fast and loose with the facts, giving far too much credit to the members of a Canadian commence who took up Mr. Carter's cause and all but eliminating his heroic co-defendant, John Artis, from the story. And the minor characters are either saints or monsters. Yet the story of a man heroically fighting his demons and winning his freedom is still inspiring (Holden).
 
"ISN'T SHE GREAT," starring Bette Midler, Nathan Lane, Stockard Channing, David Hyde Pierce and John Cleese. Directed by Andrew Bergman (R, 90 minutes). In this bio-pic, Ms. Midler protrays the author Jacqueline Susann, who took the lurid pulp genre to a new, sweaty level. No one is more suited to playing a tease of a diva than Ms. Midler, who can wring more comedy out of operatic self-absorption than anyone else. And Mr. Lane, who plays Irving Mansfield, Susann's husand, promoter and biggest fan, is a spark plug: his voice shows up before he does. Yet in this adaptation of the material, Susann's life is flattened, made campy and cute. Sly hostility seems to be a facet of the screenwriter Paul Rudnick's talent. But Mr. Rudnick and Mr. Bergman have sodefanged "Isn't She Great" that it's like watching a sketch from the old "Carol Burnett Show" that has mildewed (Elvis Mitchell).
 
"PLAY IT TO THE BONE," starring Woody Harrelson, Antonio Banderas and Lolita Davidovich. Directed by Ron Shelton (R, 124 minutes). This screwball sports comedy stars Mr. Harrelson (with a shaved head) and Mr. Banderas as fading middleweight boxers and best friends summoned at the last minute to fight each other as the opening act for a Las Vegas heavyweight bout. The formulaic road movie follows them with their pal and mutual ex-girlfriends (Ms. Davidovich) on their wise-cracking way from Los Angeles to Las Vegas, where they fight a brutal match. The dialogue has sass, and the filmmmaker's jaudiced vision of the professional boxing world is very knowing, but the relationships don't track (Holden).
 
* "SCREAM3," starring David Arquette, Neve Campbell and Courteney Cox Arquette. Directed by Wes Craven (R, 116 minutes). At this point it goes without saying that the "Scream" movies are like episodes of "Scooby Doo." Like the others, "Scream3" belongs on the Cartoon Network. This time for a better reason: the film is funny and brisk, with enough good lines to make the comedy more satisfying than the somewhat routine but still unsettling jobs to the spine. Mr. Craven and his group recognize that the franchise's real competition is not the recent hit films "The Blair Witch Project" or "The Sixth Sense," but rather "Scream" itself. "Scream 3" doesn't skimp on jacked-up scares, but it's as much as personality show as it is a slasher film (Mitchell).
 
* "THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY," starring Matt Damon, Jude Law, Gwyneth Paltrow, Cate Blanchett and Phlip Seymour Hoffman. Written and directed by Anthony Minghella (R, 135 minutes). There are diabolically smart surprises wherever you care to look in this glittering thriller. Proving that the brilliance of "The English Patient" was no fluke, Mr. Minghella shapes a hypnotic, sensually charged adaptation of Patricia Highsmith's fascinatingly retilian murder story. The traffic-stopping cast includes Mr. Damon as the dangerous chameleon of the title and, in a star-making role the English actor Jude Law as a rich dilettante who exerts a homoerotic magnetism. Ms. Paltrow plays the odd woman out with the shrewdness of a fine character actress, while Ms. Blanchett makes the delirious most of her role as a needy American post-debutante. As the story's odious playboy-snob, Mr. Hoffman is scene-stealingly wonderful. Gorgeously photographed in Italy by Jon Seale (Maslin).
 
* "TITUS," starring Anthony Hopkins, Jessica Lange, Alan Cumming, Harry Lennix and Jonathan Rhys Meyers. Directed by Julie Taymor (R, 160 minutes). Ms. Taymor, the theater director and puppeteer who created transfixing stage pictures in "The Lion King" and "Juan Darien," has turned Shakespeare's goriest tragedy, "Titus Andronicus," into a powerful contemplation of murderous revenge enacted throughout history. Mr. Hopkins is ghoulishly funny and tragic as the title character, whose political stupidity sets in motion a devastating chain reaction of killing, torture and retaliation. Ms. Lange is Tamora, the captured Goth empress who strikes back. Although the movie's British theatrical and Ameican film acting styles don't mesh, Ms. Taymore's vision is realized with a shattering force in time-traveling imagery that blends ancient Rome with Mussolini's Italy and contemporary cyberpunk flash (Holden).
 
* "TOPSY-TURVEY," starring Allan Corduner and Jim Broadbent. Directed by Mike Leigh (R, 161 minutes). Mr. Leigh's grandly entertaining "Topsy-Turvey" is one of those films that create a mix of erudition, pageantry and delectable acting oportunities, much as "Shakespeare in Love" did last year. Instead of a love-struck young playwright, it presents the curiously matched personalities of the librettist William Schwenk Gilbert and the composer Arthur Sullivanin the midst of a robust, knowing, frequently hilarious look at the musical theater over which they held sway (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"THE AMERICAN PLACE: LANDSCAPE IN THE EARLY WESTERN (AND A FEW LATER CLASSICS)." An opportunity for a new look at the Old West is a hand at the Museum of Modern Art, where a monthlong series highlighted by early westerns is in progress. Spanning the history of the genre, the series features more than 50 films in 30 programs, including works that extend from Edwin Porter, D. W. Griffith, Thomas H. Ince, John Ford, Charles Chaplin and Allan Dwan to Victor Fleming, Victor Seastrom, Sam Peckinpah, Mel Brooks, Clint Eastwood and Jim Jarmusch. This weekend is highlighted by "Biograph's Western Heroines: Lillian Gish, Mae Marsh and Blanche Sweet." This program of four films to be shown at 2:30 p.m. today and at 5 tomorrow, consists of four films, the first three starring Sweet, who was Griffith's most spirited western heroine. These three are 15-minute 1912 films: "The Goddess of Sagebrush Gulch" and "The God Within," both directed by Griffith, and "An Outcast Among Outcasts," directed by Wilfred Lucas. The fourth feature is Griffith's 3--minute "Battle at Elderbush Gulch" (1913), with Marsh and Gish among the settlers besieged by Indians and saved by the cavalry. On all four films the cinematographer was Bily Bitzer, Griffith's longtime collaborator in the development of filmmaking technique. The screenings will have a piano accompaniment. Continuing through Feb. 24 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, the series is free with museum admission: $10 for adults, $6.50 for students and people 65 or older; free for visitors under 16 accompanied by an adult. Pay what you wish on Fridays from 4:30 to 8:30 p.m. Screening information: (212)708-9400 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 6; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 148 words

HEADLINE: Valuable 'Work Colleges'

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The value of life lessons learned at "work colleges" and other colleges stressing a blend of education and practical experience is indeed significant (news article, Feb. 6). It is mostly at work where many of us put to use the critical thinking, communication and problem-solving skills that advocates of liberal education so rightly admire. 
 At a time when 60 percent of young Americans attend college, we should recognize that curricular models created when higher education was reserved for social and economic elites need to be rethought. Rather than perpetuate the longtime opposition of a liberal arts education and practical experience, we should seek ways to nurture in our students both the impulse to grow intellectually and the desire to prepare for adulthood.
 
RICHARD M. FREELAND
President, Northeastern University
Boston, Feb. 10, 2000

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Why Not Fat and Happy?

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
There is a curious thing about the John McCain phenomenon. Populist campaigns usually arise from adversity. In this time of unprecedented prosperity, one would expect voters to be fat and happy, contented with the status quo. Why, then, are so many turning to an iconoclast, a candidate who promises to shake things up?
The answer must be that a good many Americans, however full their pockets, are discontented with something. And the something is evident: the political system. Fewer and fewer people vote: in 1996, under half of those of voting age. Why vote when you feel that policy is shaped not by your votes but by money? One observer summarizes it this way: 
 "The economic boom of the 90's has masked a looming national crisis: a corrupt political system that auctions off public policy to the highest bidder and leaves the overwhelming majority of Americans feeling alienated from their own government."
That quotation is from a new book by Arianna Huffington, "How to Overthrow the Government." Yes, the same Arianna Huffington who has so pungently argued conservative views. Her rhetoric is still pungent, but her viewpoint seems to have undergone a sea change.
The book is devastating on the flood of money into our politics. There is a certain irony in that: Her former husband, Michael, spent $28 million of his family fortune in an unsuccessful race for the Senate in 1994. She notes wryly that Al Checchi spent $40 million trying to be governor of California in 1998 -- "thankfully, for those of us named Huffington, replacing Michael Huffington as the poster child of campaign profligacy."
Lobbying is another of her targets. She describes Dwayne Andreas, chairman of Archer Daniels Midland, as "Mr. Special Interest" for his success in getting federal subsidies for ethanol. He and ADM have given more than $3 million to the parties in soft money, and they get $300 million a year in ethanol subsidies. "How this differs from Al Capone buying off judges in Chicago is a topic worthy of debate in civics class," Ms. Huffington writes.
But the book is not only about money in politics. Ms. Huffington attacks what she calls "the culture of greed" that makes the rich much richer while "more children are homeless than at any time since the Great Depression." She savages Republican attempts to abolish the estate tax for the sake of the rich.
What has happened to Arianna Huffington? I asked her that question when she was here in Boston the other day. Writing a column about politics as she does, she said, brought her "face to face with distorted priorities, the abuse of language, the neglect of poverty as a social issue. I couldn't bear to hear them going on about our prosperity."
The most striking thing in the book, for me, is Ms. Huffington's discussion of what she calls the two greatest crime problems, "the exploding prison population and the failure of the war on drugs."
The priorities of the drug war, emphasizing criminal prosecution and attempts to cut off drug supplies, are all wrong, she argues. Supplies and use have increased, and will not go down until the priority is shifted to education and treatment of addicts.
Coupled with the excesses of the drug war is the policy of mandatory minimum prison sentences for even trivial drug offenses. The policy is not only inhumane, she says, but has created an enormous social problem: two million Americans in prison, where they are being brutalized.
The drug war and long prison sentences are indeed a disaster for our country. Yet it seems impossible to do anything about them. Politicians are afraid to do anything that would make them vulnerable to charges of being "soft on crime."
That is the problem that Ms. Huffington's book underlines. We have a democratic system of government, but it seems unable to respond to urgent needs. The power of money prevents economic and political reform. In California the prison guards' union is so powerful that even the most sensible criminal law reform is blocked -- because the union wants more prisons and more prisoners.
What will break us out of the stalemate? In a democracy the answer is leadership. I have no idea whether Senator McCain would look at the drug war or poverty or health care and say it is time for a change. But people are looking for someone who might have the courage to challenge the profound flaws in the status quo. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe Constitution Vote Is a Showdown for Mugabe

BYLINE: By HENRI E. CAUVIN

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Citizens in this economically struggling nation go the polls this weekend for what is in fact, if not in name, a referendum on the only leader whom this country has known, President Robert Mugabe.
Officially, the five million voters projected to go to the polls will be voting on a new constitution, and the government has been pushing hard for a "yes" vote. 
 But opponents say the document would only solidify the president's power and, with its provisions for seizing white farmers' land without compensation, erode Zimbabwe's already diminished standing in eyes of foreign investors and donors.
"What we need now is a much better image abroad to encourage investment and confidence in our country," said Jerry Grant, deputy director of the Commercial Farmers Union, which represents 4,000 farmers, most of them white.
Even the National Constitutional Assembly, a civic organization started a few years ago by people who wanted the country to replace the constitution adopted just before independence from Britain in 1980, is urging rejection.
The showdown occurs at a crucial time for Mr. Mugabe and his Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front party, which holds all but a few seats in Parliament but is most likely to face a fierce challenge from a new opposition party when parliamentary elections are held in April.
The new party, the Movement for Democratic Change, has been attracting support across much of the country. A strong turnout against the constitution this weekend could propel the party to a strong showing in April.
"What we have is a vote of confidence or no confidence in Mugabe and in the government," the party president, Morgan Tsvangirai, said. "If a lot of people turn out and vote no, it's an indication of things to come."
For months, the economy has been staggering toward a total collapse. Inflation has soared to more than 60 percent a year.
The Zimbabwe dollar has declined dramatically against the American dollar, from 12.11 in 1997 to 38.2 at the end of 1999. Fuel and electricity shortages have plagued the country for weeks, set off by mounting back bills to suppliers.
And the International Monetary Fund has cut off its credit after it had found Zimbabwe was underreporting its considerable contributions to the war in Congo.
Many opponents say they are most angered by what they call the blatant disregard for the opinions of the many citizens who were consulted by the constitutional commission that came up with the draft.
The proposal does nothing to limit the powers of the presidency, a change that was widely advocated by many who said they favored making the presidency a ceremonial post, with a prime minister answerable to an elected parliament as the chief executive.
Nor would the proposal change the parliamentary voting system, which opponents say makes it all but impossible for new parties to crack the grip of the governing party.
What it would do -- and what has outraged the small but vocal white minority -- is give the government the right to seize white-owned farmland without paying for it. Added to the draft a few weeks ago, the provision is widely seen a crude bit of racial politicking in a country where land reform has been a painful and persistent issue since independence.
Today, Justice Minister Emmerson Mnangagwa told voters on state television that if they approved the constitutional revisions they would be more likely to receive land, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Mnangagwa said the transfer of white-owned land to landless blacks had been hindered by guarantees in the old constitution that handovers involved compensation.
The National Constitutional Assembly is hoping its campaign can keep that clause and the rest of the proposed constitution from taking effect.
At the assembly headquarters today, volunteers wearing "Vote No" T-shirts hurried about, unpacking fliers and handbills and scrambling to assemble teams to monitor polling stations.
It has been a frantic, chaotic effort, and not entirely by choice, opponents of the new constitution said. Only this morning, they pointed out, the government published an official list of polling stations. Only then could the assembly apply for accreditation for its observers.
"We're not happy with the process," Dr. Lovemore Madhuku, a lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe and the vice chairman of the assembly, said. "Everything has been completely upside down."

HEADLINE: Candidate for Senate Tries To Bask in McCain's Glow

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Senator John McCain's surging presidential candidacy is lending hope to another Republican maverick seeking higher office: the Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger, who is considered a dark-horse contender to succeed Senator Frank S. Lautenberg when he retires.
Mr. McCain's arrival at Newark International Airport this morning for a day of fund-raisers, interviews and meetings in New York and New Jersey gave Mr. Treffinger, who is trailing two other moderate Republicans in the race to raise money and collect endorsements, a chance to identify himself with Mr. McCain as a fellow crusader against what both call the Washington establishment. He did not waste the opportunity. 
 In welcoming remarks at the airport that went on so long that Mr. McCain looked a bit embarrassed, Mr. Treffinger said Senator McCain's positions on fiscal policy were nearly indistinguishable from his own. They both favor lowering taxes and cutting pork-barrel spending, strengthening Social Security and Medicare and eliminating the national debt, he said. "I share the beliefs and values and goals articulated in Senator McCain's career and in his campaign for the presidency," Mr. Treffinger said.
Above all, the two share a commitment to reform the nation's campaign finance system. Mr. Treffinger says he favors eliminating political action committees, allowing contributions from individuals only, and providing matching funds and spending caps for all candidates for federal office. He made no mention, however, of their marked differences on abortion rights, which Mr. Treffinger favors, and other social issues.
Standing shoulder to shoulder with Mr. McCain in front of the senator's "Straight Talk Express" campaign bus, Mr. Treffinger praised the senator as "a true American hero," adding, "I am very proud to join his team today."
Mr. McCain did not return Mr. Treffinger's endorsement, saying that he was pleased to receive it, but that "obviously I'm seeking the support of every citizen of New Jersey." Mr. Treffinger's chief rivals for the Senate nomination, Representative Bob Franks and State Senator William L. Gormley, have both endorsed Gov. George W. Bush.
Still, Mr. Treffinger believes that even unrequited support for Mr. McCain could help his own Senate candidacy, as he acknowledged when he said that from now on, he would end all his own campaign speeches by making a plug for the senator.
Like Mr. McCain, who said today that he was gaining support from so-called Reagan Democrats in South Carolina and elsewhere, Mr. Treffinger, a former Democrat who worked on the 1980 presidential campaign of Gary Hart, is advertising his own potential appeal to Democrats.
In a letter mailed this week to registered Republicans, Mr. Treffinger, who was elected to two consecutive terms as county executive in predominantly Democratic Essex County, asserts that he is the only Republican who can win a general election. "In every statewide election, Essex County always gives the Democrats the margin of victory they need to win," he writes. "I won in Essex County, twice."
Tom Wilson, a former chairman of the Republican state committee who is directing Mr. McCain's New Jersey efforts, drew yet another comparison between the two candidates, though a somewhat hyperbolic one. "McCain spent five and a half years in a prison camp," Mr. Wilson said. "Some might say that being a two-term Republican county executive in Essex might qualify as the same thing." 
In fact, Mr. Treffinger's relations with Democratic freeholders in Essex County have been anything but contentious.
In any event, Mr. Treffinger appears to face an uphill climb. He has little support in the southern third of the state, while Mr. Gormley, who represents the Atlantic City area, has made deep inroads in North Jersey counties. Representative Franks, meanwhile, a fellow North Jerseyan whose district includes part of Essex County, said today that he had won the endorsement of nearly every prominent official in southern Burlington County.
Mr. Treffinger suffered another setback earlier this week when Mr. Gormley's campaign complained that some radio stations had unfairly charged Mr. Treffinger's campaign discounted rates for advertisements; the radio stations agreed, and billed Mr. Treffinger's campaign for several thousand dollars more.
