HEADLINE: White House Raises Questions About Governors Island Plan

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
A month after Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced a long-awaited plan to redevelop Governors Island with parks, a conference center and museums, a senior White House official has called the proposal "only a conceptual framework" and urged the city and state to provide more details.
But the comments, by Jacob J. Lew, director of the Office of Management and Budget, ultimately concern the price that the city and state will have to pay for the island, a question that remains a sticking point with both the mayor and the governor. 
 In a Feb. 7 letter to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Mr. Lew said the island could be transferred to the city and state before the end of the year at "a nominal cost."
And although he did not specify the amount, the letter made no reference to a 1995 pledge by President Clinton to help transfer the island as surplus federal property for $1.
Mr. Lew said the island might be transferred at a bargain-basement price, but only if city and state officials act quickly, using what he called "their best efforts."
In an interview yesterday, Tony Coles, the mayor's senior adviser, said the city-state plan for the island announced in January was detailed enough to warrant a commitment from the White House, and the letter to Mr. Moynihan "talks all around the promise that was made by the president."
"We had hoped and expected that the president would come through," Mr. Coles said.
Mr. Lew's letter responded to requests to the White House from Mr. Moynihan, the mayor and other officials to help remove a Congressional barrier and allow the island to be used as a nonprofit public resource.
The barrier was created in 1997 when Congress adopted a federal budget plan that designated Governors Island an asset to be sold to the highest bidder in 2002.
On Monday, when President Clinton sent his budget proposal to Congress, it disappointed New York officials by failing to delete Governors Island from Congress's list of disposable assets.
The president's proposal merely lowered the island's estimated value to $300 million from $500 million.
That provoked angry criticism from Mayor Giuliani, who said at a news conference on Tuesday that the president may no longer intend to help transfer the island to the city and state.
"It seems to me that the president is just trying to fund some of his spending programs out of that $300 million," the mayor said.
Charles Gargano, the chief economic adviser to Governor Pataki, said the new federal estimate of the island's worth was "utter fantasy." Since the city and state intend to devote much of the island to public use, and pay for its maintenance, "its fair market value is really $1 or less," he said yesterday.
But another official said the long-awaited transfer of Governors Island for $1, or another acceptably low amount, had not been derailed.
"It was reasonable to look at the president's budget and say, 'Yikes, what is the intention,' " said Tony Bullock, the chief of staff to Senator Moynihan. "But the letter from Mr. Lew comes out saying, 'don't pay much attention to the $300 million figure.' "
"What we have to do now," Mr. Bullock said, "is get busy on the details of the plan."

HEADLINE: JOURNAL;
Why Pick a Winner? There's Boy George

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
As news of John McCain's New Hampshire landslide hit the networks, I was in Beverly Hills interviewing Warren Beatty on a subject other than his unconsummated political striptease of last fall. But Mr. Beatty can't stop talking about politics, and while he has yet to endorse a candidate, he couldn't contain his ebullience about Mr. McCain, whom he regards as a friend. Yes, the Arizona senator (like the other candidates of both parties) is well to the right of Bulworth -- even on his signature issue of campaign finance reform. But still, Mr. Beatty avows: "John is a good man."
Back East a day later, I found that as goes 90210 so goes 10021 and less glossy strongholds of the not-so-vast liberal conspiracy. It isn't easy to find a Democrat who will say an unkind word about Mr. McCain. Is this because of the media's infatuation with him, a love affair so outrageously syrupy it threatens to toss the entire nation into insulin shock? Or is it merely a mandate for his war-hero past and Trumanesque public persona? Or do liberals, disappointed by Bill Bradley's fumbled insurgency and fatigued by Al Gore's hyperventilating rhetoric, feel that secretly Mr. McCain is one of them? 
 On the last point the answer should be definitively no. As one of Mr. McCain's closest advisers, the former Senator Warren Rudman, put it somewhat overzealously on the Imus show this week, to call Mr. McCain a liberal is "like accusing Hitler of founding the B'nai B'rith." Mr. McCain's legislative record has at times earned him single-digit ratings from the Americans for Democratic Action and zero from the League of Conservation Voters. He was for all the planks in the Contract With America and each article of impeachment. He has always voted against abortion rights, and as recently as a town meeting Wednesday night said "I don't think abortion should be legal" and that Roe v. Wade should be overturned. He continues to vacillate about the symbolic meaning of the Confederate flag, and he's no fan of gun control.
Yet Democrats from Massachusetts to California are flocking to vote for him in Republican primaries, and surely not just out of a desire to make mischief for the rival party. Were Mr. McCain actually to get the Republican nomination, the greater mischief would be inflicted on the Democrats. Mr. McCain is the G.O.P. candidate who has a serious shot at ending the era of Clinton-Gore.
This is not just because Mr. Straight Talk Express is, in the character department, the archetypal un-Clinton. Nor is it just because he tilts at lobbyists and big money and champions campaign finance reform (an also-ran issue in polls of voters' priorities). The other, subtle weapon in Mr. McCain's political arsenal is that, in a brilliant coup of triangulation, he is as much the un-Kenneth Starr/un-Henry Hyde as he is the un-Clinton. He's the first major G.O.P. presidential candidate in years who is not running as a pious moral scold in hock to the religious right.
Instead of proselytizing for his own religion to get votes, Mr. McCain has described his faith as "something that's between me and my family." He was the sole G.O.P. candidate who declined an invitation to kowtow to the Christian Coalition at last fall's Road to Victory conference, and yet he did meet with the gay Log Cabin Republicans and spoke of being "proud" to have their support. He was the first Republican candidate with the guts to urge his party to show Pat Buchanan the exit.
Throw in Mr. McCain's rejection of supply-side tax cuts and you don't have a liberal, but you do have a conservative who won't scare away the moderates who decide elections. He alone has positioned himself to deflect the inevitable Gore attack that a Republican president will throw the monkey wrench of voodoo economics into a booming economy. Nor do swing voters have to worry that Mr. McCain will owe Pat Robertson or Jerry Falwell a say in public policy or that he'll be policing anyone's sex life. (Indeed Mr. McCain has readily owned up to the tomcatting in his own past.) The Arizona senator has thrown in just enough pro-choice rhetoric to beguile voters for whom abortion is a secondary issue into believing that he's not Draconian on Roe -- and, taking the bait, the National Right to Life Committee is running commercials attacking him. Mr. McCain's surly G.O.P. enemies -- hard-core right-to-lifers, Tom DeLay, Trent Lott -- may be more valuable in a national election than most G.O.P. friends.
Tough as it is to believe now, George W. Bush, the former "compassionate conservative," was initially programmed to be the candidate that Mr. McCain is -- a moderate who might appeal to independents and independent-minded Democrats who were turned off by Bill Clinton yet found the puritanical perpetrators of the Starr report even more egregious (and frightening). But Mr. Bush, falling right into the same traps as Bob Dole in '96, never got beyond his kinder, gentler slogan and is already fatally stuck to the flypaper of the religious right.
Just as Mr. Dole returned a Log Cabin contribution early in that race, making himself look intolerant and petty, so the Texas governor refused to meet with Log Cabin this time, telling Tim Russert such an encounter would be "a political nightmare." It is a nightmare -- for Mr. Bush -- and it cost him one of the country's foremost thinkers on education reform, Diane Ravitch, who resigned from his campaign on principle after he spurned Log Cabin.
Eager to please social conservatives, Mr. Bush failed to stand up to Pat Buchanan's Jew-baiting and then marketed his own sectarian religious beliefs. Like Mr. Dole in '96, he has also backed into endorsing a hard-line Human Life Amendment. As a piece de resistance this week, the tone-deaf Bush campaign fielded Ralph Reed, former executive director of the Christian Coalition, as its spokesman on "Larry King Live." There Mr. Reed had to defend the governor's appearance at Bob Jones University, a school that forbids interracial dating, ridicules Catholicism on its Web site and threatened gay alumni with arrest for trespassing should they show up on campus.
Why would Mr. Bush's campaign move so far to the right? It's the same thinking -- that you can pander to a right-wing base and hope centrist voters suffer amnesia on Election Day -- that led the G.O.P. to defeats not only in '96 but in '98. Even at the height of impeachment and even in the South, religious-right-embracing incumbents were thrown out -- including South Carolina's governor, David Beasley, North Carolina's Senator Lauch Faircloth and Alabama's governor, Fob James. Pandering to the far right in 2000 -- a time when gay couples can embrace on "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" without prompting complaints to ABC -- would seem to be more ill advised than ever, including in the increasingly globalized demographics of states like South Carolina, let alone California. Mr. Bush's campaign also seems not to recognize that in primary season 2000 -- unlike primary season '96 -- there are three, not one, all-news networks, as well as a more pervasive Internet, amplifying and codifying his every last pander.
In the fall, Mr. McCain would have little such baggage -- even as he possesses a biography that makes Governor Bush look just like what his father called him, Boy George. But Democrats who are worrying about the prospect of a race against Mr. McCain shouldn't lose sleep yet. The same G.O.P. minds that blew it in '96 and '98 are doing everything possible to shore up Mr. Bush.
Typical of their prescient thinking was the conservative pundit Robert Novak's Dec. 30 column promising that Mr. Bush's public touting of Jesus "actually enhances prospects of his wrapping up the Republican nomination by early February." On The Wall Street Journal's conservative editorial page Mr. McCain is thrashed repeatedly as a "crank," a "Clintonian," a perpetrator of an agenda with "more holes than a Harold Ickes deposition," a faux creation of his "idolators in the media." One of its sages has called Mr. McCain's tax policy a probable "fatal mistake" (even though a Time/CNN poll shows that 72 percent of Republicans in South Carolina echo Mr. McCain, not Mr. Bush, on tax cuts), and just yesterday desperately (and patronizingly) trumpeted Mr. Bush as having "a softer personality" that would appeal to women.
Doesn't softer mean weak? Well, never mind. Kamikaze thinking like this should make Gore partisans jubilant, for once again the hard right is in full froth, busily transforming a potential Republican victory into a lost cause.

HEADLINE: Fog Delay Of 3 Hours Hits JetBlue On First Flight

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Stymied only by weather, the nation's newest discount airline, JetBlue, began service yesterday in its main market -- upstate New York -- with a flight from Buffalo to Kennedy International Airport.
"When you use technology the way we do, you can be efficient," said David Neeleman, the founder and president of JetBlue. 
 He made the comments in a prepared statement moments before airline executives and dignitaries, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator Charles E. Schumer, boarded the 162-passenger A-320 Airbus, and then were kept waiting for nearly three hours by fog.
The airline hopes to operate three flights a day between New York, Buffalo and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Besides Rochester and Syracuse, the airline hopes eventually to expand to 36 cities around the country, using Kennedy as its hub.
The start up of JetBlue has industry experts and airline executives watching to see whether it can survive.
JetBlue is entering a tough market. Less than half of the 39 airlines that have begun operations in the last decade still remain, according to the federal Transportation Department.
But company officials hope that the airline's low fares, new planes and strong financial backing will keep it flying.
Mr. Neeleman, a former executive at WestJet, helped to found Morris Air, a Utah-based carrier that Southwest Airlines bought six years ago for $129 million. He said JetBlue would be profitable within a year.
To keep costs and delays to a minimum, company officials hope to capitalize on the low maintenance requirements of the new A-320 planes, which include all-leather seats and television monitors with up to 24 channels. JetBlue will officially begin its service between Buffalo and New York on Thursday. The airline expects to expand to Rochester and Syracuse within 18 months, Mr. Neeleman said.
Other low-fare airlines have been grounded for a variety of reasons, including poor finances, maintenance and safety questions and crashes. But JetBlue officials hope that their start-up will have staying power. The venture is backed by $130 million from the billionaire investor George Soros and Chase Capital Partners and is said by analysts to be the best financed airline venture since the 1950's.
"From the standpoint of initial capital, they are one of the largest, if not the largest in history," said Richard Bittenbender, a vice president and senior analyst at Moody's Investors Service.
But there is some risk, he said. "I think that the primary downside would be that to the extent the economy softens and the rest of the industry lowers its ticket prices, we could see a company with a thin operating margin that would be unable to support itself like other larger, more established companies."
The inaugural flight was scheduled to take off from Kennedy at 7:30 a.m., but did not leave the tarmac till nearly 10:30 a.m.
Just as all the financing in the world could not prevent the weather-related delay, so could the flight also not avoid a little politics during this campaign season.
Mr. Giuliani, the Republican candidate for Senate, was at the airport early, hopping from interview to interview announcing and taking some credit for the new service.
Low-cost air service has long been of concern to upstate voters and politicians who want their support, and it was a central topic in a speech that Mr. Giuliani's opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, gave on the upstate economy here on Monday.
Establishing cut-rate air routes upstate was a central campaign pledge of Senator Schumer in 1998. And JetBlue and federal aviation officials said today that it was Mr. Schumer who was largely responsible for the service.
Indeed, the mayor's place in the take-credit pecking order became clear as he stood, rocking on his heels, through a 45-minute news conference, waiting for his turn to speak. He was last.
The airline will charge $45 one way between Buffalo and Kennedy and as little as $129 round trip depending on travel time. Other airlines charge $109 to $400 for the same flight.
David S. Stempler, the president of the Air Travelers Association, a passenger advocacy group based in Washington, called JetBlue's beginning a "shot in the arm for competition" in the New York region.
American Airlines, for example, is already offering round-trip fares between Kennedy and Buffalo for as low as $109, according to company officials. Just as JetBlue has begun its services between New York and Florida, both Southwest Airlines and Delta Express have also increased their flights between Islip, N.Y., and Tampa, Fla.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA;
RATE RISE IN HONG KONG

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Hong Kong Association of Banks followed the United States Federal Reserve's lead and raised interest rates by a quarter-point. The association increased short-term savings rates to 4 percent from 3.75 percent, and the city's biggest lenders immediately began announcing rises in their benchmark retail lending rates. Hong Kong's currency is pegged to the United States dollar, so changes in United States monetary policy are often followed by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and by the bank association.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 33; Column 2; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Carving Up the Desert

BYLINE: By R. Stephen Humphreys; R. Stephen Humphreys teaches Middle Eastern history at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and is the author of "Between Memory and Desire: The Middle East in a Troubled Age," among other books.

 BODY:

EMPIRES OF THE SAND
 The Struggle for Mastery in the Middle East, 1789-1923.
 By Efraim Karsh and Inari Karsh.
 Illustrated. 409 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $29.95. 
 With "Empires of the Sand," Efraim and Inari Karsh attempt a major reinterpretation of Middle Eastern history in the "long 19th century," which stretched from the French Revolution to the final peace settlements after World War I. The importance of this period for the Middle East is immense; indeed, the whole Middle East agenda in the 20th century was laid out between 1915 and 1922.
The Ottoman Empire, which had maintained a kind of regional order for six centuries, was extinguished. Radically new national borders were established in those years, and these still stand. At the same time, the resentments and conflicts generated by the war and by the postwar settlement have been equally durable -- a shattered and embittered Armenian nation, a failed Kurdistan, an Arab world divided into suspicious small states and above all the Arab-Israeli conflict.
The story of these events has of course been told many times, but Efraim Karsh, the director of the Mediterranean studies program at King's College, the University of London, and Inari Karsh, a scholar of Middle Eastern history, believe that this story has been governed by a number of self-serving myths. Among the chief myths are the following: the Ottoman Empire in the 19th century was a helpless pawn in the hands of its far more powerful and aggressive European rivals; the European powers intended all along to dismantle the empire; the Ottomans did not enter World War I as a partner of Germany and Austria of their own free will but were either beguiled by German promises or forced to join the Central Powers by the dark designs of the Allies, especially Russia; and the revolt led by Sherif Hussein in 1916 represented a true Arab national movement.
In assaulting these myths, the Karshes bring a lot of artillery to bear, and their book is distinguished by both clear, vigorous writing and much new research. The tale of the collapse of the Ottoman Empire is hideously complicated, but they hold it all together in a narrative that is not only coherent but often dramatic. Yet in the final analysis, "Empires of the Sand" is unsatisfying and at points even annoying.
To start with, the authors' approach is startlingly old-fashioned. It is all diplomacy and war. The enormous demographic, economic, social and cultural changes that reshaped the Ottoman Empire in the 19th and early 20th centuries go almost unmentioned. One would never guess that there were huge displacements of Muslim populations from Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and the Caucasus, or that the empire's population underwent rapid growth in the decades before World War I because of improvements in public health and internal security. One could not surmise that the press in the Ottoman Empire was gaining in influence, literary culture was flourishing and education was spreading rapidly. Even in the arenas of administrative and political reform, we are given only glimpses, although Ottoman statesmen were striving not only to keep their empire together but to recast it as a modern state.
All these changes were constantly present in the minds of the empire's rulers and shaped Ottoman actions quite as much as the doings of the British, French and Russian governments. What we are given is war and diplomacy without context.
A second problem lies in the sources used -- or not used -- by the authors. They have searched the Public Record Office in London quite effectively and even found some new veins of ore in that much-exploited mine. But they seem to use only published documents from the French and German archives. Most troubling, they make very little use of the Ottoman archives, which are relatively accessible for much of the period they cover. Surely the Ottomans ought to be allowed some voice of their own.
Still another problem is the authors' habit of making blanket characterizations of motives and purposes, when the evidence they themselves present would permit very different constructions. The two principal leaders of the Arab revolt, the Sherif Hussein of Mecca and his son Faisal, are subjected to a withering critique of everything they did or said. Yet even on the facts included here, Hussein and Faisal were no worse than two ambitious men trying to hedge their bets and make the best deal they could in the chaos of the war. How were their actions in any way different from, or more corrupt and self-serving than, those of the British and French statesmen the Karshes admire?
What is finally most unsatisfying, however, is the authors' insistence that they are the first to make a serious critique of the myths they identify, when in fact every one of these myths has been subject to intense scrutiny for the last four decades. For example, Ottoman diplomatic skill in a very difficult environment has attracted increasing admiration from many scholars. And I cannot remember when the Arab revolt was not looked upon with considerable skepticism.
On the other hand, the authors might be accused of creating a countermyth of their own. Never have the intentions and actions of Russia, France and Britain in the Middle East seemed so benign. One can hardly imagine why Middle Eastern politicians and intellectuals might have feared them. It is perfectly clear, as the authors argue, that the Great Powers did not want the Ottoman Empire to collapse into chaos. Yet it is hardly arguable that they meant to dominate every aspect of life there as far as they could, and were quite ready to dismantle the empire if that was to their advantage. There is nothing particularly sinister about this -- that is how great powers have behaved since time immemorial, and how the Ottomans themselves behaved in the empire's glory days. But neither was there anything benign about it. The conduct of the Great Powers was undeniably a grave threat to the Ottomans and their way of life.
The Karshes have, as they intended, given us a controversial book, and its forceful and provocative presentation will make it an important contribution to the literature. But "Empires of the Sand" falls well short of transforming our understanding of the Middle East during the last decades of Ottoman rule.

HEADLINE: On Harassment Of Tenants

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article on tenant harassment "Is It Harassment? Or Is It the Law?," Jan. 16 confirms what tenant activists had predicted in 1997 when the rent laws were weakened to permit landlords to remove all apartments with rents over $2,000 from the rent regulatory system as they become vacant. 
 That change gave landlords a substantial economic incentive to force tenants to move out, because, once a tenant was out, landlords could, by taking advantage of vacancy increases and capital improvement pass-alongs, increase the rents over $2,000 and be relieved of any form of rent regulation.
While few landlords may use physical violence, the kinds of harassment described in the article -- and observed every day by tenant lawyers and organizers -- are no less devastating for tenants.
Your article should be required reading for the City Council members when they consider the extension of the rent laws this spring, so that they will appreciate that further weakening of the rent laws will lead to yet greater harassment.
 
ELLEN GESMER
Gulielmetti & Gesmer, P.C.
Manhattan
 
The writer was a public member of the Rent Guidelines Board from 1990 to 1992. Gulielmetti & Gesmer litigates in housing and real estate law.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report;
Lights, Action in France For Second Disney Park

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
THE early struggles of Disneyland Paris, which the Walt Disney Company opened at Marne-la-Vallee east of Paris in 1992, may have led some to believe that Europeans don't like amusement parks. But in fact, the eventual huge success of the park prompted Disney to announce in September that it would build a second theme park next door to the first.
The leftist Paris daily Liberation recalled that some had described the arrival of the first park as a "cultural Chernobyl." Yet that did not deter Disney, which owns 39 percent of the company that runs Disneyland Paris, from announcing plans for a new $615 million, 62-acre park that will focus on film studios, animation and television. The official opening is planned for April 2002, 10 years from the inauguration of the first park. Nor did it discourage the French authorities, who are delighted with the prospect of 5,000 jobs that the new park is expected to generate. 
 Whatever some Europeans may think about theme parks, the majority seem to be voting with their feet. In the year that ended Sept. 30, Disneyland Paris drew over 12.5 million visitors, more than any other attraction in France. Only about 41 percent were from France, with 17 percent from Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands, 15 percent from Britain and 10 percent from Germany.
"In California, we needed 35 years to reach those results, even though the park there is larger," said Gilles Pelisson, chief executive of Euro Disney S.A., the company that operates the French Disney park.
The planned studio park is not a first for Europe. A park called Movie World near Bottrop, Germany was recently sold by Warner Brothers, the film and entertainment unit of Time Warner, to an American company called Premier Parks; Warner Brothers and Premier are building another movie park outside Madrid, to open in 2002.
The Disney project in France will have the familiar features: Guided tours of television and movie studios, demonstrations of special effects, a half-hour stunt show in which actors portraying secret agents attempt to arrest a band of terrorists on a set that recreates a Mediterranean village.
Disney's entry into the world of European theme parks was not an easy one. Disney spent roughly $5 billion, much of it borrowed, to develop the original park, only to swing open its pink Victorian gingerbread gatehouse in 1992 in the midst of a European recession. The park's hotels drew so few guests that some had to be shuttered temporarily. To hold costs down, Disney kept salaries low, which over the years has led to strikes by disgruntled employees, mainly low-paid performers.
Moreover, Disney's original marketing strategy for the park proved a flop. Originally named Euro Disneyland, signaling the parent company's intention to reach out beyond France to all of Europe, the park was soon quietly rebaptized Disneyland Paris, in recognition of the need to focus on national markets. Advertising for the park was also redesigned along national lines, taking into account the fact that features of the park that appealed, say, to Germans would not be the same ones that drew Dutch or British visitors. Wine was added to Disney menus, an omission that had irritated the French, and perhaps most important, ticket prices were temporarily reduced.
Thanks to these initiatives, annual attendance quickly took off. By the mid-1990's, Disneyland Paris was attracting more than 9 million visitors a year. Still, as the interest burden on Euro Disney's debt caused financial losses to mount, the company was forced in 1995 to obtain a five-year debt rescheduling agreement from banks and forfeiture of management fees from the parent Walt Disney Company.
For the fiscal year 1998-99, which ended Sept. 30, Euro Disney recently reported a $24 million net profit. Though that was 46 percent less than the year before, the drop was attributed mainly to a resumption of Euro Disney's payment of management fees to the Walt Disney Company and to stagnant attendance, which was hurt by the World Cup soccer tournament in France in the summer of 1998. Even so, Disney was buoyed by the rise in occupancy rates at the six big hotels at Disneyland Paris to 82.6 percent for the year that ended in September, from 80.9 percent the year before.
So successful has Disneyland Paris been at drawing crowds that some local politicians in the Marne-la-Vallee area are growing nervous. Euro Disney is pushing to increase the returns on land it bought in the early phase of the project, and this spring a megamall built by an outside developer and designed to be Europe's largest is set to open at Serris, next door to the original park. On one weekend in late October, when crowds flooded into Disneyland Paris, highways leading to the park were completely blocked by traffic. The addition of the Serris mall, plus the new park, some local leaders say, will lead to continuous gridlock.
In November, the local Communist Party demanded an immediate study of the possible impact the mall and park will have on local roads; not to be outdone, the conservative Assembly for the Republic appealed to the ministers in Paris responsible for transportation and the environment for early action to double the size of the A4 highway that links the French capital and the park.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 22; Column 2; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 1004 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 2-13-00: On Language;
Broadband

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
His necktie was defiantly ripped away. His old-fashioned mustache was shaved off. All but rocking on the soles of his feet and snapping his fingers to illustrate his with-it-ness, the new boss of AOL Time Warner Inc. announced to the world, "I am a broadband person."
As if that transmogrification were not enough, Gerald M. Levin, age 60 1/2 -- and until now a fairly dignified executive -- added plaintively that "I'm an interactive guy." But interactive is yesterday's word, for years meaning "acting upon each other" and then meaning "reciprocating by electronic means"; now used mainly by aging Wunderkinder straining to keep pace, it awaits the coinage of its opposite, interinactive, "a one-way flow of data." Hip, connected e-lexies in this winter of our content provision focused on his broadband personhood. 
 That word has a glorious history in the northern dialects of Britain. "The verie euill thoughts of the wicked," wrote Zachary Boyd in "Last Battell," his 1629 masterpiece, "in that day shalbe spread out and laide in broad-band before the face of God." James O. Halliwell, in his 1847 Dictionary of Archaic and Provincial Words, reminded us that a band was a space 20 yards square, and broad-band was "corn laid out in the sheaf on the band, and spread out to dry after rain."
Over three centuries, the band evolved from a marked-out strip of land into "a range of radio frequencies or wavelengths." In 1956, W. A. Heflin's U.S. Air Force Dictionary defined broadband as "a band having a wide range of frequencies." In our time, it morphed into a medium that not only transmits a wide range of radio, video and data signals, but also can carry other independent channels in their own bandwidths, or space on the band. (On these multiple spaces the communicators still seem to lay out wet corn.)
Then metaphor began to beat the broadband. The adjective (sometimes hyphenated) is still used to describe multiplex communications networks, but in more sweeping terms. "In a broad-band world," wrote Andrew Sullivan in The New York Times, "even the distinctions among telephone wires, cables and satellites will be erased. There will be one cultural-economic tube." The Milwaukee Journal Sentinal wrote of "the broad-band war, the struggle over who will control the ability to deliver seamless streams of data to consumers."
And now, in an interinactive linguistic breakthrough, Mr. Levin has extended the metaphor from networks to human beings. "I am a broadband person" means more, in my view, than "I work in an industry characterized by simultaneous transmission of multiple channels." It means that he sees himself as a person with broadband personal characteristics -- able to think, speak, gesture, persuade, broadcast and data-disseminate in an unlimited way, while chewing gum at the same time.
Look at yourself, dear reader. Are you a narrowband person, cribbed, cabin'd and confined in a strait gate -- or are you the sort whose mind ranges far out over the amber waves of corn? By rejecting the "verie euill thoughts of the wicked," you, too, can mega-merge yourself into a broadband person.
If that's your choice, move quickly to so identify yourself, because telecommuning lingo changes fast, and broadband is sure to be crowded out soon.
 
The Agnostic Bit
"Bits are agnostic," Bill Gates, self-dethroned boss of Microsoft, told Forbes's ASAP magazine. "They don't care how they get where they are going -- only that they arrive in the right order and at the right moment."
William Marmon of Chevy Chase, Md., demands a ruling as soon as possible: "Has agnostic -- holding the belief that the ultimate reality on matters such as the existence of God is unknowable' -- been successfully morphed by high tech to mean 'indifferent'? Everywhere one hears the word used in this perverted manner. Where do you stand?"
Hier stehe ich, in the phrase of one unwaveringly opinionated Worms dieter. In theology and usage, I react religiously.
The etymology of agnostic is plain. It's Greek for "not known." Here's how it was coined to describe the position held by people who are neither atheists nor believers: "It was suggested by Professor Thomas Huxley at a party . . . one evening in 1869, in my hearing," wrote R.H. Hutton in 1881. "He took it from St. Paul's mention of the altar to 'the Unknown God.' "
Henry Kissinger, in his 1979 memoirs, "The White House Years," was among the first to give the word a metaphoric stretch: "I favored European unity, but I was agnostic about the form it should take." The intended meaning (I have always been able to read Henry's mind) was more "noncommittal" than either "undecided" or "indifferent." In 1983 Warren Buffett, the investor, treated the word as a verbal shrug: "I look at stocks, not markets. I am a market agnostic."
Broadbandniks in the computer world have adopted that stretch toward neutrality. "We will deliver 'infrastructure agnostic' solutions," announced Steven Francesco, C.E.O. of N(x) Networks, "that can handle both voice and data and be deployed over virtually any network." (The odd-looking company name is pronounced "nex" or "nix"; the new agnostics, professing a hands-off attitude, sometimes take a negative approach.)
Another computer executive, holding that the alliance of Dell and Red Hat came as no surprise, commented, "They've always been operating-system agnostic." At Microsoft, Gates's usage gives the reheated term about bits a sense of "indifferent" to the point of "uncaring."
Can we ever know if this new meaning -- as in "Frankly, Scarlett, I'm agnostic" -- will overtake the theological sense?
Sure we can. Give the voguish jargon a little time; this anomie-tooism will pass because it is a highbrow term that lacks specificity. Neutral passively takes no side; noncommittal suggests a more active refusal to take a side; indifferent describes a mild state of apathy; unconcerned imputes aloofness; and uncaring has a hint of cruelty. But the new agnostic wanders all over the lot. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Q. & A.;
A Buzzer That Kept Buzzing

 BODY:
Q I live in a rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper West Side. A few weeks ago, the buzzer system in the building went awry and was buzzing constantly. Tenants who called the owner's office were assured that someone would fix the problem by the end of that day, as the next day was a legal holiday. The buzzer was not repaired as promised and was going all night, keeping me and other tenants awake. I called a 24-hour locksmith and paid out of pocket for the buzzer to be disconnected. When I sent the receipt in with a reduced rent check the following month, the owner returned both the receipt and the check with a letter saying that the deduction was "unapproved and unacceptable." How do I get him to reimburse me without going to Housing or Small Claims Court? . . . Madeleine Tress, Manhattan.
A David Ng, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said that while the letter writer could file a complaint for diminution of services with the state Division of Housing and Community Renewal, that would not be useful since the problem was quickly resolved by the letter writer herself. 
 Accordingly, Mr. Ng said, unless the landlord can be persuaded to reimburse the letter writer voluntarily for the amount of the repair, there would be two basic options remaining, both of which involve judicial intervention.
The first, he said, would be to sue the landlord in Small Claims Court -- an option that requires the letter writer to take the initiative. The second would be for the letter writer to continue to withhold the money from the rent and wait for the landlord to bring a nonpayment action in Housing Court. When that happened, Mr. Ng said, the tenant could raise as a defense the necessity for calling the locksmith to fix the broken buzzer.
The judge, in making a decision on whether the defense is valid, would likely make a determination on whether the tenant provided sufficient notice of the problem to the landlord and whether the tenant's action in calling the locksmith was reasonable. If so, Mr. Ng said, the court would then make a determination on whether the amount charged by the locksmith was reasonable.
 
Responsibility for Water Damage
Q We live in a co-op apartment. The upstairs neighbor's defective refrigerator icemaker caused a severe leak into one of our dining room walls. Since the room has not been painted for some years, the same color paint is not obtainable, thus necessitating repainting the entire room. What are we entitled to, the paint necessary to paint the room or the paint plus the fee that that the painter will charge? . . . Bonnie Dwork, Forest Hills, N.Y.
A Ronni Lynn Arougheti, a lawyer who is president of Heron Ltd., a Manhattan property management company, said that since the damage was caused by the upstairs neighbor, the neighbor would be responsible for compensating the letter writer for her loss. And since it is now impossible to match the paint on the damaged wall with the paint on the undamaged ones, Ms. Arougheti said, it is likely that the neighbor would ultimately be responsible for the cost of painting the entire room.
However, she said, if the letter writer has insurance, she should first submit a claim through her insurance carrier, who would then go after the neighbor for reimbursement.
"This is a prime example of why all shareholders should carry homeowners' insurance," Ms. Arougheti said.
If the letter writer does not have insurance, she said, she could file an action against the neighbor in Small Claims Court if the neighbor does not voluntarily agree to pay for repainting the room.

HEADLINE: FILM;
L.A. Noir or College Comedy, the Genre Is Real Life

BYLINE: By MICHAEL SRAGOW; Michael Sragow writes about movies for Salon.com. He is writing a biography of the director Victor Fleming.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
THEY always want you to do what they've seen you do before," says Curtis Hanson, who last directed (and co-wrote) that extravagant blend of slam-bang police saga and character study, "L. A. Confidential."
In his new film, "Wonder Boys" (opening Feb. 25), Mr. Hanson has outwitted Hollywood's powers that be. With the help of his star, Michael Douglas ("the motor of this movie"), he has taken Michael Chabon's ebullient novel, set in and around an English department at a Pittsburgh college, and come up with a different kind of movie. It's a pothead picaresque, a contemporary screwball comedy-drama with a mellow emotional tang. 
 Mr. Douglas plays the middle-aged creative-writing teacher Grady Tripp, a once-hot novelist unable to complete his latest work. (He is currently on Page 2,611.) Tobey Maguire co-stars as Tripp's most formidable student, James Leer, a weirdly talented prevaricator poised to overtake his mentor in accomplishment and glory.
But the director insists that his film is only partly about writers confronting "past promise and future success, and chances for renewal." This movie, says Mr. Hanson, "isn't all about writing; it's about characters who think that it's all about writing. And they find out that it's not."
Mr. Hanson has never been a wonder boy, at least not in the sense of enjoying an overnight sensation. Although he has had his share of commercial triumph (with the 1992 evil-nanny thriller "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle"), it took him decades to reach the forefront of American moviemakers.
He started out as a screenwriter (notably for the 1978 suspense film "Silent Partner"), turned director with exploitation films and youth movies like the engaging comedy "Losin' It" (1983) and had his breakthrough as a writer-director with the skilled Hitchcockian pastiche "The Bedroom Window" (1988).
It was just three years ago that "L. A. Confidential" raised Mr. Hanson to master-craftsman status. This simultaneously sweeping and incisive adaptation of James Ellroy's epic period crime novel took home all the major critics' awards in 1997 and won Mr. Hanson and his co-writer, Brian Helgeland, the Academy Award for best adapted screenplay. By the time that happened, says Mr. Hanson, "I had worked too long and hard to attain a position that would allow me to make movies I wanted to make" to let the burden of success derail him.
But in another sense, Mr. Hanson is a wonder boy -- or maybe a wonder man. Speak to him about great novels or movies, and you get intelligent enthusiasm raised to the level of awe. Unlike generations of film school and video store movie brats, he is a gifted autodidact who never separated his love for moviemaking from his love for all types of storytelling and who, as a high school dropout (from Tarzana, Calif.), learned his way around a film set as a photographer and journalist. For example, when some pictures he took of Faye Dunaway helped win her the female lead in "Bonnie and Clyde," Mr. Hanson had the leverage to hang out during the filming in Texas and interview Arthur Penn and Warren Beatty. The editor of "Bonnie and Clyde," Dede Allen, became his editor on "Wonder Boys."
As the chairman of the U.C.L.A. Film and Television Archive (the first one to be appointed), Mr. Hanson was busy mounting a Billy Wilder retrospective while completing post-production work on "Wonder Boys." Hoping to arouse interest in the program among students whose collective memory dates back to "Reservoir Dogs," he was co-host for a recent series of double bills with present-day film school idols: on the final night, David O. Russell ("Three Kings") helped him introduce "Sunset Boulevard" and "The Lost Weekend."
That back-and-forth approach informs his moviemaking. "L. A. Confidential" did justice to Mr. Ellroy's juicy material about the collision of power, celebrity and economic development in Los Angeles of the 1950's. But it used all that fresh content about L.A.'s underbelly (and Mr. Hanson's novel ideas about ambience and lighting) to revive the heightened, stylized world of adult drives and emotions where many of Hollywood's classic melodramas took place.
"The big thrill of making 'L. A. Confidential,' " Mr. Hanson recently said over dinner in West Hollywood, "was that I got a phone call from Billy Wilder inviting me to meet him at his office. And as soon as I walked in he said, 'Next you want to do a comedy, right?' And I said, you're right, how did you know? And he said: 'I felt the same way after I did 'Double Indemnity' and 'The Lost Weekend.' The trouble is, getting them to let you.' "
Not even Mr. Wilder, whose comedy credits range from "Some Like It Hot" to "Kiss Me, Stupid," ever made a movie like "Wonder Boys," in which the slapstick complications keep getting pushed to the side to make room for psychological complexities. Its characters are as stoned and libidinous as they are literary, yet Mr. Hanson keeps them moving according to a woozy kind of clockwork.
TRIPP'S randy gay editor, Terry Crabtree (Robert Downey Jr.), comes visiting and sniffing for the long-promised manuscript; Tripp's wife leaves him; Tripp's mistress, the college chancellor Sara Gaskell (Frances McDormand) -- who is married to the head of the English department, Walter Gaskell (Richard Thomas) -- announces to Tripp that she is carrying his baby. All this happens right before the kickoff of a campus literary festival ("WordFest"), which features speakers like a wily blockbuster writer known as "Q" (Rip Torn). Before long, Tripp's protege, Leer, shoots the Gaskells' blind bulldog and steals Walter's prize possession: the jacket Marilyn Monroe wore when she married Joe DiMaggio.
This movie is not just some gimcrack farce. Mr. Hanson says, "When I was about to launch into the project, people said, 'You're smart to do something so different,' which on the surface it is. But it was very similar to 'L. A. Confidential' in the degree of emotional involvement I had with all these characters. Each has a yearning for family and a fear of family. They're all wrestling with what the hell they should be doing with their lives."
The thrillers Mr. Hanson made as a director for hire before "L. A. Confidential" were also filled with doppelgangers, illusion versus reality games and troubled relationships and marriages -- all the stuff of identity-crisis comedy and drama. Mr. Hanson patterned these ingredients to lend texture to the plots, and to give actors like Rob Lowe (in "Bad Influence," 1990), Julianne Moore (in "The Hand That Rocks the Cradle") and Meryl Streep and Kevin Bacon (in "The River Wild," 1994) bouncy subtexts. In his most recent films, though, these elements bubble up, naturally and unpredictably, from a rich and humanistic take on life.
"L. A. Confidential" was a box office disappointment, but it upped Mr. Hanson's standing with actors, who admired the performances he got from the likes of Russell Crowe and Kim Basinger. "They looked at the performances in some of my other films, and began to see a continuity," he says.
"What this can mean is that you have better success with actors when you're trying to get them into your project. But in this case it meant that Michael Douglas was interested in the 'Wonder Boys' script, and communicated that interest to me. I read it based on that, with Michael in mind."
The book's Tripp is obese and classifies himself as "homely." So, as Michael Chabon said by telephone from Berkeley, the novelist assumed from the start that "whoever they got was going to look different."
"I was pleased when it became Michael Douglas because he would get the movie made, but the more I thought about it the more I realized he had this kind of character in him," Mr. Chabon continued. "I thought back to 'The China Syndrome,' where he played kind of a longhair, and to 'The Streets of San Francisco,' where even though he was playing a cop he was loose and rangy, and you thought there might be a joint in the breast pocket of his tweed jacket."
Mr. Hanson understood that Grady Tripp was not just emotionally and intellectually adrift: he was a benign, accepting man who endeavored to help James Leer as an unconscious tryout for fatherhood. "The essence of this character keys into the difference between Michael and his father, Kirk," says Mr. Hanson. "There's a vulnerability Michael has -- a softness, if you will -- that he's not afraid to expose, along with a humor, and a lightness. I thought he could be funny without working at it. That's what convinced me he could do it."
What clinched the deal for the superstitious Mr. Hanson was that his own first name popped up twice in the novel, along with a character based on H. P. Lovecraft, whose "Dunwich Horror" he had adapted in 1970. Plus, the actress Elizabeth McGovern had once advised Mr. Hanson to work with the screenwriter Steve Kloves -- she said, "You're both serious, but you both make me laugh" -- and Mr. Kloves's name was on this script. Mr. Kloves is best known as the writer-director of "The Fabulous Baker Boys" (1989); he had never before done an adaptation. And because of the novel's gamboling form and pothead hero, a lot of writers would have agreed with Mr. Chabon that "it wasn't the most obvious candidate for a movie." But Mr. Kloves says that this lack of obviousness made it seem obvious to him, "because I love the films of the late 60's and early 70's."
Mr. Chabon encouraged him to make the material his own, even if it meant deleting whole sections in an effort to focus the action and keep it both absurd and believable on-screen. (To those who have read the book, it registers as an in joke that Tripp's eccentric Jewish in-laws are now proper Yankees who live in a house that is "a great place to wake up on Christmas morning.") Intense script work continued when Mr. Hanson entered the picture.
Mr. Kloves says: "Curtis is more naturally drawn to being clear than I am. But he's clever about clarity. He doesn't hit the audience on the head 17 times. And he goes to great depths when he thinks about a scene. When he presents ideas, he thinks them through -- he knows how they will affect the fabric four scenes down."
With all the trims and changes, the story is still a loosey-goosey fable about the perils to maturity that lurk in the adolescent quasi-bohemia of a college campus. (It is quite an achievement for a director who never finished high school.) The film says that life as well as literature is about holding to hard choices. And that is how Mr. Hanson makes his movies.
"Wonder Boys" starts with Tripp reading a student's story, then beginning his voice-over narration -- over his own voice. It's as if the filmmaker is signaling, "Pay attention!" Mr. Hanson hoped the movie would seem "unthought-out," but also wanted every detail to add to the total effect. For example, it made more sense to him for the self-dramatizing James Leer to be a fan of Douglas Sirk and William Inge ("another wonder boy") than a devotee of Frank Capra, as he is in the book. And the film's visual poetry is the kind that sneaks up on you. "It's partly just Pittsburgh in the winter," says Mr. Hanson. In a typically beautiful, unstressed nocturnal car shot, the viewer sees, in the director's words, "the furnaces and the factories of Pittsburgh glowing behind James Leer, the one whose future lies before him," while darkness shrouds the driver, Grady Tripp.
As a Bob Dylan buff since childhood and a devotee of his score for "Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid," Mr. Hanson thought that Mr. Dylan's work would be an ideal musical expression of Tripp's taste and character. Luckily, Mr. Dylan was a fan of "L. A. Confidential." He visited the "Wonder Boys" editing rooms, and watched an hour and a half of rough-cut footage. "One day a little package arrived with a CD in it," Mr. Hanson recalls. "Can you imagine? I popped it into the player and heard a song with Dylan's unique imagery, about being 'in love with a woman who doesn't appeal to me,' and success, and things out of the movie that are also things he knows more about than any of us." (In addition to Dylan's song, Mr. Hanson built the score around nine singer-songwriters, including Leonard Cohen and Neil Young, and used three other Dylan numbers.)
At the outset, Mr. Hanson told Mr. Chabon that the best director for his novel would have been Hal Ashby ("The Landlord,""Shampoo"), because of his embrace of humanity in all its quirks and failings. Yet Mr. Hanson seems more like Ashby's mentor, William Wyler: he charges every frame in a way that sets off the vitality of his performers. "Wonder Boys" leaves you with a gallery of eloquent faces, from the fuzzily anxious Mr. Douglas and the sometimes haunted, sometimes goofy Mr. Maguire to the effervescent Mr. Downey, who brings to his part the comic charisma of the young Jack Lemmon.
Indeed, Mr. Hanson's adept handling of large, diverse ensembles -- even more than his yen to tell engulfing stories -- may be what gives his latest films their depth and dash. It is as if, by playing straight with the living figures in front of him, he is staying true to what he sees as the ultimate theme of "Wonder Boys": "Without life," he says, "there is no art."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
State Expected to Change Affordable Housing Law

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
THE General Assembly is expected to enact changes in Connecticut's 11-year-old Affordable Housing Appeals Law in April, based on recommendations made earlier this month by Gov. John G. Rowland's Commission to Study Affordable Housing.
The recommendations, arrived at after six months of deliberations by a 30-member commission composed of municipal officials, union organizers, developers, housing advocates and members of the state legislature, are intended to increase the amount of affordable housing in Connecticut. 
 They are also designed to give the towns more leverage in rejecting affordable housing proposals, which many of them have opposed for, among other reasons, size, density, impact on schools and town services and environmental objections.
Representative Patrick J. Flaherty, a Coventry Democrat who is co-chairman of the commission, said public hearings would be held in Hartford this month on nine bills embodying 44 recommendations before being sent to legislative committees in March.
Reactions to the report by developers were swift and negative. "By agreeing with low-income housing proponents and creating more onerous income restrictions, the commission has produced a chilling effect on the private sector," said Samuel Fuller, regional vice president of AvalonBay Communities, builders of luxury rental complexes.AvalonBay has used the law's requirements that towns make a range of housing available to overcome resistance to its large apartment houses.
The report recommends increasing the number of required affordable units in a development from 25 to 30 percent, and reducing the income eligibility level from 80 percent of the area or state median income (whichever is lower) to 60 percent for half of the affordable units, 80 percent for the rest. Developers receive a negotiable bonus of additional units when they use the law.
"We would have to get free land in a city like Stamford," said Mr. Fuller, "in order to get a return that investors would accept. In towns with snob zoning where affordable housing was targeted by the law, there is no way to build rental housing without the carrot of the law."
A goal of the original law was to have an inventory of affordable housing amounting to 10 percent of all dwellings in every municipality. But as communities grew the 10 percent climbed proportionately until towns lost hope of achieving it.
The larger municipalities of Bridgeport, Hartford, New Haven and Danbury have reached or exceeded the 10 percent goal. In southwestern Fairfield County, Greenwich, with 5.20 percent, has done better than its wealthy neighbors -- Darien, New Canaan, Wilton and Westport -- with around 2 percent.
Scarcity of land in the area has driven housing costs up to unprecedented levels, making Stamford and the surrounding gold coast towns anomalous to the rest of the state.
"The suburbs of Stamford," said Joe McGee, a vice president at SACIA: Business Council of Southwestern Connecticut, "drive up the median income to $94,300, among the highest in the nation. You are eligible for affordable housing if you earn $75,000 a year. The impact has been that when developers build they can meet criteria for affordables at the highest end, driving out people at the $45,000 a year level. We have many workers earning $55,000 a year who can't find housing. It's a quirk in the formula."
The state median, Mr. McGee said, is around $60,000.
"We have a crisis in housing," he said, "impacting our ability to grow our economy. Developers are obviously upset, but you can't establish public policy based on the needs of developers."
Jay Fisher, president of Griffin Land & Nurseries, which has proposed a 640-unit subdivision in Bloomfield, agrees that "anything that makes it more expensive to build is a deterrent, which is why wealthy towns want to push it that way."
In hammering out a series of compromises, Greg Ugalde, a commission member from Torrington who is chairman of the Developers' Council of Connecticut, said that the report "recognized some of the concerns that towns have as well as recognizing the need for more affordable housing."
He called a moratorium recommendation "very exciting for the towns." Under the proposal, a community that has affordable housing equal to 2 percent of its total dwellings is eligible for a three-year moratorium on building more. The town may continue adding to the supply in 2 percent increments, until it reaches 10 percent when it becomes exempt from the regulations.
"Many of us felt this will encourage towns to create more units, working toward a moratorium," said Mr. Ugalde.
The root of the problem, said Rick Redniss, a Stamford land use consultant and a commission member, "is the fact that most of Connecticut's 169 towns never enacted zoning regulations that encourage affordable housing, in direct violation of the purpose of the law."
According to Tim Hollister, a Hartford lawyer who specializes in affordable housing issues, "the law now requires regulations but without a deadline, so less than half of the towns have them."
THE report recommends setting a deadline for enacting a set of model zoning regulations for creating affordable housing. They would be devised by the state's Department of Economic and Community Development and distributed statewide, providing towns and developers with guidelines. Currently, planning and zoning officials are confronted with developers' proposals that do not comply with local zoning, or which attempt to create new zoning. Two members of the commission -- Vincent Ditchkus Jr., a Milford alderman, and Dr. Stephen Katz, a Milford psychologist -- issued a minority report. "The best thing is to repeal the law," said Mr. Ditchkus. "They have pitted the cities against the suburbs, and the suburbs should fight back. Developers have the upper hand over small towns by using the law as blackmail to build what they want."
State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Greenwich Republican who was not a commission member, opposed the existing law from its inception. "It assumes that planning and zoning officials are wrong and they bear the burden of proving they are right. That is unheard of in Connecticut law," he said.
Under the affordable housing law a town must prove that an affordable housing project is a threat to the public welfare if it rejects a developer's application. Developers have tended to prevail in court, or in negotiations at the local level when towns are reluctant to defend a lawsuit.
Diane Fox, the town planner in Greenwich, served on the commission and believes that its recommendations, if enacted, will have a positive effect on the towns. "The increase in units," she said, "and the increase from 30 to 50 years during which affordable units must remain so may give more teeth to municipalities." Under the existing law, affordable units go to the market rate after 30 years.
Since 1989 fewer than 2,000 affordable housing units statewide have been created using the law, according to informal statistics gathered by Mr. Hollister, the Hartford lawyer. Moreover, according to a report by the Connecticut office of Fannie Mae, the nation's largest provider of mortgage funds, , 68,000 new units are required to meet current needs and 48,000 households pay 50 percent or more of their income for housing. (Fannie Mae, formerly the Federal National Mortgage Association, is the nation's largest purchaser of home mortgages on the secondary market.)
"While I have concerns about whether we are undermining affordable set-aside units the percentage of housing units sold or rented below market rate by making development more difficult," said Mr. Hollister, "I supported the commission's recommendations to see whether they will work or not."
Successful challenges to the law had been rare since its enactment. But that began to change last spring when the State Supreme Court and the Superior Courts of New Britain and Bridgeport ruled in favor of Glastonbury, Newtown and Bridgewater in rejecting affordable housing applications. Vulnerability of potable water sources, open space, and septic systems -- concerns that were negligible 10 years earlier -- emerged as new reasons to oppose the law.
In addition to recommendations for change, the commission wants more financial support for housing from the state.
"That includes use of $50 million of an expected $200 million surplus for the year 2000 with which to create a Housing Trust Fund, and a $20 million Affordable Housing Incentive Fund," said Representative Flaherty, the commission's co-chairman. The amounts are intended to offset the reduction in state bonding for affordable housing from $125 million in 1989 to $5 million last year.
The Housing Trust Fund would be used to further racial and economic integration by, among other things, expanding multifamily rental housing opportunities in suburban and rural communities and homeownership in central cities. The Affordable Housing Incentive Fund would reward municipalities that built new affordable housing to adequately cover the additional services required by the housing.
"The idea of the existing law," said Eric Schwartz, president of Pemberwick Associates, second generation developers of market rate and affordable housing in Greenwich, "was to create an incentive for developers to build projects that made economic sense for them, while providing the affordable housing stock necessary throughout the state. It's become a case of cities against towns. Cities have plenty, and they want towns to share the burden."

HEADLINE: The View From/Guilford;
State's Rose Business Hangs On -- Just Barely

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH roses are going to be delivered all over the state tomorrow, it's a safe bet that most of them were grown any place but here. Roses have never been a huge crop in the state and if it weren't for William Pinchbeck, the business would be dead in Connecticut.
Mr. Pinchbeck, 67, who runs William Pinchbeck Inc., on the Post Road in Guilford, is the last man standing in the state's rose business. The company has been around for about 70 years and Mr. Pinchbeck said he sells about $1 million worth of roses a year. 
 Shirley Ferris, the state commissioner of agriculture , said the Pinchbecks have succeeded for one reason:
"They have paid a lot of attention to their market," said Ms. Ferris. "The Pinchbecks, who grow wonderful roses, sell within Connecticut and deliver to the New York market. They saw the market, reached out to the market and it sustained them."
Rose growing is fast disappearing as a national crop. In 1968 there were 347 growers. In 1998, the latest year that figures are available, 132 rose growers survive, said James Krone, executive vice president of Roses Inc., the greenhouse rose growers association in Haslett, Mich. He said 409 million roses were sold in the United States in 1968, all of them grown domestically. In 1998, 1.3 billion roses were sold, but only 325 million were domestic. The rest were imported.
"The grower losses, indeed, have been significant," Mr. Krone said. "Without question, the primary cause is low-cost imports of fresh cut flowers."
He said most roses are grown in Columbia and Ecuador because of the cheap labor there. South American roses account for between 70 and 80 percent of the roses sold in the United States.
According to Bob Heffernan, executive secretary of the Connecticut Nursery and Landscape Association, from 1960 to 1980 there were three or four growers in the state. The largest, Pierson's, went out of business after a century in 1991 at the height of the recession.
How has Mr. Pinchbeck survived in a field where others have failed? "They kept a close eye on costs," Mr. Heffernan said.
Although the greenhouse recently had dripping icicles hanging along the roof line, the inside was toasty warm and moist. It is heated in fall and winter by steam that the Pinchbecks produce by burning sawdust, wood chips, old pallets and ground up Christmas trees.
"That's what's kept us in business," Mr. Pinchbeck said. At the height of the energy crisis in 1973, he made the switch from oil to wood. In summer, they use natural gas.
Mr. Pinchbeck has been joined in the business by his son Tom, 35, the fourth generation in the rose business. Tom Pinchbeck explained that the two major costs in growing roses are fuel and labor. "Not too many young people want to go into agriculture around here," he said. Their work force of 35 comes mostly from Puerto Rico and Mexico. Both Pinchbecks have mastered Spanish.
"They can tell us about their family problems back home and we can ask them to please not take vacation the week before Valentine's Day," William Pinchbeck said.
The Pinchbecks have developed other strategies to remain competitive. They own a fleet of second-hand delivery vans so they can control the quality of their product. They do their own equipment maintenance. They specialize in a type of rose called Forever Yours that is dark velvety red. It has been so successful that the deep red rose has decorated the plush New York Plaza Hotel. "This is an exquisite rose," said Matthew Kolins of Atlas Floral Decorators located at the hotel. "It opens quickly and is beautiful, very fragrant with a rich color."
They continue to seek out innovations such as new colors. They are considering adding a sunny yellow rose called Excitement to the 15 varieties they raise.
"We try to stay away from fad colors," said the younger Mr. Pinchbeck.
He recently returned from a trip to Holland where he saw roses in terra cotta and a near black that he does not plan to raise. "We are always trying to keep abreast of changes which fit into our style of growing," he said. "I learned a lot. The Dutch are very big on technology with more emphasis on machinery."
They are gradually switching their stock from soil-based roots to pots of coir, a shredded coconut husk that holds water and air. They place the plant's roots into a pot with a brick of coir, add water and watch it swell to fill the pot. About half of their 90,000 bushes are in pots. They use drip irrigation which saves labor in the quarter-mile-long glass house. Every six years they replace their bushes as production begins to decline.
They also sell Christmas trees from their field and potted roses to garden centers.
Tom Pinchbeck said their quality of life is important. "I can walk to work and go home for lunch." His father adds, "I get to see my grandchildren every day."
Tom lives on the property with his wife, Bonnie and two daughters, Clara, 4, and Ellie, 2. The elder Pinchbecks live down the road.
Both men are Cornell University graduates. The senior Mr. Pinchbeck attended the College of Agriculture, but his son studied liberal arts. Nonetheless, he said, "I always knew I wanted to be in this business."
They said they confine distribution to Connecticut and New York so that their roses are fresh. William Pinchbeck explained that the roses are shipped in ice while still in tight buds and over two weeks gradually open and die. "Just like people they have a life cycle," he said.
The Pinchbecks sell their roses sorted by stem length. The longest are 26 to 30 inches. The shortest 10 to 14 inches. Calculating the price is based on demand and competition.
"The return per square foot is the most critical," Tom Pinchbeck said. "Different varieties bring in different amounts." He said the average return is about $10 per square foot.
The Pinchbecks sell mostly to wholesalers and florists, but will also sell to individual customers who stop by.

HEADLINE: Space for Research Is Expanding in Cambridge

BYLINE: By SUSAN DIESENHOUSE 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
DEVELOPERS and life-science companies are planning to invest about $1 billion to build more than three million square feet of new research labs in Cambridge, more than doubling the amount of research and development space in this six-square-mile city.
Most of the buildings will go up within a few blocks of Kendall Square, where the region's biotechnology industry first put down roots in the early 1980's. Five new buildings with 1.2 million square feet of space are in construction or were recently completed in the area. Four other projects in the neighborhood with a total of 2.1 million square feet of research space have received city approvals. 
 Biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies that are not building themselves have agreed to lease most of what is in construction, some at annual rents approaching $50 a square foot. The buildings themselves are among the most costly commercial structures to build, costing about $350 a square foot from conception to fit-out.
The lure for this new construction is the intellectual firepower of the Cambridge work force, forged at some of the world's top colleges, research institutes, medical schools and teaching hospitals here and across the Charles River in Boston.
On the Boston side of the Charles, where the medical schools of Harvard, Tufts and Boston Universities conduct training programs, 1.3 million more square feet of biomedical and pharmaceutical labs are being developed, according to E. Owen Donnelly, deputy director of the Boston Redevelopment Authority.
The biotechnology, biomedical and pharmaceutical companies of the life-science industry put a premium on locating in areas with plentiful academic links because new products usually spring from lab discoveries.
"To keep our pipeline full, we want to be in the Cambridge market," said Peter J. McCawley, development manager for Amgen Inc., which with 1999 revenues of $2.4 billion is the country's largest biotechnology company. "It's no secret that Cambridge has the largest and best pool of scientific research talent in the world." Amgen sells products based on genetic information unearthed by biotech research, such as Procrit and Epogen to enhance red blood cells.
Amgen, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., started work last year on a $100 million, 285,000-square-foot lab on a 71,000-square-foot site that it bought for $1.4 million in the slow market of 1994. Instead of building back then, it developed a research center near Boulder, Colo. But in 1998, it converted that lab into a manufacturing plant and started to plan its Cambridge project.
Amgen's sliver of a site here, once part of a sprawling plant that made fire hose, will be wedged in front of the research lab for Genzyme Inc. and across the street from a new lab being built for Biogen Inc. by Boston Properties Inc. Once its building is completed, Biogen will occupy 740,000 square feet in the neighborhood where it first leased space in 1984. Together, the three biotechnology companies make 5 of the industry's 10 best-selling products, according to a 1999 report by Ernst & Young.
Amgen shimmied into this little site because, like most life science companies, it wanted to be near industry colleagues and researchers to share knowledge and insights. "We can't convince these companies to take cheaper space in the suburbs," said Steve Buckley, regional director of the life-sciences practice for Ernst & Young.
THE presence here of an industry giant like Amgen, therefore, creates a new critical mass for the life science industry that will attract even more companies, according to John A. Southard Sr., an economist for Tordo Wheaton Research, a unit of CB Richard Ellis, an international real estate firm.
"Also, it signals that the region's real-estate market is finally moving to the next level of growth after one of the nation's worst downturns," he added.
Cambridge has about 11 million square feet of offices, 8 million square feet of which is in the East Cambridge neighborhood bordered by Kendall Square on the west and the Charles River on the east. It also has 2 million square feet of research labs for bench scientists who work in controlled environments, known as wet labs.
By late 1999, the labs had a vacancy rate of less than 1 percent, versus 24 percent in 1995. Since then, rents have risen as much as 150 percent to reach $50 a square foot annually for some new space, said Gregory W. Hoffmeister, a broker for Spaulding Slye Colliers International.
STAR attractions for these companies are Harvard and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which together own about half of the city's land, said Jean E. Strain, Cambridge's director of economic development.
Another magnet is the Whitehead Institute/M.I.T. Center for Genome Research in Kendall Square, which is about halfway between the two colleges. Scientists there are mapping the human genetic material. Such research could revolutionize health care with the ability to grow new organs and design drug therapies for a person's genetic profile.
With wet lab space set to jump from 2 million to about 5.3 million square feet, the city will adopt new zoning rules to prevent overbuilding.
With the real-estate boom of the 1980's, new zoning rules and special permit requirements appeared. Last month, Cambridge passed an 18-month moratorium on new permits for projects larger than 20,000 square feet around Kendall Square, and in April is expected to adopt a new zoning code to control future growth citywide, said City Councilor Henrietta Davis.
"Two years ago, property owners worried that it would become more difficult to build and they could loose value," said Mr. Hoffmeister, the broker.
Indeed, the city may reduce the ratio of usable building space to site size, from a floor area ratio of 4 to 2.5, said Lester W. Barber, Cambridge's director of zoning. For Amgen, that could have meant a building of 200,000 square feet rather than 285,000 square feet, for a loss in value of $30 million. Amgen's new eight-story building, designed by the Stubbins Associates, is to be completed in June of next year.
The current strong demand increases existing property values, said Thomas Ragno, a vice president of Beacon Capital Partners Inc. Beacon owns Technology Square, a five-building complex with a million square feet of space in Kendall Square. The complex, completed in 1975, is currently being renovated and expanded. Mr. Ragno projects $50-a-square-foot rents for the new research and development space, designed by Sasaki Associates.
