HEADLINE: Highlights in the Life Of Marian Anderson

BYLINE: By LESLIE KANDELL

 BODY:
MARIAN ANDERSON'S most famous recital was sung into a microphone. It was only half an hour, outdoors on a cold Washington Easter in 1939, and the selections, including "Ave Maria" and "America," were not showy or virtuosic.
At that time she was 42. Anderson's contralto voice was probably the world's most magnificent, but her recital on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial before 7,500 enthusiastic listeners was about more than vocalism. It showed her determination to prevail, even after the Daughters of the American Revolution barred her from performing in Constitution Hall because of her race. 
 Considering that the conductor Arturo Toscanini reportedly said to her, "A voice like yours is heard only once in a hundred years," she spent precious little time singing opera, but devoted herself to art songs and spirituals, studying privately. Neither was by choice; her race precluded scholarships and opera roles. When at almost 60 she finally sang at the Metropolitan Opera, she was its first black soloist.
First seen last year and newly revised for Black History Month, "My Lord, What a Morning: The Marian Anderson Story," a short play about her produced by the Kennedy Center, is less a musical play than a meeting of music and theater, enhanced by audio technology. It is told in a sort of simultaneous flashback, with Anderson as an old woman recalling her life.
The play will be performed today at 3 p.m. and tomorrow at 10 a.m. and noon in the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College. The number to call for information is 251-6222. The hourlong play begins when she declines a request to sing a concert in her hometown, Philadelphia, feeling that age prevents her from being at her best. At the end, she decides to accept, in a gesture of perseverance for those who will come after her. As the older Anderson, Charlene Williams is on stage the whole time.
Over the years, Philadelphia made several such requests of Anderson, and there was another that she agreed to after first refusing. That one, described in "Marian Anderson: A Singer's Journey," by Allan Keiler, (Scribner, published this month) came while she was depressed after a critical drubbing of her 1924 Town Hall recital. Her eventual change of mind put her back on the path that would lead to the Lincoln Memorial concert, the support of Eleanor Roosevelt and until Anderson's death in 1993 a series of honors.
Carlyncia Peck, a singing actress from Washington, plays the young Anderson. She and the play faced the challenge of re-creating Anderson's artistic integrity and her striking, if uneven, vocal quality.
Ms. Peck's live performance is blended into a continuation with her own recorded voice, which in turn progresses to Anderson's. Some of the recorded songs, like Brahms's "Von Ewige Liebe" and Handel's "He Shall Feed His Flock" and excerpts from spirituals, play under an acted scene and then fade.
Notably absent are "Ave Maria" and any squib from the role of Ulrica in Verdi's "Masked Ball" with which she made her breakthrough Met debut. The playwright, Kim Hines, and the producers could find only a bad recording of "America" from the Lincoln Memorial recital, so they substituted "America the Beautiful," sung by Ms. Peck.
Ms. Peck had to acquaint herself with some of Anderson's repertory and read the autobiography, but though born in Connecticut, she has not visited Marianna, Anderson's Danbury home.
In a telephone interview, Ms. Peck spoke of what children should take from this play: "The lesson of perseverance, and that it pays off when you have faith in yourself and what you do. In Town Hall, when Marian was denied success, she had to look up and say, 'I'm O.K.' We pray that the younger generation goes away with a sense of identity and pride."
Though Ms. Peck has not experienced the overt prejudice Anderson battled, she referred to something less direct. "When I go into a certain type of upper-economic store," she said, "the feeling that you get if you're approached too soon, or not soon enough, is definitely connected. I don't think that's a sleeping dog yet. We have made major strides, but we still have a long way to go."

HEADLINE: For Immigrants Chasing a Dream, Citizenship Doesn't Come Easy

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
AMID flag waving and cheers, 350 new citizens at the County Courthouse here last month declared their allegiance to the United States, their numbers but not their enthusiasm diminished in recent years.
Like 59-year-old Giovanni Abbate, formerly of Sorrento, Italy, and 20-year-old Kamyna Myeka Robinson, who emigrated from Jamaica, many of those who took the oath of citizenship last month, spent years working their way through paperwork and government regulations to achieve their goals. 
 One group of 176 citizens was sworn in on Jan. 12; a second group of 174 was naturalized on Jan. 26, fulfilling long-held dreams to vote in the United States, become eligible for federal jobs and share the privileges and responsibilities of American citizenship. Swearings-in usually occur once or twice a month.
For all of last year, however, there were only 1,728 new citizens in Westchester, compared with 1,951 in 1998,2,079 in 1997 and 3,462 in 1996. For many, the wait for citizenship has been as long as four or more years, the result of a bottleneck caused by bureaucratic mix-ups and fingerprinting errors made by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, County Clerk Leonard N. Spano said. After a green card is obtained and an application for citizenship is filed, the usual wait is less than a year.
"I kept having to go back and back, over and over again for fingerprinting," said Carl John Hegarty, 34, who emigrated from Dublin 10 years ago. "Then the I.N.S. lost my paperwork. It was a mess, but in the end it was worth it."
The problems have since been resolved, the County Clerk said, with the number of new citizens expected to reach higher levels in coming months.
As has been the trend in the last decade, most of the new citizens in 1999 were from the Caribbean and Central America -- with the largest number, 396, coming from Jamaica. Another 120 came from the Dominican Republic, 26 came from Trinidad and Tobago and 22 from El Salvador.
The following are excerpts from interviews with 10 people sworn in at the two most recent ceremonies by Mr. Spano, who -- as clerk of the State Supreme Court and the County Court -- is vested with the responsibility to administer the oath of allegiance to the United States to all candidates for citizenship.
 
'Too Cold Here'
At the age of 5, Kamyna Myeka Robinson arrived in the United States from Montego Bay, Jamaica, with her father and a brother and a sister. It had been two years since the children had seen their mother, who like many new immigrants, was the first in the family to emigrate and who worked as a household maid to save enough money so the others could come as well. Ms. Robinson, now an office receptionist, recalled that 15 years ago when she walked out of Kennedy International Airport for the first time, it was a cold, wet and to her, depressing September day. "All I could think of was that I wanted to go back home to beautiful Montego Bay," she said. "And although I still complain that it's too cold here, I'm happy now." She said her formerly middle-class family "suffered a big culture shock having to start from the bottom all over again in the U.S." In school the teachers did not understand the child's Jamaican patois, and her American classmates were unfriendly. Although the early years were difficult, Ms. Robinson is preparing to study merchandising at the Fashion Institute of Technology next fall, observing that as a citizen, she will be eligible for many scholarships.
Ms. Robinson said all of her family members applied for citizenship at the same time several years ago and hoped to be sworn in together. Although the eldest daughter is now a citizen, the others in the family continue to wait.
 
Now, a Chance to Vote
Now that he is finally a citizen, Giovanni Abbate will have an opportunity officially to go on record and say who he thinks should be president of the United States. As a new citizen, it is a responsibility he regards seriously -- unlike some citizens who were born here and take voting for for granted.
"I will vote for who I think will do good for the country," said Mr. Abbate, who dressed in his best suit and tie to honor the occasion of his naturalization. "I have a lot to figure out, because I consider the presidency to be very important."
When he arrived in the United States in 1967, Mr. Abbate worked in the construction industry, logged long hours and saved his money for the future. He met his wife, Carmella, also an Italian immigrant, in Westchester, and she too has become a naturalized citizen. The couple have five children and three grandchildren.
 
A New Life After Mexico
When he was a small boy and living in Mexico City, Rafael Barajas remembers always being hungry. "My family was very poor," he said, "and I carried bags for the ladies at the supermarket to buy food and shoes."
At 33, he is working as a handyman at Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck and happy to be thriving, he said. After arriving in the United States 12 years ago, he took jobs in the construction industry and was so tired from digging all day and stanching the flow of blood from his raw hands at night that he said he thought, "What am I doing here?"
"My father said: 'Come back if you want to. We have enough beans and rice,' " Mr. Barajas recalled. "But my cousin who lived here reminded me that nothing is easy in life, and I decided that he was right."
Mr. Barajas studied English two nights a week at a high school and finally got a better job. Now that he is a citizen, he said, his next step is to vote "and help decide what kind of government is right."
After that, he will try to bring his girlfriend, who works for a bank in Mexico City, to Mamaroneck, so they can marry and raise a family.
 
'Life Is Still Hard'
Unsure of her command of the English language, Maria Julia Ramos, who became a new American citizen on Jan. 26, spoke through her 23-year-old daughter, Silvana Ramos.
"My parents gave up their life and started a new one for us," the young Ms. Ramos explained, saying that her father, Julio Ramos, a taxi driver in Maldonado, Uruguay, left his homeland first and sent for Maria Julia and the children after establishing himself in Ossining.
Today, Mr. Ramos works as a handyman, and Mrs. Ramos is a domestic worker. Lourdes, another daughter, is married and has a child. Julio, a son, is attending a trade school, and Silvana is a bartender.
"Life is still hard for them," Ms. Ramos said, "but my parents own their home now, and in most ways, their life is better."
 
From Army to Police
For Carl John Hegarty, 33, of Yonkers citizenship signals an opportunity to accept a job offer from the New York Police Department -- a new step that he welcomes after the hurdles leading up to his naturalization.
The difficulties began when he arrived at Kennedy International Airport from Dublin in 1990, and no one showed up to welcome him. "If there had been a plane going back, I would have taken it," he said.
Mr. Hegarty served as a sergeant in the Army in the Gulf War and put in five years of active duty and five years in the reserves, but he could not re-enlist because he was not a citizen. And without citizenship, he has not been able to accept a job as a police officer. In the last several years, his application for citizenship has hit many dead ends, and with the economy thriving in Ireland, he said he thought more than once of returning to Dublin.
But when he made it through the snow-covered roads to the County Courthouse on Jan. 26, at least some of the frustrations of the past melted away, he said, as he took his place among the assembled group. "In many ways it was a relief, but it was also very anticlimactic," he added.
 
'Worth It in the End'
Like many of the others who were naturalized last month in Westchester, Amani Marji, 31, who was born in Amman, Jordan, said the process of becoming a citizen was a matter of long waits and many frustrations, although it was "worth it in the end."
Mrs. Marji of Dobbs Ferry and is an office worker for the county clerk and has lived in Westchester for 10 years. She is married to John Marji, an American-born plumber of Jordanian descent. Because she joined a large and established Jordanian community from Yonkers when she first arrived -- a large crowd of relatives greeted her at Kennedy with flowers and hugs -- she said she did not experience the isolation and feelings of rejection that many immigrants do.
The family has worked hard to assimilate, she said. And even though they speak Arabic at home and often cook Jordanian meals -- "so that our three children know their heritage," she said -- everyone in Mrs. Marji's large and extended family communicates in English at school and work. Her father works for Liberty Bus Lines in an office, and two of her uncles work at the Yonkers Water Treatment Plant. "We are doing well here," she said.
 
Last in the Family
At 80, Sogmen Petrosian, originally of Erevan, Armenia, is among the oldest of Westchester's new citizens. Escaping a chaotic political situation at home, she came to the United States nine years ago with her son, Karapet Petrosian, her daughter-in-law, Sironush, and two grandchildren.
Knowing only a few words of English -- "You can't do very much without knowing the language," Mr. Petrosian said -- the grandmother is the last among her immediate family in Yonkers to become and American citizen. "But she is happy here," said her son, who drives a delivery truck and is a caretaker for an Armenian Church in New York City.
"In America it pays to work hard," Mr. Petrosian said. "We have our own home. My daughter graduated college. My son has a good job. This is a free country and nobody bothers you. So everything is O.K."
 
New Citizen From China
Fleeing political unrest in his homeland, Weidon Xia, 39, came from Chengdu, China, in the early 1980's to study civil engineering at the graduate school of the University of California at Berkeley.
Three years ago he accepted a job with the New York Power Authority and moved with his wife, Shing, a fellow college student from China, and their two children to Mount Kisco.
Although his mother, father and sisters are still in China, Mr. Xia said he has chosen not to return. At first it was concern over the 1989 riots in Tiananmen Square that stopped him. Now he wants to stay because the family has achieved a good standard of living here. In addition to renting an apartment in Mount Kisco, Mr. Xia owns a house in Syracuse.
"I have a good job, a good family, and other than the price of a home in Westchester being very high, we have a very nice life here," he said.
Mrs. Xia has also applied for her citizenship, but she is still waiting for her papers to be processed.
 
Sending Money Home
Jose Camacho, 35, a former resident of Moca in the Dominican Republic, was also among the new citizens sworn in on Jan. 26. Once a waiter at the Tarrytown Hilton, he had to stop working after he was hit by a car last year and became disabled. Until recently, he has been able to send money home to family members.
Mr. Camacho, who lives in Ossining and has been studying English at night at the local high school, said he looks forward to returning to work as soon as his injuries heal -- "and making money for a bright future."
Among the large group of immigrants from the Dominican Republic coming to Westchester -- there were 2,876 from 1990 to 1999 -- Mr. Camacho said he is rarely homesick for his homeland. His sister, Anny, and his brother, Juan Antonio, also live in Westchester and have become citizens, although his companion, Elisa Severino, who immigrated with Mr. Camacho in 1990, has not yet done so.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
A Realtor Finds a Niche, Gay Couples Find Homes

BYLINE: By ANITA DENNIS 

DATELINE: MONTCLAIR

 BODY:
When Mark Hoebee and Larry Elardo decided two years ago that is was time to leave Manhattan for the suburbs, they wanted a place where a gay family could feel at home. A quick search on the Internet led them to Jaan Henry, whose agency these days lists and sells about 40 houses a year and boasts sales of $8 million to $12 million.
"There is a lot of economic clout in the gay community," said Ms. Henry, whose clientele is about 85 percent gay, though she is quick to add with a laugh, "I don't discriminate against straight people." 
 After doing social work and restoring old homes, Ms. Henry started out in real estate in 1984, working for a large mainstream company. But being a lesbian, she naturally saw a market for gay homebuyers.
Not surprisingly, that specialty didn't exist in the area, so she helped form a networking group of about 10 other gay and lesbian real estate agents. More and more, her business began coming from that referral base, and seven years ago she opened her own business here, Jaan Henry & Company.
"I realized this was a niche market," said Ms. Henry, 56. "People like to network with someone who is like them. If you are Asian, say, you might want to work with someone who shares a social and cultural understanding. The same is true in the gay community. People like to work with someone who is out and affirming."
Today, more than 15 years after starting out in the business, she says that while she knows gay and lesbian real estate agents throughout the country -- in fact, she has gathered a database of about 6,000 gay and "gay-friendly" agents nationwide -- she isn't aware of another agency in New Jersey agency with her specialty.
There are other very practical considerations as well, particularly in New Jersey, where liberal adoption policies have made the state something of a magnet for gay families in the area.
And like their counterparts in the straight world, gay couples do not always stay together. Since there are no clear-cut legal guidelines for dividing property, Ms. Henry can anticipate some of the legal and financial issues that the couples may face, andrefer them to those with useful advice.
For one client, Mr. Hoebee, finding a specialized realtor "was very important because we wanted someone who really understood what we were looking for. We wanted a diverse, integrated community. We wanted a place where there were not just gay and lesbian people but gay and lesbian families."
Mr. Hoebee and his partner, who now have a 15-month-old son, eventually settled in Maplewood, which along with neighboring South Orange has a thriving gay and lesbian community, according to Ms. Henry.
When Carol Morokoff, who also lives in Maplewood with her partner and their daughter, researched suburbs in the New York area, she learned that the towns most often cited as welcoming to gay and lesbian couples in the region were all in suburban New Jersey, and also included Montclair, Morristown and Plainfield.
Apparently, the state's reputation was deserved, because Ms. Henry says neither she nor her clients have ever faced discrimination in their real estate dealings. Her recent sales have ranged from a $74,000 condominium in Montclair to a $710,000 house in Glen Ridge.
In general, Ms. Henry says her clients are seeking proximity to the city, liberal political views, diversity and locally active gay and lesbian organizations. A history of progressive adoption laws has also fueled interest in the state, she says. In December 1997, New Jersey became the first state to establish that gay and unmarried couples should be subject to the same adoption standards as married couples, and that couples should not be denied the right to adopt because of their sexual orientation or marital status.
Then there are the details that people don't often think about. Ms. Henry does. For instance, she recommends that her clients ask their lawyers to draw up partnership agreements. "The laws in divorce are laid out," she said, but when a gay or lesbian couple split, disposition of the proceeds from the sale of a house can become an issue. A partnership agreement can also answer questions such as who will deduct the mortgage interest from his or her tax return.
Ms. Henry finds most people have not thought about these issues. "They think about romance and about their new house," she said.
Ms. Morokoff, who is a lawyer, likens partnership agreements to prenuptial agreements. "Is it an extra good idea to have one?" she asks. "Yes, but most people just don't like to think about it."
Among her current clients, Ms. Henry says, is a gay couple from Jersey City who have two children and want to move to the suburbs, a straight couple coming from New York who were referred by a gay customer, and a straight client moving from St. Louis who met her while she was showing a house in Montclair.
Ms. Henry and her two employees (who are straight) often work with homebuyers from around the country through her relocation service, crossroadsrelocation.org and (800) 4GAY-RELO. The service is a nonprofit effort that she has sponsored for the last six years. She says that offering it costs her about $40,000 a year for telephone, postage, printing, stationery and promotional items like magnets and pens. She finds out where callers plan to move, how much they have to spend, when they're going and other details, then puts them in touch a real estate agent in the area where they are headed. She devotes about 10 hours a week to it and considers it a way to give back to the community.
"Some people work with charitable groups," she said. "This is what I do."
In the end, Ms. Henry believes that clients of any description are looking for professionalism. "People want to work with someone who is knowledgeable, someone they can trust," she said. "I've worked with everyone from conservative F.B.I. agents to guys in red pumps. They all want to be associated with someone who is good at what they do. If you are successful, it speaks for itself."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In Carlstadt, Industrial Space for Cyberspace

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
IN an area around Central Boulevard in Carlstadt dotted with low-slung warehouses and manufacturing complexes the steel skeleton rising on a 12-acre site at the far western end of the thoroughfare is an anomaly. For it has more to do with cyberspace than industrial space.
Comdisco, the company that will occupy the site, will use the new building to house its clients' duplicate files to provide continuity services, formerly called disaster recovery services. If a client's computer files are wiped out or if the client's business results in an overload at its office the client can transmit data without interruption from the Carlstadt building. 
 The 302,000-square-foot building will be the Northeast technology services center for the international technology management company, based in Rosemont, Ill. Comdisco provides data services to businesses that range from banks and stock brokerages to dot-com companies and manufacturers.
The new structure will use raised floors to run the tangle of wires required by the high-tech equipment that will fill much of the space.It will also have enhanced heating and air-conditioning systems and a substation for additional electrical power -- as well as an independent power source with six diesel-fueled generators -- to keep the machines humming.
The Russo Development Company of Hackensack, which owns the development site within its 44-acre industrial park, is constructing the shell of the building and will lease it to Comdisco for 15 years with two five-year renewal options. Comdisco will pay to improve the interior space. No one involved with the project would disclose the overall cost but commercial brokers estimate it to be between $42 million and $63 million.
Brokers say the project is indicative of the appetite for industrial space -- and to a lesser degree office space -- by companies like Comdisco that are involved in servicing the technological and telecommunication needs of today's businesses.
A booming economy and the growth in technology-based companies have all combined "to bring more cerebral white-collar users into the industrial setting," said Jonathan S. Meisel, associate director at in the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the international commercial brokerage.
This is "only the beginning" of the activity, which "will grow exponentially as the use of the Internet grows," he said.
According to state figures, the number of high-tech related jobs in New Jersey, including telecommunications and computer software development and services, have grown by 25 percent from 1994 to 1999. As a result the number of such jobs grew by a total of 59,000 to 295,000 as of last year.
AMONG the companies that are taking or are expected to take industrial or commercial space are those that will provide Internet data centers, also called "server farms." Such centers manage Internet sites for businesses.
One such company, brokers said, is Exodus Communications, based in Santa Clara, Calif., which set up such a center in about 230,000 square feet at 300 Boulevard East in Weehawken. The 311,000-square-foot building, once used by the Metropolitan Opera for storage, is near the entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel.
Other uses, they said, are so-called "telecommunications hotels," which are outfitted with the requisite equipment and electrical power for telecom companies to set up operations, including switching stations. One such "hotel" has taken shape on the upper floors of the former 1.2-million-square-foot Macy's department store building at 165 Halsey Street in downtown Newark. Tenants such as Level 3 Communication, and MCI/Worldwide have leased a significant amount of space in the building over the last 18 months, according to Cushman & Wakefield's year-end 1999 market report.
Now a group of Manhattan developers want to set up other telecom hotels in the state. The group -- comprising Young Woo, a principal of Young Woo & Associates, and a venture of Angelo Gordon & Company and Belvedere Capital -- has closed on a 240,000-square-foot warehouse off Exit 12 of the New Jersey Turnpike in Carteret. It also has signed a contract to buy a nearly 900,000-square-foot warehouse on Jersey Avenue in Jersey City, said Mr. Meisel, who with James Quinn, a senior director at the brokerage, is representing the group in the transactions.
Such users, in turn, are helping "to fuel the state's industrial real estate market by reducing the supply of properties and making a tight market even tighter," and Paul E. Giannone, a principal at Jacobson, Goldfarb & Tanzman Company, L.L.C, a Woodbridge brokerage which represented Comdisco in the Carlstadt project.
For instance, in the Meadowlands region where Comdisco's center is situated, his firm put the industrial vacancy rate at 6.37 percent at the end of 1999, down from 7.8 percent the year before. Over the same period, average asking annual rents rose to $5.50 a square foot, from $4.75; the rental rate for new buildings is $6.50 to $7.50 a square foot.
Mr. Giannone added that while such users conduct different businesses they are drawn to the high ceilings and raised floors that industrial properties provide, in order to accommodate "the high-powered guts in a building" needed to support their operations, which run 24 hours a day, seven days a week. In addition, he said, they also need to be situated near a high-speed fiber-optic network.
THOSE factors were involved in Comdisco's decision to go forward with the build-to-suit project in Carlstadt, Mr. Giannone said. The company, he said, surveyed 25 properties, some as far west as Parsippany, but "none had everything the company needed."
Patricia M. Knoll, director of global real estate for Comdisco, said the Carlstadt site was chosen because it had all its approvals in place, was suitable for the size of structure the company wanted to build and its location. It is within a few miles of four of Comdisco's existing operations elsewhere in the Meadowlands, close to its client base in Manhattan and the rest of the New York metropolitan area and accessible to a fiber-optic network, she said.
Comdisco will consolidate operations that are now in the four nearby structures, together totaling just under 200,000 square feet, into the new building and still have 100,000 square feet left "to grow in the future," said Steven Harris, Comdisco's director of project planning.
With the growth in dot-com and e-commerce companies, which "are looking to back up their data, we have a new market segment," Mr. Harris said. The building, which 65 employees from the other locations will move to in phases from next December through July 2001, will be the largest of the 32 centers Comdisco operates in North America.
Mr. Harris said the centers his company operates have in the last three years moved away from the "old model" of such buildings being used only in the event of a disaster.
The new model, he said, is that businesses will also use the center to test their data systems or as a back-up data site.
Since computers are now a common workplace business tool the centers "also have evolved to be more people friendly," places and no longer have that bunker-like look of the past, Mr. Harris said.
As now envisioned the outside of the Carlstadt center will be faced in brick on three sides and have large windows to allow natural light inside. Also planned is a nearly 42,000-square-foot mezzanine at the front of the building. "We want it to look like an office building not like a concrete box," said Ms. Knoll.
Inside, along with the data center, the building will be divided into rooms for testing systems or conducting business, including a work and trading floor area with 1,000 seats and personal computers. There will also be conference rooms, lounges, T.V. rooms and canteens, Mr. Harris said. He added that his building would be "completely up and running" by July 2001.

HEADLINE: Taking A Shot At Their Olympic Dreams

BYLINE: By KENNETH BEST 

 BODY:
THREE years ago, while attending Connecticut College in New London, Gregory Skidmore attended a lecture expecting to learn about the Olympic experiences of Timothy Young, an alumnus who won a silver medal with the 1996 crew team that competed in Atlanta. He left the room inspired to fulfill his childhood dream of sailing in the Olympics.
"I got to hold his medal," said Skidmore, who is 23. "I held the dream in my hands. I decided to try and do it." 
 A sailing enthusiast from the age of 10, Skidmore at the time was ranked 213th in North America in the laser class of single-handed sailing competition, one of 10 sailing events that will take place in the Summer Games to be held in Australia in October. Within a year, the memory of holding an Olympic medal in his hands pushed Skidmore to the elite level of United States sailors; most recently he ranked as high as 12th in the United States and in the top 25 in North America.
Skidmore, who lives in Greenwich, is one of several Connecticut residents hoping to qualify for the United States Olympic Team that will compete in Sydney. Among them are Skidmore's friend and fellow laser sailing competitor, Andrew Scrivan, another 23-year-old from Greenwich; Anna Norgren, 25, of Orange, a teacher who competes in the hammer throw, a track and field event; and Richard DeStefano, 28, of Hamden, an exercise physiologist who competes in the javelin. Other state residents hoping to compete in Sydney include Carlos Parra, 22, of West Haven, a midfielder for the Miami Fusion of Major League Soccer; and Kristen Lilly of Wilton, a member of the champion World Cup United States women's soccer team.
While team-sport athletes may be selected for the Olympics after an invitation to try out for an all-star team, individual-sport athletes must qualify through direct competition just to get to the Olympic trials, where top finishers in each event or sport earn a spot on the United States Team. For today's Olympic hopeful it means raising money to keep training and for travel to the qualifying events. Some athletes can work, train and raise money, while others don't have the time to do all three if they are to make it to Sydney.
For Skidmore, who is competing in the laser class competition (the least expensive of sailing events) it has meant raising more than $100,000 from corporate and individual sponsors while completing his studies in economics and history, training throughout the year and sailing in key competitions in warm climates, including recent trips to Australia.
"I know I have to be just as good at fund-raising as I am at sailing," he said. "People like to help because they can make a difference. I try to share as much of my experience as possible with them, trying to give back as much as they give me."
Nearly 200 supporters from the Greenwich area will be able to track his progress with e-mail messages as well as a newsletter and a Web site (www.GloryDownUnder.com). He also has corporate support from Advest, the investment banking company based in Hartford that employs his father, Philip.
Skidmore and Scrivan met at the Riverside Yacht Club as youngsters and went through middle school and high school together before heading their separate ways to college. Scrivan recently graduated from Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva, N.Y., with a degree in environmental sciences. The two describe themselves as best friends and find comfort in having each other around amid the strain of competition.
At every major championship there is a significant amount of pressure to perform, goals to attain and results to accomplish, Scrivan said. "Having my best friend around to laugh with and talk about the races takes the edge off," he said.
His breakthrough as a competitor came in 1997 at the Cork regatta, the largest North American laser championship held each year in Kingston, Ontario. He placed fifth and finished as the third American out of 160 competitors.
In addition to financing from people in the Greenwich community, Scrivan has lined up corporate support from Nestle and Hobie Sunglasses, and from The Boat Locker, business located in Westport.
The laser-class Olympic trials will take place in April in San Francisco.
DeStefano and Norgren often train together as part of a group of track and field athletes who find strength and support in numbers. Both balance working and training as world-class athletes. "You get fired up with your training partners," DeStefano explained. "We're all on the same page as far as what it's going to take to succeed. They're very crucial to my routine. It's why I stay healthy."
He began throwing the javelin in high school in South Windsor, after running the mile in track and playing baseball. While attending Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven, he refined his throwing technique. But it was after graduating college that he started to make great strides, steadily increasing his distances to his current best of 241 feet, which is still about 30 feet short from qualifying for Sydney. He was ranked 13th in the United States last year by USA Track and Field.
Two years ago, DeStefano began to organize a javelin festival in New Haven that has attracted javelin throwers from around the world. More than 180 athletes attended, including Brian Chaput of East Haven, a javelin thrower who is a member of the University of Pennsylvania track team.
For DeStefano, one challenge is to fit in training around his job conducting cardiopulmonary stress tests for pediatric patients at Yale-New Haven Hospital and his family. He is married and the father of two.
He has also managed to find time to gain sponsorships from Fovama, a rug store, and Klub Kehais, a throwing club based in North Carolina. His travel to the national Olympic Training Center in San Diego is covered by USA Track and Field.
Norgren is ranked 23rd in the world and fourth in the United States among women hammer throwers. Her best effort to date is about a foot short of the Olympic standard of 213.3 feet.
"The thing I feel pretty good about is that I've beaten all the top three throwers ahead of me in the U.S. at one point or another," she said.
Norgren, who is an English teacher at Stamford High School, began throwing the hammer in college, where most in the sport begin to compete. While at the University of Vermont, she was a 300-meter hurdler and also competed in the shot put. When her coach thought that increasing her running to the 400-meter might be too much distance, she started throwing the hammer.
"This will be the first time the hammer throw for women will be in the Olympics," she said. "It's kind of exciting. Once it becomes an Olympic event, that's when it becomes harder to compete."
In addition to training with the local group, which includes her fiance, the high jumper Sean Mahon, Norgren has worked with Stuart Togher, the coach of the men's American hammer record holder, Lance Deal. She also has trained with Bill Sutherland of Southern Connecticut State, who previously worked with Togher.
Norgren is quick to note that if she gets to Australia, she will not be the first Olympic athlete in her family. Erik, her 29-year old brother, provided the example when he began competing in the Special Olympics as a sprinter, long jumper and softball thrower. She had her first Olympics experience at the age of 9, as a Special Olympics volunteer.
She recently gained her first sponsorship from SoBe Beverage, which has its headquarters in South Norwalk.
The Olympic trials for track and field take place in Sacramento, Calif., in July.

HEADLINE: Around Grand Central, New Office Towers And a 54-Floor Residence

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
IN 1994, when it still had eight years remaining on its lease at 245 Park Avenue, smack in the middle of the tony Grand Central area between 46th and 47th Streets, the investment banking firm of Bear Stearns & Company began looking for a new home, and soon its name was linked to sites from Times Square to the financial district.
Today it is well along on its planned 45-story headquarters, sections of its steel structure already thrusting above much of Manhattan's East Side skyline. Once the new site, the entire block bounded by 46th and 47th Streets and Madison and Vanderbilt Avenues, became available, said James E. Cayne, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, "it was our first choice, our second choice, our third and our fourth." 
 While the renaissance of Times Square has been more dramatic, largely because of the depths to which the area had plummeted in the 1970's and 80's, the area around Grand Central Terminal is undergoing a significant transformation of its own.
In addition to the Bear Stearns skyscraper, another new office building is rising in the district and several others are in various stages of planning. Construction has also begun on a 54-story residential tower, while two boutique hotels are scheduled to open in the spring. The 200-foot walkways under the Helmsley Building at 230 Park Avenue leading to Grand Central Terminal are to undergo extensive renovation later this year, while the 34-story building itself -- bought by Max Capital Management last year for $225 million -- undergoes extensive refurbishing. And any number of buildings have recently completed multimillion-dollar makeovers or modernizations, or are in the process of doing so.
"Times Square has been the focus of development," said Tara I. Stacom, executive director of Cushman & Wakefield, the real-estate services group, "but in a few years Grand Central will be the main focus."
The main reason for the flurry of face-lifts and upgrades is economic, to command higher rentals, or, at the very least, to dissuade tenants from bailing out when their leases expire. But there is also the matter of pride -- of many landlords wanting to keep up with the neighboring Joneses, who in turn were inspired to dress up their properties because of the example set by the acclaimed makeover of Grand Central Terminal.
That makeover not only improved the experience for the half-million commuters who pass through it on an average day, "it amounted to a vote of confidence in the area's potential," said Robert L. Billingsley, vice president of Colliers ABR, the leasing agent for many properties in the area. Even the success of Times Square, which until recently had been a model only of urban decay, served as an example for what's going on in Grand Central. "The ripple effect of Times Square development and energy can be felt all the way to Third Avenue," said Mary Ann Tighe, vice chairman of Insignia/ESG, the real estate services group.
Because the new Bear Stearns building was intended to accommodate the business of the firm, not to attract tenants (although it will have retail tenants along Madison Avenue, as required by zoning regulations), its raison d'etre from the beginning was decidedly pragmatic.
"If you had your druthers and could afford it, this is what you would do," Mr. Cayne said. "It was the only major site available on the East Side of Manhattan, and its location and design convey convenience, stature and commitment."
Between December 2001 and the expiration of its current lease in 2002, Bear Stearns plans to move most of its 4,500 employees in New York into the new site, which is owned by CS First Boston and the al-Babtain family of Saudi Arabia.
UNTIL it was leveled to build the Bear Stearns building, the 12-story Knapp Building stood on the site, at 383 Madison Avenue, although it remained unoccupied for a dozen years. At one time it was the headquarters of the Manhattan Savings Bank and the Webb & Knapp real estate domain of William Zeckendorf Sr., whose circular penthouse office was designed by I. M. Pei.
Bear Stearns signed a 99-year lease for the land beneath its new building in 1996. But some employees will remain at its current headquarters, 245 Park Avenue at 46th Street, where its lease on the almost 600,000 square feet of space it has been occupying includes options for the 25 years beyond its 2002 expiration.
"This is the space we will have for internal growth," Mr. Cayne said, referring to 245 Park Avenue, "so we will end up using all or most of the space available to us under the agreement with Brookfield." The Brookfield Properties Corporation owns the building.
Both Mr. Cayne and Samuel L. Molinaro, the firm's chief financial officer, said that a major factor in their decision had been the restoration of Grand Central Terminal, which they said greatly enhanced the aesthetics and quality of life throughout the broader Grand Central area. And they were equally lavish in their praise both of the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and of Metro North, whose train tracks run beneath the new Bear Stearns building, as well as beneath those of most buildings between Lexington and Madison Avenues.
"That was only one of the problems we confronted," said David M. Childs, a senior partner at Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the architectural firm that designed the Bear Stearns building. Other challenges included the design, which calls for the base of the building to rise nine floors (seven of them trading floors with 2,000 trading positions) before two setbacks between the 10th and 17th floors. From there the building becomes an octagon until it reaches the crown, 777 feet above ground, where it is sheathed in a patterned, rolled, laminated glass -- or, in the architects' phrase, "crinkled glass."
T. J. Gottesdiener, the architectural firm's managing partner on the project, added that the building would be unusual in New York because "it's a square full-block site, and there are so few of them."
"So we took advantage of this geometry," he said, "by designing a skyscraper that starts square at the base and culminates in a crystal octagon in the skyline."
Moreover, within the Bear Stearns building will be a pedestrian arcade -- a blocklong passageway that will connect with Grand Central Terminal through a new north end passageway that can be accessed at either Madison Avenue at 47th or Vanderbilt Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets.
All this costs a great deal of money, of course -- almost $280 million for construction alone. But Mr. Cayne, a world-class bridge player and a self-described "pretty good" poker player, does not regard that investment as a risk. "It's the closest thing to a sure thing I've ever seen," he said.
How so? "Because opportunities like this don't come along often," he said. "You couldn't duplicate it because New York real estate has since gone through the roof."
Dr. Axel Stawski had the foresight to buy his properties almost 20 years ago at 360 Madison Avenue and just around the corner at 17 East 45th Street. Now his Kipp-Stawski company is knocking down the building on 45th Street and keeping only the steel frame, columns, beams and slabs of the Madison Avenue building and combining the new and the old structures into a single 24-story office building at the 360 Madison address -- a mere chip shot from the new Bear Stearns tower.
"Grand Central has always been special," Dr. Stawski said, "and it's extra-special since the terminal was restored."
Lots of heavy-duty restoration is taking place in and around the terminal, the very heart of Grand Central. The 200-foot-long Helmsley arcades, which connect Grand Central Terminal with Park Avenue through the Helmsley Building at 230 Park Avenue, will be shut down one at a time for 18 months starting later this year while they are spruced up.
The makeover will include 30-foot-high ceilings (double the existing height), a 15-foot by 40-foot center skylight that will fill the passage with natural light, new double-height retail spaces facing 14-foot-high video screens along the walls, a glass floor beneath the center skylight revealing trains below street level -- and, not least, direct access to Grand Central Terminal.
In addition, the Helmsley Building itself -- originally the New York Central Building, but whose most recent name will remain on the facade of the building, as part of the sales contract, under the new ownership -- will be extensively gussied up.
Adam Hochfelder, the president of Max Capital, said that the limestone and granite of its four-story base would be restored, its glazed terra cotta roadway tiles would be cleaned, and that he is considering restoring the building's copper mansard roof and its gilded golden cupola (which previously had been restored in July 1998).
In the lobby the installation of the original brass fixtures, marble trim, travertine walls and floors is nearly completed, while the public corridors are being redone with custom screened wall coverings and Persian carpets. By late summer people who visit the 24-story building at 350 Madison Avenue -- formerly the Conde Nast Building, until that publishing company moved into its skyscraper in Times Square -- will have an unusual urban experience awaiting them. As they enter the building they will cross a glass bridge that can be illuminated from underneath, and once inside they they will find themselves in a 22-foot-wide lobby that is also made of glass, thus affording a rare unobstructed view of the sky.
"By breathing new life into these older buildings in Manhattan, where there's almost no space to put up new buildings, you preserve the archaeology of New York," said Roger Duffy, a design partner at Skidmore, Owings and Merrill, the architectural firm that designed the bridge and glass lobby. Mr. Duffy also designed the Helmsley Building arcades.
In addition to the two new buildings now under way on opposite sides of Madison Avenue, several other new office buildings are in advanced planning stages.
Tishman Speyer Properties, part owner of Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building, is planning to build a 365,000-square-foot speculative office building at 222 East 41st Street, near Third Avenue. And at the northeast corner of 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue Mitchell B. Rutter, the president of Essex Capital Partners, intends to put up a 30-story office building that will include retail stores on the street level. That building is also expected to be put up as a speculative building.
Brookfield Properties has announced plans to buy a site at the equally conspicuous corner of 42nd Street and Madison Avenue to build a million-square-foot building, which is likely to be occupied by the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, Canada's biggest bank.
Most of the activity in and around Grand Central involves office buildings. The office vacancy rate in the area -- 38th to 47th Streets, Fifth Avenue to the East River, was 7.1 percent last month, according to Barbara Byrne of Colliers ABR, compared with 6.7 percent in midtown Manhattan.
But a sprinkling of residential properties are also under construction.
The biggest of these is RFR Davis's 54-story limestone and brick residential tower at 425 Fifth Avenue, at 38th Street, on which construction started three months ago. Eighteen floors are intended for extended-stay residents, while the remainder will house apartments. The building, designed by Robert A. M. Stern and H. Thomas O'Hara Architects, will also have space for commercial tenants.
AT 52 East 41st Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, in the former Chemists Club building, the 108-room Dylan hotel and the separately owned Restaurant R are scheduled to open in April. The Dylan's owner, Morris Moinian, said that more than $1 million of the overall $30 million renovation is devoted to architectural details, including a marble staircase that spirals up three floors. (The architect is Jeffrey Beers of Manhattan.)
Nearby, at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and 41st Street, a former 12-story office building is expected to open at the end of April as the refurbished 16-story, 60-room Library Hotel. Under the husband and wife design team of Stephen B. Jacobs and Andi Pepper, each floor will be keyed to the Dewey decimal system used to catalog books. Not only will floors will be named after various subject headings (i.e., Social Sciences, Economics, etc.), rooms on those floors will contain books on those topics.
The Library Hotel's developer, Henry Kallan, said he was undertaking the $10 million restoration largely because Grand Central is about to become a mecca for tourists as well as visitors on business. "The whole area," he said, "from Grand Central Terminal to Bryant Park" -- at 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas, behind the New York Public Library -- "is already dynamic and will become more so."
It is hard to find an important building in the area that is not being upgraded, or has not been upgraded recently. The $100 million refurbishment continues on the Chrysler Center, the name recently bestowed on the 76-story Chrysler Building at 405 Lexington and the 32-story East Building (formerly the Kent Building) at 666 Third Avenue.
The work on the landmark Chrysler Building, which is nearing completion, includes refurbishing the entire facade as well as the signature stainless steel and nickel top. It also includes modernizing the system that controls and operates the 20 elevators and employing artisans to renovate the landmark elevator cabs. The building will have new heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems, and a new generator will provide emergency backup for both Chrysler Center buildings.
MEANTIME, work on the East Building is expected to last at least a couple more months, according to Valerie Peltier, senior director of Tishman Speyer Properties. That ranges from changing its white-brick exterior to aluminum and glass, enlarging the lobby, modernizing offices, improving the heating and ventilating systems, replacing the elevator cabs and much more. By adding space on each floor, the East Building will have an additional 150,000 square feet.
In addition, two small buildings and three floors of a five-story in the middle of the Chrysler Center have been torn down and will soon be replaced by three glass trylons (one 75 feet high) designed by Philip Johnson that will house a restaurant accessable from 42nd Street. (The East Building's main entrance will remain at 666 Third Avenue.)
For the better part of two years S. L. Green Realty, which has extensive holdings in the Grand Central area as well as elsewhere, has been busy rewiring and otherwise upgrading all its buildings, most of them Class B.
"It's important to our tenants to have speedy access to the Internet," said Jerry Nocera, Green's executive vice president of leasing, "so we're putting in fiber-optics that will take us into the next decade."
Beyond that, Green is carrying out an extensive renovation of the Graybar Building attached to Grand Central Terminal. This includes a new bronze and glass entrance, a renovated lobby, a steam-cleaned facade, and new floors, ceilings and bathrooms.
At the landmark former Bowery Savings Bank at 110 East 42nd Street, where the Cipriani family leased the ground floor and basement for its catering service -- and where the taped voice of Enrico Caruso resonates from the marble mosaic floor as well as the 65-foot-high ceiling -- S. L. Green was able to redo the lobby and install new elevator cabs without running afoul of the landmark preservation strictures.
The former bank has been host to bar mitzvahs reunions, weddings and similar happy occasions -- and according to Charles Kasper, the doorman at the property, "we've even had some divorce parties.'
A block west, the Lincoln Building, owned by East 60 East 42nd Street Associates, of which Peter Malkin is the general partner, is in the midst of a $28 million refurbishment. The original ceiling has already been restored by a New York firm that specializes in historic restorations. A new concierge desk was added recently, and a new corridor, new windows, a new conference center, new public bathrooms on each floor and a covered lobby entranceway are either already completed or will be soon.
Lest art and history buffs rise up in arms, they can rest assured that Daniel Chester French's sculpture of the "Seated Lincoln," the model used for the creation of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, still reposes in the building's lobby.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Former Showroom in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, Is Turned Into 27 Rental Apartments;
Old Studebaker Building Has New Tenants

 BODY:
Alfred Thompson never owned a Studebaker. But Mr. Thompson, a Brooklyn-based developer, has long been a fan of the distinctive, futuristically designed car, which ceased being made in the 1960's -- and of the five-story Studebaker building at Bedford Avenue and Sterling Place that once housed offices and a big-windowed showroom.
"The Studebaker showroom in Detroit was turned into a jail, and I was determined to do everything I could not to have something like that happen here," said Mr. Thompson, executive director of Food First, a nonprofit developer of housing and supportive services for homeless, disabled and low-income families. 
 Two years ago his company bought the 1910 building, which in recent years was home to artists' studios on the upper floors and a church in the walled-over showroom. Since then, with the help of financing from the city, the company's subsidiary, New Start Group, has converted the structure into 27 low-income rental apartments. The studio, two- and three-bedroom units, from 485 to 925 square feet, are being rented to tenants earning $22,400 to $32,000 a year, depending on family size. All have been leased at monthly rents of $487 to $725.
"This project resulted in not just the creation of more affordable housing, but the preservation of a neighborhood's character," said Russell A. Harding, president of New York City's Housing Development Corporation, which provided the bulk of the public financing for the $3.3 million project.
Because the building got government financing and is eligible for listing on the State and National Registries of Historic Places, the developer agreed to put in replicas of the original wood-frame windows, restore the terra-cotta facade and keep the interior columns exposed.
Mr. Thompson said that the showroom was turned into two floors, to create enough units to make the project economically viable and to provide 1,500 square feet of ground-floor space for a supportive services center. Tenants have begun moving in. Mr. Thompson said that while many are too young to remember the Studebaker, "they will come to know it" through photos posted on bulletin boards. Another reminder is the circular sign on the facade with Studebaker written on it.

HEADLINE: Public Housing's New Face: Will It Lift the Urban Poor?

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: ELIZABETH

 BODY:
UNDER a late morning sun the landscape is a stark profile, a jumble of bulky brick boxes that make up the Migliore Manor public housing complex in the Elizabethport section of this Union County city.
Over the next few years, these aging reminders of the underside of urban life will be turned into rubble. 
 But just a block away, the light is streaming through the wooden skeletons of the first row of town houses that are beginning to rise and that will ultimately replace the rubble.
Four generations of the Ancrum family have lived here most of their lives in those boxes. Over a pancake and egg breakfast one recent Saturday, family members ranging in age from 9 to 70 discussed the transformation of the housing complex, which overlooks the Arthur Kill and turns its back to the streets of the city's old industrial section. They also talked about the reasons they have bought into the housing program the federal government calls Hope VI.
Housing advocates and developers say they support the program's aim, which is to transform public housing from cruel and degrading places for those hunkered below the bottom rung of the real estate ladder into Levittown-like communities that fit into the neighborhood -- even though they concede the process is time-consuming and burdened by red tape.
On the other hand, some tenant groups say that by any name, the effort is simply a gentrification program that takes away more housing for low-income families than it produces.
"Wherever you go, it's never better," said Shirley Ancrum, the 70-year-old grandmother of this group, said flatly in defense of the program, her voice trailing off. "So why leave?"
Shirley's daughter, 44-year-old Wynona Ancrum -- a forceful bear of a woman with a sweet face -- added, "We said we must become part of the process, or there would be no deal."
The Hope VI program -- so named because Hope is an acronym for Homeownership and Opportunity for People Everywhere and VI because there have been four previous programs created by Congress since 1990 (number five was skipped) -- is the latest federal effort to reverse the image, and frequently the reality, of public housing as an insular and dangerous place to live. Earlier efforts, from renovation to selective demolition, were fragmented, rigid and ineffective because of the myriad sources of funds -- as insufficient as they often were.
Since 1997 Wynona Ancrum, president of the Migliore Manor Resident Council and a member of the local housing authority board, has been working with other residents to implement their vision of what will replace Migliore Manor, an eight-building complex with 250 units, and the adjacent Pioneer Homes, whose 12 buildings house 405 apartments.
"Decent housing, and not being stacked on top of one another," the elder Mrs. Ancrum said. "That's all."
Her daughter added for emphasis, "A chance to live like everyone else."
The sweatshirt that Wynona Ancrum is wearing reinforces that theme. On it are the outlines of a high-rise as well as simple pitched-roofed houses, a rising sun and the words, "The dawn of a new era," which she interprets as a new beginning for tenants.
For now, at least 600 new and renovated residences for people of various means are planned for rent or sale; about half will rise on the site of the two public housing complexes, and the rest will take shape on sites scattered in the Elizabethport neighborhood. Over all, half of the new housing will be for people who now live in public housing in the neighborhood.
"We made sure that all the tenants who wanted to come back could," Wynona Ancrum said.
Officials at the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development say the program aims to use public and private financing to allow the housing to fit in more gracefully and incorporate more services like education and job training -- a component that has grown more important with the government's welfare-to-work campaign, a link never made with past housing projects. It also encourages a shift in the ownership and management from public housing authorities to private concerns.
"The idea is to walk through a neighborhood and not be able to detect the public housing units from the low-income or market-rate residences," said Edward DePaula, coordinator of the program in New Jersey at the regional housing agency office in Newark.
Though conceived in 1993, Hope VI picked up steam only in the last three or four years. The federal housing agency has allocated $3.7 billion nationwide -- including $250 million to eight New Jersey projects in Newark, Jersey City, Camden, Paterson, New Brunswick, Atlantic City and Elizabeth.
"This program is not just about public housing, or bricks and mortar," Mr. DePaula said. "It's about changing whole neighborhoods and offering positive incentives to tenants."
YET many people contend that Hope VI is no panacea. "It's a good program," said Nicolas Retsinas, director of the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University. "But is it the solution to the country's severe housing needs? The answer is no."
Other housing experts agree with Mr. Retsinas, who says the program is saddled with a lack of resources and tenant skepticism over such issues as displacement and relocation. And, he added, for all its flexibility, the program is complex, frustrating and peppered with politics. "The longer it takes, the skepticism increases," he said.
Mary E. Rone, president of the New Jersey Association of Public and Subsidized Housing Tenants, a nonprofit tenant advocacy group in Newark, put her opposition more bluntly. "I do not favor demolition, and this is a demolition program," Ms. Rone said. "The numbers are out of sync because the housing being built will not replace all the units being torn down."
She also said that unless tenants are involved from the beginning -- which is the case in Elizabeth -- only "a handful will benefit, but for the majority it stinks."
Elinor Bacon, deputy assistant secretary for public housing investments at H.U.D., takes issue with Mr. Retsinas and Ms. Rone. "These are huge undertakings, which take a long time to complete," she said. "We don't want to overregulate, but we want the planning done up front because it is our fiduciary responsibility to make sure we have a successful development at the end, which has happened elsewhere in the nation."
As for the concerns that there will not be enough public housing for all the people who leave the old projects, Donna White, a spokeswoman for the federal housing agency, said: "To create these new communities -- and better housing -- in most cases you can't put back what has been taken down. But no one is going to be left out, because they are given alternative housing."
New Jersey has 45,000 public housing units; under the rebuilding program, 4,200 are scheduled to come down. So far, 985 units have been demolished and 500 are under construction, the federal housing agency said. Ultimately, 4,000 units are to be built, 2,400 for public housing tenants.
Many residents are relocated during the rebuilding process, and those who do not choose to move into the new housing can receive federal rent subsidies and go elsewhere. But given the scant supply of decent affordable housing, Ms. Rone said, the question becomes: where do they move?
Public housing -- mostly low-rise town houses and walk-ups -- began appearing in the 1930's to help working families in the Depression. After World War II, the focus shifted to help low-income families, ushering in the high-density mid- and high-rise complexes of the late 1940's and 1950's that most people think of today. By the 1960's, the complexes were opened up to minorities and welfare recipients; the concentration of extremely poor and minority tenants accelerated in the 1970's, and public housing came to be viewed as the last resort.
Wynona Ancrum recalled the day 21 years ago when she stepped into apartment 22G, her first one at Migliore Manor, as a divorced mother of three young children trying to raise a family on welfare. "I saw it as way to get up on my feet, and it was good through the 70's and 80's," she said.
Then Migliore Manor and Pioneer Homes -- built in 1940 and 1953, respectively, and the oldest and densest of Elizabeth's seven public housing projects -- spiraled downward while the city's industrial core was disappearing. Construction of the New Jersey Turnpike, which severed the far eastern part of Elizabeth and isolated it from the rest of the city, contributed to the decline.
By the late 1980's the housing complex became terrible, said Wynona's 26-year-old daughter, Kiona. "I was scared to go out," she said, recalling the rapes, killing and drug activity that became facts of life.
Kiona Ancrum, who is now the mother of her own four children, went on: "I lost a lot of friends. It makes you aware."
Last year she took a job as a longshoreman at the Elizabeth Seaport and got off the welfare rolls. But she never left her home. Nor did her mother, Wynona, who suffers from a bad back and asthma and is on disability, or her grandmother, Shirley, who is widowed and retired and who moved in with Wynona 10 years ago.
Though the complex is rundown and at times dangerous, and though life there can be disheartening, the three women said it was what they knew. It was home.
Even 9-year-old Shadya, Kiona's daughter, said with a child's optimism, "All my family is here and I have a lot of friends."
Today, the two complexes are home to about 1,450 people, with an average annual income of $8,200, compared with $24,487 for households in the rest of Elizabethport.
In the 1980's, the federal government no longer supported the building of high-density public housing. While even the housing agency supported razing some of the bleaker buildings, it required that the units be replaced on a one-to-one basis, a practice discontinued about five years ago.
In New Jersey, some public housing was razed and replaced by town houses before the advent of Hope VI. For instance, the Newark Public Housing Authority is involved in the state's largest rebuilding program as a result of a 1989 settlement of a federal lawsuit that maintained that the authority wasn't putting up enough apartments. The settlement called for the creation of 1,777 low-rise units to replace apartments in eight towers. All of the towers have been demolished and 1,000 new units have been built, 488 more are under way and the development of 289 more is to start this year, said Harry Robinson, a Newark Public Housing Authority spokesman.
In Jersey City, 10 years ago the housing authority began to reshape Curries Woods, a seven-tower complex with 712 apartments in the Greenville section. At that point, said Maria T. Maio, the authority's deputy executive director, "We were limited by the one-to-one replacement requirement and working around existing tenants, who under our agreement with them would not be involuntarily displaced."
Ms. Maio said that the plan then was to configure one tower and demolish another, replacing it with 100 town houses, but "there was never enough money to do everything at the same time."
In both cases, money was not available for all the support services needed by the prospective tenants, and the federal housing agency did not encourage mixing residents of various income levels.
Still, some tenants who moved into the town houses say the new homes are an improvement. Louranett George moved into a town house on the Curries Woods site with her five children in 1998 after living in a high-rise for 18 years. "It's safer and like living in your own home, which is great for the kids who have a backyard," said Ms. George, who is a resident liaison at Curries Woods and works as an administrative assistant at the Jersey City Housing Authority.
Since then, Jersey City and Newark have received Hope VI grants. Newark has received two; one, for $50 million, was given in 1994 to demolish the 630-unit Archbishop Walsh Homes and replace it with 498 low-rise units, and a $35 million grant was given in 1997 to raze the 1,206-unit Stella Wright Homes and replace it with 750 mixed-income units in the nearby neighborhood.
In 1997, Jersey City received a $32 million Hope VI grant to raze the remaining five buildings at Curries Woods and build another 130 town houses on the site. There will also be three off-site projects, one with 124 mixed-income units and the other two with a total of 70 homes that qualified public housing tenants can buy.
"Hope VI goes in the right direction," said Robert J. Rigby, executive director of the Jersey City Housing Authority. "The difficulties are in pulling it off in the real world."
WITH no Hope VI rebuilding program completed in the state, the jury is still out on its ultimate success. The process has not been without flaws, and the relocation of tenants is the thorniest issue, Ms. Rone said, adding that often tenants end up in worse housing than what they left.
"It's a real issue for H.U.D," added Michael A. Stegman, who was assistant secretary of housing for policy and research from 1993 to 1997 and is now chairman of the department of public policy at the University of North Carolina.
In Elizabeth, the Ancrums remain upbeat. "In the beginning," Wynona Ancrum said, "there were misconceptions, but the tenants have been involved in every step, which is a departure from past history."
She said that although "anything could happen, so far the process is working." And though people are becoming restless while waiting for the new housing, she said she had not received any complaints from the tenants who had chosen to relocate.
Manny Grova Jr., the councilman for the Elizabethport neighborhood and a commissioner of the Elizabeth Housing Authority, said he had not received any complaints either, though he had concerns about costruction that have since been resolved.
Mr. Grova, who grew up in a house across from Pioneer Homes and now owns a home six blocks away, said, "We feel this is a better way to go because it eliminates brick monsters and provides a better quality of life and better housing that mixes incomes and is spread out."
Doing so, added Mayor J. Christian Bollwage, will attract private investment to the neighborhood.
The five-year rebuilding program, which will cost $80 million, started about 16 months ago. The housing authority received a $28.9 million grant from H.U.D., and the rest is to come from private sources.
"It shakes up all the old pieces to the public housing puzzle and winds up with the same players, but the roles and responsibilities have changed," said Christiana Foglio of Home Properties, who has developed affordable housing in the state. Ms. Foglio's company, based in Rochester, N.Y., with an office in New Brunswick, will develop, own and manage the on-site units
Four vacant public housing buildings have been bulldozed, paving the way for the first 72 town houses, with porches and small backyards, of which 26 will be for public housing tenants, Ms. Foglio said. A dozen single-family homes that qualified public housing tenants can buy are also under construction throughout the neighborhood.
Wynona Ancrum said the support services, including job training and placement and an entrepreneurial program would start soon, leading her into a discussion of her dream to one day open a small restaurant in the neighborhood, which she is hopeful will change as the new housing goes up.
"Tenants want this to happen, especially for the children," she said.
Wynona Ancrun went on to say, "And we continue to watch the process."
For now, 9-year-old Shadya said she was looking forward to decorating her bedroom in one of the new town houses with special curtains of Mickey and Minnie Mouse or Winnie the Pooh.
Minutes later after visiting the wooden shells rising on Front Street, the family lingered a while before heading home.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: HOUSING;
COUNTRY'S HOTTEST MARKET

BYLINE: AP

 BODY:
The hottest housing market in 1999 was in the central New Jersey, according to a real estate industry survey. The region including Middlesex, Somerset and Hunterdon counties saw home prices rise by 23.3 percent last year, a report from the National Association of Realtors said. That was the highest percentage increase in the group's survey of 126 metropolitan areas in the United States. The median retail home price in the region was $221,200 in the fourth quarter. The sharp increase surprised even real estate agents and came despite higher mortgage rates. They attributed the rise to the prosperous economy and increasing population, together with a housing shortage in the most sought-after suburban neighborhoods.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: STATE ECONOMY;
ROSY REPORT

BYLINE: By WENDY GINSBERG 

 BODY:
New Jersey is enjoying its longest economic boom in history, one that is likely to continue, a report released by the state-appointed New Jersey Council of Economic Advisors says.
The council said last week that more than four million New Jersey residents were working, an increase of 65,000 jobs from the 1998, and the unemployment rate was 4.5 percent last year, 0.1 percent lower than in 1998. The council's report predicted continued but slower growth for this year, with an expected 53,000 new jobs to be created. 
 Joseph J. Seneca, the chairman of the council, said the growth started more than 100 months ago, and cited state investments in higher education and high technology. Other gauges of growth the council cited were a 5.8 percent increase in personal income and a 7 percent increase in retail sales.
George R. Nagle, executive director of the council, warned that low unemployment could mean some companies might leave the state to find skilled workers or to take advantage of lower wages. He said there was not much the state could do to encourage a continuation of the boom. "That's Alan Greenspan's area," he said.
 WENDY GINSBERG

HEADLINE: Governor's Involvement In the Global Economy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Jan. 30 "On Politics" column discussing Governor Whitman's participation in the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, ignored, for reasons that escape me, several important points about the importance of international trade to New Jersey's economic well being. 
 Over the past six years New Jersey's economy has been transformed from the economic laggard of the Northeast to the regional leader in economic expansion and job growth. Since Governor Whitman took office, we have created a record-breaking 390,000 new jobs in the Garden State. Many of those jobs are the result of an economic growth spurred by $11 billion in tax cuts. Credit must also be given to the aggressive pursuit of foreign trade opportunities for New Jersey businesses and to the steady growth of foreign investment in our state by partners around the globe.
In fact, New Jersey is one of the nation's premier sites for foreign trade. We rank fifth in the nation in direct foreign investment and we are America's ninth leading state in foreign exports. Last year a total of more than $24 billion in manufactured exports left our ports for markets overseas. More than 1,200 foreign firms are situated in New Jersey and more than 600,000 jobs in New Jersey are directly related to foreign trade.
The Governor's Economic Master Plan Commission identified foreign trade as one of four sectors where our economy is poised for growth, and last year's 12 percent expansion in foreign trade bears out their analysis.
Governor Whitman has put an emphasis on encouraging global businesses to do business in New Jersey. She fully recognizes that governors have an obligation to understand the world economy and to take part in it. Her hands-on approach to encouraging foreign trade and investment is guided by the knowledge that the competition for trade dollars grows more fierce every day.
It is deeply troubling that despite being provided with the governor's itinerary for the World Economic Forum, which included some 24 meetings with corporate and government leaders from around the world, and all of the above-cited information about the importance of foreign trade to New Jersey, your writer chose not to include it in his analysis of the governor's reasons for participating in the meetings.
Had he done so, your readers would have received the information and enlightenment we have all come to expect from The New York Times.
 
PETER J. MCDONOUGH JR.
Trenton
 
The writer is Governor Whitman's director of communications.
