HEADLINE: BUSINESS: OFF THE SHELF;
When Home Is a Foreign Notion

BYLINE: By ALECIA SWASY 

 BODY:
YOU know it's time to go home when you turn giddy over a new issue of Delta Air Lines' in-flight magazine. You find yourself muttering about seat-back trays in the upright and locked position and eating 12 peanuts for dinner.
You are on yet another airplane full of sleepwalking globetrotters like yourself -- here a rumpled gray suit and I.B.M. luggage tags, there multiply pierced body parts and a marked-up draft prospectus for a dot-com I.P.O., and seemingly everywhere management consultants from Andersen or McKinsey. 
 But that fellow with the notebook and the British accent is up to something perhaps a bit more profound: trying to locate "home" in a rootless age. He is Pico Iyer, who chronicles his search in "The Global Soul: Jet Lag, Shopping Malls and the Search for Home" (Knopf, $25). Mr. Iyer circles the planet as a writer for Time magazine, making occasional pit stops at his family's home in Santa Barbara, Calif., and his own near Kyoto, Japan, and frequent visits to modern crossroads of civilization like Los Angeles International Airport and Atlanta's Olympic village.
But first, he endures a few natural disasters, starting with a raging fire that consumed his parents' house; he escaped with a coughing cat and a manuscript. Then came earthquakes and mudslides. By Page 7, you want to summon the Red Cross.
Losing one's shelter must be jarring, but getting rid of all that stuff could be liberating -- less to dust, for one thing. The loss left Mr. Iyer searching for something beyond a building and furniture, perhaps something invisible, to anchor him.
Joining him on this trip can be discombobulating. He often starts his day in one continent, then dozes off in another, at a pace he likens to a childhood game of spinning around until he collapsed in a "dizzy heap on the floor." He concludes that modern lives are just "joy-riding in somebody else's Porsche, at 90 miles an hour, around blind curves."
Well, some of us are tooling through a school zone in a Honda. Everyone knows the experience of waking up on Monday, blinking and finding that it's already Friday. I myself misplaced all of last May through July. But that is a different kind of busy than Mr. Iyer's. My own former days as a frequent flier led me to the epiphany about the in-flight magazine and an urgent desire to get a life.
Not Mr. Iyer, who clearly enjoys a lifestyle that has racked up 1.5 million frequent-flier miles and a stamp-filled passport. Born to Indian parents and brought up in England and California, he writes that the very notion of home is foreign to him.
The book captures people in the layovers of life, beginning at LAX, a hub for the Global Soul, full of people from somewhere else. It may have a $10 million post office and a 23,000-space parking lot, he writes, but the airport is a "centerless mess with no real defining principle or heart." He describes a bit too much of that mess when he visits an adults-only establishment near the airport Hilton.
He likes Toronto better, finding New York's intelligence without its neuroses. But pity Atlanta, he writes, because the South rising again has turned the place into a "center of emptiness," a city of freeways leading to off-ramps leading to generic suburbs. Here, too, he manages to find the lap-dancing joint, this time one with a "corporate atmosphere."
Traveling to Atlanta offers the opportunity for a few jabs at a corporate sibling of his employer, Time Warner. At the CNN Center, he writes, a bumpkin tour guide who clearly isn't aware that CNN is a Global Soul embarrasses a visitor from Iraq with rude questions. Mr. Iyer finds the same lack of global brotherhood in the confused aftermath of the Centennial Park bombing during the 1996 Olympics, when a white man yells at a visitor from the Middle East: "You see what happens when we let you people in?"
What Mr. Iyer discerns in this is not so much provincialism and bigotry as a strong case for slowing life down a bit and understanding the people around us. When there are people around us at all, that is: everyone is busy sending e-mail, but a smiley emoticon can hardly replace a good laugh in a friend's company. In a similar vein, a friend of mine wrote recently that dinner tables ought to get more use than just Thanksgiving Day. (And while we're at it, let's agree to be sillier among strangers in elevators.)
SOME of Mr. Iyer's best moments come in talking to strangers. At the Olympic village in Barcelona, Spain, in 1992, he finds an archery team from Bhutan that had never seen a stadium before. His writing is most graceful in simple description, as when the temple bells ring on the Philosopher's Path in Kyoto. His pace slows in the final pages -- at last! -- and a reader can almost hear the clumps of snow falling from the dark trees.
Mr. Iyer does find a place to call home when his personal life draws him to rural Japan. But even there he is treated as a gaijin, an alien. He endures customs checks that would send most of us screaming for the American Embassy; he describes being strip-searched after agents found a Sudafed tablet in his bags.
For all the relative serenity of the final pages, though, a reader cannot count on Mr. Iyer's staying home, wherever that is, for long. In the book's acknowledgments, he thanks his travel agent.

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 1405 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ford Excursion;
Camping With the Incredible Hulk

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

DATELINE: PILOT MOUNTAIN, N.C.

 BODY:
OR all the cargo capacity of the 2000 Ford Excursion, it enters the market carrying almost more baggage than it can handle. Ford's introduction last year of its uber-utility provoked protests and galvanized a coalition of sport utility haters -- from environmentalists to intimidated drivers of small cars -- for whom the 7,000-pound Excursion was a big, fat bete noire.
There, its critics said, behold what lies at the bottom of America's slippery-slope love affair with huge S.U.V.'s. 
 Perhaps, perhaps not. Certainly there are heavy-hauling types like ranchers and boaters who can actually use its bulk, its muscle and its five-ton towing capacity; Ford insists that it is serving this market.
For those outside that demographic, the Excursion may pass a threshold of practicality. At almost 19 feet long and 80 inches wide, it cannot gain entry to many garages and car washes. It hangs out of an ordinary parking space like a fat man in a Speedo. Considering the urban aggravation factor, you might as well commute in a Zamboni.
If dimestore cowboys and urban poseurs buy the Excursion just to make a larger-than-thou statement, they will be getting what they deserve.
 Tellingly, General Motors, which builds what had previously been the largest sport utility, the Suburban, will not try to out-gross its new rival. Indeed, it has called the redesigned Suburban, with an almost straight face, "the sensible S.U.V."
Built on Ford's Super Duty pickup platform, the Excursion is available with three engines: a 5.4-liter, 255-horsepower V-8, which is standard with two-wheel drive; a 6.8-liter, 310-horse V-10, standard on 4-by-4's; and a 7.3-liter, 235-horsepower diesel V-8 that generates a globe-turning 500 foot-pounds of torque. With the larger engines, maximum towing capacity is 10,000 pounds, plus almost a ton of cargo in the truck. Like all of Ford's sport utilities, the Excursion meets federal low-emission standards.
My test vehicle was a loden-green Excursion Limited 4-by-4 with the V-10, which offers a shade less towing (9,600 pounds) and cargo capacity (1,710 pounds) than two-wheel-drive models. This configuration, at $41,665, is likely to be the bedrock of the line.
When it came to testing this behemoth, it was clear that the ordinary drive over hill and dale would not suffice. We would have to tow something -- something big. We found it in a 30-foot, 3-axle Airstream travel trailer, the descendent of those capsule-shaped aluminum campers made famous in the 1950's. Weighing in at more than 7,500 pounds and costing $57,133 (loaded with everything plus a kitchen sink, this one of Corian), the Airstream is just the kind of Paul Bunyan load the Excursion was designed to transport.
On the appointed Friday, my wife and I and another couple piled a weekend's worth of gear, plus a high-strung Weimaraner, into the capacious interior and headed for Jameokee campground.
Among the first things you notice are the outsized doors, any one of which would do justice to the abbey at Rouen. The three cargo doors (an upper liftgate and two lower doors) swing fully out of the way for unobstructed access to the hold. We removed the third-row bench, which is on rollers, to create a warehouse of 100 cubic feet. This space was so large that we could dispense with packing altogether and just shovel in our belongings, and the dog, too.
Full-length running boards are standard, to aid in the almost two-foot climb up into the cabin. Once seated, the driver has a view that is panoramic, in the sense that guides at Niagara Falls use the word. You simply tower over other traffic, coming nearly eye-to-eye with long-haul truckers. The front doors have cut-downs in the window sills so the driver can have a better view of the oversized and heated outside mirrors. Even so, it's easy to lose sight of smaller fry, like Cadillacs, swimming alongside.
Compared with the Suburban, the Excursion interior feels more refined. The seats were amply cushioned and upholstered with supple leather. Ford used lots of sound-deadening material, and it ended up with a vast volume of amniotic quiet.
All of Ford's experience at creating comfy S.U.V.'s has been brought to bear. There are 10 strategically situated cup holders and many shrewdly placed cubbyholes. The second row of seats not only recline, they also fold forward to create a flat-bed cargo area measuring 146.4 cubic feet. It looks like a carpeted squash court.
On the road, the unladen Excursion drives like the gigantic truck it started life as, jouncing merrily on heavy-duty leaf springs. Nothing could improve the ride so much as a quarter-ton of sandbags. The steering is light and reasonably direct. But the brakes -- four discs with an antilock system -- seemed inadequate to haul the 7,190-pound vehicle down from 60 m.p.h.
Whatever vices the Excursion may have as a passenger wagon become virtues when you attach a big trailer. As a matter of simple leverage, a vehicle with a long wheelbase is more stable when towing. Likewise, sheer physics mean that the heavier the towing vehicle, relative to what is being towed, the more stable and secure the ride.
Nonetheless, you can't simply plug an Airstream into the Excursion's Class IV hitch and drive off. In the interests of safety, Airstream Inc. insisted that we use a dual sway-bar rig, a spidery steel apparatus that helps to prevent the trailer from weaving. We also required an adjustable towing head as well as an auxiliary brake-control module. This device, wired under the dash, connects the truck's brakes to the trailer's. Without it, the trailer would tend to push even the Excursion off the road.
After an hour of installation, Grady Kilby, owner of Out-of-Doors Mart in Kernersville, N.C., pronounced the Excursion fit to travel. "The biggest mistake people make in trailering is having too small a tow vehicle," he said. No danger of that here.
For casual users, the 425 foot-pounds of torque is wasted. Given the weight and gearing, that power cannot make the truck hustle any quicker to 60 m.p.h. (10.6 seconds, according to Automobile magazine). Where torque comes in handy is under load. Leaving Out-of-Doors Mart, the Excursion accelerated as smoothly and crisply as ever, as if it were pulling nothing at all. At highway speeds, the engine relaxed into an effortless hum. Only on uphill grades of 4 percent or more did the truck begin to exert.
The purpose of the load-leveling hitch is to distribute the trailer's weight evenly on the truck's chassis, so that the front end doesn't rise off the ground. Even so, the Excursion felt light and the steering was a little vague, though not so much as to affect control.
In fact, the really difficult part of the trailering experience was the touchiness of the brakes. If I even breathed on the pedal, the auxiliary controller seized the trailer's drum brakes, jerking the truck back alarmingly. I learned to use engine braking to slow down, and to plan well ahead when stopping.
Our experiment in heavy trailering was, alas, not without incident. Backing down an incline of wet grass, trying to angle toward the dump station -- the mysteries of gray water and brown water are just as well unplumbed, as far as I'm concerned -- I pressed the brakes too hard. Both vehicles' brakes locked, and I folded the rig like a pocketknife, putting a nasty dent in the Airstream and an unsightly scratch on the Excursion. What an awful sound!
We returned the Airstream to the dealership and sighed in relief that more damage had not been done. Meanwhile, our calculations showed that the Excursion's fuel economy was, oddly, about the same with and without the trailer: 10 miles per gallon.
Numbers like that infuriate Excursion critics and no doubt cause chagrin for Ford's chairman, William C. Ford Jr., who is trying to put a green face on the company. At the Detroit auto show last month, as Ford announced its new Think division of environmentally friendly bikes, carts and electric cars, it was hard not view the effort as an attempt to atone for the Excursion.
Still, with more than 36,000 already sold, demand is likely to outstrip the production limit of 60,000 a year. With Ford pocketing an estimated $15,000 to $20,000 of profit on each sale, the Excursion may turn out to be one of the most successful public relations disasters in corporate history.
 
INSIDE TRACK: All that the market can bear.

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles 

LENGTH: 444 words

HEADLINE: Gas Prices Rise: Will Guzzlers Pay?

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

 BODY:
ALES of big, thirsty pickups and sport utility vehicles have boomed in recent years as the economy hummed and gasoline prices sagged to record lows.
But this winter, gas prices have surged to all-time highs. Will gas-pump sticker shock start to affect sales of large sport utilities? 
 Economists who work for Detroit automakers say there is no reason to think so. They say truck sales are affected more by factors like low unemployment, rising incomes, high consumer confidence, stable vehicle prices and record corporate profits.
But David Littmann, chief economist for Comerica Bank in Detroit, predicts that gas prices will bite into auto sales this year. Auto economists say the increase so far -- to a national average of more than $1.30 a gallon for unleaded regular -- could cost each consumer about $300 more a year.
"Higher gas prices, combined with higher interest rates, will hit consumers' wallets, and that will slow -- not stop -- auto sales and probably cause a shift in the vehicle mix," Mr. Littmann said.
 He expects buyers to take notice by the second half of this year. In response, he predicts, automakers will offer sales incentives on large, high-profit vehicles.
Still, Mr. Littmann is among many economists who predict an unprecedented seventh year of vehicle sales topping 15 million. And he expects trucks to outsell cars for a second consecutive year.
Indeed, so far, higher gas prices have not depressed sales and have not brought a shift to smaller vehicles. Vehicle sales ran at a sizzling annual rate of 18 million in January; sales for all of 1999 set a record of just under 17 million. Sales of full-size pickups and sport utilities remain strong while small, fuel-efficient cars go wanting.
Economists say there is no single price that will suddenly cause preferences to shift. Rather, they say, buying habits change only because of bad economic news, sustained high gas prices or shortages.
Some economists predict gas prices to rise further and stay there for the next year. W. Van Bussmann, corporate economist for DaimlerChrysler, expects prices to peak this summer at $1.40 a gallon and gradually come down. But he predicts that vehicle sales will be only slightly below last year's.
 Environmentalists, meantime, hope higher prices will benefit efficient vehicles. "We are not for increased gas prices per se," said Charles Griffith, director of auto projects for the Ecology Center in Ann Arbor, Mich., an advocacy group for cleaner, more fuel-efficient transportation. "But higher gas prices might well cause manufacturers and consumers to reflect on the cost of the automobile on the environment."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 4; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: What It Takes

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
ACROSS the street from the American Museum of Natural History, Betsy Gotbaum, director of the New-York Historical Society, has been watching the construction of the dazzling, hugely trumpeted $210 million planetarium with great interest and strong emotions.
"Ellen took a place that was moribund and has done something spectacular," Ms. Gotbaum said of Ellen V. Futter, the museum's director. "Actually, I feel an enormous amount of envy." 
 Ms. Gotbaum, who started her job in 1994, a year after Ms. Futter joined the Natural History Museum, has been trying to do something spectacular on a smaller scale. Her task is far more daunting, since the historical society was nearly bankrupt and had spent its entire endowment. It was within a hair's breadth of folding when she stepped in.
But meanwhile, she is eyeing the success of her neighbor to see if she can find a way to share its success. The talk of long lines of impatiently waiting visitors gave her a brainstorm.
"We're trying to figure out a way to bring over some of the 500, 600 people who can't get in," Ms. Gotbaum said. "Like, for 50 cents, come to the historical society, look around, and you won't lose your place in line."
New York City is blessed with richly stocked cultural institutions. But while New Yorkers love their venerable institutions, they take them for granted. They see them as mountains, solid, self-sustaining and self-reliant. Making dramatic changes at century-old public institutions can seem as unthinkable as sculpturing the Adirondacks.
But in the last few decades, several individuals have stepped into major but neglected institutions and shot electricity through them: among them, Thomas Hoving at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; Harvey Lichtenstein at the Brooklyn Academy of Music; Vartan Gregorian at the New York Public Library; and most recently, Ms. Futter at the Natural History Museum.
Although these people have different backgrounds and personalities, they share the ability to transform a lackluster place, give it a prominent spot on the cultural radar screen and infuse it with money, powerful board members, visitors and social panache. They also have in common an ability to redefine the nature of an institution in profound ways, a willingness to take on entrenched forces and a deep awareness of the importance of image and publicity, not to mention great reservoirs of personal charm and charisma.
A vital requirement is the ability to garner support from board members and other donors, to make partners of the money people and by doing so pull them into the action.
"You can't ever be a one-person show," said Randy Bourscheidt, director of the Alliance for the Arts, a nonprofit advocacy group. "You need somebody brilliant to start, but that person doesn't stay alone long."
These individuals also have to be confident enough to push ahead when insiders, like employees and board members, dismiss their plans as overreaching and unrealistic. By nurturing, nudging, coaxing and nagging board members, employees, politicians, journalists and the public, they turn their sometimes creaky institutions into living, vibrant centers that serve, please, surprise and teach all kinds of people: tourists, children, scholars, dabblers.
Suddenly, their institutions are in the news. Gossip columns mention the celebrities who attend their after-hours parties. Their accomplishments are touted not just in arts pages but also in the news columns.
Those who seek to achieve such things do not always succeed, and sometimes making even a little progress may seem to take forever. Ms. Gotbaum has yet to make waves at the historical society, largely, she says, because it was in such bad financial trouble when she took over.
"This place was pathetic," she said. "It was closed, with its collections in storage costing $500,000 a year. It had huge internal fights and a board that was dispirited and exhausted. But it was something that could really be fixed."
 
At the Met Museum, Displays Worthy of the Riches Within
Before the arrival of Thomas Hoving, the patrician, energetic former Parks Commissioner and curator of the Cloisters, crowds and controversy were unknown at the Metropolitan Museum. It was famous for its vast, diverse collections, spanning thousands of years. But when Mr. Hoving arrived in 1966, even the museum's fans said the displays were unimaginative and the walls grimy.
To some in the art world, the Met was a temple of high-minded aesthetics and scholarship. To others, it was stuffy, dull and snobbish, indifferent to the public and to the new art flourishing outside its doors.
"The place was slowly dying in a very elegant way," Mr. Hoving said in an interview the other day. He said he was hired by a handful of board members, "an unofficial cabal," who altered the museum bylaws to allow him to make big changes.
When Mr. Hoving left the Met 11 years later, blockbusters, corporate sponsorship and splashy promotional campaigns, previously unknown in this country, were staples at New York museums. An annual total of 3.4 million New Yorkers and tourists were visiting the Met, compared with 2 million in 1970, the last year for which figures are available.
Mr. Hoving achieved his goals by being willing to popularize the museum, to make shows sound as tantalizing as hit movies, to open doors wider, to seek a more diverse audience. He also had to ignore accusations that he was vulgarizing the place.
"The great fear was that he would lower standards," Mr. Bourscheidt said. "He was communicating with the press and creating buzz. The arts economic impact studies were especially shocking."
Mr. Bourscheidt was referring to Mr. Hoving's pioneering analyses of how much money the museum's visitors spent in the city. These studies were attacked as devices that debased art, sullying its purity. In 1971, Hilton Kramer, art critic of The New York Times, accused Mr. Hoving of having a "box office mentality."
Mr. Hoving took special heat for his practice of acquiring corporate sponsors for major shows and prominently displaying their logos, now routine practice at museums. He was criticized for selling floral patterns on vintage wallpaper in the American wing to Springs Industries for sheet and pillowcase designs. An attempt to persuade the makers of Fresca, a soft drink, to sponsor an exhibition of Florentine frescoes failed.
But most of his efforts succeeded. By the time he left in 1977, his innovations had become mainstream.
 
A Vision Grows in Brooklyn: Avant-Garde Art for the People
During the years Mr. Hoving was transforming the Met's treasures into really big shows, Harvey Lichtenstein was riding the subway to Lower Manhattan in search of remarkable but unknown creative artists. Mr. Lichtenstein, a former dancer and a passionate devotee of the arts who had been named director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1967, was haunting downtown clubs and loft theaters to find his treasures.
"First you have to have the goods," said Mr. Lichtenstein, who left the academy in June and now heads BAM Local Development Corporation, which seeks to revive downtown Brooklyn. "You can only fool people so long."
When he took over at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, it was little more than a borough cultural center where performances by the Brooklyn Philharmonic were regularly punctuated by grunts from the judo classes renting the rooms upstairs.
"I had to do things that were singular, unique in the city, that Lincoln Center wasn't doing," said Mr. Lichtenstein, an effusive bear of a man. "I had great ambitions to do things that were really important."
In the process, mostly through the Next Wave Festival, the annual umbrella series of avant-garde events that became his signature achievement, he gave artists like Merce Cunningham, Twyla Tharp, Peter Brook and Philip Glass a stage and an audience long before they were in popular demand. He made it hip to take the train to Brooklyn to see their work. (He also provided shuttle buses.)
"He delivered great stuff," said Jonathan Rose, a longtime board member of the academy. "He delivered amazing goods. BAM built an audience that trusted Harvey's taste so much, every year he'd present things people never heard of and they'd come. He didn't hit 100 percent -- he took a lot of risks -- but the peaks were so high."
As an ambitious visionary with a tendency to spend more than he had, Mr. Lichtenstein needed a strong financial deputy by his side, and Karen Hopkins, who had held administrative jobs in small theaters and who joined the academy in 1980 as a development assistant, became that person.
"I would always push her," Mr. Lichtenstein said of Ms. Hopkins, who is now president of the academy. "She was conservative in what she said could raise. But she always got it." His last-minute decision to spend $500,000 the academy did not have for an ambitious production by the French director Ariane Mnouchkine pushed her to the edge, he said. "It was the only time I made her cry. We went out on the street and she burst into tears.
"I didn't know anything about money," he continued. "I didn't know anything about money or unions or budgets or publicity or press or board relations. It was murder, war. I was under tremendous pressure to keep things going, to keep visible, to draw audiences. When there was no money, I had to manufacture it. Many times we made payroll at the very last minute."
But Mr. Lichtenstein had a superb touch for cultivating wealthy donors and board members. A particular lure were memorable parties at which big-money people could mingle with the artists.
"Harvey was developing operas with Peter Sellars," Mr. Rose recalled of one gathering. "And Peter Sellars told us: 'I'm going to walk you through the piece I'm working on.' He had us sit on chairs, on the floor. Everybody was very quiet, and he said: 'I'm going to tell you a story. I can see it. It's not written yet, but I can see the vision.' We were completely engaged."
Without money to advertise, Mr. Lichtenstein relied on critics and arts writers. He knew they needed material, and he gave them performances unlike anything they were seeing in mainstream arts spaces.
"The press heard that something new was happening in Brooklyn," he said. "They came to see. I got their support, and word got around."
Last year, 300,000 people attended performances at the once-provincial institution.
 
Raising Voices and Money At the Library
In the 1970's and early 1980's, the New York Public Library was the polar opposite of Brooklyn Academy of Music. Where the academy was freewheeling, thrilling and erratically brilliant, the library was grimly utilitarian, with spartan decor, a penny-pinching mentality and a $50 million deficit.
Vartan Gregorian, a powerhouse provost at the University of Pennsylvania, became president in 1981. In a recent conversation, he listed items covered at his first board meeting: "Closing the branches. Charging fees to take out books. Selling the books."
Mr. Gregorian disagreed with this approach. To him, the problem was not lack of money but lack of pride. Under no conditions, he said, should the library beg.
"The New York Public Library is not a charity case," he remembered saying. "It is already great. The city cannot claim to be a center of culture without it. There is no way anybody can even think about it not existing."
To realize his vision, he approached law firms, universities and corporations to persuade them to support the library, whose free services they depended on, and suggesting that those services could come to an end if they did not provide help. He added up all the money donated over several months, including $1 bills from children, and announced that the library had received a gift of hundreds of thousands of dollars. He erected a fence to keep out Bryant Park's drug dealers and posted signs that said, "Future Site of Renovations of the New York Public Library," when plans existed only in his head. His aim was to give a sense of momentum before anything concrete had happened.
When he did raise money, much of it from private donors, he spent lavishly on repairs and cleaning to make the rundown building shine. With the help of Brooke Astor, the powerful philanthropist, he created a group called the Literary Lions, which more than any other single initiative gave the dowdy library an image of glitter, wealth and high culture. Monthly dinner parties were held in sumptuous upstairs rooms. Each of the 21 tables cost $10,000 to sponsor -- the tab later rose considerably -- and was headed by the contributor's choice of a famous author. Within a year or two, Mr. Gregorian recalled, The Washington Post had ranked the sponsorship of a Literary Lions table No. 2 in social cachet, just after an invitation to a private dinner with Queen Elizabeth at Buckingham Palace.
Although major improvements like the renovation of the reading room occurred after he left in 1989, during his tenure the budget more than doubled, from $57 million to $136 million.
"He knew what he valued, the written word," said Peter Carzasty, a publicist with the Kreisberg Group, a New York public relations firm that represents many cultural institutions. "He made literature sexy."
 
Taking a Wealthy Dinosaur Into the Space Age
When Ellen Futter took over the Natural History Museum in 1993, it was one of the city's wealthiest cultural institutions, with a $220 million endowment and three million visitors a year.
But most of the visitors were schoolchildren on field trips. It was a place to take the youngsters once or twice a year, to show them the dinosaurs and the blue whale. Adults might remember it with nostalgia, but many were bored by the thought of actually spending an afternoon there. The place was ignored by the philanthropic and cultural elite.
"They'd do better if they charged to get out," Mr. Bourscheidt said.
But when Ms. Futter arrived, she did not talk about the need to overcome its dreary image. The museum was already full of fascinating collections and exhibits, she insisted.
"It was overwhelming," she said in an interview shortly before the opening of the new planetarium. "It had so much stuff. Real stuff, that could be points of entry to cover the topics people are mostly acutely interested in."
Ms. Futter is not a scientist. She is a corporate lawyer who as president of Barnard College from 1980 to 1993 saved it from being absorbed into Columbia College. At Natural History, she had an even more ambitious mission: to draw crowds and donations, to position the museum at the forefront of the city's jostling cultural shrines; in short, to make science sexy.
By all accounts, she has succeeded. The special exhibitions acquired zip, notably "The Nature of Diamonds" in 1998 and, currently, "Body Art: Marks of Identity," a display of tattoos, piercings and body paintings through the centuries. Hundreds of dinosaur bones were pulled out of storage and displayed in bright new halls. A room containing tropical plants and live butterflies enthralled visitors and press alike.
One of her most pressing problems had been the rundown, obsolete Hayden Planetarium. Ms. Futter initially considered refurbishing it on the cheap, but was persuaded to try something more ambitious. According to Mr. Rose, whose parents, Frederick Phineas and Sandra Priest Rose, gave both $20 million and their names to the project, the creation of the Earth and Space Center and its sophisticated new planetarium was an example of ideas and enthusiasm bouncing among Ms. Futter, board members and staff.
"It's part of the personality" of people like Ms. Futter, Jonathan Rose said.
"They bring you in," he added. "They don't just want your money. They want your time and your expertise."
 
Faces Pressed to the Glass, Others Hope Their Turn Is Next
Although some New York institutions have been able to transform themselves and establish a premier place in the city's cultural landscape, for others the jury is still out.
A major example is the Brooklyn Museum of Art, which like BAM had the disadvantage of its location, despite its renowned collections and the ambitious plans of previous directors. In an effort to lure art lovers across the East River, Arnold L. Lehman, who became head of the Brooklyn Museum in 1997, embarked on several strategies. Among them was a program called First Saturdays, which features swing music, dancing, exhibitions and movies, which have been crowded with hundreds and even thousands of people from Brooklyn, and occasionally from beyond.
Mr. Lehman and the board added "entertain" to "educate" in the museum's mission statement. Since then, he has made big waves with Sensation, an exhibition of provocative British art that incurred the wrath of Mayor Giuliani, produced endless headlines and is now being played out in court.
Sometimes institutions simply fall off the public radar screen. That was the case with the New-York Historical Society, which in the early 90's was in such dire financial shape that it closed its doors for two years.
Ms. Gotbaum has managed to ensure the immediate survival of the 196-year-old society, which is renowned for treasures like its original Audubon watercolors. During the last five years, she has eliminated its $1 million debt and built an endowment of $29 million. She has also put together a new 35-member board practically from scratch.
In November, the museum plans to open a renovated 17,000-square-foot space on the fourth floor to house much of its eclectic collection, from Hudson River School paintings to George Washington's Revolutionary War cot.
Ms. Gotbaum's fingers are crossed.
"I have a penchant for trying to do things with places that aren't performing the way they could," she said. "Maybe I'm crazy."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;
Stiffening Resistance to a Planned Megamarket

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
For weeks, community groups and elected officials in Clinton say, they have not been adequately informed about Costco's plan to build what would be Manhattan's largest supermarket.
Construction of the two-level store along the entire blockfront on the west side of Tenth Avenue between 55th and 56th Streets is scheduled to begin next year. 
 Last week, many local officials became even more upset when Costco confirmed rumors that it is applying for a zoning change to build apartments over the store.
Assemblyman Scott Stringer called the revision a "classic bait-and-switch tactic that we had to hear about through the grapevine." Although Costco did not need any zoning change to build the store, the company agreed to meet in December with local elected officials, Mr. Stringer said, but company officials never provided any further response to community concerns.
"This takes a big development to mega status," he said. "It's time for Costco to be forthcoming about their plans. If they're going to build a residential tower, they should have gotten their act together and told us."
Jeff Brotman, chairman of Costco, would not furnish details about the apartments at the December meeting because it was added later, when the company decided that the project would not be economically feasible otherwise.
Construction costs are higher than anticipated, he said. "In Manhattan over the last six months, they've gone up 30 percent for our projects."
Opponents say the West Side neighborhood is an inappropriate location for the 75,000 square-foot store, which would not have a parking lot or garage, because, they say, it would likely attract bulk buyers who would arrive by car.
Also, they say, delivery trucks and garbage trucks serving the store would further clog local streets. "We're at a breaking point already; there's no more room," said John Fisher, president of the Clinton Special District Coalition.
Owners of small stores in the area fear that the Costco would drive them out of business, he added.
Katherine Gray, the chairwoman of Community Board 4, said local leaders told Costco that there are several public housing developments near the site, and asked if Costco would waive for lower-income shoppers the annual $35 membership fee it charges at its stores, and whether it would accept all food stamps. Mr. Brotman said the store would not waive the fee and was undecided about food stamps.
As for traffic, Mr. Brotman said, "You're always going to have people who say they don't want any traffic, but either way, you're going to have development there." COREY KILGANNON

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Peter A. Vlachos;
Forum Austin Global Equity Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IN the 1950's, during the cold war, Peter A. Vlachos traveled the world as a sergeant in the United States Air Force Strategic Air Command, repairing advanced electronics. His interest in such gadgetry continues today as he buys shares of communications and electronics companies for his $38.3 million mutual fund, Forum Austin Global Equity. Such stocks account for 42 percent of the portfolio.
Of late, he has guided his fund to impressive results. Austin Global returned 33.3 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Feb. 4, compared with 19.5 percent for its peer group of world stock funds, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher. 
 Mr. Vlachos, 62, takes a top-down approach at the fund, using macroeconomic strategies to choose regions of the world for investing. "We look for growth in the gross domestic product and a modernizing economy," he said, "and we like to see that inflation is under control."
Right now, that approach is leading him to the Pacific Rim, including Japan. The region accounts for 30 percent of the fund's holdings, up from 6 percent just two years ago. "Japan is the second-largest economy in the world," he said from his office in Midtown Manhattan. "It's vitally important that it be not only viable but vibrant. We think it's recovering nicely from the 1998 monetary crisis."
An additional 35 percent is in Europe. "We like Europe, even though it is still lagging behind the U.S. in its drive to restructure," he said. "But it's on the right path."
He is not worried that the euro has fallen 42 percent against the dollar since the beginning of last year. "We think it should appreciate to above parity" with the dollar, he said. The euro now trades at 98.75 cents.
Mr. Vlachos is less sanguine about the domestic stock market, having trimmed the fund's United States holdings to about 30 percent, from more than 40 percent. "Near term, we expect the U.S. market to be pretty bumpy," he said. "We think the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates another quarter-point this spring, which means a little pause in the market."
The remaining 5 percent is in Latin America, though he plans to increase that share. "It's gone through a rough period," he said of the region, "but earnings will probably start to show up later this year."
Mr. Vlachos focuses on companies that are being privatized by governments and have strong long-term growth prospects. He looks particularly at those involved in infrastructure, like telecommunications companies, as well as electronics and financial services concerns.
"Privatized companies usually come out at attractive valuations because there's an awful lot to sell," he said. "These companies usually have an entrenched position in the industry; they are well-financed and have interesting growth prospects."
He also looks for undervalued companies whose share prices can be helped by mergers, spinoffs or reorganizations.
While he has no hard-and-fast rules, he likes companies with strong balance sheets and minimal debt. Depending on the industry, he wants annual earnings and revenue growth of 15 to 40 percent. Mr. Vlachos says he is willing to pay for good growth opportunities. "We don't shy away from paying high multiples," he said, "as long as we see growth and a good operating history." The forward price-to-earnings multiple of the portfolio is currently 30.
WE recently bought shares in Corning Inc., which makes components for fiber optic cable and which holds some of the basic patents in the telecommunications industry. "They're streamlining their business to focus on telecommunications," he said, noting that Corning had recently acquired Oak Industries, a maker of amplifiers and cable TV set-top boxes.
Because of high demand for its fiber optic products, he said, Corning is building new factories. The shares have returned 238 percent in the last 12 months, but the price is justified by his anticipated three-year earnings growth rate of 20 to 25 percent a year, Mr. Vlachos said.
He bought shares last December at $114; the stock now trades at $165.75, or 71 to 69 times his earnings estimate of $2.35 to $2.40 a share for this year.
Another favorite is Murata Manufacturing of Japan, which makes components for telecommunications equipment, digital television and hand-held wireless devices. The company has "U.S.-style" management, he said, meaning that it is willing to pare assets and reorganize its work force to increase profits. He sees earnings growth of 20 percent a year, on average, over three years.
Mr. Vlachos bought shares in December at 18,300 yen. The stock now trades at 21,010 yen, or 90 to 72 times forecast 2000 earnings of 234 to 290 yen a share.
Telecom Italia Mobile is the fund's third-largest holding, at 4.38 percent of the portfolio. The company is the second largest mobile telephone provider in Europe, after Vodafone Airtouch, with a customer base of nearly 18 million.
The company's shares are expensive, he added, but valued in line withsimilar companies worldwide. "There's been a lot of talk about the company merging with its parent," he said, referring to Telecom Italia, which owns 60 percent of the shares. "Anyone who wants to take it over, whether its parent company or an outsider, will have to pay a premium to market."
Earnings growth should exceed 20 percent a year, on average, over three years, he said. He bought shares in 1995 for the equivalent of $1.24. The stock now trades at 13.752 euros, or $13.5437; that is 71 times his forecast earnings this year of $0.19, or 0.193 euros.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Weighing the Value of Corporate Largess

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
AT a time when the traditional bonds between employees and companies are loosening and a growing share of the economy's work is done by freelance, part-time and temporary workers, the Ford Motor Company took a giant step in the other direction when it announced that it would offer each of its 350,000 employees a computer, printer and unlimited Internet access for $5 a month. Delta Air Lines followed with a similar though less heavily subsidized plan for its 80,000 workers.
Beyond Ford's stated goal of increasing computer literacy, the computers-for-everyone policy may have deeper ramifications. Here are three perspectives. JULIE FLAHERTY
 
HARLEY SHAIKEN
Professor of social and cultural studies at the University of California, specializing in labor issues.
This will link up employees in some new, unexplored ways. The home page is designed by Ford, so the company can get its message out on a host of issues it thinks are important. It has new access to its workers worldwide.
Yet it gets into uncharted territory, because the same technology that allows you to buy a Ford Explorer on the Internet also allows you to organize demonstrations in Seattle. Ford workers in Sao Paulo can talk to Ford workers in Cleveland. This brings the possibility of worker interaction in a very far-reaching, electronic way. How this powerful tool will be used is an open question.
Ford obviously wants to underscore the connection between the $5-a-month charge for the computer and Henry Ford's doubling of assembly-line wages in 1913 -- to $5 a day. Originally, that money came with a heavy dose of paternalism: Ford judged your moral worth to get that wage.
This time around, Ford is saying that is not the intent, and employees will be able to use the computers as they see fit. It would be disastrous public relations to break that promise, so it is likely Ford won't do anything heavy-handed. But that's Ford -- what about the next company?
As we move into the Internet age more forcefully, all these kinds of issues will be there, whether it's putting up with advertising or corporate propaganda to get a free computer, or having companies track your every move on the Net. There is going to be a new mix between what is job-related and what relates to one's private life.
 
THOMAS KOCHAN
Co-director of the Institute for Work and Employment Research at M.I.T.
As long as employees have a voice in how these kinds of benefits are utilized -- and by that I mean a positive but independent voice -- it will serve everyone's interest. If employers approach it in a paternalistic or a self-interested fashion, then it could turn into an intrusion and backfire.
I think Ford has got the right institutional setting to make this work. Auto workers know how to take care of their own time and guard their personal and family responsibilities. They traditionally have negotiated for more time off. The kind of positive relationship that Ford and the U.A.W. have will help them find the right balance between the advantages in this opportunity and the intrusion on personal time.
The key lesson from research on family benefits is that when employees have a voice in shaping how they are administered day to day, then the benefits are utilized effectively, and it serves everyone well. But when they are announced from the top down, and there isn't a workplace culture that helps employees control the use of these services, there are problems.
To employees, it clearly sends a strong message that lifelong learning is important, for all workers and their families. Perhaps a broader cross-section of the work force will be now able to benefit from the new economy and make educational resources available to their children.
 
ROBERT DRAGO
Professor of labor studies at Pennsylvania State University and moderator of the Work/Family Newsgroup on the Internet.
For most Americans now, access to the Internet allows us to be good citizens, to participate in society and to know what's going on. Children are coming home from school with assignments that can only be completed on the Internet. It's crucial.
One worry is that, given modern technology, communications is a more important component of all jobs today. If you can shift that communication from work to home, you've got people working more.
That may not be the case here. But I worry that the company will start presuming that all employees have Internet access, and people will be required to be on the Internet to get important information. That's a danger even if it is not the official policy, because supervisors will assume that people have access. That could potentially be a problem.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 6; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
As Mergers Get Bigger, So Does The Danger

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
MERGERS today are something to behold. The big ones are four or five times pricier than the biggest in the 1980's, and the number keeps climbing like an airliner gaining altitude. Giant companies on different continents come together as easily as neighborhood stores, and hardly a week goes by without another huge deal. The time has come to stop gawking at this spectacle and to figure out what is happening to so many of the corporations that shape our lives.
We read with amazement that America Online is buying Time Warner to get material to transmit over the Internet. Daimler and Chrysler have merged to gain greater access to each other's markets, creating a giant that is neither European nor American. And just last week, Pfizer said it would buy another pharmaceutical powerhouse, Warner Lambert, in part to get hold of Lipitor, a hot-selling anti-cholesterol drug. 
 Seldom since the late 19th century, when corporate trusts dominated oil, steel, copper and railroads in the United States, has there been such a march toward concentration, this time on a global scale. And the process is gathering speed. Companies around the world agreed last year to pay $3.4 trillion to acquire other companies, Thomson Securities Data reports. The total has skyrocketed from less than $1 trillion in 1995, when the current merger wave took off.
The action was very different in the 1980's, when leveraged buyouts prevailed. Companies were bought, typically with borrowed money, and broken into pieces thought to be worth more apart than together. Today, companies are merging to multiply their size.
The danger is that two or three huge corporations will come to dominate each industry and gain the power to shove up prices. As effective competition disappears, so will the innovation and striving for quality that it fosters. The American auto industry fell into that state after World War II, until Japan broke the Big Three's dominance in the 1970's. If the merger wave now unfolding across the globe goes too far, who will be the spoilers?
"There is pressure to make very diverse industries less diverse," said David Wyss, chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI. "That is because in nearly every country today, it is hard for more than two or three companies in any industry to make money."
Concentration is the natural drift in a market system, but it lay dormant or was held in check through most of the last century. Now it is unchained again, for a laundry list of reasons. One is the booming stock market: AOL's surging stock price allowed it to swallow the much bigger Time Warner. Deregulation also plays a big role: Not long ago, the joining of Citibank, Travelers and Salomon Smith Barney, for example, would have been illegal. So would many of the mergers in telecommunications, before Congress changed the rules in 1996. And there are fewer obstacles to cross-border combinations today.
Technology is both a means and a motive. New information networks allow managers to oversee bigger operations than before. Breakthroughs in delivering phone calls, TV signals and Internet data over a single line have companies scrambling for position through mergers. And e-commerce is not likely to be very profitable until a few companies emerge in dominant positions.
Excess capacity pushes mergers in established industries, to eliminate duplication and achieve economies of scale. Even the Asian financial crisis has played a role. United Technologies, for example, which makes Otis elevators among other products, acquired control last month of a big South Korean elevator maker, extending United's reach into that lively market.
"We could not have done that just a few years ago," said Ruth Harkin, United's senior vice president for international affairs and government relations. "The foreign investment rules would not have been favorable to us. And prior to the Asian crisis, there would not have been a willingness in Korea to let us merge."
The concentration of corporate power is still in a very early stage. Nothing like the trusts that dominated American industry a century ago have emerged in the global marketplace. Teddy Roosevelt's spirit is not forgotten. The antitrust structure survives and lately has been pointedly invoked, as when the Justice Department challenged BP Amoco's proposed acquisition of Atlantic Richfield. There is also talk of coordinating antitrust rules globally.
The goal, as economists put it, is an optimal balance in which some concentration is allowed, but government steps in before price-fixing develops and innovation is killed off. That's not an easy balance to strike when the pressure is on to make government smaller while mergers make industry ever more concentrated.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2782 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Again, It's Microsoft vs. the World

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash.

 BODY:
STEVEN BALLMER, the president of the Microsoft Corporation, returned again and again to a single question. "What is the soul of MSN?" he asked, referring to Microsoft's consumer Internet business by its three-letter logo.
A pressing question indeed for the 70 Microsoft managers summoned last June to Building No. 27 here for a searching review of the business. They had come from "Red West," a cluster of five buildings more than a mile from the main corporate campus and home to MSN Web sites like Expedia, Carpoint and MoneyCentral, and the MSN online service. Even within Microsoft, it was derided -- dubbed "Red Vest," a place to hide from real work while waiting for one's lucrative stock options to vest. Outside Microsoft, it was regarded as a laboratory of failure, called "Red Ink West," running up losses of as much as $1.5 billion since 1995, much of it squandered on a wayward effort to become a production studio for new media. 
 During the five-hour review, product teams showed off new ideas being worked on for the MSN Web site. One, a collaboration tool, was demonstrated with a community Web page for running a children's soccer team. The page could be created and the team's schedule listed, changed and sorted, all on a site within MSN that combined elements of a word processor, a spreadsheet and calendar software.
"The lights went up," Yusuf Mehdi, a marketing executive, recalled. "Heads nodded and we all kind of agreed: Now this is what Microsoft does well -- software that allows people to be more productive."
That realization soon became the touchstone of the company's new strategy for MSN -- the latest of several over the last five years, as Microsoft has struggled, uncharacteristically, to find its place on the Web.
The strategy, honed in recent months, boils down to this: We're going back to our roots as a software company. MSN will be pitched to consumers as the best technology tool kit for the Internet, one that makes online shopping, searching, communicating and managing personal finances on the Web easier and more productive. After all, "end-user productivity" is the jargonized shorthand that Mr. Ballmer, now Microsoft's chief executive, uses for the company's mission statement.
Whether that message will work in the consumer market remains to be seen. The test begins tonight, when Microsoft starts a yearlong, $150 million advertising campaign with sitcom-style television spots showing four characters -- two men, two women -- using MSN as their favorite Internet problem solver.
In the online business, Microsoft trails well behind the industry leader, America Online. But its catch-up strategy is plucked from the same playbook it used in the Internet browser market against Netscape Communications, the early front-runner in browsing software and now owned by AOL.
AS it did with its Internet Explorer browsing software, Microsoft is setting out to improve its Web technology, market aggressively, cut distribution deals with industry partners -- and, ultimately, change the economics of the online business. Some of the key executives behind the browser campaign -- the "A team," as one manager put it -- are now in place at MSN. Another sign that the MSN house is in order: At the start of this month, Mr. Ballmer moved back to the main Microsoft campus from "Red West." He had first moved into an office in Building D of Red West on Thanksgiving weekend of 1998, when losses were mounting.
Microsoft has not entirely showed its hand yet. And its track record on the Web is uninspiring, from mistaking the Internet for television (hence its failed foray into entertainment programming for the Web) to its costly drive to create a collection of city arts and entertainment sites, Sidewalk, which was sold off to Ticketmaster last year.
But executives here are encouraged by signs of improvement in the last few months -- rising traffic at MSN, favorable trade-press reviews for recently improved features and, last December, the second-highest monthly increase in five years in new subscribers to the MSN Internet access service. MSN now has two million subscribers; the goal for this year is to grow more than America Online, which analysts predict will add roughly four million new users in the United States.
"This is starting to feel like the early days of Internet Explorer," observed Mr. Mehdi, a former product and marketing manager for the browsing software.
Outside Microsoft, there are many people who will find the comparison unnerving. Microsoft's business practices in the browser market are the focus of the government's sweeping antitrust suit against the company. United States District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson has not made a final ruling, but in November he issued findings of fact that sided almost entirely with the government's portrayal of Microsoft as a monopolist that used its market power to bend other companies to its will and stifle competition.
The business of Web sites and online services is not the browser market, and there is no suggestion that any of MSN's moves raise antitrust issues. It seems doubtful, moreover, that Microsoft will have the kind of market power in the emerging Internet era of computing -- in which a proliferation of computing devices can be used to tap into the Web -- that the company's Windows operating system has given it during the personal computer era.
What is clear, however, is that Microsoft's culture and its business practices have not changed as a result of the antitrust case. At the Redmond campus, Microsoft workers seem to regard the case as just one more competitive challenge, a suit manufactured by their corporate enemies and hardly an accurate portrayal of the company for which they work. Microsoft is neither chastened nor humbled.
"We haven't changed anything we do in dealing with other companies," said Brad Chase, a senior vice president Mr. Ballmer brought to MSN last year, soon after Mr. Chase testified in the Microsoft trial. "We are good business partners, and we are moral partners."
The antitrust case has raised few qualms at Ford Motor, Best Buy and Tandy, all of which have forged e-commerce and distribution deals with Microsoft. In November, for example, Microsoft agreed to a deal with the Tandy Corporation in which Microsoft invested $100 million in RadioShack.com, Tandy's new online store.
For its part, Tandy will create a Microsoft area in each of its 7,000 Radio Shack stores, offering MSN Internet Access, Web TV, Windows CE-based hand-held devices, phones using MSN mobile software and Microsoft home networking software. The deal offers Microsoft a formidable bulkhead in the consumer market: There is a Radio Shack store within a five-minute drive of 94 percent of American households, and the chain is a huge seller of consumer technology.
Microsoft and America Online competed head-to-head for the Radio Shack deal. Len Roberts, the chairman of Tandy, says he chose Microsoft mainly because of its software strategy for tying together all the different Internet devices in the home. "We needed someone who could provide the technology glue -- the operating system for home integration -- and that's something Microsoft can do best," Mr. Roberts explained. "There's no question that AOL is a stronger Internet brand than MSN. But this deal is with Microsoft, and we're tying into its strategy."
In recent months, Microsoft's consumer group has become a vital leg in the company's wider Internet strategy in a way that was not apparent earlier. Industry analysts have argued that Microsoft should get out of the consumer business and focus instead on providing software for the Internet's infrastructure -- the operating systems, like Windows 2000, which is being introduced Thursday, that run big server computers serving up Web pages and e-commerce applications to desktop machines.
But that is not the view at Microsoft. Richard Belluzzo, who was recruited last September to become the group vice president of the consumer unit, recalled his early talks with William H. Gates, the chairman, Mr. Ballmer, Mr. Chase and other executives. They spoke, he said, of the evolution of software into Web-based services that people access by using cell phones, television set-top boxes and handheld devices as well as PC's.
IN the world of Web services, Mr. Belluzzo observed, a relationship with the consumer will be crucial -- to control the distribution of your underlying technology, if nothing else. (That, of course, is why Microsoft fought so hard in the browser wars. The Netscape browser could be the layer on top of Windows that would "commoditize" the underlying operating system, as Mr. Gates warned in a 1995 internal memo, "The Internet Tidal Wave.")
"It's going to be branded Web services that become the new face to the consumer, not the Windows desktop and how its icons are arranged on the screen," said Mr. Belluzzo, who came to Microsoft from Silicon Graphics, where he was chief executive, after running the consumer PC and printer business for years at Hewlett-Packard.
Mr. Chase added, "If you're not in the consumer business, you're not in the Web business, period."
Alongside MSN, the company's biggest branded Web service, is an effort that was recently dubbed "Next Generation Windows Services." It amounts to developing technology standards for the Internet in the same way Windows is a PC technology standard. One such service, Passport, is software that enables consumers to enter billing and shipping information once and not have to do it again while shopping on any e-commerce site that supports Passport. (One hundred companies, from Dell Computer to Buy.com, have signed up.)
Such Microsoft services are intended to save time for consumers and money for e-commerce sites, which do not have to write their own software. They are accessible without using any Microsoft software, but the broadest range of functions and smoothest integration are expected to come from using Microsoft products, from MSN to Windows 2000.
"What Microsoft is doing is taking the essence of its Windows strategy to the Web," said David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard business school.
It is Microsoft's umbrella software plans for the Internet -- far more than the new marketing push or new features on MSN -- that cause anxiety at America Online. After its planned merger with Time Warner, AOL will suddenly be much more a media company -- the opposite course from Microsoft's. Even so, AOL executives say Microsoft is the company they most fear.
They have seen the pattern before, as Microsoft moves relentlessly up the computing ladder, stepping from one technology platform to the next. Microsoft started with the PC operating system, then added software development tools, then software applications like word processing and spreadsheets, then Internet browsing software. The next step up is Internet services, and AOL stands atop that business.
AOL's lead appears to be huge. Its 20 million online subscribers are 10 times more than MSN's Internet Access service. AOL is the most-trafficked Internet portal site, while Microsoft ranks third; Yahoo is second. Yet at different times, Lotus 1-2-3 had a commanding lead in spreadsheets, as did WordPerfect in word processing and Netscape in browsing software.
"Microsoft has done it again and again," observed Barry Schuler, who runs most of the online services at AOL. "Microsoft sits back, waits for rivals to make mistakes; it improves its product and then it leverages its platform advantage into new markets."
AOL executives are intent on avoiding the same fate. "AOL won't be mentioned someday in the same breath with Lotus 1-2-3, WordPerfect and others," Mr. Schuler added.
Microsoft executives say that making inroads against AOL will be a long uphill climb. "There is no silver bullet," Mr. Chase conceded.
Yet they point to market research that suggests AOL has vulnerabilities. The data shows that more than 3 percent of AOL subscribers quit the service each month, an annual churn rate of more than eight million subscribers. About 15 percent of AOL subscribers get a busy signal during the most popular evening hours while the failure rate for MSN is 6 percent. A survey commissioned by Microsoft concluded that half of AOL subscribers might switch if they saw there was a "credible contender."
"The churn rate is still very high in this industry," Mr. Belluzzo said. "Nothing is really settled yet."
AOL replies that the rate at which subscribers leave its service is at "historical lows" and, based on its research, customer satisfaction has never been higher.
In the markets where Microsoft has come from way behind to win, it has improved its technology, but it has also changed the economics of the business. In office productivity software, it bundled spreadsheets, word processing and database software and sold them as a suite, charging little more than rivals charged for a single application program. In the browser market, it folded its browsing software into Windows and gave it away.
Last year, Microsoft began offering a $400 rebate to PC buyers who agreed to take the MSN Internet Access service for three years. AOL responded within a month, but only with a rebate on its CompuServe service, not the main AOL service.
Still, Microsoft is offering the rebate solely on the purchase of a PC through certain manufacturers or retailers like Radio Shack and Office Depot. The more aggressive approach would be to offer the rebates directly to consumers, not just PC buyers -- a bold and expensive bid to grab market share, if Microsoft did it.
Microsoft is apparently considering that option. "We want to change the rules, and we will," Mr. Chase said. "But just how we plan to do that is part of the fun."
Whether Microsoft's new consumer Web strategy will succeed is unclear. And it has plenty of rivals besides AOL, including Web sites that compete with one of the "personal productivity" services under the MSN umbrella -- from travel to personal finance to shopping.
Microsoft's consumer business is expected to grow nearly 40 percent this year, to more than $3 billion in revenue -- and to lose roughly $300 million, estimates David Readerman, an analyst at Thomas Weisel Partners. That loss, however, would be well below an estimated $500 million in 1998. "That's Ballmer's influence," Mr. Readerman said.
At Microsoft, that $300 million loss would be regarded as an investment in the future. But perhaps the surest sign of faith in the new consumer strategy is the people it has attracted to the business, both newcomers and executives drawn from elsewhere in the company. Two veterans of the browser wars, Mr. Mehdi and Mr. Chase, are examples.
Mr. Mehdi, 32, joined Microsoft in 1992, and given his yearly option grants is probably worth tens of millions of dollars. Mr. Chase, 39, has been at the company since 1987 and is likely worth more than $100 million. Neither will comment on those estimates, but Mr. Chase acknowledged, "We don't have to work if we don't want to."
Like some of their peers, they could have left to run Internet start-ups; Mr. Mehdi says he gets about one such offer a week. But he says he is staying in Redmond, where he now is director of MSN marketing, because he believes in the strategy, and in Microsoft. Mr. Chase echoes those sentiments, adding that he relishes the come-from-behind challenge. "We're underdogs, but we're starting to bark," he said.
Members of Microsoft's class of 1999, the 700 employees who joined the company from computer science programs and business schools last year, are also convinced that Redmond is still the place to make a difference in computing -- and a personal fortune in the bargain. Most of them declined jobs at Internet start-ups or at one of Microsoft's big rivals.
Andrew Olson, a graduate of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, passed up offers from both start-ups and from Sun Microsystems. He speaks of the "amazingly high quotient of really smart people" at Microsoft and the "exciting challenge" of trying to help MSN rebound.
Other newcomers compare a talk with Mr. Gates or Mr. Ballmer to an encounter with a "Zen master." They see a big company with extraordinary entrepreneurial energy, run from the bottom up, where every project is a venture, where if you ship the "right bag of bits" it can have a "huge impact."
"You have to be here to get it," said Ori Amiga, 22, a computer science graduate of Macalester College who is working on an Internet software project.
Others may doubt, or fear, but at Microsoft they still believe.

HEADLINE: Whose Prosperity?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re your Feb. 8 Business Day article about whose administration can claim credit for the economic expansion: It is true that President Clinton sold his 1993 tax increase as a deficit-reduction necessity. However, the president never followed the increase with a serious effort to reduce the growth of spending. 
 It was only after the Democrats failed to retake the House in 1996 and polling continued to show huge public support for balancing the budget that President Clinton came to the table and signed the 1997 balanced-budget agreement. Now that the budget is in surplus and popular with the voters, the president is trying to take credit for something in which he reluctantly became a participant and beneficiary. He was no more serious about reducing the deficit than he was about a middle-class tax cut or welfare reform.
 
DAVE WELDON
Member of Congress, 15th Dist., Fla.
Washington, Feb. 8, 2000

LENGTH: 580 words

HEADLINE: Dangerous Plans for Colombia

 BODY:
Colombia is Latin America's most complex and troubled country. Its two overwhelming problems -- a booming trade in cocaine and heroin, and a vicious, nearly 40-year-old civil war -- are intertwined and getting worse. Increasingly they threaten not just Colombia, but neighboring countries as well, including Venezuela, one of the largest suppliers of oil to the United States.
Now the Clinton administration has unveiled a $1.3 billion plan to help Colombia, including $955 million in security assistance. Colombia is already the largest recipient of American security aid after Israel and Egypt. The plan reflects neither a realistic strategy to fight illegal drugs nor an effective long-term approach to establish peace and stability. Instead it risks dragging the United States into a costly counterinsurgency war. 
 Both the drug trade and Colombia's stability are legitimate American concerns. The administration and supporters of the plan in Congress have concluded that the most effective American response is to increase military assistance and forge a close alliance with Colombia's armed forces. Washington should have learned long ago that partnership with an abusive and ineffective Latin American military rarely produces positive results and often undermines democracy in the region.
Colombia produces 80 percent of the world's cocaine and about two-thirds of the heroin consumed in the United States. Administration officials insist that the security assistance would be aimed primarily at fighting drug trafficking and not at counterinsurgency operations against leftist guerrilla groups. But in many areas of Colombia the distinction is meaningless. In recent years both the guerrillas and murderous right-wing paramilitary squads associated with the army have earned millions of dollars from the drug trade.
President Andres Pastrana is well intentioned and deserves American support. But this plan is overwhelmingly skewed toward a military approach to problems that for years have stubbornly resisted military solutions. Washington should be devoting a far greater share of its support to the Pastrana government's own admirable efforts to strengthen civil institutions and address social and economic inequities that fuel the war and the drug economy. They include reorganizing and strengthening the judiciary, as well as alternative development strategies that would help farmers grow conventional crops, like coffee and cotton, and subsidize the construction of roads and schools. Colombia's security problems cannot be ignored, and there may be ways for the United States to work with the Pastrana government to strengthen the Colombian military. But this should be done with stricter conditions and an emphasis on reforming the armed forces rather than on equipping them to fight a protracted civil war in which civilians are the main casualties.
Peace talks aimed at a negotiated settlement represent the best solution to both the drug problem and the war. The Clinton administration has provided intermittent support for Mr. Pastrana's early efforts to talk peace with guerrilla leaders. He has had little success thus far. But in recent days key rebel leaders have signaled a new interest in negotiations, agreeing to meet with government representatives in Sweden. Washington should redouble its support for these talks. Throwing its weight behind Colombia's military at this stage will only escalate a war that neither side can win.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK ON LINE;
A Pillar of Harlem Gets Lift From Teenagers

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
The teenagers who write, edit and produce the online newspaper HarlemLive report stories, create Web pages and devise promotions for their site. But they had not been exposed to deadlines until last month, when a famous Harlem institution asked for their help on its own Internet project.
In mid-January, the Institute for Learning Technologies at Columbia University asked the youths to help develop a Web site for the Abyssinian Development Corporation (www.adcorp.org), which is affiliated with the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. Financed with a $20,000 grant from the Bell Atlantic Foundation, the site had already been designed by Saman Dashti, a Web site developer. 
 About 10 teenagers signed on to help build it, and each was paid $10 to $15 an hour for their work, said Richard Carlton, the founder and director of HarlemLive. But the students had just a few weeks before the scheduled debut of the site on Feb. 3 (HarlemLive's own Web site is www.harlemlive.org).
Clifton Taylor, 14, a freshman at Central Park East High School in East Harlem, was one of a handful who did the final heavy lifting. Clifton, who grew up in Jamaica, said he was cured of an addiction to video games when he learned how to design Web sites through HarlemLive. Working on the Abyssinian site, he said, cemented his aspiration to become a professional Web designer -- as opposed to a carpenter, his previous career goal -- because it gave him a sense of what it takes to work under fire.
"I learned that when you're doing something professional you have to try not to make any mistakes," he said.
WHAT YOU SEE -- The graphic content of the Abyssinian site is minimal, but there is a great deal of helpful information: a primer on the history of Harlem, an outline of the missions of the development corporation and the church, a depiction of the organization's efforts to transform the neighborhood, and a resource directory listing agencies and groups that provide community services.
Visually, the most interesting aspect of the Abyssinian site is the Housing Initiatives section (to get to it, click on Community Building Programs on the home page), featuring before-and-after photographs of Harlem brownstones and other buildings that have been restored in recent years by Abyssinian. Another section, called Flagship Programs, tells about the development of the Pathmark supermarket and shopping center on 125th Street and Lexington Avenue, which some credit with helping to start Harlem's recent economic boom. The Abyssinian Development Corporation was one of the project's developers.
The most notable thing about the site may be its very existence. The Abyssinian Development Corporation is one of just a few major Harlem organizations, including the Studio Museum in Harlem and the Frederick Douglass Creative Arts Center, with an Internet presence.
Bruce Lincoln, manager of community outreach for the Institute for Learning Technologies at Columbia and the executive producer of the site, said it is part of an effort to bridge the neighborhood's digital divide.
WHAT YOU GET -- An inside look at one of the major groups behind the economic revitalization of Harlem.
LINKS -- None yet. NINA SIEGAL
