HEADLINE: THE WORLD: HEADS UP;
The Melting-Pot Politics of 2000 Are Truly Soupy

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
PITY the poor presidential campaign strategists. With make-or-break primaries fast approaching, they're frantically trying to cobble together winning strategies to appeal to an electorate so diverse, cacophonous and in flux as to make the folks trying to build the Tower of Babel sound like a harmonious glee club. With no big issue like war, recession or incumbency to give the 2000 race some shape, America looks more than ever like an indistinct montage of contending groups -- some new, some old standbys.
This time around, there are hero-admiring dads to take into consideration along with angry white males, single moms along with soccer moms. There are seniors whose politics are shifting ever rightward and -- perhaps most important -- a growing number of independents who, as their name suggests, are hardly a monolith. Cutting across everything is a schizophrenic view of President Clinton, who is both loved and loathed at the same time -- sometimes by the same people. 
 It's a niche marketer's dream, and a pundit's nightmare.
"There's a lot going on out there," said David Axelrod, a Democratic political consultant in Chicago. "There is no one thing that was driving everything as there was in '92 or '80 or '84. There are times when single issues overwhelm everything else. This isn't one of those times."
Handicapping the key electoral demographics is a tricky business, but here goes anyway:
The Guy's Guy. In some ways, the last few years have been tough for white guys. Sure, they're making money, either through overtime at the auto plant or overdrive in the stock market. They've got SUV's and IPO's. But in the political arena, they've had nobody to look up to. Four years ago the thought of a Colin Powell candidacy made many weak in the knees. But he took a hike on them. Now they've suddenly got two straight-talking heroes -- John McCain and Bill Bradley -- from the realms of war and sport.
Exit polls conducted by the Los Angeles Times during the New Hampshire primary illustrate what could be the makings of a gender gap involving both Mr. McCain and Mr. Bradley. According to the polls, 50 percent of men voting in the Republican primary backed Mr. McCain while only 29 percent went for Gov. George W. Bush of Texas. Among men voting Democratic, Mr. Bradley beat Vice President Al Gore among men by about four points (while he trailed Mr. Gore by five points among women).
"It's all those guilty male boomers who didn't go to Nam," Lou DiNatali, a senior fellow with the John W. McCormack Institute, a Boston-based research organization, said of Mr. McCain's appeal to men. "First, they went with Clinton, the anti-war guy. Now they go for the P.O.W."
So far, the gender gap has helped Mr. McCain more than Mr. Bradley. That's because so many more men vote in Republican primaries than in Democratic ones.
Should Mr. McCain win the Republican nomination, his male-based appeal will probably widen the already cavernous gender gap between the Republicans and Democrats, since Mr. Gore draws much of his strength from women. That situation might favor the Democrat, since there were 7 million more eligible female voters than eligible male voters in 1998. And women tend to register and vote in higher proportions than men.
Independents' Day. In the New Hampshire primary, unaffiliated voters helped power Mr. McCain to a 19-point victory over Mr. Bush, and kept Mr. Bradley close enough to Mr. Gore to remain in the race. The independents' role there has stirred interest in how much of a force they will be in other primaries and the general election. After all, they make up about 13 percent of the electorate nationally, 25 percent in the Rocky Mountain states and 34 percent of registered voters in New England.
But the independents are hardly a bloc. There are so-called "prosperity independents," affluent, generally white, college-educated, Internet-savvy, stock-buying voters who tend to be pro-environment and socially liberal yet fiscally conservative. They were a hefty slice of Mr. McCain's support in New Hampshire, but in national polls they also tend to like Mr. Gore.
Mr. Bradley also roped in his share of independents in New Hampshire as well. But his independents, while also well educated, tended to be less affluent, earning less than $50,000 annually, according to polls conducted by R.K.M. Researchers Inc. of Portsmouth, N.H. These voters tend to be more liberal when it comes to government spending.
There is a third large group of independents: people who aren't particularly interested in politics. More than 7.1 million people were added to the voter rolls in 1997 and 1998, as a result of the so-called "motor voter" law, which made it possible to register to vote when renewing a driver's license, applying for welfare and conducting business with other government agencies. Many of these new voters have registered as independents. Who these disaffected voters will vote for -- if they vote at all -- is an open question.
Bifurcated Blacks. The black vote, as always, will be critical for Democrats. But while 55 percent of blacks live in the South, they tend to turn out in lower proportions than Northern blacks, who tend to be more affluent and better educated and are less likely to live in hard-to-organize rural areas. Indeed, except for 1992, Northern blacks have voted in higher proportions than Southern blacks in every Presidential election since the Voting Rights Act was passed in 1965.
Some political strategists say that unless this changes, the black vote may be more of a factor in closely fought states in the industrial Midwest like Michigan, Illinois and Ohio than in Deep South states like Alabama, Georgia and Mississippi, where Republicans have had a lock.
The Giants Sleeps Tonight. For years Hispanics have been described as the sleeping giant of American politics, and George W. Bush has trumpeted the fact that he can appeal to this group. Yet when it comes to Presidential races, there are no signs this giant is stirring or that Hispanics will have much of an impact on the race.
Hispanics make up about 10 percent of the voting age population. But half of that group is concentrated in two states -- California and Texas. In 1996, Bill Clinton got 71 percent of the Hispanic vote in California and won the state. He got 76 percent of that vote in Texas and lost. Most strategists do not expect a markedly different result this year.
Besides, about 40 percent of Hispanics of voting age are not United States citizens and only 26 percent of those eligible to vote did so in 1996 -- far fewer than non-Hispanic whites and blacks -- despite a major effort by the Democratic Party and Hispanic leaders to get out the vote.
The one state where Hispanics may be crucial is Florida. Four years ago, Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, won only 46 percent of the Hispanics who voted there, mainly conservative Cuban-Americans. That was the lowest draw of any Republican candidate in recent memory. Vowing not to let that happen again, the Republicans -- particularly Mr. Bush, whose brother, Jeb, is the Governor -- are vigorously courting Cuban-American voters. But Democrats, noting that the Cuban-American community is younger and less vehemently anti-Castro, sense an opening.
Old Story. It used to be that the band would strike up the Roosevelt-era anthem "Happy Days Are Here Again" and elderly voters would feel all nostalgic and troop off to vote Democratic. No more. Quite simply, many of those seniors who remember the New Deal have passed away, and many more of the voters now over 65 are people who were swept up in the Reagan Revolution and have remained Republicans.
"The senior vote today is a different group of people than it was four years ago and eight years ago," said John Rother, director of Legislation and Public Policy for the American Association of Retired Persons, who is not publicly supporting any candidate. "They didn't go through a life experience like the Depression that brought everybody together and they don't have the same view of government."
The Young and The Listless. Despite efforts like MTV's "Rock the Vote," young people continue to be among the most politically apathetic groups in the country. In 1996, only 32.4 percent of people 18 to 24 years old cast a ballot -- the lowest level since 1972, when the voting age was lowered to 18.
A close race and a maverick candidate like Mr. Bradley or Mr. McCain might bring out more young voters. But it's unclear if anything can break through this group's lack of interest.
Still Angry After All. The angry white males are still around. They tend to be college grads, relatively affluent and over 50 years old. They are more likely married, living in the South and are often ex-Democrats turned Republican. They hate Mr. Clinton with a passion. According to Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Center for People and the Press, they make up about 10 percent of the population and 12 percent of registered voters.
They had a moment in the sun in 1994, when they helped power the Republicans to control of Congress. But even as their economic status has improved and their influence has waned, their anger has not diminished. "Many still feel that the cultural winds are blowing against them," said Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster in Atlanta. "That creates the sense that the forces of political correctness are working against them and what they believe."
I Do, I Do. The gender gap has been a hardy perennial in analyses of the electorate. But perhaps as important in determining who is wed to which party is a voter's marital status. Exit polls indicate that married men supported the Republican over the Democrat in every Presidential race since 1984, and that except for 1996, when they backed Mr. Clinton over Bob Dole, married women did the same.
Unmarried men have a more checkered recent history, backing Ronald Reagan in 1984 and George Bush in 1988, and flocking to Mr. Clinton in 1992 and 1996. On the other hand, Democrats since 1984 have set single women's hearts aflutter. And in Mr. Kohut's survey, 60.7 percent of unmarried women with children -- so-called waitress moms -- said they supported Mr. Gore.
"They talk about soccer moms, but, really, for Clinton and Gore, it's single moms," Mr. Kohut said.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 914 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Campus Politics Young and Anarchic, the Angry Left Is Reborn in Mexico

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY

 BODY:
DURING the cold war, when Latin American leftists gravitated toward Communism, it was easy for them to identify their enemies: local military dictators or American corporate imperialists. They had an economic system to demonize -- capitalism -- and an alternative -- socialism --- to put in its place. And they had a playbook, written by Marx and Lenin and Fidel Castro, to guide their thinking and strategy.
But times are different. There still is an activist left in Latin America, and it still does battle with inequality and poverty and undemocratic government. But the recent nine-month strike at Mexico's national university revealed a new kind of leftist movement, one whose new foe is the global economy. The strike, which devastated Mexico's most important university and divided its society, gave a preview of the vexing challenges the new leftists may pose to the region's young democracies. 
 The striking students at the National Autonomous University of Mexico declared that their fundamental purpose was to oppose the worldwide spread of free trade and the lean government, pro-business policies that promote it. But the conundrum for their movement was that the new adversary -- globalism -- was faceless. It was a product of commerce and technology more than of government or guns. It was emerging everywhere at once, with no clear alternative in sight.
If the students were confronting anarchic change, they met it with an anarchic movement. The strike steering committee took over the campus, using barbed wire to keep other students out. They elected no outstanding leaders and took their decisions in chaotic all-night assemblies. Over the months the university conceded demand after demand, but the strikers only upped the ante.
The strikers confounded everyone who dealt with them, from conciliatory university administrators to conservative intellectuals to lifelong leftists. In the end, after the federal police marched in on Feb. 6 and hauled the remaining strikers away to jail, it seemed that the strike had been an end in itself, a form of complete resistance against social and economic changes they could never hope to control.
The new leftism probably emerged in Mexico because this country has led the charge in Latin America into the globalized age. Since signing on to the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexico has seen its international trade explode, its business middle class rise like a phoenix and the country's northern half become an industrial export powerhouse.
BUT the student strikers were also a product of globalization -- of two decades of policies that laid the foundations for Mexico's recent leap into the global economy. The government has stimulated growth by restraining inflation, mainly by depressing workers' wages. Official figures show that the minimum wage today buys 48 percent of what it did in 1982. So, while export enclaves have thrived, workers elsewhere have been drawn into a spiral of downward mobility.
The national university, with 275,000 students, was once Mexico's main avenue of social ascent. Today many students graduate wondering if they will be able to earn a living. Alfonso Zarate, a political analyst, said the strike revealed how much Mexico has become "a nation of winners and losers."
The strike was not radical at the start. It began last April, as a protest against a plan to charge tuition -- about $150 a year -- for the first time in decades. The university president, Francisco Barnes de Castro, cast the plan as an effort to get resources for a critically underfunded institution. But in today's increasinly impoverished urban working class, even small tuition costs can break a family's budget.
The new left gave the students a rationale for rejecting the plan. It was a vast plot by the business-friendly government to impose private sector logic on a public university, and deny working class youth the education they deserved.
OVER time, a faction of strikers, dubbed "ultras" by their companions because of their intolerance for dissent, gained the upper hand through nasty purges. A central demand was for face-to-face negotiations with the university president. But the movement, once it was in the hands of the ultras, did not really negotiate. The strikers never moved an inch from their original demands. Administrators dropped the tuition plan, agreed to direct talks, agreed even to hold a congress to reform how the whole university was organized.
But the strikers, true to their anarchist core and lacking vision of an alternative, continued to resist.
"Rebellion is our only leader, our one true cause and the reason for everything we do," read one banner.
Alejandro Alvarez, an economics professor, at first supported the strike but fell out with the ultras. "They made distrust into a form of politics," he said.
In the end, the strike divided Mexico, which is in the midst of a delicate move from authoritarianism to democracy. While the general public applauded the police action to end the strike, many intellectuals, journalists and democratic leaders saw it as an extension of the bloody repression with which the student movement of 1968 was broken. The result was some of the most vigorous street protests Mexico has seen in years.
The damage to education and the division among Mexicans could serve as a cautionary tale to anyone who thinks the changes that globalization brings will only reinforce democratic institutions.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY;
That's Alan, With an A, The Guy Who Sets Rates

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT 

 BODY:
As interest rates creep up, it is only natural for investors to keep a sharp eye on Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
An online financial planning service, WealthHound.com, wants to help them do just that. It has started a page dedicated to Greenspan news, intended to help Fed watchers track the chairman's every move and provide them with a growing archive of articles about Mr. Greenspan, culled from financial news wires. 
 On its Feb. 1 debut, however, the Web page furnished more Greenspans than some visitors had bargained for. During its opening week, it included articles that mentioned Bud Greenspan, chairman of the entertainment portal eUniverse; Ron Greenspan, webmaster for GoCancun.com, a travel site, and Sharon Greenspan, a spokeswoman for Amazon.com, the online retailer.
But, alas, none about Alan Greenspan.
The glitch was corrected in a late-night programming session, according to Scott Mager, a WealthHound.com principal. "We are just adding his first name to the search," he said. "It will only find news if it says 'Alan' and 'Greenspan.' " ROY FURCHGOTT

HEADLINE: INVESTING: FUNDS WATCH;
Buying at Markdown?

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Franklin Mutual group of funds has been buying the stocks of department store companies like Saks and J. C. Penney, arguing that investors have beaten down such shares to bargain levels.
Many department store stocks fell sharply last year and now trade near 52-week lows. Such declines have attracted Franklin Mutual, a Short Hills, N.J., investment adviser owned by Franklin Resources of San Mateo, Calif., that is known for buying out-of-favor stocks. 
 These investments are risky -- even at deflated prices -- because department stores are vulnerable to problems if the United States economy falters, ending a record-breaking expansion that has lasted almost nine years, analysts said. But Larry Sondike, the Franklin Mutual portfolio manager who follows department stores, said he was undeterred by those and other concerns.
"There are dot-com fears, interest rate fears, cyclical fears that the economy is going to weaken," Mr. Sondike said. "The stocks have declined on overblown fears, resulting in share prices we think are very attractive."
The mutual fund group bought seven million shares in Saks and 3.5 million in J. C. Penney last year, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It also bought 2.4 million shares of Sears, Roebuck and 1.4 million of May Department Stores in 1999, and raised its stake in Federated Department Stores to 2.9 million shares from 2.2 million.

HEADLINE: A Politician Sees Future Of Japan In Its Past

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 12

 BODY:
By midday, the visitors were spilling out of the waiting room and into the corridor outside the office of Shizuka Kamei, the longtime machine politician who has suddenly become one of this country's most powerful and solicited figures.
"This is a very critical moment in Japan's history, that will decide whether we have a good 21st century or not," said Mr. Kamei, who is the policy chief in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. 
 What many of Mr. Kamei's critics question, though -- and they abound not only in the opposition and in business circles but also in his own party -- is whether this staunchly conservative former policeman is in fact trying to steer Japan into the present century or back into the last.
Take, for example, Mr. Kamei's scornful views on efficiency and competition. "The competitive market principle, which made the United States affluent and made its people happy, cannot necessarily be applied to Japan," he says.
"Mr. Kamei is an old-time politician, and he is trying very hard to keep old-time Japan going, its industries, its society," said Taro Kono, a 37-year-old member of Parliament from the Liberal Democratic Party frustrated by Mr. Kamei's powerful influence. "We lag behind the U.S. because too many people like him are trying to keep Japan the way it is, rather than adapt to our new circumstances."
Indeed, with each tentative step that Japan takes toward economic recovery, after a decade of slow growth, Mr. Kamei has emerged increasingly resolute -- and usually successful -- in his opposition to the liberalizing reforms that many say are badly needed to ensure future prosperity.
His influence was most recently on display over the New Year holidays, when, in the midst of the traditional news lull, he prevailed upon the government to scuttle quietly an important component of its longstanding plans to reform the banking sector.
The move -- decried by Japan's leading business association, the Keidanren, editorial writers and many economists -- was seen as a costly sop to the country's thrift institutions and other small banks, many of which would fail without protection. 
As the leader of a loose band of Liberal Democratic Party figures and Parliament members who unabashedly call themselves the "anti-deregulation committee," Mr. Kamei is the unapologetic champion of troubled businesses, and of a Japan whose past glories are now fast fading. His is the land of high trade barriers protecting deeply inefficient businesses, from steel and textile manufacturers to the small retail sector, while relentlessly promoting Japan's sleeker exports.
Indeed, while the government of Keizo Obuchi, the prime minister who appointed him, often preaches the gospel of competitiveness, the importance of the Internet and internationalization, for Mr. Kamei globalization stands out as a real menace.
"Japan has a long history, just like America," Mr. Kamei said in his large office, which is filled with expensive orchids and every manner of the animal that is his namesake, the turtle. "Our society is based on villages and towns which have been in existence for hundreds of years. During that time, a certain lifestyle has formed, and we should attach some importance to these traditional ways."
Many, however, see Mr. Kamei's championing of the little man and of depressed industries as driven not so much by principle as political and financial calculations.
The Liberal Democratic Party, which has governed Japan for all but two years since the end of World War II, is above all a vote-getting machine whose wheels are greased through patronage and endless fundraising.
Mr. Kamei has excelled in this world, and charges of numerous financial irregularities have dogged him throughout his political life, including involvement with the Japanese mobs that operate the country's ubiquitous pachinko game parlors.
Kaoru Ogawa, a well-known corporate gadfly, who has himself often been accused of associating with gangsters, recently called Mr. Kamei the "dirtiest in Japan."
Mr. Kamei gave an impassioned but nuanced defense of his reputation.
"I am a former police officer, and have never touched dirty money," he said. "My fund-raising comes from small- and medium-size businesses, and I have done nothing which could be reproached me."
"I am a politician, however," he added. "And I am sometimes asked to take care of certain people. Some of them have sometimes been convicted of crimes, but I have nothing to be ashamed of."

HEADLINE: Secure or Not, the Internet Has Become a Part of Life's Routine

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON

 BODY:
When Jon Tara first heard that unknown vandals with unclear motives had managed to sabotage several of the Internet's most prominent businesses last week, the San Diego software engineer posted a probing message to an online investing forum that he frequents.
"Is this the end of Internet innocence? Is the house of cards about to crumble?" Mr. Tara, 45, wondered. "Can we move to an Internet-based economy while the potential exists for a group of hackers to bring it to its knees at any time?" 
 Yet by Friday, Mr. Tara had settled back into his normal Internet routine, which includes trading stocks, exchanging e-mail with clients all day, and checking traffic conditions before he drives home from work. "I could see discontinuing trading online if the instances of this were accelerated, but it would be a very difficult decision." Mr. Tara said. "We're going to be dependent on the Internet, and I don't think you can stop that."
While the assaults hobbled popular Web sites like Yahoo, Amazon and eBay for only a few hours, the ensuing consternation underscored how heavily both businesses and consumers have come to rely on the Internet for everything from paying bills to planning vacations.
But as Internet executives beef up security and public attention turns to the F.B.I. pursuit of the culprits, some network experts -- and at least a few lay Internet users -- contend that last week's electronic attacks should sound an alarm. As people are enticed to put their personal, political, financial and even medical lives online, those who counsel caution see a need for a more gradual pace.
They say that the kind of mischief that today might merely cause delays and frustrations could eventually have more serious and far-reaching consequences. Being blocked from an eBay auction for four hours may be only a nuisance. But being shut out from E*Trade, the online brokerage firm that was also hit last week, had a more direct financial impact on those affected. And what would happen if, as many planners hope, all of a person's medical history was someday stored on a Web site? A Netscape error message may provide little solace to the next of kin.
"This should give us pause," said Lauren Weinstein, co-founder of a group called People for Internet Responsibility. "With all the dot-com hype that's been going on, not enough attention has been given to the fact that the Internet is not like the older technologies on which we have built our commerce over the last century. It has vulnerabilities that need to be factored into decisions about all these important applications."
Yu Sun, a computer science student in Seattle, had another suggestion for the Internet industry. "Maybe they should stop wasting huge amounts of money on Super Bowl advertising and spend more on improving their security," said Mr. Sun, who was unable to compare homework with a fellow student by e-mail last week while Yahoo, their e-mail provider, was recovering from the attack.
Spoilsport views are, of course, not popular among e-commerce executives, who have sought to cast the vandalism as an unfortunate cost of doing business online. Nor are many frequent Internet users or technology investors receptive to the notion of downsizing digitization.
Traffic at the compromised sites returned to normal almost immediately after the attacks. Online Valentine's Day shoppers also seemed unfazed, with reports showing traffic spikes at sites like 1800Flowers.com and VictoriasSecret.com last week.
As for investor confidence, while the share price of some of the affected companies dipped this week, all of them had recovered by the close of trading Friday.
"There's going to be problems with the Internet here and there," said Donna Pelletier, 45, of Harrisville, R.I., echoing the sentiments of many others on the eBay Cafe discussion group. "This only lasted for a couple of hours, so I don't think it's that big a deal."
Perhaps not, or at least not now. Only a tiny fraction of consumer sales -- 1.2 percent -- currently take place over the Internet, according to the Boston Consulting Group.
But several million military personnel will cast their presidential ballots via Internet this year. Online banks and bank services are proliferating. And online transactions, while still small, more than doubled last year.
The security of such transactions has already proved shaky. Last month, for instance, an extortionist disclosed some of the 300,000 customer credit cards he said he had stolen from CD Universe, an online music retailer. Days later, a new online bank, X.com, a division of the La Jara, Colo., community bank First Western National Bank, discovered that for almost a month, its customers had been able to transfer funds from any other account in the nation's banking system to accounts at the bank.
Moreover, as businesses transfer more of their internal operations online, the potential toll rises. "The biggest risk is not what we've seen so far, it's if hackers start to attack business-to-business sites," said David Pecaut, head of Boston Consulting's e-commerce practice.
That's partly why consultants urge their Internet clients to go the "clicks and mortar" route, operating through multiple channels. Charles Schwab, the brokerage firm, which has call centers and physical branches as well as a Web service, is often held up as a model.
Whether confidence in the Internet as an economic engine declines at all after last week's brazen attacks may depend on whether law enforcement authorities are able to apprehend whoever orchestrated the electronic incursions. Yet even if the rule of law prevails in this instance, Internet executives acknowledge that there is little they can do to prevent similar assaults in the future.
"There's no way today to stop the attack from occurring if it gets launched," said Greg Hawkins, chief executive of Buy.com, one of the sites disabled by a deluge of data on Tuesday, the day it went public. "All we believe we can really do is to ensure that we can deal with it as rapidly and efficiently as possible."
The form of assault on the sites last week, known as denial of service, is particularly difficult to defend against. Essentially, intruders use third-party machines to overwhelm the victim's servers, preventing customers from gaining access to the site.
As a result, lax security on any of the millions of computers connected to the Internet leaves every other one exposed.
E-commerce executives prefer to compare their security risks to those of real-world retailers. On the Internet, they note, stores are open all day, they do not worry about shoplifting, and they can operate much more efficiently. Occasional interruptions of service are unfortunate, but hardly cataclysmic.
But Web retailers offer vandals a single target to attack instead of a series of separate stores. Critics argue that such attacks are likely to increase both because of the network's inherent security flaws and because vandals will discover they are able to achieve a dramatic effect with comparatively little effort.
"The French farmers blockading the McDonald's were not that effective," said Tom Eisenmann, who teaches e-commerce at the Harvard Business School. 'What's different here is the scale.'
The Internet's scale -- and its sheer ubiquity -- are why even disgruntled Internet users are hanging tough. After being shut out of Yahoo last week, Mr. Sun and his friend briefly contemplated faxing their homework. But instead, they signed up for free e-mail accounts at another Web site. "E-mail," Mr. Sun said, "is so much easier."

HEADLINE: Nuclear Rivals Marshal Armies of Lobbyists in Washington

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11

 BODY:
Pakistan and India, the world's newest nuclear rivals, have brought their battles to Washington, where each country has assembled a bevy of highly paid lobbyists already tested in one fight -- Pakistan won -- and now engaged in another: whether President Clinton should visit Pakistan as well as India next month.
Mr. Clinton's foreign policy team will give him persuasive pros and cons. But in the end, the decision may hinge on the power of the Washington lobbyists who are being increasingly sought out by foreign countries that believe that they need professional help, whether it is to get a piece of the foreign policy pie or just to polish their image here. 
 Some countries, such as Israel, Greece and Taiwan, have always had a strong presence in the parlors of policy making in the capital, and some issues -- the Vietnam war in the 1960's; intervention in Central America in the early 1980's -- have generated vocal constituencies. But the depth and breadth of lobbying by individual countries has grown in recent years, and foreign governments are now paying out tens of thousands of dollars a month.
In the case of India and Pakistan and Mr. Clinton's travels, each side has already begun to lobby the White House, the State Department and Congress.
Traditionally, India shunned lobbyists, relying on its distinguished foreign service to make the nation's case in State Department meetings with Indian diplomats. These days, however, India is paying $50,000 a month for the lobbying services of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand, where the heavy hitters include two former Senate majority leaders, Democrat George Mitchell and Republican Bob Dole, and a former governor of Texas, Ann Richards. (Verner, Liipfert also lobbies for Ethiopia, the Marshall Islands, Slovenia, the United Arab Emirates and Uruguay.)
Adding to some grumbling at home about the use of lobbyists, the Indian government is paying an additional $25,000 a month for the clout of former Democratic Congressman Stephen J. Solarz, a New Yorker who was viewed as a friendly voice for India when he was a lawmaker.
Meanwhile, Pakistan is shelling out $30,000 a month for the services of Charlie Wilson, a former Democratic Congressman from Texas who was a staunch ally of the country when he served in the House. Even though Mr. Wilson cautioned the Pakistani government last year about hiring another lobbyist -- given that "Pakistan's resources are limited," Mr. Wilson wrote in a memorandum -- just this month, Pakistan signed a contract with the politically connected law firm of Patton, Boggs & Blow for $22,500 a month. (Other countries that are paying Patton, Boggs for help include Benin, Croatia, Oman, Paraguay and Qatar.)
The person handling Pakistan's account is a former Clinton special counsel, Lanny J. Davis, who helped the White House navigate the 1996 Democratic fund-raising imbroglio.
Mr. Davis said in an interview that he had talked to the White House and the State Department, although he would not reveal which officials he had approached, about adding a stop in Pakistan when Mr. Clinton visits the Indian subcontinent next month. To spurn a visit, Mr. Davis said, "would be conveying a message of hostility, and pushing Pakistan in a dangerous direction away from the West and toward the Taliban."
"They keep thinking it's just a matter of hiring the right lobbyist, that the right lobbyist will be their salvation," Robert Oakley, a retired American diplomat, said about Pakistan, where he served as ambassador from 1988-1991.
And sometimes the right lobbyist may indeed make a difference.
Consider the battle last fall over legislation that would allow for the resumption of United States military aid to Pakistan. Since 1990, military assistance had been suspended because of Pakistan's nuclear program. On top of that, economic sanctions were imposed on Pakistan after it tested nuclear bombs in 1998.
Last year, the Senate's defense appropriations bill had a provision that would allow the president to waive the sanctions against Pakistan; the House bill did not have a similar provision. When the bill went to conference committee, Mr. Wilson went to work.
"I worked day and night," Mr. Wilson said. "I moved to the Hill," he added, passing time on a park bench, waiting to catch members.
The odds were against him. The Indian-American population is politically active, and growing, seeking to build a lobby on the model of the American lobby for Israel, lawmakers and diplomats say. And in Congress, as a reflection of that activism and of generous campaign contributions, there is an India caucus, with more than 100 members. Given its size, it is listened to at the State Department, diplomats there say.
The co-chairman of the India Caucus, Rep. Frank Pallone, a New Jersey Democrat who has received significant campaign contributions from Indian-Americans outside his district, has publicly urged President Clinton not to go to Pakistan.
By contrast, the Pakistani caucus, never had more than a dozen or so members, and is largely dormant now.
And Mr. Wilson was up against a few negatives on the Pakistan side of the ledger: Pakistan had recently tested its nuclear weapons; Pakistani-backed guerrillas had crossed into the Kargil region of the disputed territory of Kashmir last year, bringing international condemnation and the threat of outright war with India; then, in the midst of the Congressional deliberations, came the military coup -- or "political sea change," as Mr. Wilson carefully depicts it.
In arguing his client's cause during the congressional fight, Mr. Wilson hurled some tough charges. India had been "virtually a Soviet satellite," during the cold war, Mr. Wilson said he told representatives, a depiction he repeated with emphasis for use in the current row. Another aspersion was that "Indians hate Americans," he said, a charge most Indians would probably dispute.
But Mr. Wilson had something else going for him. While a member of Congress, he had served for 20 years on the defense subcommittee of the House appropriations committee. The members of this subcommittee were on the conference committee.
"I was extremely lucky," Mr. Wilson said. "They were all friends."
Mr. Wilson, and his client, won that day.
Now, the challenge for Mr. Wilson is to keep Pakistan off the State Department's list of terrorist nations, and to persuade Mr. Clinton that he must stop in Pakistan, however briefly, during the India trip. Once again, his colleague for 20 years in the House, Mr. Solarz, is on the other side, as is Verner, Liipfert.
Mr. Wilson and Mr. Solarz both granted lengthy interviews, as did Mr. Davis. Brenda Meister, who handles the India account at Verner, Liipfert, declined to be interviewed, saying that it was the firm's policy to maintain a low profile.
On one thing, Mr. Wilson and Mr. Solarz agree: Mr. Clinton would like to make the stop. Mr. Wilson's mission is to give him the political cover to do it; Mr. Solarz's is to stop it.
That would be "inappropriate and counterproductive," Mr. Solarz said. He minces no words. Pakistan is a "terrorist state," and now it has a military government. Mr. Solarz has already made these views known to the White House and the State Department, as well as to his former colleagues in Congress.
Mr. Wilson is equally busy, trying to generate a letter from enough members of Congress urging the president to make the stop.
Is he also talking to State Department officials? "Not more than four or five times a day," he answers.

HEADLINE: Amid Campaign Hoopla, One Region Feels Left Out

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: DENVER, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Ethanol plays so large a role in the agricultural economy of Iowa that candidates campaigning before the January caucuses there, the first test of presidential aspirations, ignored the issue at their peril.
Yet huge regional issues in what is loosely defined as the Interior West -- eight states that account for nearly a quarter of the country's land mass but only 40 of its 538 electoral votes -- have been all but ignored this year because of the marginal role these states play in the nomination process. Little is heard from the stump about land management, water rights, nuclear waste cleanup or endangered species. 
 By the time the polls close on Super Tuesday, March 7, more than two dozen states and American territories will have held primaries or caucuses that could well determine the major parties' nominees. But among the Interior eight -- Arizona, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Utah and Wyoming -- Arizona alone will have voted by then (in a primary for Republicans only).
In a further reflection of the region's scant influence, for the fifth straight election not one of the presidential or vice-presidential debates is to be held in any of the eight states.
In fact, the rarity of such debates anywhere in the West prompted the Western Governors' Association to ask the Commission on Presidential Debates last week to add a fourth presidential debate or a second vice-presidential debate, to be held in a Western state. In a letter to the commission, the governors expressed concern that it "has again overlooked the fastest-growing region in the country," with issues different from those in states to the east.
"It's just insane," Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, Republican of Utah, said of what many here regard as the Interior West's status as an afterthought, a result in part of the tendency of big states like California and New York to gain greater influence in the nomination process by moving up the dates of their primaries. "Everybody races to the front, and the more it's front-loaded, lots of areas in the United States get completely left out of the process."
No region so vast has been more frequently overlooked than the Interior West, whose eight states rank from 4th to 12th in land mass but from 24th to 50th in population. And in addition to their low population, most of the eight are so heavily Republican that the party's nominee can take them for granted. Only in Colorado and Nevada do Democrats have nearly equal strength.
The lack of attention has been especially noted by environmental organizations that focus much of their efforts on the West and rely on public awareness to get their issues before Congress and the administration.
"Gays in the military -- that is an important issue, but it affects a very small portion of the populace," said Kieran Suckling, executive director of the Center for Biological Diversity in Tucson. "Clean air and clean water affect every single American."
Tom Marshall, coordinator of the disarmament program for the Rocky Mountain Peace and Justice Center in Boulder, Colo., said the cleanup of nuclear waste from cold-war weapons programs, an enormous problem in the West, "is an issue that rarely shows up, if at all, in presidential campaigns."
The same can be said for many other Western issues. "Any kind of public debate would focus on policies of the West," said Gov. Jim Geringer, Republican of Wyoming. "Like protection of national forest lands. Who wouldn't be for that? But if you don't talk about areas for grazing and areas for logging, then you've not taken everybody into consideration. And without debates, that part of it gets lost."
To increase the influence of the Interior West and shine a spotlight on Western issues, Governor Leavitt led an effort two years ago to create a Western presidential primary in early March that would have enabled voters in all eight states to cast votes on the same day. But the effort failed for a variety of reasons, and a chance for the region to broaden its influence was lost.
Nor has the West had much success attracting presidential debates. In recent years, only Los Angeles, in 1988, and San Diego, in 1996, have been host to any held in the region.
James M. Souby, executive director of the Western Governors' Association, said many universities, civic groups and other likely hosts "are not aware of the process" of applying. But the debate commission's executive director, Janet Brown, said that was not necessarily so.
This year, Ms. Brown said, the commission received dozens of inquiries but, finally, just 12 formal bids, only 3 from prospective hosts in the West. No bid, she said, came from the Interior West, and the three Pacific Coast bids were eliminated when the commission selected St. Louis, Boston and Winston-Salem, N.C., for the presidential debates and Danville, Ky., for the vice-presidential debate.
That prompted the Western governors to ask for the additional debate.
A commission co-chairman, Frank J. Fahrenkopf Jr., a Nevadan who is a former chairman of the Republican National Committee, said that he sympathized with the Western states but that at this late date, he could not hold out much hope for the request.

HEADLINE: I.R.S. IS BOLSTERING EFFORTS TO CURB CHEATING ON TAXES

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Warning that continuing cuts at the Internal Revenue Service threaten the nation's tax system, the Clinton administration is proposing more money to find cheaters and make them pay up. And the agency's top official has begun emphasizing that catching cheaters is as important as helping honest taxpayers.
The administration is seeking a 9 percent increase in the agency's budget, the largest increase, adjusted for inflation, in 13 years. That would allow the I.R.S., whose auditing staff is down one-fourth since 1995, to raise the number of auditors for the first time in 6 years. 
 Republicans in Congress who have criticized the I.R.S. said they were open to the idea that more money might be needed.
Even before the request for an increased budget is taken up by Congress, the I.R.S. commissioner, Charles O. Rossotti, is moving to ensure that the agency does a better job of collecting taxes owed by companies and individuals, he said in an interview last week. For example, he has summoned all managers in the collections department to a three-day meeting in Chicago next month to insist that they act when taxpayers do not pay.
If the budget request is approved, part of it would pay for 633 more auditors, a 5 percent increase. They would hunt for cheating by people with incomes over $100,000, especially business owners, professionals and investors in partnerships. In the last three years, audit rates among such taxpayers have fallen by two-thirds, to about one in 131 returns.
The I.R.S. said it would also focus on illegitimate business tax shelters that make profits invisible to the I.R.S. These shelters are growing so fast, I.R.S. officials say, that despite soaring profits the taxes paid by large companies have actually begun to decline. These officials say that less than 70 cents of each dollar of profit reported to shareholders in 1998 was reported by companies as taxable, down from 91 cents in 1991.
The administration also wants to hire more people to answer telephone calls to the agency, allowing about 300 auditors detailed to this kind of customer service work to resume examining questionable returns.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said that "we need to begin increasing capacity" to enforce the tax laws "to maintain people's confidence that this is a tax system that works."
He said enforcement must go hand in hand with improving service to cooperative taxpayers. "Better customer service and greater collection volumes go together," he said.
Congress and the president have kept such a tight rein on spending that the I.R.S. has hired only 20 new auditors even as more than 2,000 have quit or retired since 1997.
One result is that this year fewer than one in 300 personal returns is expected to be audited, down from one in 63 two decades ago.
The decline in enforcement has become so significant that Mr. Rossotti now warns that it threatens to "undermine our entire system of voluntary tax compliance."
Mr. Rossotti and others worry that understaffing and a growing timidity by front-line auditors and tax collectors have allowed more Americans and businesses to get away with not paying what they owe.
Indeed, the I.R.S. has fallen down at the job of collecting from those who fail to turn over taxes due, mostly small businesses and the self-employed. Since hitting a record $38 billion in 1996, taxes collected through enforcement actions like audits and levies on bank accounts have fallen by 13 percent, or $5 billion.
Mr. Rossotti has summoned 665 collection managers to the meeting in Chicago next month to drive home the message that they cannot allow delinquent taxpayers, especially those who flout the law, to get away without paying. It is the first such meeting of collection managers in the agency's history, said Jody Patterson, an I.R.S. spokeswoman.
"We need to stanch the decline in collection activity," Mr. Rossotti said in an interview.
The I.R.S. came under fire in Congress two years ago, in hearings at which taxpayers said they had been bullied and harassed. Congress answered with, and President Clinton signed, legislation intended to give taxpayers more protection against overzealous tax agents.
After the law was passed, Mr. Rossotti, a wealthy businessman brought in to fix the agency, made improving service to customers -- as he calls taxpayers -- his theme.
Last year, the mission statement -- "to collect the proper amount of tax due" -- was replaced by "provide America's taxpayers top quality service by helping them understand and meet their tax responsibilities and by applying the tax law with integrity and fairness for all."
But recently Mr. Rossotti has increasingly emphasized the catching of cheaters as much as helping taxpayers. Earlier this month, for example, he told the Senate Finance Committee, "Customer satisfaction is not achieved by failing to collect taxes that are properly due."
And he has spoken out about the agency's weaknesses in enforcing the law.
He talks about shrinking resources, for one thing. The full-time I.R.S. payroll has fallen nearly 16,000, to 81,834 employees, this year, a 16 percent decline since 1993.
Yet in the last five years the number of income tax returns has grown 11 percent and the number of complex returns filed by people making $1 million or more is doubling every three years. About 250,000 households will report an income of $1 million or more for 1999.
And this at a time when the agency has had to comply with more than 1,200 changes imposed by Congress that essentially make its job more demanding. Some of those changes make it easier for taxpayers to get answers from the I.R.S., such as having people available around the clock to answer telephone inquiries. Others require the agency to take many more steps in the audit and collection process to make sure that taxpayers are not abused.
The equivalent of 3,000 more workers have been assigned to comply with the changes.
But beyond the shrinking size of the work force has been its attitude toward pursuing tax cheats. Many I.R.S. employees are now operating extremely cautiously for fear that under the new rules they can be fired for the way they once did their jobs. In interviews with The New York Times in the last year, collection officers across the country, all of whom insisted on anonymity, said that even in cases where they had followed the rules faithfully their managers were unwilling to approve seizures and levies.
"The real problem," Mr. Rossotti said, "is that there is a lot of confusion and sometimes managers are backing off to the point where they are not managing."
Over all, tax revenues have been soaring in recent years as the economy has boomed and profits have jumped. But I.R.S. officials say many forms of cheating have proliferated and tax revenues should be even higher. Their concern is that if people think they can cheat without being caught, many more people will do it and honest taxpayers will sour on the system.
"Our entire tax system depends on the vast majority of taxpayers who attempt to pay their taxes that are due having confidence that they are being treated fairly and that their competitors and neighbors are also paying what is due," Mr. Rossotti told the Senate Finance Committee earlier this month. "If the public concludes over a period of time that the I.R.S. cannot meet these basic expectations, the risk to the tax system will become very high and the effects very difficult and extraordinarily expensive to reverse."
Mr. Clinton, in his new budget proposal earlier this month, has asked for $8.84 billion for the I.R.S. in 2001, up 9 percent from the $8.11 billion Congress approved for this year. The $729 million increase includes $174 million this year and next to hire 1,633 more people, including 633 more auditors and 33 more tax collectors.
The extra money would allow the I.R.S. to replace about one-sixth of the auditors, collectors and related personnel it has lost since Mr. Clinton took office. It would also allow the hiring of more people to answer telephone inquiries from taxpayers, a job that diverted 3 percent of auditors and collectors from their primary work last year.
A spokeswoman for the Republicans who control the House Appropriations Committee said that adding a total of 2,800 full-time employees, as proposed in the budget, is a rather large request, one that will be discussed in hearings next month. Republicans have long held a suspicious view of the I.R.S. and have criticized the agency for what they call its plodding pace and its emphasis on catching tax cheats.
"We're going to have to look very closely at this request," said Elizabeth Mora, the spokeswoman, adding that Congress has had a different set of priorities for the I.R.S. in the past. "We have been concerned and remain concerned about modernization. We are also very concerned about a balance between law enforcement and customer service. We need to make sure there is a correct balance between the two."
Two architects of the recent laws overhauling the I.R.S. said they were open to the idea that more money may be needed for enforcement.
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who chairs the House Ways and Means Committee, said he "will do what's necessary so the I.R.S. can serve the taxpayer."
And Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, who chairs the Senate Finance Committee, said, "It's important that the I.R.S. have sufficient funding to ensure successful execution of the current reorganization plan in order to make tax collection more efficient, and provide better service to taxpayers."
The I.R.S. has also backed away from an interpretation of the new tax act that required collectors to demand full payment of taxes past due -- or nothing at all.
Under that new approach, tax delinquents who did not pay in full were having their cases put aside. Tax experts said that many people who owed money would bet that the statute of limitations would expire before the I.R.S. pursued them, and that therefore people who could have paid something would no longer do so.
The new policy directs agents to collect as much as possible from such taxpayers, just as was done previously.

HEADLINE: U.N. Chief Blames Rich Nations for Failure of Trade Talks

BYLINE: Agence France-Presse 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 12

 BODY:
Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, today blamed the world's most powerful nations for the breakdown of last year's world trade talks and called for a "Global New Deal" to remedy the imbalances between rich and poor countries.
Mr. Annan described as a "popular myth" the belief that the World Trade Organization talks in Seattle were derailed by days of the violent protests that paralyzed the meeting's program. 
 Instead, he said at a United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, that their failure was the fault of the world's leading economic powers, which, he said, "could not agree on their priorities."
Developing nations played a more "active and united role" in the Seattle talks than ever before, he said, while the industrial powers bickered among themselves and showed that they did not have the will to carry out reforms in the rules that govern the international trading system.
The United Nations conference, which has earned a reputation as an advocate of poor nations, aims to bring developing nations into the global economic fold and calm fierce anti-trade sentiment.
But even before Mr. Annan could open the meeting today, some 1,000 protesters marched on the conference site in central Bangkok, demanding immediate action to share the spoils of globalization more fairly. The protesters, carried through the Thai capital on trucks laden with hundreds of balloons, were eventually blocked by riot policemen.
Mr. Annan said trade barriers put in place by industrialized countries were helping to exclude developing nations from the benefits of global trade. He called for a "Global New Deal," to spread the advantages of the freer flow of goods, jobs and capital among all countries that were open to investment.
"Can we not attempt on a global level what any successful industrialized country does to help its most disadvantaged or underdeveloped regions catch up?" he asked.
The head of the World Trade Organization, Michael Moore, said today that he was working on a plan to offer poorer countries better access to lucrative markets.
"We have agreed to try and negotiate free market access for least developed countries," he said, adding that envoys to the trade group have said they would discuss how to enact such changes. "I think confidence is back," he said.
That did not stop one of the biggest critics of Western-style globalization, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, from issuing another stinging critique of the global system when he addressed the conference today.
Branding himself a "heretic," Mr. Mahathir renewed his attacks on financial speculators and questioned whether the current wave of world economic expansion would ever benefit developing nations.
He confessed, too, that he was "frightened" at the growing power of global corporations, some of which he said "are more powerful than mid-sized countries."
On the sidelines of today's conference, Mr. Annan also worked to settle another issue that has trouble the United Nations: a proper trial for the leaders of the former Khmer Rouge regime in Cambodia, who are blamed for the deaths of more than a million people from 1975 to 1979.
He met today with the Cambodian prime minister, Hun Sen, and said afterward that he was confident an agreement could be reached to allow the United Nations to endorse a trial of Khmer Rouge leaders.
Negotiations over a trial have been deadlocked for months over who should control the courtroom, Cambodia or the United Nations.
Mr. Annan said he would send a team of legal experts to Phnom Penh soon to iron out differences with Cambodian officials.
"We both hope that at that meeting all the outstanding issues will be concluded and we can move on and establish a tribunal," Mr. Annan said.
His meeting with Mr. Hun Sen came one day after the prime minister accused the United Nations of treating Cambodia like a "dog" for insisting that his government's plan did not meet international standards.
Today, Mr. Hun Sen was visibly more upbeat after his meeting with Mr. Annan and said, "We are working to have a credible trial of the Khmer Rouge leaders, so I think it was a good meeting."

HEADLINE: Executives Make Trade With China a Moral Issue

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.

 BODY:
When a group of Florida businessmen paid a visit one recent afternoon to Corrine Brown, their Congresswoman, they put her on notice that they consider trading with China a moral crusade.
"The only way we're going to undermine that regime is to infiltrate it," Frank Pearce, a business consultant and local Chamber of Commerce leader, told Ms. Brown in a meeting. "You can't moralize across the ocean."
Wayne Nash, who runs his own import-export company, said missionaries and businessmen will work together to change China, unless Congress interferes. "The missionaries are over there doing the dangerous stuff," he told Ms. Brown, "but trade is what opens the doors." 
 The Clinton administration and corporate America have a great deal riding on whether such pitches persuade Ms. Brown, a four-term Democrat who calls herself a leader in human rights causes, to vote in favor of extending new, permanent trading rights to China. She is among 70-odd wavering lawmakers whose votes are seen as crucial.
Congress must decide, as early as spring, whether to give up its annual review of China's trading rights. In a landmark agreement last year paving the way for China to join the World Trade Organization, the Clinton administration promised that China would be guaranteed the same low-tariff access to the United States market that most countries have. But Congress has the final say.
President Clinton argues that the choice is clear. The often tense relationship with China and America's global leadership in trade would get a significant boost with a yes vote. Rejecting the agreement would deal a serious blow on both fronts.
Yet the decision is being hotly contested, and the outcome is uncertain. Trade, in the final year of the Clinton presidency, has become a tough sell. The failure of global trade talks in Seattle late last year emboldened a coalition of labor, environmental and consumer groups that now want to derail or at least delay trade liberalization with China.
"This is going to be the toughest fight we face this year on Capitol Hill," White House chief of staff John Podesta told a friendly group of farm lobbyists this week. "There are people who have strong views who don't agree with us."
Congressional leaders say they will not schedule a vote until Europe closes its own deal with China, and the timing of that remains uncertain. Yet nearly everyone agrees that the vote must take place by June, before the election year pressures become any more intense.
Congress has not rallied to the cause. Republican leaders back China trade. But, facing some ideological opposition in their party, they say that they will not push the measure through unless they get support from 90 or so Democrats, roughly half that party's number in the House.
Already, 53 members of the Democrats' left-leaning Congressional Progressive Caucus have announced that they will vote no. Pro-trade Democrats worry that the United Auto Workers and the Teamsters, two unions determined to defeat the China accord, could make this an excruciating choice for liberals facing re-election.
To turn the tide, the administration and big business, which strongly supports a China trade deal, have begun what they are billing as the largest lobbying effort on a foreign-policy vote since the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993.
America Online leads a coalition of computer and Internet companies trying to give the China vote a high-tech spin, arguing that free trade opens China's promising telecommunications and Internet industries. Michael Eisner of the Walt Disney Company, Sumner Redstone of Viacom and Rupert Murdoch of the News Corporation are pushing the accord because it would increase how many films they can market in China.
The two biggest business lobbying groups, the United States Chamber of Commerce and the Business Roundtable, have vowed to try to whip up support for the China trade agreement in several dozen swing Congressional districts with a $12 million campaign.
Jacksonville, the northern Florida port city, is viewed as a test of whether business can stoke pro-trade enthusiasm at the local level. Spurred by the national Chamber of Commerce, local business leaders hold regular meetings with Jacksonville's port authorities and the city's economic development board to plot ways of persuading the city's representatives in the House, Ms. Brown and Tillie K. Fowler, a Republican, to vote for China trade. Both have opposed extending normal trade privileges to China in the past.
The pro-trade forces are emphasizing the city's vested interest in expanding economic ties. Its port employs 35,000. With sparkling Toyotas and Hyundais parked bumper to bumper on acres of asphalt, the port is also thriving on Asian cargo. It recently struck an alliance with Hong Kong-based Hutchinson-Whampoa, a cargo handler that specializes in China trade, to serve as a way station for goods that pass through Hutchinson's new deep-water container port in the Bahamas.
"I wish the downtown were just a bit further upriver so people could see all the traffic going through here," said Kenneth R. Krauter, president of the port, which is about 15 miles from the city center.
Ms. Brown said she was ready to listen. She joined 800 local executives for a Chamber of Commerce lunch late last month. After the Pledge of Allegiance, a video tribute to Jacksonville's N.F.L. Jaguars and a pro-trade speech by a prominent local leader, businessmen tried to pin Ms. Brown down on her views on China.
They mixed testimonials about how important trade had been to their own businesses with appeals to her human rights concerns. They spoke of their passion for spreading democracy and Christianity.
"How do you change a totalitarian system?" Mr. Pearce asked her, stressing each syllable in a slow Southern rhythm. He answered his own question. "You get it exposed."
Ms. Brown gave them scant comfort. "China has always been a struggle for me," she said, describing how she had changed her mind about whether expanding trade with China was a good thing.
"We have tried to have discussions with those people for seven or eight years," she said. "What have they tangibly done in terms of human rights?"
Some local business executives said they thought they had more success converting Ms. Fowler. Over lunch, six executives of Jacksonville companies described how their own business depended on imports and exports. Hy W. Kliman, president of Global Sourcing & Trading, described how he built a thriving multinational business on the strength of a single bowling shoe contract he reached with a Chinese company in 1973, five years before the two countries had formal diplomatic relations.
Several of the business executives said that Ms. Fowler called the session an "education" and told them after the lunch that she would support the China accord. But her chief of staff said Ms. Fowler had yet to decide how to vote.
Leslie Schweitzer, an official of the national Chamber of Commerce who led the Jacksonville organization drive, said there is clearly a deep reservoir of pro-trade sentiment to be tapped. But she acknowledged that the process demands patience.
"This has to be sustained long-term every place we try it to be effective," Ms. Schweitzer said. "The problem is that the most important policy issue we face -- China -- is here right now."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;
N.F.L.'s Newest Line Is the Unemployment Line

BYLINE: By MIKE FREEMAN 

 BODY:
It was late in the regular season, and the Buffalo Bills wide receiver Andre Reed, in one of many frustrating outbursts, said something prophetic to a small group of reporters. His words may be remembered for decades.
"You will never see players like Bruce, Thurman and me again," Reed said. "Never." 
 Reed was referring to the great trio, who along with the quarterback Jim Kelly transformed the Bills into one of the top franchises in football. Bruce Smith is going into the Hall of Fame as one of the best defensive linemen of all time. Thurman Thomas was one of the greatest offensive weapons ever, and some would argue that Reed was the most crucial piece of the franchise.
Last week, on what can only be called traumatic Thursday, the Bills, because of salary-cap reasons, in one swift, brutal move, cut Reed, Smith and Thomas, ending one of the most productive, and sometimes emotional, player-team relationships in sports. The three men were key reasons that the Bills made four Super Bowl appearances.
In fact, all across the league, teams were making hard decisions to get under the $62.172 million salary cap. Such stresses produced the single most stunning day of player cuts ever. Pro Bowlers and future Hall of Famers found themselves in the unemployment line. The Vikings released the 11-time Pro Bowl guard Randall McDaniel. The Giants released center Brian Williams, who is irritated that the team said he planned to retire. Williams plans on playing for another team next season. Offensive tackle Bruce Armstrong was let go by the New England Patriots.
In Miami, quarterback Dan Marino voided the last two years of his contract, and the Dolphins made perhaps the saddest cut of all. Marino was miffed that when he recently talked to team officials, few expressed interest in keeping him. Marino told friends that when he met with the new coach, Dave Wannstedt, Wannstedt rarely looked him in the eye. So Marino figured it was time to go.
Marino is strongly considering retiring, but wants to explore his options, and will meet with Tampa Bay, Seattle and Oakland. If Marino hears the right thing from any of those teams, such as he can have a chance to earn his way into the starting lineup, he will probably play again. If not, he will retire.
The Buccaneers denied any interest in Marino, but they have to play coy, at least for now, because they do not want to get into a bidding war for Marino's services. Marino's agent, Marvin Demoff, met with at least one Tampa Bay official at the Pro Bowl, where the team's coaching staff was leading the National Football Conference squad, and the Bucs expressed slight interest.
Buffalo had its own emotional mess to deal with. What happened to Smith, Reed and Thomas proves that an accomplished veteran N.F.L. player, because of a hardened salary cap, can no longer retire gracefully.
Smith is second on the career sack list to Reggie White. Reed and Jerry Rice entered this season tied for first with 12 seasons of 50 or more pass receptions. Thomas is seventh in combined yards from scrimmage. Only Smith has one or two seasons left, mainly because Smith takes good care of himself. Yesterday, Smith signed a five-year, $23 million contract with the Washington Redskins.
The three men have had a love-hate affair with the city of Buffalo, the Bills and the news media there. In some ways, Reed and Thomas became bitter in the end. Especially Reed. In his last few years, he often complained about his role in the offense, and this season he lashed out at quarterback Doug Flutie, saying the success Flutie was having swelled his ego. And he never forgave some teammates who questioned his physical courage at the end of the 1995 season.
Thomas scowled a lot and sometimes cursed at reporters, and Smith was always thought of as selfish by the Buffalo beat writers, though with the national media, Smith was always pleasant and gracious.
But nothing should take away from the accomplishments of Reed, Smith and Thomas. Reed is right: the Bills may never see a group of special players like them again.
 
Franchise Tag Saves Money
If you want to understand why players hate the franchise tag, and teams love it, look no further than the Detroit Lions and the sticky situation involving their star defensive lineman, Robert Porcher.
Porcher is considered one of the top three defensive linemen in the game. He is blessed with great speed, power and a tremendous work ethic. In the locker room, he is respected and a team leader.
Shortly before the 4 p.m. Thursday deadline teams had to meet to declare their franchise players, the Lions offered Porcher a contract worth $35 million over five years, which included a $13 million signing bonus. Sounds like too much money for a lineman, and the offer could indeed fuel the economy of a small country. But consider that Porcher's 49 sacks in the past four years are the most among defensive linemen. Because teams rarely get a player of his caliber, they will do whatever it takes to keep someone like Porcher, even if it means offering him the largest deal in Lions history.
"Largest contract. Largest average per year and largest signing bonus," the team's general manager, Chuck Schmidt, said. "Largest period."
Porcher countered with a $41.5 million, five-year proposal that included a $15 million signing bonus. Detroit respectfully declined.
The Lions, fearing an agreement might never be reached, tagged him as their franchise player, meaning he would receive the average of the top five highest salaries at his position, which is $4.235 million. So Porcher will make his millions next season, and no one should cry for him. But on the free-agent market, Porcher would have made $7 million to $8 million a year.
So the franchise tag may, in the end, cost Porcher up to $4 million. That is something to cry about. And no team is likely to trade for Porcher because of the tag, since to trade for the player, a team would have to give the Lions two first-round picks.
Nine players were tagged with the franchise label by their individual teams, and few players were happy about it. Among them are the Miami offensive tackle Richmond Webb ($4.081 million franchise number), Kansas City guard Will Shields ($4.081 million), Jacksonville defensive end Tony Brackens ($4.253 million), San Diego defensive tackle Norman Hand ($4.727 million), Washington running back Stephen Davis ($3.532 million), and the Jets' Mo Lewis ($4.187 million). Lewis is believed to be extremely irritated by the designation, since he may have been able to earn $7 million a season as an unrestricted free agent.
Several general managers said that they expected this to be the thinnest free-agent field in years, mainly because so many top potential free agents have been franchised.
But at least one of the franchise players may find his off-season to be interesting. Rumors persist that the Redskins are considering trading Davis to Detroit for the rights to Barry Sanders, who various team officials believe may soon announce his return to football. The Redskins have denied any interest in Sanders.
 
Galloway to Cowboys
Another franchise player, the Seahawks' Joey Galloway, found a new home yesterday in a trade with the Cowboys. Seattle received Dallas's first-round draft picks this year and next.
Galloway, who missed all of the preseason and the first eight games last year because of a contract dispute, set up the trade by signing a contract with the Seahawks yesterday. Minutes later, Seattle traded him to the Cowboys, who had already come to terms with him on a seven-year, $42 million deal that included a $12.5 million signing bonus.
The Seahawks named Galloway their exclusive franchise player last Thursday after an arbitrator ruled him an unrestricted free agent.
