SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 2; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1705 words

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Tests Its Limits in Quest to Grow

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARITA, Calif.

 BODY:
This is the last frontier, the place where the suburban sprawl of Los Angeles meets a peaceful patch of live oaks, rolling hills and quiet back roads along the Santa Clara River, one of a tiny handful of wild waterways left in Southern California. It is also a battle zone, the future home of Newhall Ranch, the largest housing development ever approved by Los Angeles County, with 21,600 units for 70,000 people to be built over the next 20 years.
To its critics, including neighboring Ventura County, which has filed a lawsuit seeking to block it, Newhall Ranch is a symbol of all that is wrong with California's decades of catch-as-catch-can development, in which suburbs sprang up in ever-widening, ill-considered rings. 
 To its backers, Newhall Ranch is a sensitively planned community, the vision of a responsible developer with a long track record of building affordable slices of the American dream.
But big and controversial as it may be, Newhall Ranch is nothing compared with the projected need for new housing in Los Angeles County: about 25,000 units a year, according to the Southern California Association of Governments.
By 2025, the state's population of 34 million is projected to grow by 18 million more (a New York State) and that of the Los Angeles region by 6 million (or two Chicagos).
That pace would exceed the boom years of the 1950's, 60's and 70's combined in absolute numbers, though not in percentage. New Californians are being born or moving into the state at the rate of 1,700 a day, or roughly 1 every 50 seconds.
"L.A.'s so big that you can take the biggest project anybody's ever conceived of and it is, in regional terms, only a drop in the bucket," said William Fulton, an urban planner, "which shows you how hard it is to meet the need with traditional suburban development.
"What are you going to do?" asked Mr. Fulton, the author of "The Reluctant Metropolis: The Politics of Urban Growth in Los Angeles." "Build 200 Newhall Ranches? The truth is, with six million people, growth has got to be both up and out."
That is easier said than done in a place where even residents of modest means have long viewed a patch of yard and sky, a lemon tree and maybe even a swimming pool as all but a birthright, and the fight over Newhall Ranch is proof positive of how hard it will be to change the paradigm. Planners and politicians may talk of "urban infill" and "downtown redevelopment," but Los Angeles has been steadily sprawling for more than 80 years.
Since at least the mid-70's, residents of established neighborhoods have consistently opposed construction of apartment complexes, leaving developers little choice but to build in fringe areas like those near Santa Clarita, a collection of old farming towns northwest of Los Angeles that have been consolidated into the fourth largest city in the county, with nearly 150,000 people.
"In Los Angeles, it's part of our culture to aspire to live in open spaces in single-family homes," said Supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky of Los Angeles County, a Democrat who acknowledged that it pained him to vote for a project as big as Newhall last year but who felt he had little choice, given his own constituents' opposition to living any closer together.
"People don't want to live in skyscrapers like New York," Mr. Yaroslavsky said. "People fled New York to come here, and once you've lived in a single-family house with your own backyard, you're basically not interested in moving back to what amounts to a Holiday Inn-like existence."
The population of Riverside and San Bernardino Counties, which make up the "Inland Empire" east of Los Angeles, has roughly doubled since 1980, making the area the fastest growing part of the region, and the population there is expect to double again in the next 20 years.
Such explosive growth has ignited widespread anxiety, and a recent statewide survey by the Public Policy Institute of California found that 4 in 10 residents said they believed the state will be a worse place to live in 20 years.
The fight over Newhall Ranch, to be built in an unincorporated area of Los Angeles County, has put the debate over urban sprawl into particularly sharp relief because the project abuts the border of Ventura County, an agricultural enclave that is Southern California's least populated.
For years, Ventura has looked askance at growth and recently adopted some of the most stringent antigrowth measures in the nation, which generally require voter approval to rezone farmland or open space for development, or to expand cities beyond their existing boundaries. Mr. Fulton, the planner, calls this conflict the region's Kosovo.
The Newhall Land & Farming Company, the 117-year-old real estate and ranching concern that is developing the project, says it is merely keeping pace with realities and demand by building Newhall Ranch, to be roughly divided between single-family houses with prices up to $1 million and town houses and rental apartments. New hall began developing some of the 36,000 acres it owns in the area more than 30 years ago after county tax assessors, watching the northward growth from the San Fernando Valley, raised assessments on what had long been agricultural land.
The result was the planned town of Valencia, a still-growing leafy haven that boasts two office parks, two industrial parks and a pedestrian-friendly Town Center mall that is the shopping and entertainment hub for the Santa Clarita Valley.
This suburb, first settled by workers in the aerospace industry who were attracted by the short commute to places like the Lockheed plant in Burbank, is now home to many support workers and technicians in the entertainment industry, and to high-tech types who work in the office parks of the San Fernando and Santa Clarita Valleys.
"Despite all that you would hear, and the outcries about development," a house "is still the American dream," said Thomas L. Lee, chairman and chief executive of Newhall, which expects that about half the buyers for new Newhall Ranch houses will come from the Santa Clarita Valley itself.
"We're providing homes to people who just want a piece of the American dream like everybody else," Mr. Lee said. "The large majority of people want to live that way."
Mr. Lee added: "The people are going to be here, whether the housing is here or not. They already have a serious problem in Los Angeles."
But critics of Newhall's plans point out that much of the demand for housing in the region is actually among the growing Hispanic and immigrant populations of urban Los Angeles, where families are doubled up in apartments and can not yet afford suburban houses. (Hispanic residents were the only group in the recent Public Policy Institute survey that said the state would be a better place to live in 20 years).
At the same time, Newhall's opponents note that some 40,000 additional housing units have already been approved but not built in Santa Clarita, and they would like to see these developed before builders encroach on pristine land.
"You're just vaporizing your open space and watershed and indiscriminately paving it over for something that I can't see as a genuine need," said Lynne Plambeck, first vice president of the Santa Clarita Organization for Planning and Environment, part of a coalition of several environmental groups and Ventura County and the State Attorney General's office, which challenged New hall's environmental review as inadequate, especially in its analysis of water supplies for the new development. A trial in the case is set for next month in a state court.
In the face of opposition, Newhall scaled back the project from the originally planned 25,000 units, and it has set aside about 10 percent of the units as lower-income housing and promised to preserve about 9 square miles of the 19-square-mile project as open space.
But the critics have dismissed the concessions and contend that New hall Ranch would damage the delicate ecosystem of the Santa Clara River and threaten birds and other wildlife, as well as the flood plain.
"I sort of feel like sometimes it's a situation where if you don't build it, they won't come," Ms. Plambeck said, reversing the "Field of Dreams" formulation.
The reality is not quite so simple, of course, and whatever the fate of Newhall, the growing population's demands on state roads, schools, bridges and public transportation are already a huge concern. Newhall itself expects to pay tens of millions of dollars in the coming years for highway improvements. But statewide investment in public facilities has lagged since the 70's, which was itself fostered in part by local opposition to apartment construction.
That caused housing shortages that led real estate prices -- and, eventually, property tax assessments -- to rise.
"If you build fences around communities in areas that are adjacent to the high job growth areas of the state, you're not going to meet your housing needs, period," said Tim Coyle, the California Building Industry Association's chief lobbyist. "The politics of antigrowth initiatives not only limit housing, but ultimately they're hostile to the economic and social interests of the citizenry."
Some politicians, like Philip Angelides, the state treasurer, have proposed investments aimed at rebuilding neighborhoods.
As a member of state public employee pension boards, for example, Mr. Angelides has voted to invest $1 billion in pension funds in urban real estate development, and he has restructured tax credits to make $450 million a year available for construction and rehabilitation of affordable rental housing.
"I don't take the view that even the most robust of public policies is really powerful enough to shape growth patterns," Mr. Angelides said.
"But clearly, their absence will result in a situation in which we're the victims of unplanned growth. As long as we remain productive and attractive, we will have that growth demographic," he said. "Our challenge is how do we maintain the livability and quality of life that brought residents and economic vitality in the first place. Because if California becomes unlivable then we won't really be economically viable either."

HEADLINE: FEBRUARY 6-12;
1990's Productivity Makes It Best Decade Since 1960's

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The 1990's economic expansion, now the longest expansion in the nation's history, draws its staying power from various wells -- the two most important being the booming stock market and labor's rising efficiency.
The stock market makes people feel wealthy, encouraging them to spend. To help satisfy this rising demand, America's workers are managing to produce more goods and services in each hour of work. Their rising output keeps the economy growing and plays a big role in extending the expansion. 
 No one really knows just why workers have become more productive in recent years, or for how long they will continue to grow more efficient, as they did in the last six months of 1999. The Labor Department announced last week that productivity, or output per hour, had risen at an annual rate of 5 percent from June through December, the best performance in seven years. And the expansion marches on. LOUIS UCHITELLE

SECTION: Section 6; Page 48; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 2940 words

HEADLINE: What's a Nice Liberal Multimillionaire Doing In a Race Like This?

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub is a contributing writer for the magazine. He last wrote about schools and poverty.

 BODY:
Jon S. Corzine has spent the last several months learning the difference between office politics and politics. In his previous line of work, at the investment firm of Goldman, Sachs, where he served as chairman and C.E.O. until early last year, Corzine was counted a master politician -- the kind of executive who understood the secret ambitions and fears of everyone around him. On Wall Street, being a good politician had a lot to do with being likable. Now, however, Corzine is running for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in New Jersey, a state whose politics do not typically reward amiability. Corzine's opponent is Jim Florio, the former governor of the state and a man who is, for good reason, invariably referred to as "an ex-boxer." Last month, according to a news account, Florio fired his media adviser when the adviser refused to follow Florio's "scorched-earth policy."
One day last month, I sat with Corzine through an interminable ceremony marking the opening of the 209th session of the New Jersey Legislature. During a lull between the skirling of the bagpipes and the nomination of the clerk of the Assembly, Corzine handed me a copy of a Florio news release. Like a number of leading Democrats, Corzine advocates investing up to 15 percent of the Social Security Trust Fund in the stock market. In the release, Florio not only claimed that Corzine was threatening the stability of Social Security -- arguable, though fair game -- but also went on to declare that the proposal was "clearly in Jon Corzine's self-interest" since Goldman and other Wall Street firms would benefit from the trading activity. That was a low blow. Corzine whispered: "He's saying that I'm going to benefit from this personally. That just makes no sense." Corzine was plainly scandalized, though a less self-contained person might have found a more vehement way of expressing it. 
 There is a good reason why members of the upper managerial elite, which is to say bankers, corporate lawyers, C.E.O.'s, foundation heads and the like, don't usually run for office. These people live in a chaste and polished world limited to themselves and a large class of servitors and facilitators. Why lower yourself to the tacky level of Elks Clubs and church suppers? Why make a public dartboard of yourself? If you have a yen for "public service," as it is invariably known in this stratum, you can satisfy it by accepting an appointment in the relevant federal body. For the perfect model, you need look no further than Robert Rubin, Corzine's predecessor's predecessor at Goldman, who reached the zenith of bankerly glory as secretary of the Treasury.
Well, nobody asked Jon Corzine (pronounced with a long "i") to be secretary of the Treasury. Still, Corzine believes that he can conduct the campaign with the same fine moral tone he and his colleagues maintained at Goldman. "As standards get lowered," he says of Florio, "I think it will rub to his detriment." That may be so, though other candidates have lived to rue that calculation. Indeed, with the primary looming June 6, the central battle of the campaign just now is not between Corzine and Florio but between Corzine and his own aides and advisers, who are urging him to behave in a way that runs against the grain of his nature and his experience.
Jon Corzine, who is 53, has the balding pate, rimless spectacles, mild gaze and fuzzy beard of an English professor in a small private college. He is a good listener, a slow ruminator, a modest man who takes up less space than any zillionaire you've ever met. (He insists on anonymity for his very sizable charitable gifts.) Corzine's personality comes into clearer focus if you think of him not as Wall Street Man but as Midwestern Man. Corzine grew up on a farm in Willey's Station, a tiny town in southern Illinois; his mother was a schoolteacher and his father, besides farming, sold insurance. Corzine met his wife, Joanne, when they were both in kindergarten, married her as soon as he graduated from college and stayed married to her thereafter. (They have three children.) He was a plugger rather than a star. He made the University of Illinois basketball team as a walk-on. He hoped to get a Ph.D. in urban planning, but when his draft number came up, he joined the Marine Reserve. Ultimately, he enrolled at the University of Chicago Business School.
In 1975, Corzine joined Goldman, Sachs as a bond trader and in very short order was made a partner and then a member of the executive committee. Certain themes recur when people talk about Corzine's career at Goldman: he was a very good trader, which is to say that he has more of an appetite for risk, and more self-confidence, than his tamped-down surface discloses; absolutely everybody liked him; and he was very driven, even by Goldman standards. his gifts were political ones, at least as the business world understands them. "He never stood out here in terms of being brilliant," says one Goldman partner. "But he's off the charts in terms of getting people to trust him or putting people at ease." Goldman appears to represent the kind of Darwinian environment that offers the perfect training school for political combat. But it is not; Goldman was, until recently, a partnership in which earnings depended on group success and the ethos of the team was paramount. And Corzine believed devoutly in the team. "There is, and has been in most of my life," he says, "a desire for people, where things are competitive, to try to keep them civil and to try to define things in the interest of the greater good or the widest community."
Corzine became senior partner of Goldman in 1994. He got the job because he was widely liked and respected, because he wanted it more than others did and because a breach had to be quickly filled when the previous senior partner abruptly quit. There are various accounts of what happened over the next few years, but it is clear both that the firm flourished during Corzine's tenure and that the executive committee became increasingly disenchanted with his leadership. Among other things, Corzine wanted to take Goldman, Sachs public; many of the bankers at first did not. Corzine won that battle, but lost the war: the firm agreed to issue shares to the public, but without Corzine at the helm. On Jan. 11 last year, in an act virtually unprecedented in the history of the firm, Corzine was forced out. Some of his closest colleagues voted against him; it must have been just about the worst day in his life, but a close friend says that he could "only guess" at Corzine's feelings of humiliation. When I asked, I got name, rank and serial number. "I think in a public company you need fairly tight coherence at the top of the house," he said, a sign of company loyalty as much as stoicism.
Corzine cashed out when the firm went public, and just like that, he was worth $300 million to $400 million. His plans for life after Goldman all involved making yet more money. And then sheer accident intruded into what had been a very orderly life. In mid-February of last year, Senator Frank Lautenberg, a Democrat, announced that he would not run for re-election. Jim Florio immediately declared his own candidacy. This, in turn, triggered an "anyone but Florio" movement among the county leaders who effectively control the party. Florio is a talented politician and a serious student of policy who nevertheless has a gift for making himself disliked. Both his temperament and a decision he made in 1990 to raise taxes in order to pay for a court-ordered increase in the state's education budget contributed to making him a highly unpopular governor. And Florio brought the whole party down with him. By 1993, when Christine Whitman defeated him to become the new governor, the Democrats had lost 600 seats at the state and local level -- a rout that party leaders have neither forgotten nor forgiven.
The party leaders outside of Florio's stronghold in South Jersey decided that they must act together and began auditioning potential nominees. When none of the available candidates gained a consensus, a party activist and friend of Corzine's called up to ask if he would like to run. Corzine had long lived in New Jersey, was a major donor to the national Democratic Party and had always expressed a powerful if vague yearning for political office. Like many ex-partners at investment banks, he wanted to use his fantastic wealth to do something interesting and worthwhile. So he agreed.
The party bosses were beguiled by this plutocrat with the antiplutocratic personality. Robert Janiszewski, the executive of Hudson County as well as the head of the county party, says that he was expecting Gordon Gekko and was startled to meet "the professor from 'Gilligan's Island."' But Janiszewski also says that he wouldn't have been talking to Corzine at all if it weren't for Corzine's money. New Jersey is an incredibly expensive state in which to run for office -- you have to buy television time in New York City and Philadelphia. In order to raise his own profile and to counteract Florio's popularity among core Democrats, Corzine would have to spend a minimum of $5 million, and possibly quite a bit more, on media alone. And Corzine was willing to spend whatever was necessary.
Corzine never, ever, talks about his money, an act of reticence that one pundit has likened to Cyrano's imagining that he can make his nose disappear by refusing to call attention to it. Yet Corzine's deep pockets have already scattered the opposition. With the exception of Florio, the other Democratic candidates withdrew soon after Corzine entered the race. Governor Whitman chose not to run, a decision widely attributed to a fear of Corzine's money. The remaining Republicans, principal among them Representative Bob Franks and State Senator William L. Gormley, are not considered particularly formidable.
A recent filing shows that Corzine has already spent $3.6 million, a staggering sum this early in the campaign. Florio, whose own fund-raising has been anemic, will do his best to turn Corzine's wealth against him. "Should Steve Forbes be our role model for public office in the future?" Florio asks. "There's clearly nothing illegal in spending untold millions of your own money to purchase office. But the people of this state and the people of this country should think through whether it's good for democracy or not." Of course, the popularity of Frank Lautenberg, Christie Whitman and others implies that New Jersey voters may actually like their candidates rich.
Corzine is hoping that voters will pay attention to his views rather than to his money. And Corzine's position papers make amazing reading. He is almost certainly to the left of the entire United States Senate, including Ted Kennedy and Paul Wellstone, and he doesn't have many competitors even in the House. He opposes welfare reform and mandatory sentencing and strongly favors affirmative action, for women as well as minorities. Indeed, you would have a hard time finding any room between Corzine and either the N.A.A.C.P. or the National Organization for Women.
Corzine favors "universal quality preschool," which is to say something better and more expensive than Head Start, and "universal after-school programs" and free college tuition for all high-school students with a B average. He argues that we need to substitute a "living wage" of $8 an hour for the current minimum wage of $5.15. He advocates "universal gun registration" and "universal health care coverage," to be provided through employer mandates and tax credits. He opposes the death penalty. He believes in a stronger voice for organized labor, and he uses a phrase you don't hear often from Democratic officeholders, much less Wall Street executives: "Economic power is out of whack in America."
One of the people who helped Corzine with his platform is Susan Estrich, the former Dukakis campaign manager. Estrich was startled to discover that this living symbol of Wall Street was both more liberal and less "political" than she was. "I went round and round with him on affirmative action," she says. "I told him that if I'm skeptical, you're never going to find 51 percent of voters to my left." But Corzine wouldn't budge. Estrich says that she finds his contempt for focus-group politics highly refreshing; he has even refused to shave his beard. Corzine believes that voters will reward him for his ideological purity and political nonconformity. This may be a sign of navete rather than courage.
I spent a day hopscotching across New Jersey with Corzine early last month. The high point of the day was a restaurant meeting at the Jersey Shore in which Corzine accepted the endorsement of the Ocean County Democratic Organization. After spreading his money all over the state, Corzine has now been endorsed by most of the county leaders in Central and North Jersey -- which makes him, oddly enough, the machine candidate. Al Santoro, the Ocean County chairman, introduced Corzine as "a person who has no baggage," which is shorthand for, "He isn't Jim Florio."
Corzine's speech was not very edifying. He seems to think that the way to elevate the discourse is to increase its level of abstraction, and so he talked about "community" and "excellence" and "high standards" as if he were delivering a commencement address. There were no applause lines, and very little applause. At the same time, Corzine has precisely the gift you wouldn't expect from a Wall Street baron, which is the common touch. After the speech, he squeezed biceps and draped an arm over shoulders; he grinned and guffawed and gave every impression of having a swell time. Voters who expect to encounter J.P. Morgan or Gordon Gekko are pleasantly surprised to meet Mr. Ordinary. Marena Agnoli, the municipal chairman of the Democratic Party of Dover Township, told me: "He's just so rich that when you hear about him, all you can think is, Rich, rich, rich. But you meet him, and he could be the guy who cuts your lawn or something."
Corzine believes that voters are yearning for decency, but decency alone won't get him elected (though decency and money might). In recent polling data, Florio is leading Corzine 51 to 18 among voters in North Jersey's Hudson County -- which is probably a reflection of Corzine's low name recognition. Corzine had his first direct encounter with Florio several weeks after I met him when both men addressed the Princeton County Democratic Organization. Corzine, slow and earnest and soft-spoken, made his usual fine remarks about raising the standards of debate and then ran down his list of issues at his usual lofty level of generality. Florio advanced to the lectern and said curtly, "You have to go beyond the general principle of things." Florio then delivered an extremely polished and hard-edged recitation of his achievements and his views.
The first questioner asked how the two men expected to appeal to moderate Republicans. This is the perfect Jon Corzine question. Corzine could have said that Robert Rubin would vouch for him, that he knew more about the economy than the Republicans did and that Jim Florio had, well, some baggage. But what he said was: "I go back to the concept that people want the same thing. They want quality education. . . . Moderates are very concerned that we protect social liberties in this country. . . ."
It was a painful moment. Corzine apparently thought that his audience wanted another uplifting sermon, not political calculation. Florio took over and said in his machine-gun style, "Republicans have always tagged Democrats as believing in comprehensive, universal everything." He talked about the death penalty, which he supports, and the need to be tough on crime. And he ended by observing, with barely masked condescension, "We've got to be aware that not everybody thinks the same as everyone in this room."
Florio has accused Corzine of dodging debates, and he is right -- Corzine is simply not yet ready to go head to head with him. Some of the people around Corzine were appalled by the Princeton event. And when I asked one of New Jersey's leading political analysts how he thought Corzine was faring as a campaigner, he said: "He's absolutely awful. It's not that he's not ready for prime time; he's not ready for daytime."
The Princeton debate may in fact have been a necessary low point in the Corzine campaign. Corzine finally surrendered to his staff's entreaties, permitting them to launch a counterattack, including the revelation that Florio himself had proposed investing a portion of the Social Security Trust Fund. A new, peppery John Corzine was being born, or so said his backers. In a subsequent speech to another county group that had endorsed him, he stabbed the air with his index finger, talked about winning and said, "If I might be so bold, I think you made the right decision." That was his applause line. And he still didn't criticize Florio.
Corzine has imbibed the high-minded scorn for hardscrabble politics that is widespread throughout the educated elite. He doesn't want to lower himself to the muck and mire of attack and counterattack, as Bill Clinton did with such shameless bravura in 1992 and as Al Gore began to do this winter. Corzine, who is a thoughtful and supremely decent man, might make an excellent senator; but he may not want the job enough to do what needs to be done to get it. Five hundred years ago, Machiavelli wrote that Italy needed a good man who is willing to act badly. He could have been talking about New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Digital Commerce;
The Internet relieson networks' passing data to one another. But what happens if one of them refuses?

BYLINE: By Denise Caruso 

 BODY:
LAST week's Web site attacks were a vivid reminder that technology's sword of individual empowerment has a wicked double edge. But the term for the attack technique -- denial of service -- has the potential to assume an equally ominous meaning as telecommunications giants continue to merge their large holdings.
As we know, the Internet is a network of networks. In the beginning of its commercial ascendancy in 1995, this meant that the largest of the Internet service companies -- known as backbone providers -- had to interconnect with their competitors. 
 Using the network access points, or NAP's, that were formerly financed by the federal government, they built businesses delivering data among networks. And in the early days, not much more than a handshake between backbone engineers was needed to ensure that these companies would pass along one another's data, all for the greater good (and growth) of the market.
This "you scratch mine, I'll scratch yours" arrangement is known as peering.
"The assumption in the old days was always, 'I'm going to send you as much data as you send me,' " says David Farber, one of the scientists who helped build the original Arpanet -- the Internet progenitor -- and who is now the chief technologist at the Federal Communications Commission.
And when the two main NAP's became impossibly clogged with traffic, the busiest Internet service providers, or I.S.P.'s, formed private peering arrangements to interconnect and exchange data directly with one another.
The global Internet is still defined by the exchange of data between networks. But today, in place of back-scratchy handshakes are book-size contracts drawn up by phalanxes of corporate lawyers.
The backbone provider with by far the largest number of physical connections is UUNET, now owned by MCI Worldcom, which is on its way to becoming Worldcom Sprint. In rough descending order, UUNET is followed by Sprint; Cable and Wireless USA, which acquired MCI Internet as a result of the 1998 MCI-Worldcom merger; GTE Internetworking (after its acquisition of BBN Planet in 1997) and, depending on whom you ask, either PSI Net or AT&T Network Services.
According to prevailing wisdom, a peer is a backbone service provider that agrees to exchange roughly equivalent amounts of data with another provider without requiring that money change hands.
But how exactly does one become a peer? Under what circumstances is a peer a paying customer, and vice versa? Who decides, and how?
"There are no rules for peering," says Fred Goldstein, a network and information technology consultant with Arthur D. Little in Cambridge, Mass. "No one knows what the currency is. It's more a matter of, 'I'll see who blinks first.' "
One might consider this to be an overly loose arrangement upon which to base the New Global Economy.
In the early days of the Internet, self-interest forced backbone providers into peering. Back then, as Mr. Farber says, "without the exchange points, nobody would have any traffic."
But that is scarcely true today. It may be even less true tomorrow: upon completion of the Worldcom-Sprint merger, a single company would control nearly half of the Internet's backbone -- making it, literally and figuratively, without peer.
Given the furious pace and high stakes of the telecommunications industry today, some fear that it is only a matter of time before one big backbone provider or another refuses to exchange data traffic with one of its peers.
What happens then?
"Well, they would have a legitimate excuse," says Hal Varian, dean of the school of information management at the University of California at Berkeley. "An I.S.P. could complain, and rightly so, that another I.S.P. was sending them huge amounts of traffic and putting a load on their system."
But then, Mr. Varian says, they could also decrease the capacity of "their side of the network so their own traffic is getting swamped." "That's an excuse to say, 'We can't handle this guy's packets; we aren't going to connect with him,' " he added.
The problem, says Mr. Varian, is that there is no way to prove who is zooming whom and no way to resolve such disputes outside the courtroom. And remarkably, there is no rule that requires peers to provide this most basic function of the Internet: what he calls "fair, open and nondiscriminatory" interconnection.
Indeed, says John Nakahata, a partner with the law firm Harris Wiltshire & Grannis in Washington, the kinds of tactics Mr. Varian describes are what led to requirements for interconnections and rate regulations in the telephone world of yore.
Mr. Nakahata is the former chief of staff for the F.C.C. chairman, William E. Kennard, and was the senior legal adviser to Mr. Kennard's predecessor, Reed E. Hundt. Mr. Nakahata now represents one of the smaller backbone providers living in the shadow of the proposed Worldcom-Sprint merger.
"The Internet is growing tremendously quickly, thus competition is very fragile," he says. "If a company can start diverting growth through these different tactics, then it becomes a self-perpetuating cycle."
It is easy to fear the worst, for example, when one sees from public filings that Sprint's original merger application to the F.C.C. did not include a mention of its Internet backbone business. Because the F.C.C. would not accept the application without that information, Sprint has since amended and resubmitted it.
"We had already stated to Justice we'd be willing to do a divestiture if necessary," says J. Richard Devlin, Sprint's general counsel, explaining the omission. The company is now in premerger discussions with the Justice Department about peering and other Internet-related issues, "helping them understand the market," Mr. Devlin said.
Despite the unsettled state of affairs, backbone regulation is not yet on the table for discussion.
"My general attitude toward regulation is that you let things go until they require adult supervision," says Mr. Farber of the F.C.C. "In Japanese, the idea translates to 'the sacred sword of last resort.' That's exactly it; that's its proper place."
In other words, Mr. Farber says, "If you can't get companies to behave in their own self-interest -- and it is good self-interest to have a vibrant, growing Internet; none of these companies would exist if there wasn't one -- then this sacred sword can be used if necessary."
Growth in the Internet economy depends on robust competition. That is a fact that many companies, particularly network companies, which live and die by scale, conveniently seem to forget after their urge to merge creates a behemoth or two.
"The natural structure in this industry is for there to be only a few backbone providers," Mr. Varian says. "The challenge is to see that there are more than one."

AT&T's Consumer Chief Is Expected to Resign
H. Eugene Lockhart, president of the core consumer unit at AT&T, intends to step down barely a year after joining the company, executives close to the company said.
Mr. Lockhart's future plans are unclear. His departure would probably not be seen as a significant operational blow to AT&T. But it could raise questions about the ability of C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman, to identify and retain key executive talent. Page C2. 

Beardstown Ladies Go to Court
Courts in New York and California have made diametrically opposing judgments in lawsuits that challenge dust-jacket claims on the "The Beardstown Ladies' Common-Sense Investment Guide." The guide claimed returns from the ladies' investment approach that were much higher than actual returns. The publisher now faces several legal challenges stemming from those claims. Those suits, and others like them, question whether some of the standard puffery on a book jacket amounts to free speech protected by the First Amendment. C15.
 
Zagat to Announce Investment
Zagat Survey, the restaurant guides published by Tim and Nina Zagat, in a bid to expand into cyberspace, intends to announce today that it has sold a $31 million equity stake to a group that includes some of the digital economy's most prominent individuals and institutional investors. C17.
 
World Bank to Form Internet Fund
The World Bank's International Finance Corporation unit will announce today that it has teamed up with Softbank of Japan to create a $200 million fund that will finance Internet start-ups in 100 developing countries. C6.
 
A New Season for Gift Certificates
Companies that sell gift certificates online report that weekly revenues, so far this year, are actually increasing, despite the fact that postholiday sales to consumers have leveled off. The companies are apparently benefiting from the nation's labor shortage: As companies struggle to attract and retain workers, many are turning to corporate gift programs -- and online gift certificates, they say, are a cheap and easy way to award perks. C12.
 
Teligent-Mannesmann Deal Seen
The American company Teligent, a leader in providing high-capacity communications links using wireless technology, intends to announce today that it has formed a partnership with a unit of Mannesmann of Germany, executives close to the deal said. C2.

HEADLINE: World Bank Unit to Join In Internet Start-Up Finance

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
The Internet, with English as its dominant language and the United States its dominant backer and beneficiary, has created a digital divide, with some poor nations watching from afar as the World Wide Web transforms commerce and creates vast new sources of wealth in the developed countries.
One of the first major efforts to bridge the gap is to be announced today in Tokyo. The World Bank's International Finance Corporation unit has teamed up with Softbank of Japan to create a $200 million fund that will finance Internet start-ups in 100 developing countries. The International Finance Corporation will also join Softbank's existing plan to invest $300 million in Internet companies in China and Latin America, bringing the total amount they are devoting to third world Internet development to $500 million. 
 The new venture, named Softbank Emerging Markets, will provide seed capital to entrepreneurs building Internet businesses in poor countries. It will also seek to transfer successful e-commerce business models and train managers to apply them, World Bank officials said.
"The digital divide is one of the greatest impediments to development, and it is growing exponentially," the World Bank's president, James D. Wolfensohn, said in a statement. "We are taking a lead in the effort to close the gap. This investment will accelerate the inclusion of the developing countries in the information revolution."
Softbank is one of the most successful backers of Internet businesses in the United States. It has provided seed capital for Yahoo, E*Trade and Buy.com, among others. The International Finance Corporation is the for-profit investment banking arm of the World Bank, the Washington-based institution that aims to promote economic development in poor countries.
Softbank Emerging Markets, based in Silicon Valley, plans to make its first investments this spring. In addition to providing capital, the fund will become a joint venture partner with companies it finances. Some back-office and strategic planning services will be centralized in Silicon Valley, according to a description of the business plan provided by the World Bank and Softbank.

HEADLINE: Taking Virgin's Brand Into Internet Territory;
Richard Branson Says the Web Is Ready for His Style of Business

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 13

 BODY:
Richard Branson was fiddling with one of his new Virgin-branded mobile telephones in the living room of his Notting Hill town house here last week.
"I'm trying to think how it works," he said, staring at a special button on the phone -- a red button, with the Virgin logo. The button connects customers by voice to operators who also handle distribution for the Virgin.com Web site. With such a call, customers can order plane tickets, CD's and an assortment of other products at a discount that Mr. Branson usually hawks by nondigital means. After trying fitfully to explain the red-button function, he finally conceded that he wasn't sure how it worked, and gave up. 
 "I was one of those anti-mobile phone guys before we did Virgin Mobile," he explained, referring to the cellular phone service that he started in November and that has already signed up 300,000 subscribers.
Hands-on technical savvy or not, Mr. Branson is diving head first into the digital economy. Call it the dot-comming of the Virgin Group P.L.C.
He is the brash, 48-year-old British billionaire, who founded Virgin Atlantic Airways 15 years ago with one jumbo jet plying the London-New York route and who now owns a hodgepodge of more than 200 Virgin-branded businesses. Now he intends to turn his tarmac-and-mortar world into something a bit more virtual.
Having slapped the Virgin logo on planes, trains, soda, vodka, clothing, movie theaters, music stores, a radio station, a financial services company and even a wedding coordinator, Mr. Branson means to expand his year-old Virgin.com Web site into a worldwide e-commerce portal that he hopes will take on some of the qualities of Amazon.com.
The skeptics say he is already too late to the Internet market and will surely stumble. "A lot of traditional businesses have made these kinds of plans and they've never worked out," said Noah Yasskin, an analyst at Jupiter Communications in London.
But Mr. Branson sees himself as specially suited for an entrepreneurial leap onto the Web.
For one thing, unlike Amazon.com -- which began as a book distributor and is now a diversified digital middleman -- the Virgin Group has many of its own products to sell. That doesn't mean, though, that Mr. Branson plans to hold his Web customers hostage to the Virgin brand.
"If British Airways is selling better products than Virgin Atlantic, we'll sell the British Airways product," he said. "If Fidelity is offering a better financial product than Virgin Direct, we'll recommend the Fidelity product."
Mr. Branson says he will not get snagged on the sticking point that has caused other brand-name companies to stumble on their way to cyberspace -- the fear of cannibalizing the established offline brands. "It's a fact of life," he said, "that the Internet will kill off some of our business and severely damage a lot of conventional industry."
And then there's the matter of management and money, which in the case of the privately held Virgin Group resides chiefly in one man: Richard Branson, boss and banker, rolled into one -- even if he does have big money men as personal investors.
Having sold 49 percent of his Virgin Atlantic unit to Singapore Airlines for $965 million right before Christmas, Mr. Branson has cash to burn. And unlike most dot-com's, he notes, his money is real -- not the paper wealth of newly minted Internet stock.
But whatever the advantages Mr. Branson describes, Virgin is entering the Internet arena too late to claim the "first mover" edge that Web executives like.
Mr. Yasskin, the Jupiter analyst, says that most of the major sectors of the World Wide Web are already carved up by companies like Yahoo and Amazon.com. "At least in the U.S. market, Virgin will have a very hard time competing," he said, adding that outside the United States "Virgin still has a little time to grab some market share."
For his part, Mr. Branson maintains that the Virgin brand is so strong internationally -- the company is already Britain's biggest advertiser -- that his relatively late Internet move will not hurt his chances. In fact, he said his timing might present an advantage.
"We have not lost hundreds of millions of pounds on the Net in the few years the Net was developing," he said, a not-so-veiled reference to companies like Amazon.com that have spent and lost large amounts of money building their clientele. "Our approach is to come on the Net when the amount of people who are logging on to the Net are considerable, and where we can actually see real profits reasonably quickly."
His remarks may be self-serving, but for Mr. Branson and his privately held company, it is crucial to quickly turn a profit. Otherwise, he may find it necessary to relinquish some control over the Virgin Group by raising money in the public stock market -- in order to compete for big-time capital with the likes of Amazon.
While he says that an initial public offering is on his mind, he has no immediate plans for one, predicting that he can break into the European Internet market without a major cash outlay for a brand-building campaign. But the United States market is another matter.
"In America we're well ahead in the major cities," he said of Virgin's brand recognition. "But out in the sticks, we've still got some way to go. America will be the toughest nut to crack. We will have to spend big bucks in America."
Unlike many of the Internet pioneers who have paid handsomely to simply get their name out, Virgin already has dozens of branded products to help keep its name in the public eye. Mr. Branson said, for example, that he intends to have "Virgin.com" painted onto the sides of his planes in place of the "No Way BA/AA" slogan that has adorned Virgin's fleet since his nemesis, British Airways, announced an abortive plan for a far-reaching alliance with American Airlines.
Without the dot-com money of a publicly traded company, Mr. Branson seeks attention for himself and his company in ways beyond paid advertising. Virgin generates press releases on an almost daily basis, and he is not above publicity stunts like the Virgin Mobile rollout in November. Creating a stir widely chronicled in the British tabloids, he held a parade of sorts in the West End of London, riding a float on which he surrounded himself with nude models talking on Virgin Mobile phones. The slogan for the new company: "What you see is what you get."
He also primes the publicity pump by making himself freely available for interviews. "It's cheaper than buying a full-page ad in The New York Times," he joked.
Still, wielding his brand identity against Internet upstarts is one thing. Taking on one of Europe's fasting-growing communications powers is another. And that is precisely the collision course he has set for himself with Virgin Mobile, a joint venture with the Deutsche Telekom unit One2One. Despite its 300,000 subscribers in Britain, Virgin Mobile will be up against a combined 42 million European subscribers of Vodafone AirTouch and Mannesmann, which announced plans for the biggest industrial merger ever the week before last.
Mr. Branson predicts that Virgin Mobile will be able to gain ground on Vodafone when the licensing begins this spring for Britain's next generation of wireless telephones -- digital devices that are to combine voice, Internet access and other digital features. Toward that end, he has put together a group of investors that include the Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen and the venture capitalist George Soros.
But again, Mr. Branson may be a bit late, some contend. "It's going to take Virgin years to build a network," Mr. Yasskin said. "And by the time they do, they will have missed the huge growth period. Anyway, the incumbents always have an advantage."
Mr. Branson nonetheless says that he will be able to compete with established players like Vodafone. "There is no reason we can't offer anything that Vodafone can," he said. "We will by no means be as big as them, but we will have a slice of the market."
All of his businesses that have succeeded so far have done so by carving out a niche in a mainstream industry by emphasizing service and style -- whether it be Virgin Atlantic, with its interactive movie and game system in every seat in economy class, or Virgin Bride, a one-stop shop for weddings.
Virgin's philosophy, Mr. Branson said, is to improve upon established businesses by adding a Virginesque sensibility.
With Virgin Mobile, for example, he is taking the unusual step of giving away an earpiece with a built-in microphone with each of the company's mobile phones, so users do not have to hold them to their heads.
"A friend of mine got a brain tumor, and before he died we had dinner and he said his surgeon was convinced that using a mobile phone may have been a factor," Mr. Branson said, raising a product-liability specter that the head of a public company might be likely to suppress.
And the Virgin Web site will cater to Mr. Branson's digital naivete. "Any jargon that I don't understand" will be stripped out, he said. "I assume that I am representative of the vast majority of the people out there."
That thinking may explain why for Mr. Branson -- who in the past has attempted a solo, round-the-world balloon flight and who owns an island in the Caribbean -- taking his business onto the Internet does not seem as as much fun as some of his previous endeavors.
"It doesn't excite me in the same way that starting Virgin Atlantic did," he admitted. "It's because I could deal with people. And with the Internet, you're one step removed from the people."

HEADLINE: At Edges of Elian's Spotlight Are Other Divided Families

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
Lazara Brito and her three children huddled over the kitchen table in their Havana apartment on a recent day and thumbed through a pile of letters and drawings. These scraps of paper have been the only physical link to Ms. Brito's husband, Jose Cohen, who left Cuba on a raft in 1994 and has been waiting in vain for them to join him in Miami.
"The important thing in life is not what you know or who you know," Ms. Brito read from one letter, "but who you are." 
 That may be the cause of her family's plight, since her husband used to work for the Ministry of the Interior gathering intelligence on foreign investors interested in doing business in Cuba. And so the government considers him a deserter, or worse.
Although Ms. Brito and her children have had United States visas since 1998, she said the Cuban government had retaliated against her husband by not allowing them to emigrate and subjecting them to harassment and intimidation.
The Cohens are among hundreds of Cuban families stuck in a limbo of politics and bureaucracy, holding travel documents that remain useless without exit visas from the government. Many of them had become even more frustrated over the situation in recent months as they watched the daily Cuban protests demanding the return of Elian Gonzalez to his father in Cuba.
"It has been almost six years since he left," Ms. Brito said of her husband. "Since then, the whole family has felt the full rancor of the officials. I see all the worry over the child Elian and I ask, where is the love for my children, because for six years my children have been paying for the rancor against my husband."
State Department officials had no exact figures on how many families were being kept apart, but they said that last year approximately 1,700 people with valid travel documents for the United States were unable to leave Cuba.
For some, like the Cohens, the delay is political. Many are held up by what foreign diplomats said were excessive Cuban fees for medical exams and administrative costs -- as much as $1,000 a person in an economy in which the average salary is $10 a month. Other cases languish because a noncustodial parent refuses to give permission for his child to leave the country, or because the would-be immigrant is a professional who must first fulfill a work commitment in return for education.
"It is a big aspect of this whole Cuban trauma," said Max Castro, a senior research analyst at the University of Miami. "This is a good moment to reflect on it and for the various parties to be more consistent. There is no doubt that the Cuban government in the past has not been as solicitous as it is now on the issue of family unification."
Mr. Cohen, who now lives in a suburb north of Miami and runs an Internet business, said in an interview: "The regime gives you no option but to be with them or against them. People ask me, did I not know what would happen? Yes. But I did not know the regime would have such a strong reprisal."
Since her family obtained the United States visas, Ms. Brito said, she has written direct appeals to Fidel Castro and other high-ranking officials, asking that her children not be forced to pay for their father's actions. All she has had in return, she said, are letters saying her pleas have been sent to other government agencies.
Once, several years ago, security agents roused her from bed, searched her apartment and, as her children and another relative watched, whisked her off to jail for two days. One of her daughters found a note under the front door that said: "You will never leave. Forget it."
More recently, Ms. Brito's younger daughter, Yamila, 13, was sent from her school to take part in one of the large public rallies the government organized to call for Elian's return. Her older daughter, Yanelis, who is now 16, was asked to leave school last year when administrators discovered she had a visa for the United States.
Cuban officials said they had not forced anyone to leave Cuba, so they could not be accused of splitting up families. Ricardo Alarcon, the leader of Cuba's National Assembly, said the Cohen case involved a political defector who knew what he was doing.
"I imagine he left his children here," he said. "Nobody took them away from him. He left them here."
State Department officials said the delays were a continuing topic during the regular migration talks they held with their Cuban counterparts. They are also raised in individual complaints lodged by American diplomats in Havana, who seldom receive answers.
"It can be a long time," said one State Department official familiar with several cases. "It sort of compounds the tragedy, too, because when these people go to apply for exit permits, they lose their jobs, or their kids have problems getting into college preparatory schools."
That was what Estella Natal, a language teacher in New York, discovered while waiting for her Cuban husband, Joel Prince, a doctor, to join her. She had met Dr. Prince on a trip to Cuba in 1996, and they married two years later. At the time he was working as a prison doctor.
"He was fired from that job days after we were married," Ms. Natal said. "Then he got a job doing medical surveys, then at a neighborhood clinic and then as a paramedic. The thing is, a lot of places do not want to hire him or he does not get good training because they know he is going to leave eventually. So, he gets the leftover jobs."
Ms. Natal said her husband might have to work for several more years before he would be allowed to leave. She added that recent appointments he had been given to process his documents had been postponed because workers at the immigration office had to attend the public rallies for Elian.
"This whole custody battle is hampering everything," she said. "It's not just Elian. Elian is a symbol for the rest of us. He is really a symbol of families being divided, of a lot of politics coming between families."
That symbolism was the impetus for a recently formed Miami exile group, New Generation Cuba, which includes Mr. Cohen among its founders. The group, which portrays itself as a mix of American- and Cuban-raised exiles, met with State Department officials recently to press the cases of 14 separated families.
The group's leaders said they knew of about 200 cases, but had yet to document them all. They said some other families were reluctant to have contact with the group because they feared reprisals against relatives in Cuba.
"Fidel Castro has separated families for 41 years through death and bureaucracy," said Bettina Rodriguez Aguilera, the group's president, whose own father was imprisoned in Cuba for 14 years while she was growing up in the United States. "The only person destroying families in and out of Cuba is Fidel Castro."
But some political analysts said that while family unification was an important issue, it was different from the issue in the Elian Gonzalez case. In the boy's case, they say, the issue is the rights of a surviving parent rather than the political control of immigration.
"There is a relation, but they are not identical," said Mr. Castro of the University of Miami. "There is reason to question the Cuban government on these cases and ask them to reflect and be consistent on their view of families."
But he also said that efforts like those of New Generation Cuba appeared to be hastily organized and that the group risked losing credibility if it was seen as manipulating Elian's plight for political purposes.
"They are taking a real issue and using it in a way that may be more of a disservice to the cause because it is taken as something very opportunistic," Mr. Castro said. "It should be a continuing conversation and a demand, not something that is all of a sudden deployed."
But for Mr. Cohen's family, there is a sense of hope that someone has taken up their cause. In the family's spartan apartment -- Ms. Brito started giving away their belongings in anticipation of a move -- his children practice English, just as their father asks them to in his letters.
"I am far from you now," he wrote in English to Yanelis, his oldest daughter. "But my soul is with you and you are in my heart." He added in Spanish, "Learn this."
Yanelis said, but in Spanish: "Once we are together, that will be the greatest. Here we are feeling different from all the others because we do not have the family that all human beings want. We ask, when will it reach the hearts of those men who stop us from being with our father?"

HEADLINE: Council Democrats Plan To Dare a Giuliani Veto

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
Over the next few weeks, Democrats in the City Council, led by Speaker Peter F. Vallone, are planning to approve a barrage of legislative initiatives that have been strongly opposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, all but daring the mayor to use his veto powers.
In pushing the bills, some of which have been in committee for years, the Democratic majority in the Council is deliberately putting itself on a collision course with Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, at a time when he is eager to portray himself as collaborative and well suited to the United States Senate. 
 Democrats, including some Council members and Mr. Giuliani's Senate campaign opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, have been just as eager to portray him otherwise: as an angry autocrat who would be out of place in the Senate, where political compromise is essential.
The administration maintains that Mr. Giuliani's success as a Republican mayor in a heavily Democratic city is evidence that he can work cooperatively.
But the Council's legislative blitz also reflects a changed political landscape. As Mr. Giuliani runs for Senate and Mr. Vallone prepares to run for mayor next year, the interests of the city's two most powerful officials have diverged sharply and policy differences between them have become more stark.
Among the Council initiatives are bills that would establish grievance procedures for workfare participants and create a new transitional jobs program, change some rules that govern the city's public markets and begin an intense voter registration drive.
Council officials said they were left with no choice but to challenge the mayor head-on. "It's out of frustration with negotiating in good faith for the last six or seven months and coming up nowhere," said Bruce R. Bender, Mr. Vallone's chief of staff.
Supporters say the bills would protect workfare recipients from losing benefits over petty disputes, offer a strong mechanism for job training and bring more equity to public markets, including the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx.
But Mr. Giuliani has expressed outspoken opposition to most of the measures, calling the grievance procedures unnecessary, the transitional jobs program a reversal of welfare reform, and the public markets bill an effort to soften his stance against organized crime.
And one senior mayoral aide charged yesterday that the coordinated action on the bills had been orchestrated by Harold M. Ickes, the former White House deputy chief of staff who is Mrs. Clinton's top political adviser and also a paid political consultant for the City Council.
Council officials rejected the charge, saying the bills were good government policy and pointing out that the measures had been in the works long before anyone knew who was running for Senate. And, they said, the measures have been amended to address some of the mayor's objections.
Senior Council officials said yesterday that they were still hoping to reach a deal with the mayor, but that they were committed to the legislation and were prepared to override a veto if necessary. Giuliani administration officials declined to speculate on whether the mayor would issue any vetoes, saying they doubted the the bills would even come out of committee.
But the administration officials did not react with the vehement anger toward the Council that they had expressed in the past, suggesting that Mr. Giuliani was not looking for a fight and that they might be willing to talk. The question is whether the Council will give them time.
Council hearings on the bills are scheduled this week -- transitional jobs tomorrow in the General Welfare Committee, workfare grievance on Wednesday in the Governmental Operations Committee and public markets on Thursday in the Economic Development Committee.
All three hearings are timed to allow the committees to approve the bills and get them on the agenda for votes by the entire Council at its next full meeting on Feb. 29. Several Council officials said they expected the bills to pass with the support of Mr. Vallone.
Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, a Brooklyn Democrat who has been heavily involved in supporting all three measures, said of the mayor's past opposition: "We are attempting to move good strong pieces of legislation, and if his lack of cooperation or his trumpeting of his cooperation with us has forced our hand -- well, be careful what you wish for. He has no one to blame but himself."
And while a fight with the Council might bode ill for Mr. Giuliani's Senate campaign, one administration official suggested that the transitional jobs bill could do just as little for Mr. Vallone's mayoral ambitions.
"It is hard to believe why a moderate Democrat like Peter Vallone, the odds-on favorite to be the next full-term mayor, would support a bill that would reverse the welfare reform that New York City has experienced," a senior mayoral adviser said. "He should be embracing the welfare reforms."
There are other political implications. The grievance procedures and the transitional jobs program are strongly favored by labor unions, whose support Mr. Vallone courted when he ran for governor in 1998 and will need again to win the Democratic primary when he runs for mayor.
Mr. Giuliani, however, expects little or no support from local labor unions in the Senate race and is facing a series of contentious contract negotiations later this year.
The result of this sort of conflicting interests has been a cooling of the political relationship between the mayor and the speaker, making negotiations increasingly difficult.
In 1998, when Mr. Vallone ran for governor, politics similarly intruded on the operations of city government and for the first time in modern history the mayor and the Council failed to reach a deal on the city budget. The Council approved the budget over the mayor's veto, leading to a court battle.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Diplomat Picks Up the Pieces of Austria's Broken Image

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
DESPITE the diplomat's smile, the fatigue showed on the face of Ambassador Peter Moser, Austria's representative to the United States, the lack of sleep etched beneath his eyes.
He had been up since 4 a.m., just as he had every morning for most of the last two weeks, making urgent telephone calls to the Foreign Ministry in Vienna. He dispatched his wife to her sister's home in New York, knowing that it would be impossible to find time for her for days. 
 "This is a nightmare," he said of what has gone on since Feb. 4, with the swearing-in of a new government that includes the far-right Freedom Party led by Jorg Haider, who has praised policies of Austria's Nazi rulers in World War II. "You think of the job of a diplomat as a dream under usual circumstances," Mr. Moser said. "Well, what is going on now is the reverse.
"It does not feel real. It is surreal."
Every day the embassy's mailbag bulges with scores of letters from Americans condemning Austria; some are filled with obscenities. "There are serious letters, and then others are just offensive," said Mr. Moser, a 58-year-old career diplomat. "Maybe people get a personal relief if they call us names."
The creation of a coalition government that includes Mr. Haider's party has turned Austria into a pariah within the 15-nation European Union, which has severed routine contacts with Vienna. The Clinton administration has protested by withdrawing the American ambassador, and Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, has been warning of the possible emergence of "the extreme hateful right" in Europe.
The crisis has forced Ambassador Moser to dive into the whirlpool of Washington's 24-hour news cycle, as he tries to convince Americans, and the large foreign press corps based here, that Austria is being unfairly tarred.
In the last 10 days, he has appeared on CNN and on PBS's "NewsHour," as well as at a news conference on Friday at the National Press Club, the first solo news conference in Mr. Moser's 33-year career in the Austrian diplomatic service.
"Haider is not Austria, and Austria is not Haider," he said at the press club in an awkward effort to distance the people of Austria from the government that they put in place -- and that he must now represent.
He insisted that although the Freedom Party might be xenophobic, it was not fascist, and that while Mr. Haider might be an opportunist prone to outrageous remarks (praise for Nazi labor policies and for SS veterans), he was not a Nazi. "We from the diplomatic establishment have to walk behind him, after him, and pick up the pieces," Mr. Moser said.
Later, in his embassy office, Mr. Moser slowly sipped from a glass of water. Behind his desk was a stack of papers, topped by a book by Mr. Haider outlining his right-wing politics. On the cover is a photo of the well-tanned, carefully coiffed politician, who could easily pass for an American television anchorman.
"It was given to me," Mr. Moser said. "I don't think I will read it." He resisted an appraisal of Mr. Haider's character. "My personal feelings, I am not being paid for," he said.
Trying to salvage Austria's reputation was certainly not the assignment Mr. Moser expected when he arrived in Washington last year. His initial goal, he said, was to expand trade and to encourage Americans to think of his nation of eight million people as the economic hub of central Europe.
"I'm very sad and sorry because what we built up over the years is now being questioned," he said of Austria's efforts to portray itself as a peace-loving member of the European community, and to distance itself from its Nazi past, when Austria embraced German rule under the Austrian-born Hitler.
He said it was unfair to single out Austria for condemnation when parties similar to Mr. Haider's exist across Europe and could, like the Freedom Party, enter government someday soon. "One day they will wake up and find that they have similar problems," he said. "All of these remarks of Haider, which remember the Nazi history, are a wonderful instrument to distract attention from this fact."
He does not deny that his job is made more difficult by the perception that Austria is unwilling to confront its history, a view that grew stronger outside Austria after voters elected Kurt Waldheim president in 1986 despite revelations about his service in Hitler's army. "Yes, I think there are many people -- not only in the Freedom Party, but many, particularly older people -- who have not done this process of atonement," Mr. Moser conceded.
THE ambassador could be considered another victim of the war. He never knew his father, an Austrian soldier in the German Army, who was sent off to the front two days after his only child was born in Vienna in June 1941. His father was killed in 1943.
Mr. Moser did well in school and entered Austria's diplomatic academy in 1965. His career as a diplomat has taken him to posts as diverse as New Delhi, Seoul and Sofia. His favorite posting was in Los Angeles, where he was consul general from 1979 to 1985. "We lived in a house with a swimming pool in a wonderful neighborhood," he said.
But the carefree sunshine of Southern California is far from his thoughts as Mr. Moser rushes through Washington's winter chill from one interview to another, trying to limit the damage to Austria's reputation.
"When the dust settles," he said, "it will be a lot of work for us to get back what we have lost."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Tries to Soothe Concerns of Sharpton

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE and JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Seeking to solidify his support among black New Yorkers, Vice President Al Gore met yesterday for the first time with the Rev. Al Sharpton and received the endorsement of the Rev. Floyd B. Flake, a former congressman and now the pastor of a prominent African-American church in Queens.
The two sessions began a week-long drive by the vice president to highlight his support among blacks, which is derived in large part from his association with President Clinton. And they are signs of an accelerated strategy from a campaign increasingly confident that the Democratic presidential nomination is within Mr. Gore's grasp. 
 But the two sessions differed markedly in style, reflecting caution on Mr. Gore's part after his buzz-saw encounter with New York's ethnic politics in his failed 1988 presidential bid. He was open and voluble with Mr. Flake, prancing up and down the aisles of Mr. Flake's church, but met with Mr. Sharpton in private.
A buoyant Mr. Gore, with microphone in hand and a choir behind him, addressed hundreds of congregants at Mr. Flake's church, the Allen A.M.E. church in southeast Queens. He referred to the Scripture and he raced up and down the aisles asking the people how many years they had been married and how many grandchildren they had.
Then he heard these surprising words from the pastor himself:
"I don't do endorsements from across the pulpit because I never know who's out there watching the types of laws that govern separation of church and state," Mr. Flake said, draped in a flowing, gold-embroidered white robe and standing next to the blue-suited Mr. Gore. "But I will say to you this morning, and you read it well: this should be the next president of the United States."
Just a week before, Mr. Flake had been host to Mr. Gore's sole rival, former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, and given him a warm welcome but no endorsement.
 Mr. Flake's embrace of Mr. Gore was significant because of the influence of Mr. Flake and his church within the black middle class. Mr. Flake joins many of New York's other black leaders, including Representative Charles B. Rangel and state comptroller H. Carl McCall, in backing Mr. Gore over Mr. Bradley.
But not on that list of endorsees, at least so far, is Mr. Sharpton, whose meeting with Mr. Gore was hidden from public view. Some of Mr. Gore's top staff were not even aware of the meeting, while others, including Donna Brazile, Mr. Gore's campaign manager, were arranging it and then attended the session, which lasted about an hour and took place at the East Side apartment of Karenna Gore Schiff, Mr. Gore's oldest daughter.
The press corps that normally follows Mr. Gore were told by aides that the meeting with Mr. Sharpton was not happening and that his visit to his daughter's apartment was strictly personal.
While Mr. Sharpton said in an interview afterward that he had not yet decided whom he might endorse, he said the discussion with the vice president had been "extremely positive" and that the meeting "included a frank and honest discussion of the concerns of the people in the areas that we come from."
"Although we don't agree on everything, he showed a willingness to talk and a willingness to listen," Mr. Sharpton said. "I was impressed with a lot of what he had to say."
Mr. Sharpton has been urged by supporters of both candidates to make an endorsement. He initially considered supporting Mr. Bradley but came under pressure from political leaders like the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, who urged him to endorse the vice president (although Mr. Jackson has yet to make an endorsement).
Yesterday's meeting followed some tension between Mr. Sharpton and the Gore campaign. A week ago, Mr. Sharpton complained that he had perceived indifference from the vice president's campaign on racial issues. And he said Mr. Gore needed to make amends with blacks in New York over his 1988 presidential campaign. That year, Mr. Gore was competing against Mr. Jackson, among others, and during the New York primary Mr. Gore's ally, Mayor Edward I. Koch, was engaged in an ugly public feud with Mr. Jackson.
Gore advisers said the campaign wanted to acknowledge Mr. Sharpton's influence as a political leader but hesitated to fully legitimize him. Mr. Gore has a horror of getting entangled in New York's local political cross-currents, and did not ask Mr. Sharpton for his endorsement. Nor did Mr. Sharpton offer it.
But the two -- along with Ms. Brazile, Roberto Ramirez, the Democratic Party chairman in the Bronx, and Eric Eve, Mr. Gore's New York campaign manager -- discussed several matters concerning economic development in heavily black areas, including access to media ownership, Gore aides said.
Mr. Sharpton did ask Mr. Gore to hold a debate with Mr. Bradley on minority issues, Mr. Sharpton and Gore aides said. A week earlier, Mr. Sharpton had hinted that he would encourage black voters to support Mr. Bradley unless such a debate took place. Mr. Gore noted that the campaigns had already agreed to a debate at the Apollo Theater in Harlem on Feb. 21.
Mr. Gore's events in New York yesterday marked the beginning of a week aimed squarely at black voters, who make up one of the party's most reliable core constituencies. Mr. Gore's campaign has always perceived the black vote as its insurance policy or "fire wall" if Mr. Gore stumbled in the early primaries.
The fact that the Gore campaign is making a major pitch to black voters now, before the collection of primaries on March 7, is a clear sign of the Gore camp's growing confidence.
The schedule tells much of the story. The vice president is planning a string of events in heavily black areas of the country.
He is to speak about education at Medgar Evars College in Brooklyn today. On Tuesday in Baltimore, he plans to address the economic plight of blacks in the information age. That night he begins a southern swing through North Carolina, Macon, Ga., New Orleans, Jackson, Miss., St. Louis, Cleveland and Springfield, Mass.
Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York is to travel with Mr. Gore in the state today and endorse him.

HEADLINE: Owners to Scale Back Ratner's, a Lower East Side Landmark

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Ratner's may not be dead, but to some customers, after hearing the owners' plans for the nearly century-old Lower East Side landmark restaurant, it may as well be.
The Delancey Street kosher dairy restaurant, a virtual time capsule of the neighborhood's Jewish roots, will close in May for a three-month, $1 million renovation. 
 But just as old-timers lament that the Delancey Street neighborhood will never be the same, neither will the new Ratner's.
For one thing, it will be about half its size -- shrinking to about 100 seats. The other half will go to the Lansky Lounge, the backroom nightclub also owned by the Harmatz family, which has run Ratner's since 1905.
The nearly three-year-old lounge, named for the 1930's gangster Meyer Lansky, who dined at a back table in what is now the club, caters to the young, urban and hip who have made the neighborhood something of a hot spot.
But what most troubles some of Ratner's fans is the prospect that it may no longer be kosher -- a rabbi in the kitchen oversees food preparation -- or honor the Sabbath by closing sundown Friday to sundown Saturday, as it has done for 10 years. Fred Harmatz, who owns the restaurant with his brother Robert -- their grandfather Jacob Harmatz founded it with his brother-in-law Morris Ratner -- said yesterday that they would decide by spring whether to make such changes, which would allow the lounge to open Friday nights and expand its liquor offerings to include nonkosher drinks.
The restaurant has been kosher since it opened and began honoring the sabbath a decade ago. But a few years ago, business from Orthodox Jews began dropping off and the nightclub grew in popularity, Mr. Harmatz said. "This neighborhood is becoming young," he said. "Friday is a big bar night."
Ratner's still draws a big Sunday brunch crowd, but business during the week is half what it was just five years ago, he said.
Mr. Harmatz said simple economics may dictate the change. "It's the bottom line," he said.
In another five years or so, he said, the restaurant may close for good.
