HEADLINE: Britain's Health Care, and Ours

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Feb. 10 front-page article about Britain's National Health Service didn't mention a key factor in the difficulties faced by Jackie O'Donnell, a British cancer patient who had to pay for chemotherapy out of her own pocket. It was the pharmaceutical company that supplied the drug she needed, using the monopoly conferred by patent protection, that set the price at $16,000.
Similar practices have priced AIDS therapy beyond the reach of most of the world. Less critical is the situation in which recent billion-dollar drugs for less severe conditions are in the "blockbuster" category because of high protected prices, not the numbers of prescriptions. 
 There may still be some economic limits on how high these prices can be set, but if prescription insurance became universal, the sky would become the limit.
 
ART HILGART
Kalamazoo, Mich., Feb. 10, 2000

HEADLINE: As the Pariah of Europe, Austria Seems Unbowed

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Feb. 13

 BODY:
As a political entity turned pack of would-be toughs, Europe is proving unimpressive; it is slapping Austria around a bit, but is unable to bring it to its diplomatic knees.
France, Belgium and tiny Andorra boycotted a speech here last Thursday by the new Austrian foreign minister. But they stayed to take part in the meeting of the Organization for Cooperation and Security in Europe that she was presiding over. 
 The next day, Austria's new social affairs minister was allowed to attend a meeting on unemployment in Lisbon. But only the host would shake her hand, and the others refused to pose for the usual ministerial family photo.
Later, the German minister seemed to regret his rudeness; the Belgian and French ministers, who also walked out during her speech, reveled in theirs.
The conservative caucus in the European Parliament heard a motion to kick out Austria's People's Party for inviting Mr. Haider's Freedom Party into government with it. But members said the motion would not be voted on until April and had no chance of passing anyway.
Prince Charles postponed a planned summer visit, and the actress Claudia Cardinale said she would not attend the Opera Ball, the height of the Vienna social season. But Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands took her annual Austrian skiing vacation as she has for 30 years.
Belgium theatrically canceled an order for seven Austrian armored cars. But Sweden said it still hoped to sell Austria a squadron of fighter-bombers.
And the French finance minister, a Socialist, may have split the diplomatic hair of the week when he discovered that his Austrian counterpart is from Mr. Haider's party. "I'm not sure I'll be talking much with him," the minister told journalists.
Europe is in a quandary. Fourteen of the continent's foreign ministers threatened to isolate Austria if it let Mr. Haider's xenophobic party into government. Austria promptly called its bluff. Now Europe is divided and confused and falling back largely on bad manners.
"This is an unprecedented situation, and there is no uniform front," said Hans Rauscher, a columnist for Der Standard here. "It's not a massive, concerted action, but it's pretty strong."
Europe is not alone in having divided reactions. Israel's ambassador, the first to leave, is still gone. The American ambassador returned this weekend after the State Department tentatively accepted assurances that Austria would hew to the democratic path. But the Argentine ambassador was just recalled to Buenos Aires for consultations after a letter he wrote last October describing Mr. Haider as neither "an extremist nor a neo-Nazi" but rather "a democrat" was leaked to an Argentine paper.
Mr. Haider has predicted that any censure effort would quickly crumble. He may be proved right. It isn't just smaller European countries like Greece and Denmark that are already skeptical. Even the big powers are subdividing: Bavaria broke with Berlin over isolating its Alpine neighbor and Italy's provinces around Trieste, abutting Austria, criticized Rome.
Also, the union has discovered that it needs to be stable more than it needs to punish. After the euro slipped this week on rumors that Austria might be forced out of the monetary union, the European Union issue a hasty denial that it would impose such a harsh sentence.
And the fight has strengthened anti-Europe forces. Isolationist groups in Switzerland and Denmark have gained ground in opinion polls, citing anger at the drubbing of Austria. Britain's anti-euro conservatives are crowing their we-told-you-sos.
"It is hard to see how the E.U can now get out of the hole that its leaders have dug," Peter Ludlow, the director of the Center for European Policy Studies in Brussels wrote in a scathing essay in Britain's Financial Times this week.
By aggressive posturing, the other European countries "exposed themselves to the risk of a series of humiliating and very public compromises."
Part of the predicament is systemic: The union is bound by treaties, not a constitution, and its important decisions, like a common currency or admitting new members, are made by consensus. It is not a congress, and cannot just freeze out or vote down members. Ministers meet in order to talk.
The other problem is haste. Austria called Europe's bluff so fast that there was no time to plan a response. With careful timing, European ministers might have embarrassed Mr. Haider over weaknesses newly revealed: one of his new cabinet ministers is accused of bankrolling a right-wing paper that denied the Holocaust; another once supposedly said that any businesses that hire more than 10 percent foreigners should not get government contracts. Instead, the Europeans ended up snubbing Elisabeth Sickl, the new social affairs minister, a friendly middle-aged former school principal who says her values are "humanist."
Meanwhile, the foreign media, which for weeks whipped up images of Nazism in Austria, are beginning to turn around and suggest that someone was indulging in hyperbole. For example, the same BBC radio anchorman who on Feb. 1 asked an Austrian theater director if he planned to flee the country (the answer was a puzzled "No") by Feb. 10 was asking a European Union spokesman if his organization had been in the grip of anti-Nazi hysteria (the answer was a defensive "No").
Within Austria itself, protests against the new government, which were buoyed by the European Union response, continue, although with less vigor than in the first days. About 15,000 demonstrators shouting "Resist Racism and Fascism!" marched in Vienna on Saturday. Smaller demonstrations were held in cities throughout the country. Today a discussion at Vienna's main theater about artistic freedom under the new government was packed an hour before it even started.
A march that may be swelled by the trade union allies of the Social Democratic Party, which was forced into opposition by the new ruling coalition, is planned for Feb. 18.
More interesting will be to see what happens when Mr. Haider defies the advice of his party and goes to Brussels on Feb. 17. As governor of Carinthia Province, he is on the European Union committee on regional government.
His advisers urged missing the meeting. But Mr. Haider answered them this week with his characteristic mix of cheek and limelight-love: "I'm not going to cancel my trip just because someone wants to hit me with a tomato."

HEADLINE: Shortage in Clergy Leaves Pulpits Unfilled

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
Congregation B'nai Israel in Hattiesburg, Miss., has been without a rabbi for more than three years. Every other week, a student rabbi flies in from Cincinnati. At other times, congregants lead Sabbath services, run the Sunday school and even conduct funerals.
It is not for lack of effort that the 110-year-old synagogue has failed to attract a rabbi. It has listed its opening with the placement office of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, the Reform movement seminary, since its last rabbi left, and it usually sends a representative to Cincinnati in the spring to recruit at the college. 
 "We go to interview even when no one signs up," said Steve Doblin, president of B'nai Israel and a dean at the University of Southern Mississippi.
The temple's plight is not unusual. Not only are synagogues finding it increasingly difficult to hire clergy members, so too are Roman Catholic and Protestant churches.
In the Roman Catholic Church, according to the National Pastoral Life Center, an independent organization in New York that helps local parishes, the number of parish priests declined by 12 percent from 1992 to 1997, and churches are increasingly relying on lay people.
In the Episcopal Church, "the situation is grave," said the Rev. Hugh Magers, a member of the congregational ministries cluster at the denomination's national headquarters in Manhattan. "As best as I can tell, we have under 300 members of the clergy out of 15,000 who were born after 1964."
In Reform Judaism, about 200 out 895 congregations are without a full-time rabbi. The modern Orthodox wing of Judaism has the same problem.
"There are more jobs open now, due to the growth, thank God, of the Orthodox community, and filling positions in smaller communities can be extremely difficult," said Rabbi Steven Dworken, executive vice president of the Rabbinical Council of America.
The shortage in the ranks of the Jewish clergy began about five years ago. Before then, there were more rabbis than synagogues. "The issue of the glut was raised with the college in 1993," said Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, president of Hebrew Union College. "As a result, recruitment was not emphasized and was not considered an imperative."
Though enrollment at the college has remained stable, the number of congregations has grown. Fifteen years ago 764 synagogues belonged to the Union of American Hebrew Congregations; today 895 do. So not only are there new pulpits to fill, but, Rabbi Zimmerman said, "large congregations need more rabbis."
Rural areas have always had difficulty attracting clergy, no matter the denomination. Now, urban congregations are feeling the pinch.
"What used to be a problem for Wyoming and Montana is now a problem for everybody," said the Rev. James G. Wilson, executive director of the church deployment office at the Episcopal Church Center.
In part, the robust economy is being blamed, with many people who might have entered the ministry attracted to more lucrative fields.
"We have done too good a job educating our children and giving them banking, legal, business and medical opportunities. Years ago, many fellows became rabbis because they had no other choices," Rabbi Dworken said.
As a professor of religion at Columbia University for 21 years, Peter Awn said he had seen only four students majoring in religion at Columbia pursue careers in the clergy. In his view, the declining appeal of a life in ministry is more a result of the rejection of authority than of the lure of more lucrative jobs.
"People who might once have gone into the clergy as an avenue toward social change now see it as confining rather than liberating," Professor Awn said.
Among those who do seek jobs in the clergy, quality of life plays an increasingly decisive role as they question the long hours and unrelenting demands.
Though some experts think the decline in the clergy is cyclical, others think that failure to stem the tide would have serious implications.
"Unless we somehow increase the number of those choosing religious professional life, ultimately this will be a disaster for organized religious life," Rabbi Zimmerman said.

HEADLINE: For Women in Astronomy, a Glass Ceiling in the Sky

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER 

 BODY:
Before they could even vote or control their own property, women had reached for the stars -- and rigorously picked them apart. For more than a century, they have earned at least 10 percent of the doctorates in astronomy, often to luminous ends. In 1908, for example, Henrietta Leavitt discovered Cepheid variable stars, which have proved crucial to the measurement of cosmic distances. Some 25 years later, Cecilia Payne-Gaposchkin determined that stars are composed mainly of hydrogen -- a finding that her colleagues at first refused to believe.
Yet with all that history and momentum behind them, female astronomers still have not soared to professional heights in the numbers that might be expected. At a recent meeting of the American Astronomical Society in Atlanta, researchers presented results from new surveys of the status of women in astronomy, including one that canvassed virtually all astronomy departments in the United States and another that focused on 36 of the nation's larger and more prominent astronomy graduate programs. They compared the latest data with similar surveys taken in 1992, and thus were able to assess women's progress during a span that has been a boom time for astronomy as much as it has for the economy over all. 
 "With the Hubble Space Telescope and other advances, there's a lot of excitement in the field now, and a lot of stuff for people to do," said Dr. C. Megan Urry, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute in Baltimore, who conducted the surveys and presented the data in Georgia. "We're in a golden age of astronomy and cosmology." As a result, she said, the total number of people with Ph.D.'s in astronomy rose 40 percent in the last seven years.
Unfortunately for aspiring female astronomers, even the golden age appears to be alloyed with disparities. And though many observers have the impression that affirmative action programs in particular, and academic "political correctness" in general, unfairly give women the edge when it comes to hiring and promotion decisions, the new survey results suggest otherwise.
"Young men, and some young women, often think that women are being preferentially hired these days," Dr. Urry said. "Our data show that's not the case. If anything, it's the opposite." Women at the highest levels of the field remain a rarity: only 5 percent of the nation's full professors in astronomy are female. Among newcomers, though, women abound, currently accounting for 25 percent of the doctorates awarded in astronomy each year.
But women start leaking out of the career pipeline early on. About 43 percent of the men who were in graduate school in 1992 managed to obtain postdoctoral fellowships in the institution of their choice, compared with only 26 percent of the women. Among the elite universities, 60 percent of the male graduate students won coveted postdoctoral appointments in the same school, while only 50 percent of the female Ph.D.'s were selected to stay on as postgraduates.
When young astronomers seek tenure-track faculty positions, a few more women vanish; they go from being 17 percent of the nation's postdoctoral fellows to 15 percent of the new assistant professors.
Nobody knows why women are not advancing swiftly in a discipline that has long attracted them. Conference presenters admitted that conditions for women are vastly better today than they were 50 years ago, when the great astronomer Margaret Burbidge was refused a Carnegie fellowship because women were not allowed to use the Mount Wilson telescope or any of the other Carnegie observatories.
And astronomy is hardly alone among the sciences in its poor showing of women at the top. According to a study published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week, women who teach in medical schools are less likely than men to be promoted at each step along the path from assistant to full professor, even though they are more likely to go into academic medicine to begin with.
Some believe that any effort to push women ahead even faster is doomed to fail, because, they say, the female talent and desire just is not there. In the January issue of Status, a biannual report on women in astronomy published by the American Astronomical Society, the editors reprinted an article by David Gelernter, a professor of computer science at Yale University, which originally appeared in the conservative Weekly Standard.
"If women aren't being kept out of science by force, they must be choosing not to enter, presumably because they don't want to," Dr. Gelernter wrote, "presumably because (by and large) they don't like these fields or (on average) don't tend to excel in them, which is nearly the same thing."
"They're also less prone to the intense, cut-throat aggressiveness that usually marks the successful research scientist or engineer," he wrote.
Dr. Urry does not buy either the free choice or the wilting lily arguments. "Getting a Ph.D. in a science like astronomy is very, very difficult," she said. "You have to be in love with it, and be really interested in it and dedicated to finish. The notion that after spending five, six, seven grinding years working like dog, and then saying, 'oh, that was fun, now I choose to do something else' -- well, I don't believe it."
Overt discrimination is rare or absent, Dr. Urry and others said. Instead, they point to small slights and acts of benign neglect as the likeliest culprits in women's career lag -- the molehills that, as Virginia Valian put it in her book, "Why So Slow? The Advancement of Women," (M.I.T. Press, 1999) gradually accrete into mountains.
The publication Status presented some women's testimony in its two most recent issues, which can be found online at www.aas.org:
 *"I am on a postdoctoral search committee at a university astronomy department. I read about 100 applications, each of which has typically three letters of recommendation. One letter, written by a male faculty member for a female applicant, emphasizes twice how tiny, sweet and charming the applicant is, and gives a specific example of how amusing and cute it is to watch the applicant in the laboratory wrestling with astronomical equipment larger than she."
*"A new chair has been hired for our physics and astronomy department. Three of the 40 faculty members are women. He addresses his very first faculty memo to 'Dear Gentlemen . . .' "
*"A senior scientist and fellow Italian citizen, whom I know well but have not seen in several years, visits the institution where I am on the faculty. I say hello, and he replies, asking if I could take his clothes to the dry cleaner. . . . I declined to run his errand."
*"At a conference I approach two male colleagues in my field, wanting to introduce myself to the senior astronomer whose work closely parallels mine. I hope to join their conversation about a science issue with which I am very familiar. After continuing their conversation for a few minutes, the senior astronomer finally turns from his counterpart and addresses me, saying, 'Ah, but we are boring this sweet young girl. What can I do for you, dear?' "
*"I have just passed my Ph.D. oral exam, a follow-up to the written exam which was taken days earlier. A well-intentioned senior male faculty member approaches me with a handshake and remarks, 'I am very proud of your accomplishment, knowing how hard astronomy and physics is, especially for a woman . . .' "
*"As a young postdoc in a high-powered physics department, I attend a colloquium by a famous French man in which the opening slide is a topless dancer in a grass skirt on a Hawaiian beach. Some guys laugh and one female graduate student leaves quietly from the back. I myself am torn -- I do not want to appear humorless or to overreact (cultural norms being different in France, for one thing), and I want very much to hear the talk, but after 20 minutes I realize I have not heard a word he said after that awful picture. . . . The speaker, by the way, later wins a prestigious prize named for a famous woman scientist."
 None of this surprises Dr. Urry. Recently, she said, as she was putting together materials to bolster the case for her promotion to full astronomer, Dr. Urry was advised by a colleague to exclude mention of her work on behalf of women in astronomy. "Normally, taking a leadership position is seen as a plus," she said. "It's good to be a leader in anything but this."
Dr. Urry ignored the advice.

HEADLINE: Flashing Diamonds, and Hungry Children

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Bigger Diamonds Are a Girl's Best Friend" (Week in Review, Feb. 13): You report that "engagement rings of four carats or more are not uncommon in Upper East Side social circles."
Though Jerry Seinfeld's purchase of a two-carat diamond for his bride "horrified" Tiffany insiders, I admire his restraint. 
 When a woman, like one in your article, is disappointed with a six-carat diamond that is priced at about $75,000, we are really in the middle of a long-running economic expansion.
Every day, thousands of children die of preventable diseases and malnutrition. The 13-carat diamond pictured in the photograph accompanying your article could save some children from starvation.
Where are our priorities? If only there were status in an Upper East Side socialite's flashing a bare ring finger and saying, "My husband donated the money instead to help save the children of the world."

KERRY LANGAN
Oberlin, Ohio, Feb. 13, 2000

HEADLINE: Hostile Takeover Bid in Japan Ends on an Educational Note

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 14

 BODY:
A deal described as Japan's first indigenous hostile takeover attempt ended in what Americans would call a failure today.
But here, the effort by Yoshiaki Murakami, a former bureaucrat who had made a bid to take over the Shoei Company, a little-known real estate and electronic parts company, is seen as the most striking effort so far to challenge longstanding practices. 
 Mr. Murakami's bid, to buy Shoei's shares for 1,000 yen, or about $9.17, apiece, expired today. He increased his stake to 6.52 percent from 2.78 percent, far less than needed to veto any management decisions, but he said he considered it a victory.
"I'm very, very happy," Mr. Mu rakami said in an interview this evening. "I created a debate about shareholder value and management's responsibility for creating shareholder value, and that was what I wanted to achieve."
The acquisition fund established by Mr. Murakami, a 40-year-old former official of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, has been widely followed as a barometer of corporate Japan's willingness to change. His effort to acquire a controlling stake in Shoei is considered the first instance of a Japanese investor's having tried a hostile takeover of a Japanese company.
The outcome of his bid raises questions about the prognosis for another unsolicited takeover effort under way in Japan, a tender offer by Boehringer Ingelheim, a German drug manufacturer, for a controlling stake in SS Pharmaceuticals, which is set to expire Tuesday.
Mr. Murakami's bid for Shoei exposed the impediments that Japan's system of cross-shareholding among banks and corporations pose for investors. Shoei is a member company of the Fuyo Group, a cluster of companies, or keiretsu, that orbit around Fuji Bank and its related financial institutions, which together control 60 percent of Shoei's shares.
The keiretsu system has been long seen as one of the biggest barriers to foreign investment in Japan, as well as a significant contributor to Japan's lack of global competitiveness. Inside the keiretsu, companies are not forced to compete for financing and have little incentive to make decisions based on profitability.
Many investment strategists and analysts have assured investors that global market forces are pressuring the keiretsu to disband. Yet the Shoei case suggests that keiretsu power is still strong. Although the president of Fuji Bank has been widely quoted as saying that he intended to sell off Fuji's stakes in various group companies, Fuji and its sister insurance companies and trust banks refused to sell their shares in Shoei.
Mr. Murakami demonstrated that Shoei served as a place to give former directors of Fuji and its sister financial companies, the Yasuda Trust and Banking Company, the Yasuda Fire and Marine Insurance Company and the Yasuda Mutual Life Insurance Company, a second job and a means of maintaining their golf club memberships and chauffeured car service after retirement.
He also exposed the longstanding Japanese practice of undervaluing assets, finding 70 billion yen, or more than $648 million, in value over book value in Shoei's real estate holdings. He cites that as evidence that the company could turn a far better profit than it has in recent years.
"My motivation in this was not to seize management control but to increase shareholder value," he said. "I want the existing management to do its job."
Mr. Murakami said he planned to take his case to the March annual shareholders' meeting. He said several shareholders, including the fund management company Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder, which has a 7.7 percent stake in Shoei, have asked him to serve as their proxy.

HEADLINE: Surge in Sales Far Outpaces Rise in Business Inventories

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14

 BODY:
American companies bolstered their inventories by a modest 0.5 percent in December but their sales vaulted ahead at more than twice that pace, a sign that businesses are struggling to keep up with hardy demand, economists said.
For the 12th consecutive month, companies added to their stockpiles of goods, pushing total business inventories in December to a seasonally adjusted $1.14 trillion, the Commerce Department said today. 
 Sales grew 1.1 percent in December, to $868.8 billion.
That increase brought the inventory-to-sales ratio to a record low of 1.32, meaning it would take 1.32 months to exhaust inventories at the December sales pace.
"All of this reflects a struggle by companies to keep up with strong consumer demand," said Clifford Waldman, an economist at Waldman Associates. "The strength in consumption is almost overpowering the business world."
The Federal Reserve, which has raised interest rates four times since June to slow the roaring economy, is always on the lookout for signs that demand is outpacing supply, a condition that can lead to a sharp increase in prices.
"Businesses are hard pressed to keep up with strong demand," said Mark Vitner, an economist at First Union. "Some retailers and wholesalers have shown a little more pricing power, but it's still pretty small."
The Fed's rate increases have raised borrowing costs for businesses and consumers. But many analysts still say the central bank will increase rates again in March because the economy is growing too rapidly.
Retailers, who last year posted their best holiday shopping season since 1992, reported a 1 percent increase in inventories in December, to $369.2 billion. That followed a 1.4 percent rise in November.
At wholesalers, inventories rose 0.4 percent in December, to $305 billion after a 1.3 percent jump the month before. And, at factories, inventories grew 0.2 percent, to $470.9 billion after a 0.5 percent increase in November.

HEADLINE: Front Row;
Fashion Week parties go to the dogs Bonnie Cashin's instant legacy The anti-fur faction's new target is leather.

BYLINE: By Ginia Bellafante 

 BODY:

Fashion Week: So Much for Socializing
At a quarter past midnight last Wednesday, as models in artfully soiled jeans tried to ascend to the Rainbow Room from the ground floor of the G.E. Building, a curious thing happened: they were told no. It wasn't that they were inappropriately attired -- after all, they were heading to the Visionaire party, generally Fashion Week's edgiest event. It was simply too late to let any more people up, the elevator guards announced. Time to go home. 
 Although there were nearly 10 parties given to coincide with the fall 2000 runway collections in New York last week, they were marked by an absence of any real raucousness and, in most instances, an absence of actual fashion people. As one editor put it, "Fashion people don't go to fashion parties." Indeed, they were hard to spot among the 2,000 in attendance at The New York Post's Page Six party held at Gustavino's on Wednesday night. Arie L. Kopelman, the president of Chanel, turned up, but was out the door by 8:30 p.m.
Ever since the New York shows slipped in ahead of the European ones on the semiannual runway calendar, explained Marin Hopper, Elle's fashion director, those in the business have pared down their New York partygoing to save energy for the three weeks of foreign shows, and all the attendant hoopla, ahead.
Ms. Hopper did attend a dinner for Donatella Girombelli, the owner of the Genny and Byblos lines, at the lavish East Side home of Marina Galesi on Tuesday evening. And she showed up at a party at Barneys New York on Thursday evening given by her magazine for a small dog named Sweetie, who arrived, diva style, more than an hour after the party began. Sweetie, a mutt belonging to the designer John Bartlett and Mark Welsh, a former advertising director, has recently been given a humor column in Elle. (Mr. Welsh does the actual writing.) Many people, including Julie Gilhart, the fashion director of Barneys, brought their own dogs to the event. (She has a Jack Russell named Nora.) Others, like Anne Slowey, the fashion news director of Elle, borrowed. Pointing to an albino Jack Russell, Ms. Slowey said, "He's my date."
 
Bonnie Cashin Lives!
Last week, editors could not help remarking at the uncanniness exhibited by certain designers who had references to Bonnie Cashin in their fall 2000 collections.
Ms. Cashin, the revered sportswear designer, died on Feb. 3, an event marked not only by standard newspaper obituaries but also by a page-long appreciation in The Economist. Allusions to Ms. Cashin's work came up in the brass closures Anna Sui used on garments in her show and in the thin, decorative leather strips Marc Jacobs applied to the coats he showed.
The Cashin revival has not been limited to the runways however. Recently, Cesar Padilla and Radford Brown, owners of the downtown vintage shop Cherry, came into possession of a large stock of never-used Bonnie Cashin handbags. Designers have been buying them up, Mr. Brown said. The bags, displayed at the Cherry booth at the Metropolitan Vintage Show in New York last month, completely sold out.
And the Museum of the Fashion Institute of Technology has long been planning a Bonnie Cashin retrospective. It will begin in September of this year and run until January 2001.
 
Throwing Down the Anti-Leather Gauntlet
Despite the paint and tofu throwing by anti-fur protesters that interrupted the New York collections, Ingrid Newkirk, the London-based director of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, which took responsibility, maintains that her organization's war on fur is more or less over.
"That was our last hurrah," she said of the protests against three designers last week. Ms. Newkirk believes that the group has won the battle against fur, even though mink has continued to turn up all over runways. No matter. She said that starting today, it will begin a new chapter, with a battle against leather. "This is akin to the environmental movement's launch on toxins years ago," Ms. Newkirk said.
"The new fur war is the leather war," she added. "There's far more leather than fur on the catwalk."
Coinciding with London Fashion Week, which began on Sunday and continues through Thursday, Ms. Newkirk is releasing a documentary on the cruelties suffered by cows in the leather-making process. "The average person will be sickened," she said. Perhaps, or he just may go on eating his hamburger.

HEADLINE: W. A. Andres, 73, Executive Who Led Growth of Dayton Hudson

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
William A. Andres, who led the Dayton Hudson Corporation's expansion from a regional department store chain to a national retailing powerhouse, died Wednesday of lymphoma in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 73.
Under the leadership of Mr. Andres from 1976 through the sharp recession of the early 1980's, Dayton Hudson grew from 400 stores to more than 1,000, and its revenues tripled to $5.6 billion. 
 In 1978, a Forbes cover article said Mr. Andres was "analytical and has a reputation for getting to the heart of matters quickly and decisively." He was the company's first chief executive who was not a member of the Dayton family.
In his boldest bet, Mr. Andres quickly expanded Dayton Hudson's Target chain, correctly predicting that the future of retailing lay in large discount retailers situated mostly outside cities rather than full-priced urban department stores.
Target now provides most of the company's more than $30 billion in annual sales, and on Jan. 30, Dayton Hudson changed its name to the Target Corporation.
Mr. Andres rose rapidly through the ranks at Dayton Hudson. After joining the company as a management trainee selling robes in August 1958, he became a department manager in three months and a vice president less than five years later. By 1968 he was chairman and chief executive of Dayton. He gave up that post when the company bought the J. L. Hudson department store chain one year later.
But his move aside was only temporary. He became president of the combined company in 1974, chief executive in 1976 and chairman in 1977.
Outside the office, Mr. Andres was an avid golfer and gardener, his son Richard said. He was also an accomplished amateur magician.
"He actually put himself through undergraduate school doing magic" in Fayette, Iowa, Richard Andres said. "Magic ran through his whole life." His most memorable trick involved chopping the head off a volunteer with a mock guillotine.
Mr. Andres graduated from Upper Iowa University in 1948 and earned a master's degree at the University of Pittsburgh one year later.
He is survived by Betty, his wife of 52 years; three sons, Robert, of San Diego; Charles, of Brainerd, Minn.; and Richard, of Minnetonka, Minn.; and five grandchildren.
"They had a very strong partnership. It was always, 'Betty and Bill did this. Betty and Bill did that,' " Richard said of his mother and father.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europeans Move Toward Backing German to Lead the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
The European Union appears set to back a German finance ministry official to head the International Monetary Fund, giving a boost to a candidate Clinton administration officials privately argue is ill-suited for the job.
European foreign ministers, meeting in Brussels today, reached an informal consensus that Caio Koch-Weser, 55, a longtime World Bank official who currently serves as a state secretary in the German finance ministry, should succeed Michel Camdessus as director of the monetary fund, German and European Union officials said after the meeting. 
 The French, who had been viewed as cool to Mr. Koch-Weser, issued a statement saying that they would not block a European choice.
The Brussels meeting was a success for Germany, which has sought to foster a sense of inevitability about Mr. Koch-Weser's bid to take over the I.M.F.'s leadership. Though European foreign ministers sent signals today that they had rallied around the German choice, they put off until at least Feb. 28 any official declaration that the European Union would put its political muscle behind his candidacy. That gives Germany two weeks to rally support for him without risking a loss of face by the Europeans if it were unable to do so.
The turn of events is considered a setback for the Clinton administration. It publicly remains neutral on Mr. Koch-Weser. But the administration has made clear that it would prefer that Europe, which has customarily named the head of the monetary fund, find someone who is better known internationally and who has more experience managing currencies and setting overall economic strategy. The quiet disagreement has persisted for four months.
The leadership change at the monetary fund comes at a sensitive time. The fund, which is based in Washington, has more influences than ever before over capitalist-oriented economies worldwide. From Indonesia to Russia, the I.M.F. not only provides billions of dollars in aid and helps shape economic policies, but can also affect the political fortunes of leaders who defy its lending conditions.
Its operations have been under a microscope. The fund has been criticized for mismanaging multibillion-dollar aid programs for Russia and, most recently, Ukraine. Members of Congress have expressed concern that money provided by the fund feeds corruption in those countries.
The Clinton administration has also pushed for changes at the I.M.F. Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers has argued that the fund should focus more on preventing or combating financial emergencies and less on alleviating poverty, a task he says is better handled by the World Bank. Mr. Koch-Weser, who spent 25 years at the World Bank as a specialist in poverty relief, is not regarded as having the right resume to carry out such changes.
Still, the United States and many developing countries are watching from the sidelines as Europe fumbles its way toward nominating a successor to Mr. Camdessus. While there is no ground swell of support for Mr. Koch-Weser, he remains the only public European candidate for the job after months of debate. Germany's steadfast campaign to put him in office appears to be wearing down the French, who had earlier declined to offer any signal they would back Mr. Koch-Weser.
He has also spoken out in his own cause, blaming an arcane political process in Europe for harming his candidacy. In a recent interview, Mr. Koch-Weser said his fluent English and leadership experience at the World Bank made him a good choice to increase political support for the monetary fund at a time it is under pressure to become more responsive to social and environmental issues.
"What the fund needs is a chief executive who can get its message across and increase support," he said. "I do not think it needs a technocrat who is more like a chief financial officer."
While the outcome is still uncertain, it seems increasingly likely that the United States will have to choose between accepting Mr. Koch-Weser or using its standing at the I.M.F. to oppose him, perhaps in alliance with some developing countries. Washington would have to weigh the importance of finding what it considers an ideal candidate for the post against the costs of straining relations with European allies.
A senior administration official said today that the United States would in principle back a European choice for the job, provided that person enjoyed broad support not just in Europe but also in the developing countries.
The signal from Brussels came the same day that Mr. Camdessus, the Frenchman who has led the monetary fund for 13 years, formally retired as managing director. Stanley Fischer, the American who served as the No. 2 I.M.F. official, automatically became acting director.
Mr. Fischer, 56, who has taught at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, has long managed the daily operations of the I.M.F. and has shaped its financial-bailout packages for Asian and Latin American countries in recent years.
"You should not be worried at all about the health and the efficiency of the I.M.F. during this interim period," said Mr. Camdessus, speaking at a conference in Bangkok, Thailand, during his final day on the job.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Investors Scour for Bargains After Last Week's Sell-Off

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks ended higher yesterday as Wall Street scouted for bargains, notably among cyclical stocks, after a sharp sell-off last week that sent the blue-chip Dow index reeling into a correction.
"After all, the Dow is an industrial index and I think the selling last week has prompted a little bargain hunting," said Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Company in Great Neck, N.Y. "We have had a number of hard down Fridays to be followed on Monday by some bargain hunting." 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 94.63 points, or 0.90 percent, to 10,519.84 after the 30-stock average fell 218.42 points, to 10,425.21 on Friday, losing 538.59 points, or 4.9 percent, for the week.
The slide put the index in what is known as a correction as it fell more than 10 percent -- 11.07 percent to be exact -- from its closing high of 11,722.98 of Jan. 14.
The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed up 2.82 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,389.94.
The Nasdaq composite index climbed 23.10 points, or 0.52 percent, to 4,418.55, after seesawing most of the session.
"Big blue-chip Dow names are so oversold, they're starting to attract some money away from the Nasdaq," said Harry Laubscher, market analyst at Tucker Anthony. "We're getting a little nibbling."
The Dow's top gainer was the aluminum producer Alcoa, which rose 4 9/6, to 72 1/4, after Reynolds Metals said its shareholders had approved its merger with Alcoa. Reynolds Metals added 5 9/16, to 69 1/8.
Another big Dow mover was Intel, which advanced 4, to 109 7/8, after Dell Computer said it would offer its first desktop personal computer using long-awaited Intel memory chips.
Dell, the second most active stock on the Nasdaq, eased 7/16, to 36 7/16.
Interest-rate sensitive financial stocks mostly ended down at the start of a week that promised several important economic reports and a Congressional appearance by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, on Thursday.
In the Dow, American Express inched up 1/2, to 154, while J. P. Morgan slipped 1/2, to 112 1/8.
The market, which is on interest-rate alert ahead of Mr. Greenspan's comments, did not seem too fazed by news that crude oil futures in New York broke above $30 a barrel, the highest since the Persian Gulf war in January 1991.
In general, Internet and health care companies were down while utilities, automakers, heavy machinery companies and coal producers advanced. Buyouts fueled some of the gains. Shares of the business software provider Computer Associates International dropped 7/16, to 69 5/16, after saying it would pay $4 billion in stock for the business software developer Sterling Software. Sterling rose 1 13/16, to 36 1/4.
Among initial offerings, shares of Diversa shot up 51, to 75, in their first day of trading on Nasdaq after the biotechnology company's shares were priced at $24.

HEADLINE: Sao Paulo Journal;
Rich Brazilians Rise Above Rush-Hour Jams

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 14

 BODY:
At night the skyline in this city of 16 million is a dazzling display of lights that can easily remind visitors of Manhattan.
But something is different. Many of the lights are moving. 
 The skies of Sao Paulo, Latin America's financial capital and the richest big city in the developing world, are filled with helicopters.
Like a fleet of airborne limousines, the helicopters are increasingly used by privileged Paulistanos to commute, attend meetings, even run errands and go to church. Helicopter landing pads are now standard features of many of Sao Paulo's guarded residential compounds and high-rise roofs.
Illustrating what may be a Blade Runner-esque glimpse of the future in metropolises where rich and poor are crammed together, helicopters are the vehicle of choice for more than just their convenience. Many of the roads here are hopelessly clogged with traffic. Carjackings, kidnappings of executives and roadside robberies have become a part of the risks of daily life for anyone perceived to have money.
So the demand for private helicopters in Sao Paulo has turned the city into one of the most vibrant markets for helicopter dealers.
For pilots, navigating the city by air is like flying through an endless concrete maze. "My favorite time to fly is at night, because the sensation is equaled only in movies or in dreams," said Moacir da Silva, the president of the Sao Paulo Helicopter Pilots Association. "The lights are everywhere, as if I were flying within a Christmas tree."
At 400 and growing, the total fleet of private helicopters in Sao Paulo is the biggest of any city in the developing world. Although the fleets in New York and Tokyo are larger, the helicopters in those cities are owned mostly by corporations, not rich individuals.
Moreover, the growth of the Sao Paulo fleet has quickened in recent years, even with the slowdown in Brazil's economy after the currency devaluation crisis a year ago.
While Brazil's economy grew less than 1 percent in 1999, the nation's helicopter fleet rose more than 7 percent, to nearly 800. Most of that growth was here.
"Sao Paulo commands the most favorable characteristics of any city in the world for the civil helicopter industry," said Fabrice Cagnat, the president of the Brazilian subsidiary of Eurocopter, a venture between DaimlerChrysler and Aerospatiale of France.
The most favorable is the traffic, a byproduct of Sao Paulo's haphazard expansion in recent decades as millions of migrants from poorer parts of Brazil moved here in search of work. Roads were never sufficiently expanded to accommodate the swelling population. Subway lines can barely handle a fraction of the residents, and an efficient freeway system remains a distant dream.
With the city's crazy-quilt layout that is part Los Angeles, because of sheer horizontal breadth, and part Manhattan, because skyscrapers are so numerous, navigating by car is daunting.
"Money is time, and the time lost in traffic is substantial," said Marco Antonio Audi, the Brazil representative for Robinson Helicopters, which is based in Torrance, Calif.
The use of helicopters to avoid traffic has grown to the point where some people use their choppers to commute daily to work or to retreat to their country estates or beach homes every few days.
"One member of my congregation regularly comes to Sabbath service by helicopter to escape the horrendous Friday night traffic," said Henry Sobel, the senior rabbi of Sao Paulo's largest synagogue.
The most affordable and best-selling helicopter in Brazil is the Robinson R44, which can comfortably seat three or four people. It costs about $380,000, or roughly 90 times the average annual income of a Sao Paulo resident. Another popular model is the Bell 407, which seats as many as seven people and costs about $1.5 million.
"Why settle for an armored BMW when you can afford a helicopter?" said Eric Wasson, a Latin American sales representative for Bell Helicopter of Fort Worth, Tex.
The helicopters of Sao Paulo are not universally admired. Critics consider them an obscene barometer of the financial power enjoyed by the affluent few in a sea of poverty. According to the World Bank, Brazil's richest 10 percent control more than 50 percent of the country's wealth while the poorest 10 percent control less than 1 percent.
It is easier for a wealthy person to buy a helicopter than it is for a working-class person to buy a car. Rich Paulistanos have access to financing that often is substantially cheaper than domestic lending rates, and more financing options are emerging. Debis, the financing arm of DaimlerChrysler, recently opened an office here that will largely focus on helicopter deals.
The contrasts are not lost on the vast majority of people in Sao Paulo who cannot afford a helicopter.
"One of the contradictions of the Brazilian character is the capacity for great warmth to coexist with an extreme individualism," said Renato Janine Ribeiro, a professor of political philosophy at the University of Sao Paulo. "The desire for a helicopter is a result of a complete lack of concern for other people."
Others see the helicopters as a symbol of a worsening class distinction in Brazil.
"That there is an archipelago of wealthy consumers that is able to use helicopters just as their counterparts do in Manhattan or Bombay or wherever doesn't surprise me," said Jorge Wilheim, an urban planner. "But the ocean of people surrounding this archipelago should be getting the transportation services they need, and they are not."
Compared with the several hundred people in the city who are able to commute by helicopter, about 3.7 million residents resort to the city's precarious bus system each day, according to municipal figures. Riding the city's 10,400 buses is not only uncomfortable but often dangerous, because of the high risk of muggings. So unlicensed minivans have grown popular as a way to get around.
Earlier this month, when three people were killed and eight injured when a minivan driver fled from the police and hit a tree, one newspaper said in a front-page editorial, "No one controls the city."
While travel on the ground remains quite dangerous, there have been few accidents involving helicopters in the city.
Mr. Wilheim said Sao Paulo would need to extend its subway by six miles each year in the next decade for the public transportation system to approach those of Paris or New York. Yet there is little impetus from the authorities to make such plans when spending is restricted. A result of Sao Paulo's lackadaisical approach to public transportation is an assault on the ears of residents.
In some parts of the city, the honking horns of bottlenecks and sirens of police vehicles weaving through traffic is joined by the almost incessant sound of helicopters whizzing by. The Sao Paulo Helicopter Pilots Association says about 100 helicopters fly above the city at any given time during the day.
"I can't stand helicopters," said Paula Doria, a 21-year-old student, "because I live next to an apartment building with a heliport, and the noise is incredible." Still, she said, "If I had enough money to buy a helicopter I would, because it's a way to escape from crime."
Visually, the helicopter traffic is an added feature that can make some of Sao Paulo's more crowded districts, already adorned with huge television advertising screens and multilingual billboards, resemble a scene from "Blade Runner," the 1982 movie about a rain-soaked, futuristic Los Angeles.
Just as a wealthy elite seeks private-sector solutions for its problems in "Blade Runner," Sao Paulo's powerful are increasingly turning to private companies for services normally in the public sphere, like security, education and transportation.
James Thurston Lynch, a former banker at Chase Manhattan, understands this well. Mr. Lynch, a Brazilian who now has his own investment firm, plans to buy 100 helicopters for a part ownership program similar to the system that people use to share private jets in the United States.
Mr. Lynch, who intends to sign up 1,000 people to buy shares in his fleet, said, "I hope to democratize use of the helicopter."

HEADLINE: 3 Charged in Kickback Scheme At Long Island Housing Agency

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Feb. 14

 BODY:
A former maintenance supervisor for the Hempstead Housing Authority was charged today with forcing companies to pay kickbacks totaling more than $35,000 in return for contracts to repair the agency's buildings.
In Federal District Court here, prosecutors charged the ex-supervisor, James W. Graydon, 61, and two others, James McKay, 53, the former director of public information for the Economic Opportunity Commission of Nassau County, and David Delvalle, 43, a contractor from Valley Stream who did repairs and maintenance work at the village of Hempstead's public housing developments. 
 The three are accused of submitting inflated bills totaling $159,000 to the Housing Authority that included the cash kickbacks, said Loretta E. Lynch, the United States attorney for the Eastern District of New York.
Investigators said Mr. Graydon, who was arrested by federal agents this morning at his Uniondale home, had told contractors that if they wanted to do any work for the Housing Authority, they had to pay him.
Ms. Lynch said the contractors would then inflate their bills to the Housing Authority by the amount that they needed to pay off Mr. Graydon. The kickbacks, which began in 1994 and continued for two years, usually ranged from $1,500 to $2,000 per contract, but some were as high as $5,100, Ms. Lynch said.
Mr. McKay, a Roslyn Heights resident who was arrested several weeks ago on a related complaint charging him and Mr. Graydon with conspiring to solicit bribes, has since been charged with conspiracy to commit extortion. If convicted, he faces a maximum prison term of 20 years and a fine of $250,000.
Mr. Graydon faces a maximum of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. He and Mr. McKay were charged today with soliciting bribes.
Mr. Delvalle, who surrendered for today's arraignment, is charged with making unlawful bribe payments and filing a false tax return. He faces 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. All three defendants have pleaded not guilty and remain free on their own recognizance.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Oil Price Exceeds $30 a Barrel For the First Time Since 1991

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The price of crude oil jumped to more than $30 a barrel yesterday for the first time since the 1991 Persian Gulf war, and a sharp run-up in gasoline prices looks increasingly likely this summer.
The price of crude oil neared $30 in mid-January, slipped and then rallied again last week. All the time, traders were weighing concerns about declining inventories of crude oil, home heating oil and gasoline against the possibility of a production increase from major oil producers when they meet at the end of March. 
 As new data showed some inventories tightening last week, only promises of increased production by unnamed OPEC officials kept the price of crude oil from piercing $30. But several reports yesterday put a damper on the prospect of a production increase, and the $30 barrier was breached. The price of crude oil for March delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange jumped 81 cents, to $30.25 a barrel.
Of course, new comments from OPEC officials holding out the hope of production increases could depress the price again. In fact, yesterday's comments contradicted what appeared to be clear signals last week that Venezuela and Saudi Arabia would ask for an increase by June at a meeting of OPEC countries at the end of next month.
Even if the producers relent, the production cuts that began last March -- equal to 4.3 million barrels a day -- may have already set the stage for a sharp rise in gasoline prices later this year and a stronger political response from the United States and Europe.
"If OPEC eases in June, it's too late," said Irene King, senior oil markets analyst for J. P. Morgan & Company, referring to peak gasoline demand in the summer. Because of the lag time between increased crude oil production and the refining of gasoline, she said, "we will have to go through the early summer driving season with very low gasoline inventories; that would make the heating oil squeeze we had a few weeks ago look like a piece of cake."
Retail gasoline prices, according to the Department of Energy, rose to $1.356 a gallon this week, up 48 percent in the last year and the highest since late 1990.
In the futures market, the price of unleaded gasoline for March delivery rose 2.3 cents yesterday, to 83.41 cents a gallon. Gasoline is now above the price of home heating oil, which rose 1.5 cents, to 75.70 cents a gallon yesterday. But it is far below the 95.20 cents a gallon price of Jan. 31.
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson has no plans now to dip into the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, although he is being pressed to do so by Northeastern politicians, including Sen. Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York. A spokesman for the Energy Department said yesterday that this was "not an option in the current environment and the last four words are key." The weather has moderated in the Northeast, reducing concern about home heating oil inventories. But in California, where gasoline prices are a concern to the state's many drivers, the prices could be thrust into the spotlight as its presidential primary nears.
Mr. Richardson is scheduled to meet with energy officials in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait at the end of the month, but had to cancel a meeting with Venezuelan oil officials because of a scheduling conflict.
Anticipating what OPEC and the price of oil are going to do is complex in part because of politics, both in OPEC and the United States. The Iranian elections are this week, and some analysts have said that OPEC wants to look determined to bolster oil prices to help moderates win there. An OPEC that bowed to the West by increasing production, analysts argue, could be used against the moderates. In addition, the United States does not want to threaten Saudi Arabia and lose its support, which could happen if the Clinton administration dipped into the the Strategic Petroleum Reserve.
It is also possible that OPEC members would argue for a production increase only after the price of crude topped $30 a barrel and world inventories fell. At this point, they may find it easier to persuade members that a modest production increase of about a million barrels a day would not send crude oil prices tumbling.
But even if this is the goal, analysts say, OPEC leaders like Saudi Arabia do not want oil prices to climb too quickly. A sharp rise could prompt a stronger reaction from United States and European leaders who have to worry about the impact of higher prices on consumers, voters and the economy. So the recent comments from OPEC officials may have been intended to keep the price of crude oil from rising too fast.
A report from Venezuela helped jar the oil market yesterday, said James R. Steel, an energy analyst at Refco Inc. Alvaro Silva, the vice oil minister of Venezuela, told Dow Jones newswires that there were no plans to ask for a crude oil production increase at the March OPEC meeting. His comments contradicted the signal Friday of a production increase from an unnamed Venezuelan official. Dow Jones also reported that Shokri Ghanem, the director of OPEC's research division, said that "support is growing among OPEC members for an extension of the cuts" beyond March. And over the weekend, Iraq repeated its threats to cut its oil production.
"This is really pouring cold water on this idea that took hold last week that Saudi Arabia would allow a production increase," Mr. Steel said.
The sharp decline in inventories of crude oil and products showed up in a report by the International Energy Agency on Friday.
The report said inventories among the 29 countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development were the lowest since February 1997.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: MICHIGAN;
Trail Leads to a Transformed State

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TROY, Mich., Feb. 14

 BODY:
The popular perception that Michigan elections are still dominated by legions of auto workers toting lunch pails is as dated as a Chevrolet Citation.
Here, as in New Hampshire and South Carolina, a new economy, in which auto workers wear white collars, has generated a new electorate, whose party affiliations are loose and whose votes are hard to predict. Those voters have already helped change Michigan politics in recent years, and, according to the latest polls, they could be crucial in determining who wins the state's Republican presidential primary on Tuesday of next week. 
 The new, high-tech professionals are people like Joel Gibson, a 26-year-old car-engine software programmer whose father, grandfather and great-grandmother were all auto factory workers and staunch Democrats.
"I lean Republican, but I like to look at each individual candidate," said Mr. Gibson, who is taken with former Senator Bill Bradley and Senator John McCain.
The new workers tend to vote Republican in state and local elections, but they have proved unpredictable in contests for national office.
"They may identify themselves as Republicans, but when they pull that curtain, the independent streak kicks in, much to my chagrin," said one Republican officeholder, L. Brooks Patterson, the Oakland County executive.
Mr. Patterson knows those voters well, because it is here in Oakland County, in Detroit's northwestern suburbs, that they tend to make their homes. Macomb County, which lies along Oakland's eastern boundary and is characterized by strip malls and small ranch-style houses, remains the home of the so-called Reagan Democrats -- union workers attracted to the Republicans' appeal to traditional values. But Oakland County has dozens of auto engineering centers that have sprung up in rows of new, tinted-glass office towers as starkly anonymous as any in Silicon Valley, and tens of thousands of the new workers live here.
Dotted with small lakes surrounded by beautiful homes, crisscrossed by freeways increasingly lined by those engineering centers, Oakland County has 1.2 million people to Macomb's 770,000, and is growing twice as fast.
"Oakland is where many of these people live, and is going to be a battleground going into the future," said Jennifer Granholm, a Democrat who won election as state attorney general in 1998, partly by doing well in the county.
Ms. Granholm is a fairly recent arrival, having grown up in San Francisco. Other recent arrivals, including many engineers, have more than offset the constant stream of retirees moving south and have raised the state's population to almost 10 million, from 9.3 million in 1990.
Politicians and pollsters from across the political spectrum describe the new workers similarly: conservative on economic issues, particularly in their skepticism about government regulation, but moderate on social policy. They have helped Republicans take control of both houses of the Legislature as well as the governor's mansion.
But they have also been willing to vote for some Democrats in national elections: Bill Clinton beat former Senator Bob Dole in Oakland County in 1996, and nearly beat President George Bush here in 1992. That inclination has increasingly made them the swing voters in a state that is among the nation's most evenly divided between Democrats and Republicans.
"They're the ones who come across and vote for the Democrats who win in Michigan," said Robert Teeter, a Republican pollster in Ann Arbor.
To be sure, Macomb County, with its Reagan Democrats, was once regarded as the capital of Michigan's swing voter. But the changing face of the work force has brought a changing face to the electorate. The number of unionized industrial workers as a proportion of all voters in the state has dropped by nearly half in the last two decades, to between 6 and 9 percent, pollsters say.
Auto production remains the state's dominant industry, but auto makers and auto parts companies are changing the way they do business. For instance, while much of the actual manufacturing has either been automated or moved to Southern states and overseas, to take advantage of lower wages elsewhere, all but 8 of the nation's 200 auto parts engineering centers are now in Michigan instead of being scattered across the Midwest.
The nation's long economic expansion has been particularly good to the highly cyclical auto industry, like a prolonged return to the early 1960's, before auto makers' profits were crippled by foreign competition and, arguably, government safety and environmental regulations. The arts are flourishing in Detroit, with the opening of a cavernous opera house and the restoration of a magnificent symphony hall. Housing prices have been rising faster across this metropolitan area than almost anywhere else in the country.
Further, an acute shortage of skilled labor has kept Michigan's unemployment rate below the national average since 1995. The state's rate was just 3.6 percent in December, and the state government plans to start spending as much money advertising for engineers to move here from other states as it previously spent persuading businesses to locate here.
Michigan's shift in employment toward white-collar jobs has occurred on a massive scale. The number of unionized auto workers in Michigan has plunged to fewer than 250,000 now from 479,000 in 1980. But total employment in the auto industry, the state says, has only inched down, to 471,000 from 507,000 two decades ago, and actually grew in the 1990's.
In Pontiac, several miles west of here, General Motors recently gutted and remodeled two assembly plants with the combined floor space of the Empire State Building, turning them into offices and laboratories for 8,500 engineers. G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler can afford such grandiose undertakings: they were the world's three largest companies in 1998, in terms of sales and share of global economic output.
A statewide poll by The Detroit Free Press a week ago found that in the race for the Republican primary next week -- the Democrats are holding presidential nominating caucuses in March -- Senator McCain and Gov. George W. Bush were evenly matched if Democrats and independents voted in fairly large numbers, while Governor Bush was ahead among Republicans alone.
The poll also showed that Senator McCain enjoyed a sizable advantage in Macomb County, partly because of Reagan Democrats, while Governor Bush commanded strong support in western Michigan, where abortion opponents are numerous and active and have been leery of the senator. Oakland County was a tossup if Democrats and independents were included, while Governor Bush prevailed if only Republicans were counted.
One issue on which Mr. Bush could ultimately prove vulnerable here is government regulation. Michigan Republicans regularly deride Vice President Al Gore for saying in his book, "Earth in the Balance," that the internal combustion engine's contribution to global warming is "a mortal threat to the security of every nation that is more deadly than that of any military enemy we are ever again likely to confront." The Republicans are eager to attack Mr. Gore relentlessly on the issue should he win the Democratic nomination.
But whether they would be much able to do so with Mr. Bush as the Republican nominee is uncertain. Criticized by environmentalists in New England television advertisements this autumn, Mr. Bush announced in New Hampshire in December that he had asked Texas regulators to consider adopting California's new auto pollution rules, which are stricter than the federal government's and are particularly tough on high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks.
The regulators held hearings on the idea during the week of the New Hampshire primary, and the conservative Detroit News sent a reporter to Texas to cover them. The resulting article emphasized that G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler sold 90 percent of Texas' sport utilities and pickup trucks, and ran under a big headline that said, "Bush Cleanup Plan to Cut Truck Sales."
But beyond environmental regulation lies the broader landscape of a changing work force and changing politics here. Dwayne F. Davidson, a 41-year-old G.M. manager of computer-aided design, is a Republican leaning toward Governor Bush, trusting him to keep government small. Mr. Davidson agrees on few political issues with his father, a lifelong Democrat who spent 30 years welding car body panels in the same giant building in Pontiac where the son now oversees the design of sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks.
"I've hung out with Republicans, I golf with Republicans," Mr. Davidson said. "It has kind of rubbed off."

HEADLINE: State Power Authority in $800 Million Deal to Sell 2 Nuclear Power Plants

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
The New York Power Authority announced yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to sell the only two nuclear power plants owned by the state to Entergy Corporation.
The Power Authority plants are the Indian Point 3 power station in Buchanan, 35 miles north of Manhattan on the east bank of the Hudson River, and the James A. FitzPatrick plant on Lake Ontario. 
 The planned sale is the latest in a string of moves in the nuclear power industry that is leading a rising proportion of the country's 103 operating nuclear plants to be operated or owned by just a few companies.
The shift has some environmental groups and New York legislators concerned that intensified cost cutting, as the industry consolidates, could lead to safety problems. Officials at the Power Authority and at Entergy said the plants' sale would help lower the cost of electricity and not increase risks.
Entergy, a private company in New Orleans, is also in a tentative deal to lease and operate two other nuclear plants in New York, Nine Mile Point 1 and 2, and is seeking to buy other plants in the Northeast.
The company has agreed to pay $638 million over seven years for the Power Authority's two plants, as well as another $168 million, also spread over seven years, for nuclear fuel stockpiles.
Under the deal, the Power Authority, a quasi-independent agency, would pay for most of the costs of decommissioning the plants when Entergy officials felt they had reached the end of their useful, or profitable life, Power Authority officials said.
A fund of $630 million has been set aside for closing the plants, which is projected to grow to $1.9 billion before the plants are shut down, said Jack Murphy, a spokesman for the authority. Any additional decommissioning costs would be the responsibility of the buyer, he said.
Experts in nuclear safety had a mixed reaction to the announcement, which had been expected for several months. Environmental Advocates, a private lobbying group in Albany, released a statement criticizing Entergy for cutting corners in maintenance and inspection programs at its Southern plants, and incurring federal fines in several cases.
But David Lochbaum, a nuclear safety engineer at the Union of Concerned Scientists, a private group in Washington, said, "I don't think the sale of the plant is a safety issue."
Mr. Lochbaum said that the pressures to cut costs at power plants are rising regardless of ownership, and that Entergy had a good record of reliability and safety.
"The real issue is that these plants are going to have to produce electricity at economical rates or they won't survive," he said. In many cases, he added, that may not be possible, and the pressure to cut costs may result in safety problems.
Richard L. Brodsky, the Westchester Democrat who chairs the State Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee, said he planned to convene hearings to examine the proposed deal.
The sale needs the approval of the Power Authority's trustees, who are appointed by Gov. George E. Pataki, as well as the approval of Entergy's board, the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission and other government agencies.
