HEADLINE: At Sugar Refinery, A Melting-Pot Strike;
Workers of Many Nations Besiege Brooklyn Relic of Industrial Age

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
They call themselves a league of nations, this group of workers who trudge day after day outside the Domino Sugar refinery, a Brooklyn landmark that towers like a fortress over the East River, a monument to New York's great industrial past.
The workers, 300 men and women from Poland, Italy, Jamaica and a dozen other nations, have defied the scorching summer sun and winter winds since going on strike eight months ago, resisting concessions demanded by the refinery, one of the last large manufacturing plants in Brooklyn. 
As the strikers march down the largely deserted sidewalks of Brooklyn's once-thriving waterfront, they often complain of being forgotten, of becoming orphans of the labor movement. They say their parent union, the International Longshoremen's Association, has done little to draw attention to their cause, while New York City's labor leaders, with their focus on Manhattan and on faster-growing fields like health care, have provided scant support.
Despite this perceived lack of help and despite their differing backgrounds, ages and accents, the strikers have stuck it out and stuck together. In an extraordinary show of solidarity, not one of them has crossed the picket line, although one worker, a Russian immigrant, killed himself.
Although the number of strikers is not large, the Domino dispute has turned into a classic labor standoff between a blue-collar work force intent on defending the protections and benefits it took decades to gain and a company that insists it needs to cut costs to remain competitive.
Domino's parent, Tate & Lyle of London, one of the world's largest producers of sweeteners, says that to keep costs down it needs to lay off 100 workers, weaken seniority rules and end a guarantee of full-time work. Managers are also insisting on reducing the sick days allowed and taking away many holidays.
"I hate them," said Migdonia Espinosa, a refinery worker for 25 years, while walking the picket line. "Dedication means nothing to them. We're just numbers to them. They act like we're asking for the world. We're asking for nothing. We just want job security and seniority."
From the Williamsburg Bridge, two blocks south, the strikers look like placard-carrying ants as they huddle next to the refinery, an 11-story brick mass built in 1858 and described by one architectural guidebook as a "bulky, bold and brutal" behemoth. With its rooftop sign, which screams "Domino" in large red neon letters, the building seems to boast of a time when New York City, led by this refinery, dominated the nation's sugar trade, refining most of the sugar for American households.
Along the refinery's massive eastern wall, a makeshift tent protects the strikers from rain, and a poorly heated trailer gives them some semblance of warmth during breaks from picketing. Nonetheless, Robert Shelton, a utility laborer, said that when the temperature fell to single digits in January, there was no escaping the cold, despite layers of clothing.
"We were out there, and we were cold," Mr. Shelton said. "Our feet were cold. Our hands were cold. Sometimes the way the wind whips off the river, it feels like 35 below. The only thing that kept us going was we didn't want them to think the cold was going to stop us. They're always looking for weakness."
As he talked, his face had an eerie, almost summery glow. But then he explained that he slathers his face with Vaseline each morning to prevent windburn.
Even worse than the cold, Mr. Shelton said, was having to celebrate Christmas while on strike. "My 13-year-old girl told me, 'I hope you can go back to work so we can have a nice Christmas,' " he said. "It was the first time in my life I couldn't afford a Christmas tree. I just couldn't afford the $20, $30 for that."
The strikers, whose base pay is $600 a week, are getting by with weekly unemployment insurance checks of $360, but mostly through the moral support they give each other. (The parent union provides no strike benefits.) But they dread the day late this month when their unemployment checks will run out.
"We can sure use some more support from the outside," said Albert Maddox, 59, a mechanic. He stood a few yards from a tombstone-like marker, labeled "R.I.P. John Alschen," that the workers erected in memory of a 62-year-old striker. The man committed suicide in December, convinced that he would be laid off by Domino and would never find another job, his son said.
One factor that has perhaps encouraged the strikers, most of whom have worked at Domino for more than 15 years, to dig in is the realization that finding other jobs, especially jobs that pay as well, will not be easy in light of their limited education and skills.
The New York City Central Labor Council, the city's union federation, recently began taking steps to help the strikers. To sustain them, it has raised money, $9,000 so far, and set up a food bank, although some strikers wonder what took so long. Brian McLaughlin, the labor council's president, said the city's labor leaders had not done more because Longshoremen officials had not asked them to, but union officials said they had. "We will do anything and everything possible to help them," Mr. McLaughlin said.
Officials from the parent Longshoremen's union said they were already helping, by providing the trailer and expertise in the negotiations.
"It's a shame that a strike of this size in New York City is going on with barely a ripple," said Greg Tarpinian, president of the Labor Research Association, a New York consulting group. "For a group of workers to be on strike for this long without becoming a cause celebre in New York, the stronghold of the nation's labor movement, that's a problem."
The workers have a hard time explaining the chemistry that has held them together like glue.
"We're practically a United Nations," said Charles Milan, 59, a mechanic and shop steward. "We've got people from the Caribbean, Europe, Poland, Yugoslavia, Italy, Hispanics, blacks, Southern blacks. We have a Rainbow Coalition here. May I add that we get along beautifully. If the outside world got along the way we get along, it would be a much better world."
But the workers do not get along with Tate & Lyle's management. For months, the negotiations, despite the help of federal mediators, have been stuck in neutral, although union leaders say they occasionally slide into reverse.
Management has repeatedly told the union that it needs to shrink its work force because industry profits are down and import quotas are limiting the amount of sugar the refinery can get to process. In addition, Tate & Lyle says it will need far fewer workers because the company is starting to ship semiprocessed sugar in liquid containers to the Brooklyn refinery, rather than the traditional unrefined sugar.
"We're one of the last remaining manufacturing companies in Brooklyn, and we need to make changes and update our refining operations in order to remain a viable company on the Brooklyn waterfront," said Margaret Blamberg, a spokeswoman for Tate & Lyle.
Joe Crimi, the union's chief negotiator, said the Longshoremen would accept some layoffs or cost-cutting measures, but he insisted that any layoffs had to be by seniority. What he objects to most, he said, is that Tate & Lyle seems to be coming at the union with a meat cleaver.
"They want to take our 59-page contract and delete it down to 5 pages," said Mr. Crimi, vice president of Local 1814. "They're trying to eliminate everything we've gained at the bargaining table over 50 years. It's a disgrace. They want to get rid of seniority. Under the scenario the company has painted, the workers don't have a choice but to hold out."
He said Tate & Lyle's bargaining demands were so aggressive that they suggested that the management was trying to break the union. Tate & Lyle developed a hard-line reputation during a three-year labor dispute that began in 1992, when it locked out 750 workers at a corn sweetener plant in Decatur, Ill. Ultimately, the company broke the union there.
But Ms. Blamberg said the Brooklyn dispute was different. "It's absolutely not true that Tate & Lyle is out to break the union," she said. "Our goal is to work with the union to accomplish change and to make our facility more viable." She added that the company was not seeking to end all seniority.
This is the second grueling strike at the refinery since 1988, when Tate & Lyle bought Domino and its parent company, Amstar. The Domino factory was built by the Havemeyer family, which gave the dazzling Havemeyer collection to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. They grew fabulously wealthy in the decades after the Civil War because New York, led by the family's Brooklyn refinery, processed more than 60 percent of the nation's sugar, filling the vacuum left by the North's destruction of most of the refineries in the South.
The workers proudly assert that their strike has taken a toll on Tate & Lyle. They say the refinery, which continues to be operated by managers and some temporary replacement workers, is processing only about one-tenth of its normal output of four million pounds of sugar a day.
Mr. Crimi said a surprising development last week might push Tate & Lyle to settle. Workers at its Louisiana refinery, one of its three American cane refineries, went on strike, further straining the company's ability to meet its customers' demands.
Assessing the Brooklyn situation, Ms. Blamberg said, "We continue to be hopeful it will be resolved as soon as possible."
But Bruno Zub, a mechanic from Poland, was more pessimistic. "Things are getting worse and worse," he said. "But we can hold out to the end. We have to do this to the end."

HEADLINE: George Jackson, Movie Producer, Dies at 42

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
George Jackson, who grew up in Harlem to become a movie producer, record company executive and Internet company founder, died yesterday at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. He was 42.
Mr. Jackson died after a stroke a week earlier, said Frank Cooper, his business partner. 
 For the last year, Mr. Jackson and his partners had been working in a loft on West 26th Street in Manhattan to create a series of Web sites, called the Urban Box Office Network, aimed at minorities. The first of the Internet sites is expected to go online on Feb. 29. An article in the company's newsletter said that Mr. Jackson had a "25-hour-a-day dedication" to the Internet venture.
Mr. Jackson helped produce "New Jack City," a 1991 movie that portrayed the rise and fall of a drug dealer in Harlem. When fights among youths broke out at movie theaters around the country where the film was playing, Mr. Jackson and his partner, Doug McHenry, defended their movie, saying it carried an antidrug, antiviolence message. In an opinion article in The New York Times, the two men wrote, "The real cause of violence at the theaters is not cinematic images of drug culture but decades of poverty in our communities."
"New Jack City," which brought in $50 million in box office sales in the United States, was the most successful film produced by Jackson-McHenry Entertainment. The company produced 12 films in the late 1980's and early 1990's. Others included "A Thin Line Between Love and Hate" and "Krush Groove," the first major movie to focus on hip-hop and rap.
In 1997, Polygram hired Mr. Jackson to be president and chief executive of Motown Records. At the record company, Mr. Jackson helped promote such artists as 98 Degrees and the Temptations. He left Motown after about a year when the Seagram Company bought Polygram.
In January 1999, Mr. Jackson had dinner with two friends, Mr. Cooper and Adam Kidron, at the Mayflower Hotel in Manhattan. The three came up with an idea for an Internet company aimed at urban minorities, a group they felt was not being served by other start-ups. They wrote out their plan on a napkin.
A year later, Urban Box Office Network has 175 employees and plans 30 Web sites, ranging from one devoted to hip-hop music to another catering to young Latinos.
On the morning of Feb. 2, Mr. Jackson, an energetic man who weighed more than 300 pounds, attended a meeting at the company, but then left because he did not feel well. On his way home, Mr. Jackson asked the cab driver to take him to the hospital, said David Jaye, the company's spokesman. He fell unconscious and never woke up.
Mr. Jackson was born in Harlem on Jan. 6, 1958. He attended the Monsignor Kelly School, a private school for talented children, many of whom came from poor families. He graduated from Fordham Preparatory School in 1976, and obtained a degree in sociology and economics from Harvard College in 1980. At Harvard, Mr. Jackson played football.
He began his career at Procter & Gamble, where he worked for two years in marketing and sales. He then went to Universal Pictures. And from 1984 to 1986 he worked for Richard Pryor's production company, Indigo, which was part of Columbia Pictures, where he was executive vice president of production.
He also worked on projects with, among others, LL Cool J, Russell Simmons, Ice-T, Wesley Snipes and Mario Van Peebles.
Mr. Jackson was on the board at De La Salle Academy, a private school for children in the sixth to eighth grades. He helped found the academy on West 97th Street with his former teacher, Brother Brian Carty, and other alumni from Monsignor Kelly School. The school accepts 135 talented children from low-income families.
Mr. Jackson is survived by his wife, Yuko; a daughter, Kona Rose; his mother, Henrietta Hogan Jackson Stancil; a sister, Dr. Sharon Jackson, of Silver Spring, Md.; and a brother, Bobbie E. Stancil, of Boston.
Clarence Avant, the former chairman of Motown Records, said Mr. Jackson never lost sight of where he grew up.
"He never forgot Harlem," Mr. Avant said. "Sometimes guys can go to Harvard and forget. George understood the street."

HEADLINE: Their Way: Short, but Straight Down the Fairway

BYLINE: By CHARLES McGRATH 

 BODY:
SOME of the happiest people I know are the retired folks who have made a home-away-from-home, a sort of earthly Valhalla, at their local golf course. I hope to join them one day, and though I haven't asked, I'm pretty sure they'll have me. They're not choosy.
The people I have in mind are not country club types; nor are they the well-heeled snowbirds who have taken up roosts along the fairways of Hilton Head or Palm Springs, or even those hordes of savvy pensioners who unloaded the family homestead at the top of the market and got a good deal on a Myrtle Beach condo with a greenside view and a golf cart in the driveway. Those people are all happy, too, but I suspect they take their happiness for granted. 
 The people I'm talking about beam with contentment. "It's like dying and going to heaven," one of them, a retired chauffeur named Vin, explained to me once. "I never wait for a tee time." (Well, of course he never waits for a tee time; he gets to play on weekdays. Even heaven is crowded on Saturday and Sunday.)
You find my kind of retirees at municipal courses and scruffy nine-holers; at my favorite haunts in southeastern Massachusetts, for example: Wampanoag, a k a Swampanoag, where, I have sometimes heard it claimed, mosquito repellent was developed; Hidden Hollow, a time capsule from the 1950's, where drives from the first tee sometimes ricochet off a fossilized gravel mound; and Pine Valley, the other Pine Valley, where some of the most challenging hazards are the giant pylons holding up high-tension wires.
The golfers I have in mind are the ones you see in the clubhouse -- golf caps pushed back on their seamed and tanned foreheads -- playing pinochle and rummy late into the afternoon, without a cell phone or a pager in sight. They always seem to know the starter and the rangers, because in many cases they are the starter and the rangers, willing to put in a few part-time hours in exchange for a break on greens fees.
They also economize by never, ever paying for a golf ball. Their eyes may be going, but they can still disappear into the woods and emerge 50 yards later with pockets bulging. They will find your ball for you when you have given up, and they will throw in a couple of extras. Many of them also have extra-long aluminum ball retrievers, which they patiently dip into the drink, like herons probing for minnows; they never fail to turn up a shiny morsel or two.
When they open their car trunks at the end of the day to stow their gear, you can see, stashed behind the spare tire, buckets and buckets of barely used Titleists, Top-Flites, Wilsons, even some of those extra-costly Nike balls -- the ones guaranteed to fly straight. Imagine what's in their basements: coffee cans, laundry baskets, trash barrels -- all brimming with dimpled white eggs. They're like underground hatcheries.
Have I mentioned that these golfers seldom lose a ball of their own? That's because, with time on their hands, calmness in their hearts and mellowness sluicing through their brainpans, they have made the discovery that only comes with maturity: straight is better than long. Though self-taught, most of them, retired players are good. At a little nine-holer, I once went around twice with a retired electrician so old and frail-seeming that I thought he might evaporate in the heat -- just vanish, leaving a puddle of golf clothes on the fairway. He wound up shooting a 73, which could easily have been a 71 had he not missed a couple of two-footers I tried to give him. (That's another thing: retired golfers don't cheat; they don't need to.)
Here is how you know you're not ready to become a retired golfer: you are so stupid, so filled with rage and yearning and delusion, that you still want to crush the ball. You know it's wrong, but you do it anyway. Good sense will come, as surely as the Social Security checks will. In the meantime, I have been studying and classifying some of the basic retiree golf swings:
1. The Propeller. Actually, I have seen this only once, used by a guy named Ralph, but it was so remarkable that it deserves special mention. Ralph wristed his club around so that it passed right in front of his head and was pointing, upside down, back at the target; then, as if powered by a rubber band, he unwound the club back the other way. Rrrrrp -- 150 yards, right down the middle.
2. The Phone Booth. Probably the most familiar of all retired swing patterns. The backswing and the follow-through are almost equidistant, about 18 inches on each side. No matter what club is used, all shots hit this way tend to go the same distance, but so what -- they are straight as string.
3. The Folding Ruler. Often used by women, this is a sound technique for men as well. Contrary to the preachments of Hogan, Harmon, Ledbetter et al., the left side is allowed to collapse, in pieces -- leg, arm, wrists -- until the club is neatly stashed away, out of sight and out of mind; then, click, click, click, the process is reversed and there the club head is again, squarely smacking the ball.
4. The Sneak Attack. Good for golfers whose paunches get in the way. The club is taken back slowly, out and around the distended area, and then, before the rest of the body knows what's going on, the canny retired brain instructs the hands to lash the club down and under the radar, so to speak. The ball is already on its way, a missile that cannot be recalled -- not that you'd want to take back a stinger like that.
None of these techniques look particularly good, it must be said; neither, for that matter, does the standard retiree's uniform of Bermuda shorts, knobby knees and hairless shanks. But retirement is about what works. Only connect, E. M. Forster wrote; he said nothing about form.
SOME of the retirees I have played with have achieved a level of wisdom that transcends the golf course. A few years ago, for example, I played a couple of rounds at Wampanoag with a threesome that had been together so long they routinely finished one another's sentences. Talking in a kind of interrupted chorus, they gave me stock tips; they instructed me in how to get better gas mileage; they told me which local restaurants served the best Wednesday evening all-you-can-eat buffets. At the seventh tee, while we were waiting for the group ahead -- a ladies' foursome, as it happened -- to get out of range, one of them asked me how long I had been married. Thirty years, I said.
"A rookie!" the chorus began.
"A novice!"
"A kid!"
They then proceeded to deliver almost two centuries' worth of collective wisdom about relations between the sexes. Some of what they said was unprintable. Much of it, now that I try to recall specifics, was variations on the old theme: can't live with 'em, can't live without 'em. But it all seemed profound at the time. These guys were living proof. Here they were, still married -- more than a hundred years of connubial experience striding up the fairway -- and still playing golf together. They would be the first to tell you that they were having the best years of their lives.

HEADLINE: Tenure Gridlock: When Professors Choose Not to Retire

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
LIKE many college presidents, Arthur Taylor has strong feelings about tenure.
"It's a decided problem," said Mr. Taylor, a former president of CBS who since 1992 has been president of Muhlenberg College, a 1,900-student liberal arts institution in Allentown, Pa. "We have no way of asking someone to retire. They literally can go on forever -- and some do." 
 And not just at Muhlenberg. In recent years, as mandatory retirement policies have become illegal -- first in government and private industry, later at colleges and universities -- faculty retirement rates have plummeted, said Robert L. Clark, a professor of economics and business management at North Carolina State University who has studied retirement patterns on the 15 campuses in the state university system.
Dr. Clark found that after 1982, when the federal mandatory retirement age was raised to 70 from 65, retirement rates for professors ages 65 to 69 dropped to 25 percent from 81 percent. When mandatory retirement was eliminated in 1994, the retirement rate for faculty members ages 70 and older fell to 33 percent from 100 percent.
"And if we look down the road, that may be an even bigger deal," Dr. Clark said. Colleges did a great deal of hiring in the late 1960's and early 70's, and those professors are approaching traditional retirement age. Most new tenure-track positions are created when older professors retire. If they decide to stay, there will be few positions for younger professors.
Administrators have some options, of course. In 1998, Congress approved legislation giving universities the right to use certain age-based retirement incentives.
But Mr. Taylor said that had not solved the problem of older, less productive faculty members. "We can try to make it highly attractive for them to go," he said. "But the only way we can get them to go if they don't want to is if they collapse physically and can't come into the classroom."
So, drawing on his corporate background, experience that made him attractive to Muhlenberg's board of trustees, Mr. Taylor has instituted several measures that he believes give Muhlenberg an edge in planning for faculty turnover.
Unusual for academia, these strategies -- the use of merit pay, fixed-term contracts and phased-in retirement -- are straight out of the boardrooms of companies like CBS, where he was president from 1972 to 1976, and International Paper, where he was president for two years before that. He was also dean of the graduate school of business administration at Fordham University for seven years and owned an investment firm.
Mr. Taylor said his methods had a clear objective. "I like to see younger people getting the chance to come along faster," he said.
Tuition, fees and room and board total about $25,475 per student this year at Muhlenberg, but as with most colleges, that covers only part of expenses: personnel costs make up the biggest part of the budget.
When Mr. Taylor took over, Muhlenberg's $32 million endowment was about equal to its debt. At the end of June, the endowment stood at $82 million, while debt had fallen to $18 million.
MUHLENBERG'S faculty appears to have gotten younger in recent years, perhaps because of Mr. Taylor's emphasis on the value of youth. Nearly half of the 140 full-time faculty members have been hired since he took over in 1992. About 18 percent were hired before 1980.
But Mr. Taylor's programs have angered some faculty members, who say that older professors are being denied benefits in favor of younger ones and that a central benefit of tenure -- its promise of freedom from retirement pressure -- is being undermined.
"He makes it quite plain that he views older faculty members as an encumbrance," said Richard C. Hatch, 63, a chemistry professor who has been on the faculty since 1962. "He would just as well see those nearing retirement get out as soon as possible, and I guess I'm one of those."
Dr. Hatch says he is looking forward to retirement at the end of the next academic year, thanks to what he calls "a very good retirement package" offered by Muhlenberg and managed by the pension fund TIAA-CREF. But he adds that he does not appreciate the feeling that he and other senior colleagues are being pushed toward the door.
"I feel more and more like a dinosaur," he said. "It is more difficult to keep up with developments in the discipline, but I also find myself out of step with the attitudes that the newer faculty has towards what a college like this should be."
Some of Mr. Taylor's programs are more familiar in a corporate setting than in a university. One, a merit pay plan, ties every Muhlenberg employee's annual salary increase to a performance evaluation. That has greatly expanded the range of faculty salaries, allowing Mr. Taylor to funnel money to professors he wants to stay and away from those he would rather see go.
But Ludwig F. Schlecht, a 60-year-old professor of philosophy at Muhlenberg, says that as a result, salaries overall at the college are falling behind those at similar four-year private liberal arts colleges. Data from the American Association of University Professors seem to bear him out: full professors at Muhlenberg earned 94 percent of the national average for similar colleges last year, down from 104.5 percent just five years ago. (Associate and assistant professors, who are generally younger, have also seen declines, though not as steep.)
Mr. Taylor has also championed a program to hire some faculty members on contract for a fixed number of years, renewable at the college's option but with no prospect of tenure. That allows the college to know exactly when those professors will be off the payroll. And it gives the college the flexibility to hire a professional in a field like acting who wants to spend a couple of years teaching, or to gauge student demand for a new academic program without making a long-term commitment.
SOME professors are unhappy with these contracts, saying they undermine tenure, and even some administrators acknowledge that the system is unusual. "Depending on how much of a purist you are, it is a system that raises eyebrows because it's not a pure tenure system for faculty," said Curtis G. Dretsch, the dean of the College for Faculty. "We see it not as an erosion of tenure, but as a creative way to deal with certain situations."
Since Mr. Taylor arrived, the number of tenured and tenure-track faculty members has risen to 109 from 95. But in two cases, which Mr. Dretsch described as "very special and unusual circumstances," contracts were used to retain professors who had been denied tenure.
Mr. Taylor has also used phased-in retirements, which gradually lighten an older professor's class load and salary over two or more years, a voluntary easing into retirement that can lighten the college's payroll.
The rate at which faculty members retire can be affected by many factors, researchers have found. Professors enrolled in a traditional defined-benefit pension plan, for example, where the expected value of future benefits begins to decline once a certain age is passed, tend to retire earlier than those in defined-contribution plans, which offer employees more flexibility to control how the money is invested and typically have fewer restrictions on withdrawals.
That could have a significant effect on retirement rates in the future. When offered a choice, most younger professors opt for defined-contribution plans, perhaps making them more likely to work longer.
One variable in that equation, of course, is the unexpectedly high rates of return in defined-contribution plans in the last several years. Professors enrolled in such plans may well have substantially more money than they had anticipated. How those gains will affect retirement decisions remains to be seen.
"Since the elimination of mandatory retirement, the whole playing field has changed," said Eric Kingson, a professor of social work and public administration at Syracuse University. "It raises major questions about how a university assumes orderly turnover of faculty and deals with the demographic bubbles within the faculty as professors age."
One unanswered question is just how the aging of the faculty will affect the financial conditions of American colleges and universities.
But at Muhlenberg, Mr. Taylor thinks his incentives for early retirement have helped create a younger faculty. "I can't think of anybody who is so old that we want him to go," he said.
"I am in favor of people retiring and going on to something else before they get too old to go on to something else," he added. "I'm in my 65th year. I think that is a moment when a woman or a man should stop what they're doing and remake themselves. I truly believe that at age 65, whether you go fishing or become a writer or a painter or a craftsman, you should leave a position open for a younger person. I'm planning to retire -- well, I'd better not say when, because they're betting on it here. But not at a disgraceful age."

HEADLINE: You Don't Have to Be Old to Sue for Age Discrimination

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE nation's courts may have spent years issuing opinions that make it harder for older workers to sue their employers for age discrimination, but that has not discouraged a younger generation of employees from using the antidiscrimination laws more often to challenge being fired or not being promoted fast enough.
And while corporations still win the vast majority of age-discrimination claims, the litigation is forcing many companies to rethink their policies and offer more generous retirement incentives. 
 Lawyers expect that demographic and economic trends could lead to an explosion of age-discrimination cases. The average age of the work force has been steadily increasing. By some estimates, more than 56 million workers will be 45 or older by 2005, an increase of 40 percent since 1994.
That trend probably will collide with another: the gains in productivity that are allowing companies to make more products with fewer workers. Many industries are consolidating, and economic downturns and sweeping layoffs generally lead to more discrimination lawsuits.
"We've got this glut of older workers, many more people in their middle years who are eligible for mid-level and upper-level jobs than are actually available," said Howard C. Eglit, a professor at the Chicago-Kent College of Law and the author of a three-volume treatise, "Age Discrimination."
Mr. Eglit said, "Demographics and the inescapable process of aging that affects every individual, as well as well-entrenched views, assumptions and stereotypes that all of us entertain, ensure that the Age Discrimination in Employment Act is going to continue to play a significant role in the workplace in the next 30 years and beyond."
Mr. Eglit's research shows that the age of the typical age-discrimination claimant has declined steadily, from the 50's to the 40's, and that the number of women filing claims has risen significantly. But even as lawyers anticipate more claims, they say it will not be easy for employees to prevail.
Since Congress and the White House outlawed age discrimination 33 years ago, the courts have chipped away at the law, helping corporate America defend itself.
The courts have raised the burden of proof and limited the use by employees of certain evidence that often correlates with age, saying that while it is unlawful to fire a worker for his or her age, it may be lawful to dismiss an employee for having too high a salary or pension.
They have also restricted the use of class actions, and made it easier to dismiss cases long before jury selection. Last month the Supreme Court decided that millions of state employees could not sue their employers in federal court. Moreover, the cost of litigating age claims has more than tripled in recent years, discouraging many who suspect they are victims from filing claims in the courts. Only a tiny percentage of those complaints that are filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission lead to government-sponsored lawsuits or settlements.
DESPITE the trends and court decisions, workers won important court victories last year, and defense lawyers say many corporations that may have considered age in hiring, promotion and dismissal decisions have become more sensitive to the issue.
In recent months, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission reached a $28 million settlement with Johnson & Higgins, an insurance company, which had imposed a mandatory retirement age.
The commission also resolved a $7 million lawsuit with Thomson Consumer Electronics and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, whose jobs were moved to Mexico. And the commission filed a class-action suit against F. W. Woolworth, accusing it of dismissing 300 workers on the basis of age.
"Our level of activity in this area has remained quite high," said Ida L. Castro, the chairwoman of the E.E.O.C., the federal agency that enforces the Age Discrimination in Employment Act.
Ms. Castro said that a new area of age discrimination had begun to arise over changes in pension programs to cash-balance plans, which often benefit younger workers at the expense of their older colleagues. The commission recently announced the formation of a panel of experts to help the agency decide how to handle more than 250 complaints lodged against companies recently for converting their pension plans.
Whether the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which covers most workers over 40, applies in such situations "is certainly the hot button question now," she said.
The act was adopted after Congress passed landmark legislation in other civil rights areas. Its impetus was discrimination in hiring practices. "Before the law was passed, age discrimination was rampant and obvious," said Laurie A. McCann, a lawyer at the AARP. "There were vast numbers of advertisements for jobs saying no one over 35 or 40 need apply."
While recent studies show that employers still strongly prefer younger workers to older ones with comparable resumes, most cases now brought under the law are about discrimination in firing, not in hiring.
"When you apply for a job, the most you usually find out is that you weren't hired," Mr. Eglit said. "You're not told who was hired or why you weren't hired, and you don't know who the other applicants are. When you're fired, however, you can see if there was a pattern, and you know how you've performed."

HEADLINE: WEIGHING THE OPTIONS/FINANCE;
Extra-Credit Class: Figure Out 401(k)'s

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE; David J. Wallace is a Philadelphia writer on business and technology.

 BODY:
FOR a growing number of entrepreneurs, demographics are now destiny, as millions of workers worldwide see retirement looming less than a decade before them. Responding to the needs of these future retirees, a generation of financial educators has sprung up to offer money counseling for the days ahead. But these new services are not just for older people: younger workers are keeping a watchful eye on their retirement accounts as well.
Determining how many years until retirement is easier than identifying the number of dollars needed to pay for it. More than 38 million people are turning to their 401(k) providers, the Internet and other sources for help in covering the costs of retirement, making retirement planning a skill as crucial as software training was in the last decade. 
 The reasons are many: some employers want to provide as much information as possible to their workers. Others are seeking a haven from potential lawsuits initiated by workers for low-performing, company-sponsored funds or from claims by workers that they were not well informed about the uses of retirement or investment plans.
Employers also might be handicapped by workers who think they cannot afford to retire, leaving employers unable to replace older workers with lower-paid younger ones.
"The 401(k) plan was never designed to be a primary retirement vehicle, but increasingly it will be," said William F. Sharpe, a 1990 Nobel laureate in economics and the chairman of Financial Engines, a Palo Alto, Calif., company that offers online analytical tools to help people review their portfolios. "People need help and there are two models: teach them enough to make decisions themselves, or give them advice from people who are experts."
Mr. Sharpe, a professor emeritus of finance at Stanford University, said people now have to provide for themselves instead of relying on family support or Social Security benefits. The Internet and corporate intranets allow active investors to see more than quarterly results and let companies offer their employees a broader selection of investment choices without raising expenses, Mr. Sharpe said.
For Dorothy and John Siegfried, of Greenville, Del., a recent workshop on retirement planning sponsored by her employer turned the abstract idea of retirement into an exercise in budget forecasting. About 25 of Ms. Siegfried's co-workers at Delaware Health Management spent part of their weekend going over their spending and saving patterns.
"We're trying to calculate when we can retire without cutting back our lifestyle," Ms. Siegfried said. "It's just like preparing a budget. Thinking about where you want to be in 5 or 10 years gives you a better idea of how to make that happen."
The EDSA Group, of Baton Rouge, La., found that planning ahead while avoiding credit-card debt can be important to future retirees. Edward L. Shobe and William R. Pomeroy started the company in 1986 when the Exxon Corporation was seeking proposals to present a retirement planning seminar to its employees.
The company's instructors, who do not solicit individuals for brokerage services, use real numbers in their calculations, which enables the employees to identify their specific needs for retirement, college funds, medical expenses or debt reductions.
"You can never look at just one aspect of it," Mr. Shobe, the EDSA Group's chairman, said. "If we're successful doing our jobs, employees can retire three to five years sooner than expected, and workers like that. But the employer can replace that worker with someone who is paid less, receives less vacation and benefits. It saves the company $52,000 a year, on average."
Fee-based financial planners offer similar courses to companies, but might take the opportunity to solicit within for personal- portfolio management customers, Mr. Shobe said. That can open up an employer to liability if an adviser introduced by the company to a worker jeopardizes that nest egg, another reason EDSA's advisers promise not to solicit private business.
The Vanguard Group, Fidelity Investments and other money-management companies offer educational programs with no sales pitches, too, though they can seek additional business from the company itself.
Demand for investment education has spawned online software programs. Take the one produced by Rational Investors, of Peabody, Mass. Through its Web site (www.rvest.com), visitors can monitor, forecast and enhance their investment choices. Rational Investors was acquired last year by Standard & Poor's. Another Web site, called Understanding and Controlling Your Finances -- www.bygpub.com -- was created by BYG Publishing, of Raleigh, N.C.
Financial education raises the same issues for workers on the shop floor as it does for people in a corner office, said Michelle Owens, a financial consultant with Salomon Smith Barney in Bethesda, Md.
"Loss-aversion is far stronger than the joy of winning, and the learning curve for individual investing is huge," said Ms. Owens, who spoke to about 50 people at a recent conference of business school students at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "My worst clients are business school graduates or people in the financial industry. They're overconfident."
Curtis Brown, a vice president of Merrill Lynch Private Client Group in New York, sees people using 401(k) money for a second home or other indulgences, assuming they can finance their retirement on rapid short-term stock appreciation.
"Companies are not taking the responsibility of educating their people in terms of the risks and responsibilities," Mr. Brown said. "Yes, the individual is empowered now that information has become a commodity. But in a bull market, with Internet stocks, you see a genius mentality where people think they can do no wrong."
Employers have been shifting to 401(k)'s to reduce their liability in the event that a pension plan is underfinanced. Yet the specter of lawsuits might rise if investments fail to appreciate, or if investments lose money and workers claim they were not suitably advised of risks.
"There's a tremendous amount of misinformation in the financial marketplace," said Fred Reish, a Los Angeles lawyer with an expertise in retirement and financial planning. "There have been two lawsuits that have become well known. At the heart of both cases is the duty of the employer to prudently select the investment options and to monitor them on an ongoing basis. That's going to be the most common basis for a suit by employees."
In both cases, one involving retirees from the Unisys Corporation and a second by workers at First Union Corporation, employees claimed that company officials breached their fiduciary duty by offering unsuitable investments to the work force. Employers who fear similar suits have added a wider array of investment options to satisfy a range of workers that includes young, single new hires and long-time workers with large families.
For employers, the benefits of educating employees include a greater number of workers participating in tax-advantage retirement plans. The benefits in terms of time lost in the workplace or in greater peace of mind cannot be measured, said Richard Volpe, a financial planner from suburban Philadelphia whose company is an EDSA Group affiliate.
"Individuals tend to buy low and sell high because of panic," Mr. Volpe said. "And we haven't experienced a real bear market since 401(k) programs were introduced. People are emotional and you can never predict what they'll do."

HEADLINE: Enjoying the Ex-Presidency? Never Been Better

BYLINE: By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
JIMMY CARTER calls it his involuntary retirement.
In 1981, after only four years on the job, he lost the presidency to his chief critic, Ronald Reagan. The voters rejected Mr. Carter as inept and weak, a man unable to secure the release of the American hostages in Iran or to stem double-digit inflation and soaring oil prices and interest rates. 
 Dismissed as a nonentity by his own party, Mr. Carter, a former governor of Georgia, went home to Plains with his wife, Rosalynn, and their teenage daughter, Amy. He was 56 years old, one of the youngest ex-presidents in history. In his book "Everything to Gain: Making the Most of the Rest of Your Life," which he wrote with his wife in 1987, he described awakening to "an altogether new, unwanted and potentially empty life." And he did not feel any better about things when he took a statistical look at his future.
"I realized shortly after I got home that according to the life expectancy tables I had 25 years to go," Mr. Carter recalled in a recent interview in his office at the Carter Center here. "What was I going to do with 25 more years? I was in a little town with 600 people and no job opportunities."
And he needed money. Mr. Carter, who liked to portray himself as a simple peanut farmer, but in fact had a highly successful agricultural business before he went to the White House, discovered shortly after the election that he was broke. The family's farm-supply business, which had been placed in a blind trust while he was president, had been hurt by a severe drought and a lack of personal supervision. The debt came to more than $1 million.
"I didn't have any way to repay a million dollars," Mr. Carter said. "We hoped we could keep our house. We had to honor our debts."
Today, at age 75, as a global humanitarian, writer, professor and multimillionaire landowner, Mr. Carter has a schedule so packed that his close friend and former press secretary, Jody Powell, who is 19 years younger, says he could never keep up. The former president has thrown himself into retirement -- or, more accurately, nonretirement -- with the zeal he once gave to his careers as a Navy submariner, nuclear engineer, farmer and politician.
In 1982 he and Mrs. Carter founded the nonprofit, nonpartisan Carter Center, which promotes peace, human rights and better health care around the world. As the unpaid chairman and vice chairwoman of the board, they travel throughout Asia, Africa and Latin America, negotiating peace, monitoring elections and working to eradicate disease, increase harvests and ease hunger.
In December, Mr. Carter was in Nairobi, Kenya, negotiating an agreement between Uganda and Sudan. The same month, he was in Panama representing the United States in the ceremony marking the handoff of the Panama Canal. In November, he monitored his 29th election, in Mozambique. In October, he made a 13-day trip to Europe and Africa. He met with the prime ministers of Norway and the Netherlands, addressed the Norwegian Institute of International Affairs in Oslo, received an honorary degree from the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine for his work in disease prevention in the third world and toured remote villages in Mali that are using agricultural techniques taught to them by the Carter Center.
And that is just his work abroad. As a distinguished professor at Emory University, he lectures on everything from politics to health care. He builds houses for Habitat for Humanity. He has written 14 books since leaving the presidency and recently completed a memoir of his childhood among the black sharecroppers in tiny Archery, near Plains. He is more than halfway through his first novel, set in Georgia during the Revolutionary War.
Though he no longer farms, Mr. Carter still oversees the timber that grows on his land. He makes all the repairs around his house. He relaxes by building furniture. He makes his own wine. When in Plains, he teaches Sunday school at the Maranatha Baptist Church, where he sometimes mows the lawn and Mrs. Carter scrubs the bathrooms when it is her turn.
On a Sunday in January, out-of-towners packed the small church for one of Mr. Carter's regular lessons. Quoting from the Book of Matthew, the former president told the congregation that Jesus would judge them according to how they shared their time and money with the poor and the less fortunate. After the lesson and the minister's sermon, in another part of the ritual, the Carters stood at the front of the church for more than half an hour, posing for pictures with each visitor who wanted one.
This is retirement?
Mr. Carter's life since the White House has been so overfull and so distinguished -- he has been nominated for the Nobel Prize seven times, and in August he and his wife were both awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom -- that Douglas Brinkley, a historian at the University of New Orleans, wrote a 480-page book about it, "The Unfinished Presidency."
"He burns out Secret Service agents," said Mr. Brinkley, who traveled extensively with Mr. Carter from 1994 to 1996. "They can't keep up with him." Mr. Brinkley compares Mr. Carter's post-presidency with that of John Quincy Adams, who carried his crusade against slavery to Congress, where he served 16 years after leaving the White House, and died at his desk.
President Clinton has begun talking about emulating his predecessor's work at the Carter Center when he retires next year. (After years of cool relations, the two men appear to be more cordial now. When he awarded the Carters the Freedom Medal, Mr. Clinton said they had "done more good things for more people than any other couple on the face of the earth.")
Although Mr. Carter's constant efforts for world peace have generally won him admiration, they have sometimes exasperated diplomats and administration officials. "It can be a problem when you have this freelance peace negotiator parachuting into the world's trouble spots," Professor Brinkley said. "Jimmy Carter has a valid intellectual stance in these situations, which is, 'Let's stop fighting and then negotiate.' But he wants to duplicate the Camp David accords, so sometimes the hubris factor overflows."
 AT a stage of life when most people are easing up, why does this former president push himself with what Professor Brinkley calls a missionary zeal? "His faith teaches him that the haves of the world must help the have-nots," Professor Brinkley said. "As a born-again Christian, it's his duty to put every bit of time and energy he can into both his family, and into helping the less fortunate."
So how does Mr. Carter define retirement? As "a liberation from mandatory duties," he said.
At 62, he started skiing. At 64, he climbed Mount Kilimanjaro; at 70, he climbed Mount Fuji. He still pitches seven innings in the Plains softball games. He and Mrs. Carter enjoy fly fishing, tennis, bicycling, bird watching and jogging. During layovers on plane trips, they jog around the airport.
When he turned 70, Mr. Carter was asked by Barbara Walters which were the best years of his life. He answered, "Now is the best time of all." Five years later, the answer is the same -- "The best time is now."
His approach to late life, which he describes in his book, "The Virtues of Aging," has inspired other retirees who want to remain active and engaged. When he gave the keynote address at the American Society on Aging conference last year in Orlando, he received a standing ovation. In polls, Americans rate him as one of the older people they most admire.
In his office in mid-January, dressed in a gray suit, Mr. Carter looked trim, vigorous and youthful. It was 7:30 a.m. He had risen at 5, as usual, to read, write and prepare for a full day of meetings on everything from nuclear disarmament to health care. He showed no signs of having slept on the sofa in the living room of his apartment at the Carter Center. An ice storm had cut power throughout Atlanta, and his daughter, Amy, who lives nearby and had been left without electricity, had moved in temporarily with her husband, Jim Wentzel, and their six-month-old son, Hugo. Delighted by the unexpected visit, the grandparents had given Jim and Amy the Murphy bed they normally sleep on when they are in town.
The arrival of Hugo, Amy's first child, in July made 11 grandchildren for the Carters. The youngest of their four children, Amy, 32, has a master's degree in art history from Tulane University, but is currently staying home with her baby. Two of the Carters' three sons, Chip, 49, and Jeff, 47, also live in the Atlanta area with their wives and children. Jack Carter, 52, lives in Bermuda with his family.
Like a lot of people, Mr. Carter never planned for retirement. "I never thought about it," he said. "I fully expected to serve four more years in the White House and during those second four years to make plans for what I would do, which really was to live a more dormant life, and maybe write one volume of memoirs. I didn't anticipate the things that we're doing."
He was very clear, however, about the sort of ex-president he did not want to be. "The day after I was defeated in November of 1980, I met with the press and told them I was disappointed, that I was not going to utilize my having been president to make money for myself," recalled Mr. Carter, who donates his lecture fees to the Carter Center. "It was a kind of naive but sincere commitment that I have honored."
Mr. Carter paid off his debts by selling the family peanut warehouse to the Archer Daniels Midland Company. In addition, both Carters signed generous contracts to write their memoirs. Today, Mr. Carter said, they earn much of their income by writing books, most of which have been best sellers. In addition, he said, the 3,000 acres he owns, along with the timber on it, generate a substantial amount of money.
STILL, the Carters live frugally in the modest ranch house they built in 1961, when Mr. Carter gave up his post as a Navy nuclear submarine officer to become a farmer in Plains, surrounded by woods and flanked by a tennis court. Mr. Carter has made much of the furniture himself, including the four-poster walnut bed he and his wife sleep in.
When it came to carving out a new life in postmiddle age, Mr. Carter had a role model in his own family. His mother, known as Miss Lillian, was 55 and working as a registered nurse when her husband, James Earl Carter, died in 1953 at age 59. "After Daddy died, Mother blossomed forth, and she became more herself," Mr. Carter said.
She spent six years as a housemother to a group of hard-partying fraternity students at Auburn University, and ran a nursing home in Blakely, Ga. At 68, she joined the Peace Corps, serving in a small town near Bombay for two years.
"She came back when she was 70," Mr. Carter said. "She made 500 speeches about 'Don't let age limit you,' and about the Peace Corps." His mother died at 85.
Though he is the eldest son, Jimmy Carter has outlived his brother, Billy, and his sisters, Ruth and Gloria. All three, as well as their father, died of pancreatic cancer. As a result, Jimmy Carter, the only one among them who never smoked, is vigilant about his diet, and gets frequent checkups.
Mr. Carter talked in a comfortable armchair, with his foot on the coffee table in front of the sofa. On the opposite wall was a painting of Mrs. Carter and a young Amy that had hung in the White House. Across the room was his large, carved oak desk, a replica of the one that Mr. Carter used in the White House. On either side of the bookcase behind the desk were the American flag, and the presidential flag, which had been in the Oval Office during Mr. Carter's tenure. The bookcases were filled with biographies of everyone from Winston Churchill and Thomas Jefferson to Bach and Beethoven, as well as many volumes about the Middle East, and the work of Mr. Carter's favorite poet, Dylan Thomas.
The office, the Secret Service agents outside the door and the former president's discussion of things like the Carter Center's commitment to eradicating guinea worm disease all combined to create a formal mood. But then, from the Carters' nearby apartment, came the unmistakable sound of a baby crying. The proud grandfather flashed a grin. "That's Hugo," he said. Hugo sleeps in a cradle made by his grandfather. Mr. Carter has made cradles for almost all of his grandchildren.
One perk of the Carters' international work is the frequent- flier miles they accumulate. They use the miles to take their extended family -- 21, counting Hugo -- on Christmas vacations.
They have been to Disneyland, Mexico, Belize and Colorado. Last year, they went to Costa Rica. "Our children get to know each other better," said Mr. Carter, who acknowledged that he, like his father, was an extremely demanding parent. "Our grandchildren get to know each other better."
He teaches his grandchildren to fly fish, starting when they are about 7 or 8 -- "as soon as they can hold a fly rod," he said. One of his greatest pleasures, he writes in "The Virtues of Aging," has been showing his grandson Joshua, who is 15, how to tie flies. "Joshua has really adopted it as a commitment," he said.
At the end of the hour, Mr. Carter's personal secretary, Nancy Konigsmark, came in carrying Hugo, a blue-eyed, round-cheeked blond in a navy blue sweater. Smiling broadly, Mr. Carter reached out for his grandson. Moments later, Mrs. Carter entered the room. At 72, she was slender in a gray pantsuit, with her light brown hair in soft waves around her face.
In the Jimmy Carter Library and Museum, which adjoins the Carter Center, there is a photograph of a young Mr. Carter in his Navy uniform, with an inscription to his bride, "Darling, I love you with all my heart for all my life, Jimmy." They have been married for 53 years and, Mr. Carter writes in "The Virtues of Aging," they are closer than ever.
In a brief section of the book about sexuality among older people, he writes about their relationship. "When I was married at the age of 22 and relishing an active sex life," he writes, "I assumed that this was a pleasure that my middle-aged parents rarely, if ever, enjoyed. Now, well past 70, Rosalynn and I have learned to accommodate each other's desires more accurately and generously, and have never had a more complete and enjoyable relationship."
"Rosalynn made me tone that down a little," Mr. Carter said.
Though Mrs. Carter writes her own books, and has her own projects in the subjects of mental health and aging, they are partners in most other pursuits. "There is a much more intimate and gratifying partnership now," Mr. Carter said. "When we first got married, I was dominant, like my father was."
It was not until he got into politics that they became equals, he said. "When I decided to run for the state Senate, my first venture into political office, I got up one morning -- this is amazing to me in retrospect -- instead of putting on my work clothes, I put on my Sunday trousers," Mr. Carter said, recalling his successful bid for Georgia State Senate in 1962. "Rosalynn asked me if there was a funeral. I said, 'I'm going to go and qualify for the Senate.' I hadn't discussed it with her in advance, which to me now is inconceivable. I still can't believe I did it then."
LIKE many couples in retirement, the Carters have had to renegotiate aspects of their relationship. "When we first came home from the White House, I didn't know what we were going to do," said Mrs. Carter, talking in her office later in the morning. "We'd never been at home together."
They set up separate offices, his in the former garage, hers in one of their sons' bedrooms. "We were way apart," Mrs. Carter said. "We did it on purpose."
While her husband would get up at 5 and start working, Mrs. Carter said that she would not arrive at her office until 8:30 or 9, just when he was ready to take a break. "He'd come in and say, 'Let's have a cup of coffee,' " she said. "Well, I had just started to work. We finally put a sign on my door that said 'Do not interrupt, working hours from 9 to 12.' He was the one who suggested it."
So, is Jimmy Carter mellowing? "I wouldn't get carried away with that," said Jody Powell, who now runs a public relations firm in Washington. "The folks that work down there say he hasn't gotten any less hardheaded."
There are signs that Mr. Powell's former boss has had to accommodate to the advancing years. "I used to run seven miles a day," Mr. Carter said. "Now, I run three miles. I don't think at my age I want to climb Mount Kilimanjaro." He did add, however, that he "could probably do it."
He talked about putting in fewer hours at the Carter Center so he could spend more time with his family. "I can see the time when I would like to be in Plains more, at home," he said. "There are some things that I would like to continue to do myself -- the last phases of mediating a peace agreement or a cease-fire, or attending the actual voting in a national election and my personally certifying whether the election was legitimate or fraudulent.
"But the daily administration of the Carter Center," he went on, "the hiring and firing, the choosing of leaders, the identification of interns, the arrangement of conferences, I'm withdrawing from those things."
That seems to be news to everyone around him. Asked about what her husband had said, Mrs. Carter laughed. "We talk about it all the time," she said. "We talked about it a couple years ago. We were going to cut back. But nothing happens."
She cannot imagine her husband sitting around. "If he doesn't have a project, I'm miserable," she said. "I can't get anything done."

HEADLINE: WEIGHING THE OPTIONS/HEALTH CARE;
The Insurance You Really Hope You Will Never Need

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
ALONG with the good news that Americans are living longer comes the sobering prospect that many will lose the ability to take care of themselves. And long-term care -- whether in a nursing home, in an assisted-living center or in one's own home -- can be frightfully expensive.
A year in a nursing home, for example, can cost more than $100,000 in New York City; the national average is almost $50,000. An apartment or room in an assisted living center, with health professionals on hand, can easily run to $30,000, and care at home can be even more costly. 
 While Medicare and conventional health insurance policies do not cover these costs, many companies offer policies that do. For people who buy them relatively early, in their 40's through their early 60's, the premiums can be surprisingly modest, starting at a few hundred dollars a year.
But buying such insurance can be tricky.
For starters, it is a gamble, because most people will never use it. Only about 10 percent of people now in their 60's will ever need long-term care, said Robert Atchley, the chairman of the gerontology department at Naropa University in Boulder, Colo., who bases the estimate on data from the National Center for Health Statistics. Even for people who reach their 80's, he said, the figure is less than half.
This does not mean that long-term-care insurance is necessarily a bad idea. "You're buying coverage against a catastrophe," said Melissa Gannon, a senior researcher at Weiss Ratings in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla., a firm that evaluates the financial strength of insurance companies and advises on health insurance. "If the catastrophe happens, it was money well spent."
Dr. Atchley notes that any kind of insurance is something of a gamble. "When you buy car insurance, do you hope you're going to cash in on it?" he asked. "No, you hope you don't need it."
Still, deciding whether to buy long-term-care insurance, how much to buy and from whom requires careful balancing of costs and benefits.
DO YOU NEED IT? -- Strictly speaking, nobody needs long-term-care insurance because there is a safety net: Medicaid, the federal and state program that covers health care for people with low incomes. Nearly 40 percent of all long-term care is financed by Medicaid; many beneficiaries are formerly middle-class people whose savings have been drained by the high cost of care.
But many experts advise against relying on Medicaid. "In lots of parts of the country there aren't many Medicaid spaces," Dr. Atchley said, "and places that have space are often places you wouldn't want to live."
Still, people who cannot afford the premiums for long-term-care insurance do have Medicaid to fall back on. By contrast, wealthy people who could easily afford the premiums might decide to do without the insurance because they can reach into their own pockets if disaster strikes.
The most likely candidates for long-term-care insurance, experts say, are neither rich nor poor but relatively comfortable: couples with savings of $150,000 to $450,000, and annual retirement incomes of $70,000 or more. For these people, the right kind of long-term-care insurance could be a good bet: the benefits can reach several times the premiums paid and can protect an estate from heavy losses.
Under one plan, a 64-year-old New Jersey resident could buy a very basic long-term-care policy at a fixed premium of $460 a year. If after 20 years he needed nursing care, the premiums would have totaled $9,200 but the benefits could reach $73,000 -- $100 a day for up to two years in a nursing home or assisted-living center. With most policies, the companies stop collecting premiums when they start paying benefits.
Coverage is relatively inexpensive for people in their 40's and 50's, then rises steeply, especially for a comprehensive policy -- one that pays a wide range of expenses in almost any kind of institution, as well as care at home. The United Seniors Health Cooperative, a nonprofit organization in Washington, says comprehensive coverage for a 75-year-old can cost more than $6,000 a year.
Some experts point out that insurance is not the only way to deal with long-term care. Some families, for instance, may decide to take care of elderly relatives themselves. "Parents and children ought to sit down and talk about whether anybody wants to take care of Mom and Dad and whether they should spend the inheritance on themselves," said Robert Hunter, the director of insurance at the Consumer Federation of America.
And there are other ways of setting money aside for long-term care, including a reverse mortgage, in which a bank advances you the value of your home, then claims it when you die. The loan does not have to be repaid as long as you live in your home.
WHERE TO BUY IT? -- Many companies sell long-term-care insurance, and experts say some policies are barely worth the paper they are printed on. "There are lots of loopholes and provisos," Mr. Hunter said. "Make sure you understand any kind of limitations and exclusions."
It is important to shop around, because premiums can vary as much as $1,000 a year for essentially the same coverage. And experts strongly recommend sticking to the dozen or so companies that have cornered 80 percent of the business.
Smaller, newer companies may offer coverage that sounds wonderful at amazingly low prices, but experts say they may well raise premiums later. While premiums are theoretically fixed from start to finish, state regulators will permit insurers to raise rates -- perhaps astronomically -- if their expenses increase.
HOW MUCH TO BUY? -- One guiding rule, the experts say, is to make sure you can afford the premiums for the rest of your life. If you drop the coverage after 15 years, you will generally have nothing to show for it.
Experts say those who can afford it should buy comprehensive coverage. "People say, 'I don't want to go into a nursing home,' and therefore won't buy any policy with nursing home in it," said Nancy P. Morith, the owner of N. P. Morith, a brokerage firm in Princeton, N.J., that specializes in long-term-care insurance. But then, she said, if they have to go into a nursing home, they are out of luck.
Likewise, cheaper policies may cover nursing-home care only, leaving policyholders stuck with the bills for care at home or with assisted living, which might be their first choice. The approaches to care for older people are changing rapidly, so you want a policy flexible enough to cover services that are developed in the future.
To figure out the daily benefit you might need, find out what nursing homes charge where you expect to be. The rates will rise with inflation, of course; experts recommend a policy that offers inflation protection. It typically provides for a 5 percent increase in benefits, compounded annually. At that rate, a $73,000 benefit would grow to $193,644 in 20 years.
With the best policies, you can begin receiving benefits when you begin needing help with two out of six essential daily activities, like getting dressed and bathing, or when you need supervision for the protection of yourself or others.
HOW TO SAVE MONEY? -- Even though older people rarely spend more than two or three years in a nursing home, experts recommend unlimited or lifetime benefits. But if you need to reduce costs, the experts say, cut the length of coverage to two to five years and stick with the full range of services. When the policy expires, you may need to fall back on Medicaid.
If you think you will be able to afford some of the costs, and are looking for a policy that will cover only a catastrophically long-term illness, consider signing up for the longest possible deductible (what insurers call the elimination period). Premiums for policies with a 90-day deductible, meaning that you pay the first 90 days out of pocket, are lower than for those that pay from the first day you need help.
The premiums for some kinds of policies are tax-deductible. But before the deduction can be taken, total health expenses must exceed 7.5 percent of gross adjusted income. And these policies typically require patients to be quite frail before they can qualify for benefits.
Some policies offer other features that are probably not worth the extra cost. "Nonforfeiture," for example, gives you a partial refund or delivers partial benefits if you cancel your policy. Martin Weiss, the chief executive of Weiss Ratings, said this feature is rarely used and increases the premium.
He also advises against the feature that permits you to stop and start benefits, turning the clock back to full benefit status if you go six months without drawing on the policy. Once people start drawing benefits, Mr. Weiss said, they seldom stop.

What to Pay
Annual premiums for long-term-care insurance vary widely. Weiss Ratings, a private company that evaluates insurers, calculates that a hypothetical 64-year-old New Jerseyan could expect to pay the following.
Basic: Up to two years in a nursing home or assisted-living center; first 90 days not covered. $460 to $750 a year.
Comprehensive: Unlimited period for any kind of care. $1,306 to $2,543 a year.
 
Where to Shop
More than 100 companies sell long-term-care insurance. Experts recommend sticking with the largest, which are considered least likely to raise premiums to cover unexpected expenses. As of 1998, these were the 10 largest by market share, according to A. M. Best, the insurance rating company.

HEADLINE: 3 Retirees Rate Life After Work

BYLINE: By SHELLY FREIERMAN 

 BODY:
How's retirement? Here is what a few retirees have to say about how they are managing, especially financially.
 
HWillie Ed Morgan, 73
Willie Ed and Ethel Morgan, both retired teachers, will celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary on April 11. They live in South Bend, Ind.
I retired when I was 62 in 1988. Ethel retired two years later. I started thinking about retirement in my late 40's. I knew I wanted to be completely out of debt and have the house paid for. I bought an apartment building in Jackson, Miss., and we're still getting income from it.
We helped the kids financially until I was about 55. Then we started putting the money into annuities. Now, both of us are retired, with income from Social Security and pensions from the state. We own the house, which we've been in for 23 years. We're earning about the same income as when we were teaching.
I don't have too many regrets about our careers, even though I had problems with racism. Ethel earned her degree in library science after she graduated from college. I worked as a merchant marine and a Chicago transit worker before I earned my teaching degree. We wanted to have time to spend with the kids, who are all grown now. We have two doctors, a lawyer and a C.P.A.
My wife spends a lot of time with the Links, a social service organization run by black professional women. I'm a delegate to the United Methodist assemblies for our church, and I serve on two mayoral boards.
Now, we have two grandchildren in college. We see the process go on with our children like it went with us. I offer advice, unsolicited, of course. They never take it.
 
Renee Shapiro, 69
Mrs. Shapiro retired in 1998 and moved from River Edge, N.J., to Cranbury, N.J., where she lives in the Ponds, a retirement community.
I have two boys. I didn't start working until my youngest son was 11 because my husband wanted me to stay home. I worked in a pediatric doctor's office, and even after I moved down here, I worked twice a week, then once a week. I have a pension and a 401(k) plan from work. When they started the plans, I thought I could use that money to spend on something, but now I'm glad I took part.
I really miss my husband. He died about a year after we moved here in 1996. I thought I'd be working and living in River Edge forever. My husband probably was not feeling so good when we left. Now I'm glad we moved.
At first, I said to myself, What am I going to do if I'm not getting up and dressing for work? Now I go to the gym about four or five times a week, and I belong to the women's club, the computer club and the singles club. And I'm captain of the speedwalkers club, which is a sort of Olympics for about a dozen senior developments. The race is a relay of a quarter mile, and last year we won a silver medal.
 
Jim Schroff, 68
Mr. Schroff, who is single, lives in Manhattan.
I go to the Manhattan Bridge Club about three or four afternoons a week. Bridge requires concentration and skill, and it's fascinating to try and beat your opponents. When you get older you have to have something that occupies your mind and something that occupies your body.
I grew up in the Bronx during the Depression. We were dirt poor. My father was a building superintendent when he wasn't unemployed. He had no retirement. He was in his early 70's when he died, and he was still working. All I ever wanted was 10 good years of health after I retired. Now my doctor says, "You're going to live a long time." Then you begin wondering if you'll run out of money.
I was one of nine children, only the second child to graduate from high school and the first to graduate from college. I'm very conservative when it comes to spending because I grew up with no money.
I retired from my job as a corporate lawyer when I was 58, and did some consulting work for four years after that. I'm living on my pensions, my savings and my Social Security.
I'm not hurting now, but I wish I had taken more advantage of investment opportunities. All of the advisers suggest you start thinking about retirement in your 30's or early 40's. I didn't start until my late 40's. I didn't take advantage of the maximum allowed in the deferred savings plans.
My advice to people today: If you can afford it, stash away as much as you can while you are still working. You never can tell what's going to happen.
