HEADLINE: WEIGHING THE OPTIONS/FINANCIAL;
America's Nest Egg Is: a. Big b. Paltry c. All of the Above

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BY some measures, Americans are growing increasingly profligate, choosing to spend everything they have, and more, on big-screen televisions, restaurant meals and vacations. How many will spend it all by the time they retire?
Looking at the question in the broadest sense, there is little doubt that Americans are putting today ahead of tomorrow. 
 The personal savings rate, for one, has plummeted over the last seven years, declining to 2.4 percent of disposable income in 1999 from 8.7 percent in 1992.
Meanwhile, many households have run up their debts to dangerous levels; the Federal Reserve Board reported recently that in 1998, 12.7 percent of families -- up from 10.5 percent three years earlier -- were carrying debt payments of more than 40 percent of income, a traditional benchmark for imprudent borrowing.
"The one thing that no one seems to know how to fix in America is how we get the personal savings rate back up," President Clinton said in an interview.
Yet the talk of gloom and doom does not reflect the experience of many people in recent years. Americans may not be saving as much, but they are growing wealthier nonetheless, largely because of the stock market. To the extent that their net worth is increasing, they are better prepared for the future, including retirement.
The proportion of households that own stock directly or indirectly (through mutual funds and retirement plans) rose to 48.8 percent in 1998 from 40.4 percent three years earlier and 31.6 percent in 1989, according to the Fed. The net worth of the median family rose to $71,600 in 1998 from $60,900 in 1995, a 17.6 percent increase.
The percentage of families that reported saving anything has bounced up and down in the last decade: in 1998, it stood at 55.9, according to the Fed. But among those households that do save, the proportion reporting that putting away money for retirement was their main goal in saving rose to 34.7 percent in 1998 from 25.5 percent in 1995 and 20.4 percent in 1989.
"The situation is not as bad as it looks on the surface," said Paul Yakoboski, a senior research associate at the Employment Benefits Research Institute in Washington. "Since the savings statistics are not capturing the wealth run-up in existing savings, it makes things look worse than they are."
The question of whether the good news outweighs the bad hangs heavily over efforts to analyze how adequately Americans, and especially the 76-million-strong baby boom generation, are preparing for a retirement that could come sooner and last longer than many people expect.
TO the degree that there is an answer, it is that some people are doing quite well and others abysmally, and that everyone will be greatly affected by how the stock market performs in the years and decades to come.
"We have a very split nation when it comes to a lot of these issues," said David M. Certner, the senior coordinator for economic issues at the AARP.
In some ways, the situation is a manifestation of the broader division of society between rich and poor, haves and have-nots.
"About half the population is covered in pension plans of one sort or another, and most of them have a 401(k) and are contributing to it," said Sylvester J. Schieber, the vice president for research and information at Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a consulting firm.
"Of the half not covered by a pension plan," Mr. Schieber said, "some we don't need to worry about too much -- young people just starting out, people working part time by choice, self-employed people accumulating value in their business. But then there is a group of people who aren't covered by any plans and for the most part are not doing any savings outside of them."
But even among people who have a retirement program, analysts say there is a divide between those who have the knowledge and sophistication to handle their money well over the long run and those who are basically winging it.
That divide, they say, is increasingly important as the nation leaves behind the days of traditional defined-benefit corporate pensions, where the only variables were length of employment and retirement age. The 401(k) program and the possibility that Social Security could be overhauled to include private investment accounts have put a premium on knowing how much to save and how to invest it.
"More and more what we're doing is putting the responsibility for accumulating sufficient assets for retirement on the backs of workers, but not educating workers as to what their responsibility is," Mr. Schieber said.
An entire generation of savers now takes for granted double-digit annual returns from Wall Street -- and has never experienced a protracted downturn in the market.
"What happens if the market corrects 25 percent and all of a sudden we're not as wealthy as we were?" asked Mr. Yakoboski, of the Employment Benefits Research Institute. "How will people respond? Will they increase savings out of personal income? That's a wait-and-see issue."
Of course, research into the adequacy of savings is often not conclusive, because so much depends on assumptions about investment returns and other factors like inflation and expanding life spans.
For all the risks inherent in the market these days, analysts have been fretting for years that savers are too timid in allocating their money, favoring lower-risk investments like government bonds at the price of giving up the historically higher rates of return from stock.
A new study by the Employee Benefit Research Institute and the Investment Company Institute concluded that most people with 401(k) plans allocate their money appropriately, with younger people willing to take more risk and older people more likely to protect the capital they have amassed.
The study found that people in their 20's, for example, invested 62.1 percent of their assets in stock funds, 4.7 percent in guaranteed investment contracts (like an annuity) and 4.7 percent in bond funds. People in their 60's, by contrast, put 39.8 percent of their assets in equities, 20.6 percent in guaranteed investment contracts and 9 percent in bonds. Each age group put the rest of its assets in a variety of other investment options.
But the wealth of a substantial part of the population is not in the market.
"The bad news is that many households are not well informed about savings and investment vehicles," said Stephen Brobeck, the executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, an advocacy group. "That is offset by the fact that savings for most families is primarily still through Social Security, employment-related retirement programs and their home equity. There is less opportunity to make very poor decisions in those areas than if you're e-trading."
FOR many people, even those who have saved diligently and intelligently, the biggest risk may not be financial but demographic. Retirees are living longer and outliving their wealth, a phenomenon that some analysts think could become a much bigger problem as biomedical advances continue.
"There is a substantial risk, if you want to look at it that way, that we will see substantial improvements in mortality among the old," said Chris Carroll, an economics professor at the Johns Hopkins University. "That would have a big effect on the adequacy of people's retirement savings outside Social Security."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Stuart Goldenberg)
 
Chart: "Social Security May Need Social Security"
Since its inception in 1935, Social Security has become the largest income-maintenance program in the United States. For most retirees, it is essential: 3 out of 5 beneficiaries aged 65 or older rely on it for at least half their annual income. Yet despite the current budget surpluses, several worrisome trends are putting Social Security at risk.

HEADLINE: In Tribute To Your Year Of Service

BYLINE: By BRENT BOWERS 

 BODY:
A GOLD watch as a retirement gift? A hopeless anachronism, snorted Edward L. Hansen, a former director of marketing at William M. Mercer, a consulting firm in New York.
No, what is called for in this day and age is the personal touch, said Mr. Hansen, who retired last summer at age 63 and moved to San Diego. That was the approach his colleagues took, at least, showering thoughtful gifts on him. Knowing that he is an avid cyclist, they bought him a gift certificate to a local bike shop as well as an ergonomic bike saddle and a guidebook to California bike routes. Knowing that he likes to go to the beach, they also bought him a beach umbrella, a beach blanket and an insulated snack kit. And knowing that he is addicted to two national newspapers, they bought him two-year subscriptions to both. "If I had gotten a gold watch," Mr. Hansen said, "I would've put it in my bureau drawer, and at some point, when my estate was being sorted out, one of my heirs would say: 'Oh, look. Here's this gold watch. Who gets it?' " 
 Most companies, in fact, abandoned the tradition of doling out precious-metal watches to retiring workers long ago, and even lovers of gold watches say the reasons for the change are obvious. People change jobs more than they used to, meaning that timepieces have lost their luster as a token of a company's gratitude for employee loyalty. People also retire in more robust health, meaning they have more pressing preoccupations than keeping track of time. The influx of women into the workplace in the last few decades has also eroded the very male-oriented practice.
Now just hold on one minute, responded Max S. Beschloss, a 72-year-old former vice president for advertising at Longines-Wittnauer and now a consultant for the New York maker of luxury watches, which has been renamed Wittnauer International.
When Mr. Beschloss retired from Wittnauer in January 1996 after 25 years, he was given a solid-gold Lifetime Plus watch, guaranteed to be repaired free until the death of a designated heir, which he figured would be his 40-year-old middle son, Adam. Gold watches passe? "Most jewelers would disagree," Mr. Beschloss said. "It's something you see every day of your life, a reminder of the company's gratitude."
For Mr. Hansen, Mr. Beschloss had these thoughts: "What's a bike? God bless you, you're an enthusiast. Don't break your neck. But a watch? I need it."
So, what has replaced the gold watch as a retirement gift?
"Money!" declared Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate magnate, whose vast holdings employ thousands of people. "It's called severance. It's called 401(k)." Mr. Zell admitted to a fondness for gold watches -- he owns four or five -- but said that their days as retirement-dinner mainstays were gone.
"Wearing a gold watch is like wearing a badge that says, 'I worked in one place for 35 years,' " he said. "Nobody wants to wear that badge anymore."
Ah, but they used to, in a big way, too. John F. Gelson, 68, a former president of the Hamilton Watch Company, now a brand of the Swiss-based Swatch Group, remembered how General Motors, AT&T and most Fortune 500 companies had contracts with Hamilton or other luxury-watch makers to provide retirement-gift watches to employees. "The option we gave was a gold watch or a mahogany mantel clock," said Mr. Gelson, who lives in Lancaster, Pa.
Such luxury gifts were easy for corporations to chop when the cost of their health care plans soared in the 1980's, Mr. Gelson said. Chop they did. When he retired in 1991 after 11 years at Hamilton, he said, "I got zilch."
It is not as if the premium watchmakers are hurting. Imports of watches with gold, platinum or silver cases surged to 2,020,000 in 1998 from 1,190,000 in 1997, according to government statistics on imports. (Almost all such watches are made overseas.) Why the surge? "As James Carville said, 'It's the economy, stupid,' " replied Toby Collado, a lobbyist for the American Watch Association, an industry group in Washington.
If there is one place where the old ways survive, it must be Switzerland, the heartland of fine watchmaking. Right?
Well, sort of.
IT goes without saying that Rene Castella, a Swiss business executive whose family has owned and sold two precious-metal watch companies, loves precious-metal watches.
Mr. Castella, 46, who manages the American operations of the family business, DIXI Le Locle Holding, a Swiss maker of high-precision machine tools, out of Elmsford, N.Y., owns a bunch of them. His favorite is a Zenith with El Primero movement, the best watch in the world, he said, which he wears every day.
The traditional retirement gift in Switzerland was actually an elaborate clock, not a watch, he said. But now, most big Swiss companies give cash instead of clocks, and the recipients "won't buy a Swiss clock with it," Mr. Castella said.
Still, there are holdouts, and DIXI Le Locle Holding is one. In deference to modern sensibilities, the company offers cash or a gold watch to its retiring employees at its home base. But, Mr. Castella boasted that 90 percent of them take the watch. "This is Switzerland, after all," he said. "The Swiss people have money in the bank. They save money. Here in America, they spend it."

HEADLINE: Imagining a Ticket Booth As a Stairway to the Stars;
A New Design for the TKTS Booth Off Times Square

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
A familiar New York landmark, the ramshackle pipe-and-canvas TKTS booth at the northern end of Times Square, will be transformed into a bright red grand staircase that will provide visitors to the city with front-row seats to one of the best shows in town.
The stairs will rise gently from the base of the statue of Father Duffy, for whom the TKTS traffic island is named, and reach a height of 16 feet. The new sales booth for marked-down theater tickets will be tucked beneath the high end of the stairs. After buying a ticket, theatergoers will be able to sit on the steps, bask in the sun and take in the ever-changing public theater that is Times Square itself. 
 The design, by the Australian architects John Choi and Tai Ropiha, was announced yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Construction is to begin later this year.
The existing TKTS booth, an aging trailer adorned with bright red initials, was installed in Duffy Square 27 years ago. It sells more than $1.7 million in discount tickets annually and is operated by the Theater Development Fund, a nonprofit performing arts organization. In June the fund said it would sponsor a design competition to replace the old booth.
"It will add some beauty and some usefulness," said Mayor Giuliani.
Mr. Choi, 28, and Mr. Ropiha, 36, both of Sydney, had visited New York just once before coming to the city to receive their $5,000 award for the design. They said they had based their impressions of Times Square on films, magazines and television coverage of New Year's Eve celebrations. "We were reacting to the visual buzz," Mr. Ropiha said, "and tried to create a strong singular image in contrast."
"We wanted something quiet that would act as a foil to all that energy," said Mr. Choi.
The staircase will be made of red resin planks. The TKTS logo, which is under copyright to the Theater Development Fund, will be emblazoned in black letters about five feet tall on the east and west sides of the structure. The ticket-buyers line will snake along the sidewalk around the statue of the Rev. Francis Patrick Duffy, the Roman Catholic priest, army chaplain and World War I hero.
Jack L. Goldstein, the executive director of the Theater Development Fund, said of the competition: "We wanted an image that was up-to-date and elastic and not so ad hoc. We were looking for something that had cleverness, visual economy and force."
The new design also had to provide a few more sales windows than the current eight and offer reasonable comfort for the ticket sellers within the artificially lit, no-frills space. The Theater Development Fund is also considering adding a public bathroom. The project is expected to cost as much as $2 million, to be raised by the fund.
Prizes went to other designs selected from among 683 entries from 31 countries. The jury was made up of architects, designers, officials representing the Times Square business improvement district, and theater industry experts.
Second prize went to Thomas Phifer, a New York architect in association with the local engineering firm Ove Aup. His design calls for a raked glass roof extending over the entire square as well as over the statues of Father Duffy and George M. Cohan, who is also commemorated in the square. A raised platform will include concealed heating and air conditioning ducts for the comfort of ticket buyers as they wait.
Third place was shared by Piero Lissoni Associates, a group of 16 architects from Milan who proposed a minimalist box with a translucent wall etched with a ghostly logo and with L.E.D. panels inlaid into the pavement, and Leo Mieles, a Toronto architect who proposed a performance space on the roof. There were four honorable mentions: Rahman Polk and Byron Terrell of Chicago; Mauk Design of San Francisco; Lippincott and Margulies of New York; and U-Arc Studio of Seattle.
"There wasn't much room for an entirely radical solution," said Raymond Gastil, executive director of the competition's organizer, the Van Alen Institute, a civic organization committed to improving the public realm through architecture. "But the entries say a lot about the raw energy and talent that's out there."
The range of the designs was considerable, from a booth conceived as twin green crystals to a three-dimensional rendition of Mondrian's painting "Broadway Boogie Woogie."
Marion Weiss, a New York architect who served on the jury, remarked on "the outpouring of innovation" reflected in the design entries. An exhibition of the top designs and 32 other entries will open tomorrow at the Van Alen Institute, at 30 West 22nd Street. The institute has arranged for 200 more images to go on display today at the Urban Center at 457 Madison Avenue, between 50th and 51st Streets.
The search for a new TKTS booth did not go off without a hitch. No sooner was the competition announced than the Coalition for Father Duffy protested the very existence of the booth in Duffy Square. Maj. Gen. Joseph A. Healey, co-chairman of the coalition, wanted to ensure that any new booth would not stand taller than Father Duffy. He rallied his membership, "vets from Buffalo to Montauk," he said, who inundated the mayor's office with more than 7,000 postcards.
Representatives of the coalition was thus allowed to view the winning entries in advance of the announcement and to meet with Mayor Giuliani "to make sure we didn't make a flap" at the official announcement, General Healey said. He added that he liked the winning proposal. "The statue is singularly placed and totally visible and identifiable within a very busy setting, " he said.
Mr. Choi and Mr. Ropiha will soon return to Sydney and their jobs as designers at Hassell, one of Australia's largest architectural firms. While visiting this week, they said, they did attend a couple of plays but never waited in line at TKTS: the Theater Development Fund supplied them with tickets.

HEADLINE: Rise in Ads Gives a Lift To CBS Profit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The CBS Corporation, which is being bought by Viacom Inc. for about $37 billion, said fourth-quarter profit rose, fueled by higher advertising revenue at the television and radio operations.
Profit from continuing operations rose to $19 million, or 3 cents a share, from $3 million, or break-even, in last year's fourth quarter. The company, owner of the CBS television network and a controlling stake in the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, said revenue jumped 24 percent to $2.22 billion from $1.79 billion. 
 CBS's recent acquisitions of King World Productions Inc., the No. 1 television-show distributor, and Outdoor Systems Inc., the largest United States billboard company, helped lift revenue. Rising demand for ads, driven by a booming economy and spending by Internet companies, allowed CBS to charge higher ad rates at its No. 2-rated TV network and at its TV and radio stations, particularly in large cities.
"The network and TV stations had a tremendous quarter," said Niraj Gupta, a Schroder & Company analyst who has an "outperform significantly" rating on CBS. "And clearly the large-market radio stations are benefiting disproportionately from dot-com spending."
CBS said cash flow jumped 85 percent, to $523 million from $282 million. CBS defines operating cash flow as earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, minority interests and equity losses. Cash flow is used by many analysts and investors to measure the performance of broadcasting companies because it focuses on operations and excludes interest payments and noncash charges like depreciation.
CBS was expected to earn 2 cents a share, the average estimate of five analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. CBS shares fell $1.75, to $62.50. The stock had risen 75 percent over the last 12 months.
Mel Karmazin, the chief executive, said the earnings report was probably the last that CBS would issue as a stand-alone company.
Mr. Karmazin said he hoped that Viacom, the world's fifth-largest media company, would complete its acquisition of CBS by the end of next month or in early April. The merger still needs the approval of the Department of Justice and the Federal Communications Commission.
Ad sales at Infinity Broadcasting, CBS's radio and billboard arm, increased 32 percent, to $759 million from $573 million. CBS gets about 60 percent of its revenue and cash flow from Infinity, home to the Howard Stern and Don Imus national radio shows. Shares of Infinity fell $1.6875, to $36.3125.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Kremlin Insiders Acquire Big Siberian Aluminum Plants

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Boris A. Berezovsky and Roman Abramovich, financiers with close ties to the Kremlin, have acquired three important Russian aluminum smelters in eastern Siberia in deals that would give them nearly full control over the country's enormous aluminum industry.
Mr. Abramovich is already the principal owner of Sibneft, a leading Russian oil conglomerate. Mr. Berezovsky is widely believed to have a stake in the company as well, though Sibneft has never confirmed it. 
 But a company spokesman said on Monday that some of Sibneft's major shareholders acquired controlling interests last week in the Bratsk aluminum plant and the Krasnoyarsk aluminum plant from Lev Cherny, a Russian emigre business executive with extensive interests in the metals industry, and in Trans-World Metals Ltd., a British trading company that is heavily engaged in Russian mining and smelting.
A spokesman for Mr. Cherny said the sales have almost been completed, while a Trans-World representative confirmed only that his company is negotiating with Sibneft shareholders. Those involved declined to disclose the size of the stakes sold or the value of the transaction.
Last Thursday, the owners of the Novokuznetsk aluminum plant announced that they had sold their 70 percent stake in the smelter to LogoVaz, a company controlled by Mr. Berezovsky.
The Bratsk, Krasnoyarsk and Novokuznetsk factories together accounted for about two-thirds of the 3.4 million tons Russia produced in 1999, its output second only to that of the United States. The Bratsk plant, which by itself produced nearly 960,000 tons last year, is considered the largest smelter in the world.
The Sibneft spokesman said the shareholders would announce their development plans for the smelters they had acquired later this week.
"This is part of a general trend in Russian industry for companies to stake out more and more of the economy while they can," said Ivan Mazalov, oil analyst for the Russian brokerage firm Troika Dialog.
The period between the tenure of Russia's former president, Boris N. Yeltsin, and early elections on March 26 proved an astute time for Mr. Abramovich and Mr. Berezovsky to act. Oil prices, at the highest level in nearly a decade, have brought a windfall to Russian oil companies and helped give the Sibneft shareholders the resources to acquire the smelters.
By expanding their holdings into aluminum, the Sibneft stock owners, once part of the Yeltsin inner circle, may be trying to preserve their influence in the new political cluster around the acting Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, who is the leading candidate in next month's elections.
"Presidential elections always need money," said Aleksandr Konovalov, head of the Institute for Strategic Assessments in Moscow, adding that "having lots of money means there is more of a chance" they will be regarded as sources of support before the election and after.
But it is unclear why Mr. Cherny and Trans-World chose to reduce their holdings in Russian aluminum at a time when favorable world prices have also helped improve the prospects of the smelters, which export most of their production.
Since the mid-1990's, investigators with the interior ministry have been looking into whether Mr. Cherny was part of a wide-scale bank fraud that the police say he used to finance deals with the smelters in the early days of post-Soviet Russia. Mr. Cherny and Trans-World, through their lawyers, have repeatedly denied accusations of wrongdoing.
The business activities of Sibneft and Mr. Berezovsky have also been called into question. Minority shareholders at a Sibneft production unit have for years accused company management of spiriting away millions in revenue from the unit into offshore accounts. Sibneft has denied any wrongdoing.
Mr. Berezovsky is under investigation by the Swiss prosecutor's office on evidence that he used two Geneva companies to channel revenue out of Russia from Aeroflot, the national airline, in which he owns a stake. He, too, has denied wrongdoing.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Reckonings;
An American Pie

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
Talk about globalization. Michel Camdessus probably knew that his last speech as managing director of the International Monetary Fund might be accompanied by some protests. But he surely did not expect an American activist to follow him to Bangkok and throw a cream pie in his face.
The American represented one of the groups hoping to make April's I.M.F.-World Bank meeting in Washington a second Seattle. Sunday's pie-throwing was, of course, a publicity stunt. But the symbolism -- an American traveling to Asia to save Asians from globalization, whether they want to be saved or not -- is too apt to pass up. 
 Let's admit that there were some actual Thai protesters outside the lecture hall. And let's also admit that the I.M.F. is a more plausible villain than the World Trade Organization, the bizarrely demonized target of the Seattle protests. The I.M.F. is no more a world government than the W.T.O. is; but through the conditions that it imposes in return for loans the I.M.F. does, at least in times of crisis, get to dictate policies to sovereign states.
The W.T.O., by contrast, is basically a commercial court; all it does is determine when countries are violating the agreements they have already made. (Example: The U.S. can set whatever environmental standards it likes, but having agreed to the principle of non-discrimination, it cannot hold imported gasoline to a higher standard than the domestic product.)
The protesters of Seattle past and Washington future, however, don't make such fine distinctions. They are as opposed to free trade in goods as they are to speculative movements of short-term capital; they view the longer-term trends in the world economy, not just the short-term crises, with dismay. And that is why the spectacle of an American going to Thailand, of all places, to protest globalization is so remarkable. For Thailand is one of those export-led success stories that are the best advertisement for the W.T.O. and its free-trade agenda.
Now wait a second, you say. Wasn't there a terrible financial crisis recently? Yes, there was, and the I.M.F. mishandled it. But the Thai economy is recovering, and even post-crisis Thailand is a much better place than it used to be.
This may not be obvious to the Western visitor. Much of Bangkok is an urban nightmare of shanties and traffic jams; Thailand is still poorer than most Westerners can easily imagine. But that, in a way, is the point: because the developing world is still so poor, what looks to careless observers like exploitation is often far better than the alternative.
Try looking at some of the literature of the anti-globalists -- say, the lavish series of full-page ads that have been placed in this newspaper by the Turning Point Project. (Who's paying for those ads, by the way?) Again and again you see the less attractive features of the modern world contrasted with an imagined pre-globalization Arcadia of happy villagers living in harmony with nature. Then try checking some of the facts about life before the export boom. Never mind G.D.P.; we're talking basic nutrition and health. What you will discover is that life in that pre-globalization society was nasty, brutish and short; for example, in 1975 only one rural Thai in six had access to safe drinking water. Today it's four out of five.
No wonder, then, that many third-world leaders are contemptuous of their self-proclaimed Western friends who, in the words of Mexico's president, Ernesto Zedillo, are "determined to save developing countries from development."
Of course, those developing countries have their own gripes about the world trading system. Mainly these involve their desire for more, not less, international trade: they are rightly angry that rich countries that proclaim the virtues of free trade place so many obstacles in the way of their potential exports. And they also want more of a say in the decisions of the W.T.O. -- largely because they are afraid that it will give in to the demands of the Seattle types, imposing labor and environmental standards that they cannot afford.
What they don't want is affluent Westerners telling them -- strangely, at the very moment that some developing countries are finally starting to acquire a bit of real economic power -- what a terrible thing the modern world is. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Surging Blue Chips Help Lift Slumping Technology Shares

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
A rally in oil stocks and some bargain hunting buoyed the Dow Jones industrials yesterday. In a major turnaround from recent weeks, the strength in blue chips helped pull technology stocks out of a severe slump.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 198.25 points, or 1.85 percent, to 10,718.09. The Nasdaq composite index, which tumbled as much as 127 points in earlier trading, closed up 2.22 points, to 4,420.77. 
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 12.11 points, to 1,402.05.
For a second session, the Dow held up better than the technology-dominated Nasdaq. Consumer products companies like Procter & Gamble and Minnesota Mining led the blue-chip index. Procter & Gamble rose 37/8 , to 95 3/4, while 3M gained 6 1/4, to 89 1/8.
Analysts said the Dow was poised for a comeback after its 538.59-point drop last week, which knocked the index 11 percent below its January peak, within market watchers' traditional definition of a correction. With big gains Monday and yesterday, the Dow is now 8.6 percent below its Jan. 14 record of 11,722.98.
"A lot of really good names had been beaten down badly," said Joseph T. Keating, chief investment officer of the Kent Funds in Grand Rapids, Mich. "It was time for some of those stocks to start attracting cash again."
The Dow got a lift from a surge in oil-related stocks. Exxon Mobil rose 2 7/8, to 795/16 , as crude oil futures remained above $30 a barrel. Crude prices topped $30 a barrel Monday for the first time since the eve of the Persian Gulf war in January 1991.
Texaco jumped 17/16 , to 505/16 , on the New York Stock Exchange. A Lehman Brothers analyst raised his rating on Texaco stock, estimating that shares would reach 65 within the next 12 months.
Oil services companies like Schlumberger, up 4 1/2, to 65, also rose.
While rising prices are good for the companies that produce and explore for oil, they can contribute to inflation. That possibility helped keep investors on edge yesterday, analysts said.
Technology stocks were particularly rattled by investors who are worried that the Federal Reserve will continue raising interest rates this year as it works to keep inflation from accelerating. The Fed has raised rates four times since June, and has seen little sign that the economy's growth has slowed.
Because higher interest rates can cut into corporate profits, investors have been favoring stocks of companies whose profits are growing fast, namely, technology stocks. But some of those favorites fell yesterday as investors sold shares to lock in profits from a big run in recent weeks.
Cisco Systems declined 2 1/2, to 128, and MCI WorldCom slipped 2 1/4, to 4713/16 .
"Markets are currently going through a period of trial, where upward pressure on rates continues to take their toll on most financial instruments," said A. C. Moore, chief investment strategist for Dunvegan Associates in Santa Barbara, Calif.
By late afternoon, however, some big gains from a handful of technology stocks powered the Nasdaq index higher. Rambus rose 4019/64 , to 15147/64 on the expectation that Intel will use its technology to manufacture high-speed computer chips.
Ultimately, investors are correct to place their money on the promise of technology, Mr. Keating said.
"There are two kinds of companies you've got to own: the techs and the companies that can most successfully implement technology to stay ahead of the pack as interest rates go higher," he said.
Later this week, the government will release data on producer prices and consumer prices. Both reports are considered important gauges of inflation pressures lurking in the economy. Also, the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan, will testify before the House Banking Committee tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Profits at Deere Down in Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill. Feb. 15

 BODY:
Deere & Company, one of the world's largest farm equipment makers, said today that profits in its most recent quarter fell 24 percent on continued slack demand for farm equipment but still beat Wall Street estimates.
The company said it earned $37.7 million, or 16 cents a diluted share, which was down from $49.7 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales in the period, which was the first quarter of Deere's fiscal year and ended Jan. 31, dropped to $2.34 billion from $2.46 billion a year earlier. 
 The profit was better than the 6 cents a share expected by Wall Street analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial, and Deere's shares were up $1.44, to $40.44, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Some analysts had expected Deere to post a loss in the quarter, which would have been its first operating loss in seven years.
The company said it expected sales, excluding the effect of inflation and currency exchange fluctuations, to rise about 10 percent in fiscal 2000 compared with 1999, fueled by gains in commercial and consumer equipment.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Fall on Report of Higher Factory Output

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were down moderately yesterday, after a stronger-than-expected gain in industrial production raised investor concern about further interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve Board in the months ahead.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 8/32 to 1004/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.24 percent, from 6.22 percent on Monday. 
 As expected, financial markets traded in fairly narrow ranges ahead of Humphrey-Hawkins testimony to Congress tomorrow on monetary policy and the state of the economy from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
Treasuries initially fell after the government reported that industrial production rose 1 percent last month; economists had expected a 0.6 percent increase. Production rose 0.4 percent in December.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "Against a background of a booming economy and an extremely low unemployment rate of 4 percent, the Federal Reserve is expected to tighten interest rates once again at its March 21 Federal Open Market Committee meeting in order to pre-emptively guard against potential inflationary pressures in the future."
He said the Fed was likely to maintain upward pressure on interest rates until definitive signs emerge of a more moderate pace of growth. Mr. Fine pointed to the current spread between the two-year Treasury note rate and the federal funds rate as a clear indication that the bond market expected the Fed to raise rates another half percentage point, "with a glint of possibly more beyond that."
Economic reports are expected to continue to highlight the torrid pace of growth. Mr. Fine noted the surge in industrial production in January. This spurt in production resulted in an advance in capacity utilization, which rose 0.5 percentage point, to 81.6 percent.
January housing starts, to be released today, are likely to fall after a jump in December, but Mr. Fine said housing activity to date had shown only scant signs of decline, and did not suggest an imminent sharp slowdown in economic activity.
Another important indicator will be Friday's release of the Consumer Price Index. While inflation must still be characterized as benign despite the 2.7 percent rise in the index last year, the energy sector bears watching.
"Although the structure of the American economy and behavioral patterns regarding energy costs have changed relative to the past," Mr. Fine said, "the fact remains that rising energy costs have not yet woven their way in the overall price structure, and while the impact today may not be what it once was, it nevertheless should not be dismissed."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Wal-Mart Has Its Ups And Downs

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Propelled by strong growth in its superstores and international operations, Wal-Mart Stores reported another year of record sales and profits yesterday. So, naturally, its stock declined.
The retailer, the largest in the world, said that its revenue for the year ended Jan. 31 was a whopping $165 billion, a 20 percent increase from the previous year. 
 The increase was all the more impressive because it came after a 17 percent revenue expansion last year and a 12 percent increase the year before, proving that the juggernaut is only gaining speed.
To put those sales in perspective, total retail spending in the United States was $3 trillion in 1999, according to the National Bureau on Income Statistics. So, stripping out income from international stores, which was some $22 billion, Wal-Mart accounts for nearly 5 percent of the entire American pie.
Not only was sales growth big at Wal-Mart, it was broad. All major divisions, from the Sam's Warehouse clubs to the discount stores, reported gains in sales and profits (the international division actually had an 85 percent expansion in revenue).
The retailer's profits rose 26 percent, or $1.25 a diluted share, for the full year. For the fourth quarter, the company earned 43 cents a share, ahead of the 42 cent estimate of Wall Street analysts, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Investors responded to the good-news fest by unloading stock. Wal-Mart's shares fell 87.5 cents, to $58, largely on concerns that the retailer would be hard pressed to exceed this year's blistering growth.
In a conference call with stock analysts, H. Lee Scott Jr., the chief executive, added to the worries by warning that the company would have to contend with higher oil prices and higher labor costs. Wal-Mart, based in Bentonville, Ark., has about a million Americans working for it, making it the largest employer in the nation.
Wal-Mart is also experiencing a cyclical problem. Retail stocks have been depressed by investors' concern that continuing increases in interest rates by policy makers at the Federal Reserve will dampen consumer demand in the coming year.
"The stock's softness is more a reflection of institutional investors' concerns about how a Fed hike will affect consumer spending," said Jeff Feiner, a retail analyst with Lehman Brothers. "But the underlying fundamentals of the business will continue to be strong."
But Wal-Mart, which tends to err on the side of caution when predicting future growth, is positioned for another banner year.
For starters, it is still expanding its Supercenters. Supercenters are outsized stores that combine discount store merchandise with grocercies and a pharmacy, and they have been a particularly profitable form of retailing. Wal-Mart built 157 of these monsters last year and predicted an equally aggressive expansion this year.
More important, Wal-Mart could actually benefit from higher interest rates. Who better to benefit from consumers' watching the bottom line than a chain famous for its low prices? Gucci and Tiffany's might become jittery when the Fed raises rates, but Wal-Mart is full of consumer necessities.
Moreover, while rising wages and fuel prices are tough on businesses, Wal-Mart is better prepared than its competition is. "Wal-Mart can spread out fuel and labor costs over a dense volume of merchandise because they are more efficient," said Burt Flickinger III, managing director of Reach Marketing, a marketing consulting firm in Westport, Conn. "It could be a critical competitive advantage."
The company, meanwhile, declined to confirm or deny a report yesterday in the retail industry trade paper, Women's Wear Daily, that it was set to buy Fruit of the Loom, the apparel manufacturer that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in December. Wal-Mart has had great success reviving apparel makers, including Faded Glory and Catalina, and turning them into profitable house brands.

HEADLINE: Internet Executives Are Reassured AfterWhite House Meeting

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Executives from the nation's leading Internet companies told President Clinton at the White House today that despite hacker attacks that disrupted several major Web sites last week, they saw no need for an increase in government regulation of the industry.
The meeting was organized months ago to discuss ways to prevent the World Wide Web from being used for terrorism but took on a sudden urgency with last week's events, in which several sites were disrupted for hours. Those sites included Amazon
.com, Yahoo and eBay. 
 Many in the industry feared the government would cite the hacker attacks as evidence of the need to expand its role in regulating Internet security. But after today's meeting, many of the two dozen executives who sat down with Mr. Clinton said they were reassured that he had no such intention.
"In dealing with the challenge of security on the Internet, private industry must take the leadership role," said Harris N. Miller, president of the Information Technology Association of America.
Mr. Miller, whose trade group represents many of the leading information technology companies, told reporters after the two-hour meeting that it was important that the computer industry -- not the government -- oversee Internet security because "the private sector has made the Internet the vibrant and dynamic thing that it is today."
Officials of the Clinton Administration seemed to go to great lengths to reassure industry participants -- including a reformed hacker turned security consultant who went by the Internet nickname "Mudge" during his hacker days -- that there was no intention to impose new regulations on them that could impede the growth of the Web.
Commerce Secretary William M. Daley told reporters after the meeting that the administration would do nothing that would damage the Internet.
He said the government's role was to support the industry, and that companies were properly taking the lead in enhancing security. "It is not about the government regulating this or taking steps or actions that would at all impede the Internet because, of course, it is the dynamic engine that is driving our economy today and we must keep that open."
David Starr, the chief information officer for the 3Com Corporation, said after the meeting that "everybody was concerned going in that the government would use this as an excuse for more involvement in the Internet. But we were pleasantly surprised that they didn't."
Mr. Starr said one of the issues discussed at the meeting was whether the government could do anything to improve security on the Web to ensure that last week's incidents were not repeated. "The answer was clearly no," he said.
Mr. Clinton opened the meeting with a reference to last week's cybersalvos by hackers who are still being sought by the the F.B.I., saying that the attacks were "a source of concern, but I don't think we should leave here with this vast sense of insecurity.
"We ought to leave here with a sense of confidence that this is a challenge that was entirely predictable," he said. "It's part of the price of the success of the Internet."
It was not, he added, "an electronic Pearl Harbor."
Federal law enforcement officials said today that they were seeking to interview two young computer enthusiasts who might know about last week's attacks. But the officials cautioned that the people were not necessarily themselves suspects and that they did not anticipate any early arrests.
Whitfield Diffie, the corporate information officer of Sun Microsystems Inc., who attended the meeting, said the participants were relieved when Mr. Clinton quickly made it clear that he believed the industry had thrived because the government had applied a light hand.
"There was a general agreement on the desirability of the industry solving our own problems," he said.
Mr. Diffie said the industry leaders at the meeting were intent on letting the White House know that "the real expertise on these problems is in the industry."
At the same time, many of the participants acknowledged that there had been insufficient attention to security in some parts of the industry. "It's clear that we've got to do a better job," said Nicholas M. Donofrio, senior vice president for I.B.M.'s technology group.
He said most of the security tools already existed to prevent incidents like those last week, but that some companies had not deployed them.
As an example, he said, many computers come with a factory-installed default security system that is meant to be changed when it is put into operation. "We believe that a third of them are never changed but left just the way it arrived from the factory," he said. He described that as the equivalent of buying a briefcase with a three-digit combination lock that opens when all the numbers are at 0-0-0 and never changing the combination.
"This was a wake-up call, not a crisis," he said, employing a description used by several of the participants. "The time to fix things is now before there is a real crisis."
But like his colleagues, Mr. Donofrio was firm in saying that "this is a problem mainly for the private sector."
Some of the company officials said if the industry was to be left to solve the problems by itself, as they had urged, there had to be greater coordination and more uniform security standards.
Clarence Chandron, executive vice president for the Nortel Networks Corporation, said the group agreed that "we really need to focus on implementation now," including "a massive communications effort throughout the industry" to make sure other companies install the security systems needed to avert these kinds of attacks.
This work, he said, would most likely be coordinated by the Information Technology Association, the trade group that coordinated the industry participation in today's meetings.
Mr. Miller said his group had proposed a plan in which Internet companies would commit themselves to sharing information among themselves, including how to deal with security vulnerabilities.
The industry participants today spoke regularly and politely about the need for a continuing partnership with the government in improving computer security. But their concept of what role the government would or should have was decidedly limited.
They generally wanted the government to maintain high security for its own computers and keep up with the changing technology. "So that when we speak, they understand us," said Mr. Donofrio of I.B.M.
John Podesta, the White House chief of staff, who has been in charge of computer security, said the government had not done a good enough job of securing its own computer systems. "We need to make the government a role model," he said.
Mr. Clinton has proposed a 16 percent increase in financing for computer security issues, to $2 billion. Mr. Podesta said this would include a proposal to address the problem of having the most gifted computer security specialists quickly leave government for more lucrative positions in the private sector.
The administration is proposing a subsidy to help with education costs for computer students who would then be obligated to serve for a time with the government.
The White House provided this list of people who attended the meeting:

SECTION: Section B; Page 8; Column 1; National Desk; Education Page

LENGTH: 800 words

HEADLINE: LESSONS;
A Conservative Picks a Path Less Taken

BYLINE: By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
TOURING South Carolina, John McCain is accompanied by Lisa Keegan, the magnetic schools superintendent from Arizona, his home state, who handles inquiries about his education proposals. Widely admired by conservatives, Ms. Keegan would be on a short list for secretary of education in any Republican administration.
Ms. Keegan has been a conservative flag-bearer in the education wars, demanding publicly financed vouchers for parents to use at private schools. She wants market forces alone to regulate education. She acknowledges that when parents choose a school, it might be better if they knew how it taught reading and math, but she insists that they should nonetheless be allowed to choose on any basis they wish. 
 In Arizona, she has promoted tax credits for donations to private voucher plans. And last year she received the annual award of a foundation sponsored by the conservative economist Milton Friedman, who has championed privatized schooling since 1955.
But Ms. Keegan could ultimately surprise us, and perhaps herself. When outsiders like her accept real responsibility, solutions that once looked simple to them may no longer seem practical. Now in charge of Arizona's school accountability, she must decide which schools are successful, and the stakes have become particularly high for her: she has presided over a big expansion of charter schools, and unfair standards would harm charters as well as regular schools.
Ms. Keegan's challenge is this: to defend low-scoring schools outside the regular system, she is being forced to acknowledge that students' social and economic hardship, as well as school quality, affects results. This insight is incompatible with the idea, typically advanced by fellow conservatives, that public schools must be failures if they cannot themselves eliminate the rich-poor gap in scores.
More than 30,000 Arizona children are now in charter schools, twice the enrollment share of charter schools in any other state. Charters get state financing and are freed of almost all curricular and personnel rules. In return, they are supposed to achieve, or be closed. The idea is that regular schools, fearing loss of students, will also improve. For such competition to work, the state schools superintendent must report achievement for both regular and charter schools. And because charters promise results, Ms. Keegan plans to recommend closing those that perform poorly.
But which will they be? In Arizona, scores at charter schools are about the same as at regular schools. From 1997 to 1998, regular schools' fourth-grade math scores rose from the 48th to the 51st national percentile, while charters' went from the 42nd to the 43rd. In reading, regular schools' scores were unchanged at the 52nd percentile, but charters' dropped from the 52nd to the 50th.
This, Ms. Keegan knows, does not mean charters are failing. She professes no concern if a school's scores are low, provided students' annual gains compare favorably with gains in schools that have similar students. It is this relative standard that defies conventional cliches. David Garcia, Arizona schools research director, says schools will be compared only with those where students have similar socioeconomic backgrounds or "extenuating circumstances."
Charter schools can be nontraditional. Some recruit dropouts; simply getting many of those youths to stay in class may be a success, and so it would not be fair, Ms. Keegan believes, to judge such schools only by test scores. Her recommendations for closing will consider mitigating factors and emphasize "multiple measures" of success, for regular and charter schools alike. For example, a school might be considered adequate if students, though testing poorly, later succeed at community college.
This is a bold approach. By contrast, Florida's governor, Jeb Bush, last year gave private vouchers to parents at two low-scoring public school "failures." Those schools enrolled very poor children, and tried to improve results with innovative programs. Lisa Keegan's measures might not find failure there. (As in Florida, New York policy makers resist alternative academic measures and now identify school failure by low scores alone, without considering Ms. Keegan's "mitigating factors.")
Ms. Keegan has not yet detailed how she will decide whether to call for a school's closing. She will almost certainly be pressured by critics who contend that she whitewashes schools that serve hard-to-educate children and achieve high gains but low scores. Perhaps she came to these ideas only from a desire to excuse low-scoring charters. But because she takes the challenge so seriously, Lisa Keegan could transform education debates, providing conservatives and liberals common ways to evaluate schools.

HEADLINE: New York Is Ranked High For Deadly Heart Attacks

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
White women in New York State had the highest death rates from heart disease among white women in the United States, and New York ranked second highest in the number of deaths among women over all, the first national study of heart disease in women by region, race and ethnic origin has found.
The study, published yesterday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta and by West Virginia University, found that the death rates from heart disease were generally highest in the impoverished, rural areas of Appalachia, the Mississippi Delta and elsewhere in rural Southern states. 
 But the study also found pockets of high death rates elsewhere, too, particularly in four densely populated cities: New York, Chicago, Detroit and New Orleans. States with the lowest death rates were in the West, and the rates were low to moderate in the Midwest.
"Contrary to what many people believe, heart disease is the leading cause of death for women," said the surgeon general, Dr. David Satcher. While heart disorder has long been regarded as a "men's" disease, Dr. Satcher said the study provides a perspective on the threat heart disease in women.
Dr. Michele L. Casper, an epidemiologist at the C.D.C. who is the chief author of the study, said she was surprised by the New York findings because the high rates generally appeared in Southern rural areas where many women, particularly the elderly, might live isolated and alone, perhaps unable to care for themselves or get to a doctor.
Dr. Casper also said many rural areas had no coronary units that could sometimes prevent heart attacks or cardiac rehabilitation centers that could prevent recurrences. Such conditions might also apply to poor women living in densely populated urban areas, she said.
Dr. Casper said the current research was designed specifically to pinpoint differences in death rates among different groups of women and how the rates varied from region to region. Further studies would examine the causes, she added.
But the researchers said social and economic factors, including the style of living, were also possible reasons for the disparities in death rates generally and for the high rates in New York.
Dr. Antonio M. Gotto, dean of the Weill Cornell Medical College in New York City, said life style might be responsible for as much as 50 percent of the incidence of heart disease among women. In New York, he said, a great ethnic, cultural and economic diversity produces great differences in the way of living and in patterns of behavior, including diet, intake of fat and cholesterol, physical exercise, smoking, blood pressure and money to pay for treatment.
Among other findings of the study were these:
*The states with the highest death rates from heart disease were Mississippi, New York, ; and West Virginia.
*The lowest-ranking states among the low range of death rates were in the Pacific Northwest, the Rocky Mountain region of Colorado and New Mexico and in parts of Wisconsin and North and South Dakota. The Midwest was in the moderate to low range.
*Women in Minnesota were the most likely to survive heart disease, the study found, while white women were most likely to survive in Hawaii.
Some 370,000 women died of heart disease nationally in 1997, the last year for which figures are available. Annual rates of mortality among women, a total of 401 per 100,000 women, the C.D.C. statisticians said, were greater than for all forms of cancer combined for women.
Disparities in heart disease death rates among men will be studied next.
Dr. Nancy Krieger, an associate professor in the department of health and social behavior at the Harvard School of Public health, said the researchers were trying to move beyond the limitations of current health data.
"You just can't look at heart disease mortality among women," Dr. Krieger said. "Epidemiology research shows that what matters are the conditions you lived in when you grew up, as well as how you are able to live as an adult and the quality of care you receive" when medical care is needed.
The research confirmed previously known disparities between the five major racial and ethnic groups in the United States: that significantly more black women die from heart disease than any other group, but that whites are much more likely to die from heart disease than Asian and Pacific Islanders, American Indians and Alaska Natives.
Among black woman, the death rate from heart disease was 553 per 100,000; among white woman, 388 per 100,000; American Indians, 259 per 100,000, and Asian and Pacific Islanders, 221 per 100,000. The rate for Hispanic woman of all races was 265 per 100,000.
Counties with the highest death rates for white women were roughly the same as those for black women -- that is, in Appalachia and the Mississippi Delta, except that for whites there was a greater concentration along coastal regions of the Southeast. And the highest state rates were New York, followed by Mississippi and West Virginia.
In New York State, the death rate for all 4,929,714 women was 487 per 100,000, compared to the national average of 401. For black women the rate was 573; for whites, 477; Asian and Pacific Islanders, 236, and American Indians and Alaska Natives, 212.
Mississippi had the highest death rate for black women, 686 per 100,000.
In New York City the death rate for all 2,019,225 women was 561 per 100 thousand; for black women the rate was 587; for whites, 559; Hispanic women, 320; Asian and Pacific Islanders 248, and American Indians and Alaskan Natives, 97. The average number of deaths from heart disease among white and Hispanic women was highest in Manhattan; for blacks, Asians and Pacific Islanders, Brooklyn; American Indians and Alaskan natives the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Study Says the Internet Increases Social Isolation
The nation's obsession with the Internet is causing many Americans to spend less time with friends and family, less time shopping in stores and more time working at home after hours, according to one of the first large-scale surveys of the societal impact of the Internet.
The report raises the specter of an atomized world without human contact or emotion. That conclusion may prove controversial because some online enthusiasts say the Internet has fostered alternative electronic relationships that may replace or enhance face-to-face family and social connections. Page A1.

Berkshire Hathaway, the company controlled by Warren E. Buffett, reported stakes in Citigroup, Liz Claiborne, Jones Apparel Group and Dun & Bradstreet, among others. Surging Blue Chips Send Shares Up

When Managers Deliver Pink Slips

HEADLINE: Production Surged 1% In January

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15

 BODY:
United States industrial production in January posted its largest gain in 18 months as factories, utilities and mines all increased output, Federal Reserve figures showed today.
Production rose 1 percent last month, after gaining 0.4 percent during December. The plant-use rate, which measures the amount of industrial capacity put to work, rose to 81.6 percent in January from 81.1 percent, which had first been reported as 81.3 percent. 
 "This is an unambiguously strong report," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
Before the report, analysts had expected an increase of 0.6 percent in production and a plant-use rate of 81.5 percent.
The January increase in industrial production was the largest since a 1.8 percent gain in August 1998 when General Motors factories restarted production after a two-month strike. The plant-use rate was the highest since it was 81.9 the same month.
By category, manufacturing output rose 0.9 percent in January -- the biggest gain since October -- after rising 0.2 percent in December. Last month's rise was led by autos, semiconductors and industrial machinery.
Production of business equipment, including computers and semiconductors, rose 1.9 percent after a 0.2 percent drop in December and no change in November. That suggests businesses delayed buying new equipment until after the start of the new year to avoid Year 2000 computer-related problems.
Mining output rose 1 percent after showing no change a month earlier, reflecting a rebound in oil and gas drilling as oil prices rose. Output at utilities rose 1.8 percent atop a 4.2 percent increase in December.
By industry, auto and truck production rose 4.2 percent in January after falling 3.6 percent in December. Automakers are benefiting from the strength in consumer spending, which has been fueled by the lowest unemployment in three decades.
Production of semiconductors and other electrical components rose 4.4 percent last month after increasing 5.3 percent the previous month.
Output of construction supplies rose 0.2 percent in January after falling 0.2 percent in December. Sales of new homes finished a record year for the housing industry. The year ended with sales of 904,000 new homes, topping 1998's total of 886,000 and setting a record for the second consecutive year.

HEADLINE: Commuter-Tax Repeal Goes Before Top Court

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Feb. 15

 BODY:
The repeal of New York City's commuter tax went before the state's highest court today, and the judges reacted skeptically to the city's claim that the state could not end the tax without the city's consent.
The judges of the Court of Appeals also heard arguments from New Jersey and Connecticut that the state must repeal the tax on their residents who work in the city if it is to repeal the tax on New York State residents who make the same commute. 
 The commuter tax, which generated $360 million a year for the city, was abolished for in-state residents last year by state lawmakers, in a flurry of one-upmanship over a special election for a State Senate seat in Rockland and Orange counties.
After the Republican and Democratic candidates for the seat promised to do away with the tax, a perennial irritant to suburbanites, the cause was taken up by legislative leaders of both parties trying to bolster their parties' claims to tax cutting and the allegiance of suburban voters. That led to the sudden repeal of the tax.
The tax, imposed in 1966 and increased in 1971, was 0.45 percent of taxable income for most taxpayers. The repeal applied only to state residents, but the measure included a clause saying that if the law was found to discriminate against people commuting from out of state, it would be repealed for them, too. A trial court and a state appeals court have both found the distinction to be illegal, but commuters from other states have continued paying the tax, pending a ruling by the Court of Appeals.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani sued to challenge the repeal, citing a provision of the state Constitution saying that the state cannot enact laws affecting just one city or town without a "home rule message," a request by the local government for the change. His stance puts the mayor on the unpopular side of an issue dear to the suburban voters he is courting as he runs for the United States Senate.
Elizabeth I. Freedman, the assistant corporation counsel arguing the case for the city, told the judges today that the repeal "was a special law targeted to the city of New York."
But some of the judges took issue with that claim. When people outside the city are subject to the tax, Judge Richard C. Wesley asked, "How can you say this is a matter purely of New York City's interest?"
Ms. Freedman disputed the claim the Legislature made in the repeal bill that it had a compelling interest in eliminating the tax to promote economic growth. "What was really at issue was the outcome of the election in Rockland County," she said.
But several judges countered that she was asking them to get inside lawmakers' heads, which they described as unwise to try to do. Judge Joseph W. Bellacosa said there was no reason for the court to look any further than the lawmakers' stated intent in determining their motives for passing the repeal.
Judge Wesley noted that the state Constitution specifically says that the state can never surrender its authority over taxes. He also pointed out that the commuter tax law mentions not New York City, but cities of more than one million people -- a common trick among Albany lawmakers to write laws that apply only to the city without appearing to single it out.
On the issue of applying the tax to out-of-staters only, lawyers for Connecticut and New Jersey cited several decisions by the United States Supreme Court saying that similar forms of discrimination violated multiple sections of the Constitution that are generally aimed at preventing states from interfering with one another.
Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, said New York's commuter tax "is precisely the kind of levy that our founders sought to prevent."
But New York State's lawyer, Deputy Solicitor General Edward Johnson, argued that those Supreme Court decisions left a little room for variations in taxation -- enough, he said, for a tax that amounted to just $5 a week per person, on average, to be justified. The Supreme Court, he said, only required "a rough equity," not precise equality.
Some judges expressed sympathy for that argument, noting other cases of unequal treatment, such as universities that charge higher tuition to out-of-state students. "We seem to abide that without any problem,"
Judge Albert M. Rosenblatt said.

HEADLINE: Mohegans to Build $800 Million Casino Expansion

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 15

 BODY:
Straight out of the depressed backwoods of southeastern Connecticut, an incongruous image emerges: a glittering 40-story hotel, a 10,000-seat sports arena and a second casino building featuring a perforated-steel planetarium 150 feet in diameter on its ceiling.
But that -- and more -- is what Mohegan Indian tribal leaders will unveil Wednesday as part of a planned $800 million expansion, the latest volley in the battle for gambling dollars being waged by Connecticut Indian tribes against one another and by both together against the moguls of Atlantic City. 
 The four-year-old Mohegan Sun casino, in Uncasville, Conn., 128 miles from New York City, plans to offer visitors a sprawling entertainment complex built to rival the enormously lucrative Foxwoods Resort Casino run by the Mashantucket Pequot tribe 10 miles to the east in Ledyard.
Once the Mohegans' expansion is complete, probably in two years, both tribes expect Connecticut's gambling industry to significantly cut into the drawing power of better-known casinos in this country and abroad.
"It will make Connecticut much more a force compared to Atlantic City," said Mitchell G. Etess, executive vice president of marketing for Mohegan Sun, now the fourth-largest casino in the United States. Bob DeSalvio, a vice president of marketing at Foxwoods Resort Casino, went a step further, saying, "I think that Connecticut is becoming a very powerful force in the gaming industry nationally and internationally."
The expansion of the Mohegans' gambling operation is also expected to double the 20,000 daily visitors to their casino and add 4,000 jobs to the entire complex, which currently employs 5,500 workers, Mr. Etess said.
The $325 million Mohegan Sun opened in October 1996; the much larger Foxwoods Resort Casino opened in Ledyard in 1992. The two tribes are the only two in Connecticut recognized as tribes by the Federal government, a necessary prerequisite to opening a casino.
The Mohegans expect that their new casino's debut, expected in April 2002, will push gross gambling revenues to "well over a billion" dollars annually from about $750 million, Mr. Etess said.
All told, the casino expansion project, designed by the New York City firms of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates and Rockwellgroup, is expected to add a total of four million combined square feet of gambling, retail and entertainment space.
Outside, the monolithic hotel tower will be a landmark visible from Long Island, across Long Island Sound, its designers say. Inside, natural light will filter into the new casino and refract off crystals and panels -- 26,000 square feet in all -- of translucent woven multicolored beads, said David Rockwell, an architect with Rockwellgroup. Where the existing casino has an Earth-based theme, the new casino is meant to convey the notion of sky, he said.
Above the new casino's slot machines and gambling tables will hang a giant steel planetarium with a 65-foot cropping of backlit black onyx, Mr. Rockwell said. The hotel lobby will feature 10 abstract wooden sculptures in the form of trees whose arching canopies will be made of beads.
"It gives us the chance to create something that is much more than just a casino," Mr. Rockwell said in an interview today. "This is going to take it to a way, way different level."
On a more conventional plane, the project blueprints also call for a cavernous retail mall and what Mohegan Sun officials say will be the largest ballroom in the Northeast.
Grand as the $800 million construction project is, it will leave the Mohegans' casino complex measurably smaller than Foxwoods, which the Pequot leaders have called the world's largest casino. The expanded Mohegan Sun, for instance, will have 280,000 square feet of gambling space, compared with 315,310 square feet at Foxwoods.
The new Mohegan hotel, which will rival the tallest structure in Connecticut, City Place 1 in Hartford, will have 1,200 rooms; Foxwoods has 1,416.
The Mohegans were planning to release further details of the casino's dimensions and design at noon Wednesday at Rockefeller Center.
From a labor standpoint, the casino expansion "is a wonderful thing," said Donald M. Peppard Jr., a professor of economics at Connecticut College in New London. "Ten years ago, this area was sort of an employment disaster."
On the other hand, there is already a shortage of able workers. Once the casino begins hiring, he said, "If you're another employer around here, you're going to be pulling your hair out."
Mr. Peppard said that roughly half the gamblers at the casino were Connecticut residents.
In New London, about 15 miles south of the casino, most people welcome the expansion, said Riochard Brown, the city manager. "I think the expansion is positive," he said.
Though the expansion is meant to steal some of the monstrous revenues from Foxwoods -- which industry analysts have estimated to be over a billion dollars a year -- Mashantucket Pequot leaders said they wished their rivals well.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Connecticut Luring New York Tourists

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Residents of the New York metropolitan area are heading to Connecticut for short vacations at a record clip, a new study says.
Tourists from metropolitan New York spent $100 million on Connecticut attractions and related businesses in 1999, an increase of 46 percent from the year before, the study says. 
 Based on Connecticut's $2.5 million tourism budget, the state recouped $40 from New York City-area tourists for every dollar spent, said Ed Dombroskas, executive director of the Department of Economic and Community Development's Office of Tourism.
He credited the increase to a new strategy: advertisements featuring only the state's bigger attractions.
The state's tourism industry generated $5 billion in 1999, up from $3.8 billion in 1992, Mr. Dombroskas said Monday.
The study, which was conducted by Witan Intelligence Strategies of Avon, Conn., showed large increases in specific areas of spending. Lodging revenue jumped 24 percent, retail spending increased 41 percent and restaurant revenue rose 6 percent.
The study was conducted by a telephone poll of 700 people from metropolitan New York who had called the Office of Tourism.
Mystic continues to be the No. 1 destination in Connecticut for travelers from New York. Ninety percent of New York travelers were repeat visitors.

HEADLINE: Marriage, Fairness and Taxes

 BODY:

To the Editor:
As a liberal Democrat and a supporter of progressive taxation, I am surprised to find myself disagreeing with your Feb. 13 editorial "A Bloated Tax Cut for Marriage." While I understand the complexities involved in eliminating the marriage penalty, I believe that it should be alleviated for all taxpayers, not only the low- and middle-income earners covered under President Clinton's plan. 
 Married people are healthier and more economically stable than single people, and children of married people do better on a variety of indicators. Marriage is thus a socially responsible act. If the Republican plan is not the best one for eliminating the marriage penalty, perhaps we should look at other alternatives. But there must be some way of spreading the principle of support for marriage throughout the tax code.
 
ANYA BERNSTEIN
Newton, Mass., Feb. 13, 2000
 
The writer is a lecturer in social studies at Harvard University.
