HEADLINE: Leak at Indian Pt. Nuclear Plant Prompts Shutdown and an Alert

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN with MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
A leak in a steam generator at the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor in Westchester County released a small amount of radiation from the plant last night, forcing officials to shut it down and declare an alert.
The plant's owner, Consolidated Edison, stressed that the leak was what it called "momentary" and that there was no danger to residents of the surrounding area or to employees of the plant. 
 But the declaration of the alert -- the second level of four categories of nuclear emergency -- was the first issued by Con Edison since the Indian Point 2 plant opened in 1974. Con Ed officials said last night that they did not know what caused the leak.
The leak in the 1,000-megawatt plant, in Buchanan, about 35 miles north of New York City, occurred about 7:30 p.m., said Michael Spall, a Con Ed spokesman. It allowed hot, radioactive water, which is supposed to be kept isolated, to mix with clean water that is boiled into steam. The steam then flows out of the reactor's containment dome into a turbine that spins to generate electricity.
The leak of radioactive gas into the air occurred because the plant has a system for ejecting air from the steam process in order to limit corrosion, Mr. Spall said. He added, however, that "several seconds later" the system diverted the air back to the containment dome, limiting the amount of radioactive gas released.
"Any releases would have posed no threat to the safety of plant personnel or the general public," he added. "While this is a serious event, it is not one that threatens public health and safety."
There are four levels of response to incidents at nuclear plants: a notification, an alert, a site area emergency, and a general emergency, which is what occurred at Three Mile Island.
Last night, Con Ed quickly sent monitoring teams to the plant's perimeter, but they found radiation levels to be normal, Mr. Spall said.
Although the plant produces about one-seventh of the power used by Con Ed's three million customers, officials said there was no power shortage, nor would there be one because other plants in the region would supply the power.
Dennis Michalski, a spokesman for the New York State Emergency Management Office, said that Con Edison followed all the proper safety procedures, and alerted the state agency's office in 15 minutes. He added that the leak "occurred within the generating structure, but they shut off the valve so none of that steam left the facility."
The Nuclear Regulatory Commission received a report from Con Edison at 8:07 p.m., within the one-hour reporting time limit. Mr. Spall said the leak was in a steam generator, which is a heat exchanger inside the containment dome. The leak opened a path for mildly radioactive water to flow out of containment and into the turbine hall, from which "a small amount" -- he did not known how much -- was released to the environment, he said.
Indian Point's steam generators, four of them for each reactor, are towering metal vessels, filled with thin-walled metal tubes, in the shape of an upside-down U. The tubes are filled with water that flows through the nuclear core to the steam generators and then back to the core, carrying heat away from the reactor so it can be used to make electricity. This water gradually picks up radioactive contaminants.
Outside the tubes there is clean, nonradioactive water, which is pumped in and boils. The steam flows out through giant pipes, through the heavy concrete and steel wall of the containment dome to the turbine hall, which is used to spin a turbine and make electricity. This nonradioactive steam is then run through a big metal cooling box called a condenser, where it is turned back into water. The condenser is kept cool with water from the Hudson River.
At midnight, Mr. Spall said that operators had shut off the flow of steam from the steam generator, and shut off the flow of water that is boiled into steam. And they had reduced pressure in the reactor to 1,000 pounds per square inch, he said. Normal operating pressure is above 2,000 pounds per square inch. But bringing the reactor to cold shutdown -- when it is cool enough to open up without the cooling water boiling away -- was still several hours away, he said.
Other reactors of similar design, called pressurized water reactors, have had steam generator problems.
Indian Point 3, which is owned by the New York Power Authority, had corrosion and cracking problems with its steam generators, and replaced them. But Con Edison said it did not need to, perhaps because it paid closer attention to water chemistry, to limit corrosion.
Rochester Gas & Electric's Robert E. Ginna reactor suffered a steam generator tube rupture in 1982. Many other plants have been closed for months by steam generator tube problems.
With the economic value of nuclear plants much diminished by changes in technology and in utility rules, it was not clear whether it would pay to replace the steam generators, if that were to become necessary. Like an old car that needed a new transmission, a severe steam generator problem could lead to retirement.
Con Edison said earlier this month that it would offer the reactor for sale this year.
Indian Point 2 has had a spotty history in recent years. In 1994, the plant broke the world record for longest continuous operation -- 19 months -- of a light-water reactor, the kind used in the United States and most of the rest of the world.
But in December 1996, a minor chemical spill forced the plant to shut down. In 1998, the plant was closed again, that time for several months, because of safety concerns. And last September, the plant was temporarily shut down after a series of electrical problems caused the system to misread temperature and pressure readings.

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT;
When Young Managers Deliver the Pink Slips

BYLINE: By CHARLES BUTLER 

 BODY:
They were in high school or college when the great wave of layoffs swept corporate America in the early 90's. And while they heard stories about neighbors who had lost their jobs, they didn't give them much thought.
Now, these 20-somethings are thriving in the longest economic boom in American history. Many are managers, and holding onto employees, not letting them go, is their main concern. But when pink slips must be delivered, these young bosses often have to deliver them. 
 "My biggest fear was, I don't want this girl to walk out of here and hate me," said Michelle Anderson, the accounting manager for the MA&A Group, a consulting firm in Atlanta, who at 26 last April fired a female associate more than six years her senior. It was a first for her, and it was an ordeal.
"You're sitting there and going, 'I'm younger than this person and I'm affecting her life completely today,' " Ms. Anderson said.
Seven months later, she had to repeat the process, firing the associate's replacement.
Of course, managers have always had to dismiss underlings when their performance lagged or the company's profits sagged. Even Internet success stories like Amazon.com and iVillage.com recently had to trim their staffs for economic reasons.
But not so long ago, the bearer of bad tidings was usually an old pro, or at least someone old enough to know how to cope with the emotions surrounding it. Today, increasingly, the dirty work is done by people a few years out of college for whom management has mostly meant recruiting employees with stock options and playing the host at happy hours.
And their inexperience can create problems for companies. For instance, several employment lawyers say they are noticing an increase in age-discrimination suits resulting from the way young managers dismissed older workers. According to Rosemary Alito, a lawyer with McCarter & English in Newark, age discrimination "is becoming more an issue where you have younger people in high-level positions."
Moreover, many Internet companies and other start-ups are likely to be targets for suits because they often do not even have human-resources departments in place to conduct dismissals properly, she said.
Compounding the problem, says Adin Goldberg, a lawyer with Whitman Breed Abbot & Morgan in New York, many young managers are not practiced in politically correct office-speak. Mr. Goldberg recently advised a company to settle an age-discrimination suit involving a 25-year-old sales manager who fired a salesman in his 50's. The employee said the manager repeatedly made references to wanting "a fresh approach" in the office. While the phrase is vague, Mr. Goldberg said, most juries would interpret it as denigrating to the older worker.
Aside from the legal implications, young executives are often not equipped to handle the emotional side of firings. For Jennifer Floren, 28, the chief executive of experience inc., a Boston Internet company she founded in 1996, the memory of one of her first dismissals remains vivid.
"The woman burst into tears and started screaming, 'This is so unfair. How could you do this to me? Please give me one more chance,' " said Ms. Floren, whose Web site, www .experienceinc.com, provides career advice to college graduates. "It is so tempting to say, 'O.K., stay one more day, one more week.' "
While she avoided making that concession, she has hired a human-resources manager to handle personnel issues, including dismissals, at the 65-employee company.
Senior executives of MA&A would not let Ms. Anderson -- or any of the firm's other managers -- dismiss an employee without her going through training sessions. In the days leading up to the morning last April when she would dismiss an employee for the first time, Ms. Anderson spent several hours with the company's human-resources manager, Ellen Warden, in role-playing simulations. The coaching prepared her for reactions ranging from tears to tirades and provided a script to deliver the news sensitively but legally.
"I had rehearsed so much, I think I was a tape-recorder," Ms. Anderson recalled.
The morning of the firing, after a bad night's sleep, she arrived at work earlier than usual and paced the hallways. As soon as the employee arrived, she was called into a conference room where Ms. Anderson, accompanied by Ms. Warden, dismissed her.
"It went a lot better than I expected," Ms. Anderson recalled. "The woman said to me, 'I know this is probably harder for you than me.' "
To be sure, not every 20-something goes through such an emotional crisis. "Of course it gnaws at your stomach because you have the fate of someone in your hands," said one young executive of a Manhattan high-technology start-up who fired an employee during the Christmas holiday.
But, added the executive, who requested anonymity for fear of scaring off prospective employees, "We were confident he could get something else."
Other young managers take a similarly businesslike approach. Court Coursey, 27, says it was hard for him to lay off five employees shortly after the company he founded, certifiedmail.com, was acquired by WebMD Inc., in 1998, "especially in a high-growth company where it's a team-like atmosphere."
But, added Mr. Coursey, who now runs a holding company that develops Internet companies, "At the end of the day it's a business, and you have to make hard business decisions."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 2, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Management page in Business Day on Feb. 16 about the daunting task of young managers who have to fire employees included one example erroneously. IVillage.com says it has never laid off employees for economic reasons and has not recently trimmed its staff.

Chart: "Tips for Beginners"
Never fire on a Friday. The worker will stew all weekend and sue on Monday.
 
Rehearse the termination with a human-resources employee or lawyer to avoid saying something insensitive or illegal.
 
Keep the termination exercise to less than 10 minutes. This is a firing, not a performance review.
 
Be prepared for tears, anger and pleas. But don't give in.
 
Let the fired employee keep his e-mail address for a stated period. The gesture will make you seem understanding.

HEADLINE: CALENDAR;
Exhibitions, Talks, Film Screenings

 BODY:

Filipino Fashion
Grey Art Gallery of New York University, 100 Washington Square East; (212) 288-6400.
The Asia Society is sponsoring "Sheer Realities: Clothing and Power in 19th-Century Philippines," an exhibition of clothing and fashion accessories, which starts Wednesday and runs through April 22. 
 The items on display include clothing made with pina, a sheer cloth made from pineapple fiber; other dyed cloth; and jewelry and accessories made of gold, silver and gourds.

HEADLINE: A Chapter 11 Filing by Charter Behavioral

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Charter Behavioral Health Systems, the nation's biggest operator of psychiatric hospitals and treatment centers which has gone into a financial free fall, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors yesterday.
Charter, which is 90 percent owned by Crescent Operating Inc., a company led by Richard E. Rainwater, the financier from Fort Worth, said it made the filing to "ensure continued services to patients" in its units. 
 Charter listed less than $50 million in assets and more than $100 million in debts in filings yesterday at the United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del.
The Crescent Real Estate Equities Company, a real estate investment trust also led by Mr. Rainwater, already owns the buildings used by Charter's hospitals and treatment centers.
Three years ago, Charter ran roughly 90 psychiatric hospitals and treatment centers for more than 8,000 patients, many of them children. Operations have now dwindled to 37 units with a capacity of 2,000 patients.
Since last year, the Justice Department and the Department of Health and Human Services have been investigating Charter and Magellan Health Services Inc., which once owned the chain, for Medicaid billing fraud and patient abuse.
In 1997, Magellan Health entered into a complex $400 million deal in which it sold Charter's buildings to Crescent Real Estate and a 50 percent stake in the chain to Crescent Operating, an affiliate of Crescent Real Estate. Because real estate investment trusts cannot operate companies, Crescent Operating was formed by Mr. Rainwater and his associates to hold the Charter stake.
The 1997 deal came as the industry faced cutbacks by insurers on treatment payments. Many former officials of the chain have said that the plan -- which saddled Charter with some $125 million annually in new franchise fees and rapidly escalating rents -- contributed to Charter's financial collapse, undermining patient care in the process.
Officials of Magellan Health, Crescent Operating and Charter Behavioral have said that the chain's problems were caused by the insurance cutbacks, and that the 1997 plan did not affect patient care.
Last year, Magellan Health, the nation's largest behavioral health care company, transferred all but 10 percent of Charter to Crescent Operating.
Yesterday's filing comes a month after Charter said it would close and sell about 35 hospitals and centers. Former employees at some units have filed lawsuits contending that Charter violated federal law by failing to give them sufficient notice of the unit's closings and paying them severance benefits.
Mary E. Olson, a lawyer in Mobile, Ala., representing former Charter employees in three of those actions, estimated that about 5,000 former workers at the chain had been affected by the recent closings.
Karen Keiser-Jenkins, a spokeswoman for Charter, which is based in Alpharetta, Ga., declined to comment on the lawsuits. But in a news release, Charter said it was "unable to fully fund all benefits" to staff members dismissed before yesterday's filing.
In a release, Crescent Operating said that Mr. Rainwater would guarantee a bank loan that Crescent Operating plans to use to buy the reorganized company. Mr. Rainwater would be compensated for that guarantee, the company said. He is the largest shareholder in both companies and was the biggest stakeholder in Magellan Health at the time of the 1997 deal.
Last Friday, Jeffrey L. Stevens, an official of Crescent Operating and an associate of Mr. Rainwater, told Charter executives that the chain had $60 million in debts, according to a former Charter official who was informed about that meeting.
Ms. Keiser-Jenkins said that she was not aware of the meeting. Mr. Stevens did not return calls in recent days seeking comment.
Under a proposed plan, Crescent Real Estate would initially lease the 30 Charter facilities it owns to Crescent Operating for $20.3 million, a 13.3 percent annual return, the company said. That rate would rise by 5 percent annually.
Crescent Real Estate would also receive the proceeds of any sales of buildings once used by Charter.

HEADLINE: Data on Housing Industry Is Stronger Than Expected

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments increased unexpectedly in January, and permits for new projects climbed to the highest level in a year, suggesting builders will stay busy in months ahead even as interest rates rise.
Starts of new housing rose 1.5 percent last month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.775 million units after jumping 5.1 percent in December, the Commerce Department said today. Analysts had expected a decline of 4 percent. 
 "Consumer confidence has remained strong, and buyers are feeling pretty good," said Fred Cooper, vice president for finance at Toll Brothers, a builder based in Huntingdon Valley, Pa.
"I don't think the interest rates at current levels" are chasing potential homeowners away, he added.
 Builders are still trying to catch up with last year's record sales. Toll's backlog for the quarter ended Jan. 31 was up 31 percent from the similar quarter a year ago, Mr. Cooper said. It takes a builder 5 to 11 months to finish a home after it is ordered. "We're pretty comfortable fiscal 2000 is going to be a record year," he added.
January's increase was paced by a 17.7 percent surge in starts of apartment buildings and other multifamily dwellings.
Construction of single-family houses fell 2.1 percent. The West led the nation with a 7.3 percent increase, while starts fell in the Northeast, where winter weather affected construction.
The housing report showed permits for all new housing construction rose 8.7 percent in January to an annual rate of 1.763 million units -- the highest since January 1999. Permits for single-family homes rose to the highest annual pace since February 1999.
The level "makes it clear that higher rates notwithstanding, new home construction will continue at a breakneck pace for several months to come," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.

HEADLINE: Police Official Said to Lead Crisis-Management Agency

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is expected to name a senior police official to head the city's Office of Emergency Management, a four-year-old agency created to handle municipal crises ranging from subway crashes and water main breaks to potential chemical or biological terrorist strikes, city officials said yesterday.
The police official, Richard J. Sheirer, the department's deputy commissioner for administration, could be appointed this week, according to several senior city officials, who said the announcement had already been postponed once because of the mayor's scheduling conflicts. 
 Mr. Sheirer, 53, spent 29 years in the Fire Department, rising from a fire dispatcher to deputy commissioner under Howard Safir, then the Fire Commissioner. He joined the Police Department in April 1996 when Mr. Safir replaced Commissioner William J. Bratton.
Mr. Sheirer would succeed Jerome M. Hauer, an expert on civilian response to chemical and biological terrorism who has a master's degree in public health. Mr. Hauer, who is a consultant to the Pentagon and the Department of Justice, has built what is regarded as the premier emergency management program in the United States.
A spokesman for Mayor Giuliani, Matthew Higgins, would not comment on a replacement for Mr. Hauer and Mr. Sheirer did not return a telephone call seeking comment.
The emergency management office was created to coordinate the activities of the multitude of city agencies that respond to incidents like blackouts, disease outbreaks and acts of terrorism. The office also develops emergency plans for the city and training programs.
But the office's relationship with the Police Department has long been strained, particularly over who has ultimate responsibility to handle some emergencies. Those tensions only increased around the millennial celebrations, as both agencies prepared for possible calamities, from computer failures to a feared attack on New Year's revelers in Times Square.
Mr. Sheirer, who has a bachelor's degree in political science from St. Francis College in Brooklyn, brings to the job his experience in the Police and Fire Departments -- the two agencies most involved in emergency response -- and his close working relationship with Mr. Safir.
But he has little background in the complex world of antiterrorism, where Mr. Hauer is an acknowledged expert.
Some city and police officials have criticized the selection of Mr. Sheirer, saying his closeness to Mr. Safir would place the Office of Emergency Management too close to the Police Department and undermine some of its independence.
But others praised him, saying that his experience in both the Police and Fire Departments and his background in emergency communications make him a good candidate for the job.

HEADLINE: No Fiscal Conservatives Here

BYLINE: By P. J. O'Rourke; P. J. O'Rourke is the author, most recently, of "Eat the Rich."

 BODY:
George W. Bush and John McCain both claim to be fiscal conservatives. But what is a fiscal conservative? And who is the true conservative when it comes to fiscal matters?
Is it Mr. Bush, with his dramatic tax cuts and his vow to protect Social Security's revenue surpluses? Is it Mr. McCain, with his more prudent tax reductions, his emphasis on paying down the debt, and his openness to a privatized element in the Social Security trust fund? Or is it Bobo the sock puppet, here on my hand, who promises everyone in America a personal Web site, a billion-dollar I.P.O., a back rub and a Lincoln Navigator? 
 To a true fiscal conservative, tax cuts don't matter much, and neither does the national debt. That is because the real problem is spending. Even the best and most necessary public spending comes with a harrowing price: the percentage of a nation's goods and services controlled by its government is the percentage of freedom and independence taken from individuals and given to politicians. Currently, just at the federal level, that's about 18 percent of your life.
Think of politicians as visiting in-laws. Either George or John (or Al or Bill) will be coming over every Saturday morning and won't leave until halfway through the basketball game on Sunday afternoon.
Government spending diverts wealth from the brilliant, if somewhat erratic, intelligence of the free market to the absolutely reliable stupidity of the political arena. But while politicians may be stupid about spending, they are very sharp about how to finance their expenditures. Government can pay its bills with tax money, run up a budget deficit or print more cash, creating inflation. Inflation hurts the saver, deficits hurt the investor, taxes hurt the earner, and all three are usually the same person: you.
Mr. Bush hardly mentions cuts in federal spending. Mr. McCain would eliminate "corporate welfare," which, according to the Cato Institute, costs the taxpayer an estimated $65 billion a year -- 3.5 percent of federal expenditures. No presidential candidate has made a serious promise to cut overall government spending since Ronald Reagan. And we know how that went.
The Social Security trust fund is another thing that doesn't matter to a true fiscal conservative -- because the Social Security fund doesn't exist. The trust fund is a figment of legislative imagination and consists of nothing but a wishful proposal to give old people some money, later, maybe.
Yet Mr. McCain said that as president, he would put money aside "to make sure that those who paid into the Social Security system get what they're entitled to."
George Bush said he would "reserve the Social Security surplus for Social Security itself."
Thanks for nothing. Having government save its own money in a Social Security trust fund is like having me collect my own I.O.U.'s. What I'll get is a pocketful of cocktail napkins, matchbook covers, Post-it notes and torn-out notebook pages.
The only way to make the Social Security trust fund real is to make the money in it really belong to someone, which is to say privatize it. Mr. Bush finesses the notion. Mr. McCain is willing to try some measure of privatization, but only after Social Security is reformed though "an inclusive deliberative bipartisan process."
That should be sometime during the second Trump administration.
What really does matter about Social Security to a fiscal conservative is that Social Security is an entitlement. The conservative is appalled by a change in emphasis in American politics, from negative to positive rights. About that Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain are silent, possibly because they're off looking up definitions of the terms. Negative rights are the more-the-merrier kind. My freedom of speech stimulates your freedom to tell me I'm wrong. My choice of worship does not impair your ability to slip out of a pew and go play golf.
But entitlements are positive rights, and they are limited by finite resources. A "right to medical care" costs money. Money spent on your Prozac prescription is money that can't be spent on giving my grandmother a new hip.
Entitlements destroy citizenship. If the purpose of the political system is to give me nice things -- low taxes, fat retirement benefits, free flu shots -- then my vote should be auctioned to the highest bidder. Mr. Bush and Mr. McCain are making some generous offers. But not so generous as Bobo's. I suggest a write-in this November. I promise to be a dignified and gracious First Thumb.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. ImposesSanctions On Oil Venture in Sudan

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
The United States imposed sanctions today on a multinational oil venture in Sudan, a project that critics say has helped the government there finance a religious war against southern rebels.
The Treasury Department's sanctions prohibit American companies and citizens from doing business with the Greater Nile Petroleum Operating Company, a joint venture between Sudapet, Sudan's national oil company, and Chinese, Malaysian and Canadian partners. The sanctions ban trade and financial transactions with the joint venture and freeze any assets it has placed in United States banks. 
 The sanctions do not cover the foreign parent companies that backed the oil venture. Some members of Congress and human rights groups had urged the Clinton administration to punish Talisman Energy, the China National Petroleum Corporation and Petronas, the leading oil companies in Canada, China and Malaysia, respectively, for their involvement.
Sudan's Islamic government has used oil revenue to fuel its war against rebels in the mainly Christian and animist southern part of the country, Western religious and human rights groups have argued. The civil war has gone on for 17 years and killed millions of people.
Since 1997, the United States has banned all trade, loans and aid to Sudan, accusing the Khartoum regime of allowing slavery, supporting terrorism and seeking to overthrow neighboring governments. Today's sanctions were an extension of the earlier action, coming after the Treasury Department determined that the oil project was essentially part of Sudan.
"We made a strong finding that the Sudapet project is part of the country," a senior Treasury official said. "Once we did that, applying sanctions was more or less automatic."
The United States imposed sanctions just two days after Canada made the opposite decision, electing to spare Talisman and Sudan itself from punishment. Talisman, which has a 25 percent stake in the Sudapet project, is one of the few large Western companies willing to invest in Sudan, and has come under pressure to sever links.
The Treasury Department's sanctions are not expected to affect Talisman directly. Company officials told reporters today that they had separated the finances and operations of the Sudanese joint venture from those of the parent company. Still, Talisman shares fell 2.30 Canadian dollars, or 5.6 percent, to 38.80 Canadian dollars in Toronto trading.
Likewise, the sanctions are unlikely to affect China National Petroleum, known as C.N.P.C. The state-owned company is planning to list shares on the New York Stock Exchange this spring, an offering underwritten by the Goldman Sachs Group. C.N.P.C. is selling shares in a new subsidiary called PetroChina that consists exclusively of the company's domestic assets.
Some human rights groups and members of Congress have urged the Clinton administration to take stronger action against the three foreign companies that backed the Sudan venture. Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia, has argued that the administration should block the planned United States listing of the C.N.P.C. subsidiary because of its ties to Sudan.
"Anything they do to punish those companies, I support," Mr. Wolf said of the Clinton administration. "But I would like to see it broader. This is one of the major moral issues in the world today."
The senior Treasury official said the Trading With the Enemy Act, under which sanctions against Sudan were imposed, does not allow the administration to punish third-country companies, only United States citizens and United States companies.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE CHALLENGER;
Bradley Says Clinton and Gore Neglected Upstate New York

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH with KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: BUFFALO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Turning his attention to upstate New York, Bill Bradley said today that the federal government had not invested enough money in the region's depressed economy and criticized Vice President Al Gore for not spending enough time here.
Addressing small crowds in Buffalo and Rochester, Mr. Bradley said one reason that upstate cities had not benefited from the recent economic boom nearly as much as other regions was that the Clinton administration had not spent enough on economic development projects here. While the national employment rate increased by almost 19 percent in the 1990's, Mr. Bradley said, the employment rate in western New York grew by only 2.5 percent. 
 "One of the things we can do in being a good steward of the good economy is to recognize that not every place in America is booming," Mr. Bradley told about 200 students and administrators at Erie Community College in Buffalo.
Mr. Bradley said several times that Mr. Gore had neglected upstate New York. "Al Gore says he's been to California 60 times since he became vice president," he said. "My question to him is, how many times has he been to western New York?"
Mr. Gore last visited upstate New York on Monday, when he delivered a speech in Rochester on education.
Responding to Mr. Bradley, Doug Hattaway, a spokesman for the Gore campaign, said, "Al Gore has been fighting with the administration to expand prosperity all across the country while Bill Bradley was out on the speaking circuit making money for himself."
Mr. Bradley last visited upstate New York in October, when he made stops in Albany and Syracuse.
Today, Mr. Bradley also lamented the rising cost of heating oil, a pressing issue throughout New York and particularly upstate.
As he has done before, Mr. Bradley called on the Clinton administration to release oil from the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to drive down the cost of home heating oil. The administration has refused to release oil from the reserves, saying it should be saved for emergencies.
President Clinton said today that he would provide low-income families in the Northeast with $125 million to help with the rising cost of home heating oil, on top of $200 million provided earlier this season.
Mr. Bradley praised the administration for granting the heating subsidies, but at the same time, his campaign said "the real intended beneficiary was Al Gore." According to a press release from the Bradley campaign, New Hampshire received $5.4 million in heating subsidies last month, on the eve of that state's primary, while New York received only $2.6 million. The press release suggested that a $34 million subsidy that New York received this month was timed to arrive near the state primary, March 7, so that Mr. Gore would win more votes here.
Mr. Hattaway scoffed at Mr. Bradley's suggestion.
"The release was intended to help low-income people stay warmer," he said. "'I was in New Hampshire, and it was cold."
While Mr. Bradley spoke tonight in New York City at the Lesbian and Gay Community Services Center, Mr. Gore today received the endorsement of the Empire State Pride Agenda, one of the state's largest gay and lesbian groups. On Friday Mr. Gore received the backing of the Human Rights Campaign, the nation's largest gay and lesbian group.
Jeff Soref, co-chairman of the New York group, acknowledged that Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley had similar positions on gay issues but said his group chose Mr. Gore because "the Clinton/Gore administration has brought unprecedented changes" for gays. In thanking the group, Mr. Gore noted that he was "the first vice president to speak at a gay-rights event."
Mr. Gore said he would appoint a commission to study "how domestic partners should be recognized."

HEADLINE: Christian Groups Urge a Vast, Coordinated Attack on Poverty

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

 BODY:
Concerned that poverty persists in America despite a prolonged period of national prosperity, a broad group of Christian leaders gathered in Washington yesterday to call for an effort by churches, businesses, labor and government to help poor people.
The group's statement, a "Covenant to Overcome Poverty," urges religious organizations to make working on behalf of the poor a priority. It also asks people to evaluate political policies and candidates "by how they impact people who are poor." 
 The document was signed by officials of evangelical and mainline Protestant organizations, including the National Association of Evangelicals and the National Council of Churches, as well as by ministers of African-American churches and representatives of several Roman Catholic groups.
"We want to put poor people on the national agenda -- they're not there now," said the Rev. Jim Wallis, a leader in Call to Renewal, a five-year-old coalition of religious organizations that wrote the statement. The statement noted that one in every five American children is growing up in poverty but that the proportion is higher -- one in every three -- among children of racial minorities. Mr. Wallis said the religious leaders believed that a "moral constituency" was needed to focus attention on finding ways to alleviate poverty, especially for children's sake.
"The obvious constituency is the churches, given how clear the Bible is" about an obligation to help the poor, said Mr. Wallis, who is also editor of Sojourners, a religious magazine based in Washington. "When you have rising inequality and record prosperity at the same time, it's a biblical issue."
The statement said, "Just as some of our religious forebears decided no longer to accept slavery or segregation, we decide to no longer accept poverty and its disproportionate impact on people of color." The document called for making alleviation of poverty "a bipartisan cause," and was issued by the signers on the steps of the Capitol.
In a telephone interview afterward, the Rev. Wes Granberg-Michaelson, general secretary of the Reformed Church in America and chairman of Call to Renewal, said that while the various participating Christian groups might disagree on "specific policy positions," they were united in their belief that a shared national effort on behalf of the poor was needed. He said they agreed that poverty could be relieved neither by the churches alone nor exclusively by government programs.
The statement was issued after three days of Washington meetings, involving some 500 people from religious organizations around the country, that were organized by Call to Renewal to discuss how local groups were trying to help the poor.
"We've been laying the groundwork all across the country" with such local efforts, Mr. Wallis said. "And now we're building a network" to link the groups. He said he hoped that working against poverty would emerge as a leading moral issue.
"Part of what might be happening," he said, "is, you reach a new millennium and find some leftover questions that did not get resolved and then become the primary moral issues."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Tigers Win Big One On Assist From Selig

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
The season hasn't even started, and the Detroit Tigers have already registered a victory. They scored one over Commissioner Bud Selig, and the surprising aspect of it was he let them have it. Not a good start to the season for the commissioner. Baseball's impartial arbitrator may be the next to hand him a loss, that one on the John Rocker grievance.
If the arbitrator, Shyam Das, should overturn or even reduce Selig's 73-day suspension of Rocker for his ugly comments about all sorts of groups, the commissioner would have the excuse that he was unable to do anything about it. But in the Tigers' case, Selig has been a willing accomplice. He has allowed the Tigers to blatantly flout his directive on interviewing minority candidates for certain jobs. 
 In fact, not only has Selig failed to discipline the Tigers, but he has also praised them for taking what some skeptics might see as a cosmetic step designed to get them off the hook with the man whose powers were recently enhanced so that he could fine a team $2 million.
"I heard they were going to be fined," said one club executive, who was clearly disappointed to learn that the Tigers hadn't been fined. "Some people assumed that one of the reasons this new power was given was that he'd be able to fine clubs more if they didn't address the inequality in hiring."
About six months before the Tigers hired Phil Garner as their manager, the commissioner clearly set out his position on interviewing minority candidates. That's right, interviewing, not hiring. Baseball is a game that is played slowly and makes advancement at glacial speed. Last April Selig sent a directive to all clubs outlining the steps they were to take if they had vacancies in any of five positions of decision-making authority, including manager and general manager.
"If a club has an opening in any of these positions, the club owner must notify me personally," he said in a letter to owners. "In addition, your list of candidates must be provided to me. I expect the list to include minority candidates whom you and your staff have identified. I will provide assistance to you if you cannot identify candidates on your own."
Selig also told the owners he would discipline clubs that did not "aggressively pursue equal opportunities and initiatives."
When the Tigers decided last October to make a managerial change, they did not (1) notify Selig of the vacancy, (2) provide him with a list of their candidates, (3) identify any minority candidates or (4) seek assistance in identifying candidates.
Then, heaping insult upon insult, the club president, John McHale Jr., when asked about the Tigers' failure to follow the directive, said, "There isn't a legal obligation to adhere to any directives from the commissioner's office."
The Tigers got away with it because they established a community advisory board dedicated, in the words of a news release from the commissioner's office, "to Equal Employment Opportunities, their Diverse Business Partners Program and their community relations activities." Selig, in the release, called the Tigers' plan "a very progressive and sensitive series of programs."
He praised the club for recognizing the problem and addressing it, adding, "That, I believe, is more important than taking disciplinary action."
On the telephone yesterday, Selig said he expects the Tigers' program to be beneficial to baseball and to the Detroit community. "This is not just a glitzy thing," he said. "They have many announcements to come. They're going to be meaningful. The economics of it will be good in terms of what they're spending and what they're going to be doing. As much as I would have fined them, they're going to spend a lot more than that."
Selig talked about minority suppliers and minority banks, but his directive talked about positions whose holders control budgets and have the authority to make decisions in baseball operations. The Tigers, like most teams, still have a white manager, a white general manager, a white assistant general manager and a white scouting director, positions specified in the directive. If members of minority groups aren't interviewed, they can't be hired. That was the message behind Selig's letter.
The club executive who lamented Selig's failure to fine the Tigers raised the postulation that the Tigers' behavior was worse for baseball than Rocker's remarks. Rocker's comments, he reasoned, were the act of an individual; the failure to interview and hire members of minorities is institutional.
If there is a hint here of a double standard at work, consider some other issues that baseball officials have ignored. While Rocker has been suspended for 73 days and fined $20,000, his employer in Atlanta, Ted Turner, has made a career of making outrageous statements about ethnic groups and remains undisciplined. Marge Schott should have been so widely ignored.
The Braves also continue to encourage their fans to perform the tomahawk chop that American Indians find offensive. The Cleveland Indians offend the same group with their name and their Chief Wahoo emblem. For many years they defended their use of both by explaining that they were honoring a former player who was an Indian. Recently, the Indians admitted that well, maybe that wasn't quite the real story.
Baseball doesn't necessarily have to conform suddenly to the strictest practice of political correctness, but its officials and teams might want to try their hand at consistency.

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Running Into Controversy

BYLINE: By JERE LONGMAN 

 BODY:
The presence of the Confederate battle flag above South Carolina's State Capitol is a hot-button political issue that has reverberated beyond Saturday's state Republican primary and into the world of Olympic distance running.
The United States women's marathon trials will take place in Columbia on Feb. 26, where the flag flies over the Capitol even though many consider it a symbol of slavery, segregation and the Ku Klux Klan. 
 USA Track and Field, the sport's national governing body, has issued a statement in support of the removal of the flag from the South Carolina Statehouse, although it has not called for postponing the race or for moving it to another location.
The track federation has also offered to assist marathoners who wish to support an economic boycott of the state, which has been called for by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Runners who wish to avoid patronizing hotels will be housed by local families in Columbia, the federation said in a letter sent to the approximately 200 qualifiers for the marathon trials.
"This would minimize the economic impact of your visit to South Carolina," said the letter, which was signed by Craig Masback, the chief executive officer of USA Track and Field and by Patricia Rico, the federation's president.
The flag issue has fostered a heated Internet debate about the responsibility of athletes to use their public positions as a platform for addressing social and political matters. Some college sports programs are also joining the fight against the flag. Last week, Swarthmore College announced that it was canceling spring-training trips to South Carolina for its tennis, lacrosse, softball, golf and track and field teams, joining other Philadelphia-area schools such as Haverford College, Bryn Mawr and Temple, which have also voided trips for tennis and lacrosse teams in support of the N.A.A.C.P.-sanctioned economic boycott.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association has also been asked by a coaching group that the South Regional of the men's college basketball tournament be removed from Greenville in 2002 if the Confederate flag continues to fly above the Statehouse.
The Southern Conference, which includes such schools as Furman and the Citadel, has called for a removal of the battle flag and has indicated that it will consider moving its 2001 postseason basketball tournament from Greenville, S.C., and the 2002 and 2003 tournaments from Charleston if the issue is not resolved by the current session of the South Carolina legislature.
"We have confidence things will be resolved; that's what we're hearing through the grapevine," said Alfred White, commissioner of the Southern Conference. He noted that South Carolina Gov. Jim Hodges had won support from several black legislators for moving the Confederate battle flag from the Statehouse to a monument of a Confederate general on the Capitol grounds.
A statement issued this week by USA Track and Field said that, "For many Americans, the Confederate flag is a symbol of subjugation and segregation. We urge the South Carolina legislature to remove the Confederate flag from its Statehouse as soon as possible."
In an interview, Masback said that it would be impractical to move a 26.2-mile race at the last minute, as well as unfair to athletes who have been preparing for months for the Columbia course. He said the federation decided to take a public stance on the flag issue after being encouraged to do so by some of its officers and athletes. Jill Pilgrim, the general counsel for the federation, also said the track group was bound by contractual obligations to keep the race in Columbia.
Mike Moran, a spokesman for the United States Olympic Committee, said the U.S.O.C. was bound by its constitution not to make political statements unless athletes were being deprived of the right to compete. The 2000 Summer Games are scheduled in September in Sydney, Australia.
The 1996 trials were held in the South Carolina capital, which won the 2000 Olympic marathon trials two years ago after a competitive bidding process. The state N.A.A.C.P. began calling for an economic boycott last July. Considering that time frame, along with the fact that race organizers have also called for a removal of the Confederate flag, N.A.A.C.P. leaders said they did not oppose the holding of next week's marathon trials.
"We are glad that the Carolina Marathon Association has taken a stand on the issue," said Lonnie Randolph, president of the Columbia branch of the N.A.A.C.P. "They are not violating sanctions per se. But I did meet with race officials and expressed to them the hope that they will support our efforts in the future and not return until the matter is resolved."
Katrina Price-Crosby of South Pasadena, Calif., an African-American who will compete in the Olympic trials at 5,000 and 10,000 meters in July in Sacramento, said canceled a race appearance in South Carolina last December. She added that she has also canceled plans to attend the marathon trials to cheer on her friends. She has asked them to support the economic boycott by bringing some of their own food and by not renting cars while in the state.
Price-Crosby and Steve Holman, an African-American who is America's top miler, said they have begun exploring the idea of manufacturing red, white and blue ribbons that could be worn as lapel pins by the marathoners as a sign of silent, individual protest during next Saturday's race.
"I'd wear one in a heartbeat," said Kristy Johnston of Shepherdstown, W.Va., who has the second-fastest qualifying time. She said she had considered wearing a confederate flag pin with a line through it on her ball cap, but was afraid "I could get shot by some redneck." She said she planned some sort of flag protest during the race.
"I hope I'm in a position to express my opinion," Johnston said. "It seems like majority of people in South Carolina don't want the flag there. It's amazing a small group of people have kept the flag flying. It's unbelievable to me it's still up."
Alisa Harvey of Manassas, Va., who might be the only African-American in the women's marathon trials, said that she would consider wearing a ribbon, but added, "We need to run a race and deal with this afterward."
Holman, who lives in Arlington, Va., has vociferously called for the female marathoners to make some sort of statement about the flag during the Olympic trials.
"I would say to anyone with a microphone that if the Olympics are about bringing people across the world together, why does South Carolina continue to support a flag that stands for keeping people apart?" he wrote in a column on the online version of Runners World magazine.
In an interview, Holman said: "If they were flying a swastika, would Jewish athletes sit on their hands? I think it's pretty unlikely."
Gwyn Coogan, who finished fourth at the 1996 Olympic trials, said that she thought it was "a shame that people feel the need to fly the flag," and that she felt conflicted about competing in the 2000 trials.
"It would be great if I could say, 'I disapprove of that flag, it represents terrible things to many people, therefore I'm not going to run in the race,"' said Coogan, who lives in Frederick, Md.
"Not running would be the ultimate way of saying you agree with the N.A.A.C.P. tourism boycott. In a sense, I'm very much violating their boycott. But this event happens every four years. I've been planning to do it for four years. I need to run this race."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE: THE POLITICAL ANALYST;
Clinton Isn't Running for Office, but He Has a Lot to Say About the Race

BYLINE: By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16

 BODY:
His name is not on the ballot, he reminded the audience. He is just another voter, he said. But President Clinton could not resist weighing in today on the first political campaign season in decades that did not directly involve him.
The president declared himself a supportive spouse, but not a senior adviser, for Hillary Rodham Clinton in her bid for a Senate seat in New York. And he said he was not concerned that his wife was trailing Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York in the polls. 
 "I think she's doing remarkably well, given the unusual nature of the campaign and the formidable obstacles out there," Mr. Clinton said at his first, formal news conference of 2000. "And I think now the people will begin to listen and debate, and I think she's doing real well."
His role?
"I'm basically doing for her what she's always done for me," he said. "I'm talking to her about whatever she wants to talk about. I'm giving her my best ideas."
Mr. Clinton was reluctant, initially, to weigh in on the presidential contest. "I'm not running for office and, by and large, I think I shouldn't comment," he said. "There may be a few exceptions."
Many of the journalists questioning Mr. Clinton, fresh from the campaign trail, eagerly sought out those exceptions.
"Maybe this will be one of the exceptions that you'll be willing to make," said Claire Shipman of NBC News, offering a question on former Senator Bill Bradley's attacks on the veracity of Vice President Al Gore in the Democratic presidential contest.
Mr. Clinton bit, defending the vice president for having been "brutally honest" over the last seven years.
"When it was an unpopular thing to go into Kosovo, he wanted to do it," Mr. Clinton said, offering other examples of Mr. Gore's candid nature.
"When it was unpopular to go into Bosnia, he wanted to do it," Mr. Clinton said. "When it was unpopular to stand up for freedom in Haiti, he wanted to do it. When only 15 percent of the people thought we ought to help Mexico, but I knew it could hurt our economy, he was right there. And I could go on and on."
But Mr. Clinton stopped short of criticizing Mr. Bradley for doubting Mr. Gore's truthfulness, saying the vehement back-and-forth between the two candidates was typical campaign heat.
"I have never seen a tough race where people fought with each other, where they didn't have different interpretations of each other's record and each other's positions," Mr. Clinton said. "And then once you disagree with someone's position or someone's record, then the person will say, 'I just think you're mischaracterizing it.' "
Mr. Clinton said later that he thought Americans were too smart to blame a candidate -- Mr. Gore -- for personal mistakes made by someone else -- Mr. Clinton.
"I think the implication that anybody would be held responsible for somebody else's mistake or misconduct is just -- it's a real insult to the American people," the president said. "And they're not going to do that. That's not in their interest, and it's not in their nature. They're too smart and too good for that"
At times, Mr. Clinton came across as magnanimous toward the two Republicans seeking to replace him. He said all four major presidential candidates -- Republicans John McCain and George W. Bush included -- were "people of accomplishment, people who have certain convictions, people who have, I think, pretty clear philosophies and records."
But Mr. Clinton, brushing off a question about how often his name has been disparaged on the campaign trail, still showed his partisan ways.
"I have a lot of sympathy with Governor Bush and Senator McCain," he said, barely able to suppress a smile. "I mean, it's hard for them to figure out what to run on. They can't run against the longest economic expansion in history or the lowest crime rate in 30 years or the lowest welfare rolls in 30 years."
He continued: "They've got a tough job, and I have a lot of sympathy with them. And I don't want to complicate their problems by saying any more about them."

HEADLINE: Senaor Kerrey Accepts Presidency of New School

BYLINE: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

 BODY:
Senator Bob Kerrey, the Vietnam War hero and political maverick, is leaving the Senate -- and Nebraska -- for Greenwich Village, where he will run the New School University, known for both its strong graduate programs and its sometimes quirky classes like "Gym Culture and the Modern Amazon."
The liberal Democrat, who once considered resurrecting his bid for the White House, said he had been planning to run for a third Senate term until the school approached him. The more he thought about it, he said, the more he liked the idea of an academic post. He announced last month that he would not seek re-election. 
 Mr. Kerrey, 56, said he would bring varied credentials to the job, which starts when he leaves office next January, ranging from an undergraduate pharmacy degree to a specialty in demolition as a Navy Seal to helping the University of Nebraska expand its curriculum onto the Web.
His one experience in academia, he readily admits, was teaching a course on Vietnam in California in 1987, a post that he said he took in no small part because it allowed him to spend the worst months of the Nebraska winter on a beach in southern California. But he says the new job will allow him to pursue a longstanding interest in education. "I will be addressing what I consider one of the most difficult problems in higher education," he said in an interview from Omaha, "in that it is becoming less and less accessible to the middle class because of the costs."
Mr. Kerrey, who is chairman of the Federal Web-Based Education Commission, said he wanted to pursue the idea that the Web could be used to run a school more efficiently and lower the costs.
The school, founded in 1919, gradually rose in stature in the 1930's and 1940's when it served as a haven for social scientists fleeing persecution in Germany and other countries.
The school at first offered graduate degrees in fields like economics, philosophy, political science, psychology and sociology, but over the decades it gradually expanded. It took over the Parsons School of Design and the Actors Studio Drama School and added other academic divisions offering study in management, urban policy and music. It changed its name in 1997 from the New School for Social Research.
The university has 7,000 students seeking degrees and a full-time faculty of 162, but it is better known for its 20,000 older students in continuing education, its staff of 1,175 part-time instructors and its courses, which run the gamut from English literature to astronomy to photography.
Every catalog brings a selection of more off-beat courses, from basket-weaving, lampshade-beading and other crafts to cultural studies like "Baseball in New York" to even more eclectic social topics -- "Freaks, the Culture of the Grotesque," for example, and "Gym Culture and the Modern Amazon," a course about women and workouts.
Mr. Kerrey said he hoped to teach one class himself, in how to draft a law. He also said the fact that his longtime girlfriend, Sara Paley, a screenwriter, lives in New York was a "happy coincidence."
He will be the school's seventh president. Its sixth, Jonathan F. Fanton, was appointed in 1984 but left the $250,000 post with its official Greenwich Village residence last September to become president of the MacArthur Foundation in Chicago.
The university said that it was attracted to Mr. Kerrey both for his high public profile and his extensive work in education. "We view ourselves as a place of independence," said Philip Scaturro, the school's chancellor, "a place where free inquiry and discussion is valued, and we believe those same values are important to him."
Mr. Kerrey lost his leg in Vietnam and won a Medal of Honor. He was governor of Nebraska and operates a chain of restaurants and health clubs in his home state.
He ran for president in 1992 but withdrew quickly after failing to win much support. He toyed with the idea of running again but dropped the idea in 1998, saying he wanted to run for the Senate again.
His decision not to return to what was a safe seat came as a blow to the Democratic Party, which would like to reverse the Republican's 55 to 45 margin of control in the Senate. Nebraska tends to vote Republican, and the seat is now up for grabs.
The senator had previously said that he might consider being a candidate for vice president. "This doesn't rule it out, but it certainly says to anyone who is thinking of calling me up -- and that list is getting smaller and smaller by the day -- that I am going back to private life," he said. "Barring something spectacular, I intend to keep that commitment."
The senator does not yet have a formal contract with the school. He said he thought he had already identified the most difficult problem he would have adjusting to life in New York after decades in Omaha and Washington.
"I do notice that walking down the streets of New York," he said, "when I hear a horn honk I tend to turn around to wave, so I guess I will have to break myself of that habit."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Saudi Oil Minister Hints OPEC May Feel Compelled to Raise Output

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 16

 BODY:
Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil producer, signaled that prices have climbed too high and may need to fall to ensure stable growth in the world's economies.
The Saudi oil minister, Ali al- Naimi, said during a visit to Tokyo today that oil producers, with prices more than double the levels a year ago, will guard against "any disequilibrium that may negatively impact the world's economic growth." 
 The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets late next month to debate output levels, and the comment is the strongest indication so far that OPEC's recent policy of restricting output may change.
Crude oil prices have averaged $24.86 a barrel since mid-August in New York trading. Late today, oil for March delivery settled on the New York Mercantile Exchange at $30.05 a gallon, down a cent, after selling as high as $30.45 during the session.
OPEC, along with other producers including Mexico and Norway, agreed last March to reduce output by about 7 percent to eliminate what was then oversupply. Those cuts are to expire at the end of March.
The producer group is coming under pressure from countries, including the United States, that maintain that high energy prices threaten to curb growth and bring on inflation. President Clinton said on Tuesday that current oil prices were "a deeply troubling thing." He left open the possibility of releasing oil from the nation's strategic reserve if producers continued to restrict supplies.
The OPEC cuts have more than eliminated last year's surplus and helped the commodity price of oil roughly triple from December 1998. Still, divisions are appearing within OPEC on whether to ease the cuts. Kuwait on Tuesday and Iran today dismissed calls to increase output. All decisions on output policy require the unanimous support of the group's 11 members.
United States inventories of crude oil and gasoline fell more than expected in the week that ended Feb. 11, with crude oil supplies near a 23-year low, American Petroleum Institute figures show.
OPEC members' compliance with output limits fell to 63 percent last month from 81 percent in June, according to Dresdner Kleinwort Benson and the Petroleum Finance Company. Saudi output has increased about 350,000 barrels a day in the last six months, to about 7.8 million barrels a day in January.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE SPOTLIGHT;
Old-Line Republican Finds an Independent Streak Among the Voters

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY and DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, S.C., Feb. 16

 BODY:
Not quite a decade ago, Gov. Carroll A. Campbell Jr. of South Carolina bought an airplane ticket to Germany and brought home a BMW. Not a car, but a factory. For Mr. Campbell, who had a talent for luring foreign industry, the arrival of BMW meant thousands of new jobs and international cachet for a state once dismissed as a redneck backwater.
But in recent days, Mr. Campbell, who stepped down in 1995 after two terms, has felt the burden of his own success. For two decades, he has delivered his state's primary for every Republican presidential front-runner. Just as New Hampshire has made a habit of deflating front-runners, South Carolina has propped them back up. The state became known as the fire wall, the place where insurgents, notably Patrick J. Buchanan, inevitably flamed out. 
 Mr. Campbell is again trolling for support for yet another wounded front-runner, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, for the Republican primary on Saturday.
But the state he is encountering, a place he dominated and helped revive, is no longer the same. His political machine is intact, but there is a new generation of voters, many of them new to South Carolina, drawn by industries like BMW. They are conservative, but they are not predictable, or necessarily Republicans.
"We probably have a weakened fire wall," said Mr. Campbell, who is now a lobbyist in Washington. "We used to be a state where four or five people ran everything. Now, it's open and it's challenging, and I think that is good for us."
The immediate beneficiary of this evolving political culture is Senator John McCain, who is trying to stoke South Carolina's populist streak and build an improbable coalition of Republicans, independents and alienated Democrats. A decade ago, political observers say, Mr. McCain could never have pulled this off, and even now, his chances of victory on Saturday depend on an unprecedented turnout of natives and newcomers outside the Republican mainstream.
Regardless of the outcome, the competitiveness of the race has underscored how the changing national economy is changing politics everywhere, even in places like South Carolina. It was evidence in New Hampshire, where a new pool of voters created by that state's technology boom helped Mr. McCain trounce Mr. Bush.
But there are new pools of voters here, whether transplants from the Midwest and the Northeast working along the Interstate 85 corridor, or the thousands of retirees, many of them from the military, who continue to repopulate the coastline. There also are younger native Republicans, raised in the state's suburbs, who are less inclined to walk lock step with establishment leaders.
Mr. McCain's candidacy has sparked an open rebellion by two Republican congressmen, Lindsey Graham and Mark Sanford, who have embraced his populist message and have escorted him around the state, partly in hopes of burnishing their own chances at higher office.
"That granular political structure, built up around county courthouses, is all gone now," said Blease Graham, a professor of state history at the University of South Carolina. "Things are so much more fluid now. People are mobile, and the old loyalties are dying."
What is changing South Carolina more than anything is prosperity. The dispute over the Confederate battle flag atop the Capitol is a reminder that the state's past is far from buried. But the present and future are in view: The booming manufacturing zone along I-85 in the north and the retirees flocking to the coast, particularly near Hilton Head, where the accents are often from Chicago and New York.
Not more than 40 years ago, South Carolina suffered endemic poverty, masked by the aristocratic sheen of Charleston. Now the state is a national leader in attracting manufacturing, including $42 billion in capital investment during the 1990's, a boom that created 207,000 jobs. Once isolated, South Carolina now has 500 foreign companies that employ nearly 85,000 people. Of the state's 3.9 million residents, nearly 144,000, mostly from the Midwest and the Northeast, have moved in since 1990.
"If people think we're a bunch of corn pones with pickup trucks and trailers, they're wrong," said Vic Sherlock, a recent transplant from suburban Washington who is now an officer in the Greenville County Republican Party.
"This state is going through dramatic, dramatic growth," Mr. Sherlock said. "There is the old guard and the new guard. There is a very hard-core conservative base. It seems like the new people coming in are predominantly Republican but perhaps not as conservative."
Along I-85, growth is everywhere. In Greenville, the downtown streets are lined with restaurants like Bistro Europa or with bars where conversations are often conducted in German. Local residents have nicknamed the Interstate "the Autobahn" not only because of the high rate of speed but because of the German companies that are alongside.
In Spartanburg, a city northeast of Greenville, the county Republican Party is run by a New Jersey transplant, Rick Beltram. The old mill villages of white frame houses that were built for textile workers are still standing, but most of the mills have closed. A new downtown hotel is planned with a nine-hole golf course, and Republicans hold fund-raisers at the BMW museum beside the factory.
"I told somebody the other day that this place is beginning to look like New Jersey," said Gary Towery, who left Spartanburg more than 40 years ago and returned in 1996, perhaps overstating the comparison a bit. "I look around, and I am mesmerized by the difference in the people. You don't hear the accents as predominantly as you did before."
Few politicians in South Carolina have better gauged the changing moods of the state than Mr. Campbell. He built the state's Republican Party in the 1970's and 1980's, capitalizing on white resentment of the civil rights era and the growing sense of alienation from Washington. He and allies like Senator Strom Thurmond and Lee Atwater, the former Republican strategist, bridged the state's two rival regions, assembling a coalition of Charleston Republicans with upstate religious conservatives, many of whom were moving into the middle class and to the right economically. There were 29 Republicans out of 124 state legislators in 1987; by 1994, the party had a majority and had elected a House speaker.
"He was a party builder, more of a partisan by nature than his predecessors," said Warren Tompkins, Mr. Campbell's chief of staff, who is now the chief strategist in South Carolina for the Bush campaign. "He was able to utilize the growing discontentment with Washington, and the new economic climate, to add people to the Republican Party."
But prosperity has brought a growing independence among voters, as the freshness and rigidity of the earlier conversion to Republicanism had begun to fade. Voters began identifying themselves as independents, splitting their tickets, and black voters became better organized. The turning point came in 1998, when Mr. Campbell's hand-picked successor, Gov. David Beasley, a Republican, lost his re-election bid.
Republicans not only lost the governor's office to Jim Hodges, but their majority in the Legislature was cut, and they failed to dislodge Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat.
"We have some of the pains that you suffer from when you achieve majority status," Mr. Tompkins said. "You're not as tightly knit as you were when there were only 29 Republicans. Back then, we never had to worry about voters wandering off the reservation."
Now, the Bush-McCain race is the prism through which change is being measured. Whit Ayres, a prominent Republican pollster in Atlanta who once worked in Mr. Campbell's administration, said the influence of newcomers is significant but should not be overstated. The number of people voting in the Republican primary has grown from 149,000 in 1992 to 274,000 in 1996, and Mr. Ayres noted that many of the new residents have joined the establishment embodied by Mr. Campbell.
"If we're talking about the plant manager for BMW in Spartanburg, that person is very much a part of the traditional business establishment," Mr. Ayres said. "But if we're talking about the guy on the factory floor, I think he may be for McCain."
Four years ago, Mr. Buchanan had hoped to shatter the Campbell coalition by dividing the bubbas from the blue bloods with his blunt appeal for trade barriers. But he badly miscalculated. The factory workers who collected paychecks from foreign corporations like BMW, Michelin and Hitachi concluded that tariffs were not in their best interest.
Mr. McCain is taking a different tack, preaching free trade like Mr. Bush, but hammering away at the Washington establishment even as Mr. Bush tries to wed him to it. The great unknown is whether the same wave of independents who voted for Mr. McCain in New Hampshire -- largely under the radar of polls -- will appear in South Carolina. He is counting on military retirees along the coast, just as Mr. Bush has worked the Bible Belt in the upstate.
Frank Brafman, 72, a Republican and chairman of the Beaufort County Council, said Mr. McCain's appeal is one of personality. He said demographic changes in his area skews handicapping. He suspects, for example, that many of the new residents are Democrats, maybe 25 percent. "They are very quiet," Mr. Brafman said, but they do vote in national elections.
"I don't think I've ever experienced anything like this where nobody knows what will happen," said Mr. Brafman, who supports Mr. Bush. "It's different upstate, where Bush has the edge. It's hard to gauge how Republican are going to vote, because ideology has nothing to do with it."
Mr. Sanford, whose Congressional district encompasses much of the state's northern coast, said the notion of voters following orders from above could get someone "clubbed to death with a 7-iron" at the retirement communities on Hilton Head.
"There was this whole notion after New Hampshire that the Southerners in South Carolina would throw out what the Yankees had done," he said. "But in many neighborhoods in my district, there are more Yankees than Southerners. That whole notion just isn't true."
And what of Mr. Campbell? He stood at the back of a Bush rally last week, talking with reporters. He spoke a bit testily of Mr. Graham and Mr. Sanford; he said Mr. Graham, who became famous for his role in last year's impeachment proceedings, is trying out for a United States Senate run, a notion Mr. Graham does not exactly deny.
Mr. Campbell has taken a leave from his lobbying job to help Mr. Bush. He believes Mr. Bush will win. His numbers are rising in the polls, and South Carolina residents love the Bush family. Asked whether politicking was harder today, he laughed. "Probably," he said. "Because we had a lot of success then, and it doesn't come as easy anymore."
